column2: LONDON, Dec. 28 -- Brisk demand for equities continued in the stock market here today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (UPI) -- Arthur S. Flemming said today he was thinking about recommending that the Administration seek an increase in the Social Security tax as part of a broad overhaul of the system.
A college girl was killed and her escort was left seriously injured with two broken legs yesterday by a hit-and-run driver.
HAVANA, Dec. 28 -- The newspaper Revolucion said today that an armed attack on Cuba to overthrow the Castro regime was imminent.

LOUISVILLE, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Louisville defeated Fordham 66 -- 61, tonight and joined Indiana in the final of the Bluegrass basketball tournament. Indiana downed Mary land, 72 -- 63, in the other first round game at Freedom Hall

RALEIGH, N. C., Dec. 28 (AP) -- Dayton, Wake Forest and Duke won their first-round games in the Dixie Basketball Classic today. The games, played in Reynolds Coliseum on the North Carolina State campus, drew capacity crowds of 12,400 to the afternoon and evening programs.
PARIS, Dec. 28 -- More than 1,000 children were invited by the Government today to demonstrate that transacting business with the new French franc was child's play.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (UPI) -- The Department of Commerce reported today that imports of

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Dec. 28 -- The lame duck Suffolk County Board of Supervisors, which will be supplemented by a Democratic majority on Friday, acted today to protect Republican patronage jobs in three major county departments.

The New York City Housing Authority will offer $29,240,000 of temporary loan notes on Jan. 5. The money will be used for the development of Luna Park Houses in Brooklyn, a city-sponsored project not bearing cash subsidy. The notes will be dated Jan. 26 and will come due July 26.

Short covering and trade and commission house buying of potato futures on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday resulted from strong cash markets. Profit taking supplied the offers. Final quotations were unchanged to up 2 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 1,574 car lots.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 28 -- The military trial of an American pilot accused of having flown bombing missions for Indonesian rebels adjourned here today sixty-two minutes after it began, following a series of legal challenges by the defense counsel.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Dee. 28 -World Zionist leaders convened in Jerusalem tonight to consider a proposal to transform their movement into a world federation of Jewish organizations.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The key to Vice President Richard M. Nixon's campaign for the White House now rests in the pocket of the man who lives there.
CHICAGO, Dec. 28 -- A program to end what was called chaos in this country's scientific effort, stimulate basic research and loosen Government control over universities was proposed today.
Leo Solomon, once called a "phantom landlord and a disgrace to the city," was fined $850 in Housing Court yesterday and given a thirty-day suspended sentence.
STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 28 -- Long before the cold, foggy dawn this morning a man who would help the commuters began a curious search for the facts in the stationmaster's office here.

DETROIT, Dec. 28 (UPI) -- The Detroit Pistons, who have lost their last five National Basketball Association games, dismissed Red Rocha as coach tonight. Dick McGuire, a Piston guard, will be playing coach.
Another year of growth is foreseen by several business and industrial leaders provided there are no prolonged and crippling strikes in key industries.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 28 (AP) -- Master Palynch, under a hard drive through the length of the stretch, beat Eurasia by a nose to win today's feature at Tropical Park.

TOKYO, Dec. 28 -- Between 60 and 70 per cent of Japan's imports will be free of trade restrictions by April, 1961, a spokesman for the Ministry of International Trade and Industry indicated today. The United States is expected to be the chief beneficiary of the liberalization.
MWEKA, Belgian Congo, Dec. 27 -- Here in the savannah country on the southern edge of the dark equatorial forest 241 suspected witches and sorcerers have been put to death by poison since Dec. 1.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Oklahoma City University's Chiefs made all the right plays tonight and advanced easily into the semi-finals of the All-College basketball tournament, trouncing Clemson, 84 -- 57.
Profits of the Bendix Aviation Corporation rose 29 per cent in the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30 on a sales gain of 10 per cent, according to the annual report issued for publication today.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 28 -- Official and public wrath descended today on the German Reichs party, a splinter Rightist radical group accused of responsibility for the Christmas Eve desecration of a Cologne synagogue.
A 19-year-old youth was sentenced to five days in jail yesterday under the new city law barring persons under 21 from carrying knives.
CHICAGO, Dec. 28 -- The time has come for a massive reinterpretation of "large areas of history," Prof. C. Vann Woodward of The Johns Hopkins University said today.
LONG BEACH, L. I., Dec. 28 -- A small, alert gentleman who acts like a vigorous man of 70 years will celebrate his 105th birthday here tomorrow.
Two brothers and a sister of the late Robert R. Young, the railroad financier, filed suits in Supreme Court here yesterday to share in his estate.

Sidney J. Ungar was questioned for the fifth time yesterday by the grand jury investigating the circumstances under which he paid for a $5,500 remodeling job on the apartment of Manhattan Borough President Hulan E. Jack.
A secret top-level meeting at Gracie Mansion yesterday failed to produce a formula that would head off a New Year's Day strike on the city's subway and bus lines.

"No Room In The Ark," by Alan Moorehead, will be published Jan. 20 by Harper. Written after four journeys to Africa, the book presents animals in their natural sorroundings in the big game parks and in the uninhabited bush country.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Senator Albert Gore urged the Administration today to renounce any further nuclear tests in the atmosphere for three years but to reserve the right to resume them underground.
LONDON, Dec. 28 -- Britain's trade union movement has started a drive to reduce the working week.

Prices of United States Government securities fell again yesterday ending a brief rally that began last week. The weakness in the Governments imparted a heavy tone to most of the public market for prime fixed-income investments.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- On a height overlooking the site of the future High Dam at Aswan, in the Nile Valley of southern Egypt, this correspondent asked a laborer a few weeks ago to pose for a picture with his arm outstretched, pointing to the site.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Attorney General William P. Rogers said today that twenty-nine individuals, four corporations and one union were indicted this year as a result of disclosures before the Senate rackets committee.

As we approach year's end and give thought to the problems it is leaving to be solved we are reminded of Matthew Arnold, Victorian poet, educator and critic, born close to a year's end long ago, who had much to say of significance for our own times.

There's a supermarket in the housewife's future where shopping will be fast and fun, according to Ted Dubin, vice president of the Daitch-Shopwell chain. He unveiled a scale model of the market at the Food Exposition and Country Fair at the New York Coliseum yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28 (AP) -- A forecast of heavy snow and blizzard conditions in parts of the Midwest was the most bullish influence in grain futures trading today. It attracted a moderate demand for corn and oats on the Board of Trade.

Rudolph F. Bannow, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, said yesterday that an upsurge in business activity is almost certain in 1960, assuming continuous production of steel. The executive warned, however, against cost increases that could affect the nation's long-term economic growth.

"Ben-Hur," Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's remake of the Biblical drama-spectacle adapted from Gen. Lew Wallace's noted novel, yesterday won the richest prize in the twenty-fifth annual poll of the New York Film Critics by being voted the best picture of the year.
ATLANTA, Dec. 28 -- A campaign was opened here today to double Negro voter registration in the South before the November presidential election.
AGNES MARTIN was born in Saskatchewan and brought up in Vancouver and the great prairies have lodged in her imagination ever since.
Philip Morris, Inc., a leading maker of cigarettes and A. S. R. Products Corporation (formerly American Safety Razor Corporation) announced yesterday that they were considering a merger.
Greater efforts by Negro leaders to help speed integration was urged yesterday by Thurgood Marshall, general counsel for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 28 -- The Yugoslavs showed off a new experimental atomic reactor with considerable fanfare today. The installation, purchased in part from the Soviet Union, will produce radioactive istopes.
Broadway "angels" are going systematic.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Dec. 28 (Reuters) -- Hungary's state-owned stores and private storekeepers were adding up the score today after the country's biggest shopping spree since the end of World War II.

Blinding fog disrupted travel in the East yesterday and forced hundreds of stranded motorists and airline passengers here to settle for standing room only on packed trains. It was also the cause of several highway accidents in the area.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 28 -- Calls for bolder preaching by pastor and layman marked the observance here today of the 175th anniversary of the world's first Methodist Church.
The Government filed a civil antitrust suit yesterday in Federal Court against the manufacturers of two French automobiles and sixteen of their distributors in this country.

State Senator John H. Cooke, chairman of the State Joint Legislative Committee on Banks, expressed optimism yesterday that the Legislature would succeed in revising the State Banking law at its session beginning next week.
Kate Smith will return to star in a weekly television show next month.
DETROIT, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The automobile industry winds up 1959 this week with total production forecast by slightly more than 5,500,000 cars.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The Treasury's final sale of ninety-one-day bills for 1959 produced stronger bidding by investors today than last week, and consequently a lower discount rate on the bills. The stronger bidding presumably resulted from the fact that rates have been high lately, and from year-end selling for tax purposes.
New Yorkers got assurance yesterday that there would be no New Year's Eve cut-off of fuel oil and coal deliveries.

The New York State Supreme Court approved yesterday an out-of-court settlement of a five-year suit against top executives of the Alleghany Corporation. The suit had charged them with using the company's funds in their "personal partisan interests."
Steel mills are expected to continue to operate at near-peak levels this week and thus should establish a new monthly production record during December.
ATHENS, Ohio, Dec. 28 (AP) -- A University of Chicago Professor of Social Science says man no longer lives by the sweat of his brow but rather for his leisure experience.
About 10,000 unlicensed seamen who serve aboard 207 American-flag ocean tankers will receive a 4.5 per cent increase in base wages and overtime starting Friday.
MONTREAL, Dec. 29 (Canadian Press) -- Jean-Paul Fournier of Montreal, an aviation expert, left last night for Guinea in West Africa to help the newly independent country set up air services.

ONE project home cooks might undertake at this time is the preparation of artichokes with a piquantly seasoned bread stuffing. Big artichokes with thick, succulent leaves are now one of the most attractive offerings at the greengrocer's.

Reached in Hollywood yesterday, Paul Gregory, producer of "The Marriage-Go-Round," starring Claudette Colbert and Charles Boyer, denied rumors that Leslie Stevens' comedy would end its successful stand at the Plymouth on March 5. Tickets are on hand until that date.

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 29 -- Mr. and Mrs. A. Felix du Pont entertained with a dinner dance this evening at the Vicmead Club here in honor of Mrs. du Pont's niece, Miss Lucy Wood, and Mr. du Pont's god-daughter, Miss Rosamond Adams.
The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad experienced a net loss of $1,637,336 in November and reported yesterday a deficit for the first eleven months this year of $9,720,084.

Morgan Stanley Co., investment banking firm, has announced that Sumner B. Emerson will retire as a general partner on Friday and become a limited partner. At the same time Roger T. Gilmartin will be admitted as a general partner.
HONG KONG, Dec. 29 -- Chinese arriving here from Communist China believe an important new year policy announcement will soon be made in Peiping.
John Wild, a professor of Philosophy at Harvard University, was elected president of the American Philosophical Association's eastern division yesterday.
A borrowing cost of 3.87204 per cent was the best submitted at competitive bidding for $4,900,000 of serial bonds of the Ventura, Calif., Union High School District.
CHICAGO, Dec. 29 (UPI) -- The Executive Council of the American Federation of Teachers frowned today on a planned series of airplane-borne television courses for 5,000,000 Mid-west students.
A new era of sea power opens at Groton, Conn., today when the Navy commissions its first fleet ballistic missile submarine, the U.S.S. George Washington.
MOSCOW, Dec. 29 -- The Western powers today formally proposed May 16 as the date for the start of the Paris summit conference.
TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 29 -- Iran held open today the door to negotiation of her border dispute with Iraq.
The number of passengers on the world's scheduled airlines should exceed 100,000,000 in 1960 and may reach 103,000,000, the International Air Transport Association estimated yesterday.

As one considers the approach of New Year's Eve it comes to mind that probably only once in all the years and decades and centuries of New Year's revelry in this metropolis has the most important feature of the occasion been a full-dress attack on piracy. That was the case here on Dec. 31, 1879, eighty years ago.
LUXEMBOURG, Dec. 29 (Reuters) -- Output of crude steel for 1959 in the six-nation European Coal and Steel Community reached a new high, according to official estimates made available here today.
Massachusetts Investors Growth Stock Fund reported yesterday new highs in net assets, share value, number of shares outstanding and shareholders as of Nov. 30, the end of its fiscal year.
Undefeated Cincinnati and once-beaten Iowa will meet tonight at Madison Square Garden in the final of the Eastern College Athletic Conference's eighth annual Holiday Basketball Festival.

Ed Sullivan said yesterday he had asked two unions to look into the possibility that Hedda Hopper was "paying" movie stars to appear on her forthcoming TV show by mentioning them in her newspaper column.
Despite drizzle, gloom of day and the mud-spattered nylon stocking, large holiday crowds were about town yesterday bound for museums, theatres and other divertissements.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Internal Revenue Service announced today a program designed to curb tax abuses on expense accounts.

Next spring the good ship Hope is scheduled to depart for Indonesia on a mission that makes a challenging appeal to the hearts and minds of people the world around. And now comes the welcome news that next month the Advertising Council will begin a nation-wide public service campaign to make that appeal effective through the financial support of the American people.
LONDON, Dec. 29 -- The demand for industrial shares continued to be the feature of the stock market here today.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 29 -- Chancellor Adenauer and the United States Ambassador to Bonn, Walter C. Dowling, conferred for an hour today. They met as reports were heard that the Chancellor was contemplating another visit to President Eisenhower in Washington.

THE large view of Manhattan during the holidays is provided by New York Airways. Sight-seeing flights in a three-passenger helicopter depart every day from 10 A. M. to 4 P. M., through Sunday, Jan. 3.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 29 -- President Eisenhower announced today that the United States was reserving the right to resume the testing of nuclear weapons after Thursday. A voluntary ban on such testing will be in force until midnight of that day.
The Christmas week - end brought long lines and excellent grosses to movie theatres in the Broadway area.

George Constantine of Southbridge, Mass., is this reporter's selection as American sports car driver of 1959. George didn't win a championship (he missed by a few fleeting moments and a lost tire tread in the final race of the year at Daytona Beach) but he brought to a year of excellent racing the outstanding performance of all the hundreds of drivers and cars that competed under the S. C. C. A. banner.
PARIS, Dec. 29 -- French prestige in the United States is as great as could be wished, Foreign Minister Maurice Couve de Murville declared today.
New York City is withholding payment on a $103,425 Brooklyn dredging job pending investigation of a charge that the city might have been cheated.
Another rise in the cost of hospital insurance for 7,200,000 New Yorkers in the metropolitan area is in the making.
Bobby Fischer, the defending champion, and Samuel Reshevsky, an international grandmaster, triumphed in the ninth round of the United States chess championship at the Manhattan Chess Club last night.
The artistic talents of a diminutive and witty young nun have come to the attenion of the advertising world.

The Radio Corporation of America will make a profit on its sales of color television sets this year, David Sarnoff, chairman, declared yesterday. He said that 1959 will be the first year in which color receivers have been profitable since their introduction in 1955.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 29 -- Foreign Minister Subandrio warned today that Communist China's recent policy toward such uncommitted nations as India, Burma, Yugoslavia, the United Arab Republic and Indonesia would have detrimental consequences "to all of us."

Tiaras bloomed last evening not only on the heads of women guests at the Tiara Ball but also on a birch tree in a Florentine garden -- alias the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Bronze and gold candelabra and an active fountain completed the glittering effect.
Three New Jersey apartment buildings have been sold through J. I. Kislak, Inc., real estate brokers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Public hearings in the steel dispute closed today in a fury of recriminations. The Presidential Board of Inquiry permitted union and management spokesmen to make a record without any inhibiting rules. It was a record heavy with accusations, denials and counter-thrusts.
TOKYO, Dec. 29 -- A father and son resigned from Japan's upper house today in connection with a sensational vote-buying scandal.
NEW HAVEN, Dec. 29 -- A steady decline in the New Haven Railroad's commuter service over the next two years seems inevitable, according to Charles Shannon, executive vice president.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities published the first volume today of what it hopes will be one of the most comprehensive studies of communism ever under taken.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (UPI) -- Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell predicted today that 1960 will be the best year in history for the American people.
ALBANY, Dec. 29 (UPI) -- New York State ski conditions reported today by the Department of Commerce:
Mrs. Anita O'Keeffe Young, widow of Robert R. Young, has broken with Allan P. Kirby, the man who backed her husband's rise in the world of finance.
Drastic changes in the 2,500-man Detective Division are expected after Friday, it was learned yesterday at Police Headquarters.

Commission house liquidation and switching out of the near months depressed zinc prices on the Commodity Exchange of New York. Dealer buying absorbed the offers. Final quotations were unchanged to 10 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) off on 217 lots (60,000 pounds to a lot), the largest volume since trading reopened after World War II.
The state acted yesterday to prevent Staten Island barbers from entering into agreements to fix the prices of haircuts.

THE American Opera Society began its most ambitious effort at Carnegie Hall last night; a complete performance of Berlioz' "Les Troyens." Although Sir Thomas Beecham, the distinguished generalissimo whom it had enlisted for this campaign, was hors de combat with an attack of gout, the society went ahead with the first half of the opera as scheduled.
Despite opposition by the National Amateur Athletic Union, a Swedish amateur basketball team arrived here yesterday for a ten-game American tour.

In your Dec. 27 issue you mention that the over-all cost of the demands made by the Transport Workers Union is estimated at $75,000,000 for city transit and $25,000,000 for the private bus lines. If realized, the public would be paying a 25-cent fare, at least, and a year or two later, you may be sure, another demand will be made.
The developers of Washington Square Village have decided to drop a proposed expansion of their building plans, because they might have to pay the city $400,000 to go through with it.
A once-flourishing Roman city, Tarrha, on the Greek island of Crete was uncovered by an American archaeological expedition that had started out to find a glass factory.
TRENTON, Dec. 29 -- The State Department of Institutions and Agencies and the State Board of Child Welfare have joined to aid children with emotional problems.
RABAT, Morocco, Dec. 29 -- King Mohamed V and Cardinal Spellman had a forty-minute conversation here today about peace, liberty, Algeria and Moroccan-American friendship.
BOSTON, Dec. 29 (UPI) -- A savage storm swept into New England from the Midwest today. Carrying snow, sleet and rain, it churned up the highest tides in 108 years and stranded hundreds of persons.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The Government today listed the four fastest growing consumer products of the last twelve years as home cooling equipment, television sets, clothes driers and boats.

KATMANDU, Nepal, Dec. 29 (UPI) -- A Tibetan colony in Nepal is so filled with refugees from their Communist Chinese-ruled homeland that hundreds are camped out freezing and starving in open fields, it was reported today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Federal Trade Commission will soon issue another batch of complaints against record companies in payola deals.

ALGIERS, Dec. 29 -- France will spend the equivalent of nearly $140,000,000 in public funds next year for industrialization and power development in Algeria, according to the Cabinet of Paul Delouvrier the French Delegate General.
New Yorkers will pay up to $70 a couple -- plus tax -- for the inalienable right to dine out, rattle noisemakers and wear funny hats this New Year's Eve.

The thirteen-story glass and aluminum office building nearing completion at 1725 K Street, N. W., in Washington, was named the R. C. A. Building yesterday. The naming followed the signing of a $2,500,000 lease by the Radio Corporation of America, which will be the major tenant.

Continued year-end selling for tax purposes and further weakness in long-term United States Government bonds combined yesterday to keep the bond market on the defensive. Secondary market transactions of sizable extent tended to dry up as the end of the trading year approached.

Representative Eugene J. Keogh of Brooklyn told the leaders of sixty organizations of elderly persons yesterday that the present Congress would "in all probability" pass major amendments to liberalize the Social Security Act.
A large dog caused a small subway tie-up in the Bronx last night.
RALEIGH, N. C., Dec. 29 -- A New York clergyman declared here today that the Protestant Episcopal Church was "in the main, racist, caste-ridden and socially exclusive."
ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Johnny Longden rode Tomy Lee up the comeback trail, winning the $10,000 Alhambra allowance at Santa Anita by more than three lengths today.
The New York Committee for Democratic Voters announced a reorganization yesterday to expand its reform movement and unseat party bosses in the city and state.
LONDON, Dec. 29 (UPI) -- Britans have appreciated a good phrase since Shakespeare was supplying them. Today they examined the year's crop.

The name of Mayor Wagner was injected into testimony yesterday before the grand jury investigating the circumstances under which Sidney J. Ungar was billed $5,500 for a remodeling job on the home of Manhattan Borough President Hulan E. Jack.

The merger of Material Service Corporation of Chicago into General Dynamics Corporation was approved by stockholders of both companies at separate meetings in Chicago and Dover, Del., yesterday. Directors of the two concerns signed a merger agreement on Nov. 23.

Miss Florence M. Kelley, attorney in charge of the criminal branch of the Legal Aid Society, was named last night by Mayor Wagner to be the city's first woman Presiding Justice of the Domestic Relations Court.

The United Aircraft Corporation announced yesterday that its Hamilton Standard division had acquired exclusive North American rights to a new electron beam process developed by the Carl Zeiss Foundation of West Germany for machining or welding the hardest materials.
The Federal Reserve Board appointed new chairmen yesterday for the Federal Reserve Banks of New York, Minneapolis and San Francisco.

RALEIGH, N. C., Dec. 29 (AP) -- York Larese sank twenty-one free throws without a miss and scored 37 points as North Carolina routed Duke, 75 -- 53, tonight to gain the Dixie Classic basketball final. Wake Forest rallied to defeat Dayton, 61 -- 50, in the other semi-final.
The first definite movement toward possible settlement of New York's transit labor crisis was made yesterday.

Despite continued Soviet obstruction at the Geneva conference on a nuclear weapons test ban, the United States will continue its suspension of such tests on a day-to-day basis in the hope that agreement may yet be reached. However, it reserves its freedom to resume the tests at any time, after advance notice that it proposes to do so.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The head of the State Department's cultural relations program denied today a charge that young performers had been "virtually excluded" from exchanges in the theatrical field. The charge was made yesterday by Representative Frank Thompson Jr., Democrat of New Jersey.
It is the opinion of Bernard L. Caldwell, a Transit Authority employe, that if a picture is worth a thousand words, a scale model is worth several thousand words and at least a dozen pictures.

IN two days we will be living in another decade. The other day as I stared at my calendar I fell into the old and illogical trick of dividing time into convenient ten-year periods and brooded about the fiction of the Fifties. Which novels published then, I wondered, were best equipped for literary survival? Would any endure for 10C years? Probably, but reasonable caution made speculation seem useless.
The National Board of the Young Women's Christian Association of the U. S. A. has named Miss Briseis Teall associate general secretary for program planning and coordination.
The Cessna Aircraft Company yesterday reported the net income for the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30 at $7,937,000, compared with $5,109,000 in the preceding fiscal year.
ALBANY, Dec. 29 -- A detailed and massive blueprint for reorganizing New York's state government was submitted to legislative leaders today by Governor Rockefeller.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Premier Khruschev repeated his triumphal visit to Washington and the United States tonight -- on film.
LONDON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Japan will seek an easing of British import quotas on her products in forthcoming trade talks between the two nations, said today.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, Dec. 29 -- Auguste de Schryver, Belgian Minister for the Congo, declared today that Belgium would fulfill her promise of Congolese independence. But he rejected a nationalist demand that round-table talks scheduled in Brussels later next month be moved up to Jan. 5.
BRIDGE and fund-raising have always had an affinity. Innumerable bridge parties are held as benefits by such groups as fraternal organizations and alumni associations.

It's now pretty definite. Dividend payments this year will set a new high. Chances are also that they will rise to another record in 1960. The authority for this glowing economic prediction is Standard Poor's Corporation, the advisory and statistical service.
NASHVILLE, Tenn. Dec. 29 (AP) -- Criminal Court Judge Homer Weimar today ordered John Kasper to appear Thursday for a hearing that could send him to the workhouse immediately on a 1958 conviction.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Henry Cabot Lodge said tonight that there was "a distinct possibility that he would visit the Soviet Union before next June.

JUST in time for the New Year's eggnog, that essential ingredient, the egg, has dropped 2 cents a dozen in price. For 55 cents shoppers can now buy a dozen large eggs, which, blended with sugar, liquor and cream, will yield a rich beverage for a party of thirty or more.
NAHA, Okinawa, Dec. 29 -- The accidental slaying of a 56-year-old Okinawan woman by a United States Marine sergeant last Saturday is becoming a major political issue here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Food and Drug Administration reported today that a drug store at Lexington, Ky., had been fined $2,000 for supplying "pep" pills to a peddler at a stopping place for trucks.

It is highly encouraging to note the increasing assurance emanating from leaders in Western Europe and in this country that opinion is moving toward the position regarding foreign aid as it is summed up in a memorandum recently left with our State Department by Sir Oliver Franks, formerly British Ambassador to this country. As Sir Oliver put it:
CHICAGO, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The grain futures market was mostly higher again today with gains ranging from small fractions to about a cent or more on the Board of Trade.
Katharine Cornell, one of the theatre's "first ladies," was cited yesterday as "Woman of the Year" by the Women's Division of the American Friends of the Hebrew University.

St. Mark's scored five goals in the final period to rout The Hill School, 9 -- 4, in their seventh annual Christmas vacation hockey game before 2,500 spectators at Madison Square Garden yesterday. The game was the first of the season for both teams.
Former employes of the defunct Brooklyn Eagle are due to receive 30 per cent of an $843,069 arbitrator's award under an out-of-court settlement of a long dispute with the New York Newspaper Guild.
ALBANY, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Governor Rockefeller will visit Washington twice next month. There was no immediate information on whether he would see President Eisenhower or Vice President Nixon.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Using only five men, Utah State downed Wichita, 75 -- 68, tonight and advanced to the final of the All-College Basketball Tournament.
The mixture of rain and snow that fell in the metropolitan area yesterday gave way to "mostly snow" last night. It turned some suburban roads into slushy, slippery routes.
The fund for New York's Neediest Cases received a dollar bill yesterday that was an indirect gift from a mother and son living in Lithuania.
CHICAGO, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Russian language courses in United States secondary schools increased thirty-fold since 1957, but the supply of teachers has yet to equal demand, an educator said today.
Two of America's best-known flutists were robbed last weekend of flutes worth nearly $5,000.
HONG KONG, Dec. 24 -- More than 500,000 Chinese here are members of illegal secret societies, according to the latest police estimate.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Like the new boy who has turned up in shorts at a school where all boys wear long pants, the Saudis fear ridicule.
The New York Rangers became further entrenched in last place in the National Hockey League as they bowed to the Boston Bruins, 4 to 3, in a lack-luster game at Madison Square Garden last night.
GOSHEN, N. Y., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Backing up his decision with a dictionary, a judge has declared unconstitutional a state law requiring drivers to dim their lights under certain conditions at night.
A rundown tenement at 1708 Park Avenue, formerly owned by a corporation headed by Banton Wyckoff, was back in Housing Court yesterday.
A six-story self-service elevator apartment house at 1415 Mott Avenue, Far Rockaway, has been sold to an investor by the Mott Avenue Company. The broker was Harry Handschu, who represented the buyer.

ALBANY, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The State Commission Against Discrimination said today it had no jurisdiction in the case of a doctor who was barred from a Roman Catholic hospital because of his connection with the Planned Parenthood Association.
POCANTICO HILLS, N. Y., Dec. 29 -- The eyesight of hunters will be tested at the estate of John D. Rockefeller Jr. here before they are permitted to shoot deer on the property Jan. 11 to 22.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Albert J. Robertson, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, today announced the appointment of the following chairmen and vice chairmen of district Federal Home Loan Banks.
A West African couple, Dr. and Mrs. Hadj M. Contah, have been awarded a $7,000 fellowship for advanced study in rehabilitation of the physically handicapped during 1960.

An offering to the public of 100,000 common shares of Cooper Tire and Rubber Company was made yesterday at $38 a share. The offering is being underwritten by Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis and Prescott, Shepard Co., Inc., and associates.
HAVANA, Dec. 29 - Forty-five persons were arrested today on charges of conspiracy against the Cuban Government.
The first step toward television coverage of events at the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts was announced yesterday.

PHILIP GUSTON and Jack Levine, conspicuous representatives of two poles of American painting, are currently the subjects of important one-man shows at, respectively, the Sidney Janis Gallery, 15 East Fifty-seventh Street, and the Alan Gallery, 766 Madison Avenue, at Sixty-sixth Street.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Aggressive Lafayette swamped William and Mary, 81 -- 63, in a game marked by a fist fight between the teams tonight and joined South Carolina in the finals of the Richmond invitation basketball tournament.

Perhaps the most interesting aspect of our forthcoming Presidential campaign is its emphasis on foreign policy. More than ever before in peacetime candidates are trying to develop a knowledge of international affairs and to stress this to the public mind.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today ordered public hearings on three recent airline accidents in which seventy persons in the planes and eight on the ground were killed.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 29 (Reuters) -- Four political parties were reported ready today to apply for licenses after Jan. 6, the date on which party activity will again be permitted in Iraq.
Outright repeal of the 10-cent-a-ride taxi tax was requested of the City Council yesterday by Mayor Wagner.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 29 -- A 27-year-old Miami animal trainer who sold his pet chimpanzee to the St. Louis zoo and then stole him back faced Federal and state charges today after surrendering to authorities here.
Oil stocks, most of them under selling pressure for a year or more, bouncily took the lead yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (UPI) -- The Bureau of Mines said today the 116-day steel strike led to a 12 per cent drop in the value of usable iron ore produced in 1959 and was the principal factor in a decline in the value of metals output.
ALBANY, Dec. 29 -- Following is the text of the memorandum sent by Governor Rockefeller today to the legislative leaders on reorganization of the state government:

IN Saul Levitt's "The Andersonville Trial," which was effectively acted at Henry Miller's last evening, the essential question is this: Does a military officer have a moral duty to refuse an order that he regards as inhuman?

MADRID, Dec. 29---The announcement today that Fernando Maria Castiella y Maiz, Spanish Foreign Minister, would visit the United States and President Eisenhower's recent visit here highlight the continuing improvement in United States-Spanish relations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Secretary of the Treasury Robert B. Anderson told the nation's economists today that he was still concerned about the United States' balance-ofpayments deficit, although trends indicate that it will be reduced next year.

EUGENE, Ore., Dec. 29 (UPI) -- Four students were killed today when a station wagon carrying five University of Washington students to the Rose Bowl football game collided with a truck on icy highway 99 north of here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- President Eisenhower's decision to remove the voluntary ban on nuclear testing was described today by Administration officials as more a bargaining maneuver against the Soviet Union than a declaration of intent to resume tests.
The ninth annual Christian Gauss Award will be presented posthumously by Phi Beta Kappa to Margaret Gilman for her book "The Idea of Poetry in France.
LONDON, Dec. 29 -- Britain and Norway signed today the convention that will bind the so-called Outer Seven nations together in the European Free Trade Association.
The Governors of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut discussed a new formula yesterday for paring the heavy income-tax payments New York now exacts from nonresidents.
HOUSTON, Dec. 29 -- "If we're not ready now, we never will be."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (UPI) -- The son of the late Wendell Willkie proposed today a sweeping reform of the American school system to equip the nation's youth with the knowledge necessary to win the war of ideas with the Soviet Union.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Field Enterprises, Inc., today announced it had purchased the Manistique Pulp and Paper Company, Manistique, Mich., from the Trenton (N. J.) Times Corporation and the James Kerney Foundation.
LONDON, Dec. 29 -- At least three diplomatic working parties will be organized to align Western policies for the summit meeting with the Soviet Union, British and United States diplomats said today.

"WHEN you analyze Andy Robustelli on a piecemeal basis," said Tom Landry, the defensive genius, "there's little about him that suggests a great defensive end. He seems lacking in size, speed and other traits. But as soon as you put them all together, you have the best there is."
The Baumritter Corporation, furniture manufacturing concern, has leased the ground floor, mezzanine, basement, second and third floors of 145 East Thirty-second Street.
Oscar Mayer Co., Chicago meat-packing concern, announced yesterday that the directors had approved a 50 per cent stock dividend on the common stock, payable Feb. 1 to holders of record of Jan. 15.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 29 -- A third Government-owned steel plant went into part production at Durgapur in West Bengal today.
The police pressed a search yesterday for a hit - and - run driver whose vehicle dragged a woman's body ten blocks before he removed it and placed it at the side of a road.

I was happy to read your Dec. 20 editorial tribute to Birgit Nilsson after her very successful debut as Isolde at the Metropolitan Opera House, but I was shocked to find that debut described as a Cinderella story."

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The Seventh United States Circuit Court of Appeals upheld today the conviction of a union leader on a charge that he had evaded $562,982 in Federal income taxes on funds he had embezzled.

Under the new Federal labor reform law, state labor relations agencies now have jurisdiction over thousands of businesses which are engaged in interstate activities, but which the National Labor Relations Board had excluded from its jurisdiction because of their small size. How this is being done has become an important national issue.

The writer of the following letter is a member of the Committee for Modern Zoning. He is a past president of the New York Chapter of the A. I. A., of the Municipal Art Society and of The Fine Arts Federation of New York.
Chemical Bank New York Trust Company has designated its two top domestic men for appointment as president and first vice president.
A NEW YORK salesman is touring Europe with five dozen samples of Seventh Avenue fashion and the avowed purpose of bringing American dollars back to the United States.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Dec. 29 -- Hofstra and Rutgers will meet in the final of the Long Island Christmas invitation basketball tournament tomorrow night as a result of their victories tonight.
MAINE may have made a costly mistake a month or so ago. A visiting hunter was collared for a game-law violation and tried to pay his fine with a credit card. The judge made him get up the cash.
ALEXANDRIA, Va., Dec. 29 (UPI) -- Two more all-white schools in this Washington suburb were ordered today to admit Negroes at the start of the second semester Feb. 1.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Industrial production has been increasing about 10 per cent faster than anyone realized, the Government reported today. Furthermore, it said, output advanced sharply this month to near-record levels.
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 29 (UPI) -- Spain's No. 1 junior tennis star, Jose Arilla, today won the top title in the thirteenth annual Orange Bowl junior tennis championships.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- A panel on urban problems was told today that more and wiser Federal assistance was needed to save New York and other metropolitan areas from decay.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The Post Office Department announced today the indictment of three New Yorkers on charges of bilking the public of "many thousands of dollars" in buying dolls.
CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- A machine has been taught to converse about the weather and to call its interrogator to task when he attempts deception.
Election of Ralph T. Reed as chairman of the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce was announced yesterday by the world business group.

General Franco's enthusiastic tribute to President Eisenhower and the United States will undoubtedly convince many in the general cordiality of the Christmas season that the Spanish Government is our stanch ideological ally.

Roy Cohn's Feature Sports, Inc., is considering the promotion of other sports as well as boxing, the attorney disclosed last night when he returned from conferences in Sweden with the heavyweight champion, Ingemar Johansson.
CHICAGO, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The report of today's Livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

AUGUSTE DE SCHRYVER, who, as Minister of the Belgian Congo, assured the Congolese yesterday that his country stood by its promise of independence, is known in Brussels political circles as a master of the beau geste, the graceful, gesture. But the Minister (whose name is pronounced D'SKRY-ver) is also respected for firmness, which characteristic showed in his refusal to move up the date for a showdown conference with the Congolese political leaders.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Atomic Energy Commission took steps today to implement a compromise atomic power program worked out earlier this year with the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy.

MOSCOW, Dec. 29 -- Premier Khrushchev has given one of his closest associates on the Communist party Presidium a public dressing down following serious farm failures in Kazakhstan. The denounced official has been accused of trying to cover up the shortcomings.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Ezra Taft Benson got an earful today on what is wrong with his farm policy.

Robert G. Rese of Paterson, N'. J., has been appointed vice president in charge of the Paramus (lV J.) ortgage Corporation. The' concern, which operates in Bergen, Essex, Passaic, Morris, Union and 2iddlesex Counties, recently moved to larger quarters en Route 17.
ALBANY, Dec. 29 -- The Rockefeller administration intends to make it easier to figure out the state income tax, beginning in 1961. But the size of the tax will be the same.
CHICAGO, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Man is not the "darling of the gods" in evolution and stands no better chance for future survival than his distant cousin, the tapeworm, an expert on fossils said today.
CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- Dr. Allan Nevins urged tonight that history writing be humanized to meet the needs and interests of the "democratic public."
Philip Simon, president of Kayser-Roth Lingerie Company, Inc., urged the lingerie industry yesterday to take advantage of modern science in designing apparel.
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 29 -- A group of scientists agreed today that a new method of staging nuclear explosions underground could make the international test-detection program virtually useless.
Almost 5,000 letters, postcards and telegrams descended on station WNTA-TV yesterday demanding that "The Play of the Week" be continued on Channel 13.
LONDON, Dec. 30 -- As the new year approaches, British attention is increasingly focused on Africa as the last great area of colonial responsibility and source of intense political conflict at home.

TRENTON, Dec 30 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner said today that State Treasurer John A. Kervick had resigned from the board of directors of a private development concern that plans to build a group of luxury homes in Ocean County.

ATLANTA, Dec. 30 -- A Federal judge tentatively approved today Atlanta's grade-a-year desegregation plan. This clears the way for the Legislature to prevent school closings by repealing conflicting laws.

ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- Governor Rockefeller has reappointed Judge Samuel R. Pierce Jr., the first Republican Negro judge to sit on the Court of General Sessions, to a second interim term on the same bench.

The Senville Realty and Construction Company, builders, in association with the Landau-Jarcho Development Corporation, filed plans yesterday for a twenty-one-story apartment house to occupy the blockfront on the west side of the Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue) from Fifty-sixth to Fifty-seventh Street.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 30 -- President Eisenhower will appear before Congress Jan. 7 to deliver his annual Message on the State of the Union, the White House said today.
About 450 boys and girls from high schools throughout the metropolitan area are attending the birth of a tradition this week at the Rockefeller Institute.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The law of supply and demand can be applied to economists as well as by them.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 30 -- The Indian Government is believed to have recognized two new Indian news agencies.

An inspector for the Department of Housing was accused yesterday of assaulting a woman in the Municipal Building because she refused to sign a paper saying her apartment had been put in good order by her landlord.

Buying by floor traders and short covering firmed potato prices yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Heavy hedge selling limited the advance. Final quotations closed unchanged to up 2 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 971 car lots.
Joe E. Brown has indicated his willingness to return to Broadway this season after an absence of nine years, in a new musical comedy called "The Coach and Four."
THE first woman in the city's history to be named Presiding Justice of the Domestic Relations Court has found that parents are not always to blame when their children run afoul of the law.
Dr. Karl Burger of Brooklyn of the United States was one of five first-round winners yesterday in the international chess masters tournament at the annual congress in Hastings, England.

The District Attorney's office declined to comment yesterday on reports that the grand jury was nearing the end of its inquiry in the case of Manhattan Borough President Hulan E. Jack.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Dominican Republic's Consul in Miami was placed on five years' probation in Federal Court today for conspiracy to bribe United States customs officers and smuggle arms to enemies of the Castro government in Cuba.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 30 -- A loud ovation greeted Irene Castle in her return to the stage as guest star in the play, "Come to the Dance" by Nellise Child, at its opening last night in the Coconut Grove Playhouse.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 30 (AP) -- California dominated the boards and stifled Jerry West tonight to beat West Virginia, 65 -- 45, and win the first annual Los Angeles Classic basketball tournament.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter met today with top diplomatic representatives of Britain, France and West Germany to begin planning for the May 16 summit conference.
IN "Alley of the Sunset," acted at the Jan Hus Theatre last evening, John Duff Stradley has set out to defend a writer. Lord deliver us from our friends.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The chairman of the House Immigration subcommittee declared today that the European refugee problem had been virtually solved.
LAST month, while most of us were preoccupied with our Thanksgiving turkeys, a handful of New Yorkers with sizable sums to spend were writing orders for spring dresses, coats and suits in Paris.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Representatives of the United States garment industry agreed today to meet in New York early next week to reply to a Hong Kong proposal for voluntary controls on textiles shipped to this country.

RALEIGH, N. C., Dec. 30 -- An Episcopal Society for Cultural and Racial Unity was formed here today by an interracial group of 100 clergymen and laymen from North and South.
Steel-making capacity in the United States increased 937,300 tons in 1959 to a record of 148,570,970 a year, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The Treasury announced plans today to borrow new cash and to pay off maturing debt through auction sales of two issues of short-term securities in the first two weeks of the new year. The size of the cash borrowing is smaller than had been expected, because the Treasury finds its cash position a little better than it had foreseen.

Peck.

Into town for a quick visit yesterday came "The Burglar." That's what Johnny Unitas of the champion Baltimore Colts is sometimes called by opposing players in the National Football League.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Premier Phoui Sananikone of Laos submitted his resignation tonight to King Savang Vathana.
MOST people find state constitutions dull reading, but not John Elber Bebout. He has scrutinized all fifty and knows their shortcomings.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Dore Schary, playwright and producer said today that the American movie screen was dominated by strong, rugged males -- the "one-punch, one-shot variety."
ACCRA, Ghana, Dec. 30 -- Ghana is to establish next year a number of border settlements modeled on those in Israel.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Senator Clinton P. Anderson said today the United States should resume atomic tests if the Soviet Union did not quickly agree to an internationally inspected test ban.
ROME, Dec. 30 (UPI) -- Pope John XXIII said today that the rights of the Roman Catholic Church in the teaching of youth came before the rights of the state.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- When the year 1950 in the Christian calendar arrived in these parts, which was on the stroke of midnight Dec. 31-Jan. 1 on clocks that kept correct local time, there was a good deal of wassailing to greet "the beginning of the second half of the twentieth century."
DALLAS, Dec. 30 -- The Syracuse and University of Texas football teams reached the scene of battle today for their Cotton Bowl game New Year's Day.
A leading stage director arrived yesterday from Germany and distinguished himself from most of his profession by declaring that he was not enthusiastic about theatre-in-the-round.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Indications are that the domestic commercial fish catch for 1959 will exceed 5,000,000,000 pounds for the second time in recorded history.
A strike of 625 workers in subway, hotel, railroad and airport newsstands in the metropolitan area has been called for midnight Saturday.

HICKORY, N. C., Dec. 30 (AP) -- The touring Swedish basketball team has lost its New Year's Eve booking here against Lenoir Rhyne College, but the visitors have taken over the site of the canceled game.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- Aneurin Bevan, deputy leader of the Labor party, was said today to be on the danger list at the Royal Free Hospital of London, where he underwent a major abdominal operation yesterday.

SHERMAN, Tex., Dec. 30 (UPI) -- Representative Sam Rayburn of Texas greeted more than a dozen fellow members of Congress and hundreds of friends at a pre-birthday celebration today with a somber warning that nuclear war still threatened to wipe out civilization.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers ruined the pro coaching debut of a former team-mate tonight by defeating the Detroit Pistons, 124 -- 109, in a National Basketball Association game at Convention Hall.
The New York Central Railroad and the Long Island Rail Road will run extra commuter trains today to handle the expected early afternoon homeward rush for New Year's Eve.

The year 1959 in Latin America has been dominated by the dramatic Cuban Revolution. Last New Year's Day saw the overthrow of President Batista, and as another New Year approaches Cuba and its sensational young leader, Fidel Castro, are still in the limelight.
The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) closed its lending activities for the year yesterday by extending to Chile and Uruguay credits totaling $39,500,000.
The city's voluntary hospitals yesterday invited critics of rising Blue Cross rates to cooperate with them in exploring ways to hold down hospital costs.
REPORTS of deer kills in various states and parts of states keep pouring in, but some of them don't mean very much because the number of deer that should have been killed isn't stated.
WATERTOWN, N. Y., Dec. 30 (AP) -- A second American girl is reported missing in the West Mediterranean area.
LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, Dec. 30 -- Congolese nationalist leaders confronted King Baudouin of the Belgians today with demands for immediate and total independence.
NEWARK, Dec. 30 -- The Pennsylvania Railroad asked today for an increase averaging 28 per cent in most multiple-ride tickets between New Jersey and New York.

ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- State Controller Arthur Levitt charged today that the Rockefeller administration's plan for the reorganization of the state government would place "an unprecedented concentration of authority" in the hands of the Governor.

ONE of the handsomest gift books of this or any other year that comes to mind is "An Illustrated History of Music," by Marc Pincherle. It contains a gallery of paintings by great artists and one of those usefully informing texts that will make even an amateur among amateurs seem agreeably authoritative when Bach, say, or Toscanini or the Gregorian chants turn up in the conversation.

The stockholders of the Howard Stores Corporation approved the acquisition of the Ripley Manufacturing Corporation at a meeting here yesterday. Both companies make and retail boys' and men's clothing.
TOMORROW another leap year will begin. At one time this thought would have made many a maiden's heart beat faster -- and set many a young male traveling toward the hills.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 30 (UPI) -- The Boston Celtics tied the National Basketball Association record for consecutive victories with their seventeenth straight tonight. They scored a 96-82 triumph over the St. Louis Hawks before 11,084 fans, the largest crowd ever to watch a professional game in Kiel Auditorium.

As I write this, Monday evening, the air raid sirens on the lower East Side, and perhaps elsewhere in the city, are blaring forth their eerie message. A call to Police Headquarters brings the information that "the rain set them off." No one can deny the fact that sirens, like any other device, are subject to mechanical difficulties.
CHICAGO, Dec. 30 -- Experimental evidence was reported here today to support the view that aging of the body is due to expenditure of its "adaptation energy."
Cotton futures moved 4 points (20 cents a bale) off to 16 points (80 cents) up yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. The distant options showed the best gains.

United Artists Corporation has agreed to exchange four films with the Soviet Union. Confirmation was received yesterday by cable from Sovexportfilm in Moscow. The agreement was arranged and signed by Arnold M. Picker, United Artists vice president in charge of foreign distribution, and A. N. Davydov, president of Sovexportfilm.

B. E. Shetterly, a 33-year-old horseman from Lexington, Ky., was at this month's Philadelphia and Camden shows because curiosity about dogs had led him into a strange business. He was soliciting breeders to enter their dogs in a new Florida tourist attraction called Dog Land.

Against a setting of pink Christmas trees trimmed with gold and silver ornaments, six young women made their formal bows to society last night at the Greensleeves Ball in the ballroom of the Sheraton-East.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today canceled plans to suspend Federal grading of lamb and mutton on Monday.
OTTAWA, Dec. 30 -- Canada and the United States have moved a step closer to settling their long-drawn dispute over the development of the power of the Columbia River.
ALBANY, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Men are steadily encroaching on the schoolmarm's territory in New York State's public schools. Already men outnumber women on staffs of secondary schools.
CHICAGO, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The grain futures market was generally weak today in dull trading which brokers said consisted mainly of evening up commitments for the year-end holiday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Department of Justice reported today a civil antitrust suit against the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company and six other manufacturers of plate glass mirrors had been closed by the entry of a consent judgment.
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 30 -- Fluctuating magnetism in outer space may be responsible for the earth's auroral phenomena, a space scientist reported today.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Dec. 30 (Reuters) -- Sir Roy Welensky called today for complete independence for the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland in Federal affairs by 1961.

VIENNA, Dec. 30 -- Austria's governing coalition has approved a measure that may set the pattern for the extension of government regulation and control to all free sectors of the national economy.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- President Eisenhower will make a goodwill trip soon to four South American countries, probably in late February and early March, informed diplomatic sources said today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Nine grants totaling $321,894 to support community cancer-demonstration projects were announced today by the Public Health Service.

CAIRO, Dec. 30 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser accepted tonight the resignation of a Vice President of the United Arab Republic and three other Cabinet ministers in what appeared to be the beginning of a Cabinet shuffle.

Oscar Robertson sent tournament scoring records tumbling like tenpins last night in leading Cincinnati's unbeaten quintet to a 96-83 triumph over Iowa in the final of the eighth annual Holiday Basketball Festival.

ALBANY, N. Y., Dec. 30 (AP) -- The state's highest court today refused to reinstate twenty-one New York City policemen who were dismissed six years ago in the wake of the Harry Gross bookmaking scandal.

The new Labor-Management Report and Disclosure Act of 1959 was used here yesterday in a Federal Court suit for the first time. It was invoked to settle a jurisdictional dispute within the International Hod Carriers Building and Common Laborers' Union of America.

STOWE, Vt., Dec. 30 -- SKI KETCH: Mrs. Mary Bourdon's first love was horses. She was raised on a farm at Westchester, Pa., and rode daily over the Brandywine rolling hunting country, a few miles southwest of Philadelphia.
A Biblical scholar suggested yesterday that it was John the Baptist, and not the Apostle Paul, who first broke with Judaism and set the stage for the development of the Christian religion.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission warned in a year-end statement today that public indignation at quiz fixes and payola practices demanded that broadcasting "mend certain of its ways."
PARIS, Dec. 30 (UPI) -- Rada and Aleksei I. Adzhubei, daughter and son-in-law of Premier Khrushchev, ended their Paris visit today and flew back to Moscow.

Broadway's Hindu astrologer, Sant Ram Mandal, who contends he can solve all the world's problems, and even some of his own, was vibrating in a corner of his spooky office yesterday, predicting what is ahead in 1960.
Americans gave away an estimated total of $7,300,000,000 this year -- $40.83 for each person, based on an official population estimate of 179,000,000.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 30 (AP) -- Tropical Park placing judges admitted a photo-finish mistake today -- and touched off an unruly scavenger hunt for discarded tickets on strongly-picked Teacher in the sixth race.

GROTON, Conn., Dec. 39 -- The U.S.S. George Washington, first of a new class of undersea dreadnoughts, was commissioned here today under gray skies and in intermittent flurries of snow.

NEWARK, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Borough of Fort Lee is back on its own financial feet for the first time since 1933. It has reduced its debt and will resume full management of its finances.

The Beatrice Foods Company cleared $5,878,079 in the nine months ended on Nov. 30, against $5,006,289 in the 1958 period, the company reported. The earnings equal $2.15 a share on 2,604,850 common shares, compared with $2.04 each on 2,322,097 common shares.

Thomas E. Murray, former Atomic Energy Commissioner, recently advanced arguments in support of a plan for dismantling Soviet and American hydrogen bombs. This is a good time of the year when the spirit of human kindness at its height, to once again bring the problems of voluntary hospital workers to the attention of the public. While our bitter forty-six-day strike was settled on June 22, the fundamental problems which brought about have never been corrected. What exists today in practically every voluntary hospital in our city is a temporary truce.

The body of a 20-year-old clerk who had been missing since a Christmas Eve office party was found yesterday in an airshaft of the Seagram Building. He had fallen seven floors.
LONDON, Dec. 30 -- A bout of profit taking checked, but did not halt the advance of prices on the stock market here today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (UPI) -- America's scheduled airlines are ending 1959 with a disappointing safety record.
