Capt. Louis L. Murphy, who was in command of the tanker Valchem when she collided with the liner Santa Rosa last March 26, was absolved yesterday of a negligence charge brought against him by the Coast Guard.

Year-end bond market operations inspired by tax considerations slowed visibly yesterday as the calendar began to run out on 1959. Price fluctuations were substantial enough, however, to impart a definite tone to the market. Generally, this was firmness.
RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 30 (AP) -- All was quiet in the Atlantic Coast Line railway yards here early today when a worker looked up -- and blinked.

MOSCOW, Dec. 30 -- The Soviet Union charged tonight that a South Korean naval craft had fired on an unarmed Soviet ship off North Korea, seriously damaging her and inflicting casualties among the crew.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 30 -- Motorists are killing each other and pedestrians at the rate of forty a day in West Germany. Harassed officials of the Government and of safety organizations are baffled as to how to stop the steadily mounting slaughter.

In these words Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota yesterday described his own prospects in his quest for the Democratic Presidential nomination, for which he has formally announced his candidacy. This is one of the times that Senator Humphrey cannot be held guilty of overstatement.

As the West prepares to meet Premier Khrushchev at the summit to debate the fate of Germany, that country is suddenly being subjected to what begins to look like a concerted series of neo-Nazi outrages with anti-Semitic and anti-Catholic implications and Communist cross-connections.

To its own surprise, the Long Island Rail Road had a small net profit last month. It had expected a possible net loss of $200,000 to $250,000, but wound up instead with a net income of $17,614. In November of last year it incurred a net loss of $71,588.
Gold and silver balloons, silver stars, gold garlands and Christmas candles provided an appropriate setting for the Gold and Silver Ball in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza last night.
The frequent difficulty of finding a taxicab in this city, and pressure for removal of the recently imposed tax, raise questions.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Iraq is situated in the middle of two political extremes.

Electric power production was estimated at 13,400,000,000 kilowatt hours last week, down from 14,150,000,000 kilowatt hours the week before, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. In the comparable 1958 week the figure was 12,379,000,000 kilowatt hours.

THE Lichee Tree is the evocative name of a Chinese restaurant newly arrived in Greenwich Village at 65 East Eighth Street. The menu, with a delicately printed lichee branch on the cover, is as fascinating to read as the food is good to eat.

BOSTON, Dec. 30 (UPI) -- Another flood tide battered the New England coast today in the wake of a northeaster that took at least ten lives, caused property damage close to $2,000,000 and threatened pollution of water supplies.

Directors of the Otis Elevator Company yesterday recommended a two-for-one split of the common stock. The board also voted to increase the quarterly dividend to 70 cents a share on the present common stock, payable on Jan. 29 to holders of record of Jan. 8. Shareholders had been receiving 60 cents.
MILLBURN, N. J., Dec. 30 -- A municipal court may not concern itself with what happens on the other end of a telephone wire once the wire crosses the town border.
SCARSDALE, N. Y., Dec. 30 -- The $22,000 that was raised here at a July 4 benefit has been spent for the education, medical care and guidance of South Korean children.
Few major employers of the city's 3,500,000 workers are planning for emergency transportation if transit workers strike the city's subway and bus lines.
American Export Lines, Inc., has decided after weeks of off-and-on negotiations to purchase the 18,000-ton liner Atlantic.
STANFORD, Calif., Dec. 30 (AP) -- Two young Stanford surgeons have successfully transplanted a living heart from one dog to another.
General Sessions Judge John A. Mullen, who through the years has won the respect of both the prosecutors and defense counsel, spends his last day in court as a judge today.
ALBANY, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Legislature would set up watchdogs over welfare spending under the terms of bills filed today in the face of mounting relief costs.

MADRID, Dec. 29 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco ruled out tonight any possibility of restoring the monarchy in Spain unless it agreed to absorb and continue the present regime, its men and its policies.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Farm prices dropped nearly 1 per cent in the month ended on Dec. 15, continuing the decline that promises a hot political fight in Congress over farm policy.

While Bobby Fischer, the United States chess champion, and Samuel Reshevsky, his chief rival, were kept busy last night by their opponents, Robert Byrne of the University of Indianapolis crept up on them with a fine victory over Arnold S. Denker.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Vice President Nixon met again today with leaders of the steel industry, keeping alive the hope of a mediated settlement of the protracted labor dispute.
CHICAGO, Dec. 30 -- The world is entering another major industrial revolution, a history professor told the Society for the History of Technology today.
The Ford Foundation has earmarked $750,000 to advance the programs of the National Committee on the Aging over the next seven years. This is in addition to its gift of $500,000 in 1956.

Dick Button, champion ice skater, has replaced Ted Lewis, veteran entertainer, in "Ice Capers of 1960." Performances wilt be given next Sunday and Monday nights in the 3,000-seat South Mountain Arena in West Orange, N. J., for the benefit of the March of Dimes.
Hope for a happier year in 1960 was the theme expressed yesterday by several donors to the fund for New York's Neediest Cases.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 30 -- New incidents of anti-Semitic vandalism and the desecration of Roman Catholic churches were disclosed in widely separated parts of West Germany today.

Spurred by the finding of a strip of chromium on a Brooklyn street, the police yesterday were seeking a 1956 Plymouth in the belief that it was the vehicle with which a hit-and-run driver killed a 75-year-old woman Monday night.
The city's fiscal program for 1960-61 will include a proposal to raise $13,000,000 in new revenue to help close the $20,000,000 gap to be caused if the 10-cent tax on taxi
MOSCOW, Dec. 30 -- Premier Khrushchev's opposition to mammoth collective farm associations appears to have sidetracked a major proposal advanced by two of his leading lieutenants only a week ago.
LONDON, Thursday, Dec. 31 (Reuters) -- Cargo laws operating in favor of United States shipping were described by a leading British shipping official today as crippling to America's allies.
American girls and royal from far-off places were among the young women who made their bows last night before glittering assemblage of persons from the social and diplomatic worlds.
A. Belskaya, foreign editor of Literaturnaya Gazeta of Moscow, has pointed out in a letter to The New York Times an error in an account in The Times of a Soviet-American conflict over Mark Twain.

WEST BRANCH, Mich., Dec. 31 (UPI) -- A Roman Catholic priest from South America was arrested at a roadblock today. He was accused of absconding with about $12,000 from a parish here, where he was serving temporarily as an assistant pastor.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Department store sales in the nation last week were 20 per cent above the level of a year earlier.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Ezra Taft Benson said today that Vice President Nixon was a supporter of his farm policy.
CHICAGO, Dec. 31 (AP) -- A ate rally lifted soybean futures into a firm to strong price range today, but grains limped through the short session of the Board of Trade with price moves mostly mixed.
DANBURY, Conn., Dec. 31 (AP) -- A 6-year-old boy was taken from a frozen brook today and revived by artificial respiration. He had been under water for almost ten minutes.
The New York Knickerbockers whipped the Minneapolis Lakers, 127 -- 102, in a National Basketball Association game at Madison Square Garden last night.

Bobby Fischer, United States chess champion, yesterday defeated Pal Benko, a Hungarian refugee, in sixty-eight moves in their adjourned game from the tenth round of the national championship at the Manhattan Chess Club.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 1 point (5 cents a bale) off to 7 points (35 cents) up yesterday. The far months showed the most strength.

Investing clients of Nathaniel D. Gribin have contracted to buy a vacant plot of Land on the west side of Cannon Place, 288 feet south of West 238th Street, in the Kingsbridge Heights area of the Bronx.

MOSCOW, Dec. 31 -- The Soviet Union issued a restrained denial today of President Eisenhower's charge that its scientists had refused serious consideration of American data on underground nuclear tests.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- George Meany predicted today that 1960 would be a "year of battle" with industry and Congressional "reactionaries" for the survival of the American labor movement.
LONDON, Dec. 31 -- British automobile and steel manufacturers ended 1959 with reports of records established in the old year or expected in the new.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Dec 31 (Canadian Press) -- Two Canadian forest products giants with estimated net resources of $200,000,000 have merged. This action created a single company ranking among the world's largest in forestry operations.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The turn of a year divisible by ten revives the question of when decades and centuries end. It is widely held, even in circles otherwise quite sensible about such important matters as these, that, say, the year 1960 is the first year of the seventh decade of the twentieth century rather than the last year of the sixth decade.
ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Willie Shoemaker rode four winners at Santa Anita today and polished off his fifth national riding championship.

Business loans of the fifteen large New York City banks rose $915,000,000, to $10,618,000,000, in the final half of 1959, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with a rise of $196,000,000 in the 1958 period.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Labor Secretary Mitchell pursued today the Administration's goal of a swift termination of the steel dispute.
The city and the nation celebrated and passed last night as the old year passed into history and 1960 came in with its cargo of the unknown.

London's boat show is ahead of New York's in at least one respect -- time. While this city's boating public must wait until Jan. 15 for a view of the latest in craft and gear, those of like mind in England are satisfying their curiosity now.
THE institution of the challenge trophy has vanished from contract bridge. There used to be several.
Parry O'Brien of Los Angeles, the holder of the world shot-put record, was chosen yesterday as the 1959 winner of the James E. Sullivan Memorial Trophy.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The Food and Drug Administration today gave food processors until Feb. 1 to ask for more time to prove the safety of hundreds of additives used in human foods.
YAOUNDE, Cameroons, Friday, Jan. 1 -- Thousands of Africans cheered the birth of a nation at the start of the new year today. But the joyous salute to Cameroons sovereignty had a violent prelude.
ALBANY, Dec. 31 (AP) -- An appellate court upheld today the conviction of an Apalachin defendant who was found guilty last year of criminal contempt of court.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota, in the statement which formalized the candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination he has actively been conducting ever since his eight-hour conversation with Premier Khrushchev, became the second prominent politician in a week to supply ammunition to the rival party.

LAST Wednesday in this space I dared to record some frankly personal opinions about which novels published in the decade just finished might be read for pleasure and might be critically admired twenty-five years hence. My controversial notions were influenced not only by what I thought might be, but also by what I thought ought to be.

DURING the Fifties, just ended, public taste was elevated to-an awesome degree. Thanks primarily to international travel the palate was awakened to such magnificent dishes as quiche Lorraine, beef in Burgundy wine sauce, coq au vin and sukiyaki.
HARTFORD, Dec. 31 -- A Democratic party feud between United States Senator Thomas J. Dodd and John Golden, national committeeman, was renewed today after eight years.

CAIRO, Dec. 31 -- Informed sources believe President Gamal Abdel Nasser's drive to set up a National Union as an approach to popular government in the United Arab Republic was a major factor in the resignation of four ministers announced last night.
The Federal Maritime Board will get a new member on Monday.
The National Labor Relations Board moved yesterday to speed a solution of the jurisdictional battle aboard the twenty-six tankers of the Esso Standard Oil Company.

MIAMI, Dec. 31 (AP) -- A wide-open game with passes of all varieties is in prospect as Missouri, the Big Eight representative, meets the Southeastern Conference champion, Georgia, in the twenty-sixth annual Orange Bowl football game tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- The Department of Justice filed an antitrust suit today seeking to "block acquisition of Leonard Refineries, Inc., by the Standard Oil Company (Ohio).
A nation-wide search for photographs dramatizing the multiracial character of the United States was announced yesterday by Theodore W. Kheel, president of the National Urban League.
MONTREAL, Dec. 31 (AP) -- A Swedish basketball team, banned from playing in the United States by the Amateur Athletic Union, has accepted an invitation to play two games here.

Tonight's boxing program at Madison Square Garden revives a tradition of holiday fights that has furnished thousands of fans with a thrilling start for a new year. Although no championship bouts have been held on New Year's Day, many titleholders have performed on that date.
HAVANA, Friday, Jan. 1 -- Cuba celebrated New Year's Eve and one year of the Castro regime with revolutionary fervor.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission said today it had ordered the publisher of a New York periodical to stop selling advertising space by representing the periodical as the nationally circulated official publication of the American Federation of Labor or of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.
An expanded version of the Columbia Broadcasting System telecast, "The Population Explosion," will be shown on the network on Jan. 14 from 9:30 to 11 P.M.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 31 (UPI) -- The big and bruising Wisconsin Badgers were solid favorites today to win their battle against the Washington Huskies tomorrow in the forty-sixth annual Rose Bowl football game.
LONDON, Dec. 31 -- Three Britons and a woman in Nova Scotia shared a prize of L500 ($1,400) today in the worldwide competition to devise a new alphabet desired by the late George Bernard Shaw.
MEN will emerge as strong characters in 1960.

Generalissimo Franco's annual year-end message is interesting only because it is the same as all the other year-end messages in the interminable series that began twenty years ago. So far as the Caudillo is concerned, nothing could be better than his "normal and legitimate" regime and it must go on forever and ever.
How is the television industry put together? Who controls what in a business that daily amuses, informs, pleases or irritates millions of viewers?
A scofflaw's call for help netted another one yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 31 -- Hedda Hopper, the movie columnist, denied today reports of wholesale desertion of stars, slated to participate in her taped television show scheduled for Jan. 10 on the National Broadcasting Company network.

PARIS, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Joseph Greeson, 42 years old, Detroit-born and American-reared, is a modern man without a country. He insists that he is American. But the State Department has ruled he forfeited his citizenship by swearing allegiance to a foreign power while serving with Canadian forces in World War II.

Diamonds, platinum and blue-chip stocks wore not by any means the investors' best friends in 1959. On the average, all showed a gain in value enough to keep ahead of the 1.5 per cent rise in consumer prices in this country.

Physical possession of Ebbets Field passed yesterday from the Dodgers, a former Brooklyn baseball institution relocated in Los Angeles, to the Kratter Corporation, a New York real estate development concern. It is reported that the site will be used for a low-cost housing developmont.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 31 -- President Heinrich Luebke warned the West German people tonight that incidents such as the Christmas morning desecration of the Cologne synagogue were dirtying Germany's name in the world.
TOKYO, Dec. 31 -- Japan's trade with the Soviet Union is entering a period of expansion with the expected completion of a new trade agreement in January.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The Secretary of Commerce reported today that the nation's total output rose to a record of $178,000,000,000 this year, and said it could reach the half trillion mark by mid-1960.
Stocks closed the year yesterday with a weak hurrah. After a boisterous start, prices retreated steadily and at the final gong retained only a third of their early gains.
Leonard Ruskin has been trying to become a Broadway producer. Previous efforts to achieve that status by Guy Lombardo's erstwhile associate at Jones Beach have been in vain.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Surgeon General LeRoy E. Burney today set up a group of fight public health officers to plan a reorganization of the Public Health Service.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Friday, Jan. 1 -- A decree aimed at breaking the Chinese stranglehold on Indonesia's rural economy went into effect last midnight.
A city-wide subway and bus strike was averted last night when the Transport Workers Union and the Transit Authority agreed on a new contract.

EASTVIEW, N.Y., Dec. 31 -- Chauncey T.S. Fish, the White Plains lawyer who was arrester yesterday for contempt of court in the administration of a $118,634 estate, remained in the Westchester County Jail here today.
The Nineteen Fifties ended in Wall Street with New York Stock Exchange equity values above the $300,000,000,000-mark, more than three times the level of 1929 and twenty times above that of 1932.

Edwin Ahlquist, adviser to the heavyweight boxing champion, Ingemar Johansson of Sweden, cabled the New York State Athletic Commission yesterday that neither had made any commitment for a return title match with Floyd Patterson.
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 31 -- Vice President Nixon would welcome some tests of vote-getting strength among Republican Vice-Presidential aspirants.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On Dec. 25 and 26 The Times carried reports of rioting and political unrest on the West Indian island of Martinique. To any perceptive person who has recently visited Martinique, as this writer did last July, these reports should come as no surprise.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 31 -- Following is the text of the report to President Eisenhower by Attorney General William P. Rogers titled "Deceptive Practices in Broudcasting Media":
CHICAGO, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Year-end prices for butcher hogs today were at their lowest levels in almost four years as the market slumped as much as 50 cents a hundred pounds.

EL, PASO, Tex., Dec. 31 (UPI) -- Charlie Johnson's arm and the bruising running of Bob Gaiters paced New Mexico State to a 28-8 upset victory over fumbling North Texas State in the twenty-fifth annual Sun Bowl football game today.
More bonds were called for redemption in December before maturity than in any month since June or for a December since 1955.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 31 -- President Juscelino Kubitschek foresaw tonight an "era of mutual understanding" between Brazil and the United States.

New securities offered here in December to the public showed the usual year-end irregular trends following large flotations in recent months. Bonds marketed rose above the offerings for November and a year ago, while stock issues were down from those of the preceding month and December, 1958.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The Administration is expected to ask Congress for a three-year extension of the Federal farm soil bank for retiring surplus crop-producing land. The extension could cost up to $1,850,000,000.

A $50,000,000 fund-raising campaign to "enable the Columbia University Presbyterian Medical Center to maintain its leadership in the medical world" was announced to a group of Columbia alumni yesterday by Maurice T. Moore, chairman of the trustees.

Roger M. Blough, chairman of the United States Steel Co poration, predicted yesterday that the nation's steel mil would operate at more than 9 per cent of capacity in the first six months of 1960 to refill d pleted inventories.
LONDON, Dec. 31 -- The stock market here ended the year with rises continuing to predominate among the industrials.
WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 31 -- Frederick E. Weeks Jr. resigned today as Chief Assistant District Attorney of Westchester County.
Trading on the New York Stock Exchange last year began in the shares of a can company and ended with a transaction to the stock of a maker of portswear.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- Coaches Buddy Parker of the Pittsburgh Steelers and Paul Brown of the Cleveland Browns made a four-player deal by telephone today.
The cry of "unfair" went up yesterday from truckers and officials of auto-renting companies in the wake of the city's announcement of proposed new taxes.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 31 -- The liveliest spot in Hollywood this New Year's Eve, as on any other night of the year, is a supermarket called the Ranch Market.

State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, who has frequently championed the cause of the consumer, moved yesterday to break up a Chinese noodle monopoly. Seven Chinese noodle manufacturers were enjoined from fur- ther price-fixing.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31 -- Research in the field of biochemical genetics provided the greatest medical achievements in 1959, most of the deans of eighty-four medical schools said in reply to a poll taken by the American Medical Association.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The recent encyclical by Pope John on good taste in the press made an excellent point. It is my own opinion that a simply worded law could radically improve the quality of our newspapers, "freeing" the press to give us more news and less scandal.

Average borrowings by member banks from Federal Reserve Banks dropped $52,000,000 to $928,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Average reserves in excess of requirements declined $179,000,000 to $506,000,000.
The 1959 bond market passed into history yesterday with rising prices prevailing.

Both nations involved may welcome the news that the Soviet Union has signed a contract with American business men for the construction of a major textile plant in that country. The Soviet people need more and better textiles, and American assistance toward attaining that end is a constructive contribution toward the welfare of a people with whom we have always wanted to be friends.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Railroad freight loadings in 1959 totaled 30,990,638 cars, or 2.5 per cent above the 1958 level, but 12.7 per cent below that in 1957.
TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 1 -- The Japanese awakened today to the beginning of a year in which the lowly rat will be an honored being.

ALGIERS, Dec. 31 -- Gen. Maurice Challe, French commander in chief in Algeria, declared tonight that the nationalist rebels, having seen their best units broken up during 1959, had decided to concentrate on "blind terrorism."
Africans working and studying in the United States have given generously to aid one of New York's Neediest Cases a frail old woman who spent her working life teaching in a mission school in Africa.
NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 31 -- A program to improve the harbor and expand boating facilities here has been adopted by the Norwalk Harbor Committee.
HONG KONG, Dec. 31 -- Communist North Vietnam adopted today a new Constitution based on the principle of a peaceful reunification of all of Vietnam, according to the Hanoi radio.

THE approach of a new decade has set in motion a revolutionary concept in clock design. As the fleeting seconds of 1960 go by, it is the faces, not just the hands, that will revolve on Irving Harper's creations for the Howard Miller Clock Company.

Dr. George N. Shuster, president of Hunter College, has written a new book called "Education and Moral Wisdom." In it he examines academic freedom, the "impingement" of philosophy on our way of life and the difference between education and wisdom.
LONDON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The handful of people who live on Lundy Island want to be left alone. But the voice of the mainland, talking of laws and taxes, is getting loud.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 31 -- Laos was placed under army control today following the resignation of Premier Phoui Sananikone.
A five-alarm fire swept through ten stores in the Inwood section of upper Manhattan last night, injuring two firemen.

The two-year extension of the Federal Commission on Civil Rights was the "solitary advance" in the "highly disappointing record" of Congressional action on civil rights in 1959, the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith said yesterday.

The heads of city departments concerned with public health and safety met last nigh at City Hall to prepare details of a sixteen-point plan drawn by Mayor Wagner to maintain services if the subways had closed down today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter forecast today that 1960 would be a year of "great challenges" for United States foreign policy.

Tight money and bank mergers held net demand and time deposits of banks of the New York Clearing House Association in the year ended yesterday to $26,816,719,000 on a daily average basis, according to M.A. Schapiro Co., Inc., a bank stock investment house.
The "Emperor Waltz" ran a close second to "Auld Lang Syne" as last night's musical salute to the new year.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 31 -- Stricter enforcement of present Government radio and television controls and new laws to end "the spectacle of corruption the broadcast industry" were recommended today in a report to President Eisenhower by Attorney General William P. Rogers.
HONG KONG, Dec. 31 -- Communist China's lowered 1959 production goals for agriculture and industry have been overfulfilled.

All New York commodity exchanges closed early yesterday in preparation for the New Year holiday. Most closed at noon. Trading was dull. Evening of positions prior to the three-day week-end accounted for most of the volume.
The F.D.R.-Woodrow Wilson Democratic Club is planning an unusual political meeting for next Thursday night. It will bring together a member of Congress and five men who may seek to unseat him.
LONDON, Dec. 31 -- Some shrewd blows were struck today in the perennial contest between Ye Olde England and modern Britain.

An entire armory of new weapons for the exploration of man's past has been disclosed. Most of the devices are the fruits of such young sciences as space exploration, nuclear research and solid-state physics.
AFTER a decade or more of "togetherness," the new trend in housing design is "aloneness." The open-floor plan is yielding to the closed-door one.
DETROIT, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Ford built more cars than Chevrolet did in 1959, the first time this has happened since 1935.
ROSLYN HARBOR, L.I., Dec. 31 -- Cultural relations between the United States and Mexico are being advanced on a non-diplomatic level by an American girl and a Mexican boy.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 31 (AP) -- It was only a "human error" when Tropical Park judges reversed their decision on the winner of yesterday's sixth race after many winning tickets had been discarded, some in fragments.
The plastic contact lens industry, which was born twenty years ago and grew rapidly but never attained full stature, has come of age.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- President Eisenhower was reported today to be considering a major reorganization of the space program to provide for centralized White House control over military and civilian programs.
A big week-end is in store for skiing enthusiasts. From Canada to New York many resort operators reported the best ski conditions of the season yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 31 -- About 2,200 Britons were named today in Queen Elizabeth's New Year's honors list.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The United States has asked the Dominican Republic to recall its consul general in Miami for violation of United States laws.
CHICAGO, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- Trading in soybeans in 1959 rose 42.7 per cent above the 1958 level to offset losses in other grains, the Chicago Board of Trade reported today.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- Pete Stevens resigned today as head football coach at Temple University, but agreed to remain for three more months to assure a "smooth changeover in the coaching situation."

Year for Two Elections So much attenttion has already been diverted to the activities of Presidential hopefuls as the year open that a great many people are going to think the selection of the next President is the only election of nation-wide interest that will take place in 1960.

A rereading of the things people say on New Year's Day reveals no great variety. Again we wish one another the best. But there is an illusion in this holiday. Nature, in the cosmic sense, pays no attention to it. She rings no bells, blows no whistles and does not put on a funny hat.

As 1959 yielded to 1960 at midnight last night thousands of churchgoers hailed the milestone at solemn mass, in Watch Night services and in devout prayer that the Sixties might herald a just and durable peace for all mankind.

EARNEST MARPLES, Britain's Minister of Transport, who is on his way to New York to study traffic conditions in the United States, arrives probably too late to realize how bad the jams of the closing holiday season were in this country.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In his letter printed Dec. 18 Tarek Jabri of the Arab States Delegations Office disputes the validity of the arguments in your editorial regarding the Arab D.P.'s. That he conveniently ignores the officially established and admitted responsibility of the Arab states for the creation of the problem is understandable.
Until today, the youngest independent republic in the world was Guinea, the former French colony on Africa's West Coast which opted out of the French Communaute in September of 1958.

ALL survivors of the rugged Battle of New Year's Eve, including the walking wounded, are invited to tune in their television sets today. If they have enough strength to spin the dial and enough steadiness to push the buttons, they should see enough solid football entertainment to make them forget their miseries.
DALLAS, Dec. 31 -- The first and fourth-ranking college football teams of 1959 meet tomorrow in the Cotton Bowl, one of the prize New Year's Day football games.

Fred H. Hill has contracts to buy a private dwelling with a three-story extension at 121 East Seventy-first Street from Joan Bassler Peters and Anthony Bassler Jr. The property, 20 by 100 feet, is assessed at $67,000.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- Mighty Mississippi, a football team with a grudge, is a 7-point favorite to gain revenge against Louisiana State in the Sugar Bowl game tomorrow.
MADRID, Dec. 31 -- The Spanish Government announced today two new laws to attract foreign capital investment into Spain's recovery.
Intervention by Vice President Nixon was reported last night to have failed to produce any new wage offer by the steel industry.

RESOLUTIONS on this day ought to be about taking care of equipment and not forgetting things. But they also ought to be resolutions that the strong, hardy outdoorsman might keep, for a week or two anyway.
The establishment of a continuous survey of the country's multi-billion-dollar young male market was announced yesterday by the Petersen Publishing Company.
The final large fete of the 1959-60 debutante season, which began in June, took place last night in the Waldorf-Astoria.

Manhattan was a town of tired trumpet players and bleary bartenders yesterday, and nobody seemed excited about the clown who danced on Broadway or the bearded sign-carrier on Fifth Avenue who announced: "The Wicked Shall be Turned Into Hell, Repent!"

The fifty-four-family apartment house at 2005 Davidson Avenue in the Bronx has been sold by Irving B. Neiditch to a client of Leonard Altschul, lawyer. The sale was subject to mortgages of about $200,000, according to Hemsley-Spear, Inc., broker in the deal.
TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 1 -- Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi is preparing a frontal assault on Iran's feudal land tenure system, which holds more than 1,000,000 farm families in serfdom.

Samuel Reshevsky, seeking to reduce Bobby Fischer's lead in the national championship chess tournament for the Lessing J. Rosenwald Trophy at the Manhattan Chess Club, encountered Arnold S. Denker, the 1944 titleholder, yesterday in their postponed game from the eighth round.

YAOUNDE, Cameroon, Jan. 1 -- Renewed violence marked the dawn of Cameroon's first day of independence today. Five persons were killed and eight injured on the outskirts of this city. The new wave of terrorism brought to thirty-nine the number killed since Wednesday.

Despite the holiday calm prevailing in Palestine at the moment, a new and potentially dangerous dispute is simmering over the old problem of how to utilize the water resources of the Jordan River basin.
A "jughandle'' has come to the aid of motorists on older New Jersey highways.
Belen Amparan turned in her first Carmen at the Metropolitan Opera last night and played the role with freshness and spirit.

David Ross' plans to make a gala affair of the observance on Sunday night, Jan. 17, of the 100th anniversary of the birth of the Russian playwright Anton Chekhov are proceeding apace. The producer-director of the Fourth Street Theatre has signed Zero Mostel to star in a new version of the celebrated author's one-act comedy "The Bear."
THE New York Philharmonic marked the arrival of 1960 with a program that commemorated a former music director and that was conducted by another.

VIENNA, Jan. 1 -- A leading Roman Catholic Deputy in Poland's Parliament has warned Wladyslaw Gomulka's Communist Government that it cannot solve the country's economic difficulties without creating a democratic climate.
Despite a reduction in the amount withheld weekly for state income taxes in the new year, most New Yorkers will get less take-home pay because of an increase in Federal Social Security taxes.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Jan. 1 -- Wet, chilly weather kept President Eisenhower indoors today at his vacation retreat here.
WILTON, Conn., Jan. 1 -- Seven enterprising Boy Scouts here have started Operation Non-skid to raise travel funds for next summer's National Scouting Jamboree at Colorado Springs.

BUFFALO, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The assistant pastor of a Roman Catholic church here was shot to death today as he sat in his automobile in the church garage.
A CAREFULLY calculated defensive play was made in today's hand, and it was so recognized, but a possible counterplay was overlooked.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UPI) -- Commercial aviation's worst safety record in seven years may have had one beneficial result. All those concerned are determined to keep it from happening again.

MIAMI, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Francis Tarkenton, Georgia's quarterback, hurled two touchdown passes through Missouri's porous aerial defenses today and the heavily favored Bulldogs beat the Tigers, 14 -- 0, in the Orange Bowl football game.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- The Buraimi story starts with Bhalib Ibn Ali, the Imam of Oman, and his brother Talib.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 1 -- Art Tokle, who spent last season dominating ski jumping in the East, opened the new season today in the same role.
CHICAGO, Jan. 1 (UPI) -- A rookie, Murray Balfour, scored in the final fifteen seconds tonight to earn the Chicago Black Hawks a 4-4 tie with the Detroit Red Wings.

BOSTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The New England Council issued the following weather forecast and report on ski conditions today:

HAVANA, Jan. 1 -- The peaceful celebration of the beginning of 1960 in Cuba was in sharp contrast to the bloody violence of New Year's Day of 1959. But an essential element remained -- Fidel Castro continued in complete control of the island.

Hofstra Gardens, a 132-family garden apartment development in Hempstead, L.I., has been purchased by an investment group headed by Jack C. Arber and Ben M. Arber. The seller was H.M.S. Apartments, Inc.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 1 -- In two of Westchester's six cities, the Mayoralties changed political hands today. Similar transitions, the result of bitter campaigns for Supervisor last November, occurred in two of the county's eighteen towns.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 1 -- The 350,000 men of the Atlantic shield force in West Germany marked time in 1959. The result was little if any strengthening of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's defense wall in Europe and continue failure to attain build-up objectives.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Silver Creek Farm's Roman Colonel scored a hard-earned victory over Melpet Jr. today in the $10,000-added New Year's Handicap at Tropical Park before 15,551 racing fans.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Jan. 1 -- The first Democratic Supervisor of the Town of Huntington in twenty-six years took office today. At a reorganization meeting a short time later twenty-five Republican job-holders were dismissed.

Time had about run out before a contract settlement was reached in New York City's transit network, but a New Year's Day strike was again averted. The Transport Workers Union, led by Michael J. Quill, walked away from the bargaining table with a generous bundle of improvement in wages and benefits.
Policemen were attacked in different parts of the city early yesterday by New Year's Eve celebrants. One was beaten with his own nightstick, two were punched and another was shoved and kicked.

The staff of the Joint Economic Committee of Congress has completed its report on Employment, Growth and Price Levels. The committee doesn't identify itself with this document, but is working on its own report, which is expected to appear next month.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The news on the desecration of the Cologne synagogue, whose dedication was attended by Chancellor Konrad Adenauer only three months ago, rightly caused a healthy apprehension in a score of Government officials and in the people of Cologne.
COLRAIN, Mass., Jan. 1 -- This year has started out all wrong; the chances are that there will be nothing but famine around here. Times are hard when you can't even get a shot at a cottontail.

IT IS quite amazing what can be done with a cake, some frosting, a dusting of coconut and a good deal of imagination. The first three, plus a substitute for the last, are easily obtained. Those of us who lack the know-how for making unusual shapes out of a slab of cake can obtain it from a booklet called Animal Cut-Up Cakes, devised by the makers of Baker's coconut.

New African states are coming along at such a fast rate that the world is getting blase about them. Yet in some ways this tidal wave of freedom is one of the most significant and dramatic developments of our time.
The city's Housing Authority has asked Mayor Wagner for nearly $2,500,000 a year to operate its community-center program.
GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Max Bolkart of Germany outclassed the field today in winning an international ski jumping competition at this former Olympic site.

A method of turning out tungsten in large ingots, weighing as much as 200 pounds, has been devised by Dr. Paul Schwarzkopf, the powder metallurgist who is responsible for the development of multi-carbide hard metals used in tool materials and other major advances in metals.

IN fifteen thousand words, the reading of which constituted unusual therapy for New Year's morning, Attorney General William P. Rogers has fashioned an important document. Both for what it says and for what it doesn't.

IN the suburbs of the Rocky Mountains the Civil War was fought rather informally. There were, however, some spirited battles between the Confederate and Union forces and the fighting among and against the Indians proceeded with heightened ferocity.
The United Taxi Owners Guild is seeking permission for some of its 2,000 members to carry revolvers to ward off hold-up men. It will meet Monday night to form plans.

The Government's recent warnings about cranberries, hormone-treated chickens and candy colored with carbon black have caused the public "undue alarm," according to the editor of The Journal of the American Medical Association.
"FORTHRIGHT" is the word most commonly used when his friends are asked to describe Dr. John Harold Talbott, editor of The Journal of the American Medical Association. "Integrity" is a close second.

Net operating earnings of the Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association, the country's largest bank, cleared $86,297,920 in 1959, a record high. This compared with $77,018,825 in 1958, it reported yesterday.
CHICAGO, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Snow and cold ushered in the new year today. Blizzard conditions prevailed over a wide area of the Midwest and West.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Arkansas and Georgia Tech today cut short final workouts for their Gator Bowl football game tomorrow because of rain. A threat of showers for the game made Tech's weight advantage seem more imposing.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, called today for stern action against dealers in obscene and vulgar literature.
The sacrifice of holiday pleasures by children helped the fund for New York's Neediest Cases yesterday.

BOSTON, Jan. 1 (UPI) -- Bronco Horvath regained his scoring touch tonight and tallied his twenty-second and twenty-third goals of the season to pace the Boston Bruins to a 7-3 triumph over the New York Rangers.
KALIMPONG, India, Dec. 25 -- There is little joy among Kalimpong's 3,000 Tibetans as they face the new year.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Some nine months ago, when the New York State Legislature, upon the recommendation of Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller, passed a law granting all New York State employes an average of 5 per cent increase in salary, the Governor himself said there would be "no dancing in the streets" over the amount granted.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 1 -- Israel abolished today an export inducement device that had been criticized by the International Monetary Fund.
Deputy Mayor Paul T. O'Keefe yesterday derided proposals that had been made for abolishing the offices of the five Borough Presidents.
Plans for three new features have been made known here by Christian-Jaque, the French director. He is visiting this country to recruit American performers.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Mississippi punctured Louisiana State's once impregnable pass defense with three touchdown passes today for a 21-0 victory in the Sugar Bowl before 83,000 football fans.
NEW HAVEN, Jan. 1 -- Margaret Sullavan, the actress, was found unconscious in her room at the Taft Hotel today and was dead on arrival at Grace-New Haven Community Hospital. She was 48 years old.
DALLAS, Jan. 1 -- Syracuse's national champions, the first Orange football team to win all its games, became the first also to score a bowl victory today.

The Park Avenue Christian Church at Eighty-fifth Street, the oldest continuing congregation in the Disciples of Christ denomination, will begin tomorrow a year-long observance of its 150th anniversary.

PARIS, Jan. 1 -- Claude Maigrot, an eight-month-old baby, was in illustrious company today. He, President de Gaulle and Premier Michel Debre and seven other Cabinet Ministers were the first Frenchmen to receive the new 20-cent franc issued by the Bank of France.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- David M. Shoup, a fighting man, became commandant of the Marine Corps today. He also became a four-star general. The 55-year-old general distinguished himself in action against the Japanese at Tarawa, winning the Medal of Honor.
MOSCOW, Jan. 1 -- Premier Khrushchev declared in a toast to the New Year in the Kremlin early today that if the West did not agree to disarm, "maybe we will disarm unilaterally."

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 1 Premier Khrushchev's decision to visit Indonesia in February has taken the country by happy surprise. The announcement that he would arrive next month as a state guest was made today by the Foreign Minister.
A way in which high-tension living may act to raise the concentration of cholesterol and other fatty substances in a person's blood has been found by scientists at the National Heart Institute.

DETROIT, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The last-place Cincinnati Royals, sparked by Jack Twyman and Phil Jordon, checked the Boston Celtics' bid for a consecutive-game winning record by scoring a 128-115 victory tonight in a National Basketball Association game.
The nation's traffic death toll mounted last night toward a record for highway deaths on a three-day New Year's week-end.

PARIS. If the Forties of this century may be labeled the Atomic Decade and the Fifties that of Lunik, one migh venture on the birthday of the Sixties to call this the Decade of the Experts. For in the blinding light of our scientific revolution the straight way is lost.

MOSCOW, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The crew of the Soviet survey ship Ungo charged today that South Korean warship had made three night attacks on their vessel and killed a helmsman and wounded four sailors with a direct hit on the bridge.
GREENVILLE, S.C., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Fifteen Negroes protesting segregation staged an orderly demonstration in the white waiting room of the Greenville Municipal Airport today.
HARTFORD, Jan. 1 -- Connecticut's annual highway death toll dropped in 1959 for the fourth consecutive year since Governor Abraham A. Ribicoff instituted his anti-speeding campaign.

TROY, N.Y., Jan. 1 -- Scoring five goals in the first period, four in the second and six more in the last, the University of North Dakota hockey team routed Yale, 15 -- 0, in the second round of the ninth annual Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute hockey tournament tonight.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Jan. 1 -- A perfect sailing day brought out a record fleet of 112 boats today for the twenty-ninth annual frostbite regatta in the harbor of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club.
Close to Home Automation has hit close to home with the news that Our Town's Sanitation Department is experimenting with a device that in time may make the street sweeper obsolete.
ALBANY, Jan. 1 (AP) -- New York state's parole system is basically sound, but it needs some overhauling to fit modern conditions, a special committe said today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- A major defense debate is shaping up for the session of Congress beginning next Wednesday.

JOHANNESBURG, Union of South Africa, Dec. 31 -- The president of the Johannesburg Stock Exchange predicted today that business in South Africa would recover during 1960 from the recession that has plagued it during the last year.
CATASTROPHIC closets are not the exclusive prerogative of Fibber Magee. At this time of year, there is hardly a home without one.
HONG KONG, Jan. 1 -- High officials and a crowd of 20,000 braved subzero weather yesterday to celebrate the inauguration of train service at Hami in China's far northwest province of Sinkiang.

MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Form held today in the Orange Bowl Junior Cup tennis matches between nations. The United States defeated Venezuela, 3 -- 0; Spain defeated Belgium, 3 -- 0; South Africa defeated Great Britain, 3 -- 0, and Japan defeated Sweden, 2 -- 1.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Jet aircraft will dominate air transportation in 160, Federal Aviation Administrator E.R. Quesada predicted in a year-end statement.
NEWARK, Jan. 1 -- The Democratic-controlled Essex County Board of Chosen Freeholders refused today to revoke a $2,000-a-year increase in the salaries of its members.
LONDON, Jan. 1 -- The stock market here continued its advance today but the pace was more leisurely than has been the case lately.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 1 (UPI) -- One of the men in the Cleveland Browns-Pittsburgh Steelers deal said today he would try to sign with the Dallas Texans of the new American Football League.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 1 (UPI) -- Coach Duffy Daugherty's East Squad, loaded with all-America talent, is a one-touchdown favorite over the West tomorrow in the thirty-fifth annual Shrine all-star classic, a game played for the benefit of crippled children.
The Transport Workers Union and seven private bus companies reached an agreement early yesterday, thus completing the structure for two years of transit labor peace.

DALLAS, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Syracuse players, whooping it up after a bruising Cotton Bowl victory, said they had plenty of respect for Texas football play today but little use for the Long-horns' brand of sportsmanship.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has been forced to scale down or delay plans for manned space flight because of a tight budget and rising costs.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 1 (UPI) -- Margaretta defeated the favored Silver Spoon today in the $20,000-added Las Flores Handicap at Santa Anita before a crowd of 37,000.

The director of public relations in the British Information Services in New York, Major Cyril Berkeley Ormerod, was feted by a group of British and American friends at a luncheon here yesterday on the occasion of his inclusion in the British New Year's honors list.

The market for new capital is slated to return to high gear next Monday after a two-week holiday lay-off. Substantial requisitions by corporation and local government borrowers will compete with a variety of equity transactions for the money of investors.
WOULD-BE travelers with Christmas checks in their packets might enjoy browsing around the Globe-Trotter, an intriguing antiques shop at 1046 Madison Avenue (near Seventy-ninth Street).
Two leading shipping officials have taken the industry's protest against red tape to the White House.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- A New Yorker got a patent this week for an automatic bird feeder that feeds little birds but not big ones. It shuts its door in the face of anything as bulky as a bluejay, and a squirrel has no chance at all.

In the spring of 1941 Paul G. Hoffman, William Benton and Dr. Robert M. Hutching met on the University of Chicago campus and discussed a plan to organize a Committee for Economic Development. It was envisioned as a pool of business and academic brain power to meet the economic problems of wartime and postwar development.

Undefeated Tom McNeeley Jr. of Boston began the new year as he left off in 1959, a winner. The husky, blond, crew-cut youngster scored a fourth-round technical knockout over George Logan of Boise, Idaho, in the featured ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden last night.
PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 1 -- An aroused bunch of Washington Huskies pulled off one of the biggest surprises in the forty-six-year history of the Rose Bowl today.
A search for a formula to solve the metropolitan area's growing commuter railroad problem was listed high on its 1960 program, the Metropolitan Regional Council announced yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 2 -- This city on wheels has completed 1959 with one of the nation's brighter pedestrian-safety records.

Bobby Fischer, 16-year-old Brooklyn schoolboy, won the United States chess championship for the third time in succession at the Manhattan Chess Club last night.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 2 -- Don Meredith of Southern Methodist threw two touchdown strikes in the fourth quarter today to propel the West to a 21-14 upset victory over the East in the thirty-fifth annual Shrine football game.

A driving school that flunks substandard students has a waiting list that frequently is filled two months ahead.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Congress reconvenes Wednesday for an election-year session that may belatedly produce something at least remotely akin to the "cold war of partisan polltics" foreseen by President Eisenhower in a 1954 campaign speech.

The age of the Milky Way, the galaxy of which our solar system is an insignificant part, has been until recently estimated at 10 billion years. About eighteen months ago Prof. Fred Hoyle of Cambridge University, now a visiting professor at the California Institute of Technology and one of the authors of the hypothesis of continuous creation, presented evidence that the Milky Way was as much as 15 billion years old.

The cause of the death in New Haven last Friday of Margaret Sullavan, the actress, was still undetermined last night. However, James J. Corrigan, New Haven County Coroner, said that an autopsy had shown what he described as a "clinical picture consistent with barbiturate acid poisoning."
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 2 (AP) -- A top aide to Premier Kassim declared that pro-Western and Nasserist parties would be excluded from the new law permitting party activity.
PARIS, Jan. 2 -- Nazi swasikas and anti-Semitic inscripions have cropped up in the Pans subways and in a predominantly Jewish quarter of the city in the last few days.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 2 -- Gov. Orville L. Freeman of Minnesota predicted recently that "the nation's fifth seacoast" -- the Mississippi River -- would help the states through which it flows to share liberally in the next decade of anticipated national economic growth.

GEN. MAXWELL D. TAYLOR, who retired last June after four years as Chief of Staff of the Army, has rushed into print with a book reiterating his past condemnations of the United States policy of massive retaliation and the existing machinery for making strategic decisions.

The American Association for the Advancement of Science is the world's largest and most comprehensive scientific association, with 285 affiliated scientific societies having an aggregate membership exceeding 2,000,000. L'Atlantique and L'Essor, two nonprofit organizations that aid social welfare work and orphans in this country and in France, will gain as a result of the Gala de la Mediterranee. The fete will take place in the Grand Ballroom of the Astor Jan. 15.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 2 -- Calumet Farm's On-and-On scored a length victory over Modan Stable's Stratmat today in the $23,100 Orange Bowl Handicap at Tropical Park.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 2 -- Again operating under the theory that the best way to commemorate an event named after a brother is to win it, Art Tokle captured the fifteenth annual Torger Tokle memorial ski jump today.

A former Atomic Energy Commission scientist says he has perfected an inexpensive product that not only will melt snow but will prevent moderate falls of snow from accumulating on sidewalks.

THE television networks are looking feverishly for advertisers to pick up at least part of the tab for some of the news and public affairs programs that are being presented in the evening hours on which the broadcasters have always relied for their profits.

Men and women of German origin now in this country were called upon yesterday by a prominent New York rabbi to form a "German-Americans for Brotherhood" organization to protest the recent outbreaks of anti-Semitism in their homeland.
Mrs. Margaret Emerson, one of the last surviving social leaders of the gilded era preceding World War I, died yesterday at the age of 75.

LONDON, Jan. 2 -- An organization of young Conservatives called upon the British Government today to fix 1970 as the beginning of independence for Kenya.
Relief from the pressure of having to be happy during the holidays is beginning to brighten the lives of many persons who react violently against Christmas, according to a current medical journal.

Steel capacity increased slightly in the United States in 1959, despite the 116-day strike, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported last week. The addition of 937,300 net tons pushed capacity to a record of 148,570,970.

Herter had some words of caution for his fellow countrymen. Despite a "new atmosphere of hopefulness," he said, there has been no real change in Moscow's objective to win the world.

The East Side House Settlement will benefit from the sixth annual Winter Antiques Show, which will be open to the public at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-seventh Street, from Jan. 22 to 27.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2 -- Otto Haas, founder of the Rohm Haas Company, chemical manufacturers, died today at his home in suburban Villanova, two days after his retirement. He was 87 years old.

Resident buying offices were setting the stage last week for the start of the new year's spring showings this month. Preparations were in high gear for buying offices. They readied clinics to show additional spring lines and early summer merchandise to an expected heavy influx of buyers into this city, beginning tomorrow.

The curtain came down on the 1959 performance of the stock market last week with traders pleased about the year just ended and expecting another good one in 1960. Stocks finished 1959 on a fairly strong note after recovering from some unsettlement earlier in the week.

Vitamin B12 is found widely in nature and is essential to the nutrition of all animal species. It is present in all body cells but in instances of vitamin B12 deficiency the effects are reflected first by the bone marrow, where blood cells are formed.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UPI) -- The head of the nation's airline pilots accused the Federal Aviation Agency today of endangering lives through "petty, ridiculous harassment of flight crews."

BARELY PASSING -- Teaching is described as a "profession in which a premium is placed upon mediocrity" in a report completed recently by the New York State Department of Education. The Lincoln Square redevelopment has cost the Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul the Apostle a third of its members in a year's time, its pastor has told his parishioners in a year-end appeal for increased support.

In a Presidential campaign that even in its earliest stages has already produced one major surprise, the announcement of Senator John F. Kennedy's candidacy is the least surprising development conceivable. Young Mr. Kennedy has long been running for the Presidency with the coolness, determination and skill that have marked his political life since his first Congressional victory in 1946.
AUGUSTA, Me., Jan. 2 -- The death this week of Gov. Clinton A. Clauson returned the Maine governorship to Republican hands for the first time in five years.
New York's auction galleries, after a winter break at holiday time, will resume a full schedule of sales this week.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 2 (UPI) -- Neil S. McCarthy's Ole Fols raced to a length victory at Santa Anita today in the $27,250 Malibu Stakes for 4-year-olds.
DETROIT, Jan. 2 -- The Chrysler Corporation is using new telemetry techniques to study the behavior of moving vehicles in an effort to develop better performance and greater comfort.

The names of twenty-three editors and one cartoonist, the Pulitzer Prize jurors for 1960, were announced yesterday by Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University.

KIRYAT SANZ, Israel, Dec. 21 -- The "Master, Teacher and Rabbi" of some 3,000 Hassidic Jews in the United States, Rabbi Solomon Leib Halberstam of Brooklyn, now resides here.

All through the holiday season Mrs. Henry J. Heinz 2d says she has felt more or less like Scrooge. As chairman of the second Spoleto Festival of Two Worlds Ball scheduled for Friday night, she has had to keep her committees working when they have had so many other things on their minds.

THE second stamp in the American Credo series is to be brown and green on white, conveying one of Benjamin Franklin's "Poor Richard's Almanack" sayings, "Fear to do ill, and you will fear nought else.'
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The Arabs prefer to call the Persian Gulf the Arab Gulf. In terms of actual power, British Gulf would be more accurate.

The slim, youthful, pipe smoking director now is officially set to direct the movie version of Dore Schary's hit drama, "Sunrise at Campo-bello," which he originally staged on Broadway.
VIENNA, Jan. 2 -- The only synagogue in Vienna was desecrated in the early hours of this morning.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Jan. 2 -- With little more than a year left on the timetable for completing major sections of the Niagara power project, contractors are using special processes for pouring concrete in sub-freezing temperatures.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Vice President Nixon's suggestion that Republican Vice-Presidential aspirants seek opportunities to test their vote-getting strength is regarded here as an interesting but not very practical idea.

ALBANY, Jan. 2 -- A task force named by Governor Rockefeller last June to study the state's power needs and resources has recommended joint development of nuclear power by private utility systems.

Retailers in this area ended 1959 on a happy note. Sales for the holiday-shortened week posted a good gain. Leading store executives estimated volume as 5 per cent ahead of the comparable period a year ago. Widespread store clearances and promotions spurred sales.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 1 -- African countries in 1960 can expect more attention and also tangible assistance from the United Nations and its related agencies. Increased aid will go also to needy nations in Asia and Latin America.

IT hardly seems possible but "Cher Papa" concerns a teenaged girl who is not precocious, not morbidly curious about sex, not planning to elope with a middle-aged man just for kicks. Franzie, the heroine of "Cher Papa" is 17 and -- fasten your seat belts -- she is in love.

THIS pungent, shapely and instructive novel begins, and for the first half continues, comically. Billy Fisher, an ambitious and mendacious teenager in the Yorkshire town of Stradhoughton, describes his progress through one critical Saturday.

CHARLES DARWIN published his classic work on evolution in 1859: a historic fact to which considerable publicity has been given. Darwin centenary committees have been successful in their efforts at commemoration, so that few of us are now ignorant of what Darwin wrote and when.

LITTLE FERRY, N.J., Jan. 2 -- The president of three commuter bus lines that were struck on New Year's Day told Local 225 of the Transport Workers Union today that the strike can continue just as long as it wants it to.

THE Roman god, Janus, was singularly equipped. He was able to look forward and backward at the same time because he had two faces. Yet a soothsayer with a foggy brain can sometimes see through the fog.
