PROBABLY not one person in ten this past New Year's concerned himself with making the traditional resolutions. Along with cold showers, calisthenics before breakfast, the memorizing of Kipling's "If" and similar practices aimed at self-improvement, it is a tradition gone from most homes today.
Newsstand workers in the metropolitan area struck last night against the Union News and Garfield News Companies.
IT took the Metropolitan Opera a long time to get around to "Macbeth," but it appears determined to give the most powerful opera of Verdi's early years a chance to find a firm place in the repertory.
THIS boy, Paul, lives in New Jersey and his profession explains why grown men can make a fine living raising and selling fishing worms to people fully able to dig them. Paul is a toad merchant.

Steel: 23 Days to Go Secretary of Commerce Frederick H. Mueller last week presented a glowing economic report on 1959. Total output rose to a record $478 billion, compared with the previous high of $452 billion in '57.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 2 (AP) -- All thirty-seven members of the crew of the American freighter Valley Forge were believed safe today after the ship had broken up on a reef in the South China Sea during a severe storm.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., Jan. 2 -- Panelists on a radio broadcast, "Life in Suburbia," agreed tonight that it wasn't the amount of time fathers spent at home but the way they spent it that was important in creating a happy home.
Exaggerated claims in advertising for aluminum siding -- such as "the factory-applied finish will last indefinitely" -- have come under attack by the paint industry, which manufactures the finishes.

KENSINGTON, L.I., Jan. 3 Sheltered behind an elaborate Georgian gate residents of this village are observing the fiftieth aniversary of a community at has remained relatively unmanged amid the bustle of rgeoning suburbia.

CONTRACT bridge is called a game of the "whist family." This family of games began, at least as early as 1500, with a game called triumph, which meant the same as the present word trump. Later games of the family often derived their names from features that perhaps at the time were new: ruff; ruff-and-honour; slamm.

IN March, 1946, Edmund Wilson's second book of fiction (aside from drama) was published, well reviewed, and bought by almost 60,000 people. It was called "Memoirs of Hecate County," and it contained among many other things, several vivid scenes of sexual commerce between men and women, which in part may explain the sales figures, It certainly explains why the Society for the Suppression of Vice brought suit against Doubleday, the then publisher in July, 1946.

The proposed public offering of stock in the enterprises of William J. Levitt, the nation's best-known home builder, focuses attention on the growing trend of broad financing for construction ventures.
CHICAGO, Jan. 2 -- What are the qualities of a good President?

The state of Israel is bitterly protesting the exclusion of Israeli cargoes from the Suez Canal by the United Arab Republic. Israeli resentment is all the greater because the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development has granted a $56,500,000 loan to Cairo for widening and deepening the canal. This was done only three days after the Greek freighter Astypalea had been stopped at Port Said because her cargo contained a shipment of Israeli-made cement.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 2 -- An American pilot facing a double death sentence on charges of having flown for Indonesian rebels in 1958 side-stopped today when a military judge asked whether he was "guilty or not."

The closing drive of 1959 is carrying over into 1960. A new decade promises to bring even more progress than the one just ended, and this could prove to be no small accomplishment, since great strides were made in the Nineteen Fifties.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 2 -- The New York Knickerbockers scored a 126-118 National Basketball Association victory today when the Cincinnati Royals fell apart in the last six minutes. The Royals had a lead of 113-110 when they hit a cold Shooting streak.
PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 2 -- The future looked rosy indeed today to Coach Jim Owens, whose Washington Huskies walloped Wisconsin, 44 -- 8, in the Rose Bowl.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 2 -- Clearing of the site for a tenstory University Health Center and office building for Harvard University will begin early this month.
LONDON, Jan. 2 -- The British Government approaches the summit conference in a more optimistic mood than either the Administration in Washington or President de Gaulle's regime in Paris.
FOR jazz recording, 1959 was a year of culminations, of backward glances and peeps into the future. All of these elements can be found on disks released the year came to an end.
Banks across the nation will begin this week to report record operating earnings for 1959.
What happens to international air fares on April 1?
In the art world, the New Year will get off to a lively start this week as many galleries open new one-man and group shows.

The Bethlehem Steel Company has announced the retirement of George Brown as manager of the company's shipyard in Hoboken. He will be succeeded by Charles J. Tiedemann, who had been assistant manager of the Hoboken yards.

MEMBERS of the audience aren't the only ones who line up vehemently for or against modern music. So do the performers. While a member of the audience may say that he will have to hear a new work several times before he knows how thoroughly he dislikes it, the player is a captive audience, not once but many times.

ORLANDO, Fla. -- That old bugaboo of the motoring tourist, the sign that reads "No Vacancies," is likely to become a collector's item in this central Florida city and its next-door neighbor, Winter Park.

MIAMI BEACH -- A familiar outcry of vacationing parents, one that goes something like "Yeah, but what are we gonna to do with the kids?", appears to have been reduced to a faint whisper at this Gold Coast resort.
The last Brooklyn link in the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway will be forged Tuesday.

THE car noses its way through the thick traffic of downtown Johannesburg, past the flattopped ochre hills that mark the "golden reef" on which the city stands, and out beyond the industrial slums that divide the "white" areas from the African locations where the native labor of Johannesburg's mines and factories must live.

Trans-Canacla Air Lines carried more than 3,100,000 passengers in 1959, the first time in its twenty-two years it topped the three million mark. Gordon R. McGregor, president, reported the gain in the line's annual review, made public last week.
Tax experts looking at the Internal Revenue Service's new expense account reporting requirements for businesses have concluded that they are aimed at the few, not the many.

Week Ended Dec. 31, 1959 Foreign exchange market closed out the year with a mixed trend. British pound sterling showed a firmer undertone as the Canadian dollar turned to the softer side. Business transacted was heavy at times.

ONE of the oldest Spanish American restaurants in the city has moved to new head quarters downtown at 82 Beaver Street, corner of Pearl Street El Patio was opened in 1850 It has been in continuous operation ever since, although its ownership and its name have changed several times.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- A Public Health Service conference opens here tomorrow on metropolitan planning for city hospital construction.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- A Congressional fight was in the making today over a special housing program designed to halt a further decline in residential construction.
LONDON, Jan. 3 -- For Britain the old year ended with a boom in full swing and the new one opened on a note of general optimism.
" Le Sacre du Printemps" is a frequent visitor in our concert halls but until late yesterday afternoon New York had not heard it conducted by its composer in twenty years.

The Bethlehem Day Nursery at 249 East Thirtieth Street, which has been caring for neighborhood children in the 3to-6-age group for seventy-eight years, will be aided by the proceeds of a theatre benefit next Monday.

WHEN William Black, Columbia '26, called on President Grayson Kirk to offer the university $5,000,000, his return to Morningside Heights evoked memories of student days when he counted his financial resources in cents.
Physical and operating changes in the St. Lawrence Seaway have been recommended by American-flag shipping men.
William Goetz, the motion picture producer, will supervise two Biblical dramas to be filmed in Israel for presentation next season on the American Broadcasting Company television network.

Richard Schulze, conductor and recorder player of the Telemann Society, opened yesterday afternoon's Theodore Thomas Commemoration Concert at Town Hall with a report on latest efforts to save Carnegie Hall from demolition.

The Swedish national basketball team, still hopeful of meeting an American quintet despite the cancellation of its ten-game tour here, was scheduled to leave by bus for Hartwick College, Oneonta, N.Y., this morning.
LONDON, Jan. 3 -- British married women are going out to work in ever-increasing numbers, but they do not regard themselves as career women.

MOSCOW, Jan. 3 -- In the vast subarctic tundras of Eastern Siberia, newly discovered diamond deposits are being worked. Soviet geologists say that one day they will become the largest producer of industrial diamonds in the world.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- A serious effort will be made soon to get former President Harry S. Truman to support the Senate majority leader, Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas, for the Democratic Presidential nomination.
VADUZ, Liechtenstein. Jan. 3 (UPI) -- To ski or not to ski at the Olympics in America next month. That was the political question today in Liechtenstein.
Joseph E. Seagram Sons, Inc., has taken another step in its advertising agency realignment.

The Rev. Dr. John Heuss, rector of Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church at Broadway and Wall Street, said yesterday that a Roman Catholic "has just as much right to become President as any other well-qualified citizen."

GENEVA, Jan. 3 (Reuters) -- Ships of the future may sail from the North Sea down to the Black Sea and up again to the Baltic if plans being discussed for the intcrnationalization of Europe's inland waterways materialize.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 3 -- This Buddhist kingdom is now under control of the Laotian army. But the army denies that it has carried out a coup.
A two-day, round-the-clock search by co-producer Martin Gabel to fill the starring role in "Sweet Love Remember'd" ended yesterday in his own home with the signing of his wife, Arlene Francis.
Somewhat higher ground was achieved last week by prices of cotton futures in the domestic market.
Since World War II, Africa has been swept by change at a rate that has accelerated notably in the last four years. Between Jan. 1, 1956, and Dec. 31, 1959, six new nations emerged.

GOTBBORG, Sweden, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The East German flag was raised today on the 12,396ton Atlantic liner Stockholm. The ship, which once sailed between Goteborg and New York, has been sold by the SwedishAmerican Line to East Germany, which plans to use it for cruises in the Mediterannean and the Black Sea.
The weekly earnings of factory workers in the city rose 40 per cent in the last decade, while prices went up 24.2 per cent. Both prices and earnings had reached highs by the end of 1959.

Looking like anything but a last-place team, the New York Rangers snapped a four-game losing streak by walloping Montreal Canadiens, 8 to 3 in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

Dr. Leona Baumgartner, the city's Health Commissioner, said in a television interview last night that her department was cooperating with the schools in an attempt to persuade pupils never to start smoking.
Moscow. THE Russian taxi driver looked at the plaid rectangular box as we stepped from the house and began to open the car trunk.

When we speak of the TVA we mean the Tennessee Vailey Authority and not that entertainment gadget that so many of us have in our homes. When we say that TVA grows, as it has been doing, we don't mean that it has been spreading geographically, but only that it has been putting out more power.
Henry Goelet, realty investor and builder, has contracted to buy the Cockroft Building, a sixteen-story office structure at the northwest corner of John and Nassau Streets.

MADRID, Jan. 3 -- Monarchists in Spain, including Cabinet ministers and other high officials, are seriously perturbed by signs of a rift developing between Generalissimo Francisco Franco, chief of state, and Don Juan, the 44-year-old Count of Barcelona and pretender to the throne.
The nation's first-ranked team, Cincinnati now owns the longest basketball winning streak among the major colleges. No longer does California, the National Collegiate champion, have that distinction.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Jan. 3 -- Last Thursday, the closing session of 1959, the stock exchange dealings here suddenly became turbulent. Volume exceeded all normal limits. Many stock prices soared to new peaks. "At least for Swiss stocks," said one Zurich banker, "Thursday was without precedent in history."
One thousand recordings of news from The New York Times are being pressed in Bridgeport, Conn., today as the firsts in a weekly series for blind persons.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I. Jan. 3 -- Arthur Knapp Jr. of Larchmont won the Sam Wetherall Plate as the outstanding skipper in the twentyninth annual frostbite regatta without having to sail a single race today.

PARIS. Many Americans are genuinely puzzled by French resentment over our North African policy. They simply don't understand why such things as abstentions in U.N. votes or platitudinous communiques on friendship with Arab states inspire furious anger here.
The Women's City Club "has recommended to Governor Rockefeller that separate conservation work camps be established for delinquent youths in the l6-to-21 and 21-to 25 age groups.
The fatal shooting of a man and the injuring of a companion on the lower East Side early yesterday was said to have stemmed from a New Year's Eve beating given to the dead man's brother.
Governor Rockefeller contem plated withdrawing from the competition for the Republican Presidential nomination at least four weeks before he did so.
BUFFALO, Jan. 3 (AP) -- A 77-year-old man was charged today with the New Year's slaying of a Roman Catholic priest from whom he earlier had received communion.
Food prices should remain stable in 1960 and help hold inflation in check, according to Ralph W. Burger, president and chairman of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif, Jan. 3 -- The selection of Bob Hope as master of ceremonies for the movie industry's annual Oscarawards program is the first sign that Arthur Freed is determined to make the event a worth-while show that will move along quickly, entertainingly and in good taste.
Wagner's "Der Fliegende Hollaender," ("The Flying Dutchman") will return to the Metropolitan Opera on Wednesday, Jan. 13, for the first time since the season of 1950-51.

City Councilman Stanley M. Isaacs expressed doubt yesterday that Manhattan Borough President. Hulan E. Jack had voted three times in the Board of Estimate against a Harlem slum clearance project in which Sidney J. Ungar, the real estate operator, was interested.

An account of refugee relief over the world since the end of World War II is given by Dr. Edgar H.S. Chandler in "The High Tower of Refuge." The author, who is director of the World Council of Churches Refugee Service, describes all that his organization and others are doing to aid the millions of men, women and children who are waiting for admission to any country that will have them.
Invoking the name of Jesus was urged yesterday by the Rev. Oscar V. Lynch as a means of overcoming serious temptations. He preached at the 10 A.M. solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

DETROIT, Jan. 3 (UPI) -- John McKenzie scored his sixth goal of the season with less than two minutes remaining tonight to give a 4-3 victory to the Detroit Red Wings over the Boston Bruins. The triumph enabled the Wings to remain in a tie for second place with the Toronto Maple Leafs in the Rational Hockey League.
William Black, president of the Chock Full O' Nuts Corporation, yesterday gave $5,000,000 to Columbia University toward the construction of a medical research building.
THREE judges and a lawyer took part yesterday in a congenial discussion on "Small World" on channel 2.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 3 (UPI) -- Clyde Lovellette tied his professional career high of 37 points today in leading the St. Louis Hawks to a 110-108 National Basketball Association victory over the New York Knickerbockers.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I would appreciate an opportunity to comment on a letter by Edgar R. Fiedler published on Dec. 22. In his letter Mr. Fiedler comments on the Nelson Commission proposal to raise the minimum wage in New York City to $1.50 an hour.
ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- The 183d annual session of the New York Legislature will convene at noon on Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts challenged his potential rivals for the Democratic Presidential nomination again today to fight it out in the primaries.

The last tangible reminder in New York City of the Trolley Dodgers, that fabulous group that clowned and cavorted and sometimes played baseball, it Brooklyn for forty-four years, is to be given over to the wreckers this summer.
MOSCOW, Jan. 3 -- President Eisenhower's decision to reserve the right to resume the testing of nuclear weapons continues to be treated with restraint here.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- A cartoon on the front page of The Daily Express pictured a plump German dusting the tunic of an S.S. uniform. The caption was from Heinrich Heine: "A tale of long ago that I cannot get out of my mind."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The Justice Department reported today that it had brought more antitrust cases in 1959 than in any year since 1942.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 3 -- Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam of the Methodist Church questioned tonight whether Senator John F. Kenedy could be "free of Roman Catholic hierarchical control" if he were elected President.

The Park Department is taking steps to accept the historic Perkins family estate of Riverdale as a gift. The land, overlooking the Hudson River, will be maintained as an arboretum known as the Perkins Garden.

WHEN Warren Spahn of the Braves achieved victory No. 267 last season he became the winningest lefthander in the history of the National League. Whose record did he break? It's a question that can be answered only by the most rabid baseball fans. The chances are that the casual sports follower never heard of Eppa Jeptha Rixey.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- What do economists do at the end of four days of dissecting each other's brains and brainwork? They jam themselves into a hotel meeting room that's too small and too hot, and listen to a pair of widely respected colleagues discuss how they influence and are influenced.

Newborg Co. has announced that F.A. Morgan Easton, with the concern since 1905, has retired as a general partner and become a limited partner. Melvin T. Kafka, a limited partner, has become a general partner.
MOSCOW, Jan. 3 -- Premier Khrushchev pledged in an interview made public today that the Soviet Union would not resume testing of nuclear weapons unless the West did.

A black cocker spaniel, Ch. Clarkdale Capital Stock, was proclaimed best in show yesterday at the Roosevelt Hotel in the forty-third national specialty and obedience trial of the American Spaniel Club.

An orchestra from the Soviet Union played for the first time in the United States last night. The Moscow State Symphony, here as part of the American-Soviet cultural exchange, began a seven-week American tour at Carnegie Hall with a smashing public success.
BILOXI, Miss., Jan. 3 -- A Federal grand jury investigation into the lynching of Mack Charles Parker, a Negro, will open here tomorrow amid growing national pressure for new civil-rights legislation.

The ways of wind, weather and water in the Persian Gulf are being charted through the cooperative effort of a group of international oil companies operating in that area -- one of the centers of world petroleum production.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- With an eye on the November Presidential election, Democrats are preparing for a fast start and a sustained brisk pace in the Congresaional session that convenes Wednesday.

VIENNA, Jan. 2 -- Communist leaders in Eastern Europe seem to be taking extra precautions against any domestic dissidence that might be stimulated by an agreement between the United States and the Soviet Union to lessen world tension.
The visit of the Three Wise Men of the Orient to the Infant Jesus in Bethlehem was reenacted here yesterday for Spanish-speaking Roman Catholic and Protestant congregations.
The City Planning Commission's proposed resolution to overhaul zoning regulations was denounced yesterday by a body of professional engineers.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Planning must begin now at all levels of government to prevent unnecessary economic hardship if disarmament is achieved, the National Planning Association warned today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The two letters appearing in The New York Times of Dec. 16 and 26, concerning the Presidential decree banning foreign retail trade in Indonesian rural areas, need comment to avoid any misunderstanding.
Two gifts in memory of Americans who served in Korea aided the fund for New York's Neediest Cases yesterday.
The Mayor's Committee on Slum Clearance is in a state of semi-paralysis, waiting for the fall of an axe In the guise of the Panuch report.
National Merit Scholarship winners have justified the faith placed in their academic promise.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Jan. 3 -- The big basketball game at Peekskill Military Academy this year will be between the varsity and faculty. One thing is certain. The faculty isn't taking the game lightly.

The leasehold of the 600room Towers Hotel at 25 Clark Street in the Heights section of Brooklyn has been sold by the Spencer-Taylor hotel chain. The lease, at rentals aggregating more than $3,000,000, was bought by a syndicate of investors headed by Jules Zeif.
NEW VERNON, N.J., Jan. 3 -- Consternation has swept this idyllic countryside.
A report on an experiment in Cleveland with private construction of cooperative housing for former slum dwellers is to be published here today.
Anniversaries are a dime a dozen, but when any company in the mutual fund business is able to celebrate its thirty-fifth birthday. it has a right to crow.
Total disarmament might appear feasible to some theorists but not yet to practical seekers for peace, in the opinion of most student panelists appearing on The New York Times Youth Forum yesterday.
LONDON, Jan. 3 -- Swastikas have been drawn on three Jewish buildings here and some of their windows smashed in the last twenty-four hours. Similar incidents occurred last week.

The death toll on the nation's highways climbed last night toward a new record for the threeday New Year's week-end as the homeward rush of holiday travelers brought a heavy rash of traffic accidents.

Although the United States chess championship was clinched by Bobby Fischer of Brooklyn Saturday night, his last game with Samuel Reshevsky commanded a full house yesterday at the West Side Y.M.C.A. The result was a draw in forty moves, the offer being made by the youthful champion.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 3 -- New Government directives on the question "What Is a Jew?" were issued in Jerusalem today by Interior Minister Moshe Shapiro.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- If East-West exchanges are accomplishing nothing else, they seem to be popularizing that old Scottish, and now bourgeois, game of golf in the Soviet Union.
A peace plan sponsored by Vice President Nixon and Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell stirred hopes early today for a speedy steel settlement.
BEDFORD, N.Y., Jan. 3 -- Geoffrey Craig was the big winner at the Sunnyfield Farm horse show today.

HONG KONG, Jan. 1 -- While austerity and a "greater leap forward" in production were the keynotes of Communist China's entrance into the New Year, the promise of at least one consumer pleasure was dangled before the eyes of the populace.
SPARTA, N.J., Jan. 3 (AP) -- Two men skating on Lake Mohawk today plunged through thin ice and drowned after one had tried to save the other.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The Arab-Israeli conflict is quiescent now, overshadowed by President Gamal Abdel Nasser's quarrel with Premier Abdul Karim Kassim and by East West issues. Yet the conflict between Arabs and Israelis is still the most fundamental rift in the Middle East.

New health problems arising from the city's changing population and "explosive high birth rates" have produced an "urgent need" for more facilities and trained personnel, the Department of Health said yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Grain futures dealers looked hard and long last week for market influences without finding anything new, while prices shifted generally within small fractions on technical trade considerations.

AN exceptionally detailed and sensitive performance by Teresa Wright lent stature to last night's dramatization of Margaret Bourke-White's struggle against Parkinson's disease. The play, written by Joseph Liss, was seen on "Sunday Showcase" over Channel 4.
Representative Adam ClayClayton Powell Jr. declared yesterday that thirteen Italians were running numbers games in Harlem because the police there arrested only Negro numbers bankers.
TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 3 -- Iran formally laid claim today to half of the Shatt al Arab, the boundary river that is at the heart of her dispute with Iraq.

IT is an old truth that much of the personal sorrow and misfortune in an unhappy world is not caused by malicious intent and deliberate ill will. People with the very beat intentions sometimes destroy themselves and others merely through weakness and self-doubt, through vacillation and avoidance of decisions. They may be honorable and intelligent and respon- ible -- as Wilder Stone was.

IF a man asks you to hop in his oomiak or come up for some knpiak, you'll know you're in Alaska or that he' just came from there. Oomiak is the Alaskan word for the large Eskimo walrus-skin boat and knpiak the word for coffee, according to Robert G. Hart.

Expansion programs slated to cost $200,000,000 were announced over the week-end by three utilities. The largest calls for the American Electric Power System to spend $112,000,000. Completion of this project will increase the system's capital outlays since World War II to more than $1,400,000,000.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 3 (AP) -- A bitter surrender of the Minneapolis-St. Paul territory by the new American Football League left a clear field today for the National League to put a franchise in the Twin Cities for 1960.
At the end of 1953 the most widely consulted of all indices of American business trends underwent its first major revision since World War II.

When Congress reassembles day after tomorrow it will have to deal with several problems it might prefer to postpone, including civil rights. With a Republican in the White House and Democratic majorities on Capitol Hill this Presidential year is more than usually baffling; it is baffling for both parties, and especially when the subject of civil rights comes up, for the party that counts on carrying Mississippi as well as the City of New York.
Two more Jewish temples in the city were found yesterday to have been painted with swastikas.
Joseph Zaretzki, minority leader of the State Senate, warned yesterday that the Democrats would oppose any reorganization proposal reducing the authority of the Controller.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- An accelerated water resources program was recommended in a 174-page report by a Senate Interior and Public Works subcommittee issued today.

Some Small Mysteries of Life Life from season to season, week to week and day to day is filled with small mysteries. This, for example, is a week pretty much like any other week; one perhaps has hoped that it would turn out to be just a little better than some other weeks.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3 (UPI) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs scored three times in the third period tonight and beat the Chicago Black Hawks, 4 -- 0. The Leaf goalie, Johnnie Bower posted, his fourth shutout of the season.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 3 -- Alto Lark led the New York Tuck Tapers to a 130-115 victory over the Seattle Bakers tonight in a National Industrial Basketball League game at the Westchester County Center.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 3 -- Steel users enter the new year with misgivings about the adequacy of their supplies. Although the flow of finished steel is mount ing it still wasn't enough last week to calm fears of shortages.
A port record for a two-day winter period will be set today as the last of 8,700 ship passengers arrive here.

Mayor Wagner's task of preparing a balanced and an adequate expense budget for the fiscal year starting July 1 has been made more difficult because of commitments to subsidize transit operations and to repeal the 10-cent tax on taxicab rides.

The Chesapeake and Ohio Railway, the first in the industry to issue its 1959 income statement, reported yesterday a dip in net income to $46,000,000 from $52,000,000 in recession-hit 1958. On a common share basis, earnings were $5.60, down from $6.36.

THE exclusiveness of baseball's Hall of Fame is its greatest strength. Gaining admittance is just a trifle easier than squeezing a camel through the eye of a needle. Another election is in the offing, one for the so-called "moderns," those heroes whose careers lasted beyond 1930. The Baseball Writers Association will do the balloting and, if past performances are any criterion, no one will be elected.
Dr. Edward V. Sittler, former Nazi radio propagandist, moved again yesterday to recover his American citizenship. He was removed last month from the faculty of Post College of Long Island University.

Svetozar Gligoric, international grandmaster from Yugoslavia, defeated Dr. Karl Burger of Brooklyn in the fifth round of the annual masters' tournament at the Hastings Chess Congress yesterday and took first place, according to a London report.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The Government had to pay more than 5 per cent on its regular weekly issue of six-month bills today for the first time. The average yield on both the sixmonth, or 182-day, bills and the companion issue of ninety-one day bills rose, presumably influenced by the steel settlement.

NASHVILLE, Jan. 4 (UPI) -- The subject of integration is expected to come before the legislative sessions of five Southern and border states during the first half of 1960, according to Southern School News.

The group of professional engineers that has criticized the proposal to amend New York City's zoning regulations was invited yesterday to discuss it with the City Planning Commission, sponsor of the proposal.
Sales and earnings of the Michigan Seamless Tube Company in the fiscal year ended Oct. 31 were the highest in its thirty-two-year history, William A. McHattie, president, reported yesterday.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 4 (AP) -- "There's no better way to start the new year."
The Kaiser Industries Corporation announced yesterday that negotiations had been completed for the acquisition of the National Steel and Shipbuilding Corporation of San Diego.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- In conjunction with the wholesale furnishings show, the Merchandise Mart is exhibiting a model room with ideas that every space-hungry American family ordinarily would be enthusiastic about.

The Friedgen Pharmacy, a Morningside Heights landmark for fifty-seven years, will close its doors at the end of the month. This means that Matilda, a stuffed goat, will have to find a new home.

ONEONTA, N.Y., Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Swedish national basketball team is suing the Amateur Athletic Union for $5,000 because of the A.A.U. order that canceled its scheduled games against college teams in the United States.

Continental Bulk Service, Inc., a public carrier of industrial and commercial fluids, has taken a long-term lease on a one-story building on a one-acre site on Wilson Avenue near Hyatt Street in Newark, N.J. The transaction was negotiated by Robert E. Baumgarten of Houston, Settle Co., brokers.

Aggressive trade and commission house buying and short covering advanced prices of potato futures yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Hedge selling and profit taking supplied the contracts. Final prices were up 4 to 7 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 1,531 car lots.
Ernest Marples, Britain's Minister of Transport, arrived here yesterday for a seventeen-day study of road traffic, parking and express highways in Los Angeles, Chicago, Washington and Baltimore.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- There was general agreement here tonight that the steel strike settlement was definitely inflationary in at least one important respect: It has greatly inflated Vice President Nixon's political stock.
TAMPA, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Mike Davies and Don Candy had little trouble disposing of their opponents today as the thirtythird annual Dixie International tennis tournament opened.
DETROIT, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The automobile industry started the new year today aiming to build almost 700,000 cars this month, a record.

BUFFALO, Jan. 4 (AP) -- David J. McDonald, president of the United Steelworkers of America, told a rally of more than 5,000 tonight that the agreement reached with the steel industry was 40 per cent better than the companies' last offer.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Dec. 24 -- Reduced United States aid has slowed the process of improving Nationalist China's ground forces.
RABAT, Morocco, Jan. 4 -- The United States and Morocco have concluded an agreement under which the Voice of America transmitter will be able to operate in Tangier until the end of 1963.

LONDON, Jan. 4 -- Queen Elizabeth II approved today the names of fourteen Britons who will serve under Sir Henry Urmston Willink as members of a Royal Commission inquiring into the police and its relations with the public.

A COUPLE of the darnedest questions are suggested by two art shows that opened yesterday, one of them an exhibition of three sculptors at the Zabriskie Gallery, 32 East Sixty-fifth Street, and the other an exhibition of collages near-by at the Sagittarius Gallery, 777 Madison Avenue near Sixty-sixth.
ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- Governor Rockefeller's proposal for a state minimum wage of $1 an hour, if enacted, would mark the first time that Now YorkState has had a general minimum wage law.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 4 (UPI) -- Following is a chronology of the steel-contract dispute:

BONN, Germany, Jan. 4 -- An international investigation is under way into charges that Theodor Oberlaender, West German Refugee Minister, took part in a massacre of Ukrainian prisoners eighteen years ago.
One of the country's most experienced advertising men thinks that people are not making enough use of the accumulated advertising wisdom of the past.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Vice President Nixon, lately revealed as the offstage conductor of mediation in the steel dispute, was drawn into the controversy in the first place by the president of the United Steelworkers, David J. McDonald.
The nation's two largest independent sales finance companies borrowed a total of $125,000,000 yesterday in the public market at the same interest cost -- 5.32 per cent.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 4 -- A wealthy doctor and his former receptionist went on trial in Superior Court today on charges of murdering his estranged wife because she obstructed their romance.

Mrs. Whitehouse Walker, chairman, has announced that the Feb. 23, 24 and 25 performances of the off-Broadway musical "Little Mary Sunshine" at the Orpheum Theatre will benefit the Green Acres Family Camp, a project of the New York City Mission Society.
Twelve city agencies asked for 1960-61 departmental allocations yesterday that would total $225,788 more than their present allocations of $5,721,227.

THE term variety meats may have a grim, penny-pinching sound, at least for those who remember World War II rationing. Often at that time the only choice at the butcher's was scrawny chickens or the so-called organ meats, the latter rather untidily displayed.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- For the first time in American history women voters are expected to outnumber men in electing a President next fall.
The Court of Appeals in Albany has said that the Patriarchate of the Russian Orthodox Church in Moscow is an agency of the Soviet Government rather than an independent religious body.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your Dec. 28 editorial on pedestrian deaths, as well as the Traffic Department's analysis are both interesting, but provide no solution to the problem of mass murder on the city streets. Any real solution can only come with a complete reversal of our mental, moral and ethical approach to this situation.
FRANKLIN LAKES, N.J., Jan. 4 -- The New Jersey Audubon Society, founded in 1910, will mark its golden anniversary this year.

TOKYO, Jan. 4 -- Japan's newest major political party, a moderate Socialist grouping, has come out in favor of retaining a military alliance with the United States until the international situation eases.
ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- Governer Rockefeller will urge the 1960 Legislature to authorize a limited easing of last year's tax increase program.

Steel prices will not be raised "in the immediate future," several top steel executives declared yesterday after reaching agreement with union representatives on a new wage contract. However, they left the door open for price increases later, after higher production costs and other factors have been assayed.
LONDON, Jan. 4 -- An aroused Briton warned today that the noise that pounds increasingly against the eardrums of humans in an advanced society may turn them one day into a race of "shouting maniacs."

The Presidential aspirations of the Senate majority leader, Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas, were regarded with some pessimism yesterday at the fiftieth annual meeting of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
Victims of Nazi persecution were remembered yesterday two gifts to the fund for New York's Neediest Cases.
ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- School-finance needs are providing the ammunition for a major impending political battle over state fiscal and tax policy.

Combined net operating earnings of The First National City Bank of New York and its trust affiliate amounted to $47,962,000, or $5.66 a share, last year, compared with $60,274,000, or $5.02 a share, in 1958.
PARIS, Jan. 4 -- There were at work today in France some 40,000,000 calculating machines -- all human, all fallible and apparently all bad-humored.

Enough time has passed now to make it clear that the attempt to overthrow the Stroessner Government in Paraguay has been a failure. Technically speaking, it did not deserve to succeed. It was poorly organized, ill equipped and without any significant social program or internal support.

TULSA, Okla., Jan. 4 (UPI) -- The nation's youngest Governor, Hawaii's first Congressmen and men in the space field were in the list of the ten outstanding young men of 1959 announced today by the United States Junior Chamber of Commerce.

Powerful forces shaped the literary character of Albert Camus, who was killed yesterday in an automobile crash. These forces included poverty and injustice in his native Algeria, communism, service with the French resistance movement in World War II, the cold outer darkness of existentialism and, finally, the saving grace of a new-found faith in life.
United States Government securities occupied the most sensitive spot the bond market yesterday.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 4 (AP) -- Pineapple, under a hustling ride by Bill Hartack, beat Effendi by a head to win today's featured seventh race at Tropical Park before 9,661 fans.
When the Nineteen Sixties are mentioned these days, adjectives abound. The new decade has been dubbed the "soaring sixties," the "fabulous sixties" and the "golden sixties."
LONDON, Jan. 4 -- Strong demand lifted industrial share prices to a new record in the stock market here today.
CHICAGO, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The grain futures market went into the new year today still looking for influences that could shake prices out of their slim trading ranges.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 4 -- Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d will write songs for a remake of the movie, "State Fair," to be released this year by Twentieth Century-Fox.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- A historic labor-management struggle in steel ended today with a major victory for the United Steelworkers of America.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The program for granting rapid tax write-off privileges to defense projects, begun during the Korean conflict, has ended, the Government announced today.

ATLANTA, Jan. 4 (UPI) -- The Atlanta Board of Education adopted today a revised pupil placement plan to bring it within the requirements of a Federal judge who had ordered the city's schools desegregated.

One of labor's foremost exponents of harmonious industrial relations urged last night that the steel settlement become the jumping-off point for a general effort by employers and unions to cooperate on automation, foreign trade and other national problems.
The city will begin this month to install brighter street lights to curb prowling hoodlums and teen-age delinquents in areas with high crime rates.
Thousands of New Haven Railroad commuters were delayed in both the morning and evening rush hours yesterday by breakdowns of equipment. The evening difficulties were shared by the New York Central.

ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- Scores of new industrial expansions and a 27 per cent increase in the number of out-of-state companies seeking industrial sites were cited today as proofs that the business climate of New York State had improved under Governor Rockefeller's administration.
A payroll fraud in the Bureau of Community Education here that involves the bureau's director and eight other school employes was charged yesterday.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Jan. 4 -- Suffolk County's new Democratic-controlled administrate reorganized governmental dipartments today along part lines.
ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- Governor Rockefeller reported today that he had received an "understanding" reaction to his withdrawal as an active candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination.

The Federal Reserve Board has reported the following percentage changes from the 1958 level in department store sales by cities. These figures, which are regularly published on Sunday, were delayed last Week because of the New Year's holiday.
Don Carter and three other bowlers to be named later this season will compete in the men's phase of an invitation tournament at Madison Square Garden on June 8.
ADELBODEN, Switzerland, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Ludwig Leitner, an Austrian-born German, made a clean sweep of the Adelboden international ski races by taking the giant slalom today.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 4 -- Chauncey T.S. Fish, a civic leader and former Mayor of White Plains, was released tonight from Westchester County Jail after accounting for an estate of which he is an executor and trustee. He had been jailed for five days.
NEW HAVEN, Jan. 4 -- Margaret Sullavan, the actress, died of an accidental overdose of barbiturates, New Haven County Coroner James J. Corrigan said today in a preliminary oral finding.

NICE, France, Jan. 4 -- Driving through Italy you notice a name scrawled in black letters on the walls of barns, garages and houses. The name is Coppi. The man was Fausto Coppi. He was a bike racer, one of the greatest who ever lived and a national hero.

A solid bloc of college basketball coaches in the immediate area has a complaint. It is the coaches' position that their teams do not play enough games, even though the National Collegiate Athletic Association permits each team to engage in twenty-six games a season, exclusive of post-season tournaments.

LONDON, Jan. 4 -- The counselor of the West German Embassy expressed to the Foreign Office tonight his Government's "deep indignation" at the "desecration" of synagogues and private homes in West Germany by paintings of swastikas and Nazi slogans.
In the presence of about 300 persons, Miss Florence M. Kelley was sworn in by Mayor Wagner at City Hall yesterday as the first woman Presiding Justice of the Domestic Relations Court.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 4 -- Al Lazaroff scored only 10 points but got twenty-six rebounds as the Upsala basketball team beat Fairleigh Dickinson, 76 to 75, tonight. It was Upsala's fourth straight triumph.

"THE Play of the Week" tried a change of pace last night -- a psychological thriller involving a demented man's resistance to being institutionalized. The program's tradition of doing different drama on the TV screen happily is sustained; the two hours on Channel 13 are chilling and interesting.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Jan. 4 -- Vice President Nixon acted successfully in settling the steel strike under instructions from the President, James C. Hagerty said today.

Andre Maurois, the French historian and biographer, and Louis Aragon, France's leading Communist writer, are collaborating on a "paraliel history" of the United States and the Soviet Union from 1917 to 1960.
BILOXI, Miss., Jan. 4 -- A Federal grand Jury of twenty-two whites and one Negro opened an inquiry today on the lynching of Mack Charles Parker.

"To the Sound of Trumpets," a drama about a World War I romance involving a British officer and an American nurse, will be presented as the first special program by "Playhouse 90" on Tuesday, Feb. 9, from 9:30 to 11 P.M.
SOME pretty rich stuff has been coming in here lately about one thing and another from magazines and press agents of various states. Some of it may mean something some day somewhere.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 4 -- An American pilot asserted today that the reason he had flown missions for Indonesian rebel forces in the spring of 1958 was to combat communism.

The New York Power Authority decided yesterday to borrow $120,000,000 this month in the public market, instead of $200,000,000. Market conditions were believed not suited to the volume of borrowing first planned, it was explained.

HOUSTON, Jan. 4 (UPI) -- A foreign trade consultant predicted today that this country would slash its balance of payments deficit to $2,000,000,000 this year from an estimated $4,500,000,000 in 1959 as the result of a 10 per cent jump in export and a rise of only 3 per cent in imports.
Traffic accidents in the city last year killed 696 men, women and children, Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy announced yesterday. The victims were pedestrians ana occupants of automobiles.
POCANTICO HILLS, N.Y., Jan. 4 -- More than 600 persons have applied for the 420 permits to hunt deer on the Rockefeller estate here Jan. 11-22.
BOSTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Boston Celtics snapped a threegame losing streak tonight by whipping the Syracuse Nationals, 127 -- 120. The Nationals had won three in succession.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The steel strike retarded the rise in consumer installment buying in November, but did not prevent it from setting another record. The volume of installment credit outstanding at the end of the month was a record of $38,723,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 2 to 15 points (10 to 75 cents a bale) yesterday, with the far months showing the most weakness.

Vince Boryla, the former Notre Dame and Denver basketball ace who served two and a fraction years as coach of the New York Knickerbockers, is to be their general manager and director of player personnel for the next two and a fraction years.
PARIS, Jan. 4 -- Albert Camus, one of France's leading literary figures, was killed today in an automobile accident. He was 46 years old.
A number of military leaders are alarmed over budget limits facing Project Samos. This is the program to photograph the Soviet bloc's military might from artificial satellites.
December sales of the eight major department stores in the New York metropolitan area rose 6 per cent above the level of 1958, according to a survey yesterday by The New York Times.

Premier Khrushchev has begun the new year with a hint at a promise which, if turned into a firm New Year's resolution and actually carried out, could do much to ease international tensions and facilitate disarmament -- two objectives he professes to seek.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 4 -- India and Pakistan announced today that they had reached a preliminary agreement on many items of a thirteen-year-old financial dispute between them.

The Futterman Corporation, a newly formed company, has acquired twenty-four income-producing properties through a purchase and exchange offer in which investors in real estate partnerships converted their partnership interests into stock.
A watchman armed with only a nightstick chased a suspected gunman through two blocks of crowded Bronx streets yesterday after the critical wounding of a Housing Authority policeman.

PARIS, Jan. 4 -- A mission of the International Committee of the Red Cross has found evidence of continued brutality and tortured, along with generally improved conditions in French prison camps in Algeria since a year ago.

HERRICKS, L.I., Jan. 4 -- The toughest teacher in town is pounded, pummeled and pinned by his students. He never objects. He gets off the floor only long enough to make sure they are slamming him down with finesse.

FOR Billy Fisher, the fateful Saturday began like any other. Wallowing between sleeping and waking, postponing the evil moment when he must resume his job as clerk at Shadrack Duxbury's tasteful funeral home, he found it as easy as ever to "abandon the facts" again and return to Ambrosia, the kingdom where men ind events marched to a tune of his own devising.
In an effort to Improve relations with Puerto Ricans and other groups, the New Haven police will start a seminar of five Wednesday afternoon sessions on human relations on Jan. 13.
The Citizens Union called yesterday for a 50 per cent increase in the general-purpose financial aid extended by the state to its cities.
THE cooperative efforts of a psychologist, a furniture designer and an audio engineer have been producing a soothing service called "stereo-analysis" for New Yorkers.

BERLIN, Dec. 29 -- "West Berlin has stored more supply goods than any other place in the world," Mayor Willy Brandt said in a year-end report. "Our policy of stockpiling has rendered the possible threat of a new [Communist] blockade ineffective."
Albert Martin Cohen, a former State Assemblyman and Brooklyn lawyer who is active in Democratic Party politics, was ordered disbarred yesterday by the Appellate Division, Second Department.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Paul Wohl's courteous comments in his letter published Dec. 25 reflect an attitude held by many thoughtful people interested in the story of Poland. But to my view it is an attitude based on wishfulness -- wistfulness might be a better word -- and a disinclination to face the most important fact in the story of any country: the people's reaction.
EACH season, Sally Victor threatens that this collection is her last. Fortunately for her many fans -- they are as loyal as Garbo's, as enduring as Gable's -- she doesn't really mean it.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- Frank S. Whiting, president of the American Furniture Mart, said today that the settlement of the steel strike had changed the outlook for the home-furnishings market from "good" to "excellent."
The complicated union jurisdictional battle aboard the Esso Standard Oil Company's fleet of tankers grew sharper yesterday.
A police investigation was opened yesterday into charges that Italians were permitted to operate as numbers bankers in Harlem while Negro operators were arrested.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The first of a series of reports presaging a major overhauling of the country's public assistance system was sent to Congress today.
ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- The Rockefeller administration's program for the reorganization of the state government appeared headed today for the political arena.

State and city mediators will begin efforts today to settle the strike of 750 newsstand workers in the metropolitan area. The walkout has closed 350 to 400 stands since Saturday night, according to union sources.

Following are excerpts from remarks made last night by Roger M. Blough, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, in a taped television interview with John Cameron Swayze over the National Broadcasting Company network:

The election of Henri Busignies as vice president and general technical director of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation was announced yesterday by H.S. Geneen, president. Mr. Busignies had been president of the I.T.T. Laboratories division.

Two front-line actresses are expected to join Jason Robards Jr. in "Toys in the Attic." They are Irene Worth and Maureen Stapleton. Both will depict sisters in Lillian Hellman's drama, opening Feb. 25 at the Hudson. Miss Worth last appeared here in "Mary Stuart" and Miss Stapleton in "The Cold Wind and the Warm."
A total of thirteen liners entered the harbor yesterday in a record number of arrivals for a winter season. The ships required more than twenty-five tugs to ease them into the piers.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 4 (AP) -- Ryan Aeronautical Company said today it had acquired Aerolab Development Company of Pasadena, which would continue operations there as a Ryan subsidiary.
ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- Charles S. Desmond of Buffalo was sworn in today as the seventeenth Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals, the state's highest tribunal.

The acquisition of the Woodley Petroleum Company, Houston, Tex., by the Pure Oil Company has been approved by the directors of both companies, according to a joint an- nouncement made yesterday. Under the plan Pure will exchange 1,193,881 of its common shares for substantially all of the assets of Woodley, which has 852,772 shares outstanding.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The State Department said today that an American technical assistance official was injured during a riot at Kandahar, Afghanistan, Dec. 21.

The Astor Hotel and the Manhattan Hotel began to swarm yesterday with the early, arrivals of an expected 2,200 delegates to the joint annual conventions of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, the American Football Coaches Association and affiliated sports groups.
The steel settlement opens the way for what most Government and private economists believe will be the country's most prosperous year.

THE six youngsters 10 to 14 years old who were adjudged juvenile delinquents yesterday for breaking the windows of a Hebrew school in Boro Park denied being anti-Semitic. In the opinion of Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy, their act had no broader implications than any other serious piece of vandalism.
Of Proper Painting The head of the house was sitting at his desk in the office the other day, watching the clock as it stumbled and staggered toward 5. The telephone rang.
The styles that will be shown in the country's stores for spring and summer and for cruise and resort wear went or display yesterday for buyers.

ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- Sixtythree years ago last month, a boy was born in the room above Patrick Desmond's saloon on the corner of West Avenue and Virginia Street on the lower West Side of the brawling lake port of Buffalo.

It was all very well for the city to have four new "very fancy and very rare" goldfish at the Aquariun at Coney Island. But alas, it was an embarrassment of riches, for the city was unable to find four peasant types for comparative display.
Putnam Co. and associated investment bankers are offering today 45,000 units of ANelex Corporation securities.

A Clock Maker Withdraws Word from the New Haven Clock and Watch Company the other morning that it was ending the manufacture of timepieces after 142 years dampened the enthusiasm of those who have made a hobby out of collecting data on clocks.
Cheers were sounded for the steel strike accord yesterday, but most business leaders tempered their approval with worry over the prospect that the inflationary fires would burn all the faster.

SATURDAY Is father and son day at Madison Square Garden as the New York Ranger face the Detroit Red Wings in a professional hockey game. Children under 16 will he admitted for half price if accompanted by their fathers.

Rubber futures soared in active trading yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York. Quotations rose 105 to 165 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 1,540 tons. Commission house buying and short covering induced light stop-loss purchasing.

ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- Mayor Wagner is planning a legislative battle to get a state contribution of $9,000,000 toward the cost of transporting school children in New York. At present the city gets only $1,000,000 of the $29,000,000 the state pays to school districts for the transportation of students.
Cincinnati led United Press International's major college basketball ratings yesterday for the fifth straight week while California replaced West Virginia in second place.

The Board of Education yesterday appointed one of its members, former Police Commissioner Francis W.H. Adams, to conduct a departmental trial on charges of a payroll fraud in the Bureau of Community Education.

MOSCOW, Jan. 5 -- Moscow read today of still another example of unsatisfactory work tag conditions in Kazakhstan, the Central Asian republic that is under scrutiny following farm and industrial failures there.

CAIRO, Jan. 5 -- The highest authority on construction of the Aswan Dam said today that the United Arab Republic had received offers from five countries to help build the second stage of the great irrigation power project on the Nile.

Six rounds of the international masters tournament at the Hastings Chess Congress were completed yesterday. Svetozar Gligoric, the grand master from Yugoslavia, handed Arturo Pomar of Spain his first defeat and retained his half-point lead with a 5-1 score.
Hunter College's Assembly Hall will be New York's chief orchestral concert hall next season.
Offensive and defensive platoons will be marching on and off the field again next fall if the nation's college football coaches have their way.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower, Vice President Nixon and a host of other top political figures attended the party tonight for Mr. Dirksen.

E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., has reduced the price of its 15-denier nylon hosiery yarn from $5.25 a pound to $3.89. Other suppliers of the yarn, which is used to make the great bulk of women's hosiery, indicated that they would meet the 26 per cent price cut.
The Chicago Black Hawks with the National Hockey League's leading scorer, Bobby Hull, will meet the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden tonight at 7:30.
HARTFORD, Jan. 5 -- The Connecticut Public Utilities Commission warned the New Haven Railroad today that it would not accept a plea of poverty as an "acceptable answer" to its operating difficulties.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Following are major issues facing the second session of the Eightysixth Congress, which convenes tomorrow:

Net operating earnings of The Chase Manhattan Bank rose 16.1 per cent-in 1959, to $64,634,545, or $4.91 a share, the bank announced yesterday. This compared with $55,648,375, or $4.23 a share in 1958, base on the 13,167,000 shares now outstanding.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Top officials of Canada and the United States will confer here tomorrow on methods of preventing economic rivalries from endangering friendly relations inside the non-Communist world.
A two-year contract for 7,000 New York workers in the corset and brassiere manufacturing industry was ratified overwhelmingly last night at a union membership meeting.

MONTREAL, Jan. 5 (UPI) -- Bobby Hull, hoping to become the Chicago Black Hawks' first scoring champion in a decade, retained a narrow lead over Boston's Bronco Horvath today in the National Hockey League statistics.
Presidential politics and national legislation will be the two major concerns, in that order, of the second session of the Eighty-sixth Congress, which convenes in Washington today at noon.
A New York City law that forbids a person under 21 years of age to carry a knife or other sharp instrument will be challenged as unconstitutional by the Legal Aid Society.
The steel settlement marked a rout for the major companies in what they considered a crusade to re-establish the lost prerogatives of management.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- While President de Gaulle talks about "grandeur" in France the United States Senate is doing something about it right here in Washington. Today, for example, the Senate, which has been on a multimillion dollar rebuilding spree of Augustan proportions, dedicated the fanciest subway this side of Moscow -- a $2,000,000 airconditioned line running 1,000 feet from the new Senate Office Building to the Capitol.

ART FLICK has gone scientific on us now, and is wandering around in a happy haze of biological jive. He had the misfortune to kill a black white rabbit, or varying hare, that zigged in color when it should have zagged.

The William E. Hooper Sons Company, producer of textile converters for heavy industrial fabrics with headquarters in Philadelphia, leased office space in the Wurlitzer Buliding, 120 West Forty-second Street. The lessee is moving from its New York showroom and sales office at 320 Broadway, Newmark Co. was the broker.
CHICAGO, Jan. 5 (AP) -- A few meager gains were scattered through the grain future market today on the Board of Trade, but prices generally closed weaker after a dull session.
Sales were strong, markdowns were lower and profits were improved for the country's department and specialty stores for the nine months ended on Oct. 31.
The Allied Chemical Corporation has announced the appointment of two division presidents and a division executive vice president.

How much money to spend on research and what products develop are questions that plague many top business men. Yesterday Paul B. Wishart, president of the MinneapolisHoneywell Regulator Company, predicted that such problems might be the most important for management in the Nineteen Sixties.
TRENTON, Jan. 5 -- The New Jersey delegation to the Democratic National Convention will support Gov. Robert B. Meyner for the party's presidential nomination.

LONDON, Jan. 5 -- Prime Minister Macmillan departed on an 18,000-mile tour of Africa tonight, ready to "recognize and meet all the aspirations of all the peoples that dwell in Africa and to give them all the help we can."

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 (UPI) -- Two airline employes testified today that spark plugs in three of the four engines were malfunctioning when a cargo plane crashed in a Chicago area Nov. 24, with death for twelve persons.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- State officials recommended today an expansion and revision of the Federal-state hospital building program under the 1946 Hospital Construction Act and its amendments.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 5 -- Yugoslav Foreign Ministry spokesmen declined today to confirm or deny reports circulating in Belgrade that the defection of a high Polish official had led to the recent expulsion of the two Yugoslav military attaches from Poland.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- ator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts said today he was "delighted to receive the endorsement of Ohio Gov. Michael V. DiSalle for the Democratic Presidential nomination.
The city's cultural institutions are finding it difficult to subsist in the face of increasing demands and inadequate, income, Budget Director Abraham D. Beame was told yesterday.
The Bank of France began this week issuing to the public bank notes in the form of the new, "heavy" franc.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Jan. 5 (AP) -- The General Electric Company has disciplined some executive for conferring with rival manufacturers on product pricing in violation of company policy, Ralph J. Cordiner, chairman, said today.

TWO young members of the Philadelphia Orchestra scored personal successes when they appeared as soloists with their orchestra last night at Carnegie Hall. The work in which Eugene Ormandy gave them such a chance to shine was the Brahms Concerto for Violin and 'Cello.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Gen. Laurence S. Kuter, North American Air Defense commander, has asked the Pentagon to reverse its position against increased support for the Army's Nike Zeus anti-missile missile.

PARIS, Jan. 5 -- The Government seized copies of four newspapers today in France and Algeria because they published commentaries on the International Red Cross Committee's recent report on conditions in French prison camps in Algeria.

THE Bon Marche, a store known for Its well-styled, inexpensive furniture, is so aware of today's furnishing needs that, while it is geared to young budget-minded people, it is attracting their parents, too.
Two hundred plainclothes policemen staged all-day raids on policy betting haunts yesterday in Harlem and arrested fifty-two men on charges of violating the gambling laws.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 5 -- Pedro Albizu Campos, leader of the terrorist Nationalist party of Puerto Rico, is still in prison here despite what turned out to have been a partial pardon by Gov. Luis Munoz Marin.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 5 -- Gov. Michael V. DiSalle fired a big gun today in behalf of the Presidential nomination of Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts.

Small investors may now find it more difficult than before to obtain credit to finance stock and bond purchases. The reason is that the interest rate charged by banks on loans to brokers and dealers secured by stock-exchange collateral was increased yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- President Eisenhower ended a tenday vacation in Georgia today. He flew back to a city abustle with preparations for the reopening of Congress tomorrow and for the big political year ahead.

ONEONTA, N.Y., Jan. 5 (AP) -- Pity the Swedish Olympic basketball team. First, the Amateur Athletic Union banned its scheduled games against American college teams, on the ground that the tour was arranged by a professional promoter.

ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- State legislators taking their seats in the Assembly and Senate tomorrow will find on their desks the heftiest stack of bills ever to greet them on the opening day of the Legislature.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In spite of recent discouraging news we must not give up hope for the Geneva test-ban negotiations. Also we must not put the blame for lack of progress entirely on the Russians. I believe a major dragging of feet has come from our side.
DETROIT, Jan. 5 (AP) -- President George Romney of American Motors Corporation declined a $100,000 bonus from the company's high earnings in 3scal 1959, a company spokesman said today.
The Transit Authority reported yesterday that it had had the money all along to pay for its two-year, $35,000,000 contract agreement with the Transport Workers Union.
The Paulist Fathers announced the formation yesterday of the Institute for Religion in American Life.
BRIDGE experts are split into two distinct groups on the subject of bridge-playing wives.

"The Red Executive: A Study of the Organization Man in Russian Industry," by David Granick, will be published Jan. 21 by Doubleday. It is a description of the life of a manager -- his education, home life, early jobs, chances for promotion, problems and recompenses and his place in the Soviet economy.
Two 16-year-old boys were arrested yesterday for breaking three windows of a Jewish center in Queens Dec. 19.

Business men and labor unions were urged yesterday to combat juvenile delinquency by providing more jobs for teen-agers.

Stocks made a new attempt at a New Year's boom yesterday and this time succeeded. The market averages, helped by strength in almost every major group pushed up to the areas of Monday's highs and closed there.

IN EVERY bridge system that is popular today, a player estimates the value of his hand by a point-count method in which a ace counts 4 points, a king 3, a queen 2, and a jack one. ACCRA, Ghana, Jan. 6 -- Prime Minister Macmillan of Britain received a friendly but restrained welcome from Ghanaian crowds today as he began his African tour.

A seasonal increase in the week ended last Friday of 4,921,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend, total supplies were 188,966,000 barrels compared with 184,045,000 a week earlier and 186,482,000 a year ago.

The Gramercy Chamber Ensemble gave a concert last night at the Lexington Avenue Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association and came up with two seldom-heard pieces. One was Ernst Krenek's Symphonic Music for Nine Solo Instruments, the other Schumann's "Spanische Liebeslieder."

"Destiny's Tot," the case history of an anti-Semitic rabble-rouser, will be dramatized in a special telecast by the National Broadcasting Company on Sunday, Jan. 24.

The sun has been setting over various parts of the British Empire since World War II ended, and Africa is no exception. Either as colonies or protectorates, the map was once marked a solid red from Alexandria to Capetown, with other patches on the West Coast. Now independence has either come or is on the way for all of Africa and the hegemony of the white man is ending.
