DETROIT, Jan. 7 -- If the sales manager of an auto company wants to know how many economy cars his chief competitor sold in Los Angeles County last month, R.L. Polk Co., can soon provide the answer.

Short-term interest rates continued to move upward yesterday. Three dealers in bankers acceptances increased the yield to investors 3/8 of a point, and two others announced an advance of 1/4 point. At the same time, the loading sales finance companies announced increases of 1/3 to 3/8 of a point in the yield on commercial paper sold directly to investors.

Loans to business by the larger New York City bank dropped $225,000,000 in the week ended last Wednesday the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with a decline of $159,000,000 in the week a year earlier.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare challenged today the truth of an editorial critical of his department in the current issue of The Journal of the American Medical Associatlon.

Carmine G. De Sapio turned a formal lecture on politics into a living demonstration for 250 City College students yesterday The New York County Democratic chairman managed to respond gracefully to six questions from the floor without giving any answers.
THEY will settle down again, but trout fishermen are beginning to toss and thrash around restlessly in their long winter hibernation. They do it every January and the signs are always about the same.
QUEBEC, Jan. 7 -- A caucus of the National Union today chose Antonio Barrette, Minister of Labor, to succeed Paul Sauve as Premier of the Province of Quebec. Mr. Sauve died Saturday.
MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The eloquence of Branch Rickey won new support for the Continental Baseball League today from Minneapolis-St. Paul interests.

BONN. Germany, Jan. 7 -- The World Jewish Congress asked the West German Government today to investigate the background of people with responsible public and professional jobs so as to eliminate former active Nazis.

ACCRA, Ghana, Jan. 7 -- Prime Minister Kwame Nkrumah said today that Ghana was willing to surrender her sovereignty and submerge herself in an African union to avoid the "Balkanization" of the continent.

A new book by Lawrence Clark Powell, librarian of the University of California at Los Angeles and author of "A Passion For Books," will be published Tuesday by World, Called "Books in My Baggage," it is a collection of essays on books, book collecting, authors and the joy of reading.

Mrs. Aline B. Chaffee Shrady, oldest volunteer worker of the Community Service Society of New York, died of a heart attack Monday in her home at 28 East Seventieth Street. Her age was 90. She was the widow of Dr. Arthur M. Shrady, New York physician.

The domestic sugar contract fell yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange on the heaviest volume since Aug. 18. Final quotations were unchanged to off 5 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 33,450 tons.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Many Democrats in Congress immediately criticized President Eisenhower's presentation of the nation's defense posture in his State of the Union message today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- This was "hail and farewell" day for President Eisenhower and Congress.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Jan 7 -- The managers of West Germany's spectacularly successful economy, long accustomed to praise, are living through difficult days. The severest wave of criticism at home and abroad since the currency reform twelve years ago is washing over them.
Vandals inscribed Stars of David and the phrase "An eye for an eye'' yesterday on the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine and Riverside Church.

The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company has predicted that the rate of general price increases in the United States will be about the same this year as last year, about 1.5 per cent. It made the forecast in its monthly economic survey.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Robert McKinney, editor and publisher of The Santa Fe New Mexican, said today that he would leave for Europe Saturday to continue his study of United States international policies on peaceful uses of the atom.
ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 7 -- Fire in a Public Service Company substation here today cut off the electric power of 22,500 consumers in the Essex County suburbs for nearly eight hours.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The United State's position at home and abroad was portrayed by President Eisenhower in his State of the Union Message to Congress today as follows:

Addressing a joint session of Congress yesterday, President Eisenhower appealed for bipartisan support of the legislative program outlined in his State of the Union Message. There will be time later for a detailed consideration of this program. Here we attempt only a first appraisal, in which we begin, as did the President, with a consideration of --
A critically injured man disappeared from a Brooklyn hospital nine days ago while he was in traction.
United Aircraft Products Inc., is entering a new field witt the purchase of the assets of Western Way Welding of Gardena, Calif. The transaction was made for an undisclosed amount of cash.
WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 7 -- An up-to-date school for juvenile delinquents can be a good neighbor, welfare leaders said here today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- President Eisenhower told Congress today that the United States had fired Atlas inter-continental-ballistic missiles 5,000 miles to hit within two miles of the target. His text told of fourteen such successful tests to which he added last night's successful firing making the total fifteen.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission announced today that the gulf oil corporation had signed an order consenting to the sale of $35,000,000 worth of properties.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., JaN. 7 (AP) -- Carlyn Sarah, who failed to win in fifteen starts last year, defeated the even money favorite. Betty Linn, today's featured race at Tropical Park.

The Public Service Commission was urged yesterday to require the Consolidated Edison Company to make complete studies of the cost of serving each class and type of electricity customer in support of its request for rate increases of more than $31,000,000.
PATCHOGUE, L.I., Jan. 7 -- Fred J. Stacey, a retired Air Force colonel, refused to surrender Suffolk Civil Defense headquarters here today to Harry C. Dayton, a retired Army colonel.

THIS is the day of the hanging. Gene Sarazen, a toughie who murdered par with brazen callousness, is about to get his comeuppance. Never has he expressed regret or showed any inclination to reform. It didn't take the jury five minutes to arrive at a guilty verdict. So he will be hung today.

SYRACUSE, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Wilt Chamberlain scored 44 points and grabbed thirty rebounds tonight to lead the Philadelphia Warriors to a 120-105 victory over the Detroit Pistons in a National Basketball Association game.

BOSTON, Jan. 7 (UPI) -- Bronco Horvath got a goal and an assist to tie for the National Hockey League scoring lead as the Boston Bruins whipped the Chicago Black Hawks, 5-1, and climbed back into fourth place tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The big news in last year's State of the Union Message was President Eisenhower's plan to estabiish a committee to determine long-range national goals. The national goals committee did not get a mention today.
Not since the 1938-39 season, involving ten Madison Square Garden games, have the Hawks of St. Joseph's College in Phildelphia defeated St. John's of Brooklyn.
LONDON, Jan. 7 -- Bitter conflict within the British Labor party over its basic political principles erupted again today.
Senator John F. Kennedy said yesterday that if he were the Democratic Presidential candidate he "would like to discuss the issues and not Mr. Nixon's past."
Rabbits with wilted ears an mice with plastic boxes of diamond dust in their abdomens were among the tools describe yesterday by scientists trying to pry loose the secrets of the "soft skeleton."

When James P. Parker became commodore of the Eastern Yacht Club of Marblehead, Mass., this month he acquired an unusual distinction. Perhaps nobody else in the country is simultaneously the highest ranking officer in two leading organizations for yachts and dogs.
The first unit in a planned world-wide radio transmission system using the "forward scatter" technique has been installed in Ireland for Pan American World Airways.
A nation-wide study commission advised the Methodist Church yesterday to continue its system of racially segregated jurisdictions.
LONDON, Jan. 7 -- Britain is studying suggestions by the United States for dealing with the trade problems of the West and for increasing economic aid to underdeveloped countries.

IN the Union of South Africa, where the members of the ruling white minority are "few, guilty and unloved," a number of talented young writers have burst into print during the last ten years. Of these none is more talented or more regularly productive than Nadine Gordimer, whose fifth book in seven years, "Friday's Footprint and Other Stories,"* is published today.
MOSCOW, Jan. 7 -- The problem in the Soviet chess world today is: Must children be turned into pawns to keep the world chess title in Soviet hands?
Mayor VVagner swore in the city's new five-man Board of Ethics yesterday and charged it with administering "the finest Code of Ethics of its kind in the United States."
Directors of the J.C. Penney Company yesterday proposed a three-for-one split of the common stock, subject to approval of stockholders at the annual meeting on May 26.
All signs point to another busy week-end for ski enthusiasts. The promise by the weatherman of continued cold weather in the snow country means that existing covers will remain intact.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Senator Wayne Morse, is the star of a television film that has become a best-seller in the labor movement.
William R. Staats Co. and associates are offering to the public today 460,000 shares of common stock in the Trans-WoLd Financial Company at $8.625 a share.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 3 points (15 cents a bale) up to 13 points (65 cents) off yesterday. The near May contract showed the only rise.

PARIS, Jan. 7 (Reuters) -- The French shipbuilding industry should be reduced, until 1962, to a few shipyards able to meet international competition, Robert Buron, Minister of Public Works, Transport and Tourism, recommended in a report released here today.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. Jan. 8 -- Although several state legislators are proposing ways of spending toll surpluses from the New Jersey Turnpike, the Turnpike Authority has plans of its own.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Jan. 8 (AP) -- A rabbi accused the General Electric Company and Alco Products Inc. today of creating a life of uncertainty and depression for residents of Schenectady.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The existence of thought control depends upon who is the controller and who is the victim. McCarthyism represented vicious thought control to the reactionary so-called liberal. The latter's attempt to force race mixing upon the South through propaganda has the same meaning to the Southern conservative.
Four city teachers were suspended without pay yesterday for reportedly making false statements about past membership in the Communist party.

WHEN good players bid a slam voluntarily it seldom pays to double them for the normal reason of increasing the penalty score. It is safer to assume that they know what they are doing and that some special feature of their hands, such as a void suit or freakish distribution, may permit them to make the slam.

BERLIN, Jan 8 -- In a demonstration of protest against anti-Semitic and neo-Nazi incidents, tens of thousands of young Berliners paraded past a newly dedicated Jewish community house and synagogue in down-town Berlin tonight.

Steamship passenger traffic between the United States and Canada and Europe was off for the second consecutive year in 1959, while air travel over the North Atlantic route continued to reflect a steady postwar gain.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 8 (UPI) -- The long-awaited meeting between the 1959 Kentucky Derby winner, Tomy Lee, and Hillsdale will take place tomorrow at Santa Anita in the $50,000 San Carlos Handicap at seven furlongs.

The condition of the world fifty years from now as the Soviet Union expects to find or make it is considered in a book to be published by Public Affairs Press this spring. Called "Report from the Twenty-first Century," it is written by two Russian journalists, M. Wassiljew and S. Guschtschew.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 8 -- Communist China has renewed her accusations that Indonesia has been mistreating Chinese residents in implementing a ban on trade in rural areas by aliens.
An industrially sponsored short film, made at the unusually high cost of $350,000, may be presented at a commercial theatre here.

Last night's program by the New York City Ballet at the City Center contained two novelties; namely, the season's first Balanchine-Glinka "Pas de Trois" and Violette Verdy's first appearance this season in the title role of Birgit Cullberg's "Medea."
MORRISTOWN, N.J., Jan. 8 -- A business group today gave a better reception to plans for a jet airport in Morris County than the plans had received at previous meetings in the area.
Eight men charged with conducting a policy-numbers game in Grand Central Terminal were arrested in an employes' locker room in the station yesterday afternoon.
LONDON, Jan. 8 -- The Government-subsidized British Film Institute withdrew today its in vitation to Leni Riefenstahl, a friend of Hitler, to lecture at the National Film Theatre.
CHICAGO, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

MASSENA, N.Y., Jan. 8 (AP) -- Ships plying the St. Lawrence Seaway carried 20,103,767 tons of cargo during the first season of the international waterway. That was a 71 per cent larger volume than that of the last year on the old St. Lawrence Canal.
A 5-month-old boy was rescued from a smoky hotel bedroom on Broadway by a fireman who groped for him as a babysitter screamed from an adjoining rooftop.
The post-season football calendar became more crowded yesterday with a projected Gotham Bowl game in Yankee Stadium on Dec. 10.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 8 -- A two-year study the United Nations has found that religious discrimination declining around the world.

PARIS, Jan. 8 -- On the first anniversary of his installation as President, Gen. Charles de Gaulle was faced today with the need to decide the conflict between Finance Minister Antoine Pinay and Premier Michel Debre.

OFF the beaten track at 331 East Sixty-fifth Street is the salon of Vincent-Harmik, two relative newcomers to the millinery world. Midwesterner Vincent Borg and Iranian-born Harmik Gasparian combined forces to show their first collection in January of last year.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 8 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru said today he would reject the proposal of Premier Chou En-lai for a meeting in the immediate future to discuss the border dispute between India and Communist China.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Jan. 8 -- John E. Brownell of the Williams Club beat Alan Englander of the Yale Club, 15 -- 10, 15 -- 11, in the opening round of the Luckenbach memorial squash racquets tournament at the Nassau County Club tonight.
Many neighborhood bars, particularly those patronized by the younger, set, are experiencing an increasing demand for canned beer instead of that on draught or bottled.
Roman Catholics over the world will mark the Feast of the Holy Family tomorrow. They will observe the event by receiving holy communion a family units in their local parishes.

NEWARK, Jan. 8 -- The late business manager of Local 21, Retail Clerks International Association, was accused today by an Essex County grand jury of responsibility for the shortage of $250,000 from the local's health plan funds.
TOKYO, Jan. 7 -- The United State defense bill in the Far East will rise by at least $30,000,000 a year when the new security treaty with Japan goes into effect.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 8. (AP) -- "A new gang of hoodlums is getting ready to take the place of the old Frankie Carbo syndicate," Harry Falk, California athletic commissioner, charged today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Rumbles of the controversy over Sir Julian Huxley's views on God and evolution have reached this country and aroused considerable interest among the many scientists who are members of the Rationalist Press Association, of which Sir Julian is vice president.

DETROIT, Jan. 8 -- Retail sales of passenger cars surged sharply at the end of December, giving further impetus to the auto industry's plans to establish a production record in the first quarter of this year.
A storm of controversy bats blown into Greenwich Village over the selection of a recipient for the fifth annual award of its Brotherhood Award Committee.

Lawrence B. Karter, realty investor, contracted to buy four five-story and two four-story houses at 102-04 Mott Street and 109 Mott Street from clients of Emanuele Tratta, lawyer. The buildings contain forty-five apartments and four stores.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (UPI) -- Senator Kenneth B. Keating said today that Baseball Commissioner Ford Frick would meet with him Monday to discuss the proposed third major league.

MOUNT HOPE, N.Y., Jan. 8 -- All four Canadian rinks in the twenty-fourth Douglas Medal bonspiel reached the quarter-final round as the three-day event opened at the St. Andrew's Golf Club curling arena today.
MOBILE, Ala., Jan. 8 (UPI) -- A fast and well-balanced South team today ranked as a 3 1/2-point favorite over a flashy but slower North squad in the eleventh annual Senior bowl tomorrow.

International exchanges of culture are not always dazzling affairs replete with treaties and ambassadorial protocol. As in the case of the 140 pupils of Les Clochettes, a nursery-kindergarten in Bayside, Queens, it can be as simple as writing to twenty-eight countries offering an exchange of children's art.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 8 -- The Wiltwyck School completed its testimony in Supreme Court today in a suit to compel the Town of Yorktown to permit the construction of a home for emotionally disturbed boys. The town will begin to present its case Monday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The Administration promised domestic sugar interests today a decision soon on the position it would take regarding sugar quotas in relation to actions of Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba.

The International Longshoremen's Association announced yesterday that it would make an "all-out" effort this year to negotiate a master contract covering 10,000 dock workers in ports on all five Great Lakes.

Within hours after President Eisenhower revealed in his State of the Union Message the reliability and accuracy of our Atlas intercontinental ballistic missile the Soviets announced that they propose to fire more powerful rockets to a target area in the Central Pacific.
MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 8 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey opens this week-end a swing through nine states in his quest for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

Books in Demand If the beat selling list are any indication, in recent months the adults have been the ones seen reading children's books. Among them are letters from children at summer camp; an account of a household with several little boys running through it, and an author who could recall in detail the games he played when he was young, a memory that few of us have.

There was one moment on Miriam Burton's program last night at Carnegie Recital Hall that was really electrifying. It was in the "Polo," the final Spanish folksong of a set of seven by Manuel de Falla. With color, fire and strength, Miss Burton really cut loose and rattled the rafters.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- United States space officials speculated today that the Soviet Union might attempt to shoot a man into space in rocket flights over the Pacific Ocean.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8 (UPI) -- Eric Monti, a hometown pro playing a neighboring course today shot a 5-under-par 66 to take the first-round lead in the $37,500 Los Angeles open.
NEW CANAAN, Conn., Jan. 8 -- The United States Supreme Court has been called upon to settle a long-standing zoning controversy here.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 8 -- A special session of the Connecticut Legislature to consider the plight of the New Haven Railroad has been endorsed by State Representative John M. Lupton, Republican of Weston.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The Secretary of Agriculture announced today that current support prices for dairy products would continue through the 1960-61 marketing year beginning next April 1.

Bear, Stearns Co. and associated underwriters offered the public yesterday 260,000 shares of the Class A common stock of Guerdon Industries, Inc., Marlette, Mich., manufacturer of mobile homes. The shares carry common stock purchase warrants for an additional half share.
"It took a lot of digging but I finally climbed out of my rut of procrastination," wrote a contributor to New York's Neediest Cases fund yesterday.
Margaret Sullavan, the actress who died of an accidental overdose of sleeping pills eight days ago, had a secret. She was fighting deafness.

WARSAW, Poland, Jan. 8 (Reuters) -- Polish civil air authorities, "for commercial reasons," have refused British European Airways permission to introduce Comet 4B jet services on the London-Warsaw run.
A member of a bar association subcommittee that made an unfavorable report on former Magistrate Robert F. Mahoney said yesterday he wished the magistrate were still on the bench.
TRIVANDRUM, India, Jan. 8 -- Communists and anti-Communists are fighting a bitter political campaign in Kerala.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 8 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold has expressed hope that Laos will follow a line of "independent neutrality and democratic progress."
WESTPORT, Conn., Jan. 8 -- Improvements including a new pavilion, bathhouse facilities and a new roadway will be started at Sherwood Island State Park next week. The total cost is $700,000.
The Hungarian Catholic League of America will hold its sixth annual Charity Ball on Jan. 23 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 8 -- The Government of Rhineland-Palatinate moved today to suppress a local convention of the extreme Rightist German Reichs party scheduled for this week-end.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The index of average wholesale primary market prices rose 0.1 per cent to 118.9 per cent of its 1947-49 base during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
The zone defense Harvard used against Columbia in their Ivy League basketball game at University Hall last night presented no serious problem for the favored Lions.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The new commandant has told it to the Marines.

In the evening twilight of July 26, 1938, the sky over New York State was streaked by an object from beyond the solar systems, according to a report published yesterday in the magazine Science. It has been stanchly maintained by many astronomers that such visitations do not occur.

THE audience that goes to hear Andres Segovia is loyal to the point of fanaticism, and when the famous guitarist appeared at Town Hall last evening, there was as usual a capacity audience, seats on stage and frantic last-minute bargaining for tickets in the lobby.

CONCORD, N.H., Jan. 8 -- A slate of candidates pledged to Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts was formally entered today in the New Hampshire Presidential primary, with background applause from Democratic leaders in the state.
ACCRA, Ghana, Jan. 8 -- Prime Minister Kwame Nkrumah pressed his drive for Panover Ghana today. He said he acted because Africa faced new onslaught by "the devil of colonialism."
An efficient and modern steamship terminal, reborn from the ruins of fire and explosion, went back to work yesterday.
PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 8 -- Princeton University sophomores will not be required to attend chapel any more after the start of the next semester.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Vice President Nixon will be represented by a full slate of delegates in the Ohio Republican Presidential primary on May 3, former Senator John W. Bricker said today.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 8 -- The mystery of what happened to spoil the good relations between Poland and Yugoslavia deepened today.
Two-platoon adherents in the college football set were sent reeling by a surprise blow yesterday.
The bond market moved forward confidently on all fronts yesterday.
The sponsor of the Friday night fights on radio and television said yesterday that the National Broadcasting Company wanted to drop the bouts next September.
The United Lutheran Church of America denounced the cu rent rash of swastika-daubing as "anti-Christian as well as anti-Jewish."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: How can the Mayor and his administration expect to eliminate the problem of slums by further enforcing strong laws to punish property owners? Before he comments further on this subject. Mayor Wagner should find the real cause of the slums, and that is the city itself.
ALBANY, Jan. 8 (UPI) -- Skiing conditions reported to the State Department of Commerce today:
Governor Rockefeller is still in the race for the Republican Presidential nomination, Senator Barry Goldwater told a New York Young Republican Club luncheon yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission said tonight that his agency was hamstrung with difficulties in trying to establish standards for radio and television programing.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: May one who fought against Nazi Germany as a member of the United States Army express himself on the resurgence of anti-Semitism in West Germany? Because Germany has been so closely identified with this social disease, one thinks more of it than other countries seemingly infected.
Stocks continued their down ward movement yesterday, losing a little ground in almost every important group.
The Army's information chief mounted a strong attack yesterday against a national defense policy that relies almost wholly on massive nuclear retaliation.
Twenty-six hundred New York millinery workers who earn less than $65 a week will receive an increase of $5 a week under an agreement announced yesterday.

Two six-story apartment houses at 3905 and 3915 Carpenter Avenue, the Bronx, were purchased by the Realty Equities Corporation, Bernard I. Sandford, executive vice president. They were sold by the builders, who erected them in 1940.
Borough President John T. Clancy of Queens has asked for a 1960-61 expense budget appropriation of $10,826,730. This is an increase of $733,619 over the current allotment.

A boom in West Germany made stocks among the good buys of 1959, it was reported yesterday from Frankfurt by Associated Press. The West German Federal Statistical Office estimated that share vain as measured by its Index of stock prices rose an average 72 per cent in the year.
SURVEYS show that readers of food pages like recipes best. In compliance with this demand, the reader letters answered today deal with three recipes -- two requested and one suggested.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 8 (AP) -- National Airlines, which has lost seventy-six passengers and crew members in two recent crashes, said today a charge that its planes had been weakened in pilot flight tests was based on a misunderstanding.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8 -- Dr. Richard E. Shope, a research specialist at the Rockefeller Institute, offered hope today that outbreaks of equine viral encephalitis could be prevented from reaching the epidemic stage in the future.
MOSCOW, Jan. 8 -- The Soviet Government has taken emergency action in the last month to supply consumer goods to the settlers of virgin lands in Kazakhstan.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Jan. 8 (AP) -- A second plane flew to Station Charley in the arctic today to rescue twenty-five United States military and civilian scientists trapped on the disintegrating ice island.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 5 points (25 cents a bale) off to 6 points (30 cents) up yesterday. The market lacked a trend, and held in a narrow range all day.
A police sergeant dying from a stab wound shot and killed the man who had attacked him in a Bowery mission last night.
The price of zinc moved upward yesterday in the wake of increased buying touched off by the steel strike settlement.

Houston, Tex., is planning to sell bond issues totaling $9,800,000 to finance public improvements. The date selected for the sale is Jan. 27, The bonds, which will be secured by taxing power, will come due serially on March 1 from 1961 to 1980.
BOMBAY, India, Jan. 8 -- Pilots of the state-owned Air India International struck a noon today to protest the airline's selection of a non-guild pilot for jet training in the United States.

FLORIDA and Gulf Coast fishing, both fresh and salt, is almost certain in the next months to see an upsurge in the use of what is called ultra-light tackle. This stuff has been on the boom for a couple of years and seems to fascinate many anglers.

IN buying furniture today the old rules no longer apply. Fifty years ago the three clues indicating fine quality were fashionable styling, veneers well applied and hand methods or joining, such as dovetailing and doweling

MEMPHIS, Jan. 8 (UPI) -- A $1 par value share of stock in the newly formed Memphis Chicks baseball organization will be given to each baby born here in 1960 as long as stock is available, Leo Burson, president, said today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Joe Foss received assurances today that any attempt to "push around" his new American Football League would receive stern Congressional attention.
A state Supreme Court justice held yesterday that New York's middle-income housing program was really a low-income program -- and perfectly legal as such.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8 -- A national movement to draft Adlai E. Stevenson for the Democratic nomination for President is being sponsored by his Midwest supporters. They have plans to announce it within a few days.

The task of recruiting about a dozen men to depict Roman gladiators, slaves and patricians for the forthcoming production of "Caligula" appeared to be a relatively simple one. The requirements were that they be more than 6 feet tall and muscular.

Trading volume potatoes futures on the New YorK Mercantile Exchange yesterday reached the second highest point for the 1959-60 crop year. During the day 2,476 carlots were traded, compared with the previous high of 2,808 on Dec. 17, 1959.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8 -- The bodyguard of Roger Touhy told a coroner's jury today that he had no idea who killed the Prohibition era gang leader in an ambush here on Dec. 16, only three weeks after he had left prison.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 8 -- Nassau County's Republican legislators, while giving "careful study" to Governor Rockefeller's proposals for increasing school aid, plan to introduce measures of their own to meet the "special problems" of schools in Nassau County.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Corn prices were left behind to day in a general grain futures advance which ran to 2 cents a bushel in soybeans and 3 cents in rye on the Board of Trade Corn was off major fractions in spots while old-crop wheat months moved up three-quarters of a cent at the best.
Gaspar Ortega of Mexicali, Mexico, often called the "unlucky Indian" because so many split decisions have gone against him during his lengthy boxing career, finally got lucky last night.

TEL AVIV, Jan. 8 -- Israel's bumper cotton harvest yielded nearly enough fiber last year to meet her mills' requirement for domestic consumption. The industry, started six years ago, ginned an estimated 7,300 tons of fiber.

THE Tchaikovsky Festival continues apace. Last night's program of the Moscow State Symphony, conducted by Konstantin Ivanov, presented the First Symphony, the "Variations on a Rococo Theme" and "Francesca da Rimini."

A Long Island banker threatened to sue New York University unless it disavowed the findings of two of its professors that interest and service charges to customers were higher at the bank than at New York City institutions.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- President Eisenhower's forecast of a big budget surplus in the coming fiscal year has produced surprisingly little talk in Congress of a reduction in taxes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Missiles and Rockets magazine said today that the Russians had a semi-ballistic space bomber. This could mean that they are seven to eight years ahead of the United States in developing a Dyna-Soar type manned boost-glide space vehicle, the magazine said.
A REMINDER that international expositions can leave behind them something more than memories of aching feet was offered by the New York Philharmonic at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 8 -- Following is a summary of a proposed code of rules to guide governments in the eradication of religious discrimination:
An examiner of driving licenses was dismissed from the Motor Vehicle Bureau yesterday, minutes after he refused to waive immunity before a Bronx County grand jury.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 8 -- The United States has asked the Soviet Union to agree to have the United Nations Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space meet as soon as possible.

Guests at the second annual Spoleto Festival Ball last night Were given a preview of some of the events scheduled for Gian Carlo Menotti's annual Festival of Two Worlds, which will take place in Spoleto, Italy, from June 9 through July 10.

The question of "work rules" was a key factor in the settlement of the steel dispute. The way these and related problems are handled will also be crucial in how the settlement works out -- with effects on labor-management relations that could be nation-wide.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 8 -- Interest aroused by a bitterly fought campaign and a forecast of fair weather promised a heavy turnout tomorrow in this state's gubernatorial run-off primary.

ALIMONY laws enacted in the era of gaslight and hansom cabs still cast a long shadow across the American home. In credibly enduring, these laws today are as antiquated as the horsehair sofa. This is the opinion of many of the nation's leading legal and family welfare authorities.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- A new mobile locator is regarded by its backers as capable of cutting in half the cost of spotting enemy radio transmitters.

THE exhibition, "Landscape -- 1500-1960," at Durlacher's, 11 East Fifty-seventh Street, is anything but an exclusive gathering, including as it does a good many pictures that do not fall into the strict category of landscape.

The H.L. Green Company in a letter accompanying a proxy statement to stockholders charged yesterday that Maxwell H. Gluck and C. Brooks Peters were seeking to capitalize "on the company's problems arising out of the Olen [Company] shortages."
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 8 -- Ocean depths never before explored by man have been reached by the bathyscaph Trieste, the Naval Electronics Laboratory announced today.
Twenty-six years ago, at Floral, Saskatchewan, in the heart of Western Canada's wheat prairies, Gordie Howe got his first pair of ice skates.

Steel executives sought cheer yesterday in the hope that a dent had been made in the long-term thinking of their unionized workers. Assessing the results of the industry's most costly strike, they were hopeful that the workers had been impressed with the need for cooperative effort to raise efficiency and curb inflation.
LONDON, Jan. 8 -- Selling of industrial shares declined appreciably here today and the stock market ended the week on a firm note.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Jan. 8 -- Harold John Adonis testified in his conspiracy trial today that he had kept $30,000 out of $35,000 he had received for Republican party expenses between April, 1946, and February, 1949.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The Food and Drug Administration denied today industry requests for a hearing on the administration's proposal to prohibit the use of existing stocks of seven coal-tar colors in foods.
The owner of three Bronx stores was arraigned yesterday in Felony Court on a charge of stealing more than $100,000 from Planned Credit, Inc., a factoring concern of 50 East Forty-second Street.
Mayor Wagner yesterday called a City Hall conference for Monday on the rash of hit-and-run accidents here.

QUEBEC, Jan. 8 -- Antonio Barrette, who was sworn in today as Quebec's Premier, the third in less than four months, is in many ways a remarkable man. His formal education ended at the age of 14 when he quit school over the objections of his parents to take a job as a railway messenger boy at a 5 cents an hour.
CHICAGO, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Calumet Hecla, Inc., said today it has acquired virtually all stock of Flexonics Corporation of Maywood, Ill., through an exchange of stock.

QUEBEC, Jan. 8 -- Antonio Barrette, Quebec's eighteenth Premier, was sworn in today by Lieutenant Governor Onesime Gagnon. With only a few minor shifts, the old Cabinet of the late Premier Paul Sauve remained in office.
Gold rained yesterday upon Jacob Lipkin, the sculptor who lives by barter. But true to his principles, he spurned it.

A MUSEUM unknown to many Manhattanites, but lauded as a cultural and educational center by Staten Islanders is the Staten Island Institute of Arts and Sciences, 75 Stuyvesant Place, Saint George (near the ferry dock).
A Housing Authority lawyer tried to show yesterday that the Consolidated Edison Company paid too much rent for underground cable ducts.

Financial officers of ten governments in Asia, Europe, Latin America and Africa nave been designated to take a six-month training course in Washington, D.C., under the auspices of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank).
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The Farmers Home Administration was authorized today to make emergency loans to cranberry growers In New Jersey through June 30.

Having clinched first prize in Thursday's eighth round, Svetozar Gligoric of Belgrade, Yugoslavia, relaxed in the final round of the international masters' tournament at the Hasting Chess Congress in England yesterday.
British experiments that may have uncovered the cause of rheumatoid arthritis were reported here yesterday.

There can be nothing but satisfaction here and in Latin America over President Eisenhower's forthcoming visit to Brazil, Argentina, Chile and Uruguay. No American President in office has ever taken this much of a voyage to Latin America. Herbert Hoover made an extensive journey as President-elect. Mr. Truman visited Rio de Janeiro in 1947 and President Eisenhower went to Panama for a conference in 1956.

LONDON, Jan. 8 (UPI) -- The big Viscount airliner lurched as its wheels thrummed along a runway at fog-shrouded London Airport. Mrs. Trixie Prestcott's gin and tonic spilled on the floor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The United States was said today to be prepared to soften its demands somewhat to achieve a final settlement of the Soviet Union's debt for wartime lend-lease aid. Negotiations on the long-pending aid account will be resumed here Monday after a lapse of more than seven years.

The market for new capital is slated for an exceptionally heavy volume of business next week with more than $335,000,000 of Government and corporate fixed-interest securities and a substantial number of equity issues on the docket.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9 -- In his third and last will, Benjamin Franklin erred in an attempt to peer a couple of hundred years ahead. But with customary foresight, he anticipated that possibility.

Settlement of the steel labor dispute got business and the stock market off to good starts for the new year. Stocks soared after the announcement of an agreement, then retreated under profit taking, tighter brokerage money rates and anti-inflation developments.

MONTEREY, Calif. -- There is a lot more the Monterey Peninsula than the gnarled cypress trees of its shoreline, which have become a California trade mark. ABADAN, Iran, Jan. 8 -- From the long pier that stretches before the oil refinery here, the scene of a heated international dispute provides a peaceful view.

NEVER before have so many persons been interested in the breeding of flowering plants and the development of new varieties. Many nurseries and seed companies have staffs, headed by college-trained geneticists, devoted solely to developing improved varieties.

TO all lovers of free Shakespeare in Central Park next summer: caution. Also, patience and fortitude. We must do our duty humbly. We must walk softly, looking neither to the right nor the left, and speak gently.

MORE and more the books on American public affairs are being written by working newspaper men. Being alert and intelligent, they keep in touch with the changing kaleidoscope of day-to-day events at the same time that they are the masters of the theoretical content of their subjects.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The Eighty-sixth Congress with its lopsided Democratic majorities returned to Washington for its second and final session this week in a surprisingly languid mood.

ALBANY, Jan. 9 -- About half of New York's wage and salary earners will receive refunds on the state income tax deducted from their pay last year. The others probably will have to make further payments.

Recent forecasts of a sharp rise of more than $2,000,000,000 in United States commercial exports in 1960 have had the seemingly odd effect of generating pessimism about 1961.

TRENTON, Jan. 9 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner will present to the Legislature on Tuesday a program for solving New Jersey's property assessment dilemma.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia -- Hardly a three-hour flight from this city, which has an 8,200-foot elevation, is another African capital, Khartoum, the low, flat seat of government for the Sudan. The contrasts in the altitudes of these cities typifies the differences of the sovereign states in which they are situated.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- President Eisenhower devoted more than one-fifth of his State of the Union message this week to "the titanic challenge" presented to the free world by the need to help "the uncommitted and newly-emerging nations" in their desperate effort to "lift themselves to decent standards of living."

PARIS, Jan. 9 -- Claude Breart de Boisanger, who was designated as administrator of the Comedie Francaise last April as part of a vast reform of national theatres, is expected to be dismissed next week.

NEW HAVEN, Conn.,Jan. 9 (AP) -- Yale snapped a five-game losing streak and scored its second Ivy League victory of the season tonight, beating Pennsylvania, 67 -- 57, in basketball.

AT a recent Pro Musica Motet Choir performance of fifteenth and sixteenth-century music, one of the listeners remarked: "I've never heard so much silence from an audience." And this on a rainy night when sneezes, coughs and damp rustlings could have been expected.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The American National Red Cross celebrates this year the fiftieth anniversary of its nation-wide first-aid program. "Many hundreds of persons are now alive who would not be but for the Safety Services of the Red Cross," a report issued here today said.

NEW trends in architecture, changes in modern living and less time for gardening have affected the use of perennials. Rarely are they used now in broad, luxurious borders.
