THERE are persons in the A neighborhood, as well as across the state line, who do not like ice shows. This is not written for them -- they are entitled to their opinions in a free man's country. It is written for the devotees who wait anxiously each year for the arrival of the spinners and the splitters, the gliders and the whirlers.

VANCOUVER, B.C. -- British Columbians, resigned to high labor costs, industrial strife and a prospect described as far from a boom, face a dramatic year because of a race between giants for the development of vast hydroelectric projects.
The State of Maryland borrowed $23,121,000 yesterday to finance public improvements. The money was raised by serial bonds secured by the full taxing power of the state.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 (AP) -- In the dullest trading of the new year, the grain futures market sat virtually stationary today with only one contract ending more than a minor fraction from the preceding close.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Jan. 12 (AP) -- A Methodist woman leader asserted today that some unofficial laymen's groups were "trying to preserve the segregated structure of the Church." She also criticized "propagandists who try to pin the Communist label on any who work for racial integration." She did not identify them.
LONDON, Jan. 12 -- An American Air Force captain has been winning races here with an overgrown gift horse that eats coat sleeves and seems to run best on human affection.
Atomic science and religious symbolism are paired again in an elaborate canvas painted by Salvador Dali for Huntington Hartford.

A six-story building contaning fifty-three apartments and nine stores at 390 Jackson Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the Ferol Realty Corporation, which built it in 1930. It was bought by Bernard Gordon realty operator.
ASUNCION, Paraguay -- Paraguay rode out the ill effects on its economy of an economic recession in Argentina, her main market, and ended the year in solid financial shape.
LA PAZ, Bolivia -- Bolivia clung to monetary stabilization last year and was rewarded with a slight upturn in agricultural production and mineral exports.

TOKYO, Jan. 12 -- Japan announced a sweeping new free trade policy today that is expected to make it easier for Japanese to buy products from the United States and other countries. The move is expected to mean millions of dollars in new business for American manufacturers in the export trade.

WINNIPEG, Man. -- The Manitoba Development Fund has become involved in hosiery and whisky as part of its activity in encouraging industrial and commercial expansion in Manitoba. The fund is a government agency that "complements," rather than competes, with the activities of ordinary lending institutions.

Three of seven savings associations announced yesterday that they would not appear in state Supreme Court today. Representatives had been ordered to appear in an investigation of an alleged fraud by a Moroccan insurance firm.

Ingemar Jonansson, the world heavyweight boxing champion, said yesterday that prospects for a return bout in New York in June with the former champion, Floyd Patterson, now looked brighter than they had in recent months.
A comprehensive study of national transportation problems has been completed by the Department of Commerce and will probably go to the White House in a few days.
Anthony (Bang Bang) Brandofino, hoodlum, was arrested yesterday as the leader of four men who spirited a critically injured patient from a Brooklyn hospital Dec. 30.
TAKING infinite pains, the Phoenix has put on a difficult if not impossible drama. Ibsen's "Peer Gynt'' opened on the home grounds last evening.

TORONTO -- The Ontario government has ambitious plans for the transformation of Moosonee, a village of 350 population perched on the bleak shores of James Bay, into this bustling province's first salt-water port.

William Adams Delano, a noted architect who designed the balcony on the South Portico of the White House, died yesterday at Presbyterian Hospital after a long illness. He would have been 86 years old Jan. 21. His home was at 131 East Thirty-sixth Street.
The Princeton swimming team beat Columbia, 55 -- 40, yesterday at the losers' pool. Records in two events were set, including the Lions' own mark for the 400-meter relay.
TORONTO -- Despite the deglamorizing of uranium, last year was a banner one for mining in Ontario. Production is estimated at $900,000,000 -- a solid $100,000,000 above the record output in 1958.
The United States Court of Appeals yesterday unanimously upheld the narcotics conspiracy convictions against Vito Genovese, underworld leader, and thirteen other persons.

ON the day after tomorrow you may be the first on your block to serve a bottle of 1959 wine from Europe. One hundred and eighty cases of that year's harvest, loudly and universally praised as the greatest of the century, arrived by steamship this week from France.
YELLOWKNIFE, N.W.T. -- While work on a road between this Northwest Territories city and the "outside" continued slowly last year, transportation remains the area's chief problem.
TRENTON, Jan. 12 -- Gov. Robert Meyner pledged a state-aid program today to alleviate critical commuter railroad problems.

NICE, France, Jan. 12 -- Recent scientific data obtained from the flight of the United States "paddle-wheel" satellite, Explorer VI, and other rockets have shown that the vast belt of radiation around the earth named after Dr. James A. Van Allen of the University of Iowa is bigger, less condensed, probably more homogeneous in structure but more difficult to understand than scientists thought two years ago.
CARACAS, Venezuela -- This nation's budget for 1959-1960 amounted to about $1,700,000,000. Of this, about $250,000,000 could not be met out of income. The 1958-1959 budget had also had a deficit.

PARIS, Jan. 12 (UPI) -- Gamble Benedict, runaway 18-year-old heiress, and the former Rumanian chauffeur, Andrea Porumbeanu, are guests of a lawyer in his Paris apartment, the lawyer, Jean Cosacesco, said tonight.
Futures prices on the New York Commodity markets moved irregularly yesterday in relatively quiet dealings.
President Eisenhower declared yesterday that freedom and decency could be destroyed everywhere if Americans ignored "the virus of bigotry" or permitted it "to spread one inch."

The H.K. Porter Company, Inc., Pittsburgh diversified industrial concern, is entering the paint business through purchase of more than 90 per cent of the stock of Patterson-Sargent Company of Cleveland, Ohio, T.M. Evans, Porter chairman, announced yesterday.

GUATEMALA -- The advent of 1960 found the Government and the monetary authorities engaged in two main parallel actions. Their object was, for one, to protect the stability of the currency, and, for the other, to insure an adequate rate of growth for the economy.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The State and Defense Departments are still split on the question of permitting the Panamanian flag to be flown in the Panama Canal Zone as a symbol of residual sovereignty.

While many United States exports have not been faring too well recently in increasingly competitive overseas markets, the demand abroad for at least one United States product seems to be sharply on the rise.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 12 -- A Roman Catholic group characterized part of a United Nations report on religious discrimination today as a "tissue of fabrication."

The modern city is like a small boy who has grown up too swiftly, Senator Kenneth B. Keating, Republican of New York asserted last night. "His suit no longer fits him," the Senator said. "It's bursting at every seam. He has put on weight, he has put on muscle and he needs to be completely retailored, readjusted to the new and different world in which he lives."

The practicability of near-foolproof and almost completely automatic operation of electric power generation has been demonstrated by a rigid six-month test, according to Thomas Roy Jones, president of Daystrom, Inc.
PARIS, Jan. 12 -- President de Gaulle was reliably reported tonight to have removed Antoine Pinay as Finance Minister.
The City Council unanimously recorded yesterday its belief that the Federal and state minimum wage should be raised to at least $1.25 an hour.

ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- Thomas E. Dewey has refused to join a Democratic-sponsored committee of former Governors to assess the Rockefeller administration's controversial plan to reorganize the state Controller's office.

"Lincoln and the Civil War," a narrative account edited by Courtlandt Canby, will be published by Braziller on Feb. 1. The story of those crucial years is told in the words of those who have written about them, such as eyewitnesses and historians summing up and interpreting the record.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 12 -- A fund of $1,500,000, set up to compensate union members for work lost to labor-saving devices on the waterfront, is to be distributed this spring among nearly 14,000 West Coast longshoremen and ships' clerks.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Lyndon B. Johnson crushed today another challenge to his leadership of the Democratic party in the Senate. By a vote of 51 to 12, the Senate's Democratic members sustained the Texan's method of operating the controlling party machinery. They rejected Senator Albert Gore's motion for a fundamental re-organization.

Prices of United States Government securities surged for ward again yesterday in what dealers described as an unusual trading session. In some quarters the continued weakness in stock prices was a signal for interest having short positions in bond to cover their commitments.

The big competition for department stores in the Nineteen Sixties will come from the mail-order houses and the junior department store chains, it was asserted last evening by Edward W. Cart- er, president of Broadway-Hale Stores, Inc., Los Angeles department store.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Attorney General William P. Rogers urged the Supreme Court today to overturn a lower court decision holding the Civil Rights Act of 1957 unconstitutional.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld. -- The New foundland economy was shaken at the start of 1959 by a strife of the International Woodworkers of America against the Anglo-Newfoundland Development Company, Ltd., pulp and paper operators at Grand Falls.

RIO DE JANEIRO -- Record inflation and budgetary deficits overshadowed Brazil's economy in 1959, but the year saw continuing economic expansion and evidence of faith by foreign investors in the country's future.

TORONTO -- Undisputed merchant king of Canada and possibly its wealthiest citizen is a man whose surname is a household word from sea to sea. Yet, beyond this superficial fact, John David Eaton is one of the least-known public figures in this country today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The chief of the Federal Aviation Agency served notice today that he would not be "pressured" by those in the aviation industry who wanted safety rules written to please them.

William A. Shea, a founder of the Continental League, revealed yesterday plans the new league had for player pensions. His action was in reply to statements made on Monday in Washington at a meeting between Baseball Commissioner Ford C. Frick and Senator Kenneth B. Keating, Republican of New York.

IT hardly could be classified as a deal of earthshaking dimensions. Nor can it have any profound effect on the National League pennant race. Yet a trade that sends Richie Ashburn from the Phils to the Cubs for Alvin Dark and two lesser performers has to be important, not so much because of who they are but because of who they were.
EDMONTON, Alberta -- Like great many other cities in North America, this provincial capital has been suffering from growing pains virtually since the end of World War II.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The Navy disclosed today that it was postponing the construction of four ships and the conversion of another because of shortages in funds. The vessels had been planned on the basis of money appropriated by Congress.

Sugar production during the current crop year is expected to dip slightly from the 1958-59 record yield but remain above consumption. Some of the Latin American countries hope to recuperate part of the lost revenue resulting from lower prices by capturing a greater share of the United States market.
MONTREAL -- Heavy trading early last year, followed by setbacks in the latter part were recorded by the Montreal and Canadian stock exchanges.

HAVANA -- The United States technical assistance program, which has been going on for many years in Cuba, continued to operate in 1959, the year of the advent of Dr. Fidel Castro's revolutionary Government

The election of George E. Stoll and A.P. Fontaine as executive vice presidents of the Bendix Aviation Corporation was announced yesterday by Malcolm P. Ferguson, president. Both were formerly vice presidents and group executives.

LIMA, Peru -- The man mainly responsible for Peru's economic recovery and the restoration of public confidence is Sehor Pedro Beltran, who became Premier and Minister of Finance last July. Before his appointment inflation was spreading and the country drifting onto rough economic shoals.

The Seeburg Corporation in its fiscal year ended on Oct. 31 more than tripled its earnings of the preceding fiscal year, the nation's largest manufacturer of coin-operated phonographs, disclosed yesterday.
In the cotton futures market yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange, old March rose 2 points (10 cents a bale) up, but the other months wer 1 to 7 points (5 to 35 cents) off.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The Atomic Energy Commission fulfilled a long sought but troublesome goal today by formally agreeing to construct an experimental nuclear power plant in Puerto Rico.

Following are excerpts from an opinion filed yesterday by Federal Court Judge Irving R. Kaufman in the Apalachin case. It upholds the New York State Police roadblock and questioning of sixty-three men who attended the meeting on Nov. 14, 1957.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The Public Health Service reported influenza outbreaks in nine states today.

NEWARK, Jan. 12 -- Newark residents gave a vote of confidence today to the present form of municipal government. In a special election they supported the Mayor-City Council system by a vote of 34,972 to 14,572.
BOGOTA, Colombia -- Colombia's oil industry expanded significantly last year. And spokesmen for both foreign and national oil companies predict "another very active year" in 1960.
Latin America has never been so healthy as in January, 1960.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica -- The year 1959 was an uneasy on for Costa Rica, not only politically, but also financially.

MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 12 (UPI) -- College football rules makers agreed "almost unanimously" today on a liberalized substitution rule that would eliminate the check-off system that delayed games last season.

VANCOUVER, B.C. -- The Aluminum Company of Canada announced in December that improving business in Canada, the United States and Europe was enabling it to increase production at smelters in Quebec and Kitimat, B.C.

CARACAS, Venezuela -- The year 1959 was, for Venezuela, a period of readjustment. Despite a fundamentally sound economy, the country found itself facing problems with its budget and its international trade balance.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- A $10 loitering case from the Police Court of Louisville, Ky., was examined by the Supreme Court today in an unusual session.

After a holiday recess, the marathon conference on banning nuclear weapons tests -- 150 sessions over a period of fourteen months -- has resumed work in Geneva in acrimonious deadlock but under increased pressure to reach agreement.
A suit to ban advertising on the outside of buses that use roads in or near city parks was dismissed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Jacob Markowitz.
BALBOA, C.Z. -- The value of the Panama Canal as a trade and defense asset for the entire Western Hemisphere was underlined both positively and negatively during 1959.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 12 -- President Sukarno has given himself the authority to ban or dissolve political parties opposed to the aims and principles of the state.
Diversification is paying dividends for Jamaica, the largest island in the West Indies Federation.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti -- This country appears on the verge of an economic comeback.
MEXICO CITY -- Japan, whose commercial relations with Mexico hit something of a low in recent years, came back to be an important supplier of Mexican imports in 1959.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay -- Uruguay joined the movement of South American countries toward exchange liberalism and monetary stabilization last year.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras -- More than $27,000,000 in loans from international organizations since 1956 and annual expenditures of more than $1,000,000 by United States agencies have been unsuccessful in lifting Honduras from the economic doldrums.
OTTAWA -- Canada will embark this year on a major research project that will probe deep into the secrets of the Arctic Ocean.
YESTERDAY (Jan. 12, 1960) THE GOVERNOR Conferred with Thomas Thatcher, State Insurance Superintendent, and with Dr. Herman E. Hilleboe, State Health Commissioner.

There is no pat phrase to describe the economy of the Americas in 1959, treated in our special annual section today. It was good, bad and indifferent, prosperous, critical and (in the case of Cuba) chaotic -- all depending which of the countries one looks at. At best, one can say that there has been uneven progress toward industrial development, which is the central feature of the hemisphere's economy.
PARIS, Jan. 12 -- The United States proposed today close links with Western Europe in a world-wide program of aid to underdeveloped nations and of general economic cooperation.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras -- Business men in Honduras are unhappy. They point to three factors they label "discouraging": The antipathy of the Government toward private enterprise, its preoccupation with "social" legislation, and its restrictionist measures.
On the day the porpoises passed his ship much faster than he thought they should have, Dr. Max O. Kramer knew they had the answer to a problem that could revolutionize underwater travel.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 12 -- Frank J. Matula Jr., high-ranking Teamsters Union official in Los Angeles, has received a three-week "freedom break" in his six-month county jail sentence on a perjury conviction.

WINNIPEG, Man. -- Four hundred miles north of here a new community has been hewn out of what was wilderness less than three years ago. It is the town of Thompson, site of a new nickel mining operation of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., and second only to Inco's Sudbury, Ont., operation as the biggest nickel-producing operation in the world.

ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- The Senate speedily completed legislative action today on Governor Rockefeller's proposal to grant a $25 income tax credit to "heads of households." The bill was signed into law two hours after the Senate had acted.
WILLEMSTAD, Curacao -- The Island chain of the Netherlands West Indies had a prosperous year in 1959, stemming from two facets: oil refining and tourist trade.
OTTAWA -- Canada continues to attract foreign capital from sources other than the United States and Britain.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee has received recommendations for a sweeping overhaul of United States foreign-policy machinery.

The oil pattern of the Western Hemisphere is undergoing a marked change. Reflecting the upsurge of production in the Eastern Hemisphere, which now has developed its own resources, oil operators in North and South America are in the midst of a program of readjustment.
The city moved yesterday to put on property owners a greater share of the liability for injuries resisting from sidewalk breaks or obstructions.
PANAMA -- Foreign and domestic trade as well as industrial and farm production carried over during 1959 at the same high level as 1958.

The New York Times sports car awards for 1959 were presented to four winners yesterday at the monthly meeting of the Madison Avenue Sports Car Driving and Chowder Society at Sardi's West Forty-fourth Street.

Mayor Wagner warned sixty of his top appointive aides yesterday that any city employe who failed to perform a full day's work would be replaced. That goes for everyone from department heads to the lowliest civil servant or provisional employe, he declared.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 12 -- On the initiative of the West Berlin city Government, a move is gaining momentum to reshape the teaching of history in West Germany schools.

MONTREAL -- The consensus of experts on the economic effects on Montreal of the first season of operation of the St. Lawrence Seaway is that it was not as good as prophesied and not as bad as had been feared.

An overwhelming majority of Presbyterian ministers responding to a recent church magazine poll stated that the religious affiliation of a Presidential candidate was relevant to his election. About one-half of those who replied said they would not vote for a Roman Catholic candidate under any circumstances.
MEXICO CITY -- In December Mexico finished the first year of the Administration of President Adolfo Lopez Mateos.
The "better late than never" theme ran through the letters of some of yesterday's contributors to the fund for New York's Neediest Cases.
MEXICO CITY -- The over all economic, picture for Central America and Panama was largely a poor one last year.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Here is a simple calculation which may interest anyone who dismisses the threat of overpopulation.
WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 12 (UPI) -- The State Supreme Court ruled yesterday that privately operated restaurants were not required by law to serve Negroes.
RIO DE JANEIRO -- The republics of Latin America took their first firm steps in 1959 toward a joint approach to the region's fundamental problems.
More than sixty prominent New Yorkers, many of them supporters of Adlai E. Stevenson in other campaigns, announced yesterday the formation of a Humphrey-for-President Committee, Eastern Division.
MONTREAL -- The construction boom Here is spearheaded by two major projects in downtown Montreal: Place Ville-Marie and the Windsor Plaza.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 -- The manger of Consolidated Electrodynamics Corporation, of Pasadena, Calif., into Bell Howell Company, of Chicago, was approved today by shareholders of both companies at meetings in their respective cities.
SANTIAGO, Chile -- A solid foundation was built last year for the economic rehabilitation of Chile. As a result, the country looks confidently to the new year and a final end to prolonged inflation.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The press and a number of civic organizations have greeted with enthusiasm J. Anthony Panuch's special report to the Mayor on New York City's relocation problem. There is danger that the reception accorded the report will leave the city with the impression that the report has solved the relocation problem.
In a 2-to-1 decision yesterday the United States Court of Appeals upset a lower court ruling that revoked the citizenship of Joseph Profaci, one of the twenty defendants in the Apalachin case.

Mayor Wagner put his long-range fiscal program, seeking $250,000,000 in new revenues, formally before Governor Rockefeller yesterday. He does not want all of it at once, the Mayor said, but "a start can and must be made this year."
A new device to test the nautical know-how and reactions of pleasure boat skippers will be introduced on Friday at the National Motor Boat Show in the New York Coliseum.
Joseph J. Lordi was elected to his second term as president of the New York Athletic Club by a unanimous vote at a special meeting at the city clubhouse last night.
Senator Styles Bridges suggested yesterday that the Republicans permit an open battle in selecting a running mate for Richard M. Nixon next July.

TORONTO -- One of the toughest road-building jobs ever tackled in Ontario will be completed next summer when construction crews finally close The Gap -- a rugged, granite-ribbed stretch of frontlerland north of Sault Ste. Marie.
TRENTON Jan. -- Following are excerpts from Gov. Robert B. Meyner's annual message delivered today before the New Jersey Legislature:
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 12 (UPI) -- Dow Finsterwald toot advantage of a stunning collapse by Eric Monti today and won the $37,500 Los Angeles open with a 72-hole score of 280.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Articles in the press concerning the National Aeronautics and Space Administration may lead one to believe that the sole function of this splendid organization is to see that the free world takes the lead in space developments.

A disgruntled merchant seaman attacked Federal Judge John M. Cashin yesterday with a penknife but was overpowered by a clerk and a bailiff before he could harm the judge. The bailiff was cut severely on the palm of his right hand.
The Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday that 729 persons had been injured in traffic last week.
Jewelers say a lot of curiosity has been raised by almost identical insertions that have been made in newspapers by Tiffany Co., Van Cleef Arpels and Cartier, Inc. One of the insertions reads:

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The projected visit by President Eisenhower to South America is of special significance. His recent appointment of a commission to investigate Latin-American affairs indicated recognition of a disquieting situation throughout the Caribbean area as well as South America.

MEXICO CITY -- In 1952, a naturalized Italian immigrant tried unsuccessfully to sell the Mexican Government some seamless steel tube manufacturing machinery in a transaction considered to be advantageous all the way around.

Restoration to the voting rolls of 1,377 Negroes in a Louisiana parish by order of a Federal court is the first positive result of the Civil Rights Act of 1957. After this it will be impossible to say that the power given under this law to the Attorney General to institute civil suits to protect voting rights is ineffective or meaningless.
Four persons were injured yesterday afternoon leaping twenty feet from a Brooklyn factory building during a fifty-minute fire.
EDMONTON, Alberta -- Since the end of World War II, gas and oil have been eating steadily into the markets once powered by coal in western Canada.
BOGOTA, Colombia -- Most business experts here use the same word to describe Colombia's economic recovery in 1959: "incredible."
SAN SALVADOR -- The new year finds El Salvador stressing industrialization to soften the impact of the drop in world prices for two chief exports, coffee and, to a lesser extent, cotton.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Senator Stuart Symington made his bow today in a role that some supporters hope will enhance his stature as a Presidential aspirant.

The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad took on the New York Central Railroad yesterday in a finish fight to nail down, the two railroads respective rights to $400,000,000 of Park Avenue real estate.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 12 -- More than 200 persons were arrested here today and will be sent to labor camps and other correctional institutions in an aftermath of yesterday's rioting.
SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., Jan. 12 (AP) -- Olympic planners today dropped Rumania from the list of competing nations for the Feb. 18-28 winter games here.
ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- Governor Rockefeller declared today that the responsibility for spending local school money and the power to raise that money by taxes should go hand in hand.

TWO exceptionally well-en-dowed exhibitions of drawings and prints are on view this week. The drawings, mostly by twentieth-century masters, are shown at the Iolas Gallery, 123 East Fifty-fifth Street.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 12 (UPI) -- Bob Waterfield signed today as head coach of the Los Angeles Rams.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Republican leaders emerged from a White House conference today with a challenge to the Democratic Congressional majorities to pass meaningful civil rights legislation and hold down Federal spending.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 12 (AP) -- C.V. Whitney's Silver Spoon scored a two-length victory today in the $20,000-added Santa Monica Handicap at Santa Anita.
SAN SALVADOR -- The drive for industrialization in El Salvador resulted in the construction of two new plants last year and the prospects of more in the near future.

An affirmation of his previous decision that policemen have a legal right to stop, question and search suspects was made yesterday by Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman, who presided at the recent Apalachin trial.
DETROIT, Jan. 12 (UPI) -- Three months ago creditors seized a Greek ship sailing under Panamanian registry here and more than $100,000 in debt claims eventually were filed against the ship.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. -- Thirty years ago Chile embarked on a forestation program from which the country is now in a position to reap gratifying rewards. The objective was reclamation of land unsuited to agriculture.

QUEBEC -- The discovery that rich deposits of iron ore lie just beneath the surface of what not long ago was regarded as a worthless wilderness has revived a boundary dispute between Quebec and Newfoundland.

SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., Jan. 12 (AP) -- The first contingent of Marines landed today, the United States speed skaters worked out and the ticket director for the winter games revealed that 112,646 admissions had been sold.
A contract to buy the six-story apartment house at 324-26 East Fifty-sixth Street has been sold by Enkells-Rakoff Co. to Frank and Vincent S. Grasso.
Adam Clayton Powell Jr., the Democratic Representative from Harlem, said yesterday he expected to meet this week-end with District Attorney Frank S. Hogan at their "mutual convenience."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- A flood of bids for $1,500,000,000 of one-year Government securities produced prices that will cost the Treasury an average of 5.067 per cent and will give the investors an average yield of 5.36 per cent on the money invested.
The New York County Lawyers Assocation disclosed yesterday that its report to the Mayor on former Magistrate Robert F. Mahoney had dealt with the magistrate's practices in traffic court.
Heavy production and low prices was the story in the cocoa market last year, a situation expected to continue this year.

BUENOS AIRES -- Two major pipelines linking the northern oilfields of Salta to Argentina's centers of consumption were completed late last year. Huge new gas and light crude oil reserves thus were tapped.

LONDON, Jan. 12 -- Sir Anthony Eden recounts in the third installment of his memoirs how the late Secretary of State Dulles came to make his famous "agonizing reappraisal'' statement in Paris in December, 1953.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The United States put its chips on liquid hydrogen today as the super-energy rocket fuel that will make the United States a contender in heavy space vehicles.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 6:

BOSTON, Jan. 13 -- "By squeezing the water out of the curriculum," the reform of the nation's high schools is beginning to give colleges a "teachable freshman." But the colleges now must realize that graduates of good high schools find the first two years of college "dull and repetitive."

LONDON,. Jan. 13 -- A British company announced today that it had contracted to buy the Cross County Shopping Center in Yonkers, N.Y., through a Canadian subsidiary from Cross Properties, Inc. The price was $22,500,000.

ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- New York City will receive an increase in state aid for its schools this year through a revision of the formula for the distribution of money. The revision will be state-wide in its application.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The Civil Rights Commission's proposal for Federal voting registrars got a chilly reception today from President Eisenhower.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- President Eisenhower withheld today a formal endorsement of Vice President Nixon's candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination. But he left little doubt at his news conference that it would be forthcoming.
Much of the recent vigor that made for rising prices and broad volume in the bond market petered out yesterday.

A Nation and Statistics As a nation we have long been devoted to statistics with many offices both public and private preparing figures upon figures that can tell us at a glance just what and how much we eat, where we are going and where we have come from, which pursuits mainly occupy our time, and the answers to hundreds of other equally vital questions.
PARIS, Jan. 13 -- On economic matters Wilfred Siegfried Baumgartner, designated today as Minister of Finance, is cut from the same conservative cloth as the man he succeeds, Antoine Pinay.
TWO cooking classes of a semi-informal nature and with an international flavor will open in Manhattan next week.
The Grand Street Settlement will again venture into the realm of the never-never when it holds a "Let's Pretend Dance" as part of its special drive to raise $350,000.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 13 -- Prime Minister Macmillan has thwarted Sir Roy Welensky's dream of early independence for the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland.
LONDON, Jan. 13 -- The Labor party appealed to the British people today to boycott consumer goods from South Africa during March.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 13 -- Stu Sherard, a diminutive sophomore from Marshall, Mo., paced Army to an 80-to-70 basketball victory over the University of Massachusetts today. He tallied 34 points as the once-beaten cadets rallied for their ninth victory of the season.
MIAMI BEACH, Jan, 13 (UPI) -- The college football rules - makers today voted coaches unrestricted use of the "wild-card" substitute for 1960.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Jan. 13 -- Hofstra's basketball team gained its twelfth victory in thirteen starts this season by defeating Manhattan, 67 -- 57, today. The setback was Manhattan's fifth in ten games.

Futures prices moved in narrow ranges yesterday in generally dull trading on the New York exchanges. Potatoes, cottonseed oil, hides and coffee rose; cocoa, sugar and zinc declined, and price movements for wool, rubber, lead and copper were mixed.
Rabbi Irving Miller, chairman of the American Zionist Council, said last night that acts of anti-Semitic vandalism were a blight on civilization.
"If Tommy Thompson were around today as a boxer he would be a top lightweight contender."

MANILA, Jan. 13 -- Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, the Philippine Ambassador to Washington, is treading a thin line of diplomacy between the nationalist sentiments of the Government hen and maintenance of normal relations with the United States.
Mayor Wagner yesterday sent the name of former Magistrate Robert F. Mahoney to the city and county bar associations, asking for a report on his fitness for the bench "as soon as feasible."
MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Jan. 13 -- A tragedy on the highways has touched off one of the suburb's biggest good-neighbor endeavors.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 13 -- A Chamber of Commerce official warned the Board of Select-men today that Greenwich would become an "unimportant shopping suburb" of near-by Stamford if it approved a proposed new parking pattern for the business district.
ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- Governor Rockefeller, continuing to speak out on national issues, tonight criticized the Eisenhower Administration's rural development program.

MOBILE, Ala., Jan. 13 (AP) -- Six persons were injured tonight when a section of wooden bleacherst collapsed at Fort Whiting auditorium shortly before the fight between Kenny Lane and Ralph Dupas. The six were taken to a hospital.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UPI) -- Following is a transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference here this morning:

Thirty-seven persons and nine corporations called to testify in the state's investigation into the operations of a one-room insurance concern in Tangier accused of having "insubstantial assets failed to appear yesterday.

The annual Great Teachers Awards of the Society of Older Graduates of Columbia University were presented last night to Douglas Moore, MacDowell Professor of Music, and to Dr. Raymond D. Mindlin, Professor of Civil Engineering.
People who work in the world of books gathered to pay another tribute yesterday to Joseph Margolies, who is retiring as manager of the World Affairs Center Bookshop.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The Government plans another bonds-for-mortgages exchange within the next month. It would be about the same as the one made last fall.

The consumption last week of the nation's stocks of light fuel oil, used mainly for home heating, was more than double that of the week before.

TOKYO, Jan. 13 (Reuters) -- Japanese shipowners will receive 1,000,000,000 yen (about $2,800,000) in subsidies during the new financial year beginning April 1, a Transport Ministry spokesman said today.

The Missouri Pacific Railroad, like most other carriers, has been considering the practicability of opening merger studies with some connecting lines. Among these carriers is the Chicago and Eastern Illinois Railroad.

NICE, France, Jan. 13 -- An appartus for taking samples of microscopic life on Mars, if there is any, is now being designed at the Stanford University School of Medicine at Palo Alto, Calif., by Dr. Joshua Lederberg, the Nobel laureate.

A SUIT, headed by A-K is usually the best possible opening lead. The leader wins the trick; he sees the dummy, which helps him to plan his future defense; he retains the lead, so he can immediately put his plan into operation; and he still has control of the suit he opened.

CONCORD, N.H., Jan. 13 (AP) -- A television cowboy singer opened a well publicized bid today to become President of the United States. Meanwhile, a brother of President Eisenhower announced that ha was not a candidate "under any circumstances."
A serious decline in the caliber of medical students is beginning to worry observers in American education and medicine.
A cross-section of American music, from, the Civil War figure of Gottschalk to the very contemporary Leon Kirchner, was played last night in Carnegie Hall by the Orchestra of America.

TWO ballets, both by George Balanchine, were restored to the season's repertory by the New York City Ballet at the City Center last night. They were "Scotch Symphony," to the music of Mendelssohn, and "Square Dance," to music of Corelli and Vivaldi.

LONDON, Jan. 13 -- Sir Anthony Eden told today of "unhappily timed" intervention by the late Secretary of State Dulles during the British leader's effort to find a means of including a rearmed Germany in the Western Alliance.

California went ahead yesterday with the salt of $100,000,000 of building construction and veterans' aid bonds despite the fact that market conditions had worsened since the sale was postponed from Dec. 9.
THE Ninth Annual Ice Skating Carnival for children 8 to 17 years old will be held on Saturday from noon to 2 P.M. at the Wollman Memorial Skating Rink in Central Park. Admission is free.

Despite continued political, military and economic differences in Western Europe the Paris economic conference has approved, in principle, an ambitious American plan for a North Atlantic Trade Organization. The plan is designed to achieve in the economic field, and on a wider basis, what the North Atlantic alliance is intended to achieve in the military field.
A few of the esthetes who live in the 193 studios in Carnegie Hall have been thought eccentric just because they danced all night or throbbed with occultism all day.

Stiff prison sentences and fines were given yesterday to twenty men convicted on Dec. 18 of conspiracy to conceal the true purpose of the gangland gathering at Apalachin, N.Y., in 1957. Before imposing sentence, Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman characterized the defendants as hardened and unregenerate gangsters who had led double lives of crime and respectability.

The Carrier Corporation had record sales and increased earnings in the fiscal year ended Oct. 31, according to the annual report of the producer of air conditioners, industrial machinery and electric power-generating equipment.

Many hardy souls with sufficient stamina to observe two New Year's celebrations in a fortnight turned out last night for the eleventh annual Bal Blanc in the Grand Ballroom of the Astor. The winter's worst storm struck New York State and Connecticut yesterday, leaving up to nine inches of snow, fallen power lines and treacherous road conditions.
Prices on the New York Stock Exchange returned to Dec. 3 levels yesterday as two strong upward movements failed to carry through.

Dunhill International, Inc., the tobacco concern, continues to follow a policy of diversifying its interests, according to the latest insiders' list released by the New York Stock Exchange. The report shows that last month Dunhill bought 21,500 shares of Coty, Inc., the cosmetics company.

Charles W. Ufford Jr., the second seeded player, moved through the second round of the New York State squash racquets singles championship yesterday at the Downtown Athletic Club courts.

"Memoirs of Hecate County," Edmund Wilson's satirical story of life in suburbia, is under consideration for stage and screen. Rights to the controversial book are at the point of being acquired by Ray Wander and Jeffrey Hayden, husband of Eva Marie Saint.

Robert Mitchum will join Cary Grant and Deborah Kerr in Universal - International's "The Grass Is Greener," which starts shooting in Ireland in April. Stanley Donen is scheduled to direct the comedy, which is based on a British play by Hugh and Margaret Williams.

The prosperous Port of New York Authority will retire $30,000,000 more of debt this year than it has to.

A one-story taxpayer occupying a plot 60 by 100 feet at 242 Jackson Avenue Jersey City has been sold by Herbert Lieblein. It was bought by William Hionas for cash over a purchase money mortgage. The building is under a twenty-one-year net lease to Wilnat Stores, Inc., a chain known as Carter's.
LONDON, Jan. 14 -- The couturiers of London announced today that they will carry the war and their tweedy styles to the enemy's ground -- in Paris.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Housing construction activity showed Improvement In December for the Second consecutive month, the Commerce Department estimated today.

BATON ROUGE, La., Jan. 14 -- Dr. George H. Mickey, dean of the Louisiana State Univerisity Graduate School and internationally known biologist, was arrested today and charged with the murder of a 38-year-old woman biology professor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The chairman of a Senate subcommittee making a general investigation of air safety said today that a plane that disintegrated over North Carolina on Jan. 6 had been blown up by a bomb.
CHICAGO, Jan. 14 -- The Government filed notice of appeal to the Supreme Court today in its eleven-year-old antitrust suit against E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co.

The Boxing Writers Association held its annual dinner in the peaceful purlieus of the Sert Room at the Waldorf Astoria last night. Some 500 devotees of the ring sport turned out for the thirty-fourth annual affair presented by the organization.
WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 14 -- How do school boards pestered by all the skyrocketing problems of school growth and costs feel about Governor Rockefeller's proposal to give them power to levy taxes?

Average borrowings by member banks from the Federal Reserve dropped $102,000,000 to $911,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Average reserve balances in excess of requirements increased $74,000,000 to $583,000,000.

HAVANA, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The Cuban Government has started taking over sugrarcane land from both Cuban and United States owners. The expropriations had not been expected until the end of the harvest, seven months off, or at least until the current harvest was well under way.

ON the northwest coast of Sicily some forty miles west of Palermo lies the city of Castellammare. It is as picturesque as most Sicilian cities and the views along the near-by shore are spectacularly beautiful. But the scenic beauty that surrounds them provides little solace to the inhabitants of the area, who are among the most miserable of any people in Europe.
McCann-Ericksn, Inc., appears well on the road to reorganizing itself along the line of a General Motors Corporation -- or perhaps an army.

The Federal Maritime Board announced yesterday a set of new proposed rules covering the filing of agreements by steamship lines operating as common carriers subject to Section 15 of the Shipping Act of 1916.
The Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, L.I., said yesterday it had started an intensive evaluation of its curriculum.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported the following spot primary market prices for the dates shown:
A freakish incident yesterday prevented the completion of the 12-pound open shot-put event of the eleventh annual Cardinal Hayes' schoolboy track and field meet.
A 9-week-old Brooklyn baby who has an allergy to all food except mother's milk was being fed yesterday on human milk airlifted from Evanston, III., 900 miles away.
The city schools were directed yesterday to be "on the alert for youngsters who may need guidance to correct dangerous prejudices that could lead them into trouble."

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 14 -- The head of the largest Jewish Orthodox rabbinical body in the United States took sharp issue here today with a recent assertion that Orthodox Judaism dominated the religious life in Israel.
Louis Armstrong broke up his wife's birthday party and tool her along to help treat 400 youngsters on the West Side to a free show.
MONTREAL, Jan. 14 (UPI) -- The Montreal Canadiens scored a 3-1 victory tonight over the second-place Toronto Maple Leafs and increased their National Hockey League lead to 13 points.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Rail and truck loadings rose last week following the New Year holiday. Rail loadings were 22.5 per cent above the level of the preceding week, with increases in every category of freight.

BOSTON, Jan. 14 (UPI) -- Don Simmons, Boston's goalie, recorded his second straight shutout and six of his teammates shared in the scoring tonight as the Bruins gained 6-0 triumph over the last-place New York Rangers.

Specialists in Soviet affair suggested yesterday that Premier Khrushchev might be employing Stalin's old balancing tactics to maintain equilibrium between his ambition and aggressive Communist party lieutenants.

Brunswick-Balke CHICAGO, Jan. 14 (UPI) -- Brunswick - Balke - Collender Company said today it planned to acquire Union Hardware Company of Torrington, Conn., for 93,500 shares of unissued common stock.
GREENPORT, L.I., Jan. 14 -- The sleek lines of an ocean cruising-racing yacht are taking form in a shipyard at this former whaling port.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (UPI) -- Secretary Ezra Taft Benson said today that the Department of Agriculture strongly endorsed the use of "carefully tested chemicals" to maintain the unexcelled quality of American food.
The big names -- Ancarrow, Century, Chris-Craft and Trojan, among others -- and several that are new and hopeful have entered the inboard-runabout field.
Governor Rockefeller endorsed "in principle" yesterday a statutory change that would add $25,000,000 to the state's contributions toward school operating costs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- President Eisenhower has answered Congressional criticism of his space program by ordering an accelerated development of super-thrust space rockets and asking changes in the basic law.
CHICAGO, Jan. 14 (AP) -- General selling hit old-crop wheat and soybean futures today and prices sagged a cent to more than 2 cents a bushel on the Board of Trade.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: New York lost two of its finest citizens early this week by the death of Edwin F. Chinlund and George W. Perkins. These two men rose to high position in the business world, but they were both unique in the degree to which their patriotism and sense of public responsibility compelled them to public service.

STRATFORD - ON - AVON, England, Jan. 14 (Reuters) -- The Shakespeare Memorial Theatre and its annual series of plays are in for a sweeping overhaul at the hands of the theatre's 29-year-old director, Peter Hall.
"The Play of the Week," with a benevolent sponsor waiting in the wings, listed four more plays yesterday for presentation on Channel 13.

LEE LUVISI, 22-year-old pianist from Kentucky, gave a program last night in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium under the auspices of the Young Artists Series. He played a Bach-Busoni chorale prelude, the entire Op. 76 set of Brahms piano pieces, Schumann's G minor Sonata, the Bartok Suite, Chopin's Andante Spianato and Polonaise and the Kreisler-Rach-maninoff "Liebesfreud."
BALTIMORE -- A visit to the plant of the Owens Yacht Company, Inc., here disclosed power boats being built by the mile. It is a mass-production operation that resembles an automobile assembly line.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Gen. Lyrman L. Lemnitzer, Army Chief of Staff, does not share all the critical views of his predecessor about Defense Department organization.
The Florida State University is planning the sale of $9,846,000 of housing revenue certificates on Jan. 27. The issue will come due serially from 1961 to 1999.

KITZBUEHEL, Austria, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The three-day Hahnenkamm ski races, which have the aspect of a dress rehearsal for the Winter Olympics, begin tomorrow with giant slalom races for 118 men and eighty-one women from twenty nations.
Defense lawyers sought in court yesterday to prevent Governor Rockefeller from getting the grand jury minutes that led to the indictment of Borough President Hulan E. Jack.
GENEVA, Jan. 14 -- The representatives of the world's three nuclear powers talked today about a man nobody knows.
A $7,993,400 commitment to subsidize the 15-cent fare on franchised private bus lines for the next two years was voted by the Board of Estimates yesterday.

Senator Hubert H. Humphrey drew Democratic cheers here last night when he defied what he called warnings that he would "not be acceptable to certain elements in the Democratic party" because of his demand for full civil rights for all.

NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 14 -- State Senator Abner W. Sibal of this city announced today that he was a candidate for the Republican nomination for Congress from the Fourth Congressional District (Fairfield County).
Bishop James A. Pike proposed last night that the Federal Government start a "crash program'' to perfect the rhythm method of birth control as a means of limiting population.
Directors of Prentice-Hall, Inc., yesterday proposed a stock split to be effected through a 50 per cent stock dividend for distribution to shareholders of record of April 15.
More than l,000 members of the United States Power Squadrons will begin a series of meetings today in the Astor Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- E. R. Quesada, administrator of the Federal Aviation Agency, emphasized today that the February crash of an American Airlines plane into the East River was not caused by the absence of approach lights at La Guardia Airport.

Although many tickets have been sold for the theatre benefit of the Manhattan Society for Mental Health, some still remain for the Jan. 26 event. It will be the performance of "The Miracle Worker" at the Playhouse Theatre.
Experimental evidence that chicken eggs can cause cancer in laboratory animals has been reported in a leading American scientific journal.
The International Maritime Workers Union, an offspring of the National Maritime Union and the Seafarers International Union, goes to Federal District Court today to defend its existence.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Strong opposition slowed today an effort to make primary elections and nominating conventions subject to a proposed new law on campaign spending.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Following is the text of a speech by Senator John F. Kennedy Democrat of Massachusetts, at the National Press Club today:
BANGALORE, India, Jan. 11 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru declared tonight that India had no alternative but to follow a socialistic path if her economy was to develop rapidly.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Officials in Washington described Premier Khrushchev's Speech to the Supreme Soviet today as a major propaganda effort. Its purpose, they said, was to put increased pressure on the West in advance of coming top-level negotiations.
Municipal Court Justice Free 3. Moritt has written the score and lyrics for a musical version of "The Barretts of Wimpole Street," Katharine Cornell's greatest hit to date.
A post-New Year gift of salary increases was presented by the Board of Estimate yesterday to the top justices of four city courts.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- Dr. Charles Hill, Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster, condemned anti-Semitism in West Germany and Britain today. Recent antiJewish incidents, the Cabinet Minister said, seemed to go doeper than pure anti-Semitism although this was the mask assumed.
THE Acting Borough President of Manhattan, Louis Anthony Cioffi, is a stocky, black-haired man of 43 years.

The smaller colleges appear to be the chief beneficiaries of the change in the football substitution rule adopted Wednesday. The talent-loaded advocates of outright two-platoon specialization undoubtedly will not be satisfied with the latest liberalization.
ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- A list of "who's eligible" for the new $25 Income tax credit for "heads of households" was issued today by the State Tax Commission.

The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission suggested yesterday that the three television networks and their affiliated stations set aside 7:30 to 8 P.M., Monday through Friday, for public servvice programing on a weekly rotating basis.

A research scientist, Dr. Otmar Silberstein, plans to spend much of next week in his Staten Island laboratory studying roast beef. He will cook it, carve it, taste it, prod it and generally submit the meat to critical scrutiny.
The first major legislative business of the Senate in the present session is the bill to revise the antiquated campaign expenditures law, which in its essence has been on the books since 1925.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The tight-money policy in 1959 had one of its intended effects -- to curb the growth of the money supply.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 14 -- The Pacific Gas and Electric Company received word here today that the Government of Alberta had authorized an increase in the amount of natural gas a P.G. E. subsidiary hopes to import into this country from Canada.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Property damage has been found to account for most of the direct cost of motor vehicle accidents, it was disclosed in a survay today.
MOSCOW, Jan. 14 -- Premier Khrushchev said today that the Soviet Union intended to reduce its standing armed forces by one-third in the next year or two, from 3,623,000 to 2,423,000 men.

THE Gatti restaurant, newly established at 246 East Fortieth Street, has a relaxed, Old World atmosphere typical of some trattoria in Florence or Rome. The vaulted ceiling, plain red brick walla and fanciful wrought-iron grillwork set the mood for a fine meal in the best Italian tradition.
New and faster turbine helicopters have been ordered by New York Airways to replace the piston-engine types now in use.
PARIS, Jan. 14 -- President de Gaulle will hold a special conference next week on Algeria.
CHICAGO, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
In the world of banking and borrowing the big news frequently tends to be made by changes in the prime rate -- the interest charged to the very best credit risks. It now stand at 5 per cent.

The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, big food store chain, raised its quarterly dividend yesterday with a declaration of 25 cents. Its directors also voted a 3 per cent stock dividend. Both are payable on Feb. 24 to holders of record on Jan. 25.

A HOST of problems that have bothered women for years have been efficiently designed out of existence by the nation's housewares manufacturers. Common sense rather than gimmicks govern most of the improvements of products shown at the National Housewares Exhibit in Chicago this week.
AFTER the banaiities of Broadway it tones the muscles and freshens the system to examine the squalor of Off Broadway.

George Washington's highscoring Colonials, averaging 75 points a game, meet the Redmen of St. John's University at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory tonight in the metropolitan area's top basketball game.

NO longer can there be any doubt about it. With the inexorability of surf pounding against a sea wall, the adherents of two-platoon football hammer ceaselessly against the crumbling bulkhead of the college rules committee. Every year new pieces break away in a continuing process of erosion and eventually unlimited substitutions will tumble over the weakened barrier to flood the rich lowlands beyond.
Comparing clothing labels, once the sport of Brooks Brothers boulevardiers and Harris Tweed dandies, may come into vogue for National Football League fans next season.
MEMPHIS, Jan. 14 (UPI) -- Charlie Flowers of Mississippi today said, "I wouldn't play with the New York Giants now under any conditions."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Senator Kenneth B. Keating said today that the United States jurisdictional veto seriously impaired the World Court and hurt American interests.

The directors of the Standard Packaging Corporation will hold a special meeting today to consider terms for a possible acquisition of Brown Bigelow, a leading manufacturer of calendars and other advertising specialties.

The larger New York City banks continue to take an "unrealistic" attitude with respect to interest rates on consumer installment loans, a small bank that is a major lender in this field contended yesterday in its annual report.
TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 14 -- Premier Manouchehr Eghbat charged today that the Communists had helped to incite the student riots here last Montey.

The Federal Reserve System reduced its holdings of Goverment securities $411,300,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This was its largest open-market liquidation since Jan. 8, 1958 when its holdings of Govenments went down $493,000,000.
Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad sold yesterday $4,350,000 of equipment trust certificates to investment bankers led by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc. on a bid of 99,512 with a cent coupon.

Premier Khrushchev denied yesterday that the decision to reduce Soviet armed manpower was a sign of economic weakness. However, in the last three months at least three indications of a strain on resources in the Soviet Union have appeared.

The six-story building containing seventy-six apartments at 2116 Ditmas Avenut, Brooklyn, has been sold by the 2116 Realty Corporation to an Investor for cash over two mortgages. Irving Bira and Solomon Tucker were the brokers.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Senator John F. Kennedy proclaimed his intention today of exercising "the fullest powers" of the office if he were elected President.

This year's "two-in-one" boat show required the National Association of Engine and Boat Manufacturers; the sponsor, to lease the Coliseum for twice the time it is open to the public. The event spans ten day. Twenty days will elapse between the time the first exhibit entered the building and the last one leaves.

CATTLEMEN seem to be allowing their livestock a slightly longer lease on life, judging by the low veal and high beef, supplies of recent months. Prices have climbed on several veal cuts this week, while beef, although in good supply, remains at last week's cost levels.
HONG KONG, Jan. 9 -- The number of refugees arriving Hong Kong from Communist China has increased with onslaught of winter -- a grim winter in China by all accounts.
ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- The opening salvos were fired today in the 1960 skirmish of the political and social battle over a residency requirement for relief recipients.
OTTAWA, Jan. 14 -- Governor General George P. Vanier opened the third session of Canada's twenty-fourth Parliament today amid scenes of traditional pomp.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Democratic politicians are buzzing over the statement made in New Hampshire yesterday by Robert F. Kennedy that he will "advise" his brother, Senator Kennedy of Massachusetts, not to contest the Wisconsin primary with Senator Humphrey of Minnesota because special local conditions would make "unfair" this particular test of the party's Presidential preference.

Low-price issues led a stock market rally yesterday that won back about 7.3 per cent of the ground lost since Jan. 5. There were gains in most leading groups and only the chemicals showed uncertainty.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower nominated today G. Frederick Reinhardt of San Francisco, a career foreign service officer, to be Ambassador to the United Arab Republic.

Those Interested mainly in outboards at the show will find more boats that look like boats than there were two years ago or even last year, the automotive fin that for a while amounted to a craze in the field was less evident last winter.

The twenty-three outboard cruisers in the show, a record number for the type, range from a 17-foot boat to a 24-footer. They have facilities for living afloat and are built of molded plywood, sheet plywood and fiberglass.

THE year Columbus discovered America, a composer from what is now southwest Belgium, who was entering middle age, was helping with the music of the Papal Chapel in Rome. His name was Josquin des Pres, and last night the Dessoff Choirs gave a program of his music at Town Hall.
Harlem was recovering yesterday from the shock it suffered upon the indictment of Hulan E. Jack.
DACULA, Ga., Jan. 14 -- Another day in the education, of a hunter traveling with a dog has gone by without disaster and with a certain amount of progress.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 14 (UPI) -- The Calumet Farm's On-and-On shaped up as the favorite among twelve horses entered today for the 550,000 added Tropical Handicap which features tomorrow's closing day at Tropical Park.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- John L. Lewis formally stepped down today as president of the United Mine Workers of America, Thomas Kennedy, vice president, was elevated to the presidency by the union's international executive board.

Roosevelt Raceway yesterday revealed it would offer a record total of $1,265,000 in stakes and feature races this year. This is almost twice as much money as it offered for last year's stakes and special races.
Large rent reductions, a jail sentence and heavy fines were imposed on neglectful landlords and agents yesterday from two sources -- housing court and the State Rent Administration.
ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- The city of Oswego took steps today to convert its harbor into a deepwater facility capable of handling major shipping in and out of the St. Lawrence Seaway.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 14 -- Top-level conferences of movie executives have started here in an effort to avert a strike of actors that may end movie production here the end of this month.

MOSCOW, Jan. 14 -- Premier Khrushchev expressed confidence today that the Soviet Union would fulfill its ambitious Seven-Year Plan before 1965, its expiration date. Production goals in important sectors will be exceeded before then, he asserted.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The director of the Government's grain storage program testified today that he had sold his grain elevator interests to his son before he took the Federal Job.

IF Egon Schiele had not been felled by the 1918 influenza epidemic at the age of 28, he might well have been among the unmistakably great artists of the century. As it is, Schiele, who is represented, at the Bayer Gallery, 51 East Eightieth Street, with sixteen paintings and drawings in an exhibition of German and Austrian art, stands firmly ensconced in history as a draftsman of great originality.
NICE, France, Jan. 14 -- group of politically minded scientists are working to get support for a cooperative European space research project.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- Industrial shares again moved irregularly in the stock market here today, but the undertone was described as firmer than yesterday's. Selling pressure was lighter, and a predominance of gains among the thirty common shares making up the Financial Times industrial stock index lifted the average a point to 331.3.
Several key airlines in the deadlocked dispute over international air fares are scheduled to meet some time next week to discuss possible areas of agreement, trade sources reported yesterday.

FROM the screaming, bravaing and commotion last night in Town Hall, one night have thought that the concert was, at the very least, a Liszt program played by Vladimir Horowitz. It was nothing of the sort.

A New Jersey man was arrested yesterday and charged with attempted grand larceny, following his admission to the Waterfront Commission that he had falsely promised union membership and jobs to about twenty men in return for a fee of $132 each.
Bond issues amounting to $34,550,000 were posted for sale yesterday by Texas municipal government bodies.
IN his new composition, "Spectra," Gunther Schuller has reseated the orchestra to bypass "the acoustically insurmountable ensemble problems" of nineteenth-century procedures.
The Big Count is getting under way.
A labor leader pledged the support of merged labor yesterday to agencies fighting the exploitation of Puerto Rican workers.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- A manufacturer of electronic equipment has invented a key that is made by breaking off a piece of the lock. The parts must match exactly or the door cannot be opened.

FREDERICK ASHTON'S "Illuminations," an extraordinarily sensitive and original fantasia on the life and poetry of Rimbaud, was revived by the New York City Ballet last night at the City Center after much too long an absence from the repertory.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Average wholesale primary market prices rose 0.2 per cent to 119.1 per cent of their 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Israel will require a total investment of $750,000,000 for economic development in the next five years, the executive head of the Israel Bond Organization said yesterday.
A man and wife "blessed with fifty-four years together" sent $5 to New York's Neediest Cases yesterday to celebrate their wedding anniversary.

CLARE Potter and Hope Hendler joined forces this week to present their ideas on spring. The clothes, by Miss Potter, and the hats, by Miss Hendler, were shown against a backdrop of pink and white striped denim and masses of camellias.
DETROIT, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Ward's Automotive Reports said today that new car sales for the first ten days of January were slower than expected in some quarters.

PARAMUS, N.J., Jan. 15 A masked bandit shot and killed a salesman and wounded two other employes tonight in an attempted hold-up of Bamberer's department store in the Garden State Plaza shopping center.
Soccer showed substantial expansion last year in American high Schools and colleges, Donald Yonker, president of the National Soccer Coaches Association, said yesterday.
CHICAGO, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Grain futures prices leveled off within a mostly steady range today after withstanding two setbacks that pared major fractions off several contracts.

PARIS. This otherwise tranquil Continental winter has been marred by a singularly unpleasant development. Nasty little rats, hiding since Hitlerism's crash, have emerged from their holes to scurry about with vicious messages of bigotry.

WASHINGTON Jan. 15 (AP) -- Senator Barry Goldwater said today that his office in Phoenix, Ariz., "inadvertently" had leaked out a tentative report written by Republican members of the Senate rackets committee. The Republicans had denounced some of their Democratic associates on the committee.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 15 (AP) -- The Kentucky Derby winner, Tomy Lee, and First Landing renew an old argument tomorrow in the $50,000-added San Fernando Stakes at Santa Anita.

Some 50,000,000 customers in the United States will spend $10,000,000 every day for the next ten years to buy large kitchen and home laundry appliances. That was the prediction yesterday of John F. McDaniel, general sales manager of the General Electric Company's Hotpoint division.
PARIS, Jan. 15 -- In bitterly cold weather, the all-Negro musical "Free and Easy," by Harold Arlen and Johnny Mercer, came to Paris tonight and received a warm reception.

ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- Governor Rockefeller today proposed the abandonment of the state's eighteen truck-weighing stations. They are the principal enforcement arm of the truck weight-mileage tax that has been imposed since 1951.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is regrettable that our Government should have endorsed the Suez loan to Nasser without exacting specific guarantees from the Egyptian dictator that he will henceforth respect the rights of all nations to unrestricted use of the canal.

A FEW days ago a bridge teacher in New York sought to get in touch with Dudley Courtenay and discovered that neither the American Contract Bridge League nor the Bridge World magazine could give him Mr. Courtenay's present address.

GAINESVILLE, Fla., Jan. 15 -- Vice President Nixon said tonight that a Congress reacting to election-year pressures would have "gravely damaged" the collective-bargaining process if it had been asked to settle the steel strike.

LONDON, Jan. 15 -- Industrial shares ended the week on a rising note in the stock market here today. Gains of a shilling (14 cents) or so were common, particularly among the leaders and the Financial Times industrial common stock index responded with a rise of 2.9 points to 334.2.

CHARLES ROBBERTS SWART made the speech from the throne at the opening of South Africa's Parliament yesterday. In doing so, he represente'd Queen Elizabeth II, the sovereign whom he has said his country will renounce when it becomes a republic loosely linked with the British Commonwealth.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 15 -- Pakistan has refused to allow Israel to send an observer to a United Nations meeting scheduled for Karachi.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UPI) -- The United States Tariff Commission heard further requests today that quotas on lead and zinc be abolished.
The Sunday hour from 9 to 10 P.M. on National Broadcasting Company television is continuing its efforts to inject occasonal foreign flavor by the way of entertainment.
Less than a dozen major fixed-interest securities are slated for the market next week. The volume involved is some $110,000,000, compared with about three times that amount this week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Pentagon experts pointed today to the similarity between the Soviet military strategy enunciated by Premier Khrushchev yesterday and the United States strategic policy. Basically, the strategy is to rely on nuclear weapons instead of conventional forces.
About the only thing missing in the Grand Ballroom of the Astor last night to make a habitue of the French Riviera feel completely home was a breeze off the Mediterranean.
Freezing rain and fog hampered motorists in the metropolitan area and elsewhere in the Northeast yesterday, causing many skidding accidents and tie-ups and making many persons late for work.

LONDON, Jan. 15 -- Britain's Court of Criminal Appeal annulled today the convictions of three men by a Nottingham court because the judge had told the jury to reach a verdict within ten minutes lest the members be locked up for the night.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Adlai E. Stevenson today lauded President Eisenhower's forthcoming trip to Latin America as a sign of United States concern for relations with its neighbors to the south.

LONDON, Jan. 15 -- Britain was handicapped in her efforts to negotiate an effective agreement with Egypt on the Sudan and the Suez Canal by a lack of United States support stemming from its fears of an Egyptian revolution, Sir Anthony Eden declares in an article in tomorrow's Times of London.
The terms of a proposed merger of the Standard Packaging Corporation and Brown. Bigelow, producer of calendars and other advertising specialties, were disclosed yesterday.

Clothes for Dogs Dog owners in the United States spent $150,000,000 on canine apparel last year, according to an estimate by a leading dog food manufacturer. Togs lavished on these household pets included sportscar and matador coats, reversible raincoats with rhinestone-studded hoods, opera cloaks, pajamas and lounging robes -- many practical and luxury items called for in a complete wardrobe.
SEA ISLAND, Ga., Jan. 15 (AP) -- Mickey Wright, the 1958 winner, today made a bid to repeat with a 37, 36 -- 73 opening round in the Sea Island women's invitation open golf tournament.

President Eisenhower was not at his best in this week's press conference; and one of the points on which he was weakest involved the question of taking representative Democrats along with him to the summit conference in the spring.

DENVER, Jan. 15 (UPI) -- An insurance policy trapped John Gilbert Graham in a lie and led to his confension of bombing a United Air Lines plane in Colorado Nov. 1. 1955. Forty-four persons were killed.
GENEVA, Jan. 15 -- United Stetes, British and Soviet negotiators had a puzzling new document to study today -- the text of the speech made yesterday in Moscow by Premier Krushchev.

BATON ROUGE, La., Jan. 15 (AP) -- The police said today that stains of blood of the same type as Dr. Margaret Rosamond McMillian's had been found in the auto owned by Dr. George H. Mickey, scientist, charged with her murder.
HONOLULU, Jan. 15 -- American and Japanese scientists took up an electronic watch today for the first sign of a Soviet super-rocket flashing toward its target in the Central Pacific.
The city was accused yesterday of harassment to the point of confiscation by lawyers for the owner and lessee of a building in which 150 violations of the multiple dwelling law were found.

Howard Ross, a 33-year old Brooklyn elevator mechanic and Lee Wraith, a 15-year-old VVycoff, N.J., high school sophomore, were the more persevering of the crowd that stormed the opening of the National Motor Boat Show in the New York Coliseum last night.

VIENNA, Jan. 15 -- Seven East European Communist Governments offered indications today that they would strengthen Premier Khrushchev's unilateral disarmament move by cutting their armed forces along the lines and for the same reasons the Soviet leader outlined yesterday.
Commodity prices on the New York exchanges moved irregularly yesterday. Trading was generally dull. Evening-out of positions prior to the weekend accounted for most of the volume.

Heavy construction awards increased sharply in the week ended Monday, bringing the total for the first two weeks of the new year to $647,000,000, a gain of 21 per cent over a year ago, The Engineering News-Record reports.
LONDON, Jan. 15 -- Britain expects the economic conference held in Paris this week to result eventually in a broad coordination of the economic policies of Britain, Western Europe and North America.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 15 -- (AP) -- Bob Cousy, Boston's old pro, did it almost by himself tonight as the Celtics scored a 124-112 victory before 10,434 fans to halt the Philadelphia Warriors' ten-game National Basketball Association winning streak.

NEWARK, Jan. 15 -- A hearing was asked today to determine whether telephone service should be taken away from two women who allegedly refused to terminate a conversation so that a doctor could make an emergency call on a party line.

Subtle yet typical cell changes are said to have been found in cancer patients at sites remote from their tumors. Those who have reported this discovery believe it supports the view that cancer, even when seemingly localized, may involve the whole body.
A new defense of the old prescription of prolonged bed rest for some heart disease patients has been made by specialists in New Orleans.
ROME, Jan. 15 -- A cordial reception was given here to "Fantasy Train," called "Jazz Train" in New York, which had its European premiere tonight.
Governor Rockefeller postponed yesterday a meeting he had scheduled with Mayor Wagner for early next week on the case of Borough President Hulan E. Jack of Manhattan.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 15 -- The Screen Writers go on strike here at 12:01 A.M. tomorrow (3:01 A.M., Easten standard time).

WASHINGTON, Jan. (AP) -- The Internal Revenue Service said today that it would ask for changes in the tax laws if new reporting requirements failed to eliminate abuses of business deductions for expenses and entertainment
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 15 -- Navy's indoor track team set three academy records in opening its season with a 90-19 rout of Princeton today.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 6 points (30 cents a bale) off to 5 points (25 cents) up yesterday.

JUDGING from the number of bright, shiny diamonds that are being proudly flashed around these days, Cupid was almost as busy as Santa during December. For many, this will be an active winter of pre-wedding parties and shopping sprees.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The staff of the Joint Economic committee of Congress has found that "the single most important contribution which the federal Government could make economic stability" would be to improve budget policies, particularly to reduce the ups and downs of military hardware procurement.
CHICAGO, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Influences in the grain futures market were scarce and minor last week, with price shifts in most pits limited to small ranges.
BOSTON, Jan. 17 (UPI) -- The Montreal Canadiens beat the Boston Bruins, 3 -- 1, tonight for their eighth triumph in nine games with the Bruins this season.
MIAMI, Jan. 17 (UPI) -- The estranged wife of a missing Tampa salesman said today that she was certain that her husband was on the airliner that crashed into the Gulf of Mexico on Nov. 16.

YORBA LINDA, Calif., Jan. 17 (AP) -- Jerry Barber bettered par for the third straight round and drew away from the field today at the 54-hole mark of the $20,000 Yorba Linda open golf tournament. Barber shot a 69, three under the par of 36, 36 -- 72 for the long, rolling hills of the Yorba Linda Country Club.
The Corporation Counsel's office has filed eighty-three suits against members of Associated Food Stores Cooperative, Inc., for alleged short-weighting in meat sales.
Dr. John J. Theobald, Superintendent of Schools, said yesterday that the New York City school system would get the full benefit of any Federal funds available for aid to education.

The target date for the opening of the new Metropolitan Opera House at the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts has been changed again. Last May it was July, 1961, a month after the planned opening of Philharmonic Hall.
Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. and District Attorney Frank S. Hogan have agreed to cooperate in promoting curbs on policy gambling in Harlem.

The Bowery Savings Bank, largest in the country, had net operating earnings of $13,026,259 in 1959, compared with $10,734,420 in 1958, according to Earl B. Schwulst, president and chairman. The earnings report to depositors is the first in the bank's 125-year history.
Conquest of "self-love," which he termed the "spirit of the world," will bring mankind closer to Christ, the Rev. Robert I. Cannon said yesterday.
