AMMAN, Jordan, Jan. 17 (AP) -- King Hussein criticized Arab leaders today for what he called their irresponsible approach to the Palestine problem. He said the were using Palestine Arab refugees as "pawns for selfish political objectives."
BEAR MOUNTAIN, Jan. 17 -- Einar Dohlen of the Bear Mountain Sports Association retained the New York State Class A ski-jumping title today before a record crowd of 33,100 patrons.

BANGALORE, India, Jan. 17 -- The Congress party ended its annual convention today with a strong defense of India's policy of nonalignment and support of independence movements in Africa, especially in Algeria.
St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church opened a week-long program of religious, musical and social events yesterday in celebration of its 125th anniversary.
The sea otter, whose soft fur and beguiling friendliness were almost its undoing, has regained its grip on existence.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Ezra Taft Benson said today that he would expect Vice President Nixon to support the Benson farm program in the Presidential campaign and to carry it out if elected.
BATON ROUGE, La., Jan. 17 (AP) -- A service station manager said today he had sold gasoline to Dr. Margaret McMillan the night she was killed on a rural lane south of here.

Beethoven's only opera, "Fidelio," will return to the Mettropolitan Opera after an absence of eight seasons on Thursday, Jan. 28. The work will be mounted in a new production, the gift of Mrs. John D. Rockefeller Jr. It will be designed by Horace Armistead, with Herbert Graf as stage director and Karl Boehm as conductor.
Seven Sea Scouts found themselves on the receiving end of a good deed yesterday. They had to be rescued by the police.

SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Jan. 17 (UPI) -- Tom Brown and 17-year-old Karen Hantze walked off with the singles championships today in the annual Thunderbird tennis tournament before a chilled crowd at the Paradise Racquet Club.

Two leading private institutions in the field of international finance, American Overseas Finance Corporation, Ltd., and Transoceanic Development Corporation, Ltd., have announced plans to consolidate.
A ninteen-story business building will be constructed on West Fortieth Street, in the growing new textile district south of Times Square.

MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 17 (AP) -- The accceptable candidates for the job as the National Football League commissioner apparently have narrowed to the acting commissioner, Austin H. Gunsel, and Marshall Leahy, a San Francisco lawyer, the Associated Press learned today.
CHICAGO, Jan. 17 (UPI) -- The Chicago Black Hawks scored a 3-1 victory over the New York Rangers tonight by wearing down the Ranger goalie, Gump Worsley, in the final period.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The Eisenhower Administration's last budget battle with Congress starts at noon tomorrow, with the delivery of the President's spending estimates and requests for the coming fiscal year.
The Israel Bond Organization adopted yesterday a quota of $75,873,550 in Israel bonds to be sold this year. The receipts will help to consolidate Israel's economy.

The Port of New York Authority urged Governor Rockefeller and the Legislature yesterday to reject New York City's request for the right to impose real estate taxes on profitable authority-operated projects within city limits.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 17 -- The kettle-sized atomic generator unveiled last January at the White House by the Atomic Energy Commission is still producing electricity after a year of continuous operation.
MADRID, Jan. 17 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco has moved to heal the breach that has been widening recently between him and Don Juan, Count of Barcelona and pretender to the Spanish throne.
Controller Arthur Levitt, the only Democrat holding statewide office, announced yesterday that he disapproved of Mayor Wagner's bid for authority to impose an off-track betting tax in New York City.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 17 (AP) -- Ray Blum won the five-mile race today and captured the title in the Silver Skates outdoor speed-skating meet Slum, from Nutley, N.J., was timed in 16 minutes 23.3 seconds.
A mother was killed last night and her two teen-age daughters were injured by a hit-and-run driver as they were returning home from church.

"ARROWSMITH," Sinclair Lewis' novel about an Idealistic young physician, was transferred to the television screen with rewarding results last night. Phil Reisman Jr.'s excellent adaptation of the story was presented on the "Show of the Month" over Channel 2.
MOSCOW, Jan. 17 -- The best popular reception that the Soviet Government can arrange awaits President Eisenhower on his visit here June 10 to 19.
Mayor Wagner made public yesterday a second stage of his administration's program for the prevention and control of youth crime.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 17 -- Bisheswar Prasad Koirala, Prime Minister of the Himalayan Kingdom of Nepal, arrived in India today on a two-week state visit.

ALBANY, Jan. 17 -- Democratic legislative leaders said today they opposed Governor Rockefeller's plan to give cities and school districts the right to levy the present 10 per cent Federal tax on local telephone service.

PARIS. An interesting question is raised in Sir Anthony Eden's memoirs, now being serialized by The Times of London. When should United States foreign policy be considered policy and when should it be regarded as simply the personal view of important American officials?

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Bob Pettit passed the 10,000-point milestone today in his sixth season, sooner than any other player in National Basketball Association history. Pettit's 34 points paced the St. Louis Hawks in a 135-119 romp over the Minneapolis Lakers, who were led by Elgin Baylor's 43 points.
Canadian Tabacofina, Ltd., of Montreal, manufacturer of Belvedere cigarettes, has agreed to stop immediately an advertising campaign mentioning its endorsement in Consumer Reports magazine.
The black cat that dashed out of the dressing room Saturday night had absolutely nothing to do with Cincinnati's loss to Bradley, the rival basketball coaches maintained yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 17 (UPI) -- Johnny Unitas showed 56,876 fans in the Coliseum today why he was the National Football League's player of the year as he led the West to a 38-21 victory over the East in the tenth annual Pro Bowl game.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 17 -- The United Arab Republic has joined Cuba in a decision to sponsor a conference of the under-developed countries of Latin America, Africa and Asia, to be held in Havana next September.
A new code of ethics to end improper sales and advertising methods by some food freezer plans was announced yesterday by the State Attorney General. So far, seven companies have signed the agreement.
IF quizzes were still In order, this would be a legitimate question: What has Valerii Klimov in common with Van Cliburn? The answer: He won a Tchaikovsky competition in Moscow in the spring of 1958.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The Naval Research Laboratory has developed a radar that can see over the horizon and detect missiles as they are launched from submarines.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Jan. 17 -- A new system of lobbing microwaves over the horizon opened here today when Sir Raynor Arthur, Governor of the Bahamas, put through the first telephone call to C. Earl Schooley, director of long lines operations of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in New York City.
Another rent Increase Is on the way for the 106,000 families in the city's housing projects, the chairman of the New York City Housing Authority said yesterday.

With some qualifications, the Cooke-Volker bill in the State Legislature would require a year's residence for a person to receive public relief. Introduction of the bill calls attention to a massive and pressing problem. But the measure also calls for a sense of proportion in appraising it-and some human understanding.
An undersea mountain that was probably an island 10,000 years ago has been discovered in the South Atlantic west of the tip of South Africa.

A theatre party to the world premiere of "Never So Few" at the Radio City Music Hall on Thursday will benefit the March of Dimes. The proceeds will be used In Its fight against crippling diseases. The first mezzanine has been taken over for the motion picture.
LONDON, Jan. 17 -- Thousands of Britons marched in silence on the West German Embassy in London today to protest signs in Germany of a revival of anti-Semitism.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- A House investigating committee recommended today that all officers or civilians leaving the Department of Defense be prohibited from selling anything to the Pentagon within two years of their departure.

ALBANY, Jan. 17 -- Governor Rockefeller will confer with Republican legislative leaders tomorrow on the prospect of driving some of the administration's nine highway safety bills out of committee this week.

The resistance of American maritime management and labor to technological advances is jeopardizing the future of the merchant marine, according to a report made public today by the National Academy of Sciences-National Research Council.
SEA ISLAND, Ga., Jan. 17 (AP) -- Mickey Wright won a duel with Mrs. Kathy Cornelius today for her third straight Sea Island women's open golf victory.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Those interested in public policy as related to labor unions cannot ignore Arthur Krock's suggestion in his Jan. 7 column of the need to apply the antitrust laws to unions. Mr. Krock is to be commended for once again placing this idea squarely before the public for sober and reflective study.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- President Eisenhower will visit the Soviet Union from June 10 to 19, the White House announced today.
Mayor Wagner's emergenc as a political leader has come as a climax to a series of signs and portents that began to appear several months ago.
THE cause of original drama on television was admirably served last night in Roger O. Hirson's play, "One Loud Clear Voice," which was presented on "Sunday Showcase" over Channel 4.

Patricia Neway, the soprano, gave a program of songs by John Gruen last night at Carnegie Recital Hall. The 33-year-old composer repaid the compliment by serving as her accompanist in five of the six groups.
Mayor Wagner appears to have taken over the top role in the Democratic state organization in matters of national politics, displacing Carmine G. De Sapio.

HONG KONG, Jan. 17 -- A Chinese economist feels that the need for steel is so pressing in Communist China that the Ministry of Railways should make its own. Unless this is done, he says, there is no possibility of enough railroads being built to meet the nation's requirements.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I would like to comment on the letter of Philip Marshall Brown published Jan. 13 in which he proposes an inter-American cultural institute as a remedy for our inter-American ills.

New Yorkers who pay income taxes once a year instead of in weekly installments deducted from their pay checks and turned in by their employers already are bracing for the ordeal. The deadline is midnight April 15.
Dr. John C. Bennott, dean of faculty at Union Theological Seminary, charged yesterday that "images and suggestions" in some Protestant Sunday School lesson materials stimulated anti-Jewish prejudice.
Every seat was sold and the stage itself was used for a few hundred extra customers or Saturday evening at Hunter College. The event was Eileen Farrell's recital.
A year can mean a lot in the life of a young composer.
SAN DIEGO, Jan. 17 (AP) -- The scratch boat, Barlovento, moved into the lead tonight as darkness came on the first day of the San Diego-Acapulco yacht race.
CHICAGO, Jan. 17 -- Concern over the growing tightness in the supply of money for home mortgages dominated discussions of home builders today as they opened their annual convention.

IF Pete Dawkins had not recently bounced back onto the sports pages, the discussion never would have arisen. But the rugby exploits of the all-America halfback from Army while a Rhodes scholar at Oxford channeled the talk in the direction of Yanks at Oxford.
DETROIT, Jan. 17 (UPI) -- Gordie Howe's second goal of the game, coming with less than two minutes to play, lifted the Detroit Red Wings to a 4-3 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight.

LONDON, Jan. 17 -- The stock market recovered last week from the break of the week before, but it was still showing the effects of the tremors in Wall Street and uncertainty over the level of interest rates.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Jan. 17 -- The stock market last week displayed irregularity with rather sharp fluctuations and a continued big turnover.

THE NEW YORK CITY BALLET gave us two interesting novelties on its Saturday programs at the City Center, when it presented Violette Verdy for the first time in "Firebird" at the matinee and a revival of "Prodigal Son" in the evening.
GUATEMALA, Jan. 16 -- Guatemala'a fiscal situation is "critical" though not "alarming," according to Finance Minister Julio Prado Garcia Salas.

A $52,500,000 garage program to stimulate mid-Manhattan shopping was recommended yesterday by Traffic Commissioner T.T. Wiley. He said the plan would generate more than $100,000,000 in retail sales a year.
IN an informal poll conclude among half a dozen young women employed in a midtown office this question was asked: "What fashion purchase would you like to make this week ?"
At least five inquiries into the mystery of the airliner that crashed during a night flight from New York to Miami on Jan. 6 were proceeding yesterday.
BOSTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- -- John Thomas' track coach at Boston University says he thinks the 18-year-old leaping wonder will crack his own world high jump record in a matter of weeks.

The performance of the off-Broadway musical, "Little Mary Sunshine," on Feb. 9 will be a benefit for the Carroll Club. Tickets may be obtained from Mrs. John S. Burke, benefit chairman, at the club, 22 East Thirty-eighth Street.

CAIRO, Jan. 17 (AP) -- A treasure of antiquities found lying neglected in the basement of the Cairo Museum is the only collection showing all the splendor of the ancient pharaohs, the chief curator said today.
SOME 28,000 viewers better have a stiff upper lip this week. "The Play of the Week" last night proudly displayed its battle ribbons and then promptly went A.W. O.L.

The twenty football-playing schools of the Public Schools Athletic League approved a plan yesterday that would realign the league into two divisions. This was done to create a more equitable distribution of power.
PARIS, Jan. 18 -- The West African republics of Senegal and Sudan, which together make up the Federation of Mali, opened negotiations today with France to become independent.

ATLANTA, Jan. 18 -- A statement by State School Board Chairman James S. Peters that integration is "inevitable" in Georgia, and that school closings could destroy Senator Herman Talmadge politically, jolted politicians and the 1960 Legislature here today.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The president of the Lawn Tennis Association of Australia said today he favored open tennis tournaments. Meanwhile, Harry Hopman, the Aussie Davis Cup captain, assailed the professionals.
Traffic Commissioner T.T. Wiley's plan to build garages all over mid-Manhattan to attract shoppers was denounced bitterly yesterday by the Metropolitan Garage Board of Trade.

Differences in small-college and big-college basketball are gradually diminishing, metropolitan coaches agreed yesterday. Speaking at the Metropolitan Basketball Writers' luncheon at Leone's, most of the coaches argued that the tall players spelled the difference among teams.
Specialists yesterday had pieced together three-quarters of the fuselage of the National Airlines plane that crashed in North Carolina Jan. 6.

CARROLL, Iowa, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The Minneapolis Lakers professional basketball team rode an airplane with a defective electrical system to a landing in a cornfield during a heavy snowstorm near here early today.

ALL a customer at Abraham Straus has to do is supply the roof, and this store's decorating staff will do the rest. In the model rooms opening today, walls, windows, furnishings and art are -- surprisingly enough -- all for sale.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 18 -- South Africa's treason trial entered its fourth year today when it was resumed in Pretoria after a recess of nearly two months.

ALTAMONT, Tenn., Jan. 18 -- A bird dog fiddling along with wandering hunters gets a fine education in what the educators of children call group adjustment or some such nonsense. The dog gets handled by all kinds of people, sleeps in all kinds of places and sometimes eats all Kinds of food.
YORBA LINDA, Calif., Jan. 18 (AP) -- Jerry Barber of Los Angeles shook off the pressure of Billy Maxwell's eagle 3 on the final hole today and won the $20,000 Yorba Linda open golf tournament.
Mayor Wagner's assumption of command over Democratic Presidential maneuvers in New York gave rise yesterday to a great deal of grumbling among some party leaders.
Plans have been announced for the construction of three apartment buildings in Manhattan.

PORT JEFFERSON STATION, L.I., Jan. 18 -- A former member of the Brookhaven Town Board who was convicted recently on bribe charges was found dead tonight in his home on Main Street. The police said the case was apparent suicide from an overdose of sleeping pills.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The Supreme Court held today that the Constitution bars military trials for civilian employes and dependents accompanying the armed forces overseas in peacetime.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Dr. Robert G. Storey, Texan who is vice chairman of the Civil Rights Commission, urged Congress today to authorize the appointment of Federal registrars to protect, Negro voting rights.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The barges that ply this country's rivers won a major victory in the Supreme Court today over their ancient enemies, the railroads.
Pencils flew over order pads yesterday as heavy buying marked first New York showings of many new home furnishings lines.
Prices on the New York Stock Exchange fell yesterday to their lowest level since Nov. 27 but volume ebbed as well and the decline was orderly.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- President Eisenhower proposed a $40,995,000,000 military spending plan today that he said was designed to cover "one of the greatest transitions in history."
ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- Governor Rockefeller said today that he had not given up hope of obtaining $70,000,000 for local school financing by taking over a Federal telephone tax.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- Independence for Cyprus has been postponed a month because of differences over the size and nature of two military enclaves on the island scheduled to remain under British sovereignty.
NEWARK, Jan. 18 -- A new $1,500,000 control tower at Newark Airport was used today as a podium to advance the Port of New York Authority's campaign for a new metropolitan jet airport.

A FRENCH restaurant is not something that many people expect to find in the country 150 miles north of Chicago. But just outside Fond du Lac, Wis., you will find one called Postilion, run by Liane Kuony a vivacious and charming Frenchwoman.
The Federal Government yesterday ordered an ocean-going hydrofoil ship capable of transporting 100 passengers twice as fast as the speediest ocean liner.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- Monroe Green, advertising director and assistant business manager of The New York Times, today predicted a substantial growth in newspaper advertising in 1960 and throughout the decade ahead.

Bond issues totaling $12,965,000 were posted for sale yesterday to finance local school building projects in the following seven states -- New York, Ohio, North Carolina, Texas, Michigan, Minnesota and California.

"Generally, boats designed to perform at high speeds perform poorly at low and medium speeds. It is equally true that boats which perform well at moderate speeds are rarely capable of high speeds. The unlimited hydroplanes [the country's speediest power boats] are fast, but they are not safe."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Five Western nations began today to prepare for disarmament talks with five Soviet bloc countries in Geneva March 15.
The National Aeronautics and Space Administration may put a series of "umbrellas" into orbit around the earth to serve as radio and television mirrors.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UPI) -- Senator John J. Williams of Delaware today beat out about twenty-five fellow Republicans for a vacancy on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
Tri-Continental Corporation wound up 1959 with assets of $414,303,032, the highest level in its thirty-year history, according to its annual report released yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Government spending on research and development will rise 5 per cent in the coming fiscal year. President Eisenhower's budget today called for $8,391,000,000 in this category.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- Persistent selling lowered share prices in the stock market here today. The selling and lack of buyers, particularly for the industrials, was attributed to warnings from the chairmen of some of the leading banks that caution should be exercised at the present high price level.
ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- A plan for rehabilitating Westchester County's congested, deteriorating parkway system was presented to Governor Rockefeller today.
Victor Zalazar of Argentina scored a unanimous decision over Tony Dupas of New Orleans in the ten-round feature bout last night at the Academy of Music. Zalazar weighed 159 3/4 pounds and Dupas 151.

The first notable Arab voice of reason concerning the million Arab refugees -- a key issue in the whole Palestine conflict -- has been raised by King Hussein of Jordan. He accuses the Arab leaders, as distinct from their people, of "irresponsible, ridiculous and even criminal" misuse of the refugees as "pawns for their own selfish political purposes."

Patroness and junior committees have been announced for the Yorkville Dinner Dance at the Plaza on Friday. Mrs. Albert C. Bradley is chairman for the event, proceeds from which will aid the Yorkville Community Association to provide summer vacations for city children at Camp Yorkville at Lake Tiorati in the Bear Mountain-Harriman section of the Palisades Interstate Park.

Bill Bunetta, a good bowler from Chicago, refers to himself as a "cranker" in the sport. He said he was a mighty tired cranker when the National AllStar tournament finished Friday night in Omaha, Neb. He finished fifteenth in the field of sixteen finalists.
The youth program of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest will benefit from the annual "After Dinner Dance," to be held in the Ballroom of the Sheraton-East on Feb. 12.

A 30-year-old Brooklyn man who appeared before Municipal Court Justice Fred G. Moritt ten days ago for nonpayment of rent returned yesterday to be married by the judge while the complaining landlord served as best man.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- President Eisenhower confronted Congress with a new sort of budget challenge today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The Supreme Court decided today that Oregon's employers' liability law governed a suit for damages for the death of a carpenter who drowned while working at Bonneville Dam on the Columbia River.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18 -- The Supreme Court of Pennsylvania ruled today that unemployment compensation benefits could not be denied to industrial workers who had been discharged as security risks.

KITZBUEHEL, Austria, Jan. 18 -- Ski fans here are fiercely passionate. About 10,000 of them stood ankle deep in snow leaning into the slant of the mountain for hours yesterday to watch the men's slalom final event of the Hahnenkamm week-end.

DETROIT, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The auto industry edged past the announced goal of an average production of 168,000 to 170,000 units last week and continued to push toward the mark set in the week ended April 30, 1955 -- 189,279 units.
HALIFAX, N.S., Jan. 18 (UPI) -- Longshoremen began today unloading a $1,000,000 cargo from a Panamanian ship whose owners cannot be located and whose crew refuses to leave.
HAVANA, Jan. 18 -- Premier Fidel Castro today characterized a statement on Cuba by Vice President Nixon as an "insolent declaration."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 Leaders of the Republican minority in Congress hoisted a "save that surplus" banner over President Eisenhower's budget today.
BOSTON, Jan. 18 -- Maj. Gen. Cortlandt Parker, U.S.A., retired, of Portsmouth, R.I., died today at Phillips House of Massachusetts General Hospital. His age was 75. He retired on Aug. 31, 1946.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Eddie Litzenberger, the Chicago Black Hawk hockey player, was seriously injured early today in an auto accident that killed his wife. He probably will be sidelined for the rest of the season.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The Supreme Court refused today to review a lower-court decision holding a ruling of the National Relations Board to in error. The board's ruling has certified an electricians' cra union as a bargaining unit in plate glass plant that had history of plant-wide bargaining.

Intergroup education to speed understanding among different ethnic and religious groups has been "sorely neglected" in the last ten years, according to two surveys reported to the American Jewish Committee yesterday
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- It is supposed to be a sign of great political sagacity in Washington to say -- preferably to an outsider -- that "Anderson is the real power in this Government."
CHICAGO, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The butcher hog market extended its upward trend into the third week today. Gains ran to 25 cents a hundred pounds, the highest peak since Nov. 11.
MORE and more the opinion of the American consumer appears to be a valuable commodity in itself.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed unchanged to 30 points lower ($1.50 a bale) yesterday. The weakest month was distant July, which closed on a bid of 31.10 cents a pound, compared with 31.40 cents last Friday.

IN Kay Boyle's thirteenth novel, provocatively titled "Generation Without Farewell," the overpowering element is the locale itself, occupied Germany in 1948. That time is important, too: the old swastikas, unlike those of recent weeks, have not all been wiped off the walls.

Seventeen national women's organizations began a joint effort yesterday to combat segregation in the public schools. The work will operate under a coordinating council named the National Organizations of Women for Equality in Education.
Directors of the Boeing Airplane Company and of the Vertol Aircraft Corporation yesterday approved a plan for acquisition of Vertol by Boeing.

MIAMI, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Mary Fisher's Fulcrum, an 11-to-1 shot making his winter racing debut, got up in the final stride and defeated Pryson in today's featured Key Largo Purse at Hialeah. Greek Circle finished third and the favored Tudor Melody was a well-beaten fourth.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- President Eisenhower is expected to discuss plans for a visit to Japan when he meets Premier Nobusuke Kishi at the White House tomorrow.

MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Marshall Leahy, a lawyer, virtually eliminated himself tonight as a candidate for National Football League commissioner when he said flatly he would not move from his native San Francisco.

Edgar Allan Poe: a Controversial Figure Last year the literary world here and abroad celebrated the 150th anniversary of Poe's birth on Jan. 19, 1809. Articles and books about him attempted to clarify for the general reader the complexity and genius of Poe, also to appraise objectively his influence on American and European letters.
Last night s concert at Carnegie Hall by Kiril Kondrashin and the Moscow State Symphony featured Emil Gilels.
ZURICH, Switzerland, Jan. 18 (UPI) -- Neither ice nor snow nor auto wrecks nor the heat of political battle could keep Liechenstein's ski team from receiving visas today for the Winter Olympics.

Anti-Semitic hate expressions in New York are a "very serious" situation calling for strong community disapproval and intensified police action, it was said yesterday by leaders of religious, educational, civic, labor, industry and veterans groups.
Bill Gay, the Neptune of the Bronx, led a visitor into his chlorinated kingdom last week. There was pride in the swimming coach's step, and with good reason.
A storm that heaped snowdrifts from the Rockies to the Great Lakes drove into the Northeast last night. The Associated Press reported.
LONDON, Jan. 18 -- A possible threat to the stability of the world diamond market seems to have been averted.
WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 18 -- Revisions in Westchester's charter were endorsed today by the County Board of Supervisors, but they were not as broad as the County League of Women Voters wanted.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- President Eisenhower asked Congress today for more than $1,000,000,000 for civil aviation and the merchant marine in his new budget.
MONTE CARLO, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The twenty-ninth Monte Carlo auto rally -- a test of driving skill and auto dependability -- got off to a slippery start tonight from Oslo.
The collected papers of Mark Van Doren were presented to Columbia University last night in a ceremony in Low Memorial Library.
More grist will be fed this week into the mill of the preOlympic indoor track season, which made such a spectacular getaway in Boston last Saturday.
HOLDCROFT, Va., Tuesday, Jan. 19 -- A Capital Airlines Viscount crashed and burned in a marsh near here late last night. The State Police reported that all forty-eight persons aboard were dead.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- A constitutional conference on the future of Kenya opened under the threat of immediate failure today when the fourteen-member African delegation led by Tom Mboya, the nationalist, refused to attend.

HONG KONG, Jan. 13 -- The question of whether Hong Kong should establish a voluntary quota on exports of certain cotton garments to the United States has produced a major dispute in this British colony.

Empire Resources Corp. Empire Resources Corporation, a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Empire Trust Company, cleared $481,010 after taxes in 1959, Henry C. Brunie, president, 'reported to stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday.
LONDON, Jan. 18 -- The Federation of British Industries told the Government today that manufacturers were limited in what they could do to cut prices.

Unless the oracles are mistaken, Henry Fonda, co-star of "Silent Night, Lonely Night," has almost made up his mind to appear in "Critic's Choice" next season. Rehearsals will start Oct. 15 for a local unveiling around Christmas.
ROME, Jan. 18 -- Pope John XXIII severely condemned anti-Semitism today, expressing detestation and abhorrence of all forms of persecution and discrimination.
John J. McCloy will retire as chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank at the end of this year, he indicated yesterday in a letter to stockholders. He will be 65 years old in March, 1960.
TOKYO, Jan. 18 -- On the eve of the signing of a new security treaty between Japan and the United States, it is still difficult to assess how the pact is being received by the Japanese people.
A candidate for the title of the most unusual bird at the Bronx Zoo went on public display there yesterday.
CAIRO, Jan. 18 -- The Soviet Union has agreed to finance the second stage of the Aswan High Dam project, the Government of the United Arab Republic announced today.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Jan. 18 -- Europeans and banner-bearing African nationalists clashed here tonight shortly after Prime Minister Macmillan arrived at Salisbury Airport.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Zora Folley jabbed his way to a unanimous verdict over Eddie Machen tonight in a twelve-round bout at the Cow Palace. The lack of action by the two ranking heavyweights brought frequent boos from the crowd of 6,500.
It appeared almost certain yesterday that "Startime," the "Arthur Murray Party" and other National Broadcasting Company television programs would undergo time changes in the next two weeks.
The growing interest in antiques as an image of the gracious living of the past has added a new dimension to the marketing concept for White Horse Scotch whisky.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In The Times of Jan. 11 Ernest R. Anderson, a spokesman of those who oppose fluoridation, takes issue with the letter of Dr. George Baehr published Dec. 29.

The nation's major chain and mail-order companies showed a near-record year-to-year growth in sales volume in 1959. A survey completed yesterday by The New York Times showed a gain last year over 1958 levels of 9.2 percent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The White House last week released letters from the President, dated Jan. 13, which invoked an improvement of great importance in the system whereby national policies formulated by the President are implemented throughout the Administration.

ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- The Joint Legislative Committee on the Banking Law decided today to introduce four bills providing a choice of solutions to banking problems in the metropolitan area and the rest of the state.

SEVERAL painters and sculptors who are well-honored abroad but are relatively unfamiliar to Americans are included in the new exhibition of European contemporary art at the Bertha Schaefer Gallery, 32 East Sixty-fifth Street.

LAWN, N.J., Jan. 18 -- Mayor Wagner toured the Fair Lawn Industrial Park here this morning to get ideas that might be applicable to New York City's proposed industrial park in the Flatlands area of Brooklyn.

OXFORD, England, Jan. 18 -- On Thursday night the Oxford University Union will debate the motion, "That this house holds America responsible for spreading vulgarity in Western society." Whatever the outcome, the wording of the motion suggests that the image of the United States is becoming dangerously blurred in Britain.

About half of all new cars sold In this country will be compact models by 1963, according to George Romney, president of American Motors Corporation. The prediction was made yesterday in a talk to the New York Society of Security Analysts.

United States Government securities moved upward in price yesterday. In a trading session marked by the aggressive bidding by dealers concerned about short positions, the long list of Treasury notes and bonds rose by as much as 22/32 of a point.

CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Jan. 18 (UPI) -- Italian sledders served notice they were out to win the two-man world bobsled title for the fifth year in a row in today's first trial runs for the world championships.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As one of the several newspaper and radio reporters who interviewed Castro of Cuba in his home near Havana last Feb. 28 and saw what a rare opportunity he had to bring about the blessings of freedom and democracy to his country, the course of events has compelled me to change my opinion drastically.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Attorney General William P. Rogers said today that the Government had appealed in the Du Pont-General Motors stock-divestiture case because it felt the District Court's decree had offered an inadequate remedy for a violation of antitrust laws.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The Administration proposed tax legislation today to pave the way for mere liberal depreciation allowances on the funds that business spends to equip itself.
GENEVA, Jan. 18 -- The Soviet Union indicated today that Moscow wanted to keep for itself the final decision as to where nuclear control posts could be stationed on its territory.
BERLIN, Jan. 18 -- West Berlin students and policemen clashed briefly today at a rally protesting against the presence of former Nazis in high posts of the West German Government.
MOSCOW, Jan. 18 -- Premier Khrushchev had the United States Ambassador out to his country home this week-end for a sleigh ride and Sunday dinner.

American manufacturers of shirts, blouses, brassieres, slacks and other items of apparel might have shown more opposition to imports from Hong Kong and Japan if their business had been on a downswing. But domestic production showed a substantial gain in 1959 from the level of the preceding year and now is moving upward.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- The home building industry was bitterly divided today on whether it should campaign for a Federal subsidy on residential construction or for more strict Government control of the nation's economy.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The Treasury bill rate fell sharply this week, particularly the rate on 182-day bills, the Treasury disclosed tonight.

The Southern Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for 1959. Directors meeting yesterday also voted an increase in the dividend and approved the largest three-year expansion program in the utility system's history.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Record outlays for human welfare were projected today by the Eisenhower Administration.
ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- The Senate tonight killed a bill that could have required a non-Communist oath as a condition for receiving relief payments.
Mayor Wagner appointed Philip Sokol, a 52-year-old career employe, Deputy Commissioner of Welfare yesterday.
GENEVA, Jan. 18 -- In a somber courtroom in the city's old quarter, a wizened lawyer who once stood for the solid respectability Geneva holds dear went on trial today for murder.
TRENTON, Jan. 18 -- Both houses of the Legislature, by an overwhelming vote, went on record today as opposed to the building of a jet airport in Morris County.

We applaud the joint program of Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers and the electrical contractors in the New York area designed to relieve the industry of the financial burden of the increased wages and fringe benefits granted in the contract recently agreed upon. Most important, from the public point of view, is that this step would reduce the need for increased prices of electrical installations.
Production of steel this week is expected to ease slightly from the high level of last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

Ten years ago, after long and arduous campaigning, an important principle was established in the New York Legislature and accepted by Governor Dewey under which state financial aid was granted to public libraries for the first time. This principle is the recognition that libraries are educational institutions, hardly a revolutionary concept, and so are entitled just as public schools and colleges to state encouragement.

New opposition within the Board of Education to the proposed school budget for 1960-61 developed yesterday. Two members charged that the system was not doing enough to "eradicate the disease of prejudice."

Most potato positions fell yesterday in active trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The November position rose 2 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on very light volume but the other months dropped 7 to 9 points.

"Roads to Discovery," a new book by Ralph E. Lapp, the physicist, will be published Feb. 3 by Harper. It discusses atomic developments in terms of the men who took part in their advances, beginning with Roentgen's discovery of X-rays, which "initiated" the atom age.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) The St. Lawrence Seaway, which was opened last April, is expected to operate at a loss of $2,359,000 in the year starting July 1. President Eisenhower gave the figures today in his budget message to Congress.
The free press of the United States was described last night as an assurance to the world that this country could have "no secret designs" to start any war and as an example for peace.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 18 -- A private secretary and a convicted swindler pleaded guilty today in Westchester County Court to charges of conspiracy and falsification of documents in the financing of the Shelton Towers Hotel in New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Like most Americans who look over their financial accounts these days, President Eisenhower is confronted by a familiar dilemma. That is to say, he took in more money than he ever expected to get, but had more financial worries than ever before.
CHICAGO, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Trading in grain futures probably was at its slowest pace of the year today with market incluences meager.
OTTAWA, Jan. 18 Canadian Press -- Prime Minister John Riefenbaker said tonight that hoped it would be possible long for Canada to end her Constitution without reference to the British Parliament.
It is time New York State "got off the ground" in advancing middle-income housing, Mayor Wagner told Otto L. Nelson Jr. in a letter yesterday.
The fatal crash of the Vickers Viscount was the fourth for Capital Airlines since the line became the first American carrier to put them in use in 1955.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan 18 -- Heads of the major movie companies and leaders of the Screen Actors Guild faced one another today across the bargaining table in an attempt to avert a strike by actors that could shut down production at the end of this month.
FLORENCE, Italy, Jan. 18 -- The second half of the Italian high fashion showings opened here today in the Sala Bianca of the Pitti palace.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- following actions today:
Work on a second deck for the George Washington Bridge advanced here yesterday.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Surely every boy at one time or other has had the urge to walk up a down escalator -- or down an up escalator.
MILWAUKEE, Jan. 18 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey tonight put together the qualities that he believed a President needed to lead the United States "to the heights."
YESTERDAY (Jan. 18, 1960) THE PRESIDENT Sent $79,800,000,000 budget to Congress.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 18 (AP) -- A medical scientist said today that propagandists had misrepresented the real findings in two surveys linking smoking and lung cancer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UPI) -- Soviet Ambassador Mikhail A. Menshikov reported today that the Premiers of five Soviet republics and a number of other "high officials" would arrive in New York Jan. 29 to begin a three-week tour of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Representative James Roosevelt voiced "dismay and indignation" today over published reports that Representative Hale Boggs faced religious obstacles to his selection as chairman of the Democratic National Convention next July.
The mop-up of labor troubles in the wake of the steel settlement two weeks ago has left some marathon strikes still dragging on.
The alumni of the Horace Mann School in the Bronx sent their second contribution to New York's Neediest Cases yesterday. The school's first donation was received on Christmas Day.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The Supreme Court rejected today an appeal by Negro railroad firemen who had complained that a union had discriminated against them by taking away work and giving it to junior white firemen.
Final plans are being made for the Seven Seasons Cabaret, which will aid the Phoenix Theatre and also will mark the seventh anniversary of the non-profit institution.
ARCHIE MOORE was properly sympathetic. There was a catch in his voice as he spoke, although his crocodile tears could not quite obscure the merry mischief in his eyes.

GLOSSARIES to bridge books acknowledge only two kinds of cue bid, which they define as "a bid indicating first-round control [the ace or a void] in a suit the opponents have bid or in a suit the opponents are likely to lead against a slam contract."

THERE'S nobody like the Germans for waxing sentimental and moral over the fates of those fragile females who ply the oldest profession in the world. They have done it in many previous pictures, going all the way back to "Joyless Street," and they are doing it again, in a modern idiom, in a steamy item called "Rosemary."
A letter to the coach of a team in the new American Football League:
CHICAGO, Jan. 19 -- The Government's housing chief argued vigorously today against "feeding the fires of inflation" by "pouring a billion dollars of taxpayers' money" into housing.
TOKYO, Jan. 19 -- The United States-Japanese treaty of mutual cooperation and security, signed today in Washington, makes numerous concessions to Japanese sensibilities.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Wilber M. Brucker, Secretary of the Army, said today there had been no change in the United States' determination to resist any Chinese Communist military pressure constituting aggression against Taiwan or an effort to drive the United States out of that area.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 19 -- The first act of violence in the outbreak of anti-Semitism in West Germany was reported tonight. Authorities released the news that an unsuccessful attempt was made last Wednesday to set fire to a synagogue.

Last Monday in these notes an announcement was made of the forthcoming publication of "For Victory In Peaceful Competition with Capitalism" by Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev. By a mischance the announcement omitted the name of the publisher.
LONDON, Jan. 19 -- Prices in every section of the stock market here fell back today. The heaviest falls were among the industrials.

HOLDCROFT, Va., Jan. 19 (AP) -- The fire-blackened wreckage of a Capital Airlines Viscount yielded the last of fifty bodies today, nearly fifteen hours after the Chicago-to-Norfolk plane had pancaked into a swampy ravine near here.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 -- A top advertising executive today assailed Robert Montgomery's broad implication in Washington that it was common knowledge in television networks and advertising agencies that quiz shows were rigged even before the fakery was exposed.
In an optimistic glimpse into the future last night, the Pentagon's deputy director of research and engineering envisioned a world free of prejudice, bigotry and weapons of mass destruction.

The head of the nation's fourth largest bank believes an increase in the prime rate is "long overdue." At the same time, high Federal Reserve officials are understood to believe that the factors making for a rise in the discount rate are less now than they were ten days ago.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Senator John F. Kennedy has decided to enter Wisconsin's Democratic Presidential primary against Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota.
THE New York Chamber Musicians, a group of Philharmonic players dedicated to the cause of intimate music, gave a concert last night at the B. de Rothschild Foundation for the Arts and Sciences.
Stocks yesterday sustained their sharpest decline since Nov. 16, following du Pont down a slide that trimmed about $3, 300,000,000 from aggregate market values on the New York Stock Exchange.
Kansas Gas and Electric Company sold 200,000 shares of common stock yesterday to investment bankers led by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc.; Kidder, Peabody Co., and White Weld Co.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 10 -- The presidents of the major movie companies and representatives of the Writers Guild of America met here today to discuss issues that had led the writers to go on strike last Saturday night.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan, 19 -- The newly independent states of Africa, like other sections of the continent, face difficult problems in building sound and self-sustaining economies, a United Nations commission reported today.
HONG KONG, Jan, 13 -- Communist China is trying to settle the nomads of its Central Asian border areas.
Yale, the 1959 Heptagonal indoor track and field champion, again stands out in the tencollege group consisting of the eight Ivy League schools, Army and Navy.

MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 19 -- Sideline observers awaiting tomorrow morning's kick-off of the forty-first annual meeting of the National Football League today foresaw defeat for proponents of any plan that calls for immediate expansion.
HAVANA, Jan. 19 -- An attempt by unidentified planes to set fire to cane fields of Cuban sugar mills was reported this morning from Las Villas Province.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UPI) -- The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has asked the Federal Communications Commission for increased rates for leased teletypewriter services "in gradual steps" at an appropriate time.

The number of persons injured in city traffic decreased last week compared with the same period a year ago, the Police Safety Bureau, reported yesterday. At the same time the number of persons killed also declined.
ALBANY, Jan. 19 (UPI) -- Skiing conditions reported today to the state Department of Commerce:

CAIRO, Jan. 19 -- President Nassar is understood to have accepted the Soviet offer to build the second stage of the Aswan High Dam because Premier Khrushchev reacted more quickly than the West to President Nasser's bid for aid to complete the project.
Strong suspicions that one, if not both, of the recent National Airlines crashes may have been caused by sabotage have profoundly shaken the aviation industry.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 19 -- A reformed jewel thief made such a favorable impression on officials here today with his good jail record for the last eleven years that he was granted eligibility for parole.

The nation's railroads, which have been demanding that their 800,000 unionized workers take a pay cut, have made their first offer of higher wages. The offer was made in Chicago Monday to negotiators for the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers.
Michael J. Quill asserted yesterday that a proposed $52,500,000 mid-Manhattan garage program would "torpedo" the city's 15-cent subway and bus fare.

TUNIS, Jan. 19 -- The insurgent Algerian nationalists announced tonight a reorganization of their Provisional Government that is regarded here as possible preparation for peace talks with President de Gaulle.
FLORENCE, Jan. 19 -- It women really start wearing pants out to dinner instead of to the supermarket, you can put the blame on two Italian designers, Irene Galitzine and Emilio Pucci.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The Census Bureau will seek more details when it counts the population in April. This was disclosed today by Robert W. Burness, director.

MIAMI, Jan. 19 (AP) -- A.J. Ostriker's Catapult closed with a rush on the outside today to win the Sabal Palm Purse by a length at Hialeah before 15,637 racing fans. Run For Nurse was second, Vox Pop third and May-be Best fourth.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 19 (UPI) -- The Coast Guard today called off an air and sea search for the 45-foot schooner Maramel after the yacht had established contact by marine telephone.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Hooks, crosses and even the roundhouse right are more exciting, but Zora Folley may someday get a heavyweight championship fight because of the dependability of his left jab.
With prosperity at home, the United States should be able to hold its own in business abroad this year, according to a forecast yesterday by a major business group.
Legal woes mounted yesterday for the men who received prison sentences and fines last week for conspiring to lie to the Federal Government about the purpose of the 1957 meeting at Apalachin, N.Y.
Rising prices carried the day in all parts of the bond market yesterday.
Gen. Thomas S. Power urged last night that American defense programs be accelerated to hasten the day when no Soviet surprise missile attack could prevent or minimize retaliation.

IT was imaginative of Newell Jenkins and his Clarion Concerts to remember that this year marks the 300th anniversary of the birth of Alessandro Scarlatti. They observed the occasion at Town Hall last night with a performance of the composer's oratorio, "Il Martirio di Sant' Orsola."

PARIS, Jan. 19 -- Maj. Gen. Jacques Massu, French commander in the Algiers region, was summoned to Paris today to explain statements, attributed to him, that the army might oppose President de Gaulle by force.

Last year there was a notable increase in consumer use of credit. Installment and single-payment debt outstanding crossed the $50,000,000,000 mark near the end of the year, up about 15 per cent since the first quarter of the year.
ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- The Nelcommission investigating New York City government is caught in a crossfire today in both sides of the aisle in Legislature.
An unemployed cook who pleaded guilty yesterday to 180 traffic tickets that he had failed to answer was sentenced to two years in jail.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Cash dividend payments by corporations set a new record in 1959 and new securities sales declined, according to official estimates published today.
Pierre Mendes-France, former Premier of France, challenged the non-Communist world yesterday to "make an out-and-out wager" on winning the economic fight with the Communist countries.
The Federal Government has decided that if Webb Knapp, Inc., wants to change its plans for the New York University-Bellevue slum clearance project it must pay $116,831 more for the land.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- New Jersey members of the House of Representatives threw their organized weight today into the fight against a jet airport in Morris County.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Following are the texts of a treaty of mutual cooperation and security signed today by the United States and Japan, of a minute to the treaty and of a joint communique issued by the White House after meetings of President Eisenhower and other United States officials with Premier Nobusuke Kishi:
The Port of New York Authority said yesterday that it would continue its studies on a new metropolitan airport despite the opposition by the New Jersey Legislature Monday.
ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- Confidence continued to increase here today that New York's local school systems would be able to tap a $70,000,000 tax reserve this year.

The International Benefits Committee of the American Red Cross in Greater New York is sponsoring a benefit recital by Alain Bernheim at the Carnegie Recital Hall, 154 West Fifty-seventh Street on Feb. 25. The French pianist, a protege of the late Walter Gieseking, will be making his American debut.

BEN SLIMANE, Morocco, Jan. 10 -- This strategic airbase, which the United States will relinquish by the end of March, is one of the most extensive commands ever held by a major in the United States Air Force.
The first profitable year for the Commonwealth Oil Refining Company, Inc., since operations were begun in 1956 was reported yesterday in the 1959 report of the Ponce, Puerto Rico producer.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It appears from Chang Hsin-Hai's letter, published in your world-famous paper on Dec. 6, that to the Chinese the MacMahon Line does not legally exist since the Simla Convention of 1914 was not ratified by the Chinese Government.
Two well-known American personalities engaged in a curbstone conference on the Presidential political outlook yesterday that went virtually unnoticed in the hurly-burly of the big city.

Some $77,166,777 in claims against the defunct New York, Ontario and Western Railway was ordered settled yesterday by the Federal district court here for $8,252,820. Under the court-approved plan, claims of holders of the road's refunding mortgage 4 per cent bonds, due in 1992, are to be settled for 5.28 cents on the dollar, for each $1,000 of face amount.
ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- The Senate approved today a bill shifting from the state to localities the power to decide whether persons on relief are to be returned to states in which they formerly lived.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It has been reported from Japan that 2,500 policemen had to evict 700 students from the airport, where the students had threatened to prevent the departure of Premier Nobusuke Kishi for Washington. This may convey to some readers the impression that the Premier does not represent the majority of the Japanese people in negotiating with the United States a revision of the 1951 Security Treaty.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The House Agriculture Committee told the Government today that it should continue its grading of lamb, but should try to work out new standards.

THESE days Tom Mboya, a young Kenyan with an imperturbable smile, may be presiding over an all-Africa meeting at Accra, making a speech in the United States or, as he did yesterday, campaigning in London for freedom for his country.
The American Association of Advertising Agencies took a major step yesterday in its a fort to rid the air of offensive television advertising.
A parade of speakers appeared before the Board of Eduration yesterday to urge a variety of improvements in the proposed school budget for 1960-61.
The familiar cry of "too much homework" was heard yesterday from an unfamiliar source.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 19 (UPI) -- Harbor interests expressed concern today over a report that the port of Buffalo had lost considerable grain trans-shipment business in 1959 through the use of the St. Lawrence Seaway.
"THE child's room should not be an orphan in the home. It should be treated as an important part of the house."

Anybody can achieve the merely difficult task of being chairman of a state delegation that has already been elected. New York's Democracy has not yet chosen its 114-vote delegation to the Democratic National Convention, a delegation that will choose its chairman. But Mr. Wagner has done the impossible; he has made himself the leader before there is any delegation.
STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 19 -- The Stamford League of Women Voters charged today that private developers were acquiring land here that should be made available for parks.

BOSTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Sugar Ray Robinson blocked traffic again today as he went through another workout for his Friday night bout with Paul Pender for the New York and Massachusetts version of the world middleweight championship.
KAMPALA, Uganda, Jan. 19 (Reuters) -- Three chiefs were reported to have been beaten to death by mobs today in the Bukedi district of eastern Uganda.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The Secretary of Defense and the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff cited revised intelligence estimates of Soviet strength today in a highly optimistic review of United States military power.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UPI) -- The Justice Department asked the Supreme Court today to review a $1,857,545 damage award to the 1954 Dixon-Yates private power combine on the ground that it bad impaired honesty standards for Federal officials.
ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- The first appropriations bill of the session raced through the Senate and crawled through the Assembly today.

CAMDEN, N.J., Jan. 19 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Warriors coasted to one of their easiest National Basketball Association victories this season, defeating the New York Knickerbockers, 114 -- 93, before 3,016 at Camden Convention Hall tonight.
THE PRESIDENT Was luncheon host to Premier Kishi of Japan. Attended signing ceremony for new United States-Japanese treaty. White House issued joint United States-Japan communique.
THE deal shown today was freakish and involved certain recurrent problems of bidding and play. Its principal aspect is geographical.
The City Council adopted unanimously yesterday a resolution calling on the police to mobilize all available security forces to protect the city's houses of worship.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- A spokesman for the nation's airline pilots said today that Congress must take over the drive for greater flying safety.
A Soviet armed invasion of the United States would result in the systematic destruction of 100,000,000 lives within a year of the first assault, Representative Craig Hosmer declared here last night.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 19 -- For those African countries producing the bulk of the world's diamonds, 1959 was the gem of all business years. Latest estimates put last year's production well above the previous peak, set in 1957.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Influential House Democrats have moved a bit nearer President Eisenhower's position on the politically explosive issue of the interest rate on Government bonds.
ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- A strong belief exists among legislative leaders that it will be impossible to muster enough votes to extend the freeze on new bank holding companies for another year.
A field of forty cars, evenly divided between American and foreign makes, looms for the international compact car races scheduled for the Daytona Beach International Speedway on Jan. 31.

In formal ceremonies in the same White House room in which President Buchanan received the first Japanese diplomatic mission to the outside world just a hundred years ago, Premier Kishi signed yesterday a mutual security pact which makes Japan a full-fledged ally of the United States and an equal partner in the community of the free world.
A holdover grand jury questioned Sidney J. Ungar yesterday about his activities in real-estate management, operation and syndication in addition to his dealings with Hulan E. Jack.
Capt. Frank S. Siwik was ordered yesterday to stay ashore for a year. He was skipper of the cruise ship Santa Rosa when she rammed a tanker last March off New Jersey.

The dates and pairings for the Public Schools Athletic League basketball play-offs in Madison Square Garden were announced yesterday by Frank E. Galloway, secretary of the High Schools Games Committee.
Only the establishment of a state penal institution here can effectively reduce the overcrowding of city prisons, Correction Commissioner Anna M. Kross declared yesterday.
NEW HAVEN, Jan. 19 (UPI) -- The police here arrested three more Yale students in a morals case involving a 14-year-old girl.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Jan. 19 -- Prime Minister Macmillan served notice today to Prime Minister Sir Roy Welensky that the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland would not be granted dominion status until it was clear that the expressed wish of the peoples "is to enter into a full and independent federation."

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 -- American Steel Foundries stockholders approved a two-for-one split of the company's common stock at their annual meeting today and heard from Joseph B. Lanterman, president, that net earnings in the first quarter of the present fiscal year were treble those of a year ago.
CHICAGO, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

THE heads of the three networks are holding one of their periodic summit meetings, this time on the proposal of John C. Doerfer, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, that the three chains do public-service television programming on a rotating basis.

PARRY O'BRIEN apologized the Instant he put the shot in his first effort of the 1956 Olympic Games in Australia. "I'm sorry," he said. "I was very nervous. Besides, they gave me a brand-new shot that was slippery."
A package of six bills aimed at reducing the number of New York families now living in single rooms was passed unanimously yesterday by the City Council.
Detroit raised $13,175,000 in the public bond market yesterday on four issues. It will use the funds to finance improvements in highways, sewerage, street lighting and other municipal services.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 19 -- The United Nations announced today that the meeting place of a regional commission session had been shifted from Pakistan to Thailand so that Israel could attend.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The Supreme Court heard argument today on a case that may determine whether the Civil Rights Commission holds any further hearings in the South.

New York University will not play in the Holiday Festival basketball tournament next Christmas season. Vic Obeck, director of athletics, confirmed the information last night while attending a meeting at the university's Alumni Club on West Forty-third Street.
The first open defiance by a producer-director of Hollywood's "blacklist" has been made by Otto Preminger.

LONDON. The United States has now accepted the Soviet challenge to an era of competitive coexistence during which there will be increasing emphasis on an economic contest to win the ideological allegiance of under-developed lands.
The United States Maritime Administration has been told that it may be faced with an unexpected $200,000,000 bill if it fails to help remedy conditions for American-flag tankers.

A WEEK ago I would have said that the art of landscape painting, as the contemplation of nature for its own sake, had died a natural death after a period of senility in the early years of our country.
SPLITTING the air with outraged howls and pitiable sobs, 7-month-old Renee Shwabe took small consolation in the fact that she was posing with one of the nation's leading family life educators.
The union of the artist and the craftsman in the eighteenth century world is being celebrated today, about 150 years later, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- State Department officials acknowledged today that Soviet success in financing and construction of the Aswan High Dam on the Nile River would probably enhance Soviet prestige in Africa and Asia.

A Brooklyn College spokesman said yesterday that the suspension of a graduating senior from the editorial board of The Kingsman, the college's student newspaper, would be continued but that no action would be taken against him "as an individual student."

Ranking religious educators of the Roman Catholic, Protestant and Jewish faiths yesterday hailed current extensive examination of religious educational texts to promote relations among ethnic and religious groups.
The One William Street Fund, Inc., wound up 1959 with its highest net asset total to date, according to the annual report released yesterday.

Directors of the Continental Steel Corporation yesterday declared a quarterly dividend of 75 cents on the present common stock, payable on March 15. In previous quarters, shareholders received 50 cents, plus an extra of $2.50 at the year-end.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The immediate result of yesterday's Supreme Court decisions barring military trials for civilians abroad with the armed forces will probably be to subject more of those civilians to trial in foreign courts.

MONTE CARLO, Jan. 19 (UPI) -- A Dutch sportscar driver was killed in a crash and three other vehicles dropped out of the running today in the early hours of the twenty-ninth annual Monte Carlo automobile rally being run over Europe's icy roads.
CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Jan. 19 (UPI) -- A German bobsled team challenged the Italians' supremacy today in the second day of the trial runs for the world two-man championships.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 19 -- President Adolfo Lopez Mateos of Mexido arrived here today on a five-day state visit to Brazil. The visit is part of a South American tour that is viewed as marking his nation's full adherence to hemispheric plans for economic and political cooperation.
LONDON, Jan. 19 -- The terms of the contract signed by the Soviet Union for the marketing of its diamond exports to the West are not to be made public.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The White House has failed to resolve a bitter inter-departmental fight over the use of chemicals in the production of food.

Among the many reforms in the New York City school system proposed in the Heald report, one that would have lasting benefits and that wouldn't cost the city a cent awaits the initiative of Mayor Wagner. This reform is improvement of the method of selecting members of the Board of Education.

DECATUR, Ala., Jan. 19 -- One of the biggest winter concentrations of crows anywhere in the South, and maybe anywhere else, is in this region -- something like 250,000 birds. It ought to attract hunters from everywhere in the country, but so far it has not attracted many.
CHICAGO, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Grain futures here on the Board of Trade slowly drifted into general weakness today in another meager trade volume. Only rye and near soybeans rose.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization of parents, lists the following films as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old. They will be shown Friday through Sunday, unless otherwise noted.
British European Airways hopes to put sixty-passenger convertiplanes in service from mid-London to the Continent by the end of 1963.

The southeast corner of York Avenue and Eighty-seventh Street -- a plot 100 by 90 feet -- has been sold for all cash by the Jewish Child Care Association to Jack Resnick, realty investor and builder. John J. Reynolds, Inc., was the broker.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The nomination of Raymond A. Hare, a career diplomat, as a Deputy Under Secretary of State was approved today by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
The Tennessee Gas Transmission Company plans to distribute about June 14 one new share for each two common shares held May 20.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The recent proposal of Governor Rockefeller to the Legislature on the current pressing problem of the education of our children epitomizes the basic difference in the philosophy of the Republican and Democratic parties.

"A GUEST AND HIS GOING,"* a new novel by P.H. Newby, is a light and tasty souffle compounded of equal parts of comedy, satire and lunacy. Such expert entertainment of this bizarre variety has not been offered to the book-reading public since the publication of two earlier novels written by Mr. Newby in the same vein, "The Picnic at Sakkara" and "Revolution and Roses."
LONDON, Jan. 19 -- Commonwealth status for Cyprus is being written into a bill establishing the island's independence from Britain, authoritative Government sources said today.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 19 -- A labor union's right to expel members for disloyalty has been upheld by a Superior Court judge.

THE GOVERNOR Took injection against influenza with Lieut. Gov. Malcolm Wilson. Received Pakistani Ambassador Aziz Ahmed and Pakistani Consul General in New York, K.M. Kaiser. Signed deficiency appropriations bill passed today by Legislature.
Inauguration In an Off Year If 1960 were an inauguration year instead of an election year, someone would be taking the oath of office as President of the United States today.

Philip Rose is faced these lays with the same problem that confronted him when he produced "A Raisin in the Sun." As with the Lorraine Hansberry hit drama, he cannot obtain a proper Broadway theatre for his production of "SemiDetached," by Patricia Joudry.

Long liquidation and selling by professional traders depressed potato futures yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The market was firm early in the session on short covering, influenced by cold weather in Idaho.
Repeal of the city's highly controversial 10-cent-a-ride taxi tax was voted unanimously yesterday by the City Council, effective July 1.
SAN FRANCICO, Jan. 19 -- Gov. Edmund G. Brown twirled his hat into the Presidential ring today.

President Eisenhower's "last budget battle with Congress" began last Monday. Exactly one year from today, at noon, Mr. Eisenhower may still be worrying about the next Federal budget, but he can then begin to worry about it as a private citizen, and not as the Chief Executive of this country.
Weather and the perversity of steel girders snarled traffic on the Henry Hudson Parkway near the George Washington Bridge during the morning rush hours yesterday.

Richard Burton, the angry young hero of "Look Back in Anger," and Jeanne Moreau, who swept aside social and cinematic traditions in the Frenchmade "The Lovers," will team in "Moderato Cantabile," a production that combines elements from the strongest recent currents of French and British film-making.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 19 -- The dispute between the owners of a controversial collection of Italian Renaissance paintings and their agents reached Superior Court today.

Mayor John F. Collins of Boston, sitting in a wheel chair yesterday, puffed on a big cigar and crossed his legs as he reiterated a phrase that became a slogan before he took office two weeks ago: "The Mayor of Boston should run the city with his head, not his feet."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The United States and Japan signed a treaty of mutual cooperation and security today. They pledged to regard an attack on the Japanese home islands or on United States bases there as a threat to the peace and safety of both countries.
A JARRING reminder of the nature and extent of organized crime in the United States was offered last night over Channel 4.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UPI) -- The Senate voted today to make state primaries for Federal office subject to campaign spending limits and reporting requirements of the Corrupt Practices Act.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed unchanged to 13 points (65c a bale) off yesterday. The new crop months were the weakest.
IF stores keep mending their merchandising ways, shopping for furniture may become a pleasure rather than an anguishing experience.
The Columbia Broadcasting System is trying to make arrangements to tape a "Playhouse 90" drama in London that would star Laurence Harvey and Simone Signoret.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Several independent iron-ore mining companies signed new contracts today with the United Steetworkers of America. Other major independents, also located in the Minnesota-Michigan iron range, were expected to sign shortly.
A plan to merge all of the war colleges of the armed forces under a single command and with a common curriculum is being pressed upon the services by President Eisenhower.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Planning to buy a house this year, or borrow money for any other purpose?
ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- A Queens Assemblyman appealed today to the Legislature for a limitation on the right of insurance companies to cancel automobile liability policies.

The city bore down on landlords of neglected tenements in two courts yesterday. In a third court, a landlord charged with failure to provide proper heat, challenged the authority of the Magistrates' Court to try him.

THOSE whose childhood was spent in such widely separated parts of the world as a Sicilian city, a tropical hamlet in Puerto Rico or a bleak Nova Scotian fishing village may have one memory in common. That recollection would be of eating salt cod.

IT was a rugged afternoon at the Theatre de Lys yesterday. Between Feodor Dostoevski's "Notes from the Underground" and Eugene lonesco's "Victims of Duty," a rising barometer and a falling thermometer, only the hardiest of theatregoers are likely to have emerged toward dusk as clear-headed as when they had entered.
The National Motor Boat Show, whose growth has matched that of boating for fun almost every year for half a century, is not going to get any bigger as long as it remains in the New York Coliseum.
Among the fifty persons who died in the Capital Airlines crash in Virginia Monday were seven Naval officers, five seamen, five wives of servicemen and two children of servicemen.

CHILDREN under 12 are admitted at half price to the Saturday morning performance of the Ice Follies of 1960, at Madison Square Garden. Tickets are $2 to $6. The show, which will run through Sunday, has performances tonight and Thursday at 7:30 P.M., Friday at 8:30 P.M., Saturday at 11 A.M. and 3 and 8:30 P.M., and Sunday at 2 P.M. and 6 P.M. For information, call Columbus 5-6811.
LONDON, Jan. 19 -- An old British export to America will return to the roost tomorrow with the introduction of tenpin bowling here.
YAOUNDE, Cameroon, Jan. 18 -- Premier Ahmadou Ahidjo took full responsibility today for the summoning of French reinforcements to suppress the rebellion in this new West African country.

Directors of the Trade Bank and Trust Company plan to continue a program of extra stock dividends as long as the institution continues to grow as rapidly as it has in the past, Henry L. Schenck, president, told the annual meeting yesterday.
ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 19 (AP) -- A Scandinavian Airlines jet liner plunged into a hilltop within sight of Ankara's airport tonight, killing forty-one of the forty-two persons aboard.
The United States and the Soviet Union are exchanging butterflies these days.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In accordance with the usual democratic practice and fair play, I hope that you will publish these main objections to the news article "Guatemala Chief Gains in Congress," written especially for The New York Times and published in your Jan. 17 issue.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The United States Court of Claims ruled today that the main purpose of the League of Women Voters was influencing legislation. The 3-to-2 ruling cost the league $11,913.70.
Senator John F. Kennedy will be the principal speaker at this year's $100-a-plate Democratic fund-raising dinner, Michael H. Prendergast, the Democratic state chairman, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- John C. Doerfer, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, has persuaded the three national television networks to carry cultural and educational programs on a regular basis during prime evening hours.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts gave a clear indication today that he would announce tomorrow his entry into the Nebraska Presidential primary as well as the one in Wisconsin.
CHICAGO, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department ou Agriculture follows:

The men's and juniors' North American sailing championship regattas will be held in Wisconsin next summer and the comparable event for women off Annapolis, Md. The dates and locations were announced at the annual meeting of the North American Yacht Racing Union in the New York Yacht Club last night.

MOSCOW, Jan. 20 -- An article in Pravda suggested today that the Soviet Union no longer felt bound to return Shikotan Island and the Habomai group to Japan when a Japanese-Soviet peace treaty is signed.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Jan. 20 -- The Dominion party warned Prime Minister Macmillan today that "unless the security of the European in Southern Rhodesia and the country's natural wealth are assured, the colony will have no alternative but to secede" from the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland.
NEW HAVEN, Jan. 20 -- Taking ten of eleven first places, Yale's varsity swimming team swamped Wesleyan, 73-21, tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The United States Court of Claims cleared Lawrence West-brook of wrongdoing today in connection with a $9,000,000 Government tungsten contract that figured in the 1952 political campaign.
ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- Legislation setting up a parking authority for New York City was filed in the Legislature today by Assemblyman Bentley Kassal, Democrat of Manhattan.
Mayor Wagner announced yesterday that his administration would introduce in the Legislature on Monday two bills to increase penalties against hit-and-run motorists.
DURING the last month, New Yorkers have been intrigued by a series of newspaper advertisements that have come to be known as the Black Pearl Mystery.

Why do you own a dog? "Some people choose a dog to reflect their own personality, others to complement or compensate for a lack in their own personality," said Dr. Eugene L. Hartley, Professor of Psychology at The City College, yesterday.

Stockholders of the Silex Company will be asked at a special meeting on Feb. 26 to vote on the company's plan to merge with the Proctor Electric Company. Shareholders also will be asked to increase the authorized common stock of Silex to provide the additional shares necessary to effect the merger.
HONG KONG, Jan. 20 -- Communist China failed to reach its 1959 goal for grain production, an article in the Hong Kong Communist newspaper Ta Kung Pao disclosed today.

A GOOD conductor can impress his personality and style on an unfamiliar orchestra in a short time if the ensemble itself is of high quality and its members are willing to cooperate. Such a conductor, William Steinberg, and such an orchestra, the Boston Symphony, joined forces at Carnegie Hall last night with fascinating results.
