The Douglas Aircraft Company incurred a loss of $33,822,000 in the fiscal year ended Nov. 30 as a result of its heavy jet program, Donald W. Douglas, chairman of the big Santa Monica, Calif., aircraft builder, said yesterday.
MONTREAL, Jan. 20 -- John C. Doyle, president of Canadian Javelin, Ltd., was charged in Criminal Court here today with the theft of $4,800,000 worth of the mining company's stock.

The Soviet Union's decision to finance the second, as well as the first, stage of the Aswan High Dam in Egypt testifies again to the great importance Moscow attaches to the Middle East. It should not be overlooked that the Soviet Union has agreed to this step despite the fact that President Nasser has cracked down hard during the past year on Communists in the United Arab Republic.
Volume dried up on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday as investors vacillated. Prices moved off a little and for the ninth time in the last eleven days the declines out-numbered the advances.
"FRAGILE -- handle with love," the advice given to prospective fathers on the care and feeding of their occasionally cantankerous spouses, brings emotional dividends to mother and child.

Yesterday the President transmitted the last of his three major annual messages to Congress -- his annual Economic Report, which is required of him under the provisions of the Employment Act of 1946. The other two are the State of the Union Message, which he delivered in person before a joint session of the House and Senate on Jan. 7; and the Budget Message for the fiscal year 1961, which he transmitted last Monday.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Jan. 20 -- A twenty-seven-month court fight that delayed the construction of a new high school here apparently ended today when the school board announced it would proceed with plans to build the school.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 20 (UPI) -- The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) (Sohio) announced today that it was abandoning plans to acquire Leonard Refineries, Inc., a Michigan refining and marketing company.
Three men, including a father and son, were arraigned in Special Sessions Court yesterday on charges of operating a loan shark ring that preyed for the most part on taxicab drivers.
ACCRA, Ghana, Jan. 20 Ghana will become a republic July 1 under terms of a Government bill published here today. Prime Minister Kwame Nkrumah is almost certain to be the republic's first President.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 20 -- The president-elect of the American Geriatrics Society said today there was "a lot of chaff and not too much wheat" in the thinking about problems of the aging.

The merger last year creating the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York has proved even better in practice than it seemed to promise on paper, Henry C. Alexander, chairman, told the annual meeting yesterday.
The establishment of the Harry S. Truman Chair in American Civilization at Brandeis University, Waltham, Mass., was announced yesterday.

"My Life in Poetry," the autobiography of Stanton A. Coblentz, will be issued Monday by Bookman Associates. Mr. Coblentz is the author of sixteen books of verse and twenty of prose, compiler of four anthologies of poetry and the founder and editor of Wings, the poetry quarterly.
DALLAS, Jan. 20 -- Robert Vernon Spears, who made Dallas his headquarters for about ten years, has had at least nine convictions in many states.

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- Sir Anthony Eden told President Eisenhower on July 27, 1956 that the British Cabinet was convinced it must be prepared, in the last resort, to use force against Egypt because of her seizure of control of the Suez Canal.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Prof. Dudley W. Johnson, of Lehigh University, in a letter on this page of The Times of Jan. 18, questioned whether removing from antitrust laws the special immunity of organized labor would effectively check the unions' monopoly powers to (1) prod inflation by enforced annual wage increases, and (2) halt essential national production by control of the labor supply of nation-wide industry.

Light fuel oil supplies, used mostly for home heating, were further depleted in the week ended last Friday, according to the American Petroleum Institute. They dropped by 5,595,000 barrels in the week to 138,539,000 at the week-end.
ALTHOUGH the surfaces are bright in "Parade," which opened at the Players Theatre last evening, the materials are thin.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Jan. 20 -- The Belgian Government brought together forty-four leaders of the Belgian Congo today to hear their opinions on how to set up an independent state.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 20 -- Important executives at major studios here said today that they intended to continue their policy of not hiring writers who refused to cooperate with Congressional investigating committees.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr., Democrat of Manhattan, said today that he had supplied information to the New York District Attorney's office that would lead to the top of the city's number racket.

Funds for a "stand-by" air alert for the Strategic Air Command, more intercontinental ballistic missiles, and a cut in Air Force and Navy personnel and piloted planes were proposed Monday in the President's defense budget.
The National Maritime Union yesterday scored another victory in its drive to organize nineteen ships operated under the Honduran flag by the United Fruit Company.

CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Jan. 20 (UPI) -- Official tryouts for the world two-man bobsled championships entered their next-to-last day today with the Germans sweeping the board for the second time in a row.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Villanova, led by the rebounding of George Raveling and the scoring of John Driscoll, turned back Seton Hall, 94-65, tonight.

Three old friends will make music on Sunday, Feb. 14, when the Moscow State Symphony makes its final New York appearance at Madison Square Garden. They are Van Cliburn the American pianist Valerli Klimoy, the Russian violinist, and Kiril Kondrashin, the Russian conductor. Konstantin Ivanov will share the podium with Mr. Kondrashin.

LENZERHEIDE, Switzerland, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Linda Meyers' victory today in the Lenzerheide women's giant slalom race highlighted the finest showing so far in Europe by America's men and women Olympic skiers.

LAST night at the City Center the New York City Ballet presented an entire program of new choreographies by five choreographers to music by eight Latin-American composers under the general title of "Panamerica."

A low-price cooking stove, not much larger than a teapot, is warming the hearts of Brazilian housewives and heating up some new kerosene business for an affiliate of Standard Oil Company (New Jersey).
A plan for leasing machine tools, said to be unique in the manufacturing industry, was announced yesterday by the Jones Lamson Machine Company of Springfield, Vt.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Following are excerpts from President Eisenhower's letter of transmittal and from the Economic Report sent to Congress today:
The Government rested its case yesterday in the seventh week of the conspiracy trial of Alexander L. Guterma, the financier, and other defendants.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (UPI) -- Senator Jacob K. Javits introduced today a bill that would eliminate poll taxes and other economic qualifications for voting in national elections in a dozen states.
MOONACHIE, N.J., Jan. 20 -- The Board of Assessment here has taken the first official step in the borough's effort to make the Port of New York Authority pay taxes.
BOSTON, Jan. 20 -- Gov. Foster Furcolo proposed today a billion-dollar accelerated highway program for Massachusetts.
Manned exploration of the universe may be blocked 588 trillion miles out -- less than one-thousandth the diameter of this galaxy -- by the "disintegration barrier."

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20 -- The city, two railroads and railroad labor joined today in announcing a nonprofit corporation that is designed to increase fast rail transportation within the city, help the railroads stay in business and keep automobiles out of midtown.

Gilbert Miller is to produce "I Give It Six Months" (tentative title) next season. It is the same comedy that George S. Kaufman and his former wife, Leueen MacGrath, were writing last October under the temporary name of "The Common Language."
The neighborhood organizational approach was endorsed yesterday for dealing with intergroup tensions resulting from population shifts.

PARIS, Jan. 20 -- The reform of the Comedie-Francaise, which had not been going smoothly since its inception last April, got another jolt today when Claude Breart de Boisanger was discharged as its administrator.

As Europe's colonial domain continues to recede in Africa a new factor begins to emerge in that hitherto rather quiescent continent. It further complicates the task of African leaders to give effect to their people's clamor for freedom and independence.
CHICAGO, Jan. 20 -- The nation's home builders gave qualified endorsement today to the emergency housing legislation advocated by the Democratic leadership in Congress.

Bond issues totaling $54,195,000 were sold yesterday in the public market by the states of Washington, Louisiana and North Carolina. The state offerings topped a heavy schedule of market borrowings by local governments.
Un Bal Masque a 1'Opera de Paris will be the theme of the ninth annual April in Paris Ball. This year the event will be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Astor on April 8.
MONTE CARLO, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The number of American drivers in the Monte Carlo auto rally was cut in half today as the dwindling band approached France's icy Massif Central mountains.

ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- Organized labor in New York State took a cautiously critical attitude today toward Governor Rockefeller's recommendations for higher social insurance benefits and a new state-wide minimum wage.

A VISITOR to Manhattan recently strolled along Ninth Avenue fascinated by the open-air markets between Thirty-fourth and Forty-sixth Streets. She stopped to buy a prickly pear, admired a bunch of plantains and turned to a basket of mushrooms.

The short interest in shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange fell sharply in the latest reporting month. The Exchange reported that the short interest decreased to 2,747,844 shares on Jan. 15 from 3,077,469 on Dec. 15.

MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Willie Pastrano of Miami Beach gained a unanimous decision over Jerry Luedee in a ten-round, light-heavyweight bout at the Miami Beach Audiditorium tonight Pastrano weighed 177 3/4, Luedee 174.
TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 20 -- William Allen Taylor, the man believed to have taken the place of Spears on the ill-fated National Airlines plane last Nov. 16, also had a long criminal record.

Dr. James E. Alien Jr., State Commissioner of Education, has estimated that operating the public elementary and secondary schools for the next decade will require an additional expenditure of $160,000,000 annually.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A Times-tested recipe is suggested for a comparatively easy-to-prepare main dish.

An empty New Haven Railroad train was derailed at Grand Central Terminal yesterday morning, causing the cancellation of four outbound trains and the delay of twenty-five inbound trains with thousands of commuters. No injuries were reported.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The Senate adopted today a proposal to require reports from virtually all state and local political committees on money raised and spent in Federal election campaigns. The vote was 53-37.
MOSCOW, Jan. 20 -- The Soviet Government promised special civilian privileges today to more than 250,000 officers who will lose their jobs in the one-third reduction of armed forces.
LONDON, Jan. 20 -- The African delegation to the stalled Kenya constitutional conference charged Colonial Secretary Iain Macleod today with having "succumbed to European settler pressure."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Senator Stuart Symington proposed today to bring farm price and income stability and a reduction in crop surpluses through higher price supports and more rigid controls.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Two Republican Senators put an expanded school construction bill before President Eisenhower today but failed to get his endorsement.

A large list of patrons and patronesses has been reported for the twenty-first White Elephant Party. The event, to be held Feb. 4, is a benefit for the Child Adoption Service of the State Charities Aid Association, and will be the first function to take place in the new ballroom of the Pierre Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- For nearly two years the Navy has virtually foreclosed bidding on oil cargo shipping contracts to United States-flag ships that previously did business with Israel.

MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 20 -- Seven National Football League club owners tonight voted for Marshall E. Leahy, 49-year-old San Francisco lawyer, as commissioner of the professional circuit. Four others favored Don Kellett, 50-year-old general manager of the world champion Baltimore Colts.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 20 -- The West German Bundestag condemned today the recent outbreak of anti-Semitic vandalism as a "disgrace."
HAVANA, Thursday, Jan. 21 -- Juan Pablo de Lojendio, Marquess de Vallisca, the Spanish Ambassador to Cuba, was early today ordered to his face to leave Cuba in twenty-four hours.
Peter Kavanagh was ordered yesterday to show cause why he should not destroy the 100-copy edition of "The John Quinn Letters" that he published here last week.
LOS ANGELES. CATERING to the improved tastes of furniture buyers is the keynote of the annual winter market week at the Home Furnishings Mart here.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 20 (AP) -- Jorge Zayas, publisher of the Havana newspaper Avance, took political refuge in the United States today.

GENEVA, Jan. 20 -- The Soviet Union was reported today to have reversed its field and dropped some of its demands for veto rights in the operation of an international control system to detect nuclear tests.

A policy of mutual concessions intended to make the "Filipino First" program compatible with the revised United States-Philippine trade agreement was outlined yesterday by top officials of the United States Department of Commerce.
BOSTON, Jan. 20 -- Radioactive fallout may virtually cease within the next few years, instead of continuing for as long as a century as indicated earlier.
The Southwestern Public Service Company yesterday announced a two-for-one split of its stock, effective on March 1, pending approval by regulatory commissions.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 20 -- The Board of Selectmen tonight postponed a new parking plan after 100 merchants had engaged in a mass protest. The board agreed to defer the plan until "adequate" off-street parking was provided.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Army leaders drew unfavorable comparisons today between this country's army and that of the Soviet Union.
YESTERDAY (Jan. 20, 1960) THE PRESIDENT Sent annual Economic Report to Congress.
The Allied Chemical Corporation last year chalked up an increase of 46.2 per cent in earnings over the 1958 figure and set a new sales record, according to the report issued yesterday.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The editorial in The Times of Jan. 18 on "Residence and Relief," opposing passage of the Cooke-Volker bill by the State Legislature, correctly states that "a residence requirement for relief is no way to deal with the public assistance problem."
THE words bubbled forth from a joyous heart. They have since been paraphrased and used elsewhere. But Laughing Larry Doyle said them first almost fifty years ago.
New Yorkers received renewed assurances yesterday that the subway system is safe.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan 20 -- Providence College defeated Yale tonight, 9-4, in hockey.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- President Eisenhower will visit Japan about June 20 on his way home from the Soviet Union.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 20 -- In a jaunty black and white checkered sports cap, Robert Vernon Spears came to the temporary Federal Court House for his arraignment this afternoon.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 (UPI) -- Bobby Hull got his twenty-seventh goal and an assist tonight to take over the National Hockey League scoring lead and help the Chicago Black Hawks beat the Boston Bruins, 3-1.
NEW DELHI, Jan. 20 -- A party of top Soviet leaders arrived today to begin an eighteen-day tour of India and the neighboring Himalayan kingdom of Nepal.
MIAMI, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Bally Ache made his winter debut at Hialeah Park today and scored a six-length triumph in the $28,800 Hibiscus Stakes before a crowd of 18,402.
PARIS, Jan. 20 -- President de Gaulle and his Government struck back at French civil and military critics today with reaffirmation of the policy of self-determination for Algeria.
Sidney J. Ungar testified about his real estate operations for two and a half hours yesterday before the grand jury that indicted Borough President Hulan E. Jack of Manhattan.

BOSTON, Jan. 20 (UPI) -- Tommy Heinsohn tallied 43 points tonight to pace the Boston Celtics to a 144-126-victory over the New York Knickerbockers in a National Basketball Association game. It was Boston's fourth straight success and its eighth in a row over New York.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- President Eisenhower began his final year in the White House today with some sound advice to the younger generation of his party.
The proposed developers of the Bellevue South slum clearance project suggested yesterday that merchants displaced by the development band together to operate its shopping center.

Bill Tully of the New York seeding, won by 15-8, 15-9, A.C., the 1959 victor, was eliminated in the quarter-finals of the New York State squash racquets singles championship yesterday at the Downtown A.C. Dave Johnson, Heights Casino, No. 5 in the tourney, one notch back of Tully in the 10 -- 15, 15 -- 9.
Control of the $450,000,000 first and second stages of the new Delaware water system will pass this year to the city's operational arm, the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity.
The premiere of the New York Philharmonic's Young People's Concerts has been put off from this Saturday until next month so that the jingle of the sponsor's coin can join in the chorus.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to 14 points (70 cents a bale) off yesterday. The old-crop months were weakest.

The professional qualifications of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad's management as well as the line's efficiency came under severe questioning yesterday at a Public Service Commission hearing here.

Affliction Without a Cure Of all the coldseason ills a man is heir to, none exacts a greater toll from one's sense of emotional and physical well-being than the return to work of the winter vacationer.
The latest insiders' list issued by the New York Stock Exchange shows stock sales by three officers of the Fruehauf Traller Company.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The New Haven Railroad has announced a 10 per cent fare increase, with others to come every six months until a total of 70 per cent is reached. President George Alpert states that it is this or else complete shutdown.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 20 (UPI) -- An insurgent group of stockholders has assumed control of Timely Clothes, Inc.
ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Two plane crashes in Turkey, about five hours and 250 miles apart, appeared tonight to have claimed fifty-eight lives.
LONDON, Jan. 20 -- Stock market prices advanced here today as yesterday's bout of small selling dried up.

DECATUR, Ala., Jan. 20 -- Vast flocks of crows can be located in the evenings hereabouts with almost no trouble, and the crow-hunter gets a couple of hours of fast shooting. On fair days he can shoot all day long by working on the scattered crows -- if he is a good caller and can stay hidden.
CHICAGO, Jan. 20 (AP) -- A late mild flurry of buying sprinkled the grain futures market with a few small gains today, but it appeared to be indicative of nothing significant.
Sanford Stein and Solomon Chodorov, former rent collectors in run-down tenements formerly operated by Banton Wyckoff, were involved in court actions again yesterday.
The Outboard Marine Corporation yesterday clarified the purpose of its new Special Products Division.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Robert Vernon Spears, a "nature doctor" with a criminal background, was found, safe and healthy, in a Phoenix, Ariz., motel today by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. He had been listed among the forty-two victims of an airplane crash in the Gulf of Mexico last Nov. 16.

The merged labor federation has just scored its most dramatic breakthrough in its fight to eliminate racial discrimination in its affiliated unions. The victory took the form of an overwhelming decision by a special convention of the 200,000 member Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen to scrap the color bar in its constitution.

Net income of the Maryland Shipbuilding and Drydock Company in the year ended on Dec. 31 declined to $661,975 from $2,125,885 in 1958, William Purnell Hall, president, disclosed in the annual report issued yesterday.

EVEN lifetime scholars have a difficult time sorting out the personages proliferating in ancient Indian literature. It has been estimated that the great Hindu epic poem, the Mahabharata, runs to some 200,000 lines -- longer, probably, than any mythological or religious texts in history.
The controversy over pilotage on the Great Lakes is nearing settlement, according to reports in the industry yesterday.
Tho Durst Organization, builders, have announced plans for a twenty-two-story office building at the southeast corner of Third Avenue and Forty-sixth Street.

DSCHANG, Cameroon, Jan. 18 -- Murderous anarchy spreading through the hill country of Bamileke is threatening an early distintegration of Cameroon, Africa's newest state. The country became independent of France Jan. 1.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- President Elsenhower advised his fellow Americans today to count their economic blessings and share the responsibility for continuing the highest living scale in the world.

SKI SKETCH: Joe Jones, a Rutland (Vt.) insurance broker, might be compared with the Pied Piper of Hamelin. He heads the Pico Ski Club's junior program, one of the busiest in the East. The club has 100 youngsters enrolled in its racing group and 200 more in the recreational division.
The Board of Education is not doing enough to promote integration in the public school system, the Commission on Intergroup Relations charged yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan 20 -- President Eisenhower told Congress today that the economy was in good shape and that the United States should be able to step up its rate of economic growth in the Nineteen Sixties.
Experts on Chinese and Slavic studies and a former British civil servant received three of ten prizes of $10,000 each awarded here yesterday by the American Council of Learned Societies.

An offering of $25,000,000 of first and refunding mortgage bonds of the Connecticut Light and Power Company was made by underwriters yesterday. The bonds bear 4 7/8 per cent interest coupons and mature in 1990. Morgan Stanley Co., Putnam Co., Chas. W. Scranton Co. and Estabrook Co. are joint managers of an underwriting group offering the bonds at 99 per cent to yield about 4.94 per cent to maturity.

The old-crop potato positions continued strong yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The near months rose 3 to 8 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 907 car lots. The November position, which is influenced by the coming crop, was off 2 points on only thirteen car lots.

The old-crop potato positions continued strong yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The near months rose 3 to 8 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 907 car lots. The November position, which is influenced by the coming crop, was off 2 points on only thirteen car lots.
Steady gains against the pollution of metropolitan waters were reported yesterday by the interstate Sanitation Commission.
United States Government securities fell out of step yesterday with a bond market that otherwise continued to engender rising prices.

A 35-YEAR-OLD Frenchman is taking status out of fur and giving it a soul. He is Jacques Kaplan, who looks like a doctor of philosophy from the Sorbonne and not at all like a graduate of France's St. Cyr military academy.

The head of a state inquiry into the city's affairs assured Mayor Wagner in a conciliatory letter yesterday that he had been describing city problems in a speech last week, rather than criticizing the Wagner administration.

A HOLD-UP play in bridge is refusal to take an ace the first time its suit is led. The hold-up may be an entry-killing play, an avoidance play (to keep one opponent out of the lead), a timing play, or a deceptive play.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Charges directed toward the removal of James R. Hoffa as president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters will be brought to a hearing in Federal Court Feb. 23.

Electric power production in the nation dipped to 14,236,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the week ended Jan. 16. This was a decline from a record 14,308,000,000 kilowatt-hours set the week before, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday.
ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- The League of Women Voters urged the Legislature today to make the requirement for a house-to-house canvass of voters optional rather than mandatory.

ANN SCHAFFER has a positive passion for Paisley. The diminutive London-born owner of "Ann's Threadneedle Antiques," 46 Eighth Avenue, regards old Paisley shawls in the way most people feel about children -- tenderly, lovingly and with a certain amount of awe.

It is hardly news to investors and Wall Street followers that the stock market has beer taking a pretty bad drubbing so far this year. But there art patterns within patterns and there are exceptions to the rule, not only for individual issues but also for industrial groups.

Lamb Industries, Inc., had an operating profit of $567,544, or 58 cents a share, last year, Edward Lamb, chairman, reported yesterday. In 1958 the company had an operating loss of 546,621 before a special credit of $1,735,030.

THE articulate Socialist and Vice President of the Bundestag who urged Germans yesterday to clean out all remnants of nazism is a rarity -- a professor who to his title-conscious compatriots is not "Herr Professor" but plain Carlo Schmid.
WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 20 -- A land transaction that has shaken Tarrytown politically for two years will be investigated by a Westchester County grand jury, the District Attorney's office said today.

THE Tichman Trio, playing last night at the Lexington Avenue Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association, introduced a piece of music to New York. It was the Trio for clarinet, 'cello and piano by Robert Parris.
MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 20 -- The Long Island State Park Commission's policy on airplane advertising over Jones Beach State Park was clarified today by Robert Moses, the commission president.

The Yankees, individually and collectively, apparently are determined to try any route that will restore them to their former high estate. Bill Skowron, for instance, is trying the water iroute. The Moose, for all that he has just turned 29, is taking swimming lessons as a possible remedy for the injuries that have plagued him through his career.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 20 -- Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd announced today the terms under which South Africa will become a republic within the next few years.
The Federal Trade Commission came under attack yesterday from Walter Weir, chair man of the executive committee of Donahue Coe, Inc.
ALBANY, Jan. 20 (UPI) -- Assemblyman William J. Butler left legislators to ponder today a new expression, a new word and a new concept to encourage greater lucidity during legislative debates.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The Soviet Union may have fired a high-thrust space rocket into the Pacific today. The Pentagon announced that it was studying unverified reports that an object had landed at noon, Eastern Standard Time, in the vicinity of the area set aside by the Russians as a range for the period from Jan. 16 to Feb. 16.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) made a loan equivalent to $17,600,000 yesterday in Colombia to increase the supply of electrical power to Bogota and surrounding areas by about 117,000 kilowatts.

The visit of President Eisenhower to India last month and the wonderful reception that he received did not mean that India was turning her back on Russia. Premier Nehru's policy of nonalignment and independence has not changed.
HANOVER, N.H., Jan. 20 -- The Navy swimming team defeated Dartmouth, 52-43, today in Spaulding pool.
Following is a list of the passengers and crew members aboard the plane that crashed yesterday at Montego Bay, as issued by Avianca Airlines:

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 21 -- Global consumption of primary forms of energy increased 37 per cent from 1951 through 1958, to the equivalent of 3,700,000,000 metric tons of coal. The total represented an average of 1.3 tons for each person in the world or 50 per cent more than per capita consumption in 1929.

Wayne County, Mich., borrowed $4,360,000 on Wednesday night to finance public school construction, at an interest cost of 4.395 per cent. The county sold an issue of aerial bonds due from 1960 to 1985 and callable in 1975 to a syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 21 (AP) -- Pat Tiernan of Manhasset, L.I., defeated the National Collegiate champion. Judy Eller of Miami, 2 and 1, and Mrs. Maurice Glick of Baltimore ousted the four-time Arkansas champion, Mrs. J.J. Miller of Hot Springs, 2 and 1, in upsets today in the Helen Doherty women's golf tournament.
Record sales and earnings were achieved by the Divco-Wayne Corporation in its fiscal year ended Oct. 31, the annual report of Newton Glekel, president, disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The increase in the British bank rate brought a shiver resembling fear in some sections of the economic community here today.
Three former New York Governors -- all Democrats -- called yesterday for a nonpartisan legislative commission to study Governor Rockefeller's State Government reorganization plan.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Jan. 21 -- Joseph Kasavubu, president of the Association of the Lower Congo, or Abako, urged today that a Congolese Government be formed as quickly as possible.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 21 -- Honolulu fans soon will see National Basketball Association games on television.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- A House petition to get civil rights bill out of the Rules Committee to the floor no wincludes the names of 145 Democrats and 30 Republicans.
Moscow's claim yesterday of a one-and-a-quarter-mile circular error in a 7,762-mile rocket flight caused raised eyebrows but no excitement in the Pentagon.
A state inquiry into the city's affairs will start public hearings Monday on whether construction activities in Staten Island are being "abused for the benefit of a favored few."

WALLOPS ISLAND, Va., Jan. 21 -- A small monkey named Miss Sam survived a brief but jolting rocket ride today to test the emergency escape system to be used in manned space flights. The experiment was pronounced a complete success by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

KEEPING a kosher home may demand less physical effort of today's Orthodox Jewish housewife than it did just a few decades ago. But modern kosher housekeeping does present one major problem. The very processed foods that save endless hours of preparation also create questions as to the acceptability of such products under Jewish dietary laws.

MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 21 -- National Football League club owners again failed to resolve the stalemate in their efforts to elect a new commissioner tonight. They adjourned until 10 o'clock tomorrow morning. In the lead, but still two votes short of election, was Marshall E. Leahy, the 49-year-old San Francisco lawyer who is counsel for the Forty-Niners.

Business loans at leading New York City banks declined $322,000,000 in the first three weeks of 1960, compared with a decline of $324,000,000 in the 1959 period, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- A United States Court of Appeals judge suggested today that it was not for the courts to decide whether this country should test nuclear weapons.
The detection of potential delinquency in children under 6 years old has been reduced to a relatively exact science, city officials said yesterday.
JERSEY CITY, Jan. 21 -- Hudson County Judge James Rosen today ended the trial of City Clerk James A. Tumulty Jr. by dismissing a charge of neglect of duty.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 21 -- Dynamite caps have been found in the luggage of Robert Vernon Spears, who was arrested here yesterday two months after he supposedly died aboard an airliner that crashed in the Gulf of Mexico.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 21 -- About 7,000 dock workers were merged into one union under the aegis of the International Longshoremen's Association. The action ended seven years of dock strife in Puerto Rico.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 21 -- Top-level meetings between movie company presidents and the Screen Actors Guild were finished for the time being and company heads were leaving here today for their New York offices.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- There is sound basis for the criticism that the President's messages to Congress this year stress the production of private possessions, which could be spared, over national needs, which must be supplied if the United States is to attain and keep the power level required to effect its proclaimed objectives and the security of its system.

Everybody is right in the dispute that has arisen because of the enthusiasm deeply felt by Peter Kavanagh, an amateur printer, over the life and work of the late John Quinn, who died thirty-six years ago. The New York Public Library, which receives documents under agreement not to permit their being published or copied for a certain number of years, is undoubtedly right.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 21 -- The women's New Jersey squash racquets tournament opened at the Pretty Brook Tennis Club today with the four seeded players among the thirty-three contestants winning in the first-round.
The nation's steel companies expect to spend $1,600,000,000, nearly a record, on new equipment and construction in 1960, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 21 (UPI) -- A trim and confident Stan Musial took a $20,000 salary cut with a smile today and promised to make St. Louis Cardinal fans forget his 1959 batting average of .255.

A United States Navy policy that has tacitly recognized the Arab boycott of ships trading with Israel has not aroused serious objection by the Israeli Government, shipping industry spokesmen said yesterday.

DALLAS, Jan. 21 -- Mrs. Robert V. Spears tearfully admitted tonight that she met her husband two weeks ago in a Dallas hotel and had begged him to give himself up. She said he had admitted that another man had taken his place on the doomed airliner that crashed in the Gulf of Mexico killing all forty-two persons aboard.
President Eisenhower sent a congratulatory message to the Poetry Society of America last night for its fiftieth anniversary dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

DETROIT, Jan. 21 (UPI) -- Norm Ullman, for the first time in his National Hockey League career, scored three goals in a game as the Detroit Red Wings whipped the Boston Bruins, 5 to 2, tonight. Two of his goals came thirty-five seconds apart.
Thirty-five leading members of the state bar agreed unanimously yesterday to support new legislative efforts to reorganize the state courts.

WHEN you consider that the nineteen-year-old Audubon Artists organization has more than 400 members, and that almost as many nonmembers participate in the current eighteenth Annual Exhibition, it is clear that no review could properly encompass this mammoth show.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Rail and truck loadings rose slightly last week from the levels of the week before and showed a greater increase from the year-ago level.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- President Eisenhower and the late Secretary of State Dulles recognized as early as August, 1956, that military measures against President Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt might be necessary, according to Sir Anthony Eden.
Dore Schary has been signed to produce a special telecast dedicated to getting out the vote.

In dramatic affirmation that the United States is a two-ocean country, facing the Pacific as well as the Atlantic, President Eisenhower will fly to Japan in June for a visit to Emperor Hirohito immediately after his ten-day stay in Soviet Russia. Furthermore, if precedent and mounting pressures prevail, his trip may be extended to other Far Eastern capitals as well as to our own newest states, Hawaii and Alaska.

MONROVIA, Liberia, Jan. 21 (UP) -- President William V.S Tubman of Liberia said today that he favored an economic common market for Liberia and the new independent states in West Africa, but that all talk of political mergers should be regarded with caution.

MIAMI, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The Claiborne Farm's favored Natalie, under a strong ride by Manuel Ycaza, finished fast to win today's feature at Hialeah. The Ken-Love Farm's Meadows Miss was second and H.F. Krihendahl's' Judy Jump-Up third.
HAVANA, Jan. 21 -- Cubans rallied today to support for the Castro regime's order to the Spanish Ambassador to leave the country within twenty-four hours.
ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- New York City stands to receive about $5,500,000 of the $25,000,000 in additional state aid for education that Governor Rockefeller will ask the 1960 Legislature to allocate.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Jan. 21 -- Raulston Schoolfield, impeached by the Tennessee State Senate and removed from his Criminal Court judgeship in 1958, was ordered permanently disbarred today from practicing law in Tennessee.
Moves just initiated for a broad new American-European economic partnership should lead to further large expansion in two-way trans-Atlantic trade, two business groups were assured yesterday.

FLORENCE, Italy, Jan. 21 -- Life in the fashion business is full of surprises. Ever since the Italian spring collections began here last Monday, the audience of American fashion press, manufacturers and store buyers had been waiting to see Princess Irene Galitzine's couture collection.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 21 (UPI) -- Silver Spoon, carrying 127 pounds, raced to an easy victory at Santa Anita today in the $28,000 Santa Maria Handicap for fillies and mares.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Senator Frank J. Lausche of Ohio decided today to stay out of any primary fight for his state's sixty-four votes at the Democratic National Convention.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Tranquilizing drugs have yielded United States manufacturers extraordinary profits, a Senate committee found today.

LUSAKA, Northern Rhodesia, Jan. 21 -- The hostility of mass African opinion in Northern Rhodesia to remaining in the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland was demonstrated to Prime Minister Macmilian today.
Americans appear to be traveling by air as much as ever, despite a sudden burst of airline crashes.

Owners planning to enter their yachts in June's Newport-to-Bermuda race must have new measurement certificates this year, it was learned last night at the meeting and dinner of the Cruising Club of America in the New York Yacht Club.

UNTIL the abominations of our own unhappy age became generally known the Thirty Years' War (1618-48) was often cited as the most disgraceful and the most terrible example of man's inhumanity to man in Western history. A general war involving most of the nations of Europe, it was fought in Germany, Austria, Bohemia, the Netherlands and Denmark.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- The Government raised the bank rate today from 4 per cent to 5 per cent. The increase in the rate, the key to most interest rates, startled Britain's financial and business circles.
Air-India announced yesterday it would begin trans-Atlantic service on May 14 as the first Asian airline to serve this country's East Coast.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is incontestably true that the potentially harmful effects of fluorides are publicly recognized by many medical and dental authorities, here and abroad. Nevertheless, those dangers to adults are really secondary objections to fluoridation.
CHICAGO, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 21 -- The Fund for Adult Education reported at its national headquarters here today that it would go out of business. Since 1951 it had received Ford Foundation grants totaling $45,000,000 to use independently in developing liberal education for adults.

Norman Rothschild, a Syracuse promoter, testified yesterday he had paid $10,000 to Gabriel Genovese for help in arranging the Johnny Saxton-Carmen Basilio welter-weight title bout in 1956. However, the promoter denied that the payment to Genovese, who was subsequently convicted as an undercover manager, was detrimental to boxing.

COALBROOK, South Africa, Friday, Jan. 22 -- Rescuers worked frantically early today to reach more than 500 men trapped in a deep coal mine here. The shaft roof collapsed in at least two places following explosions.
VIENNA, Jan. 21-- Polish leaders have appealed to the nation's non-Communist scientists and engineers to help solve her serious economic problems.
Needy students at City and Hunter Colleges will benefit from the estate of a man who decided in 1877 that he could not afford to attend even a tuition-free institution.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 21 -- Authoritative sources said today that a plot to take over the Venezuelan Government was nipped by the arrest of its leaders this week.

ALGIERS, Jan. 21 -- Organizations of Right-wing Europeans, known here as "ultras" or "activists," belabored the French Government and President de Gaulle tonight in concerted moves to arouse popular opinion and influence decisions of the President.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I should be grateful if you could extend the hospitality of your columns to enable me to point out a glaring misrepresentation of facts and the fallacious conclusions drawn by Chang Hsin-hai in his letter published in your esteemed journal of Dec. 6,1959, regarding the status of the so-called McMahon Line.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The Pentagon said today that the Soviet Union hit the impact area in its Pacific missile test yesterday.

Armstrong Rubber Sales and earnings of the Armstrong Rubber Company in the quarter ended Dec. 31, 1959, look good compared with the previous year, Frederick Machlin, president, said yesterday. The company does not issue quarterly reports.
LONDON, Jan. 21 -- Prices of leading industrial shares here today responded with falls of several shillings to the rise in bank rate from 4 to 5 per cent.
The Magnavox Company has secured its first foothold on the world export market with the help of the leading chain store operator of Britain.
A tendency among teacher candidates to keep their professional preparation to the legal minimum was deplored yesterday by the municipal colleges.
OMAHA, Neb., Jan. 21 -- Senator Kennedy arrived here late today and was greeted by supporters with a thick wad of petitions containing, they said, more than enough names to enter him in the primary.
A Columbia University teacher has been chosen to direct a $200,000 study of the feasibility of staggering working hours in the city in order to relieve rush-hour transit congestion.

The auto industry aims to turn out 2,278,500 vehicles this quarter. If the goal is realized, it will top the former first-quarter record of 2,129,000 units in 1955. But perhaps even more significant: car makers are planning this huge output with 136,000 fewer hourly employes than in 1955.

Ebbets Field isn't the only major league ballpark that will disappear permanently from the landscape this year. Demolition already is well advanced on Braves Field, the Boston home of the Braves before they moved to Milwaukee.

The three television networks announced jointly yesterday that each would devote at least one hour a week of prime evening time to informational, educational or cultural programs, beginning next November.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- Eugene O'Neill's "A Moon for the Misbegotten," was played in a West End theatre for the first time last night. The play, which was done on Broadway two years ago, was put on here at the Arts Theatre, with Margaret Whiting as Josie Hogan starred.
The property at the southwest of York Avenue and Seventy-fifth Street has been purchased by a client of Adele Kirsch, broker, for improvement with a twenty-story apartment building.

MOSCOW, Jan. 21 -- The Soviet Union said today it fired a rocket 12,500 kilometers (nearly 8,000 miles) yesterday to within about a mile of the target point in the Pacific Ocean. The Government announced that the advertised experimental launching of a new "more powerful" ballistic missile had been a complete success.
NETCONG, N.J., Jan. 21 -- The Netcong Businessmen's Association has become the first group of business men in Morris County to endorse a proposed jet airport for Morris County's Great Swamp.

SONJA HENIE was the Golden Girl of figure skating. She was the artist supreme during the winning of three Olympic championships and the dynamism of her personality was instantly communicated to the spectators. The electric sparks she generated made the turnstiles whirr. Skill plus appeal brought gold to the Golden Girl.
LONDON, Jan. 21 -- Thurgood Marshall, the American attorney who is here with the African delegation from Kenya, wrote to his wife several days ago:

From chorus boy, to juvenile lead is the jump that is elevating Ron Husmann. Now in "Fiorello!," young Mr. Husmann has been chosen for the important assignment in "Tenderloin," the musical that is being written by Jerome Weidman, George Abbott, Jerry Bock and Sheldon Harnick.
IT is the dead of winter, but Pete Ross of Macy's has anticipated that weary feeling every woman gets in viewing her home at this time of year.
Scientists have isolated for the first time a nucleic acid that by itself can transform cells from normal to cancerous.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- After consultations with the Board of Trade, the British Motor Corporation announced today that it intended to establish new factories in Scotland, South Wales and Northeast England.

PORK seems to be ensconced on a seesaw at present, dropping down in price one week and swinging back up again the next. However, although this is the "up" week, pork is still among the best meat values.

It is a remarkable achievement which the Soviet Union claims to have performed in its first mid-Pacific rocket shot. The Soviet asserts that the rocket traveled almost 8,000 miles and landed within a mile and a quarter of the planned point of impact. If true, this flight surpassed anything achieved thus far by our own Atlas missile.
Governor Rockefeller urged the insurance business last night to consider the public good as well as profit to be derived from investing the billions it controls.
BOSTON, Jan. 21 -- The earth appears to have lost 5 to 10 per cent of the hydrogen originally in its water and air, but a further loss has been inhibited by the richness of oxygen in the atmosphere.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 21 (AP) -- A Trans World Airlines plane carrying thirty-four persons was brought down safely today after circling the city for more than two hours because of a faulty nose landing gear.
BOSTON, Jan. 21 -- Although Ray Robinson observed the custom of taking a day off from the rigors of training the day before a fight, Paul Pender went through a brisk exercise session today.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 21 -- Senator John F. Kennedy announced today his intention to enter the Wisconsin Presidential primary against Senator Hubert H. Humphrey. He also said he would enter the Nebraska primary.

Manufacturers of lipsticks completed yesterday a memorandum to Arthur S. Flemming, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, setting forth in detail why they felt that they should be permitted to continue using seventeen coal-tar dyes.

Col. John J. McEwan, who began a colorful football career by booting the opening kickoff of the first Army-Notre Dame game in 1913, received the annual distinguished service award of the Touchdown Club of New York last night.

PARIS, Jan. 21 -- Maj. Gen. Jacques Massu, a hero of the European population of Algeria, was believed tonight to be facing dismissal from his post as military and civil commander of the Algiers region.
A contributor to the Neediest Cases, touched by the story of a couple who fear they may have to give up their baby for adoption, yesterday offered financial aid for a year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter said today that Chinese Communist participation was "inevitable" if a disarmament agreement were to be concluded between East and West.
In a generally quiet session stocks rose yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, but volume continued to decline.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Exports appear to have held their own in the final months of 1959, except for the depressing effects of the steel and dock strikes.
A fuel oil delivery racket that cost Brooklyn consumers $5,000,000 to $15,000,000 a year in excessive heating bills was reported yesterday.
Four hundred space scientists ended a four-day conference here yesterday unperturbed by the presence of four smaller visitors -- three males and a female -- all under sixty-three inches high.
CHICAGO, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Grain futures on the Board of Trade today generally finished again in a narrowly mixed range.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Jan. 21 -- The Adelphi College swimming team won its seventh dual meet against one defeat by beating Manhattan College, 68 -- 25, in the winner's pool tonight.

Addressing state Governors in 1957, President Eisenhower dealt, as he had before, with the temptation to transfer the problems of states and cities to Washington for solution. "Every state failure to meet a pressing public need has created the opportunity, developed the excuse and fed the temptation for the National Government to poach on states' preserves," he said in that address at Williamsburg, Va.

The last of four independent unions representing 45,000 telephone workers in the metropolitan area ratified a new wage agreement yesterday. Its action assured labor peace until at least Oct. 29, when the first of the new pacts expires.
MILLBURN, N.J., Jan. 21 -- The past of the Paper Mill Playhouse here will be recalled in a series of benefit performances to raise funds for the suburban theatre's future.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 21 -- High Soviet Union officials were reported to have hinted here today at additional economic aid to help India develop heavy industries.

New York's top track and field athletes win turn out in force tonight at the 102d Engineers Armory for the Metropolitan Association Amateur Athletic Union indoor championships. Competition will begin at 7:30 P.M.
Two men were shot and killed in Manhattan and Brooklyn last night in separate slayings.
YESTERDAY (Jan. 21, 1960) THE PRESIDENT Met with President's Committee for Traffic Safety.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter said today that he was deeply worried about the Cuban situation.

EVERY morning, Monday through Friday, a smartly turned out woman makes her way through Grand Central Station to 417 Madison Avenue. To other commuters, she looks like a lady of leisure in town to shop, with lunch at the Colony.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 21 -- The sun shone warmly on Budapest's Lajos Kossuth Street, melting the snow from the eaves of buildings and forcing pedestrians into the street to avoid the drip.

For the second time this week, the New York office of the Securities and Exchange Commission went to United States District Court here seeking an injunction against a securities concern. Judge Archie O. Dawson signed a temporary restraining order barring E.J. Quinn Co., Inc., from continuing business because of alleged violations of S.E.C. bookkeeping rules.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The House Ways and Means Committee today completed work on a bill to stimulate American business investment in overseas operations. It will take a formal vote on the bill early next month.
New York University proposed yesterday that it take over the unfinished portion of Washington Square Village for university housing.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: For over sixty years the Public Education Association has been urging citizens to take a more active interest in their schools. We agree with Dr. Henry T. Heald when he says that "New York City lacks a first-class school system because its citizens do not want it badly enough."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Following is the list of 175 members of the House of Representatives who signed a petition to get the civil rights bill out of the Rules Committee:
Last year was a big one for beer. This year promises to be even bigger.

DECATUR, Ala., Jan. 21 -- This crow shooting ranks somewhere between pheasant shooting and the most difficult shooting of all, whatever that may be, but much nearer the latter. It is what a certain New Brunswick guide would call "desperate tricky."

Holding on to History An old hand at exploring the streets of a big city and using footwork for the purpose has found himself doing the same thing in a small city which takes more pride in its past than in its thriving present and pays particular attention to preserving reminders of that past.

Three writers have won Eugene F. Saxton Memorial Trust maintenance fellowships in recent months. They are Ken Kesey of Menlo Park, Calif.; Marion H. Montgomery Jr. of Athens, Ga., and Alfred Delano Livingston of Headland, Ala.

Average member bank borrowings increased $3,000,000 to $914,000,000 in the week ended last Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Reserves in excess of requirements dropped an average $30,000,000 to $538,000,000.
Mayor Wagner yesterday named Nathan At. Ohrbach chairman of the Mayor's twenty-three-member Businessmen's Committee for Off-Street Parking in mid-Manhattan.

World sugar futures fell sharply on heavy volume yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The near positions were weakest. Final quotations dropped 2 to 7 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 65,000 tons, the largest volume since Jan. 2, 1959.

The television adaptation of "Moon and Sixpence" received four of the Sylvania Television Awards for 1959. The awards were presented last night in ceremonies at the Plaza Hotel. The story by Somerset Maugham about the painter Paul Gauguin was adjudged the outstanding telecast of the year as well as the best drama.
MILAN, Italy, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Renata Tebaldi has postponed indefinitely her American tour because she is overworked and needs a rest, a member of the soprano's household said today.
CHICAGO, Jan. 21 -- Despite signs that home building has been surprisingly strong in the last few months, the residential construction industry is pessimistic on the prospects for the coming year.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 21 (UPI) -- Gene Littler and Dick Knight, a pair of seasoned professionals from San Diego, tied for the first-day lead in the $50,000 Bing Crosby tournament today with five-under-par 67's.
HONG KONG, Jan. 21 -- Communist China said today it would not be bound by any decisions on disarmament in which it did not have a voice.
ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- The first salvos in the 1960 battle over the state's "full-crew" law were fired tonight by the top state official in the merged labor movement.
American insurance companies may be confronted with claims exceeding $10,000,000 as a result of air crashes during the last ten weeks, experts here estimated yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- He's a fighter, a fierce competitor. And he always fights to win.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- President Eisenhower urged his Committee for Traffic Safety today to redouble its efforts to reduce highway fatalities.

Among the thirty-seven persons who died in the Avianca Airlines crash in Jamaica early yesterday were the son and daughter-in-law of Senator Homer E. Capehart, Republican of Indiana; the president of a meat-packing concern, and seven residents of the New York metropolitan area bound for vacations in Jamaica.

The importance of the nation's mass communication mediums in conveying the meaning of American democratic life to under-developed countries was cited last night by Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association.

Atlantic Coast Line Co. (Conn.) A dividend of 60 cents a share has been declared by the Atlantic Coast Line Company (Conn.), a railroad holding company. It is payable on March 11 to holders of record of Feb. 4.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Senator Stuart Symington said today that Administration officials were indifferent to the high profits paid commercial warehousemen for storing surplus grains.

MONTE CARLO, Jan. 21 (AP) -- A stream of mud-splattered cars, including one driven by a pair of Americans who weren't expected to finish, rolled into Monte Carlo tonight after sixty-nine hours of steady driving through ice, snow and rain.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The Administration's downward assessment of the Soviet military threat brought a charge of complacency and an expression of concern over official motives from members of Congress today.
The Board of Education selected sites yesterday for eight school and awarded contracts for the construction of four other school projects.

Top ski conditions were reported yesterday as snow continued to fall at many of the northeast's areas. The bright picture was the most comprehensive of the season. Even operators in New Jersey and Pennsylvania filed cheerful reports.

MOSCOW, Jan. 21 -- The entire population of Moscow is being vaccinated against smallpox following the discovery of at least nine cases of the disease here. One death has been attributed to the outbreak.

"A DREAM OF TREASON," last night's offering on Channel 2's "Playhouse 90," had one major flaw in its plot structure. It was, nevertheless, a work that contained some provocative ideas about behind-the-scenes activities in Washington diplomatic circles.
The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation and Delta Metal Company, Ltd., yesterday said they had organized a new aluminum fabricating company in Britain.
MONTREAL, Jan. 21 (UPI) -- Phil Goyette's three-goal spree and four goals by the Richard brothers helped the Montreal Canadiens rout the last-place New York Rangers, 11 -- 2, tonight.

Undercurrents of uneasiness became more noticeable in the bond market yesterday, slowing the bullish tone that has prevailed in the secondary market for prime corporate and local government bonds and reducing to a minimum exchanges of United States Government securities of more than short term.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to 15 points off yesterday. July showed the most weakness.
Consumption and production of newsprint in the United States rose to records in 1959, according to trade association reports issued yesterday.
MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, Jan. 21 -- Thirty-seven persons were killed early today when a Colombian airliner turned on its back, exploded and caught fire in landing at this Caribbean resort.
The first official hint of hope for a railroad wage agreement came last night from the chief Government peacemaker assigned to the negotiations.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Department store sales in the nation last week were 3 per cent above the year-ago level.

CATHOLIC COLLEGES -- Enrollment in Catholic colleges has gone beyond 300,000 for the first time in history. Statistics reported in the current issue of "America" show a total of 303,665 full and part time students at the end of the fall semester.

SLEEPERCOACH service on the Twentieth Century Limited between here and Chicago appears to be highly successful. The New York Central reports that, in the first two months, the cars have operated at more than 90 per cent of capacity.

The demand for college-trained engineers is rising and the number of students enrolling for engineering courses is dropping, according to a report last week by the Engineering Manpower Commission of Engineers Joint Council.

NEW ORLEANS -- First-time visitors to this city's fabulous Mardi Gras celebration usually wake up the morning after its roaring climax convinced that half of what they saw just couldn't have happened anywhere.

THE fundamental value of American-Soviet cultural exchanges is so great that it is beyond dispute. With their H-bombs, missiles, armies, navies and air arms the two dominant powers have won fear and respect from each other.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I was deeply pleased that, asked in his press conference whether he would approve of first use by the United States of gas or germ warfare, President Eisenhower replied that his own instinct would be against their use unless they had been used against us.

THE suburban beavers that some time back built a dam on Titicus Brook near Ridgefield, Conn., should have known better. People don't want dams in such places, or if they do they hire other people to build them.

STOWE, Vt. -- The ski business continues to boom in Stowe. Although the year-around population of this upland community is not more than 1,800, as many as 6,000 devotees of the slope and trail have been staging regular invasions on winter week-ends to take advantage of excellent ski conditions at near-by Mount Mansfield and Spruce Peak.
FOR more than 1,200 performances of the Broadway hit, "My Fair Lady," Franz Allers has directed the orchestra in the pit of the Hellinger Theatre, where the musical is playing.

Writing and Speech PEOPLE sometimes talk vaguely about the conversational style in writing. Still more often they deplore the divorce between the language as spoken and written. It is true that the spoken and written language can drift too far apart -- with the eventual consequence of forming a new written language.

ACOMMUNITY music school is a very stimulating place. Here may be a tousled 10-year-old rushing to a 'cello lesson, or a gangling teen-ager hurrying for trombone instruction, or a gentle, soft-spoken grandmother arriving for her piano lesson to which she looks forward with great anticipation.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 23 (UPI) -- Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation worked in secret today in attempts to link Robert Vernon Spears to the crash of an airliner in which forty-two persons died.

WASHINGTON. A SPECTER is haunting the politicians -- the specter of two or four more years of divided government in Washington, with neither political party able to win commanding control. The very real possibility that the 1960 elections may return a Republican to the White House and a Democratic majority to Congress is causing bewilderment over the state of the American party system.
Mayor Wagner yesterday summoned the heads of fourteen city departments to City Hall next Wednesday to work out a unified system for combating corruption.

THE sole serious fault in the novels of Harold Q. Masur is their infrequency: we've been vouchsafed only eight book-length cases for Scott Jordan since the lawyer-detective made his debut in 1947. The latest, and by several lengths the best in a good field, is SEND ANOTHER HEARSE (Random, $2.95).
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 23 -- The Dodgers, baseball's foremost success story in 1959, have flipped open the book on 1960. The title could be "Great Expectations."

MONTREAL -- There was a time, not many years ago, when, two or three weeks after the Yuletide and New Year's festivities ended, all that the winter resort areas of Quebec had to look forward to was a long period of the doldrums.

TOGETHERNESS, we are told by the family magazines, is the trend of the times. Grand Central City-the world's largest office building, planned for one of New York's busiest commercial sites-will put togetherness on a monumental architectural scale.

IN WARSAW, in 1957, Polish intellectuals were circulating a caustic comment on Soviet art: "An expressionist," they said, "paints what he feels; an impressionist paints what he sees; a socialist realist paints what he hears; and if he is deaf he paints what he reads."

I HAVE on my files hundreds of treasured letters from drama lovers from all parts of the United States asking for interpretations of various incidents and passages in "Shadow and Substance," but bless their hearts, I never try to be a doctrinaire with them -- I prefer them to take from the play their own interpretations arrived at through their own emotions and feelings.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 21 -- When Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts this week followed Senator Hubert H. Humphrey into the Wisconsin Presidential primary he set the stage for a make-or-break struggle.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 23 -- An international meeting now taking place in Budapest provides a vivid illustration of the deep changes that have occurred in Eastern Europe since 1948.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 15 -- Communist East Germany is operating a $30,000,000-a-year subversion and espionage program in West Germany, according to Western intelligence reports made available here.

A million workers in 1,800 plants -- and that's one of every sixteen or seventeen of all factory workers -- can thank one man that those plants are convenient to their homes and equipped to produce at a profit.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 23 -- Dr. Richard Ernest van de Ross has European and African ancestors. In South Africa he and other persons of similar ancestry are known as "coloreds."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The missile race between the Soviet Union and the United States seemed this week to have the strident ring of a boastful argument between two gun-toting children over who could draw a better bead on a target.
Amidst all the woes that beset the business today, advertising people are prone to forget that the United States is a paradise for their profession.

THE British recapture of Fort Ticonderoga, the subject of this book, may be new to many readers -- despite the rash of books set against Revolutionary War times. The uneasy spirit of 1776 is shown reaching the Vermont frontier, uprooting Stephen Tuttle's peaceful family life.

STROUDSBURG, Pa. -- Since real snow lately has been so scornful of the Pocono Mountains, resort proprietors have been turning increasingly to the artificial kind for their ski slopes. Even without real snow, however, the area gets a good deal of cold, bright weather, which means that ice skating is frequently available, not to mention ice fishing and, indeed, on Lake Naomi, the new-fangled excitement of sport car racing on the ice.

PHOENIX, Ariz. -- Northern Arizona, usually bypassed by winter tourists in favor of warmer desert climes to the south, currently has, in its immediate neighborhood, a special seasonal appeal to an increasing number of discerning travelers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UPI) -- The derailed Federal program of grants for city planning is due to get back on the tracks. Applications are again being accepted for grants under liberalized provisions of the 1959 Housing Act.
City officials are weighing the new warning of the Department of Air Pollution Control that "air pollution is a growing menace" to the city.
Public education officials of New York and the five other largest cities in the state will meet in Albany tomorrow to map joint plans for easing the financial problems of their school districts.

The human heart is one of the most amazing creations of nature, infinitely more efficient than any man-made machine. It beats at a steady tempo more than 100,000 times a day, 36 million times a year, more than 2.5 billion times in the course of a lifetime of three score and ten.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23 -- One of the special outstanding musical and social events of the season -- the 103d anniversary party of the Academy of Music -- tonight featured a program in which three soloists appeared with the Philadelphia Orchestra.

Initial arrangements have been made for the Golden Jubilee Gala that will be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Astor on March 18. Mrs. Anthony Del Balso, general chairman, has announced plans for the event, a benefit for the Greater New York Councils, Boy Scouts of America, which includes scouts in the five boroughs.

GROWING African violets from leaf cuttings is an economical and easy way to fill the window sill with flourishing plants. Although division is the simplest and "quickest way to propagate African violets, often a choice plant is single-crowned.

Trading volume in all commodity futures on the sixteen exchanges in this country dipped 1 1/2 per cent last year from the 1958 level, according to John Pepion, executive vice president of the Association of Commodity Exchange Firms, Inc.
Only slightly fewer persons than usual were traveling by air last week. However, the general mood of passengers was perceptibly more subdued than before the recent series of air crashes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- On the track where he first crashed the spotlight four years ago, Dave Sime gave one fleeting glimpse of his blazing speed tonight. Then he discreetly retired for the evening -- and the rest of the indoor season.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Jan. 22 -- The question of Sudan's seeking possible Soviet aid was pondered anew here this week after Cairo announced that the Soviet Union had agreed to build the second stage of the high Aswan dam after completing the first stage.
WHAT a passenger-carrying freighter may lack in glamour, elaborate social life and frenzied sight-seeing and shopping in foreign ports is more than amply compensated for by complete relaxation.

A NEW era is about to open for the San Francisco Ballet; or at any rate they are staking everything on its being a new era. On Lincoln's Birthday (with fitting connotations of emancipation), the company will open a series of nine pairs of week-end performances at the Alcazar Theatre, with the hearty cooperation of that theatre's management.

The Soviet Union is genuinely prepared to disarm drastically and to accept strict controls if the Western nations will do likewise, Philip J. Noel-Baker, winner of the 1959 Nobel Peace Prize, said here yesterday.
CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- The chances for Government pumppriming in the market for home mortgages appeared this week to be growing slimmer.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 23 -- On the same day this week, a Government spokesman and Prof. Carlo Schmid, in his role as Vice President of the Bundestag, spoke out on the subject of anti-Semitism, the spokesman to a news conference and Professor Schmid to the lower house of Parliament.

HONOLULU -- Time was when the toughest words a vacationist in Hawaii had to master were "Waikiki" and "Duke Kahanamoku," both of them names of bathing beaches here on the island of Oahu, and "Nuuanu Pali," which is Oahu's great cliff with its scenic look-out.
A 7-point spurt in the last five minutes helped Iona College defeat Fordham, 57-52, before 3,800 at the Rams' gymnasium last night. It was the first basketball game between these teams since 1955.

BOSTON, Jan. 23 -- Paul Pender rested at his home in adjacent Brookline today with his wife and his two daughters. The 29-year-old ex-fireman, who last night gained a piece of the world middleweight championship by outpointing Sugar Ray Robinson, just didn't want to leave the house.

One hundred and thirty dwellings are planned by Joseph Pizzo, builder, in a development called Custom Grafted Homes at Stewart Avenue and Meade Street, in Bethpage, L.I. The houses are priced at $14,990.

Once upon a time, colleges -- even the best among them -- had to compete desperately for students. Each college had to equal, if not top, the offerings of its competitors. If the competition was located nearby, the pressure to amass the same volumes in the library, the same number of Ph.D.'s in each department and the same courses in each field of study was even greater.

LONDON, Jan. 23 -- Dr. Nahum Goldmann, president of the World Jewish Congress, declared tonight that "germs of the Nazi infection exist nearly everywhere and the effort to eradicate them has to be universal."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The prospect of the biggest surplus in more than a decade promises to give the 1960 battle of the budget a unique twist for a Presidential election year.

HOLLYWOOD. THE highest-paid lackeys in the world, Hollywood screen writers, are on the way to emancipation. Frequently, these days, they walk on a set while their scripts are being filmed and even dare to offer a suggestion. Often they speak up strongly for their work at a story conference.

FORMAL instruction in photography on the creative level is now being offered in more than thirty American colleges and universities. The main goal of these courses is the development of individual capacity for personal expression.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 23 -- Ken Venturi fashioned a four-under-par 68 over the Cypress Point course today for the third-round lead at 209 in Bing Crosby's $50,000 golf tournament Venturi used a new putter of his own design.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 23 -- The New York Knickerbockers defeated the Minneapolis Lakers tonight, 115-104, in a National Basketball Association contest before a crowd of 4,373. It was the Lakers' fifth loss in a row.
A fledgling for thirty years, the chemical tanker is emerging as the one segment of the tanker fleet that sounds a note of optimism.

BEFORE Evelyn Waugh fixed the public image of that essentially "private person," Ronald Arbuthnott Knox, in this splendid first biography of the celebrated monsignor, one still was at liberty to view Knox as a cross between a Gilbertian curate and a kind of P.G. Wodehouse clergyman whose idea of a pastoral cure was a perpetual long week-end punctuated, at canonical intervals, by the highest of high teas.
Construction of new supermarkets leveled off last year while merger activity dipped sharply.
The City Housing Authority is seeking to change the state Public Housing Law to permit the conversion of eight of its forthcoming middle-income rental developments to cooperatives.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The Villanova five scored 21 points in six minutes of the second period tonight and went on to trounce Penn, 71 -- 58 in the second game of a Palestra double-header. Len Wilkins' clutch scoring helped Providence upset St. Joseph's in the opener, 64 -- 63.
GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 23 -- A town-wide mosquito-control program aimed at preventing a possible outbreak of eastern quine encephalities will begin here in March.

TO THE EDITOR: Harold Schonberg's article on Birgit Nilsson, the great Wagnerian soprano ("Ho-yo-to-ho! A New Bruennhilde," Jan. 10), tells us that Miss Nilsson will be singing the Princess in the Met's production of "Turandot" next year, an event eagerly anticipated by opera lovers because "America has not heard a great Turandot since the days of Jeritza and Raisa some thirty years ago."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Speaker Sam Rayburn said today that Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. would "in all probability" get the chairmanship of the House Education and Labor Committee.
LONDON, Jan. 23 -- Much has been written about the glamor and romance of the diamond trade, but basically it is a hard-headed, efficient and tightly-knit world business operation.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: President de Gaulle's decision to replace Antoine Pinay, one of the most influential political survivors of the Fourth Republic, with Wilfred Baumgartner, a distinguished civil servant, raises some vital questions about the direction in which the new French regime is moving.
CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- Chicago's police scandal brought the resignation today of Police Commissioner Timothy J. O'Connor.

THERE is nothing negative about Marcia Davenport. She loves love; she loves Italians, and she loves Milan. She has chosen -- rather boldly in a day when literary love is a clinical progression from pad to pad -- to confine her whole attention to one passionate affair between a young American divorcee and a Milanese business man.

BOSTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The Boston Celtics put on an early scoring rush tonight and went on to a 130-121 National Basketball Association victory over Syracuse. Tommy Heinsohn led Boston to its fifth straight success with 32 points.
Ambassador Bonsai said yesterday on arrival in New York from Cuba that he was in the United States to consult on '"the highly regrettable deterioration" in Cuban relations with Washington.

MALARIA ERADICATION -- The World Health Organization reported in Geneva, last week that eleven countries or territories have eradicated, malaria and that many other "have almost achieved that goal or are well on the way toward it."

Representative Charles A. Halleck, Republican of Indiana, predicted here yesterday that a "good" civil rights bill would pass this session of Congress. Mr. Halleck is minority leader in the House of Representatives.
ROME, Jan. 23 -- The Vatican picture gallery, the Pinacoteca, renowned for its Italian renaissance paintings, is about to open two new rooms dedicated to art of the last two centuries.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Vice President Nixon contends that the steel settlement on Jan. 4 warded off "even higher" union demands.

EAST PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 23 -- The Police have tentatively ruled out the possibility of foul play in the death of a 12 - year - old newsboy found hanging from a tree in a patch of his woods near his home.

HOLLYWOOD. THE spotlight in Hollywood last week was not on any movie studio, but on a large room over a mammoth drug store. For there, in the board room of the Association of Motion Picture Producers, meetings occurred that could be of vast importance to the film industry.

NEW YORKERS unable to go far afield for a midwinter break, yet tired of being trapped in taxi tie-ups on murky city streets, will find plenty of vacation variety within a radius of 150 miles of the metropolitan area.

On a tree-shaded Knoll on Staten Island, not far from the shore of the Kill van Kull, 314 retired sea "captains" are spending their last days in comfort because pf a Revolutionary War privateer.

CAT CAY, Bahamas, Jan. 23 -- Sailing in stiff and cold north-east winds that cost her a spinnaker and kept wet crewmen shivering in foul-weather gear, Jack Price's forty-foot Comanche won the annual Miami to Cat Cay race today.

ST. GEORGE'S, Grenada -- Scarcely a day's sail away from Trinidad, the capital and commercial center of the British West Indies, are two of the loveliest of the Windward Islands, Tobago and Grenada, which seem all the more restful and relaxing in contrast with the capital's hustle and bustle.

The Mary Washington Colonial Chapter of the National Society of the Daughters of the American Revolution will hold its annual benefit bridge party in the Ballroom of the Colony Club on the afternoon of Feb. 15.
ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 23 -- Dartmouth's hockey team routed Cornell tonight, 12 -- 0, for its third straight Ivy League victory. The loss was the tenth in a row for the Big Red.

Frank, associate justice of the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court, is his recollection of the sixteen years he spent as an assistant district attorney in Bronx County.
