PUERTO VALLARTA, Jalisco, Mexico -- Exactly three years ago a writer in these pages reported that he had visited Puerto Vallarta on Mexico's beautiful west coast, on the warning of friend that 1957 would be "the last good year."
FORT MYERS, Fla. -- From Feb. 6 through 13 this sedate resort town will again honor the memory of its most. Illustrious winter resident, Thomas Alva Edison. The celebration is an annual event.

CHARLESTON, S.C. -- A vintage azalea season is is in prospect this spring in celebrated and historic gardens open to the public near Charleston. It is reported from the three most important ones, Middleton Place, Magnolia and Cypress (which collectively have adopted the title Charleston's Famous Gardens) that thus far their plants have been spared severe winter cold and are in excellent condition.

MOSCOW, Jan. 23 -- The Soviet Union issued its final economic report on 1959 this week, spelling out the previously reported 11 per cent Increase in total production and pointing up a number of failings as well.
MONTE CARLO, Jan. 23 (UPI) -- Seventy-nine cars today finished the difficult mountain driving test, final event of the Monte Carlo auto rally.
ATLANTA, Jan. 23 -- Tuskegee Institute declares that, aside from action by the courts and Federal agencies, the nation did little to improve the lot of the Negro in 1959.

UTICA, N.Y., Jan. 23 (AP) -- Two Canadian rinks today won the right to play for the championship of the forty-ninth annual Utica men's curling bonspiel.

THE present darkness at the Hayden Planetarium is not to be taken as ominous, for the Planetarium, which has been closed since early this month, will reopen on Saturday, equipped with a new and strikingly modern Zeiss Planetarium Projector.

To the Screen Editor: Mr. Crowther hag enthusiastically praised "On the Beach." It is a motion picture whose theme is so large, indeed on the scale of the Book of Revelations, that it could either succeed eminently or fail ingloriously.

NO one has been arrested so far in this new and chilly year for disturbing the peace by making noises about the extraordinary quality of the year's new films. Apparently big-city people are more restrained in their enthusiasm than they used to be.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 23 (AP) -- The State Democratic Executive Committee refused today to adopt a national party loyalty oath that would bind Alabama's Presidential electors to support the regular party ticket in this year's election.
NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 23 -- The location of a jet airport in New Jersey should be given the fullest study before irrevocable decisions are made, Senator Clifford P. Case believes.

The Government of Liberia has set forth "three powerful arguments" before the International Court of Justice in The Hague in support of its claim for membership in the United Nations maritime agency, admiralty lawyers reported last week.

IAKE PLACID, N.Y. -- There is one thing that skiers and other winter sportsmen invading this area cannot complain about this year, and that is the weather. Snow came early to the Adirondacks and, as a result, everyone is happy.

The threat of an Income tax action that could have crippled the International Longshore-men's Association was removed by the Internal Revenue Service yesterday. The Federal agency restored the union's status as a tax-exempt organization.

A SERIES of annual awards for the colleges and universities producing the best yearbooks, in the opinion of a jury headed by Edward Steichen, is announced by Popular Photography in its February issue.

FOR THIS WEEK: Use accurate measurements when feeding house plants. Avoid wetting the leaves. . . . Check climbing roses for loosened canes and retie any stragglers. . . . Keep pots of hardy bulbs for forcing in cool rooms to avoid bud blasting. . . . Humidity is important for house plants especially in winter months when homes are heated.

PORT TOBACCO, Md. -- It is about thirty-five miles from Washington, D.C., down to this forgotten community on an arm of the Potomac River, and for winter vacationists driving south on U.S. 301 it is less than five miles off the main road.
ALBANY, Jan. 23 -- Action to end thirty years of licensing discrimination against the family station wagon was started today by Governor Rockefeller and top Republican legislators.

Jamaica High's basketball team beat Flushing, 56 -- 55, yesterday in a Public Schools Athletic League Division III contest. It was presented as the high school game of the week on Channel 7 from Archbishop Molloy High School, Briarwood, Queens.

A COLLECTION of plants in the home is appropriate and pleasing only if the flower and foliage colors blend "with their surroundings. Unlike flowers in the garden, where sky and lawn are the background for a riot of color, house plants should be chosen carefully to complement each other as well as the color scheme of the room.

Harrington Manor, a colony for forty families on Lynn Street and Harriot Avenue in Harrington Park, N.J., is offering homes at prices ranging from $27,900 to $32,900.

NO New Yorker can long remain unaware of the odd things going on under the side-walks of New York. Steam billows from manholes; snow melts almost before it lands, and during heavy rains certain hot spots of pavement remain dry as dust.

THIS first volume of Herbert Hoover's "An American Epic," is the record of the beginning of intercontinental economic aid. It tells the dramatic story of the author's development of a mission for the relief of Belgium and Northern France, 1914-1930, called the American Commission for Relief in Belgium.

IN Hanson Baldwin's review of the "Triumph in the West" based on Lord Alanbrooke's diary, he maintains that the British were right in wanting to invade Austria from Italy. MIAMI BEACH -- The heat is on, both literally and figuratively, in this Gold Coast resort. This is the time of year when Miami Beach reaches a feverish pitch in anticipation of a heavy influx of winter visitors, with February and March the peak months.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The searching spotlight of publicity arid criticism undoubtedly will continue to focus on the Federal regulatory agencies in the coming months -- just as it has in the last two years. The very future of these extremely important arms of the Government may be at stake.
Yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall, William Steinberg confirmed the fine impression he had made earlier in the week.
The Rev. Dr. Reinhold Niebuhr assailed yesterday the Christian pacifist idea that unilateral disarmament by the West would solve the nuclear dilemma.

THERE may be as many as fourteen American pianists competing next month in Warsaw for the sixth international Chopin prize. Five entrants have been selected "unconditionally" and another nine have been accepted "conditionally."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Steel workers at four companies that did not accept the settlement agreed to by major producers have voted by a 2-1 margin to reject managements' latest offers.
HONG KONG, Jan. 20 -- A large-scale movement of Chinese Settlers has begun into areas of Sunnan Province bordering North Vietnam, Laos and Burma.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UPI) -- The State Department reported today that it had intensified efforts -- using foreign aid as a wedge if necessary -- to halt racial or religious discrimination against Americans by foreign governments.

PARIS, Jan. 23 -- President de Gaulle this week made some of the most spectacular moves he has taken to establish his authority in Algeria.

THE old Vulture gold mine at Wickenburg, Ariz., petered out around the turn of the century, and the town's Hassayampa River dried up long ago, but neither of these factors discourage hopeful prospectors from panning away once each year to see what they can find.

This is Faust, with Nicolai Gedda in the title role, Victoria de los Angeles a Marguerite and Boris Christoff as Mephistopheles, in a Parisian recording conducted by Andre Cluytens.

A Memphis builder says that a new "unified wall" concept, which has cut construction costs and fuel bills in a two-story home, will lend momentum to the trend toward the use of masonry for both interiors and exteriors.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Next to the public as a whole, newspapers are perhaps the chief beneficiary of the First Amendment and should be most zealous in its defense. The clear intent of the amendment is compromised by the rule ,of compulsory utterance recently proposed by the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission and accepted by at least one network.

ORLANDO, Fla., Jan. 23 (AP) -- Florida's Democratic Executive Committee endorsed Senator George A. Smathers today as a favorite-son candidate for President.

ON her sixteenth birthday a girl named Jean, carrying her suitcase, walked on high heels down the long community room of a Carmelite convent between two rows of nuns who sat silently watching her, their faces half-hidden under black veils.

CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Jan. 23 -- Italy's Eugenio Monti and Renzo Alvera, trading risks for split seconds, built a commanding lead in their bid for a fourth title today with fast times in the first two runs of the world two-man bobsled championship.

IN reply to the letter from Kenneth Colegrove dealing with your review of "The Truman - MacArthur Controversy and the Korean War," by John W. Spanler, I feel that a rebuttal is in order. The "failure to free Korea from the Communist invaders" is a patently false phrase, since the line of demarcation (of influence) remains today approximately that agreed upon between the Allied Nations and the Soviet Union in 1945.

MANY tourists to the Far East overlook southern India and, as a result miss a variety of experiences and sights that adjacent areas, including northern India, cannot match. MARCIA DAVENPORT, a woman of charm, poise and formidable sophistication, knows a great deal about an impressive variety of topics. The daughter of the distinguished opera singer, Alma Gluck, Mrs. Davenport knows lots about music and proved It with a solid biography of Mozart.

The return to power of Charles de Gaulle on the night of June 1, 1958, came after an eighteen-day crisis that involved violence in Algeria, in Metropolitan France and in the Mediterranean island of Corsica.
ALBANY, Jan. 24 -- Governor Rockefeller flew to Washington tonight to seek the aid of President Eisenhower in balancing the 1960-61 state budget.
Respect for authority in family life evokes love and obedience, Msgr. Charles J. McManus said yesterday at the 10 A.M. solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.
Fifty stage-struck teen-agers from Harrisburg, Pa., enthusiastically applauded "Leave It to Jane" at the Sheridan Square Playhouse yesterday afternoon and later met the cast.
St. James' Protestant Episcopal Church celebrated its 150th anniversary yesterday with a commemorative service and a program of sacred music.
YONKERS, Jan. 24 -- More than 6,000 persons paid to glide on the ice at the Edward J. Murray Memorial Skating Center during its first week of operation, city officials reported today.
An economic agreement signed by the Soviet Union with a Western concern last week may have signaled a major switch in Soviet tactics on world commodity markets.
BEDFORD. Mass., Jan. 24 (AP) -- New American communications research may soon make possible intercontinental television, scientists disclosed today.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A letter by the Hungarian writer Robert Major In the issue of Jan. 12 correctly attributes the blossoming of Nazis the world over in part to their toleration in this country. However, it is not only "at international Nazi rallies here in America" that "Slovak and other Nazi leaders have been feted."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter heard a personal report today from Ambassador Philip W. Bonsal on deteriorating relations between the United States and Cuba.

ROME, Jan. 24 -- Chancellor Adenauer agreed today with Italian statesmen that general disarmament was desirable but that "the defense of the West must be maintained and assured." The statement was made in a communique on his discussion here.
Representative Emanuel Celler declared yesterday that the civil rights bill written by the House Judiciary Committee could not pass without Republican support.

Governor Rockefeller will be sure of moral support from the Governors of other populous states today when he tries to persuade President Eisenhower that individual states should be allowed to take over the existing Federal tax on local telephone service.
TOKYO, Monday, Jan. 25 -- Japan will wait for Communist China to make the first move toward improving relations between the Asian neighbors, Premier Nobusuke Kishi declared today.
PARIS, Jan. 24 -- The career of Gen. Maurice Challe, who clamped a state of siege on Algiers tonight, shows he has never run away from a fight.

Today and tomorrow meetings will be held at which, final plans will be drawn up for the Viennese Opera Ball. It will be held on Feb. 5 in the Waldorf Astoria. Proceeds will go to the Margit Bokor Memorial Fund that is used for cancer research at Columbia University.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Steel Company, the only major unsigned producer, agreed today to an indefinite extension of its contract with the United Steelworkers of America.
The Democratic Presidential Candidate will suffer in the State unless insurgents join with the party organization, Michael H. Prendergast, Democratic state chairman, asserted yesterday.

ALGIERS, Monday, Jan. 25 -- Armed European demonstrators opposed to President de Gaulle's Algerian policies clashed last night with French gendarmes, leaving nineteen persons dead and 141 injured. Some of the 5,000 Europeans who were in the streets held out against security forces early today.
A. Philip Randolph, president of the Brothehood of Sleeping Car Porters, called last night for Negro marches on the 1960 political conventions to demand equal civil rights.
AN interesting program of new and old music was presented by the Fireside Players at Town Hall yesterday afternoon. The concert was the third event of Town Hall's second annual Festival of Music.

Methodists in the New York area are voicing strong opposition to a nation-wide study commission's report issued early this month that recommended the continuance of the church's racially segregated jurisdictions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Senator Kenneth B. Keating, Republican of New York, is driving dull care away the days for the ninety-six Senators of both parties who are not active or "available" candidates for President or Vice President.

A TIMELY journalistic study of the economics and emotional base of Fidel Castro's revolution in Cuba; a successful experimental drama on the life of a trapped teen-ager and an absorbing psychoanalytical study of a homosexual anti-Semite -- these were among the weekend offerings on commercial television networks.
A charge that gambling law were being inadequately enforced in this city was mad last night by Joseph F. Carlino, Republican of Nassau County, Speaker, of the Assembly.
Grants totaling $6,951,900 for international development and training were announced by the Ford Foundation yesterday.

Late yesterday afternoon the telephone rang in the Brown home at 214 Bridge Street, Pittsburgh. Mrs. Bernadette Brown answered, yes, she said, this was the home of George Brown, the Duquesne basketball player.

" Swan Lake," Russian-made feature-length version in color of the ballet with music by Tchaikovsky, is among three new films slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The film will open today at the Normandie Theatre, Fifty-seventh Street east of Seventh Avenue.
PORTLAND, Me., Jan. 24 -- A British MG Magnetic and a three-car team of French Citroens took top honors today in the Cumberland Motor Club's second annual twenty-four-hour sports car rally.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Jan. 24 (UPI) -- The United States women's Olympic ski team added to its impressive string of victories today. Blonde, 21-year-old Beverly Anderson of Mullan, Idaho, won the White Ribbon of St. Moritz.
HUNTINGTON, L.I., Jan. 24 -- Huntington residents who are experts in business and industry will make a survey aimed at modernizing the town's government.
STOWE, Vt., Jan. 24 -- Marvin Moriarty, who made the 1956 United States Olympic ski team as a teen-ager, but failed to make the present squad, performed with the skill of a champion today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- National income in 1959 reached an annual rate of $400,000,000,000 for the first time in the nation's history.
Changes in the State Education Law to free the city's Board of Education from a morass of administrative detail were requested yesterday by Charles H. Silver, board president.
DETROIT, Jan. 24 (UPI) -- Gordie Howe fired a goal with three minutes gone in the final period tonight, enabling the Detroit Red Wings to gain a 2-2 tie with the New York Rangers.
Walter L. Morgan has every reason to gloat today.
Henri Salaun of Boston, one of the country's best squash racquets players, won the Harry Cowles invitation tournament again yesterday at the Harvard Club.

PARIS, Jan. 24 -- Officially the fashion collections here open tomorrow, but already Paris Is abuzz with visiting fashion experts. Though Helena Rubinstein was too ill to attend her own party today, throngs of visiting guests went to her penthouse on the Quai de Bethune for a buffet luncheon.

VALENTINA KOJELIS, soprano, sang a debut recital at Town Hall late yesterday afternoon. A native of Lithuania, she studied at the State Conservatory there and with private teachers in Munich, Germany, and Chicago.

WOMEN who prefer traditional furnishings for their homes will find that the easiest way to create suitable backgrounds is to select from the host of fabrics called "documents." These are copied from museum collections.

It seems odd. All of the world's great chefs have been men, but the one individual who has probably done more than any other to give fine cuisine a foothold in the United States is a woman. She is Mrs. Frances Roth, a kind and intelligent gem of a person, with a seemingly inexhaustible capacity for getting her own way.

Dr. John J. Slawson, executive vice president of the American Jewish Committee, appealed yesterday for greater emphasis on four major areas of inquiry and action to combat prejudice and to promote intergroup relations.

THE philosophic Mr. Dooley, as reported by Finley Peter Dunne, tartly remarked one time that no matter whether the Constitution follows the flag, the Supreme Court follows the election returns. It was delivered with a brogue, of course, but that was only for flavor. No sectionalism ever could contain the wide range of Mr. Dooley's solid thinking.
BOSTON, Jan. 24 (UPI) -- A four-goal outburst in the final period carried Boston to a 6-2 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs and ended a five-game streak without a victory for the Bruins tonight.
The northeast corner of Seventh Avenue and Fourteenth Street has been sold by the Realty Control Corporation, Jack Fine, president, to a client of Saul Pierce, lawyer. Adele Kirsch was the broker.
Warren Mirabile, 5 years old, reached up to a table and pointed to a coffee can covered with rawhide at both ends and painted a streaky blue.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The personality of Premier Khrushchev is a big factor in the differences between the present-day Soviet Union and that of the Stalin era, a Senate report said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- As Congress nears a showdown on civil rights, supporters of the legislation are confident that their strategy is working well in the Senate. They are less hopeful about the House.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 24 (UPI) -- Ken Venturi, hacking and slashing his way through high winds and rains on the treacherous Pebble Beach pourse, won the $50,000 Bing Crosby golf tournament today with a final round of 77 for a 72-hole total of 286.

HAVANA, Jan. 24 -- A purge that observers believe will eliminate anti-Communist labor leaders in Cuba is being conducted by the Confederation of Cuban Workers, the central organization controlling labor on the island.

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- Archbishop Makarios was understood today to have offered Britain the military areas she wants in Cypress in exchange for a greater degree of Cypriote control over the civil administration within those areas.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The St. Louis Hawks, with their vaunted front line of Bob Pettit, Clyde Lovellette and Cliff Hagan racking up 103 points, set a season's high score for the National Basketball Association today when they routed the New York Knickerbockers, 155 -- 129.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, Jan. 24 -- Einar Dohlen of the Bear Mountain Sports Association registered his third straight victory in class A competition before a record crowd of 33,500 today.
The American Electric Power Company posted record revenues and earnings in 1959, according to a report issued today by Philip Sporn, president.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Jan. 24 -- The Stock Exchange here last week opened with a considerable amount of stop-loss orders. With little foreign arbitrage buying in evidence, substantial falls were noticeable both among internationals and domestic shares.
CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Eugenio Monti and Renzo Alvera of Italy won their fourth consecutive world two-man bobsled championship today.

CLIFFORD ODETS' story of a "practical" young virtuoso who chose to become a prize fighter rather than a concert violinist has been updated, with a couple of twists, by the members of a youth orchestra here.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A Times tested recipe is suggested for an easily prepared main dish.
It is rather surprising to note in London reports of the announcement of an increase in the "bank rate" from 4 per cent to 5 that this action "caught the City (the financial district) off guard."

A Presbyterian church on Manhattan's lower East Side played host yesterday to representatives of four faiths. A Jewish rabbi, a Buddhist monk, a Moslem and a member of the Baha'i movement each spoke at the morning service of the Emmanuel Presbyterian Church, 737 East Sixth Street.
TRUSTEESHIP COUNCIL Meets at 11 A.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Commission on Human Rights: Subcommision on Prevention of Discrimination and Protection of Minorities -- 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.
MONTE CARLO, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Walter Schock and Rolf Moll led a 1, 2, 3 sweep by German teams, all driving Mercedes, in the Monte Carlo auto rally today.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 24 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru hailed the Soviet Union today as sincerely striving for world peace. However, he cautioned that if disarmament talks were to succeed they must be based on mutual respect and confidence rather than on fear and hostility.

PARIS, Monday, Jan. 25 -- President de Gaulle stood up to the European rioters of Algiers this morning and told them: "I will do my duty."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I also would like to comment, as Frances R. Grant does in your issue of Jan. 18, on the letter of Philip Marshall Brown published on Jan. 13. To learn about South American problems as seen through North American eyes is always instructive and often surprising.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 24 -- Long-range questions about inventory and steel prices hac little or no effect last week on demand for steel. Most steel makers reported new order volume not far behind record shipments.

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- The British section of the World Jewish Congress expressed "fundamental opposition" today to the supply of nuclear weapons to West Germany and urged that country to eradicate nazism in all its forms.
"Person to Person" will lose both its sponsors Feb. 12, an unexpected development that may cause the television program to be removed from the air soon.

Discussing the 1960 annual Economic Report of the President, this newspaper commented on the physical contrast between this document, required of the Chief Executive "within sixty days of the beginning of each regular session of Congress."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Negotiations for a new economic -- and probably political -- relationship among the Atlantic powers are being conducted through diplomatic channels.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 24 -- At the entrance to the Anglican Cathedral Church of St. George here there stands a sign that says in letters a foot high: "This cathedral is open to welcome men and women of all races to all services at all times."

Last week-end's transcontinental developments in track and field suggest that the preOlympic indoor campaign which will be waged mainly in New York on five of the next six Saturdays, is going to be marked by drastic week-to-week changes.
An inquiry into possible corruption in the delivery of fuel oil will be started today by a grand jury in the Bronx.
Money is not enough when giving aid to poor, primitive lands, six panelists on the New York Times Youth Forum agreed yesterday.
A strong protest against a proposed law to restrict the right of grand juries to hand down presentments was made yesterday by the New York Grand Jury Association.
The American premiere of Eugene O'Neill's "Hughie," the one-act play written in 1941 and published here last spring, will take place on Broadway on March 15.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Maurice Stokes, once one of pro basketball's best rebounders, looked on today as a new star, Wilt Chamberlain, hauled down a record thirty-seven rebounds and sparked the Philadelphia Warriors to an easy 104-95 victory over the Cincinnati Royals.

Jolly Toys, Inc., doll manufacturer, has leased floors at 85 Tenth Avenue and 449 West Fifteenth Street, two buildings in the Manhattan Industrial Center that are connected by an enclosed bridge. Robert Joseph Co.

Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey said last night that the states and the Federal Government should negotiate with the railroads "to render a certain amount of commuter service on a contract basis."

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Jan. 24 -- The police announced here tonight that one of the thirty-seven victims of last Thursday's plane crash at Montego Bay was an impersonator who had taken identity papers belonging to Jaime Ruiz, a Colombian citizen who was supposed to have been a passenger.
Lincoln Printing Preliminary discussions have been held between Lincoln Printing Company and Security-Columbian Banknote Company concerning the possibility of a merger, it was announced yesterday.

Leading figures of the sports world were honored last night at the ninth annual awards dinner of the Sports Lodge of B'nai B'rith at the Roosevelt Hotel. This year's dinner was a memorial to Bill Corum, sports columnist.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday posted moves of 4 points (20 cents a bale) up to 10 points (50 cents) off on a bid price on far July.

There was good news for track fans yesterday. The Bulova Photo-Timer, which takes the guesswork out 0f finish judging, will be back in service for the five Madisor Square Garden meets, starting with the Millrose Games Saturday.

The New York Central Railroad reported yesterday a net income for 1959 of $8,402,968. Although this was more than double the $4,050,995 cleared in the recession year of 1958, when the company received $13,700,000 of back mail pay, it was the second slimmest profit year since 1947, when net income was only $2,036,000.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The ninety-one day Treasury bill rate took a steep dive this week, dropping to a discount rate of 4.116 per cent from 4.436 per cent last week.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Jan. 25 (UPI) -- Wilt Chamberlain, the league's leading scorer, poured 58 points through the net and grabbed forty-two rebounds tonight to lead Philadelphia to a 127-117 victory over Detroit in a National Basketball Association game.

MONTE CARLO, Jan 25 -- It is easy to understand who won the Twenty-ninth Rallye Automobile de Monte Carlo, which ended here yesterday. Mercedes 220 sedans did. They finished one, two, three. The German factory will be bragging about this victory in ads all over the World all the rest of this year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- President Eisenhower suggested today that an informed electorate was more important than party loyalty to a proper solution of issues confronting the nation.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Twenty-three Senators offered today an amendment that would more than double the $1,000,000,000 Federal school aid bill and provide money to raise teachers' pay.
THE Frenchwoman has an elan that is enviable, but the American woman has achieved no small reputation for wearing clean-cut classic clothes in the casual manner.
The Greenwich House Music School Scholarship Fund will benefit from the opening performance of the Piccolo Teatro di Milano in "The Servant of Two Masters" at the City Center on Feb. 23.

By 1975, some 30,000 businesses now privately owned will have "gone public," according to a forecast made yesterday by Robert A. Weaver Jr., president of the Bettinger Corporation, Milford, Mass, Mr. Weaver spoke at the opening session of a five-day meeting of the American Management Association being held here to discuss the advantages of, and the alternative to, public ownership.
The tides that swirl through Africa in an upheaval comparable to that of awakened Asia are vividly demonstrated by events in two neighboring countries.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Organized labor's spokesmen condemned today President Eisenhower's Budget and Economic messages.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Several Senators, it was announced today, have requested a delay in acting on the President's nomination of Thomas S. Gates Jr. to be Secretary of Defense until they can frame some questions for the nominee. These will concern his recent news conference comment on a "new" intelligence complex for appraising the missile program of Soviet Russia.

THE Central Documentary Film Studio of Moscow, which should know better, has certainly made a mess of "Swan Lake." Actually it seems to have approached the ballet as simply the taking-off off point for a leisurely tour of the Bolshoi Theatre -- backstage, in the orchestra pit and the dressing rooms -- together with lingering visits among the portraits and manuscripts of the Tchaikovsky Museum.

The seven Project Mercury astronauts are not expecting the comforts of airline travel on their flights into orbit and back. However, engineers are taking great pains to make sure the fliers' travels will not be any rougher than need be.
A Polish-born Jewish student from New York's Yeshiva University will leave tonight to visit West Germany to investigate anti-Semitism at the expense of the Bonn Government.

ON Thursday President Eisenhower is due to arrive in La Quinta, Calif., for a brief vacation at the home of George E. Allen. While visiting there he will spend his days playing golf at the El Dorado Country Club.

Proceeds from a cocktail dansant to be held in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria on Feb. 14 will benefit the Disabled Veterans Association of the Leib Cossack Regiment and its military museum in Courbevoie, a suburb of Paris.

The flve-story apartment building at 54 East 176th Street in the Bronx has been sold by the Pearl-Ann Corporation to a client of Irving Kulick, lawyer. The Wishnow Horowitz Real Estate Company was the broker.
The Maritime Administration announced yesterday that it had cut the strings that have been attached to the sales of United States Liberty ships.
CHICAGO. Jan. 25 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by We Department of Agriculture follows:
The city administration scored a touchdown for New York football fans yesterday and now will try for a few extra points.

WHEN it comes to collecting anything and everything few people can surpass William B. Sudduth Jr. He has so many curios that he has opened as a hobby a store, called "Trash Treasure," located at 421 East Seventy-second Street and open from 1 to 7 P.M. daily.

PARIS, Jan. 25 -- Paris is off on the loose line. After the first real day of spring fashion collections here, although none of the traditional trend-setting designers have yet shown, there is strong evidence that lowered waistlines and a general loosening up of the silhouette are on the way.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to hear an appeal attacking an Arkansas law requiring public schoolteachers to list all organizations to which they have belonged in the preceding five years.

The Federation of French Alliances in the United States will benefit from a modern dress performance of Moliere's "Le Misanthrope" starring Jacques Dumesnil and Madeleine Delavaivre at the Phoenix Theatre on Feb. 15.

ASWAN, United Arab Republic, Jan. 15 -- he social changes forced by Egypt's industrial revolution are clearly evident in this Nile River town where the railroad from Cairo ends and the steamer for the Sudan embarks.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Jan. 25 -- Senator John F. Kennedy came "Kefauvering" through two of New Hampshire's industrial centers today, and he challenged other Presidential candidates to follow the same pattern.
THE restless five-foot, three-inch son of Russian immigrant parents, Samuel I. Newhouse has amassed more than $150,000,000 as a doctor of an uncommon sort.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- A major revision of the outdated law controlling election-campaign spending and reporting passed the Senate tonight. The vote was 59 to 22.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 25 -- Senator Stuart Symington carefully skirted the civil rights issue today while displaying his political wares in the Old Confederacy.
MIAMI, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Calumet Farm's Pied d'Or, at 10 to 1, scored a six-length victory today in the West Indies Purse at Hialeah before 17,628 racing fans.

"Tiger at the Gates," a French play by Jean Giraudoux, will be the first to be sponsored by the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) on station WNTA-TV's "The Play of the Week" beginning Feb. 8. It has been described as a high comedy at the philosophical level that offers an ironic view of mankind.

Business of building material dealers in the Northeast in the first half of 1960 should equal or better last year's, Elmer S. White, vice president of the Northeastern Retail Lumbermen's Association, said yesterday.
BOSTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Ted Williams quietly signed a 1960 Boston Red Sox contract today, settling the question of whether he would play, but not how much he would play.
PARIS, Jan. 25 -- France remained outwardly calm today amid numerous signs that the population was behind President de Gaulle's efforts to uphold the power of the state.

Reflecting an increase in sales, earnings of the Monsanto Chemical Company rose last year to a record of $48,977,000 from $34,550,000 in 1958, according to the preliminary annual statement issued yesterday.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 25 -- The Pennsylvania Democratic State Committee picked forty uncommitted national convention delegates today in a move to enhance Gov. David L. Lawrence's potential as a "kingmaker."

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 25 (AP) -- The Reynolds Metal Company and the Aluminum Workers International Union reached agreement today on an hourly wage increase, fringe benefits and noneconomic provisions for new three-year labor contracts expiring in 1962, a Reynolds spokesman said.

The nation's brass manufacturers, who occupied such a vital niche throughout the early development of American industry, are facing some stern problems these days. And many industry officials are pretty gloomy about their prospects.

TRENTON, Jan. 25 -- The State Supreme Court ruled today that the statute requiring the assessment of all real property in the state at 100 per cent of its true value applied also to taxable personal property.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The Institute of Human Relations named President Eisenhower as its first Honorary Fellow today and praised his global leadership for peace and freedom.
A method that may help scientists break the most important "code" in the world was described here yesterday at a symposium on virus research.
The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) last year had estimated consolidated net earnings of $626,000,000, or $2.91 each on the average of 215,064,000 shares outstanding during the year.
CHICAGO, Jan. 25 (AP) -- After a succession of small advances in the last three weeks, some new-crop wheat futures hit new high prices for the season by small margins today.
G. Russell Clark, State Superintendent of Banks, appealed yesterday to the state's commercial bankers to reconsider branch banking and holding company bills now before the Legislature in Albany.

Title to the fourteen-story office building at the northwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Forty-third Street was transferred yesterday, clearing the way for the conversion of the structure into a showplace of Australian products.
The State of California announced yesterday that it would take bids on March 9 on two issues of serial bonds totaling $100,000,000.

The State Attorney General started actions yesterday to dissolve two corporations for allegedly attempting to exercise "monopolistic control" of last June's heavyweight title fight between Floyd Patterson and Ingemar Johansson.
Peter Kavanagh surrendered 117 half-copies of his book, "The John Quinn Letters," to the State Supreme Court yesterday in sorrow and anger. He had cut the books in half, lengthwise, with a knife.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In his letter published Jan. 18 commenting on Arthur Krock's suggestion in his Jan. 7 column that antitrust laws be applied to unions, Prof. Dudley W. Johnson raises some interesting points on a problem of outstanding importance.
YESTERDAY (Jan. 25, 1960) THE PRESIDENT Discussed phone tax with Governor Rockefeller of New York. Discussed atomic fallout with Governors' committee.
Several things are happening this week to dramatize the swift developments in today's family of nations.

Nearly a hundred business leaders here pledged yesterday to make the prevention of juvenile delinquency their business. Their formula: jobs, scholarships, recreation, sports and positive public relations.
Robert Moses exploded a report yesterday that he would "retire from, active public life this April."

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- Labor without Bevan. This unusual, upsetting prospect faced the leaders of the Parliamentary Labor party tonight when they met to prepare for the reassembly of the House of Commons tomorrow.
Private Investors here and in Canada are being offered today $20,000,000 of fifteen-year 6 per cent convertible subordinated debentures of Home Oil Company, Ltd.
Syracuse University disclosed plans yesterday to establish what it described as the world's largest center for the study of journalism, television and other media of mass communication.
The Police Department yesterday released a list of addresses of raided gambling places that was compiled considerably before recent "disclosures" were made that such betting centers existed.
ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The Press Minister, Haluk Shaman, declared yesterday that Turkey enjoyed "complete freedom of the press."
WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 25 -- Two Westchester Park Commissioners were criticized for "autocratic" conduct today by some Democratic and Republican members of the County Board of Supervisors.
ROCHESTER, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Bob Turley said today he had rejected the New York Yankees offer of a contract calling for a, 24 per cent cut in salary.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Jan. 25 -- Additional charges were filed today against Suffolk County Judge Lloyd P. Dodge in an investigation of rezoning of Brookhaven Township properties in 1955.
If any team gets rough with the New York Knickerbockers, Carl Braun will advise his players to retaliate.
BLANTYRE, Nyasaland, Jan. 25 -- Excited young Africans gave Prime Minister Macmillan a noisy, hostile reception today on his arrival in Nyasaland.
TRENTON, Jan. 25 -- The State Supreme Court ruled today that New Jersey had no right to demand money from the Sperry Hutchinson Company on the basis of unredeemed trading stamps.
PARIS, Jan. 25 -- Among the leaders of the insurrection in Algiers are four men fanatically dedicated to the proposition that Algeria must remain French at all cost.

Those who make this suggestion seem to forget how often in the past we have denounced the Soviet Union and Communist China for their practice of using economic power to put economic and political pressure on other nations.
A New York County grand jury yesterday accused the Department of Hospitals of laxity in enforcing the laws governing the operation of private nursing homes in the city.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Jan. 25 -- Patrice Lumumba, president of one wing of the Congolese National Movement, is being released from jail to attend a conference here of Congolese and Belgian leaders.
Detroit, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Chevrolet and Ford rolled to production records last week and the whole auto industry may set a production record this week.

Neale Fraser, the ranking amateur player of the world, and Roy Emerson, who teamed with Fraser to regain the Davis Cup for Australia, will compete in the indoor championships of the United States Lawn Tennis Association.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 25 -- Transcontinental railroads and intercoastal water shipping interests opened a battle today before the Interstate Commerce Commission.
The city's unwillingness to spend enough for repairs is causing its $1,500,000,000 plant to run down, Public Works Commissioner Frederick H. Zurmuhlen charged yesterday.

Merger discussions are being held by the Eaton Manufacturing Company and the American Metal Products Company, it was disclosed yesterday in a joint statement by John C. Birden, chairman and president of Eaton, and A.M. Mras, president of American.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 25 -- The decision of former President Juan D. Peron of Argentina to leave the Americas for the first time in his five-year exile finds Argentine Peronists searching for new leaders and fresh ideas.

Soviet, American and Canadian scientists have reached a tentative agreement to exchange information about the floor of the Arctic Ocean so that a chart can be made of that little-known but highly strategic region.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- More active leadership and financial support from the Federal Government of state efforts to protect citizens against radioactive fall-out were demanded here today.
