If there has ever been a group in Congress hoist by its own petard, it is the Southern Democratic bloc now facing the prospect of Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. becoming, through seniority, chairman of the House Education and Labor Committee.
PARIS, Tuesday, Jan. 26 -- Premier Michel Debre flew to Algiers last night to bolster the French Government's efforts to restore order among European extremists challenging Its authority there.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- President Eisenhower insisted today on extension of the 10 per cent Federal tax on local telephone service after June 30. He rejected Governor Rockefeller's plan to transfer the levy to states for educational needs.
Mayor Wagner and leaders of industry and labor in the city have worked out the first specific program to provide more and better jobs for Negroes, Puerto Ricans and other low-wage workers.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Mary M. Dremucha's letter opposing rent control, published recently, expresses a widely held but hardly accurate viewpoint.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Donald H. McGannon, president of the Westinghouse Broadcasting Company, urged the Federal Communications Commission today to seek enactment of a "commercial bribery law" making payola a crime punishable by fines and imprisonment.

A truck driver who was accused by the police yesterday of killing a pedestrian in a hit-and-run accident said he had fled the scene because he did not want a blemish on his twenty-six-year record of perfect driving.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The United States has been asked, and apparently will agree, to forgo its new "buy American" policy in a major new aid package for India and Pakistan.

ALBANY, Jan. 25 -- A special commission to revise the formula for state aid to education and a substantial increase in the aid were urged here today by education officials from the state's five largest cities.

BAYVILLE, L.I., Jan. 25 -- F. Darius Benham, 57 years old, a public relations man and founder of the Circus Saints and Sinners, was killed in a fire that destroyed the top floor of his home at 1 Meadow Lane.
MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 25 -- George Halas, owner of the Chicago Bears, failed in an attempt today to break the deadlock over the election of a commissioner for the National Foothall League.
The next stop in the forward push of the Continental League:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- With cries of disgust and outrage and a tale of a one-eyed mule, Senate Republicans excoriated the Democrats today for abusing Vice President Nixon.
Solomon Chodorov, former rent collector for Banton Wyckoff was ordered yesterday to pay $1,200 in fines or spend 240 days in jail for violation of probation.
GENEVA, Jan. 21 -- The American woman in the Geneva restaurant opened her eyes with delight at the sight of the menu.

ALTHOUGH Louis A. Lippa begins "The Breaking Wall" in a placid mood, he has fiery things in mind. He sets off an emotional explosion in an Italian village; and the performance at the St. Marks Playhouse, where his play opened last evening, meets him on every emotional level.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Secretary of Defense Thomas S. Gates Jr. said today that the recent downward revision in estimates of Soviet missile strength had been based on ''refined and better" intelligence information. It was not based on guesswork about Soviet intentions, he said.
Diana Barrymore, 38-year-old daughter of the late John Barrymore, was found dead yesterday in her apartment at 33 East Sixty-first Street.

Raymond Pannell, Canadian pianist, played a debut performance at Carnegie Recital Hall last night. Mr. Pannell, who made his orchestral debut at the age of 13, studied at the Juilliard School and is now on the faculty of the Royal Conservatory of Music in Toronto.

IT is a good thing, from time to time, to stand back and take a long look at the history of writing in America. The latest opportunity to do that is provided by Leon Howard's new book, a splendidly opinionated volume called "Literature and the American Tradition."
A ranking union official said yesterday that Governor Rockefeller's legislative program was disappointing in the light of his position as a leader of the liberal wing of the Republican party.

A state investigator charged yesterday that Borough President Albert V. Maniscalco of Staten Island had "rendered substantial favors to particular builders" and "received substantial favors in return," including improvements on his home.
Market values on the New York Stock Exchanges shrank about $3,250,000,000 yesterday as prices dipped to their lowest level since Nov. 18.
BERLIN, Jan. 25 -- The Rev. Dr. Otto Dibelius, Evangelical Bishop of Berlin and the East German province of Brandenburg, announced today his intention to resign from all church offices next year.

For Coach Herman Wolfe, the bottom fell out of the basketball season last week. A Commerce player was found to be ineligible and the team's victories were forfeited. Wolfe was the man who blew the whistle on himself.

A TON of red tape colors the life of an average Polish housewife. Two examples were reader's letters published last month in the weekly Polish women's magazine called Przyjaciolka (Friends). The publication reputedly follows a traditional Communist policy.
Defense counsel for Alexander L. Guterma and Robert J. Eveleigh, financiers, asked a Federal jury yesterday to acquit them in their conspiracy trial.

Grand Slam of Golf Probably the greatest individual achievement in the history of sports will be celebrated today when Bobby Jones receives a trophy marking the thirtieth anniversary of his golf grand slam at the annual National Golf Award Dinner of the Metropolitan Golf Writers Association.

TWO plays by August Strindberg, "Miss Julie" and "The Stronger," constitute this week's bill on "The Play of the Week" over Channel 13, The evening is one of the most powerful and absorbing in the history of television drama.

DETROIT, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The cargo-handling capacity of the Detroit Marine Terminals, Inc., will be doubled this spring on completion of a $1,500,000 expansion program, the company's president, David C. Lowe, said today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The United States will continue its attitude of patience toward the Cuban Government of Premier Fidel Castro.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The prosecutor in the Finch murder trial testified today that he did not advise CaroleTregoff of her constitutional rights either before or after charging her with murder.

The election of two trustees and a change of policy have been announced here by the Phelps-Stokes Fund. The forty-eight-year-old institution, which aims at improving the status of Negroes in the United States and in Africa and of North American Indians, is transforming itself from a grant-making into an operating agency.
fied corporatioa to deliver the top dollar to fighters for closedcircuit television."

HOPEFUL, Ga., Jan. 25 -- A major research blow in pure science was struck here today. It was established beyond quibble, or shown to be pretty likely, that running quail will stop running when a hawk-call is sounded.

Samuel (Chico) Rollins, a promising West Side lighlweight who had scored three straight knockouts at the Academy of Music, went ten tough rounds there last nigh before gaining the decision over James D. Ellis of Trenton.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Harold Russell Tyler Jr., a New York lawyer, has been chosen to head the Justice Department's Civil Rights Division.

DAVOS, Switzerland, Jan. 25 (UPI) -- American preparations for Alpine skiing at next month's Winter Olympics hit a peak today when Tom Corcoran won the men's giant slalom in the Coppa Grischa ski meet and Linda Meyers took the women's over-all honors for week-long competition at three sites.

Victor E. Rockhill has been named president and chief executive officer of the Chase International Investment Corporation, wholly owned foreign financing subsidiary of the Chase Manhattan Bank. Robert H. Craft, former president, has been named a vice chairman.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 25 -- If an economic history of Hollywood is ever written a few sympathetic footnotes should be reserved for the plight of the hyphenated movie men caught in the writers strike.
ALBANY, Jan. 25 -- The fate of banking legislation this year is likely to hinge on the attitude taken by Democratic members of the Legislature, Assembly Speaker Joseph Carlino predicted today.

New concepts in home building and community development will be put to the test in Pittsbugh's East Hills project. It represents the newest thinking in the rebuilding that has been under way in the city for more than a decade.

THE picture looked familiar. A smiling Hank Bauer beamed from the sports pages the other day as he signed another baseball contract. But it almost seemed as if it was one of those what's-wrong-with-this-picture deals. It was not a Yankee contract the hardbitten ex-Marine was signing. It was one with the Kansas City Athletics.

A GUEST conductor is a rarity at the Little Orchestra Society, which has been the steadfast concern of Thomas Scherman, its creator. A harmonica soloist is a rarity with any orchestra. There was one of each at Town Hall last night:
The future of the aircraft carrier -- certain to be debated bitterly at this session of Congress -- may be influenced by the results of a recent fleet, air defense exercise of the Navy and Air Force.

The Armco Steel Corporation, the nation's sixth largest producer of the metal, turned in the second highest earnings in its history in 1959 on the second largest sales volume, according to the preliminary report released today.

Black and Decker The directors of Black Decker Manufacturing Company voted a quarterly dividend of 40 cents a common share. It is payable on March 31 to holders of record of March 15. The company paid 30 cents a share in September and again in December of last year following a two-for-one split in September.

American support and participation in efforts to maintain trade cooperation by West European nations was urged yesterday by representatives of the new Outer Seven freetrade trade alliance. The Outer Seven, officially the European Free Trade Association,consists of Britain, Norway, Sweden, Denmark, Austria, Switzerland and Portugal.

The labor dispute that has shut down shipyards of the Bethlehem Steel Company in Quincy, Mass., and Hoboken, N.J., appeared no closer to settlement yesterday evening after Federal mediators recessed separate meetings with company and union negotiators.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- For several years President Eisenhower has been trying to shift telephone tax collection from the Federal Government to the states. But now Governor Rockefeller of New York has asked for it in the name of education and the President says "absolutely not."
LONDON, Jan. 25 -- Michael Blundell, head of the moderate, multiracial New Kenya Group, urged today a gradual unfolding of freedom for Kenya.
NO STATISTICIAN or social satirist has yet tried to account for the astounding numercial increase in art galleries.

IN response to the question "Where do you keep the barley?" most grocers will direct the customer to the back of the cereal section. If in a talkative mood, they probably will add that the demand for barley is not what it used to be.
ALGIERS, Jan. 25 -- The army command was reported to have tanks and armored cars on the outskirts of the city.
SOUTHAMPTON, England, Jan. 25 (AP) -- An American freighter and a Norwegian tanker, both badly damaged, were towed into port today after a grinding collision that locked them together for five hours.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Five Western powers began today the long process of working out a new over-all disarmament program.
TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 17 -- Some Iranians feel today like that figure common in dreams: a man trying desperately to run, but unable to lift his feet.

Mayor Wagner has included the firm of S.J. Kessler Sons on his 1960 list of architects approved for business with the city. But the Mayor explained yesterday that this did not mean that the firm was approved for business with the city.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 25 -- The Government, under heavy pressure to check the rising cost of living, issued today price ceilings for necessities such as food, clothing, kerosene and transport.

Continued cold weather in Florida, which may damage or delay the potato crop, strengthened futures early yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Later in the session liquidation, particularly in the March position, reversed the price movement.
STEAMBOATSPRINGS. Colo., Jan. 25 (AP) -- Mack Miller of Gunnison, Colo., scored a smashing victory today in the first cross-country race trials for the United States Olympic Nordic combined ski team.

ALBANY, Jan. 25 -- A special committee named by Governor Rockefeller, rejected today a proposal that veterans' organizations and volunteer fire companies remain exempt from state fund-raising regulations.

ACCRA, Ghana, Jan. 25 (AP) A newspaper founded by Prime Minister Kwame Nkrumah said today that the Rev. Dr. Billy Graham was a good actor and a good psychologist, but "Nkrumahism is the highest form of Christianity in an age of greed and hypocrisy."

The Republic of India celebrates its tenth anniversary today. How young India is -- and how ancient! When the barbarian tribes were still swarming all over Europe, India was a continent with a refined civilization, an old religion, a great literature, exquisite arts. But today she is ten years old.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- House Democrats ran into solid Administration opposition today in their drive for quick passage of a billion-dollar emergency housing bill.
DMITRI SHOSTAKOVICH'S Eleventh Symphony ("1905") was the big item of the Moscow State Symphony's concert last night at Carnegie Hall.

The market for United States Government securities continued to adjust itself yesterday to the likelihood of the Treasury's offering new debt securities bearing 5 per cent interest in exchange for the $11,363,000,000 of certificates of indebtedness due Feb. 15.

The Federal Reserve System has decided to keep a permanent eye on the operation of the Government securities market. As the outgrowth of the joint study by the Treasury and the Federal Reserve into the financing of Government securities dealers, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York has created a new department to gather facts and figures and named its first woman officer to head it.
LAST night some friends and other curious people gathered at the Living Theatre, where John Cage was telling some stories while David Tudor provided some accompanying sounds.

It was business as usual at a bank here yesterday despite construction work on an eighteen-story office building that is literally rising through the bank, a branch of the Chemical Bank New York Trust Company.
A spectacular 176-square-mile sanctuary that is 95 per cent under water has been established in the Bahama Islands by prominent American and Bahamian conservationists.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The Federal Aviation Agency was told today that the time had come to "crack down" on communities that failed to provide land for installation of airport approach lights.

CONTRACT bridge is an amateur game in which the prizes have no intrinsic value and the players usually do not even have their expenses' paid as they do in amateur sports. Every expert, therefore, often spends several hundred dollars to travel to a national tournament and seek the transient glory of a championship.
The Women's Division of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York is sponsoring a Festival of the performing Arts to take place in the Grand Ballroom of the Astor on Thursday afternoon.

"Redhead," starring Gwen Verdon and Richard Kiley, will close March 19 at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre. The final showing will be the 453d for the musical by Herbert and Dorothy Fields, Sidney Sheldon, David Shaw and Albert Hague.
Another of the more than 1,000 motor common carriers in the nation now operating as a closed corporation is planning a recapitalization program to pave the way for a public stock offering.

Ten fuel oil company executives and employes invoked the Fifth Amendment yesterday in refusing to answer questions put to them by the Bronx District Attorney's office in an investigation into a possible oil delivery racket.
A class of Brooklyn boys and girls listened attentively yesterday while a former teacher who is also a former First Lady, delivered some thumbnail precepts on their education am their future.

Robert F. Kennedy, former chief counsel of the McClellan Committee, has written an account of that committee's investigations into labor-management corruption over the last three years. To be called "The Enemy Within," the book will be published Feb. 24 by Harper.
One victim in the Montego Bay air crash in Jamaica, B.W.I., on Thursday was Identified yesterday by Colombian authorities as a fugitive from Justice who was using a stolen passport.

ALGIERS, Jan. 25 -- More than 2,500 defiant European settlers faced Army paratroopers across barricades in the heart of Algiers tonight, but both sides held their fire. Through the nerve-racking day, the Right-wing insurrectionists built up their ranks from about 900.
TUNIS, Jan. 25 -- President Habib Bourguiba demanded today that France evacuate the naval and air base at Bizerte before Feb. 8.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UPI) -- Senator William Proxmire charged today that James R. Durfee, chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, had "flagrantly violated" the Government's code of ethics by accepting free hospitality from airlines in Rome, Mexico City and Pinehurst, N.C.

The full-page advertisements critical of Earl W. Kintner, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, that have been inserted by Ted Bates Co., Inc., in newspapers has reportedly caused considerable irritation in Washington.

Sylvia Wene, the little Philadelphian who has reached perfection in bowling three times and twice in the last eight weeks, claims "the twelfth strike in a 300 game isn't as hard to make as the eleventh." However, Miss Wene admits it's hard trying to brush aside' all the thoughts that run through her mind just prior to rolling that twelfth strike.

TUNIS, Jan. 15 (Reuter) -- President Bourguiba told an audience of 100,000 at the rally today that on Feb. 8 "we shall put into practice measures for the evacuation of the last French soldier from Tunisia."

The Kroger Company, large grocery chain with headquarters in Cincinnati, cleared more than $2 a share and sales were about $1,911,000,000 last year, Joseph B. Hall, president, said yesterday. This compared with share earnings of $1.76 and sales of $1,776,175,147 in 1958.
Art and medicine, inseparable companions at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, entered a new phase yesterday. Art took precedence in a show by the faculty and staff.

The Southern California Edison Company sold $30,000,000 of its first and refunding mortgage bonds yesterday to investment bankers managed by Blyth Co., Inc. at an interest cost to the utility of 4.97 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UPI) -- James R. Durfee, chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, testified today that three trips he had taken as a guest of commercial airlines were part of his official duty "to promote aviation."

Maj. Gen. John B. Medaris has been in charge of the Army missile program at Redstone Arsenal at Huntsville, Ala., for the last four years. He will resign from the Army at the end of this month and has signed a contract with Putnam for a book tentatively titled "Countdown for Decision."

A manipulation by "professional racketeers, promoters and boiler room operators" of the stock of the Oreclone Concentrating Company that caused losses to investors "in excess of four million dollars" was charged yesterday by the State Attorney General.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The Administration produced a sweeping new proposal today to advance Negro voting.
The American Photocopy Equipment Company achieved record sales and earnings in

The July domestic sugar position fell to new lows for the life of the contract yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange and the March, May and November contracts equaled the old lows. Selling by Cuban interests depressed the market.
Jacob Ruppert announced last night an ambitious campaign to promote its beer in the coming year.

Perm State, Maryland, Villanova and Boston University are among the leading independents who will be competing against Yale of the Heptagonal group and Manhattan of the metropolitan set for Eastern varsity track leadership this winter.

Joseph Schechter, City Director of Personnel and chairman of the City Civil Service Commission, died last night at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived at 27 West Fifty-fifth Street. An aide said Mr. Schechter had entered the hospital Friday with a heart ailment.
Allen W. Dulles, director of the Central Intelligence Agency, denied last night that there had been any change in the method of reaching intelligence estimates of Soviet strength.

PARIS, Wednesday, Jan. 27 -- Another night of quiet in Algiers. Another night of paratroopers watching insurgent and insurgents watching paratroopers. Another night of wondering what dawn would bring in this strange insurrection.

City College's athletic department announced yesterday that it has decided to end its traditional basketball ties with its long-time metropolitan rivals, Fordham, Manhattan, New York University and St. John's.

HOUSTON, Jan. 26 (UPI) -- The owners of the Houston Buffs reluctantly offered today to sell their American Association franchise "without profit" so that Houston could get ready for major league baseball in the new Continental League.

The New York Rangers will be back on home ice tonight after a road trip that produced one victory and a tie for them in seven games. The Blues, still nursing hopes for a Stanley Cup play-off berth, will skate against the National Hockey League's pace-setting Montreal Canadiens at Madison Square Garden.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The Senate passed legislation today to deal more effectively with the growing problem of juvenile delinquency. It now goes to the House of Representatives.

In so far as a reasonable, friendly and understanding statement of the United States attitude toward Cuba today can help to reduce friction, President Eisenhower has provided it. The statement expresses concern over the deterioration of our relations with Cuba, makes a pledge not to intervene or take reprisals, and expresses "a real understanding and sympathy with the ideals and aspirations of the Cuban people."

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 26 (UPI) -- Jackie Jensen, the husky slugger who was named the American League's most valuable player in 1958, quit baseball today to devote more time to his family and his business enterprises.

NIKOLAI LOPATNIKOFF and Charles Rosen shared the spotlight at last night's concert of the National Orchestral Association at Carnegie Hall. In presenting the composer and pianist as it did, the association showed itself serving one of its secondary purposes in an admirable way.
A World Trade Center that may cost $250,000,000 was proposed yesterday for thirteen and a half acres along the East River, adjoining New York's downtown financial district.

ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- Governor Rockefeller announced today a plan to give nonresidents $5,500,000 in tax relief, beginning next year. He proposed that the nonresidents receive essentially the same privileges as the taxpayers who live in the state.

Air-India, the Indian flag carrier airline, has leased a floor in the new office building at 410 Park Avenue, southwest corner of Fifty-fifth Street, from the Kleban Realty and Construction Corporation. The lessee will use the space for its North American headquarters. George L. Studley, vice president of Julien J. Studley, Inc., was the broker.
"Hello, Mrs. Jones?" "Yes." "Mr. Jones is calling from El Al Israel flight two zero one."
Sales and earnings of the Kimberly-Clark Corporation in the fiscal year ending on April 30 are expected to be about 10 per cent higher than in fiscal 1959, John R. Kimberly, chairman, said yesterday.

GEORGE SEMENTOVSKY, Yugoslav-born pianist, who has been working in this country for the last few years, gave his Town Hall debut recital last night. His program consisted of Beethoven's Sonata in E flat, Op. 31; Schumann's "Symphonic Etudes," the first four of Kodaly's Op. 11 set of piano pieces, five Preludes by Scriabin and Chopin's B minor Sonata.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: B.L. England's letter criticizing the T.V.A. and other public power utilities was printed in The Times the day after it was announced that the private utility corporation serving New York had been granted a $14,000,000 rate increase. Consolidated Edison's net profit in 1958 was $65,357,119.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Following is a statement on Cuba issued by President Eisenhower at his news conference today:

At his press conference yesterday President Eisenhower made a spirited defense of his Administration's defense and space programs. He assured the nation of his confidence in the latest intelligence estimates, which, on the basis of Soviet capabilities and intentions, give the United States a clear superiority in nuclear deterrent power and the free world a clear superiority of defensive capability.
The 100-year-old Roman Catholic Church of St. Nicholas at East Second Street and Houston Street has been sold and will be demolished.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 26 (AP)The directors of the McDonnell Aircraft Corporation have approved a 2-for-l stock split that

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: S.H. Dana's letter printed Jan. 19 was concerned with the actions of a New York City policeman regarding four boys, ages 14 to 15, walking up or down escalators at the Grand Central subway station at 10 P.M.
Three young men were arrested last night and held in $15,000 bail each after they had allegedly strutted through Union Square Park giving the Nazi salute and shouting "Heil Hitler!"
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The Administration called on Congress today to extend its ban on cancer-inducing agents in foods to color additives.
Any price uncertainty the market for United States Government securities may have had in the face of the Treasury's imminent refunding of $11,363,000,000 of maturiing debt oame to an end yesterday.

PARIS, Jan. 27 -- The Given -chy look of last fall is sweeping Paris this spring. It is a fairly extraordinary event when one couturier's line from one season has such a profound influence on his colleagues the next, but that seems to be the case.
ROME, Jan. 26 -- Pope John XXIII told the synod meeting here today that the Roman Catholic Church would not renounce celibacy as a requisite for ordained clergy.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- President Eisenhower said today the United States had an "admirable" record in the exploration of space, and that Americans had no reason to bow their "heads in shame."
PARIS, Jan. 26 -- Signs of anxiety, notably in Paris, began today to disrupt the appearance of calm in France.
FAIRFIELD, Conn., Jan. 26 -- A civic organization took action today to halt a school expansion program here.

KARLSRUHE, Germany, Jan. 26 -- A former West German naval officer said at his treason trial today that he had become so "Americanized" by the United States Navy that he almost abandoned his double life as a Soviet spy.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Americans are poor salesmen of their surplus farm products in world markets, a study group of the House Agricultural Committee concluded today.

ONE of the Museum of Modern Art's most popular features, the Art Lending Service, celebrates its first decade with a selective exhibition of paintings, prints, drawings and pieces of sculpture sold through this service at prices ranging from less than $100 to a top of $750.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 26 -- Hungarian economic planners consider the raising of productivity of individual workers one of the Government's most vital problems.

Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., reported yesterday that it established new highs in operating revenues, net income and sales of gas, electricity and steam in 1959; Directors, at their meeting yesterday, also voted to increase the quarterly dividend to 75 cents a share, up 5 cents from the previous payments.
SAMUEL BARON, flutist, and Robert Conant, harp- sichordist, presented an interesting program of French and German music at Carnegie Recital Hall last night.
PARIS, Jan. 26 -- French democracy hung in the balance tonight.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, Jan. 26 -- A new effort to determine what effect world events are having on Jews on both sides of the Iron Curtain began today with the first meeting of the executive committee of the B'nai B'ritu International Council.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UPI) -- Following is the transcript of President Elsenhower's news conference today:
Injuries in city traffic last week totaled 740 persons, the Police Safety Bureau announced yesterday. This was a decrease compared with 1959. when 846 persons were injured in the comparable week.

Another attempt by Federal mediators to renew contract negotiations between shipyard workers and the Bethlehem Steel Company failed yesterday. Consequently a strike at two of the company's yards enters its fourth day today with the possibility of spreading to other Atlantic Coast yards.
A week of confusing commuting is in store for several hundred residents of South Jamaica because a $9,200,000 grade-crossing elimination job is finished.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- A provision that may get around right-to-work laws now in effect in nineteen states has been written into the now sleel industry labor contracts.
David Campanella, 16-year-old stepson of Roy Campanella, former Dodger catcher, was jailed yesterday with two other youths on charges of petity larceny.
The rate of personal saving in the nation last year was lower than in all but two years or the last decade.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday he would reappoint former Magistrate Robert F. Mahoney if the city's two major bar associations recommended him.
Brightening economic conditions in the city have enabled the Welfare Department to ask for a reduction of $7,238,058 in its budget for the fiscal year beginning next July 1.

Net income of the United States Steel Corporation during 1959 dropped to $253,975,686 from $301,558,231 in 1958, refleeting the impact of the steel strike, Roger M. Blough, chairman, disclosed yesterday.
LONDON, Jan. 26 -- Hopes rose tonight for an early agreement on British bases on Cyprus and proclamation of the island's independence in March.

The experiences of international trade centers in New Orleans, Boston and San Francisco were studied by the Downtown -- Lower Manhattan Association before reaching the decision, announced yesterday, to advocate a vast world trade center in New York.
CONCORD, N.H., Jan. 26 -- The image of Governor Rockefeller of New York, albeit dim, remains part of the Presidential primary picture in New Hampshire.

Rear Admiral Henry C. Perkins, commander of the Eastern Area and of the Third Coast Guard District, will retire June 30 after thirty-five years of commissioned service in the Coast Guard. He will be succeeded in these two commands by Rear Admiral Edwin J. Roland.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The Air Force announced today the selection of locations for four additional intercontinental ballistic missile bases. This completes the list of eleven launching sites for the thirteen Atlas squadrons in the current program.
The grand jury that indicted Borough President Hulan E. Jack sat again yesterday and heard two witnesses.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The Senate approved today a list of military promotions. It included the nominations of Lieut. Gen. Clark L. Ruffner to full general and Vice Admiral Harold P. Smith to four-star admiral.

American Tobacco An extra dividend of $1 and the regular quarterly dividend of $1 have been declared on the common stock of the American Tobacco Company for payment on March 1. A similar extra was paid last March. Stockholders will meet April 6 to consider a two-for-one stock split.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Following are the text of a statement made by Attorney General William P. Rogers today on a new proposal to protect voting rights, and the text of a draft bill he submitted:

Directors of Von's Grocery Company and of Shopping Bag Food Stores, both California supermarket chains, approved plans for their merger yesterday. Their combined sales of $185,017,000 and supermarkets numbering sixty-six, would make the resulting chain the second largest on the West Coast, according to the announcement.

The Federal Reserve Board's failure to lift the 3 per cent interest ceiling on foreign time deposits has impaired the usefulness of New York City as a center of world finance, the head of the city's largest and the nation's second largest bank asserted yesterday.
THE gap between fabrics for dress fashions and those for home furnishings is narrowing. Some day a woman may shop for dress and curtain materials at the same counter.
General of the Army Douglas MacArthur celebrated his eightieth birthday last night with ninety-seven old friends from the thinning ranks of his associates in war and peace.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Gov. Edmund G. Brown of California and others criticized the Eisenhower Administration anew today on the ground that it was permitting home building to be threatened by a shortage, of home mortgage credit and high interest loans.
The Government asked a Federal jury yesterday to convict Alexander L. Guterma and Robert J. Eveleigh, financiers, of conspiracy to conceal the looting of the F.L. Jacobs Company.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your Jan. 22 editorial "The Algerian Storm" affirmed that General de Gaulle's "offer of self-determination for all Algerians * * * was not sanctioned by the Algerian rebel leaders. * * *"
BLANTYRE, Nyasaland, Jan. 26 -- Prime Minister Macmillan was the object today of the most violent demonstration he had encountered in Nyasaland.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UPI) -- The United States today marked one of its busiest daps in space And missile activities. It successfully fired two Atlas intercontinental ballistic missiles 5,000 miles on target.

Following to the text of the report by the Downtown-Lower Manhattan Association, Inc., proposing a World Trade Center for the Port of New York. It was submitted to Governor Rockefeller, Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey and Mayor Wagner.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Wednesday, Jan. 27 -- Indonesia has warned Communist China that she might delay the repatriation of overseas Chinese if they continue to "disrupt" the national economy.
President Eisenhower son greetings and Vice President Nixon personally congratulated jguests of honor at the National Golf Award Dinner at the Hotel Plaza last night.
Opinions as to the state of the stock market shade from "very blue" to rosy, The New Times found in a survey yesterday of analysts' comments.
ALBANY, Jan. 26 (UPI) -- The following ski conditions were reported today by the New York Slate Department of Commerce:

Burlington Industries, Inc. the nation's largest textile company, plans to broaden its activities into the rug field through a proposed merger with James Lees Sons Company, a major rug maker. The combined companies would have assets of about $586,000,000.
Proposals for a World Trade Center at the foot of Wall Street have aroused interest at the New York Stock Exchange.

The Soviet economy last year failed to achieve its capital investment plan. The deficiency casts a shadow over the prospects for the current Seven Year Plan and appears to be a factor behind the decision to demobilize one-third of the Soviet forces on active duty.
A Suffolk Courity justice of peace found himself yesterday facing a law violation in the Federal court, Brooklyn.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Jan. 26 The Foreign Ministry received a cablegram today from the Colombian Consulate in Madrid saying that Mario Campuzano, killed in an Avianca crash in Jamaica last week, had been imprisoned in Spain "for various crimes" the last five years.
YESTERDAY (Jan. 26, 1960) THE GOVERNOR Announced program of tax relief for nonresident income taxpayers.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 26 -- The board of directors of the Screen Actors Guild will ask its members for authority to call a strike against the major movie studios.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 26 (UPI) -- Willie Mays signed today with the San Francisco Giants for around $85,000. The figure was believed to make him the highest-paid player in baseball.

The National Broadcasting Company let its comedians know yesterday that they have nothing to fear. They can go right on inserting canned laughter in their shows without having to acknowledge that the response was technically produced.
MIAMI, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Bill Hartack had another big afternoon at Hialeah Park today. He won four races and just missed on two other mounts.

CAMDEN, N.J., Jan. 26 -- Forty of the city's 205 police department members appeared today before a grand jury investigating alleged police corruption. They were handed twentypage financial questionnaires to be filled out and returned by Feb. 16.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The United States will offer a new concession to the Soviet Union in an effort to end the stalemate on the banning of nuclear test explosions. It is understood that the Administration will propose that the test-ban treaty, now under negotiation in Geneva, provide for the following:
YESTERDAY (Jan. 26, 1960) THE PRESIDENT Held news conference. Nominated Harold Tyler to be head of Justice Department's Civil Rights Division.
ALBANY, Jan. 26. -- State tax collections for the first nine months of its current fiscal year were $198,400,000 higher than in the corresponding period of last year.

Cotton futures moved 6 points (30 cents a bale) up to 3 points (15 cents) off yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. The near months showed little change, while the far March and May contracts were a little stronger at the close because of small commission house buying at a time when there were very few offerings.
CINCINNATI, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The National League has booked 312 night games for 1960, including a record sixty-four at home for the world champion Los Angeles Dodgers.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Jan. 26 -- An 18-year-old mother who was kidnapped and raped Jan. 9 disclosed today that she had received a fourteen-page letter of remorse from her attacker.

Capital Airlines, Inc., is going ahead with its plan to offer stockholders 909,659 shares of common stock on a basis of one new share for each share held. A statement concerning the offering was filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission (S.E.C.).

Dr. George N. Shuster received an emotion-charged tribute yesterday as he was awarded a rare honorary doctorate by Hunter College. He is retiring March 1 after twenty years as president of the college.
The printers of The New York Times, members of Typographical Union 6, helped the fund for the Neediest Cases yesterday with gifts totaling $534.
Discussion here yesterday of European free-trading movements ranged from the power of Premiere to the outlook for tomato canning in Italy.
ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- The State Senate voted today to relax the educational requirements for welfare case workers and investigators.
ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- The state has run into administrative delays in spacing out the renewal dates of drivers' licenses and automobile license plates.

HOPEFUL, Ga., Jan. 26 -- Turkey hunting along the banks of the Flint River is about half hunting and half observance of a complicated hunting system. A hunter has got to yelp up his turkey if he expects it to count in anybody else's eyes.
TANGIER, Morocco, Jan. 26 -- The outlook for economic cooperation in Africa under United Nations sponsorship was somewhat marred today.

DALLAS, Jan. 26 (UPI) -- A New York University economist took sharp issue today with the view that high interest rates for mortgages would be more than offset by a growing supply of available loan funds to support the housing market.
The "man of the year" in automobile racing will be honored Saturday night at the annual dinner of the Auto Racing Fraternity of Greater New York in the Park Sheraton Hotel.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 26 -- The Los Angeles police chief defended his force today against charges of brutality and discrimination against Negroes.
A leader in world mental health left for Moscow yesterday to persuade the Russians to participate in World Mental Health Year in 1960.

David Merrick, Broadway's high-geared producer, who acquired the rights to "Irma, La Douce" last summer against the competition of a dozen American and European managers, is moving ahead with production plans for the musical.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The Democratic majority of the Congressional Joint Economic Committee charged today that the nation's recent failure to achieve rapid economic growth and stable prices was due in great part to faulty economic policies of the Eisenhower Administration.
LONDON, Jan. 26 -- A crack in non-African resistance to proposals for far-reaching voting reforms appeared today at the Kenya constitutional conference.

EXCEPT for the Mediterranean Sea, no body of salt water has played a larger part in human affairs than the English Channel. And yet, although many books have been written about rivers, seas and oceans, until now there has been none about the narrow strait that separates England from France.
Dr. Edward Teller, the nuclear scientist, said here last night that it was hopeless to control disarmament "when we do not even know what fantastic weapons" the controls should try to detect.

WHEN Dr. George Nauman Shuster set March 1, 1960, as the date on which he asked to be relieved of the presidency of Hunter College, he pointed to the many new ties between the community, the nation and the college.
AKRON, Ohio, Jan. 26 -- A Los Angeles physician, virtually an unknown amateur auto racing driver, will attempt to break the land speed record this summer with the world's first pure jet-powered car.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization of parents, lists the following films as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old. They will be shown Friday through Sunday, unless otherwise noted.

A proposal that the city pay many of the doctors in municipal hospitals who now volunteer their services was made yesterday by Dr. Morris A. Jacobs, Commissioner of Hospitals. This would include some top supervisory personnel.

ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- The State Board of Law Examiners reported today the names of 523 persons who passed the exanimation for admission to the New York State held on Nov. 19 and 20. They were among 1,066 who took the examination.
ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- A reorganization in the method by which the New York City Board of Education is chosen was proposed today by two Republican legislators from the city.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 26 -- The Security Council unanimously recommended today the admission of the new African state of Cameroon to membership in the United Nations.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 26 -- The invalid wife of a prominent surgeon, two women servants and a cab driver were found murdered today in the surgeon's large colonial home on an isolated estate here.

The world's two leading ship-classification societies reported a seeming paradox yesterday. One noted a gradual decline in world-wide shipbuilding; the other, a great expansion in shipbuilding installations.
A bill was introduced in the City Council yesterday to impose special licensing regulations and penalties on fuel oil dealers.
CHICAGO, aJn. 26 (AP) --The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
HONG KONG, Jan. 26 -- The United States may have lost any support it had in Hong Kong for voluntary restrictions on textile manufactures exported to the American market.
HAVANA, Jan. 26 -- Denunciations of the United States by radio commentators in Havana increased in violence today.
CHICAGO, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Grain futures on the Board of Trade developed some firm spots today in the most active trading in more than two weeks.

Dr. John J. Theobald, Superintendent of Schools, said yesterday that he would recommend to the Board of Education tomorrow that the city system employ a special representative to serve as a sort of ambassador without portfolio.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The New York State Legislature will shortly be called upon to consider the Cooke-Volker bill which asks for one-year state residence as a requirement for receiving state public welfare assistance. Such proposals have been put to the Legislature before and have been defeated.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company today reported 1959 net income of $30,956,040, equal to $8.90 a common share. It compares with a profit of $21,501,320, or $6.23 a share, in 1958.

BRIDGE experts must reconcile themselves to the fact that their fame has a strictly limited radius. Even among the fifty million bridge players in the world only a few thousand ever have heard of the leading players.
The increasing recognition by American universities that international affairs should receive top priority was cited yesterday by John W. Gardner, president of the Carnegie Corporation of New York.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UPI) -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee ended a week's delay today and unanimously approved Livingston T. Merchant as Under Secretary of State for political affairs.
The first heavy transport plane to land on the inland plateau of the Antarctic has set down at Byrd Station in the heart of Marie Byrd Land.
A drama critic entered The Lambs den yesterday and came out like a lion.

Primary hypertension, a condition characterized by high blood pressure alone, may be the result of an inherited biochemical error rather than the pressures of anxiety, the New York Heart Association's annual conference heard yesterday.
Mrs. Reinaldo Herrera has accepted chairmanship of the patroness committee for the sixteenth annual March of Dimes Fashion Show to be held at the Astor Feb. 15.
After another sinking spell yesterday morning, stocks rallied to close with a modest gain.

ABOARD U.S. CARRIER VALLEY FORGE, at Sea, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The world's largest balloon came back to earth today, eight hours after launching. The Navy ordered its descent. The balloon carried photographic equipment to record cosmic rays.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- President Eisenhower reaffirmed today a policy of no reprisals against the Cuban people and no intervention in Cuba's Internal affairs.

DUNEDIN, Fla., Jan. 26 (AP) -- Al Watrous, 60 years old and three times the champion, started his bid for a fourth title when he carded a one-under-par 71 for his first round in the $15,000 Professional Golfers Association seniors' gold tournament today.
MOSCOW, Jan. 26 (Reuters) -- The 1,200,000 officers and men being demobilized from the Soviet armed forces were urged today to help populate Siberia.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- President Eisenhower's moderate statement on policy toward Cuba was issued today in the face of grave charges and bitter condemnation of the United States and its officials by Premier Fidel Castro and his followers.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Alvin Ray (Pete) Rozelle has more than one pood reason to remember the birth of his daughter.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- President Eisenhower endorsed today the controversial new intelligence estimates that, downgrade the Soviet missile threat.
Mayor Wagner launched his promised drive yesterday to put the city's single-room occupancy buildings out of business.
PARIS. KEEPING pace with rising hair styles, spring hats shown in Paris last week have high, roomy crowns. Roundtopped or flat, they have tiny brims for daytime; sweep low over the face for evening.

BUCHANAN, N.Y., Jan. 26 -- Thirty New York union leaders got a view today of the shape of things to come at the $100,000,000 atomic electric plant under construction here by the Consolidated Edison Company.
ALGIERS, Jan. 26 -- The civilian chief in Algeria was working today to avoid a breach between Metropolitan France and this embattled North African territory.
New York City has borrowed $40,000,000 on tax anticipation notes due on May 5 at an interest rate of 3 1/4 per cent, Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa said yesterday.

"NEW Skies for New York" is the title of the sky show that reopens the Hayden Planetarium on Saturday. The star of the show, if one will excuse the expression, is a new Zeiss projector that replaces one that has served the Planetarium since it opened in 1935.
MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 26 -- In a sudden switch that brought to an end seven days of bitter wrangling among the twelve club-owners, a new commissioner of the National Football League was elected tonight.
ATLANTA, Jan. 26 -- Thirty-three Southern educators warned today that if public schools were closed the resulting social, economic and political damage would bring a collapse of democratic society.
A major advance in the field of radiation detection was described by scientists here yesterday.

The American Civil Liberties Union informed the Department of Defense yesterday of its opinion that on Okinawa and the other Ryukyu islands "security provisions are too strict and democratic liberties too limited."
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 26 -- India celebrated her tenth anniversary as a republic today in a whirl of gaiety, ceremony, oratory and displays of military strength.
Harness racing fans will see horses from the Soviet Union in action next August at Roosevelt Raceway if the track's plans work out.
The real issue being tested across the street barricades in Algeria is whether the capital of France is Paris or Algiers.
PARIS. The Fourth French Republic ended two years ago with a whimper. But if the Fifth is brought down by another Algerian mob, it will go with a bang.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- President Eisenhower challenged today a contention of Sir Anthony Eden, former British Prime Minister, that the United States had abandoned its British and French allies in the crisis that followed Egypt's 1956 seizure of the Suez Canal.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Ac tual manufacturing costs are fractionally small part of the retail price of a drug such as Miltown, the producer conceded today.
Scientists at the National Institutes of Health are pursuing the cosmopolitan mice of Harlem in search of clues about human cancer.
TRENTON, Jan. 27 -- Gov. Robert L. Meyner met with Democratic leaders here today to select an organization candidate for the party's United States Senate nomination.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Governor Rockefeller bluntly told Republicans here tonight that he was "seriously concerned about the future vigor and purpose" of the party.

In line with its declared policy of seeking a ban on all nuclear weapons tests that can be detected and controlled the United States has advanced, as one way of breaking the Geneva deadlock, a new plan for an approach to the problem.
PARIS, Jan. 22 -- Right wing students in Paris staged a miniature version of the Algerian uprising today as they barricaded themselves inside the Sorbonne's Faculty of Law in the Latin Quarter.
SPRING VALLEY, N.Y., Jan. 27 -- Rockland County's first public school program for trainable mentally handicapped children was pronounced a success today by Dr. Merrill L. Colton.
ALGIERS, Jan. 27 -- The general strike of Europeans has begun to alarm the administration here chiefly because of it effects on the Moslem population, whose food is immediately dependent on wages.
CHICAGO, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

DUNEDIN, Fla., Jan. 27 (UPl) -- Charlie Sheppard of Highland Park, Ill., and Duke Gibson of Kansas City carded 4-under-par 68's today to share the first-round lead in the Professional Golfers Association senior tournament.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- For hour after hour today non-Southern Democrats filled the nearly deserted House chamber with oratory in an effort to embarrass Republicans into joining their fight for a civil rights bill.

HAVANA, Jan. 27 -- President Osvaldo Dorticos Torrado flatly rejected tonight what he called the "insinuation" in President Eisenhower's statement yesterday that the friendship between Cuba and the United States could be destroyed by the intrigues of international communism.
Spokesmen for two major Manufacturers called on the nation yesterday to speed development of a supersonic airliner lest Russia score another technological "first."

The Alleghany Corporation, holding company that controls the New York Central Railroad, yesterday elected Alfred E. Perlman, Central's president, to its directorate. Mr. Perlman succeeds Mrs. Anita O'Keeffe Young, widow of Robert R. Young, former chairman of both Alleghany and Central.
The city must set aside 439,261,679 in the fiscal year beginning next July 1 to pay interest on its debt and amortize it, Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa estimated yesterday.

New facilities for the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center are "essential" for it to hold its place second to none in the combined field of teaching, research and medical treatment, Gen. Lucius D. Clay said yesterday.
CHICAGO, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Henry Hank of Detroit, a powerful puncher, scored a sixth-round technical knockout tonight over Jesse Bowdry of St. Louis.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Senator Estes Kefauver cautioned one drug company today that its pricing policies were inviting price control by popular demand.

Net operating Income of the New York Savings Bank was $2,430,566 in 1959 after payment of $10,330,945 in dividends to depositors, Richard L. Maloney, president, announced yesterday. This compared with $2,387,084 after payment of $9,626,954 in dividends the year before.

Are you considering getting a dog but delaying because you cannot make up your mind which breed to choose? The coming Westminster show, to be held in Madison Square Garden on Feb. 8 and 9, may help you reach a decision.
Sealed indictments were returned yesterday by the Brooklyn rackets grand jury charging six fuel oil dealers with conspiring with city inspectors to cheat consumers on deliveries.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Senator Stuart Symington charged today the Administration manipulated intelligence information about the military forces of the Soviet Union to permit balancing the budget.
Investigation Commissioner Louis I. Kaplan has opened another municipal graft inquiry.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 (AP) -- A Government report on stocks of grains in all storage positions on Jan. 1 caught soybean traders by surprise today and they took prices down sharply in a rush to adjust market positions.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is estimated that 25 to 30 million Americans are haled before traffic courts each year: also that 30 to 40 per cent believe that they have meritorious defenses. Acquittals occur in less than 1 per cent of contested cases, it is believed.
The bond market had another strong session yesterday, with prices moving up for fixed-income investments of all Kinds in response to broadened demand and more aggressive bidding.

MIAMI, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Clematis and Shuffle Off formed the biggest daily-double pay-off in Hialeah's thirty-five-year history today -- $3,126.30. Each horse won by three length Clematis paid $59.90 for $2 in the first race and Shuffle Off $78.70 in the second.

ABOARD U.S. CARRIER VALLEY FORGE, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The instrument-stuffed gondola from the world's largest balloon was fished from the Caribbean today, its plastic covering apparently heavily damaged by sharks but still in shape for another flight.
The problem of sponsor identification was subjected to close scrutiny in a study made public yesterday by Trendex, radio and television rating service.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 27 (UPI) -- The Merrick Stable's John William, a colt who has been improving with every start, today scored his third straight victory. He captured the $23,100 San Vicente Handicap for 3-year-olds at Santa Anita by a half-length.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- A report filed with the Legislature last summer charged that the favor of personnel in the Public Works Department was "aggressively" sought by engineering concerns seeking state contracts.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Jan. 27 -- Belgian and Congolese leaders agreed today that the Belgian Congo would become independent June 30.
Sales and earnings of the St. Regis Paper Company rose to new highs in 1959, the company announced yesterday in a preliminary report.

Electric power production climbed to another record last week. The Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday that output In the week ended on last Saturday came to 14,523,000,000 kilowatt-hours. This compared with 14,236,000,000 kilowatt hours week before.

J.P. Miller is recovering from the effects of a windfall experienced by him last week. Two full-length plays, written by the television dramatist and scenarist, who is an unknown quantity as far as Broadway is concerned, were sold then.

The Joint Economic Committee of Congress has released its conclusions on the vaguely comprehensive subject, "Employment, Growth and Price Levels." To put it more precisely, it has issued two reports, a nine-man majority report and a six-man minority report, and the supplemental views of three of the individual members.

The nation's supplies of light fuel oil, used mostly in heating homes, dropped an additional 5,901,000 Barrels in the week ended laat Friday, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end total Stocks were 132,638,000 barrels, against 138,539,000 a week earlier.

ONE afternoon last week a doctor left the sixth floor of the Museum of Modern Art with a Picasso lithograph in a shopping bag. The receptionist on the main floor smiled at the physician as he passed her desk. She observed the familiar lettaring on his brown paper bag: "Art Lending Service, Museum of Modern Art."
LONDON, Jan. 27 -- Trading in the stock market began on a confident note here today, but prices closed below their best on profit taking.

Interest In Weddings Declines The head of the house is reading in the society pages now tne announcements of weddings to come and of weddings-that-have-been (and at this season there are aplenty, midwinter ranking with June as a popular time for marriage) with less interest than he did some days ago.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : On Jan. 19 you published a letter from William R. Mathews, editor and publisher of The Arizona Daily Star, under the title "Communist Cuba Feared."
A subdued and surprisingly conservative Casey Stengel held his first news conference of the year in the Yankee offices yesterday.
ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- Governor Rockefeller sought public support for his highway safety program tonight in a state-wide telecast.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 27 -- A red carpet was put down to welcome Prime Minister Macmillan today to South Africa. He arrived by plane on the final stage of his journey through Africa.

The New York Board of Rabbis called yesterday for the elimination of sectarian religious material and "doctrinal teachings" from the public schools. The board termed such religious activity a violation of the principle of separation of church and state.
Houston, Tex., received bids yesterday on eleven issues of bonds totaling $9,800,000 for the financing of public improvements.
Fort seniors from Paramus High School in New Jersey -- which has no Negroes or Puerto Ricans among its 1,100 students -- left their classrooms yesterday for a lesson in intergroup education.
The Speedwell Society, Inc., will benefit from a performance by the Georgian State Dance Company from the Soviet Union.

Alf Pike, the New York Rangers' coach, said the other day that his fiery captain, Red Sullivan, needed rest. It was Alf's plan to use Red as a penalty-killer last night at Madison Square Garden; but without Sullivan, the Blue might not have gained a 2-2 tie with the Montreal Canadians.

A leading British banker yesterday offered one way for the United States to ease its balance of payments deficit of some $7,000,000,000 in 1958-59., Sir Oliver Franks, chairman of Lioyds Bank, said in his annual report that America "could not and would not" live with a deficit on such a scale for long.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 27 -- The Port of Buenos Aires was paralyzed today for the third time this month by a new fortyeight-hour stevedore strike. The Port Workers Union claimed a full stoppage by 6,000 men who handle the unloading and loading of vessels.
DENVER, Jan. 27 (AP) -- A young housewife said tonight She was "floored" when President Eisenhower answered a letter she had written to him.

A crisis of the magnitude that now faces France is a crisis of the West. To think of what might happen if the Algerian conflict is not settled -- a civil war, chaos, a long period of strife between France and the European settlers in Algeria -- is to recognize what a catastrophe could come to pass.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- Outright repeal of the forty-seven-year-old state law that requires railroads to provide specified numbers of workers on trains was recommended today by the Public Service Commission.
FORT LEE, N.J., Jan. 27 -- The North Jersey Playhouse, which has occupied the old Grant Lee Theatre here for three years, will move to the Steak Pit Restaurant in Paramus next month.

Two major Protestant magazines -- The Christian Century and The Lutheran -- said yesterday that they believed that Senator John F. Kennedy, if he were elected President, would be subject to restrictions imposed by the Roman Catholic Church.

FRED SCHMERTZ will attend the Olympic Games in Rome this summer. For him it will be an anticlimax because his emotions are so geared that any meat that follows his beloved Millrose Games automatically loses zest and appeal. He knows that this is not precisely in accord with the facts, but he can't help himself.
Students of Army engineering threw a bridge over "enemy" Water yesterday -- and saw it sink when the first man stepped on it.

TORONTO, Jan. 27 (UPI) -- Dave Creighton, a cast-off from the New York Rangers, scored in the third period and enabled the Toronto Maple Leafs to gain a 2-1 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks tonight.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 27 -- President Elsenhower declared tonight that "our country is over-all, the strongest power on earth, both militarily and economically."

A Brooklyn magistrate ruled yesterday that Gamble Benedict, the 19-year-old runaway heiress, was a ward of the court. He directed that she be paroled in the custody of her grandmother, Mrs. Henry Harper Benedict, pending a hearing on Feb. 26.
LONDON, Jan. 27 -- Of the seventeen white Britons attending the Kenya constitutional conference as delegates, only a handful can be described as diehard "white settler" types.

The latest report of insiders' activities published by the New York Stock Exchange showed another major sale of holdings in a sugar company operating in Cuba. Delta Development Corporation, listed as an owner of more than 10 per cent of the stock of Guantanamo Sugar Company, sold 90,000 shares of Guantanamo in December, re0ducing its holdings to 163,146. On Nov. 1, 1958, Delta owned 253,146 shares.
The Democratic State Committee taxed the Rockefeller Administration yesterday with clamping "the dead hand of inaction" on programs designed to assist the aging.

Governor Rockefeller's decision to grant non-residents essentially the same treatment as residents on their New York State income tax returns remedies an injustice of forty years' standing and should help to encourage the cordial relationship with New Jersey and Connecticut that is to be greatly desired in metropplitan problems.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Attorney General Rogers' devisement of a new law whereby appointees of Federal District Courts would become inspectors of violations of the right to vote in elections to fill state as well as Federal offices carries more benefits to more groups than is usual in a single legislative package.

PARIS, Jan. 27 -- President de Gaulle stood like a rock today against attempts to defeat or modify his policy of self-determination for Algeria. There was growing evidence of overwhelming support for his stand from the public in France.
LONDON, Jan. 27 -- Life in the United States as seen by twenty-five American critics was pictured to Britain tonight.

THE year's tournament results have been tabulated for the Far West -- formerly eleven states, reaching from the Pacific Coast eastward to Colorado; now thirteen states, with the accretion of Alaska and Hawaii.
More than 1,000 New York Athletic Club members and their guests paid tribute to the club's current national and Pan-American Games champions last night at a dinner in the N.Y.A.C. gymnasium.

In proposing a major strengthening of the Civil Rights Act of 1957, President Eisenhower's Administration has taken the curse off the almost casual approach to this subject he showed in his State of the Union Mesasge early this month.

EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Jan. 27 (UPI) -- A Minuteman missile, designed for an intercontinental range of 5,500 miles or more, was succesfully cessfully tested today in a tethered flight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- American officials worried today not merely about the fate of President de Gaulle's policy of self-determination for Algeria but also about the future of the French Government itself.

BOSTON, Jan. 27 (UPI) -- The Philadelphia Warriors maintained a 12-point lead through the second half tonight and beat the New York Knickerbockers, 129 -- 117, in a National Basketball Association game before 10,000 fans.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The cosmetics and color dye Industries were told in effect today that they might as well abandon their opposition to an anti-cancer provision in color additive legislation.

Dr. George N. Shuster, retiring president of Hunter College, accused television last night of cheapening the image of America here and abroad. He said the American shown by television was a "tape-recorded demonstration of banality."
Fordham University's basketball team snapped a six-game losing streak as it rallied in the closing minutes to defeat Long Island University, 62 -- 54, at Fordham's gymnasium last night.

The $250,000,000 World Trade Center proposed for the lower Manhattan waterfront was endorsed yesterday by James felt, chairman of the City Planning Commission, and by executives of business, industry and port development groups here and in New Jersey.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 27 -- Politics received a strong Hollywood flavor here tonight. The dinner honoring President Eisenhower was steeped as deeply in showmanship as in steak.
AMERICAN women are learning geography from the labels on dresses. The most exotic are from Asia and the newest one reads "Eliza of Kuala Lumpur." It should send a number of women scurrying to a map.

"Washington's Lady," a biography of Martha Washington by Elswyth Thane, will be published Monday by Dodd, Mead. It is a re-creation of the hidden drama of the private life of George and Martha Washington during their years of exile from home -- the eight years of the Revolution when Martha regularly wintered at headquarters and the two terms of the Presidency.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company told a Senate hearing today it had encountered "no unusual problems, tensions or difficulties' in pursuing a policy of racial and religious integration in its apartment projects.
Sales and earnings of the Hercules, Powder Company set new highs last year.
A real estate, agent who answered nineteen building inspection charges yesterday was served with ten summonses alleging 179 additional violations, some dating to 1955, as he left Housing Court.

ALTHOUGH Barry Morell's Faust is known to local operagoers from his City Center days, last night marked his first performance of the role at the Metropolitan Opera.

DALLAS, Jan. 27 -- Open warfare and Congressional investigations probably would follow if the National Football League moved into Dallas, Joe Foss, the commissioner of the new American Football League, said today.

EDISON, N.J., Jan. 27 -- Bernard (Barney) Coons, an award-winning photographer for The New York Daily Mirror, was killed here this afternoon when a car he was driving became sandwiched between two truck trailers on Route 1.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The Administration plans to speed the development of the superthrust Saturn rocket by a year in an effort to overcome the Soviet space lead.
