Laurence Harvey, the eager young status seeker of "Room at the Top," is not so enthusiastic about his current high status in the film world.
SANTA CRUZ, Calif., Jan. 27 -- A satellite engine hailed as promising the United States greatly increased agility in space exploration was unveiled today.
David L. Freed of Salt Lake City is the new non-playing captain of the United States Davis Cup team.
SEATTLE, Jan. 27 (UPI) -- Bob Madden, a 14-year-old Tacoma (Wash.) high school student, today staked a claim for a title with a first-round victory in the 1960 national figure-skating championships.
PARIS. Jan. 27 -- The army holds the key to the French crisis.
NORTH BRUNSWICK, N.J. Jan. 27 -- The possibility that the murder of four persons here yesterday was the work of a psychopath was suggested today by Warren W. Wilentz, Middlesex County Prosecutor.
The spirit of old Broadway touched briefly at the Plaza last night for the Rialto Ball.

TODAY marks the start of the Chinese New Year. It is the 4,658th year in the history of the Chinese people, according to the honorable moon calendar. According to Chinese legend, each year is named for an animal, and this is the Year of the Rat.
ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- A legislator from Levittown, L.I., moved today to insure that pupils in hard-pressed school districts would continue to receive free textbooks and milk.
PANDEGLANG, Indonesia, Jan. 16 -- "Saja mau pulang R.R.T.!" said the Chinese alien, fiercely.

GEN. PAUL ELY, France's top military commander, finds himself again today, as he did in May, 1958, in the difficult role of the link between civilian government and an army wavering on the brink of disobedience.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Federal investigators said today that two engines of the Capital Airlines plane that crashed near Holdcroft, Va., on Jan. 18 had been disabled and that the two others might have been working, in reverse.

In designing the Jet Airport proposed for Morris County, N.J., every effort will be made to minimize hardship for residents of the area, according to S. Sloan Colt, chairman of the Port of New York Authority.
Prices of cotton futures moved 4 points (20 cents a bale) up to 4 off yesterday. There was some Irregularity at the close on the New York Cotton Exchange.

The six-story building containing thirty-six apartments at 739-41 East Sixth Street, near Avenue D, has been sold by the Sabron Realty Corporation. On a plot of 45 by 90 feet, it is assessed at $75,000. It was purchased by the Zorac Realty Corporation for cash over mortgages amounting to $73,000.
QUESTION: When is a machine not a machine?
O. Roy Chalk, who tried unsuccessfully last year to buy the New York subway system, has offered to purchase the city's largest private bus company.

THE Moscow State Symphony gave its ninth and final Carnegie Hall concert last night. A sold-out audience greeted the orchestra, and there also was some activity outside the hall, where women of the World Brotherhood Foundation were passing around circulars that exhorted Premier Khrushchev to save Carnegie Hall.

BRISBANE, Australia, Jan. 27 (UPI) -- Margaret Smith, a 17-year-old Australian, upset Maria Bueno, the Wimbledon and United States champion, today in the women's singles quarter-finals of the Australian national championship.
BOSTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Dartmouth defeated Boston University, 90 -- 83, in a double-overtime basketball game tonight.
Bad news for steels and motors hit the stock market yesterday and prices continued their decline after another feeble attempt to rally.
Mayor Wagner has given the heads of thirteen city departmens until Tuesday to devise a "uniform program" to prevent corruption in their inspection services.

The net income of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation last year rose $11,175,000 above the 1958 level on a sales gain of $15,031,000, it was reported yesterday. In another development, the Westinghouse board declared a dividend, payable March 1, of 30 cents a share on the common, which was split two for one recently.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 (UPI) -- A veteran Chicago police lieutenant was discharged from the force today for touring Europe with the city's top gangster. A captain resigned rather than take a lie detector test.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The Administration, in a sudden change of tactics, sent its first team to the Capitol today to urge the repeal of a restriction on United States participation in the International Court of Justice.

Dr. William Jansen, formerly city Superintendent of Schools, testified yesterday in the departmental trial of two suspended teachers and denied that he had promised them clemency if they became informers.
PARIS, Jan. 27 -- Today the great house of Dior showed a collection that is already being acclaimed as one of the most beautiful, spectacular and youthful that the house has ever introduced.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The United States broke off today its negotiations with the Soviet Union on Moscow's wartime lend-lease debt.

Plans to show a West German television film that depicts the evils of militarism and Nazism have been dropped by the National Broadcasting Company after the collapse of negotiations with the German owners.
A spurt in new business in December helped the nation's machine tool industry to finish last year with a wide gain over its 1958 showing.
YESTERDAY Jan. 27, I960 THE PRESDENT At Los Angeles. THE SENATE Confirmed several nominations, including Livingaton T. Merchant to be Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs.

ROME, Jan. 27 -- The Synod now meeting here dedicated its prayers today to the "church of silence." This term was first used by Pope Pius XII to designate the clergy and other Roman Catholics who suffer silently in Communist-dominated countries.
CHICAGO, Jan. 27 -- Vice President Nixon advised all Republican candidates tonight to run on the Eisenhower record.
HOPEFUL, Ga., Jan. 27 -- Between turkey and quail, a hunter keeps going here from 5 A.M., when he gets up if he can, to about 6 P.M., when everything goes to roost. After that he is his own man.

Lawyers deeply Involved in commercial enterprises run increasing risks of being named as defendants when penalties are sought by Federal regulatory agencies, the general counsel of the Federal Trade Commission said here yesterday.

Trade buying, purchasing by Brazilian interests and short covering buoyed coffee prices yesterday on the Hew York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Profit taking and light hedge selling supplied the contracts. The B months rose 35 to 55 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 42,250 bags and the M. futures 37 to 55 points on 26,250 bags.
In recommending repeal of the railroad full-crew laws the Public Service Commission has handed the Legislature an election-year hot potato.
AN old Army game, played more recently at a Cats kills resort, saved a new variety series from complete disaster last night.

A Senate committee study the country's transported system and its problems has not been completed as expect. Even a preliminary report may not be ready before Congress adjourns, Senator Warren G. Magnuson, chairman of the Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee, said yesterday.

The recent trend of major New York City banks to move uptown from their traditional Wall Street area headquarters seems to leave the Irving Trust Company content to remain where it is -- at 1 Wall Street.
Senator Thruston B. Morton, Republican National Chairman, ridiculed Democratic criticism of the Administration's foreign and defense policies last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The boom in auto imports and the decline in exports have not cut the business of American auto manufacturers as much as the bare figures indicate, according to an analysis by the Business and Defense Services Administration of the Department of Commerce.

THROUGH a happily exploitable coincidence, the scene of John Hadfield's "Love on a Branch Line"* is called Arcady. It is a spot in rural England where a back-country peer of the realm lives in splendor on his own private railroad train to the stirring music of the American Jazz Age.

KARLSRUHE, Germany, Jan. 27 (UPI) -- A court trying a former German naval officer for treason was told today that Soviet intelligence had been able to build a complete picture of movements of senior naval officers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization with the defendant's help.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 20.

The heads of two additional New York City banks expressed the hope yesterday that bank lending rates would remain stable. But each observed that rates were set in a competitive environment and could not be held down if other rates should rise.

The life of the grand jury that indicted Manhattan Borough President Hulan E. Jack was extended yesterday to April 5 by General Sessions Judge Thomas Dickens. He acted after Assistant District Attorney James J. Fitzpatrick had said the panel would not complete its business by Feb. 5, when it was to have been disbanded.
Alexander L. Guterma and Robert J. Eveleigh were convicted yesterday of conspiring to defraud the United States by impeding the efforts of the Securities and Exchange Commission to protect investors.
THE three works on last night's program of the Clarement string Quartet at the Ninety-second street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association were connected in a strange way.

A builder testified yesterday that he cashed a $2,500 check the day before Borough President Albert V. Maniscalco of Richmond paid him $500 as the first installment on a $2,500 garage project at the Maniscalco home.
COLUMBUS, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey hinted today that he would not enter the Ohio race for delegates to the Democratic National Convention.
MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 27 -- Immediate expansion of the National Football League became a strong possibility today when the clubowners amended the league rule covering new franchises.

Charles Bruning Company The Charles Bruning Company, Inc., yesterday declared an increased quarterly dividend of 15 cents, payable on March 1. This is equivalent to 30 cents a share, compared with the 25 cents paid quarterly prior to the 100 per cent stock dividend of last Dec. 29.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 27 -- West Germany pledged its cooperation today in any United Nations study of the origins and purposes of recent anti-Semitic outbreaks.
DETROIT, Jan. 28 (UPI) -- American Motors Corporation today reported net earnings of $12,216,665, or $2.05 a share, during the three months ended on Dec. 31.

EXTRAVAGANTLY imaginative Richard Avedon, who has always done the utmost in fashion photography, has done it again. His latest impossible-to-believe achievement: Cape Canaveral as a fashion background.

ALGIERS, Friday, Jan. 29 -- Paul Delouvrier, French Delegate General in Algeria, called on Moslems as well as the Europeans of Algiers last night to rally to the support of President de Gaulle. He asked this help "without condition" toward an end of the insurrection by European settlers.

The Family Decides on a Car The head of the house strolled in the other day with an armful of the latest catalogues produced by the auto industry. Every member of the family took to the bait, and the mad rush was on.

Early buying of coffee by Brazilian and Colombian interests touched off stop-loss purchasing yesterday on the, New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Later in the session, profit taking caused prices to tumble.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The recent strength of the bond market was reflected today in the interest rates that the Treasury placed on a pair of new securities. As the prices of debt securities have risen, their yields have declined, to the extent that the rates on the two new Treasury issues were lower than had been expected as recently as a few days ago.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: One must always agree -- on the basis of its unmatched stature -- that The New York Times is a most responsible pillar of journalism. At the same time one must also recognize the fallibility even of The Times.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Jan. 28 -- A stolen car recovered in Newark caused the police to believe today that they might have an important clue in the murder Tuesday of four persons in near-by North Brunswick Township.
New York's "gray areas," blighted neighborhoods that have not yet sunk to slum depths, will get priority in a three-year study of the city's renewal needs and how to meet them.

Arizona State's Mal Spence from Jamaica, B. W. I., filed an eleventh-hour entry yesterday as the fourth starter in the Sheppard 600 of the Millrose Games. The competition tomorrow will open Madison Square Garden's five-meet indoor track schedule.

As David Merrlck's assistant, Eduard Fuller made himself useful in unraveling knots of fifteen shows done by Mr. Mervick. Now the 33-year-old Mr. Fuller, who resigned from Mr. Merrick's staff last Friday, feels he has absorbed enough knowhow from his indefatigable mentor to join the managerial ranks.
BEETHOVEN'S passionate commitment to freedom makes his only opera, "Fidelio," as timely as this morning's headlines and as timeless as man's highest aspirations.

Changes in the top management of the Irving Trust Company were voted yesterday by the board. George A. Murphy, president for the last three years, was named chairman. William E. Peterson, a senior vice president, was elected president.

MOSCOW, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The Soviet press reported today new crackdowns on certain Communist party leaders in the republics of Latvia and Georgia. Leaders in these republics were accused of such things as poor leadership in farming, of nationalism and conservatism.

ONE of the greatest frustrations to many homemakers is the suffering caused by the ennui of household chores. These housewives may have longed for a home of their own, but once in it, they would like to get out of it, at least once in a while.
CHICAGO. Jan. 28 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock' markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
The Hospital for Special Surgery and New York Hospital are about to reach a friendly parting of the ways.

CAMDEN, N.J., Jan. 28 -- A proposal to extend rapid transit into southern New Jersey from Camden and Philadelphia has been found practical by consulting engineers who were retained by the Delaware River Port Authority.

Baseball contract/signing may have descended to a level that is just about the lowest form of "cheesecake." Camera bulbs flash and there is no end of todo as the player affixes his signature to a blank piece of paper. Actually, no one ever sees the contract and the event really wouldn't be news at all unless the player took the contract and tore it up.
CHICAGO, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Grain futures dealings on the Board of Trade were confined mainly to soybeans today with prices again weak, but showing some signs of recovery at the close.

LEVITTOWN, L.I., Jan. 28 -- For the fourth time in the last eight years, an automobile involved in a collision roared twenty-four feet over the front lawn of the Howard Handlers' home here today and came to a stop inside the house.
HONG KONG, Jan. 28 -- Communist China and Burma signed a treaty of friendship and mutual nonaggression and a border agreement today.
Six Brooklyn fuel oil dealers pleaded not guilty yesterday in Kings County Court to indictments charging them with giving bribes totaling $7,550 to two city officials from 1956 to 1959.
Scientists have discover what may be the specific target in living cells -- a single gene location -- that cancer-causing viruses attack, according to a reoprt in a leading scientific journal.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 28 -- A series of inter-union meetings in the movie industry that could play an important role in deciding whether a strike ends production or not, has been started here.
A record expense budget was proposed yesterday by the Board of Education for 1960-61.

BRISBANE, Australia, Jan. 28 (UPI) -- Playing in 103-degree heat, Neale Fraser rallied twice today to defeat John Pearce of Sydney, 4 -- 6, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 8, 6 -- 2, in the Australia tennis championship.
PARIS, Jan. 28 -- The French Government ordered its civil and military chiefs in Algeria out of Algiers tonight to prevent their submergence by the settlers' insurrection against Paris.
The New York State taxes on cigarettes and tobacco may be listed as deductions in Federal income tax returns for 1959, the Internal Revenue Service announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- A Senate subcommittee investigating the tranquilizing drug business was told today that "certain medical groups," including the American Medics Association, had attempted to gloss over the problem of misleading advertising.
LONDON, Jan. 28 -- The stock market showed no decided trend here today and price movements were erratic.

Fur manufacturers were told last evening that the "shortage" of skins in recent months was "artificial" and they were urged, accordingly, not to pay too much or to buy more than their immediate needs.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Jan. 2f -- Congolese delegates urged Belgian officials today to set up a provisional government in the Belgian Congo before June 30 the date set for independence.
Governor Rockefeller's proposals for reorganizing the State Controller's office were endorsed yesterday by Frank C. Moore, a Republican and former state Controller.

Business loans at leading New York City banks declined $37,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, compared with a decline of $50,000,000 in the 1959 week, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York'reported yesterday.

Collins Aikman The Collins Aikman Corporation declared a 30-cent dividend on the common stock, payable on March 1 to stockholders of record of Feb. 16. This is 10 cents more than the previous quarterly payments.
DALLAS, Jan. 28 -- The professional football war is on and Texas is the battlefield.

For nearly a decade and a half there has been an International Court of Justice, under United Nations auspices. For many years before World War II began a somewhat similar body, authorized by the League of Nations, and called the Permanent Court of International Justice, also sat in the red brick Peace Palace at The Hague.

Charlie Scott of Philadelphia will seek to reverse his upset loss of six weeks ago to Benny (Kid) Paret of Cuba when the two meet in a scheduled ten-round welterweight bout at Madison Square Garden tonight.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange move irregularly yesterday to close points (25 cents a bale) up to points (35 cents a bale) off.

MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 28 -- The International Ladies Garment Workers Union voted today to pool the pension funds covering 100,000 of its New York members. The action by the union's general executive board represented the first step in a program designed to merge the retirement reserves protecting all its 420,000 members in the United States.
A defendant in a criminal case has the right to subpoena a member of Congress as his witness, Federal Judge Edward Weinfeld ruled yesterday.
The Active Members Group of the New York, branch of the English-speaking Union of the United States will hold its annual Commonwealth Ball this evening in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.
The Oyster Bay-Babylon (L. I.) Union Free School District 22 (Farmingdale) borrowed $4,255,000 in the bond market yesterday on serial obligations due from 1960 to 1988.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28 -- The appointment of the first Donner Professors of Science at five Eastern universities was announced today.

The ballroom of the Sheraton-East was aluminized last night as a reminder that the Animal Kingdom Ball was the tenth (tin or aluminum) annual event of its kind to benefit the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- In about two years, the Soviet Union may have enough missiles to mount a massive attack on the United States, Gen. Thomas S. Power, commander of the Strategic Air Command, said today.
LONDON, Jan. 28 -- The British Medical Research Council reported today an advance against the common cold. It consists of growing certain viruses from common colds in laboratory glassware.
Mayor Wagner yesterday approved a detailed report listing wide administrative changes in the Welfare Department.

The Western Union Telegraph Company has found another potential buyer for its international telegraph operations. The would-be purchaser is identified only as Barnes investing Corporation or Chicago. The agreed-upon price is $13,500,000.

WHEN Charlie Youghil died at the age of 80 his widow, Jessie, was not surprised that as her only prop for her own old age he had left her a shabby copy of a book that had been privately printed in 1827.
HAVING been absent without leave for six years the American Savoyards have returned to the Jan Hus House, where they opened with "H. M. S. Pinafore" last evening.

DUNEDIN, Fla., Jan. 28 (AP) -- Al Wntrous of Birmingham, Mich., won a five-way sudden-death play-off on the second extra hole today to take the Alfred K. Bourne Trophy. The trophy is awarded to the low scorer for thirty-six holes in the 55-and-up age group in the Professional Golfers Association senior tournament.
MOSCOW, Jan. 28 -- The Soviet Union and some of its Communist allies are reported to have discussed a peace treaty informally with East Germany.
THE recent Florida freeze has caused a price conflagration in the realm of vegetables. Most are up this week; not one is down.
A United States-flag tanker, in financial difficulty at a foreign port, has posed a problem for Washington.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Senate Humphrey of Minnesota made a complaint today against the particpation of high Defense Department officials in Republican political activities in this Presidential election year. He said this involvement was "unethical and beneath the dignit of the Administration."
A persistently strong market for fixed-income securities furnished inviting framework yesterday for the Treasury's February refunding of $11,363,000,000 of certificates of indebtedness.
Anyone who wishes to buy standardised horses may do so at Madison Square Garden on Nov. 28, 29 and 30.

MOUNT HOPE, N. Y., Jan. 28 -- The St. George Club rink from Montreal, skipped by W. E. (Ted) Thompson, successfully began defense, of the Ardsley Medal in the fifth annual Cuthbertson bonspiel at the St. Andrew's Golf Club curling rink today.
PARIS, Jan. 28 (Reuters) -- Following, in unofficial translation, is the text of a speech broadcast tonight over the Algiers radio by Paul Delouvrier France's Delegate General in Algeria:
LONDON, Jan. 28 -- The British Air Registration Board has delayed a certificate of airworthiness to the Boeing 707 jet airliners ordered by the British Overseas Airways Corporation.

The executive assistant to Borough President Albert V. Maniscalco of Richmond deposited $2,708.30 in cash on the same day -- Nov. 14, 1958 -- that the builder who erected a garage at the Maniscalco home cashed a check for $2,500.
Many American business concerns are doing more than just lending vocal support to the Eighth Olympic Winter Games, which open in Squaw Valley, Calif., on Feb. 18.
SUNNYVALE, Calif., Jan. 28 -- The command post of a worldwide network of launching, tracking and recovery bases for artificial satellites was dedicated today by the Air Force.
What assurance printed on a product has the greatest influence on housewives?
In a market afflicted more by lassitude than by any urge to sell, stocks on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday gave up about $3.200,000,000 of their aggregate market value.

Mae West, whose scheduled appearance on "Person to Person" was canceled last October by the Columbia Broadcasting System because it "might be misconstrued," will participate in a lampoon of the interview program when she appears on the Red Skelton show.
ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- Governor Rockefeller's proposal to provide $5,100,000 in income tax relief for nonresidents working in New York is regarded as virtually certain of enactment.
HOPEFUL, Ga., Jan. 28 -- There are too many ham actors around this place, and some of them are dogs. In fact, the Clark Gable of Riverview Shooting Preserve is a pointer named Mac.

HAVANA, Jan. 28 -- The attempt to overthrow the Trujillo regime in the Dominican Republic came from within that country, according to Dominican exiles living in Cuba. Hundreds have been arrested there, according to the reports they have received.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 28 -- The American Rocket Society was told today that the "tremendous admiration the people of the Soviet Union hold for American scientific and technical advances" was a key to future understanding and cooperation between Russia and the United States.
BOSTON, Jan. 28 (UPI) -- The American League is giving a week's head start to the National League this year and isn't happy about it.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Citizens' Committee for Children strongly endorses New York City Board of Education President Silver's request to State Education Commissioner Alien for a study of legislation which would change the State Education Law "to free the city's Board of Education from a morass of administrative detail."
Not-so-little Hofstra College in Hempstead, L. I., which cloud-walked through its first undefeated football season last fall, is coursing along at a, level almost as high in basketball this winter.

HOLYWOOD, Fla., Jan. 28 (AP) -- Tish Preuss and Patricia Hahn scored one of the biggest upsets in the fifteen-year history of the women's international four-ball tournament today, when they defeated the defending champions, Mrs. Marlene Streit and Mrs. Ann Casey Johnstone on the nineteenth hole.

IN the ordinary course, the borough presidency of Richmond provides a comfortable measure of personal distinction, the ease and security of $25,000 a year and a round of activities that would drive an impatient man to the brink of stupefaction.

Gamble Benedict, the runaway debutante, told a State Supreme Court Justice yesterday that she would continue to live with her grandmother and would not see Andre Porumbeanu "as long as he is married."
Fifteen of the city's voluntary hospitals are in such financial straits that they may have to close, hospital leaders said yesterday. And, they added, seven more cannot pay their bills.

TODAY Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson meets with representatives of lamb producers, processors and distributors and with consumer groups to discuss revision of standards for grading lamb. Those standards have been a subject of controversy for the last year.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 28 -- The loans to Indonesia announced today constitute the first major United States aid to the country since warm relations were restored between Jakarta and Washington. Ties had been strained following an anti-Jakarta rebellion that started in central Sumatra in February, 1958.
Earnings of the Standard Oil Company of California declined last year, the preliminary statement of R. G. Follis. chairman, disclosed yesterday.
TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 19 -- An American visitor here is likely to hear both praise and blame for the United States role in Iran.
MIAMI, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Bill Hartack's continuing role as the hero of Hialeah was short-circuited today as he was beaten on heavy favorites in the co-featured Matecumbe and Sanibel Purses.
WESTBURY, L.I., Jan. 28 -- Contracts with a potential of $18,000,000 in the next sixty-two years for leasing of the new Island Inn at Roosevelt Raceway were signed here today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The space agency put before Congress today its ten-year program for the exploration of space, leading to manned flight to the moon in the Nineteen Seventies.

COCHIN, India, Jan. 28 -- Hundreds of thousands of political workers were ready today for a week-end of door-to-door canvassing throughout Kerala in probably the bitterest election campaign in Indian history.
HAVANA, Jan. 28 -- Surprise and relief were expressed by many Cubans today over the sudden cessation of bitter attacks on the United States by the Cuban revolutionary Government.
Mayor Wagner is giving a final review to a blueprint for establishing a City Industrial Development Council to check the flight of business from New York and attract new industries.
A group of teen-agers listened to their elders tell them about the world yesterday, but when the day was done it was clear that most of them were already fending for themselves.
LONDON, Jan. 28 -- Britain announced today the further relaxation of controls on imports from the dollar area.
CHICAGO, Jan. 28 (UPI) -- The 60,000-member Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen broke off wage negotiations today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Rail and truck loadings of freight last week were well above the 1959 level, but below that of the preceding week.
For Henri J. Lesieur, the take-off of Air France's first Boeing 707 jet from Idlewild on Sunday will mark a particular milestone.
Repeal of the city's highly controversial 10-cent-a-ride tax icab tax was voted unanimously by the Board of Estimate yesterday, effective next July 1.

CONCORD, N.H., Jan. 28 (AP) -- The political climate grew warmer in New Hampshire today when the name of Senator Hubert H. Humphrey was entered for the primary election on March 8, challenging Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts.
MILWAUKEE, Jan. 28 (UPI) -- The St. John's basketbal team of Brooklyn rallied from a 3-point half-time deficit tonigh and beat Marquette, 69 -- 63.
TOKYO, Jan. 28 -- The Foreign Ministry accused the Soviet Union today of interference in Japan's domestic affairs.
PARIS, Jan. 28 -- "Revolution?" asked the French house painter in his streaked blue overalls. "Revolution against de Gaulle? Think, sir, that is out of the question."

WHEN a painter turns to sculpture, the change seems to produce better results than when a sculptor turns to painting. Fritz Bultman, an established painter, has been making sculptures for about nine years, but exhibits them now for the first time at the Gallery Mayer, 762 Madison Avenue, near Sixty-sixth Street.
The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said yesterday that its net income fell to $117,235,859, or $2.44 a share, in 1059, from $137,741,946, or $2.91 a share in 1958.

George E. Spargo has been dropped as assistant to the chairman of the Mayor's Committee on Slum Clearance. This was disclosed yesterday in the committee's quarterly report. No record of the action appears in the committee's minutes.

"Today the rhythm of our life is too quick. In the immensity of the sea alone in a small boat you meet again your personality. It is not true that we are nothing in this world, but we are less than we think we are.

Powder snow fell on most of the ski areas in the north country yesterday and snow riders began making plans for another busy week-end. Fine conditions were reported as near as the southern Catskills and all the way to the northern extremities of Canada's Laurentians.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- A picture of an aircraft carrier and an exchange of messages between two admirals were flashed between Washington and Hawaii today -- by way of the moon.

KANSAS CITY, Jan. 28 (AP) -- A bomb exploded here tonight outside a synagogue that recently was smeared with a swastika. No one was injured. The blast, heard within a radius of two miles, shattered windows of the Kehilath Israel Synagogue in a southeast residential section.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Legislation to repeal the law requiring a double loyalty oath of students aided by Government funds was submitted to Congress today. Early Senate committee action was indicated.

SOME ten months ago Jackie Jensen of the Boston Red Sox wrote a rather startling article for The Saturday Evening Post. The title was "My Ambition Is to Quit." That literary gem caused considerable muttering both on big league diamonds and on sidelines.
ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- The Board of Regents called on the citizens of the state today to banish racial segregation from New York's schools as psychologically unsound and socially unrealistic.

PARIS, Jan. 28 -- One of the most interesting things to watch in the couture is what happens to the bright young designers who made smash hits with their first collections. Do they keep it up? Do they go on to ever greater glory? Or after that one flash of triumph do they simply fade away?
Picket lines of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America ringed the eight East Coast yards of the Bethlehem Steel Company from Baltimore to Boston yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Department store sales in the nation last week were 8 per cent above the year-ago level.

Average member bank borrowings declined by $141,000,000 to $773,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Reserves in excess of requirements dropped $283,000,000 to $293,000,000.

One of the world's leading astrophysicists proposed yesterday that the material that formed the planets was originally sorted into two great bands by the rival forces of gravity and magnetic repulsion.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 28 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister Macmillan of Britain described the United States today as "a reluctant debutante in world affairs."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Informed sources reported today that Generalissimo Rafael Leon das Trujillo Molina, dictator of the Dominican Republic, had broken up the largest conspiracy yet attempted against his rule.

MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 28 -- Immediate expansion, regarded as hopeless ten days ago by some National Football League owners, became a reality tonight. By a vote of 11-0, with the Chicago Cardinals abstaining, the league admitted the Dallas Rangers.
Scientists of West and East Germany have agreed to joint representation in the International Union of Geodesy and Geophysics, Prof. J. Tuzo Wilson, president of the union, said yesterday.
The way was cleared yesterday for the New York Hospital Cornell Medical Center Foundation to receive the first part of an $11,000,000 bequest by Anne Parrish, the novelist.

YESTERDAY (Jan. 28, 1960) THE PRESIDENT In California. THE SENATE Began consideration of proposed Constitutional amendment outlawing poll taxes.
SEATTLE, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Carol Heiss of Ozone Park, Queens, took a commanding lead among senior women today in the national figure skating championships.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- Talks on terms for the independence of Cyprus ended tonight after Britain, in a final attempt to win Cypriote agreement, had offered to triple her financial aid to the infant republic.
PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Jan. 28 -- President Eisenhower began a four-day golfing holiday today in the warm desert country in the lee of the Santa Rosa Mountains.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 28 -- West Germany is seeking from its allies the right to veto any Berlin agreement they may reach with the Soviet Union.

Making all due allowance for the political aroma of President Eisenhower's speech at a Republican fund-raising dinner in Los Angeles, one cannot pass unchallenged his optimism on the subject of American education. "Time and again," said the President, "we hear spurious assertions that America's * * * educational * * * efforts are deficient."
In dull moments at night in some outlying areas policemen in radio cars have been known to use salty language over the air and have even taunted the Commissioner.

Harrison E. Salisbury, who for five years had been barred as a correspondent from the Soviet Union, returned to a "new" Russia last year. Based in Moscow, he traveled 30,000 miles, Including a trip to Outer Mongolia and two trips to Siberia.
CHICAGO, Jan. 28 (AP) -- A family separated by the Iron Curtain for more than fifteen years was united in Chicago today, through the intercession of Soviet Premier Khrushchev.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The Roman Catholic hierarchy in the United States called upon Americans today to protest privately and publicly against further manifestations of racial and religious hatred.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- A pilot-investigator today disputed reports that propellers may have been pitched at a dangerous angle on two engines of a Capital Airlines Viscount that crashed with fifty aboard near Holdcroft, Va., on Jan. 18, None survived.
GARUT, Indonesia, Jan. 13 -- A small placard on the bedroom wall of a Chinese alien tells of a Communist dream for Asia. It is a dream that terrifies Indonesians.
Four leases of office and shop space in the new Time and Life Building, Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue) and Fiftieth Street, were announced yesterday by Rockefeller Center, Inc.
A former technical and trade school became the city's newest four-year college yesterday.

Yesterday the stock market continued its descent to new low prices for the year, an almost daily performance sine the year's start. But the most active stock traded -- Allis Chalmers -- moved against the trend, closing at 395/8, up 3/8 point, on a volume of 49,000 shares.
SAN DIEGO, Jan. 28 (UPI) -- Mason Rudolph, a Clarksville Tenn., pro, shot a nine-under-par 63 today to take the first round lead in the 72-hoIe $25,00 San Diego open.

ONE of the mass magazines is engaged in investigating the leisure-time activities of its readers. It sends a questionnaire to a "sampling" of these readers and one of the questions it asks is, "Do you play contract bridge (never) (seldom) (occasionally) (regularly) (often) ?"
MOSCOW, Jan. 28 -- The Soviet Union has charged that the new Japanese-United States security pact is directed against Moscow and Peiping.
Plans to increase the coverage on individual airline passengers by 20 per cent without an increase in premiums were announced yesterday.
DETROIT, Jan. 28 (UPI) -- Jean Beliveau took over the scoring lead in the National Hockey League and Henri Richard scored two goals tonight as the Montreal Canadiens beat the Detroit Red Wings, 4-2.
WATERBURY, Conn., Jan. 28 -- A privately sponsored interracial housing project is being planned for a thirty-seven-acre site near the Waterbury Country Club.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported the following spot primary market prices for the dates shown:
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 28 -- Anti-Semitism was condemned for the first time today by an organ of the United Nations.

A riot raged for thirty-five minutes on Central Park South at the Avenue of the Americas yesterday afternoon as pro-Castro and anti-Castro Cubans disputed the right to honor the birthday of Jose Marti. Cuba's national liberator.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The log jam on civil rights legislation in the House of Representatives gave signs of breaking today.
ONE of the more exotic operatic productions of recent years was given last night at Hunter College by the Manhattan School of Music.
Two Democrats prominent in 1960 Presidential speculation charged the Eisenhower Administration last night with a leadership failure.
CHICAGO, Jan. 29 -- Mayor Richard J. Daley of Chicago is in serious political trouble.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Jan. 29 (AP) -- A pair of Tennessee team-mates scored a 1-up victory over Tish Preuss of Pompano Beach, Fla., and Patricia Hahn, Wilmington, Del., today and gained the semi-finals of the women's international four-ball golf tournament.

CONCORD, N.H., Jan. 29 (AP) -- Senator John F, Kennedy's backers reported today what they described as a signature scandal that apparently will force two of the Senator's three Democratic rivals out of New Hampshire's Presidential primary.
LONDON, Jan. 29 -- Government securities took over the running from industrial shares in the stock market here today. They scored gains of up to 7s 6d ($1.05) on persistent small buying.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Jan. 6 -- Caduceus, a 9-year-old champion pacer, will compete in the Interdominion championship at Sydney, Australia, in February before three Americans on a talent search for a horse for an international race at Yonkers Raceway.
LEONARD BERNSTEIN was back on the podium with the New York Philharmonic at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon. In his four-week absence the music of Mahler had been the main business of the orchestra.
Boris Karloff and George Rose will join Hugh Griffith and young Richard O'Sullivan In a television version of "Treasure Island" on Saturday, March 5.
HAYWARD, Calif., Jan. 29 (UPI) -- Billy L. Smith, whose nearly severed right leg was sewn together last July in an unusual feat of surgery, will lose the leg.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court agreed yesterday that Magistrate Anthony E. Maglio should be censured but not dismissed as a result of his handling of a case in Brooklyn Felony Court on Oct. 27.

If religion has a proper influence on a man's life, it is "an inescapable element in the evaluation of his competence for political leadership," the dean of the Andover Newton Theological Seminary said yesterday.

The early history of New York was recalled last night at the tenth annual dinner and ball of the St. Nicholas Society. The event was held in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza and was attended by many descendants of the city's founders.
IF Gloria Davy's voice had been the only attractive part of her Town Hall recital last night that would have been cause enough for praise.
The bitter feeling between the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America and the Bethlehem Steel Company grew yesterday.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 29 -- A 30-year-old former mental patient was released today as a suspect in the murder of four persons last Tuesday in near-by North Brunswick Township.
MIAMI, Jan. 29 -- A pair of internationally famous racers grass will be among the contestants in the $25,000 Bougainvillea Turf Handicap at Hialeah tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Officials in Washington were following France's Algerian crisis today with concern.

BRISBANE, Australia, Jan. 29 (UPI) -- Jan Lehane, 18 years old, and Margaret Smith, 17, set up the youngest final round in the thirty-eight years of the Australian national tennis championships today when they scored upset victories in semi-final matches.

The United States Court of Appeals threw out yesterday its decision of last Nov. 2 that ruled invalid a 1955 stock repurchase agreement between the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad and a New York-Chicago banking group.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Jan. 29 -- The Socialist trade unions began a twenty-four-hour strike today throughout Belgium in an effort to force the Government to put through a program of social and economic laws.
TRIVANDRUM, India, Jan. 29 -- Three days before its elections the Indian state of Kerala presents an odd combination of turbulence and peace.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 29 -- There are strong indications in Hungary today that the Communist regime of Janos Kadan is planning to deemphasize the police and other repressive organs of the state.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I want to reassure the head of one of our largest advertising agencies that his client's product can indeed, shave sandpaper. I know, for I have made the experiment.

Last night at the City Center the New York City Ballet restored to the repertory, and in very good form, Todd Bolender's grimly hilarious strip cartoon of the days just before World War I, entitled "Souvenirs."

ALLENDALE, N.J., Jan. 29 -- The four-man police force in this small borough in northern New Jersey is not going to waste time and money on drunken driving charges unless court procedure above the local level is changed, Police Chief Robert D. Wilson Sr. declared last night.
CHICAGO, Jan. 29 -- The American Medical Association said today that it had a new written code to clarify its advertising standards for its Journal and ten other related specialized publications.
MOSCOW, Jan. 29 -- Nikolai I. Belyayev, formerly first secretary of the Communist party in Kazakhstan, was demoted today to leadership of the party in the Stavropol region.

THE Ernest Hemingway 1 play, "The Fifth Column," was very substantially rewritten last night in A.E. Hotchner 3 adaptation presented over Channel 2. The main pity was that Mr. Hotchner did not go considerably further.
Benny (Kid) Paret of Santa Clara, Cuba, absorbed the hardest punches of Charlie Scott and fought back to win a split decision in their ten-round fight at Madison Square Garden last night.
PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Jan. 29 -- Mrs. Dwight D. Elsenhower will not accompany the President on his goodwill tour of four South American countries next month, the White House said today.

Several hundred business men went looking for a business yesterday. A good many of them were so anxious to see what was available, that they Were waiting for the doors to open at the Coliseum at noon and the five-day Start Your Own Business Exposition to begin.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (UPI) -- A Congressman told the chief of the nation's space agency today that the United States space program might "suffer tremendously" from his refusal to give Congress information on some contracts.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 29 (AP) -- All America Oscar Robertson of Cincinnati tonight missed by 4 points in his effort to set a three-year college basketball scoring record. But his 29 points were the big punch in a 64-43 Cincinnati victory in a game kept to a snail's pace by the Citadel.
LANSING, Mich., Jan. 29 -- Michigan is planning to issue about $200,000,000 in bonds during the next two years to maintain its $1,250,000,000 five-year highway program schedule.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (UPI) -- Organized crime costs the public $22,000,000,000 a year, J. Edgar Hoover reported today.
The maritime industry was warned yesterday not to depend on the United States Treasury for finance solutions to its problems.

Members of the American Ballet Theatre will be honored as part of the celebration during their twentieth anniversary year at a reception to be given Wednesday.It will be held at the New York Public library's Fifth Avenue building by the library's Committee for the Dance Collection.

On the basis of preliminary estimates the country's national income in 1959 appears to have reached the $400 billion level for the first time on record. This would represent an increase of approximately $34 billion, or more than 9 per cent, over the previous high of between $366 and $367 billion first attained in 1957 and matched in 1958.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that prices received by farmers for crops and livestock increased about 1.3 per cent during the month ended on Jan. 15.

DALLAS, Jan. 29 -- Wise money in this citadel of money established Atlanta as the favorite today to beat Oakland in the race for the eighth and last franchise in the American Football League. In the end, though, the winner probably will be the city backed by the league's anti-trust lawyers.

"The Last Voyage," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer color entry with Robert Stack, Dorothy Malone, George Sanders and Edmond O'Brien, and the Swedish-made "A Lesson in Love," described as the first romantic farce by Ingmar Bergman to be shown in this country, have been booked as forthcoming attractions at local houses.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 28 (AP) -- Investigation of the bombing of a synagogue disclosed today the existence of a neo-Nazi youth party in two Kansas City high schools.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Senate investigators brought out today that Ciba Pharmaceutical Products, Inc., charges retailers $39.50 for a drug it has sold to the Government for 60 cents a thousand.
The embryonic Continental League, which aims to become baseball's third major circuit emerged from its cocoon yesterday.
It may be only the second th of winter, but yesterday was a fine harbinger of ing. The circus was back in news.

DUNEDIN, Fla., Jan. 29 (AP) -- Battling a blustery wind and a bad cold, Charles Farlow of Greensboro, N.C., shot a brilliant six-under-par 66 for his second round today to take a two-stroke lead at the half-way point in the twenty-first annual Professional Golfers Association seniors tournament with a 138 total.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- A proposed Federal program to aid in the commuter crisis caused a split today between eastern railroads and those in the West and South.
The first "package" shipment of equipment for an Army anti-aircraft battalion is on the high seas today bound for missile sites in Germany.
HOPEFUL, Ga., Jan. 29 -- Here is a boy, 10 years old, who owns a private covey of about fifty wild, native quail and can hunt them any time he wants to, and he thinks he has troubles.
HANOVER, N.H., Jan. 29 (AP) -- The dean of the Dartmouth College Medical School was killed and six persons were injured in a two-car crash last night.

"Thy Will Be Done,"the autobiography of Arthur Wilson, a Protestant Episcopal minister, will be published by Dial Press on March 15. It is the story of a modern clergyman who found himself torn between his devotion to his God and his love for a woman.
LONDON, Jan. 29 -- A white member of the multiracial New Kenya Group cautioned today against turning the Government of Kenya over to "an uneducated electorate."
MAYOR RICHARD JOSEPH DALEY of Chicago is a man with a tendency toward overweight and an explosive temper. He fights an endless, frequently losing, struggle with syntax and pronunciation.
Commuters must assume a more responsible role in the rapid transit crisis, Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey warned here yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 29 -- Representatives of Asian and Africans nations debated today the possibility of seeking United Nations action in the Algerian outbreak.

General Steel Castings Consolidated net income of General Steel Castings Corporation for 1959 slumped to $2,018,499, or $2.48 a share, from $2,232,709 and $2.75 a share in 1958. Sales declined to $39,432,527 from $39,535,449.
The police averted a near-riot in Harlem early yesterday when they rescued a young hit-and-run suspect from an angry crowd.

NATHAN MILSTEIN, 55 years old and looking under 40, gave a Carnegie Hall recital last night that was sold out, with an overflow audience on the stage. It was a distinguished audience, with seemingly half of the musicians in New York in attendance; and it was a wildly approving audience.
C.B.S. president drew attention to his network's programing, with particular emphasis on public service presentations and their increase on the network.
ALGIERS, Jan. 29 (Reuters) -- Algiers' civilian population stocked up canned foods today with the feeling that "anything can happen" in the settlers' revolt against President de Gaulle.

There were new skies for New York last night at the American Museum-Hayden Planetarium, with 9,800 sharp and brilliant stars, plus a view of the year 13,000, when the North Star will be lost to mariners.

Edward Durell Stone, architect, has purchased the five-story limestone residence on a lot 25 by 100 feet at 7 East Sixty-seventh Street, near Fifth Avenue, from Joseph L. Ennis Co., realty operators. The house contains twenty rooms and an elevator.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Sharply Increased imports in December, and in 1959 as a whole, cut the United States export-import trade surplus to the narrowest margin since World War II.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Kenny Sears and Richie Guerin, scoring 47 points between them, led the New York Knicks to an easy 128-113 victory over the Cincinnati Royals tonight.

Offerings to the public of new stocks in January were the smallest in three months and below the level of a year ago, but flotations of bonds rose to the highest figure since October. They were the heaviest for any January since 1958.

WESTFIELD, N.Y., Jan. 29 (AP) -- Two crack New York Central passenger trains sideswiped early today at a track crossover near here when one train failed to stop at a signal. None of the 470 passengers was injured seriously, but four required hospital treatment and several were treated at the scene for minor cuts and bruises.
The smashing of a multimillion-dollar narcotics ring that had operated in the metropolitan area for five to ten years was announced yesterday by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.
STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 29 -- Mayor J. Walter Kennedy announced the signing today of an agreement between the city and two private sponsors for a $10,000,000 redevelopment project.
PARIS, Jan. 29 (Reuters) -- Following, in unofficial translation, is the text of a radio-television speech made tonight by President de Gaulle:

Laboratory tests nave turned up the first traces of fire on the body of Julian Andrew Frank, the New York lawyer who was killed in the crash of a National Airlines plane in North Carolina Jan. 6, informed sources revealed yesterday.

Conservation and Our World Seldom have men acted in concert and in time to preserve from destruction some aspect of their world's natural wealth. Consequently, much has been lost that could have been saved.

The visit of thirty New York union leaders to the Consolidated Edison atomic generating plant, now being built up the Hudson, calls attention to a story of automation that everyone should know -- especially leaders of management and labor.
BUFFALO, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Airman 1/C Bruce C. Barwise was lifted from Lake Erie today, after three days in an Air Force survival capsule. He said he "could have stayed a lot longer."
Federal Court permission was given yesterday for a group of Wall Street traders to foreclose mortgages on two American vessels.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Efforts to get a Senate vote on anti-poll tax measures were brought to a standstill today by Southern opponents.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- A two-hour closed meeting today between a New Jersey delegation from Congress and the Federal Aviation Agency failed to solve the question of where to build a fourth airport to serve metropolitan New York.
General of the Army Douglas MacArthur was admitted to Lenox Hill Hospital yesterday for what an Army spokesman called an examination for a urological condition.
LONDON, Jan. 29 -- The Government is thinking of giving the British an extra hour of drinking time.

SAN DIEGO, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Four golf pros, including the first-round leader, Mason Rudolph of Clarksville, Tenn., were tied for the lead today midway through the $20,000 San Diego open. Each posted a 36-hole 135.

Broadway's best friend and customer is James Joseph Myers. A white-haired, straight-backed, six-foot-tall man of 65, he attends the theatre every night and often during afternoons. But what is more remarkable about Mr. Myers' playgoing habits is that he will see a show for as many as twenty-four times.

A spokesman for the Dominican Liberation Movement said yesterday that leading members of the professions and the business community in the Dominican Republic were among those arrested as plotters against the regime of Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina.
ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- State Controller Arthur Levitt said today he was backing compromise legislation to grant home rule powers to more villages and all towns in the state.
GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Jan. 29 (AP) -- A judge upheld today the validity of a will giving most of a $4,500,000 estate to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York.
CHICAGO, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Grain futures on the Board of Trade ended the week under renewed selling and with most of the near contracts weak.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29 (UPI) -- There were 37,800 traffic deaths in the nation in 1959, an increase of 800 over 1958, the National Safety Council reported today. However, the mileage death rate was the lowest in its records, it added.

THE annual cruise tournament of the Greater New York Bridge Association, held this year on a Caribbean cruise of the Nieuw Amsterdam, ended yesterday. The ship, which left New York Jan. 15, is due back this afternoon.
Four men were indicted yesterday on charges of bribery and conspiracy in obtaining auto drivers licenses.

Thirty-four Presbyterian ministers will emplane tomorrow night on a goodwill mission to Puerto Rico. During an eleven-day visit each clergyman will live in the home of a Puerto Rican Presbyterian minister. The visitors will preach from their hosts' pulpits, pray with their parishioners and visit their friends.
CARMEL, Calif., Jan. 29 (AP) -- A life-saving artificial kidney that can operate continuously without human monitoring was introduced today to the medical profession.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- A radar system patented this week is intended to prevent a pilot from being misled by the reflection of a distant mountain range and crashing on a nearby peaK. Karl F. ROSS of New York, the inventor, was inspired by press reports of night accidents in which conventional radar did not give warning of a solitary crest in the airplane's path.

The five-story building containing forty apartments and occupying a plot 79 by 157 at 101 Linden Boulevard, corner of Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, was purchased by an investing client of Lawrence H. Levinson, lawyer.
The first all-container steamship cargo service in foreign trade began yesterday in Port Newark, N.J.

John W. Kimble, suspected as scofflaw, has been in jail for '.2 months because he could lot raise the $2,500 bail. But yesterday the authorities said that Mr. Kimble had been the innocent victim of a man who had used his chauffeur's license in it was stolen in 1957.
TUNIS, Jan. 29 -- The Provisional Government of the Algerian Moslem nationalist movement instructed the Algerian Moslem population today to stay aloof from the French in the turmoil in Algeria.
The Treasury's terms for refunding $11,363,000,000 of debt due on Feb. 15 slid smoothly into the yield structure of the Government bond market yesterday.
The growing business in odd lots of Treasury securities has become so great a processing problem to Government bond dealers that they are resorting to deferred deliveries.

American Enka Corp. The American Enka Corporation ordered a 25-cent dividend on the common stock, payable on March 18 to holders of record of March 4. Earlier payments wer 35 cents each in June, September and December, when a year-end dividend of 75 cents was also paid.
A live homemade bomb was found in a locker in Grand Central Terminal yesterday.

IRON MOUNTAIN, Mich., Jan. 29 -- America's top snow fliers, headed by eight eager members of the United States Olympic squad, will take part in the National ski-jumping championship on Pine Mountain's eighty-five-meter hill tomorrow.

Adlai E. Stevenson, who has been an Illinois district delegate to the last several Democratic conventions, disclosed yesterday that he was being replaced this year by "the president of a corset-makers' union."
Still with no sign of undue excitement or pressure to sell in the market yesterday, prices on the New York Stock Exchange moved to the lowest level since April 2 and closed at the low since April 10.

A SMALL-BONED dark-eyed woman, who never changes the color or style of her hair, is making sure that other women do. She is Rosie Carita, one of two Spanish sisters who have been deciding what human heads will look like for the last several years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) Pro football's quarrel over rights to play in Dallas and other cities was described by Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, today as a private battle and not one for Congress to settle.

AFTER weeks of hearings In which individuals and organizations critical of television have had their say, the Federal Communications Commission is now receiving the testimony of the heads of the networks.

PARIS, Jan. 29 -- Today the Paris spring fashion collections ended for the fashion press but not for the manufacturers and store buyers. Still to come Monday night and Tuesday morning are the two most important of all, Givenchy and Balenciaga.

ALGIERS, Jan. 29 -- The French Army took the first step tonight toward pulling the teeth of the five-day-old insurrection by Europeans here. The move came soon after the broadcast of a firm speech by President de Gaulle in which he refused to alter his policy of self-determination for Algeria.
Little known to the outside world and even to the French public before the present crisis, Maj. Gen. Marcel Gracieux was reported yesterday to be looked on in Algiers as a key man in that crisis.
PARIS, Jan. 29 -- The words were strong but their primary force came from the power of the personality of the man who spoke them.
A report that Brazil had been stymied In its error to form a world cocoa price stabilization pact with African producing nations sharply depressed futures on the New York Cocoa Exchange yesterday.

Twelve Government administrators from the Soviet Union landed here yesterday for a goodwill visit after a twelve-hour nonstop flight from Moscow. Shortly after they arrived some of them were engaged in an "amiable debate" with Governor Rockefeller about political systems.

A formal request for $700,000 in budget funds to create a long-projected corps of police cadets was made yesterday by Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy. He proposed that 250 cadets be appointed at the outset.
SEATTLE. Jan. 29 (AP) -- Carol Heiss of Ozone Park, Queens, won her fourth consecutive women's title tonight in the national figure-skating championships.
Lieut. Gen. Jean Albert Emile Crepin, the commander of central Algeria, has the reputation of being a tough, no-nonsense general.
New 4-cent stamps are now circulating around the nation with what looks like the famous signature of George Washington but isn't.
The City Hall door was virtually closed last night on any possible new appointment of Robert F. Mahoney to the Magistrates bench. His term as a Magistrate expired last Dec. 31.
TRENTON, Jan. 29 -- A bullet fired through the window of a train as it sped through North Philadelphia this afternoon struck a passenger in the head.
By tracing outward leaks in the electrically charged layer of the upper atmosphere, a space physicist has drawn a new picture of the earth's environment as far as 40,000 miles out.
A state inquiry yesterday subpoenaed specific files of city Investigation Commissioner Louis I. Kaplan after its chief counsel had charged that Mr. Kaplan "has not been doing his job properly."
Mayor Wagner held out hop yesterday for more city fund for voluntary hospitals fo treating Indigent patients.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Average wholesale prices at the primary market level rose 0.2 per cent to 119.5 per cent of their 1947-49 base during the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 29 -- Communism is in the midst of another virulent campaign against Chancellor Adenauer. As usual, the only visible effect has been to add starch to the aged West German leader's posture.
The Public Service Commission directed the Consolidated Edison Company yesterday to prepare a comprehensive cost-of-service report on all of its electrical rate classifications.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- The National Union of Railwaymen, the largest of the three unions on the nationalized railroad system, announced tonight that it was calling a country-wide strike effective Feb. 15.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Dr. Henry T. Heald's address at the United Parents Associations annual luncheon on Jan. 9, and recent newspaper articles regarding New York City schools, impel me to take issue with Dr. Heald and to comment upon fiscal independence.
Two meet records were set and one tied last night as Andrew Jackson High of Queens won the team title in the Mayor's track meet at the 102d Engineers Armory.
GLEN COVE, L.I., Jan. 27 -- Five ordained ministers of the Church of Christ are heading a volunteer labor battalion of laymen that is erecting a church on a three-acre site here.
With John Thomas and Don Bragg in the spotlight, Madison Square Garden's five-meet indoor track and field schedule will open tonight with the fifty-third annual staging of the Millrose Games.

PLANNING a meal around a pickle might seem bizarre, but it is not altogether far-fetched. There are many shops in New York City with ample supplies of pickled walnuts, one of the most unusual of relishes. Although they are little known on this side of the Atlantic, they have had a long and deserved popularity in England -- one of the principal sources.

BUFFALO, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The International League put an undisclosed price on its Buffalo and Toronto territories today, and agreed to discuss their acquisition by the Continental League with Branch Rickey tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Eleven farm groups took to the White House today their plea that the Administration curb the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare in his handling of chemicals and drugs used in agriculture.

PARIS, Jan. 29 -- A threat of national disaster has again forced most of the major French political parties to band together behind President de Gaulle and his policy of self-determination for Algeria.
MIAMI, Jan. 29 -- Brisk offshore winds are expected to greet a record fleet of forty - three yachts when the twenty - sixth annual Sir Thomas Lipton Cup race gets under way at 10 A.M. tomorrow.

AS a shopping area, Greenwich Village is changing all the time. Some of the newest and most charming shops can be found in one block on West Tenth Street. This intriguing area is bordered on one side by Sixth Avenue, on the other by Greenwich Avenue.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Democratic Senators cited a secret intelligence briefing today to support their forecast of growing Soviet missile power.

The market for new capital is slated to continue at a moderate pace next week. Major fixed-interest securities ready for marketing aggregate some $85,000,000. Two, major stock issues will add about $10,000,000 to next week's total.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that his administration was continually strengthening its defenses against unethical behavior by city employes.

BOSTON, Jan. 29 (UPI) -- Louis J. Heydt, 54-year-old actor, collapsed and died tonight after having played the first scene of "There Was a Little Girl," in which he appeared opposite Jane Fonda, daughter of the actor Henry Fonda.

DETROIT, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Ward's Automotive Reports said today the auto industry in the United States would break all previous January production records by turning out 691,400 passenger cars this month.

Senator Hubert H. Humphrey said yesterday that the "limited" campaign started here in his behalf about two weeks ago was gaining such momentum that his supporters were now talking about the possibility of running some delegates in the New York primary next June.

His short, unambiguous, forceful speech clears the air. It was a necessary antidote to the frighteningly weak and emotional appeal of the French Delegate General in Algeria, Paul Delouvrier, on Thursday.
The stock market In January experienced the greatest loss for any January in the history of The New York Times combined average of fifty representative stocks.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 29 -- A series of new rebuffs met Caryl Chessman today in the convict-author's newly joined battle to avoid the gas chamber exactly three weeks from now.

TRWIN SHAW'S "Two Weeks in Another Town"* brings together the spirit of prewar Hollywood and the spirit of postwar Rome. This is not least among the unhappy marriages that clutter Mr. Shaw's galvanically sad new novel.

Marvin Grafton, whose belligerent ballets on the rubber strip have earned him the reputation of being one of the best high school foil fencer in the city, is a 17-year-old Forest, Hills senior with the smile of a cherub and the strength of a water buffalo.

MOUNT HOPE, N.Y., Jan. 29 -- The No. 2 rink of the Schenectady Curling Club, skipped by Ernest Corrado, eliminated the 1959 winners from the St. George Club of Montreal today from the main event of the fifth annual Cuthbertson bonspiel.
ABAKALIKI, Nigeria, Jan. 29 -- Cannibalism, which had been believed extinct in Nigeria, had a brief surreptitious revival in late December.
Bandits shot down two armed guards in an armored truck and escaped with a payroll of $23,937 at the door of a Brooklyn factory yesterday morning.
It has been said -- and it bears saying again -- that America dotes on statistics.

MARVIN CHERNEY'S paintings at the Washington Irving Gallery, 49 Irving Place, are melancholy, compassionate studies of people he has encountered. There are pensive children, a Second Avenue waiter, a rabbi and various aged people -- all described with a modest, sometimes hesitant, brush.
A TALENTED, impressive and expensive quartet took over the "Bell Telephone Hour" on Channel 4 last night. Short of a phone rate increase, it was worth it.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 1 point (5 cents a bale) off to 11 points (55 cents) up. The new crop months showed the most strength.
