With mutual funds now serving as a medium of investment for pension plans, some concern has arisen as to how they should be supervised at the state level.

ONE of Germany's most amusing writers, Georg Christoph Lichtenberg (1742-1799) is almost unknown in English-speaking countries. He was long due for a renaissance, and here it has arrived. Both volumes at hand try their utmost to do justice to the physicist who made fun of bungled experiments, the astronomer who delighted in women's fashions, and the satirist who, at heart, loved people.
The writer of the following letter was legal adviser to our embassies in South and Southeast Asia in connection with the economic and technical assistance programs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The United States has a stockpile of sophisticated new weapons ready to try out if its present moratorium on nuclear tests should be called off, the Atomic Energy Commission hinted today.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Jan. 30 -- Congolese leaders insisted today that they must have independence without reservations. But several expressed themselves in favor of a link between Belgium and the Congo after the Congo gains independence June 30.
GERTRUDE STEIN was pleased to say that everything was the same and everything was different. What she meant by that depended on where and when she said it.
PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 30 -- Princeton's hockey squad Scored five goals in the first twelve minutes tonight and held on to trounce Northeastern, 9 -- 3, before 1,000 fans at Baker rink.

Looking like any serious business men with briefcases, twenty accountants with the New York Stock Exchange are in reality super-sleuths. Their job is to examine the books of member concerns without notice once a year.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Ch. Marbelane's Citation, a Kerry Blue terrier owned by Patrick Corless of the Bronx, took best-of-breed honors on the opening day of the forty-seventh annual Maryland Kennel Club show.

SOME of the most imaginative settings and costumes ever devised for a television production will be on view Wednesday night when Shakespeare's "The Tempest" is presented on the National Broadcasting Company network.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 30 -- Community tensions were reported rising this week in North Beach, often labeled the national capital of the Beat Generation.

American exporters are beginning to find themselves in a position long familiar to their European counterparts. It is one of constant uncertainty and bafflement over tariff policies affecting a major market.
TO THE SPORTS EDITOR: I disagree both with Arthur Daley and with Gen. Garrison H. Davidson (whose letter you printed last Sunday), concerning the trend toward two platoon football.

THE late John Marlowe had been an ornament to the English bench. He proved even more of an ornament to English letters when, after his retirement, he wrote "Crossroads," a profound philosophical summation of the human condition.
Paul Richards Bunker, director of the Munich office in Germany of the American Committee for Liberation, died there yeterday of cancer. He would have been 65 years old tomorrow.

ROBERT YOUNG and Eugene B. Rodney, star and producer, respectively, of "Father Knows Best," are trying to decide what is best for their future. They are threatening (what! again?) to abandon a television show that after six years still places consistently on the "Top Ten" list of the Nielsen ratings.
The stock market underwent another sharp setback last week, with the averages plunging to their lowest levels in ten months.

THE grandiflora rose always has puzzled me. I never really have understood how it differs from a hybrid tea or floribunda. I never am sure I recognize it when I see it. Since other gardeners usually are equally puzzled, the problem, seemed worthy of perusal.
The weather is raising hob with the nation's utilities.
The City Commission on Intergroup Relations announced yesterday that it was stepping up its activities to combat "dangerous forces of religious bigotry and racial intolerance."
LONDON, Jan. 30 -- In what we like to think of as the piping times of Victorian peace, the Czar of all the Russias announced to his staff: "Gentlemen, saddle your horses; France is a republic again."

THE Italian novelist and short-story writer, Alberto Moravia, has always been preoccupied with the darker human relationships. Never has he depicted them more disturbingly than in "The Wayward Wife," a collection of seven short stories and a novella, originally written between 1927 and 1948.

Rockefeller's Budget Tomorrow Governor Rockefeller submits to the New York State Legislature his budget for the fiscal year starting April 1. The Governor has already said his budget would not exceed last year's record $2.1 billion budget and that he would not ask for new taxes or tax increases.

MlNEOLA, L.I, Jan. 30 -- A 20-year-old electrical worker who had admitted kidnapping and raping a young mother in Hempstead on Jan. 9, surrendered to the police today and was committed to a mental hospital for observation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- As the debate raged this week over the Administration's revised intelligence estimates one of the private service journals published by coincidence an Army officer's appeal for more intelligence agents.
BOSTON, Jan. 30 -- The forty-seventh dog show of the Eastern Dog Club began its two-day run today with 115 dogs fewer than last year. The totol was 1,044.

IN his sensitive foreword to "The Spirit's Pilgrimage," the great correspondent and Indophile, Vincent Sheean, calls this autobiography of Madeleine Slade "a story with terrifying undertones and dark, concealed approaches, but touched into glory now and then by the pure shimmer of hope."
HAVANA, Jan. 30 -- As a successor to its Yuletide "friendship airlift," the Cuban Tourist Institute announced today a new plan to attract American tourists for the carnival season beginning Feb. 6.
FOR THIS WEEK: Save brush trimmed from ice-damaged trees and shrubs for staking tall annuals and perennials this summer. They make good marshmallow toasting sticks for evening cookouts. . . .
VIENNA, Jan. 30 -- Prominent Anstrians are making an effort to restore something of Vienna's former glory as a creative center of culture and science.

RADIATION DETECTOR -- A new type of radiation detector was described last week at the meeting of the American Physical Society by the Hughes Aircraft Company of Los Angeles. Dr. Stephen S. Friedland of the Hughes Nuclear Electronics Laboratory, who demonstrated the device, known as a "solid-state radiation detector," said it "promised important applications in nuclear physics, space exploration, military operations, civil defense, medicine and industrial processes."
Charles Fairchild Fuller, an architect here and in Stonington, Conn., died Friday at St. Luke's Hospital of a heart attack. He was 63 years old.

A BAD memory and a good digestion are the only recipe for a contented life. That was the comfortable conviction of Maxwell Arbuthnot, a stout pillar of Edinburgh society, an eminently respectable and wealthy lawyer rising 61. Actually his memory was excellent, but he was blessed with the power of swift forgetfulness.
Edward J. Moylan has been picked for one of the most prized coaching posts in tennis.

For Ages 10 to 14. IT is a very thin partition indeed that separates the best so-called juvenile science fiction from most examples of this literature now being produced for the adult market. One can only ascribe this to the growing sophistication of young readers and to the accelerating world in which they live.
The President's Diary President Eisenhower made a revelation at his recent press conference that rings familiarly in many minds -- he had once tried to keep a diary but had given It up.
The Pepsi-Cola Company will mark a decade of resurgence with the dedication tomorrow of its new world headquarters here.

A group of Soviet Government administrators who visited New York University yesterday lectured university officials and the two or three students they could find about the asserted superiority of the Soviet educational system.
The direct selling industry, the oldest form of salesmanship, whose genealogy in this country began with the pre-Revolution Yankee peddler, is enjoying its greatest prosperity.

IT usually requires a fairly experienced craftsman and a well-equipped workshop to build a desk, a combination storage cabinet, or a multipurpose wall unit. However, home handymen can actually build these projects with only a few simple tools -- and with little or no cabinet making skill required.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 30 -- Lee Petty of Randleman, N.C., and Marvin Panch of Daytona Beach, who drove new Chrysler Valiants, led a field of compact cars today in a prelude of tomorrow's international races here for these small cars.

A youthful squad of women golfers was named yesterday as the 1960 United States Curtis Cup team. Six of the seven who will oppose the British at the Lindrick Golf Club, Worksop, England, May 20-21, are under 30 and three are newcomers to international competition.

To the Music Editor: IN Howard Taubman's article on Carnegie Hall it was stated that "engineers assert that acoustics are now a science." The inference is that the acoustics of Carnegie Hall were a matter of happy coincidence.
TRIVANDRUM, India, Jan. 30 -- Police units from three nearby states have been summoned to Kerala to prevent violence in the state-wide legislative election Monday.
The writer of the following was formerly chief of the documentary film unit office of United States Military Government for Germany.

THE smaller new suburban homes demand a different planting approach from the three-story mansions of turrets and bays of a bygone era. Modern plantings must be scaled to smaller proportions and designed for easier upkeep.
John Thomas attained a new peak of human endeavor last night.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- A number of officials and experts in finance have concluded that the present system of international payments and reserves needs a major overhaul to avert serious trouble.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The strategy of Senator John F. Kennedy's campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination, which he is unfolding more and more, is an adroit combination of pitched battle and psychological warfare.
Herbert L. Spencer, executive director of the Samuel H. Kress Foundation, died Friday night in his apartment at 345 West Fifty-eighth Street. He was 65 years old.

THE central fact about these light verses emerges with prosaic certainty from the author's prefatory acknowledgment. He says they (and some 800 others) were written during the last seven and one-half years "under pressure of a newspaper deadline."

SOMEONE has said that a writer who would be really good must, in the revelation of his material, run the risk of being boring. This novel opens by taking that risk, slowly describing a particular vacation spot and the lives of some of its people.

NEW DELHI. TOMORROW, in the long, narrow state of Kerala, in southwestern India, more than seven million voters will choose between Communist rule and a stanch anti-Communist coalition led by Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's All-India Congress party.

MORE THAN PRIZES -- "Essay contests are educationally undesirable." This statement of policy was recently released by the American Association of Secondary School Principals to crystallize the general discontent of teachers and administrators with a publicity technique which "almost always supplants effective instructional techniques."
Former Magistrate Robert F. Mahoney said yesterday he was "surprised" by the finding of two bar associations that he was not qualified for reappointment.
GOEDGEGUN, Swaziland, Jan. 30 -- Prime Minister Macmillan received his warmest reception in southern Arcia when he arrived today.
Cigar store Indians are among the carved figures that will be auctioned on Friday and Saturday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

MIAMI, Jan. 30 -- Noble Sel, owned by Dr. Frank Recio of Coral Gables, Fla., won the Bougainvillea Turf Handicap today. Under a competent ride by George Gibb, Noble Sel scored by a neck over Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Herff's Tudor Era. Amerigo, owned by Mrs. Tilyou Christopher, finished third, a neck ahead of the 60 to-1 shot, Sindon.

HERBERT WENDTS "In Search of Adam," a history of modern man's search for his ancestors, was published in the United States in 1956. Now, in "Out of Noah's Ark," Mr. Wendt has turned to the story of man's efforts to find and describe his animal companions here on earth.
When labor unrest stirs in some section of the city's economy, often one of the first persons aware of it is the Rev. Philip A. Carey, director of the Xavier Institute of Industrial Relations.
THE dollar may not go very far these days, but 125 of them will take an American tourist all over Western Europe, and then some.

The exact nature of the motions of the constituent atoms of water is still largely unknown. In fact, the structure of all liquids is only dimly understood -- specifically the motions of Individual atoms, which are believed to be the true cause of such properties as fluidity and resistance to compression.
LONDON, Jan. 30 (UPI) -- A Soviet scientist issued an unusual statement today cautioning against the hazards of space flight. But he said the problems were not beyond solution.
A cooperative apartment development in Queens has special kitchen appliances designed to save time for working couples.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 30 -- First Landing survived a claim of foul today and captured the $166,490 Santa Anita Maturity by a half-length. It was his biggest victory since he won the Garden State Stakes two years ago as a juvenile.

SOME mystery novelists, once they have become successful In the "straight" field, forget their origins and leave their former fans hungry and desolate. But Van Wyck Mason, despite the success of his historical novels, continues to satisfy us, if too infrequently, with the pyrotechnic exploits of Col. Hugh North, of which the latest (and one of the best) is SECRET MISSION TO BANGKOK (Doubtoday, $3.95).
Six factory workers in the Ford assembly plant at Mahwah, N.J., were accused yesterday of taking $100,000 worth of automobile parts in the last two years.
Dr. Arthur Larson, consultant to President Eisenhower, urged last night that the International Court of Justice at the Hague be expanded into a complete world-wide legal system.
The New York Knickerbockers gave fits to 10,367 fans before staving off a last-period rally and whipping the Philadelphia Warriors, 115-108, at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

ON his favorite subject, the cinema, Francois Truffaut, the writer-producer-director of the French drama, "The 400 Blows," is almost as articulate as he is intense. The 28-year-old Parisian paid his first visit to this country to collect the New York Film Critics' award for his first feature film, judged the best foreign-language production of 1959.

At least six major port areas in northeastern Brazil are undergoing extensive Improvements to facilitate the increasing volume of ocean-going freight handled there. The ports are in the region of the easternmost bulge of Brazil, southeast of the Amazon delta.

Last week marked the publication of the most violently critical attack on the established system of public education since the launching of "Education and Freedom" by Rear Admiral Hyman G. Rickover a year ago. The new book is "The Future of Public Education" by Myron Lieberman, and Its sub-title, in a polite understatement, calls it "an unorthodox diagnosis -- and some startling proposals for reform."

PARIS, Jan. 30 -- France is a country beset by crises this week-end. There is even one in harness racing. It involves Jamin, possibly the world's greatest trotter; his owner,, Mme. Olry-Roederer, the boss of champagne millions, and stubborn, 29-year-old Jean Riaud, the horse's trainer-driver.
Challenge to de Gaulle "France," Charles de Gaulle has said, "cannot be France without greatness."

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- Hugh Gaitskell and his followers, termed "the so-called bright boys of the Labor party," were subjected to bitter attacks today for proposing to de-emphasize nationalization in the party's Constitution.

A ghostly witness stood by last week as the United States Government put an end to recently revived negotiations intended to settle the twelve-year-old dispute about Uncle Sam's $10,800,000,000 of lendlease aid to Russia in World War II.
The Presbytery of New York is expected tomorrow to nominate Its moderator, the Rev, Edler G. Hawkins, for moderator of the General Assembly of the United Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A.

WASHINGTON. AMERICA may have made more lasting and valuable contributions to the art of government than its unique system of Presidential primaries, but none, I think, that is more revealing of our national character. We like our politics to contain a maximum amount of entertainment and a minimum amount of -- well, politics.

ATLANTA, Jan. 30 -- The approach of the Deep South'a first showdown over school desegregation has stirred widespread concern here because of the accompanying threat to the continuance of public education.

MY name is Mike Kane and I covered the Cuban Revolution for the Taft chain of newspapers. Our man in Havana is Jack Brett, the bureau chief, and this is Margaret Ames. 29, his Girl Friday. It wasn't long until she was my girl, period.

PARIS. "THE RHINOCEROS," which opened at the Theatre de France (formerly the Odeon) on Jan. 22, is Eugene Ionesco's thirteenth play. It was ten years ago that his first, "The Bald Soprano," was performed at the Theatre des Noctambules with three persons in the audience on opening night.
ST. PAUL, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Tom Augustitus of Detroit captured the first-day lead in the national outdoor speed-skating meet today, threatening the long reign of Ken Bartholomew.

Late in 1907, in a speech before some 100 prominent Los Angeles business men attorneys clergymen and their wives, Lincoln Steffens, the journalist and an authority in his day on municipal corruption, was asked to give not a superficial view of corruption, but to get right to the basic roots of the evil.

The figure 8 has a dual role in January's statistics. The passage of the month means that 8 per cent of the year has gone by. And, in the passing, January has registered an 8 per cent gain In retail sales volume over the 1959 figure.

FOR the adventurous, one of the calamities of this swiftly shrinking world is that daily there remains a little less to discover, much less to explore. And the chances of individual adventure -- with the riches that should attach to such enterprise -- are now almost entirely whittied away.

A BLUE, green and orange-brown 4-cent stamp emphasizing "the importance of water conservation" is promised by Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield for release on April 18. The firstday sale will be in Washington.
PARIS, Jan. 30 -- For France and the world the Fifth Republic was shown this week for what it is -- a single man on whose strength or weakness everything depends.

ROME, Jan. 30 -- Palmiro Togliatti, leader of the Italian Communist party, made clear today that the party would concentrate its efforts in the future on conquering at least a part of the Italian middle class.
The Port of New York has lost a seventy-year-old client -- the Prince Line.

EARLY this spring, at several New York hotel auditoriums, an extraordinary scene will take place. A score or more of celebrities, representing such varied occupations as acting, writing, science and mountain climbing, will seek to demonstrate to audiences composed of several hundred clubwomen their acceptability, on the 1960-61 circuit, for the ladies and gentle art of lecturing.

The rate at which bank customers used their checking accounts, called the demand-deposit turnover, decreased in December by 1.5 per cent from the November level in New York City, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UPI) -- The House Government Information subcommittee disclosed today a new refusal by the Navy to give information to Congressional auditors.

TO THE SPORTS EDITOR: It has been called to my attention that the story carried in your Jan. 17 edition listing the 1959 All-America collegiate soccer team noted the first team choices Huryn and Pintz were members of the Penn soccer squad.

WHEN Samuel Beckett's "Krapp's Last Tape opened in a double bill at the Provincetown Playhouse on Jan. 14, everyone appeared to be pleased. To judge by random, comments, everyone has been pleased since.
REGINA, Sask., Jan. 16 -- The search for helium in southwest Saskatchewan has been growing rapidly, sparked by a discovery of the gas last summer.

ALAN MOOREHEAD has put me in a quandary. He has written a book so good that any praise of mine seems inadequate. He writes with such strange brilliance that he evokes the color and scents of the African scene with tremendous power; more than any other book I have read on Africa this one made me feel I was sharing the experiences with the author.

IT may be that February in Paris will be more conducive to hard negotiations over the proposed reduction of International air fares than were the rustlings of the palm trees of Waikiki at the fare meeting held in Hawaii last October by the International Air Transport Association.
An outstanding performance in the epee division lifted Princeton to a 16-11 fencing victory over City College yesterday at the loser's gym.

TO THE EDITOR: William K. Zinsser's "A Walk Among World's Fair Ghosts" (Jan. 17) evokes considerable nostalgia, but his ghosts are indeed unconcerned with corporeal matters if they do not recall that Dali's girlie show was entitled "Dali's Dream of Venus" in 1939 and "20,000 Legs Under the Sea" in 1940, never anything as mundane as "Bottom of the Sea."

Companies supplying most the oil products to the milllons of motorists and other consumers east of the Rocky Mountain will go on trial tomorrow in Tulsa, Okla., for violation of the Federal antitrust laws. The are charged with conspiring to raise prices on crude oil and refined products.
Eight students at the University of the Dominican Republic in Ciudad Trujillo were shot dead Friday while demonstrating on the school's grounds, a Puerto Rican student reported yesterday in San Juan.

TO THE EDITOR: Gilbert Millstein's essay on tips. "Who Tips What and Why," (Jan. 10), the latest in a rash of articles on the question of tipping, leaves a somewhat distorted picture of the position of the waiter with respect to the tipping system.
Francis Anthony Jamieson, a principal political aide of Governor Rockefeller, died yesterday morning in New York Hospital at the age of 55. He lived at 522 East Eighty-sixth Street.
Add motels to the list of uses to which abandoned motion picture theatres can be converted.

CROSS - COUNTRY motorists aren't exactly singing "three cheers for the red, white and blue" this winter. Those are the colors of the route markers of the new interstate highway system, and since the markers began to appear in various parts of the country in recent months, many drivers have found the new signs more confusing than helpful.

IN "A Heritage and Its History," Ivy Comptcn-Burnett has written another of her modern Greek tragedies. Not that it (or any other of her novels) is modern in the sense of being strictly contemporary in setting and atmosphere.

LAS VEGAS, Nev. -- Unabashed and virtually unadorned, this desert retreat from reality has moved, with a clattering certainty, from the Fabulous Fifties into what it confidently expects will be the Super Sixties.
Western analysts devoted much time last week to evaluation of the 1959 economic reports issued almost simultaneously last week-end in Moscow and Peiping.

ORDINARILY, the exhibition of fifty-nine works of art purchased by various people from the Museum of Modern Art's Lending Service, an exhibition that opened Wednesday, would warrant only an appreciative paragraph or two in this column.

Department store sales in the nation in the week ended on Jan. 23 were 8 per cent above the 1959 level, the Federal Reserve Board has reported. In the preceding week sales were 3 per cent above the year-ago level.

An extensive building program being undertaken by the Young Men's Christian Associations in the United States and Canada is demonstrating that institutional structures, when designed and planned with imagination, can be as attractive as the best of modern architecture.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Ninety years ago, in the Fifteenth Amendment to the Constitution, this country established the principle that no citizen should be denied the right to vote because of race or color.

Two Americana Influential in painting a few decades ago but not seen much recently are brought back in shows opening this week -- George Overbury Hart at the Zabriskle Gallery, 32 East Sixty-fifth Street, and Arthur B. Davies at the Graham Gallery, 1014 Madison Avenue.

To the Travel Editor: The Port Tobacco-Mulberry Grove-John Hanson story, "Reviving a Potomac Port," in the Jan. 24 Travel Section was incorrect in stating that John Hanson, a native of Port Tobacco, Charles County, Maryland, was unanimously elected President of the Continental Congress.

NONE of the wives of famous Civil War figures lived more obscurely than Frances Adeline Seward, the girl from Auburn who married William Henry Seward when he was establishing himself as a young lawyer in upstate New York.
Keepsake A COUPLE of weeks ago in the paperback supplement, we were saying that rabid paperback collectors have a name for the hard-cover version of the same title. It is "Keepsake Edition."

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Jan. 29 -- Emperor Haile Selassie appealed today to the leaders of the big powers to keep the governments of lesser powers "fully informed" on their discussions during exchanges of visits and at the coming summit conference.
UNITED NATIONS. N.Y. Jan. 30 -- Global commerce in grains -- exclusive of rice -- rose sharply in 1959 as compared with 1958.

A leading Roman Catholic layman will deliver the principal address in the Chapel of the Four Chaplains in Philadelphia at a ceremony next Sunday honoring Rabbi Maurice N. Eisendrath for his "pioneering efforts in bringing about closer ties amongst Protestants, Catholics and Jews."

Spring business began opening up last week for resident buying offices. Good-size reorders, following the initial requests on apparel shown this month in the spring market, were received, buying offices reported.
The eighth Winter Olympic Games at Squaw Valley, Calif., may run into heavy snow after the first five days if the longrange weather predictions of Dr. Irving P. Krick are realized.

PARIS, Jan. 30 -- Eight Deputies of the conservative Independent party, which is deeply split over the policy of self-determination for Algeria, announced today their support "without reserve" for last night's speech by President de Gaulle.
DETROIT, Jan. 30 -- The Michigan Legislature, worn down by an eleven-month tax battle last year, wag handed a balanced budget this week by Gov. G. Mennen Williams.
General of the Army Douglas MacArthur was reported last night to be in "serious but not critical" condition in Lenox Hill Hospital.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 30 -- The search for the slayer of four persons Tuesday in near-by North Brunswick has settled down to a plodding investigation of details.
Mayor Wagner will not contest the right of the Nelson commission to obtain the file of a city investigation into the affairs of Borough President Albert V. Maniscalco of Staten Island.
LONDON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The British Broadcasting Corporation reported today that Hungarian authorities executed 150 teen-agers last month for having taken part in the 1956 anti-Communist uprising.

A bid for fiscal independence, on an optional local basis, was made last week by school officials from the five largest cities in New York State. This has reopened the debate over the desirability of granting such independence to local schools.
Fritz Kreisler, who will be 85 years old Tuesday, will make a trip to City Hall to receive a scroll and a medal from Mayor Wagner and Cardinal Spellman.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 30 -- A New Jersey Public Utility Commission order directing the New York Central Railroad to resume passenger service on its West Shore Division has railroad representatives bewildered.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The Army's new rifle, the M14, a versatile weapon capable of firing faster than a machine gun, was issued this week. It is expected to replace four weapons.

TO THE EDITOR: STOYAN CHRISTOWE, who reviewed "A Day in Spring" by Ciril Kosmac, expresses surprise at learning that Caporetto is now Kobarid, and is in Yugoslavia, not Italy. After having been alerted by this discovery, he should have checked his other facts.
A new heating system for garden apartments, using individual units in each suite instead of a central system in each building, has proved successful in a test in Westchester.
Preliminary data indicate the free world last year increased somewhat its industrial production lead over the Communist bloc.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Jan. 30 -- Members of the Woman's Club of Great Neck have announced plans for a benefit concert to be given in the clubhouse on March 1 by members of the Blue Hill Troupe. Proceeds will help to raise funds toward the furnishing of the Interfaith Chapel to be constructed at the United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point.
BOULDER CITY, Nev., Jan. 30 -- This is the silver anniversary year for the dam that some call Hoover, some call Boulder, but all call blessed.
WASHINGTON. During 1960 and for the next several years there will be a substantial increase in international activities in rehabilitation services for the handicapped.
TRENTON, Jan. 30 -- When the annual State Planning Conference is held here Tuesday, the problems of metropolitan north Jersey will be high on the agenda.
DURING the darkest days of World War I two foundation stones of abstract art were laid, Dada in Zurich in 1916, and, the next year in the Netherlands Neo-Plasticism, better known as "De Stijl."

For Ages 11 to 16. WITH "The Story of Yankee Whaling," The American Heritage Junior Library series goes down the ways in fine style. This is not, of course, a brand new subject for young people -- recently we have had Henry Beetle Hough's "Great Days of Whaling" and Brian O'Brien's "Scrimshaw and Sudden Death" -- but we have not had anything so luxuriously illustrated.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va. -- The dead of winter in this revived Colonial town might almost be described as cheerful. True, the gay gardens are dormant, and the deep green of boxwood and magnolia stands out sharply against a serene landscape.
The Lotos Club, a men's club devoted to promoting and developing the arts and professions and to encouraging their practitioners, is ninety years old this year.
Increasing numbers of company executives are being moved from one part of the country to another, and their frequent moving is said to have resulted in several changes in the construction of homes.
As self-operated elevators in office buildings are coming into increasing use, passengers are wondering more and more what makes them tick.

A temporary discount on rents, patterned after the oneday sales often used by retailers, has been offered at a large Brooklyn apartment project as a new approach to meeting the keen competition that now prevails in residential construction in Brooklyn and Queens.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Jan. 25 -- Israel is planning to overhaul her economy to prepare for the impending loss of some of her major financial props.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 31 (AP) -- New York State dogs won three of the top six prizes tonight at the close of the Maryland Kennel Club's forty-seventh annual dog show.
A physician will become the thirteenth president of Amherst College, a liberal arts institution at Amherst, Mass., on July 1.

From Mayor Wagner's viewpoint, it is fortunate that New York City is not in desperate need of major financial help from the Legislature this year. Recent scandals in his Administration and the new criticism of its operations by the Nelson Commission appear to make such help a political impossibility.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 31 -- With a 154-foot effort in an extra third round Sherwood won the President's Cup today and completed a sweep of the Telemark Ski Club's "triple crown."
People who underpay their taxes by whim or by Will may be undone by the Treasury at costs ranging from a dime to thousands and thousands of dollars.
Political pressure for the allocation of shipbuilding contracts will not sway the Maritime Administration Administrator Clarence G. Morse has declared.

NEW CITY, N. Y., Jan. 31 -- Hockland County has opened a fight for state tax relief. It points to the burden put on the Rockland tax structure by the reduction of tax assessments on large areas acquired by the state, for parks and other purposes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The Administration's new proposal for court-appointed referees to help Negro voting in the South was endorsed today by Senator Jacob K. Javits -- but with an important condition attached.
PACKANACK LAKE, N. J., Jan. 31 -- This lake community's Ice Rescue Patrol has been having one of its busiest years, with twelve rescues since the skating season got under way.
MOSCOW, Jan. 31 -- Communist party leaders of the East European countries are gathering in Moscow for what is advertised as an agricultural conference.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UPI) -- The Federal Trade Commission has issued nine more complaints charging members of the record industry with bribing disk jockeys to push recordings of their songs.
MANY city folk have been concerned with our water supply lately. We have finally been assured that, if not pure as driven snow, it more than meets the standards of the Public Health Service.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 31 -- Steel output at the highest level for a six-month period in history is virtually assured. Order volume and steel demand continued at record levels last week. There have been no signs of any let-up in the pressure for regular and in inventory steel needs.

For thirty-five minutes the Modern Jazz Quartet brought a high level of taste, imagination and intelligence to a jazz concert at Town Hall on Saturday night that was otherwise lacking in these qualities.
Kenneth N. Dayton has been elected to the board of the Northern States Power Company, Minneapolis. He is vice president and general merchandise manager of Dayton's, department store, there.
