WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The theory that an explosive caused National Airlines crash in North Carolina Jan. 6 is gaining strength.

ALGIERS, Feb. 1 -- The end of the insurrection today was dramatic by its very quietness. No bands played as the remnant of Pierce Lagaillarde's beaten men climbed in Indian file through a gap they had torn themselves in their paving block-and-rubble barricade.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 1 -- Auguste de Schryver, Minister of the Belgian Congo, appealed to Congolese leaders here today to support the colonial administration in maintaining peace. His appeal followed new violence in Katanga province.

MOSCOW, Feb. 1 -- The Soviet Government announced this evening that it had given a United States automobile dealer an exclusive franchise for the distribution of 10,000 Moskvich cars in the United States in the next two years.

On his seventeeenth birthday last Saturday, Bob Barnek scored 21 points in a televised high school basketball game. His personal triumph was marred because his school, Fort Hamilton, lost, but the game was a high point of the season in which his public image finally caught up to his private dream.

GEORGE SZELL and the Cleveland Orchestra gave a Carnegie Hall concert last night that qualifies as one of the season's memorable events. They were abetted by Ernst Haefliger, Swiss tenor, who was making his New York debut and by Maureen Forrester, Canadian contralto, whose singing was something to treasure in its own right.
TULSA, Okla., Feb. 1 -- The trial of twenty-nine companies representing a major segment of the oil industry began today in a courtroom filled almost entirely with lawyers.
An actual demonstration of how to convert brownstone rooming houses to modern apartment buildings will be un- dertaken by the city this summer.
This is Lou Cordileone Day in Jersey City. The Clemson tackle will tie honored for the gridiron exploits that brought reflected glory to his native city and all-America glory to himself.

VILSECK, Germany, Feb. 1 -- In light snow and freezing cold, troops of the United States Seventh Corps crossed the Danube and Altmuhl Rivers this morning to start Exercise Winter Shield, a week of mock war.
Reconsidering an earlier decision not to come East for indoor competition this winter. Dyrol Burleson will run in the Baxter Mile at the New York Athletic Club games Feb. 13 at Madison Square Garden.

The Bristol-Myers Company achieved record sales and earnings last year, according to the concern's preliminary report. The company produces toiletries, proprietary drugs, cosmetics, penicillin, streptomycin and fiber glass reinforced plastic products.

William Schuman was the composer whose music was dis- played in last night's Composers Showcase at the Circle in the Square. The two halves of the program revealed two very different aspects of the composer's work.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK Times: On Jan. 14 Premier Khrushchev announced before the Supreme Soviet his intention to reduce the Soviet armed forces by 1,200,000 men. Hungarians have good reason to doubt the sincerity of such announcements. Nov. 3, 1956, remains vividly in our memory.
TRENTON, Feb. 1 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner presented a record budget to the Legislature today.
CONCORD, N.H., Feb. 1 (AP) -- The name of Henry Cabot Lodge, United Nations Ambassador, wa entered today in New Hampshire's Republican Presidential primary March 8.
ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- State spending of $156,778,000 for highways and parkways and eliminating grade crossings was proposed today by Governor Rockefeller for the fiscal year starting April 1.

Following is the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's new table of desirable weights for men and women 25 years old and over according to height and frame. The figures represent weights in ordinary indoor clothing and heights in shoes with one-inch heels for men and with two inch heels for women.
Seventeen free public concerts featuring American music and performers will be the highlight of the twenty-first WNYC American Music Festival.
WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 1 -- Two members of the Westchester County Park Commission were continued in office today despite criticism by some county supervisors.
General of the Army Douglas MacArthur's condition "has been showing gradual improvement, which can be expected to continue," a medical bulletin issued yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital said.
PARIS, Feb. 1 -- President de Gaulle prepared in effect, today to assume special powers to consolidate his victory over the European insurrection in Algeria.
A total of 340 Negro and Puerto Rican pupil was transferred without incident yesterday from Harlem and East Harlem to five predominantly white schools in Yorkville.

Everybody goes to Africa these days, including such persons as British Prime Minister Macmillan, King Baudouin of Belgium, U.N. Ambassador Henry Cabot Lodge and U.N. Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold. Mr. Hammarskjold, the latest to return, is in a position totally different from that of the others, for he is expected to represent impartially the interests of more than eighty nations.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 1 -- Israeli and Syrian jets clashed today as week-long border fighting continued.
A man who had hoped to be released after more than four months in prison as a scofflaw suspect was back in prison last night on a charge of armed robbery.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 1 (UPI) -- Len Matthews of Philadelphia registered a sensational one-round knockout over Johnny Busso tonight.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower returned by jet today from California after a pause in Denver to visit his ailing mother-in-law. He was rejoined in Denver by Mrs. Eisenhower.

PETER VOULKOS, whose sculpture and paintings are on view in the Museum of Modern Art's thirteenth "New Talent" exhibition, is an artist of exceptional vitality. Not only is he considered by many to be America's most original potter, but also he now proves himself to be a naturally gifted sculptor and painter as well.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 1 -- Chancellor Adenauer has told Premier Khrushchev that the Soviet Union must stop slandering West Germany if Mr. Khrushchev wants his proclaimed policy of international relaxation to be taken seriously here.
The Syracuse Nationals will oppose the New York Knickerbockers in the second game of a National Basketball Association double-header tonight at Madison Square Garden.
TOKYO, Feb. 1 -- Premier Nobusuke Kishi opened the Government's campaign today to win ratilication in the Diet (Parliament) of the controversial United States-Japan security treaty.

A costume party called the Trinidad Carnival Ball will be held March 1 -- Shrove Tuesday -- in the Sheraton-East. It will be a benefit for the Cancer Control Research Foundation of the Variety Club of New York.
The American production of "The Play of Daniel," the medieval Biblical music drama, will make a ten-week tour of European festivals starting late in May.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- United States officials hailed as "hopeful" today President de Gaulle's victory over European foes of self-determination in Algeria.
MOSCOW, Feb. 1 -- Communist China apparently will not send a delegation to the agricultural conference that has brought Communist leaders to Moscow.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The Soviet Union will have at least 150 intercontinental ballistic missiles in operational readiness in 1961, according to the latest intelligence estimates of the United States.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 1 -- Major unions decided today to concentrate their lobbying activity on a limited program of Congressional objectives in this Presidential year.

A 22-year-old man held for three-and-a-half months as a deserter was ordered released from Army custody yesterday fey Federal Judge Archie O. Dawson. He ruled that the young man had been inducted illegally.

LONDON, Feb. 1 -- Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd indicated to the House of Commons today that Britain had gone as far as possible in her negotiations with the Cypriote Government-to-be and regarded further postponement of the island's independence as unfortunate but not disastrous.

The first national intercollegiate match-game bowling championship will be held in New York this spring. The tourney is an outgrowth of the growing Eastern intercollegiate championship, aided by more interest in the sport in colleges throughout the nation.
THE PRESIDENT Returned from California. THE SENATE Resumed debate on polltax measure.
Carmen Basilio's co-managers have been barred from New York boxing for life under an unusually severe ruling by the State Athletic Commission.

NEWARK, Feb. 1 -- The future of the New York Central Railroad's West Shore Division remained uncertain today in the face of an order by the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners that the railroad provide passenger service within New Jersey.

"Ring the Night Bell," the autobiography of Dr. Paul B. Magnuson, one of the pioneers of orthopedic surgery, will be published Feb. 15 by Little, Brown. In telling his story, Dr. Magnuson also gives a view of American medicin over the last fifty years.
TRENTON, Feb. 1-- Following is a breakdown of New Jersey's estimated income and spending for the 1960-61 fiscal year, as outlined today by Gov. Robert B. Meyner in his budget message:
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 1 -- Lithographers began returning to work today after the settlement of a ten-week strike, the first in the industry for many years.

Bob Turley, the right-handed hurler with the fireball delivery that once was clocked at 94.2 miles an hour, has removed himself from the category of dissatisfied Yankees. Quietly and without notice, Turley slipped in and out of town last Saturday.
The Union of Composers of the Soviet Union has recommended an opera by a littleknown New York composer for performance in Russia.
Fixed-interest securities of prime quality continued in broad demand throughout the Government bond market yesterday.
ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- Governor Rockefeller submitted to the Legislature today a pay-as-you-go budget that contemplates record state expenditures and tax collections.

PENSACOLA, Fla., Feb. 1 (AP) -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People filed a civil-rights suit today seeking integration of Negro students and teachers in Pensacola's white city-county school system.
Reports that cold weather in Florida last week did not damage or delay the potato crop resulted in heavy trading and declines in those futures yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- A three-point program to eliminate the reckless driver "before he eliminates us" was proposed today by Justice Tom C. Clark of the Supreme Court.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Feb. 1 -- Archbishop Makarios said tonight he was "not closing the door" to a settlement of the dispute over British bases.

The total in budget funds requested by 120 city agencies for the fiscal year beginning next July 1 is $2,391,194,522. If granted, this would produce a record expense budget that would be $214,588,413 larger than the present one of $2,176,1606,109.
The president of Consolidated Edison said here yesterday that Soviet technical progress posed a challenge to the present American lead in electrical power.
TRENTON, Feb. 1 (UPI) -- Twelve visitors from the Soviet Union engaged in some frank political talk today with Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey.
CHICAGO, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The decline in grain futures prices on the Board of Trade speeded up today. After the most general setback in several days many contracts were near their lows for the season.

Stocks rose yesterday for the seventh time this year. The advance recovered about $1,900,000,000 of last week's loss, but volume fell away in a generally sleepy session. Transactions on the New York Stock Exchange fell to 2,820,000 shares from 3,061,000 on Friday.
JEAN-MARIE LE PEN, who is typical of the extreme Rightists accused of subversion in France, was in a bitter mood in Paris yesterday at the collapse of the insurrection in Algiers.

Absent from Broadway much longer than he expected, Sidney Kingsley is hankering to return next season. Last represented by "Lunatics and Lovers," a frolic that closed after a run of 336 performances in 1955, Mr. Kingsley is planning to usher in a brace of plays of his authorship, provided they are ready.
ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- Governor Rockefeller, who was not exactly heralded as the taxpayers' best friend last year, is moving perceptibly toward such a role in 1980.

SYRACUSE, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The state chairmen of the major political parties told New York editors tonight that the people and press must rise to the responsibilities posed by a Presidential election and the Continuing crises of modern times.
Mediation efforts were begun yesterday to settle a strike of drivers, helpers and oxygen technicians employed by five major private ambulance concerns.
THE GOVERNOR In New York City to attend funeral of Francis Jamieson. Submitted annual budget recommending new appropriations of $2,026,000,000 and expenditures of $2,035,000,000.
The clash that began last week southeast of the Sea of Galilee ended a period of relative quiet on the troubled borders of Israel.

ALBANY, Feb., 1 -- A crime investigating unit within the Division of State Police that would be available for investigations in any branch of the Government was proposed today by Governor Rockefeller.
PARIS, Feb. 1 -- "In the Soviet Union we have some totalisator betting at tracks, but no bookmakers," said Prof. Vladimir Vite, the foremost Soviet harness-racing authority.
FOR some 5,000,000 Americans, nothing is quite so exhilarating as attaching their feet to long waxed slats and hurtling down a snow-crusted slope or mountain.
The seven-story apartment house at 566-568 West 159th Street has been acquired by Abraham Mathews, real estate investor, from the 556 West 159th Street Corporation, Eugene Purcell, president.

In a surprise move, William J. Grede yesterday became president of the J.I. Case Company, 118-year-old manufacturer of agricultural, construction and road building machinery. He succeeds Marc B. Rojtman, 42 years old, who will assume the important new post of special adviser to the president and the Case executive committee.

The annual gold medals of the National Institute of Arts and Letters, to be awarded this year for essays and criticism and for painting, will go to E.B. White and Charles E. Burchfield, the water-colorist.

LONDON, Feb. 1 -- Iain Macleod, Secretary of State for the Colonies, proposed today that Kenya be brought to independence under a parliamentary system that, "as time goes on," would guarantee the majority Africans the predominant voice.
ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- Governor Rockefeller proposed in his but get message today that taxpayers be relieved of paying the cost of running the State Public Service Commission.
Dr. John J. Theobald, Superintendent of Schools, congratulated five high school seniors yesterday as the New York City winners in the nineteenth annual Westinghouse Science Talent Search.

The Port of New York Authority has designated Feb. 16 as the sales date for a new issue of revenue bonds. The issue will total $30,000,000 and will come due serially on Feb. 1 from 1961 to 1980. Proceeds will be used to finance construction.

Matters brought out by a state inquiry's hearings on Borough President Albert V. Maniscalco and other Staten Islanders "must be presented to a grand jury," District Attorney John M. Braisted Jr. of Richmond said yesterday.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange fell 1 to 48 points (5 cents to $2.40 a bale) yesterday. The weakness was mainly in the new-crop months.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The House Rules Committee agreed today to take up a civil rights bill this week and act on it without "dilly," "delay" or "dally."

AS fast as one New York specialty store disappears, another pops up to take its place. One of the most recent comers is P/J, 938 Third Avenue (59th Street). Described as a "gentlemen's boutique," P/J takes its name from two of the three owners, Peter Orosz and Jack Kellog.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Senator Stuart Symington introduced a bill today providing for a powerful single Chief of Staff for the armed forces.

Governor Rockefeller in one year in office has done what he set out to do: establish fiscal integrity in New York State. He presented yesterday a 1960-61 budget that is balanced, that will finance large capital construction without a penny of bond issue borrowing, that wilt build up reserves instead of drawing them down, and that continues and enlarges governmental economy.
The inquiry into the fuel-oil delivery racket here has been broadened in Brooklyn.
DETROIT, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Thd United States auto industry, with record January car production behind it, began the new month today at a pace which may shatter output records for any February.

HUDSON, Wis., Feb. 1 (UPI) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey challenged Wisconsin Democrats today to decide whether they wanted a candidate who could win the nomination or one who could beat the Republicans.
CINCINNATI, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Oscar Robertson broke the three-year scoring mark for major college basketball players with a 36-point performance tonight for a total of 2,571 points.
Shadow and Substance The more sophisticated a man becomes and in knowledge of scientific facts the more likely he is to find continuing fascination in the unscientific folklore of his ancestors.

Directors of the Union Oil and Gas Corporation of Houston, Tex., and of the Texas Natural Gasoline Corporation of Tulsa, Okla., agreed yesterday on plans to merge the companies under the name of the Union Texas Natural Gas Corporation.
CHESTER, Pa., Feb. 1 -- The $10,000,000 cargo liner Mormacpride was launched in the Delaware River here today.
LONDON, Feb. 1 -- A token strike by London subway workers caused transportation chaos today.
TRIVANDRUM, India, Feb. 1 -- The voters of Kerala crowded the polls today to elect a state Assembly after a bitter campaign between Communists and an anti-Communist alliance of three parties.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Senator George D. Aiken said today that the time had come for the United States to explore "dispassionately" the idea of internationalizing the Panama Canal.

LONDON, Feb. 1 -- Wall Street's weakness and threat of a national railroad strike here combined to depress industrial share prices in the stock market today. The setback, which lowered The Financial Times index of industrial common stocks 3.3 points to 326.3, was the sharpest since the bank rate was raised from 4 to 5 per cent on Jan. 21.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 1 -- France balked today at a Dutch request to start talks leading to the association of the Netherlands Antilles with thg European Economic Community.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Senator Monroney of Oklahoma is not among the Democrats who are seeking national office in 1960. But he produced one of those "new" ideas which some of these candidates accuse the Administration of lacking while not notably producing any of their own.

A new issue of $15,000,000 of long-term sinking fund debentures of the Province of New Brunswick, Canada, is being offered for public subscription today by investment bankers headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., Kuhn, Loeb Co. and W. C. Pitfield Co., Inc.

Five apartment houses that occupy a combined plot of 241 by 100 feet on St. Paul's Place in the Bronx have been sold by the Bernhard Mayer Estate, Inc., ending an ownership of thirty years. The properties were acquired by a client of Jack Lampert, lawyer, in a deal negotiated by the Wishnow Horowitz Real Estate Company, broker.

Warren Brothers Co. An extra dividend of 40 cents and a common stock dividend of 3 per cent was declared yesterday by Warren Brothers Company, Cambridge, Mass., paving contracting concern. Payment will be made on Feb. 26 to stockholders of record of Feb. 12.
The Hadassah Medical Organization has established, special departments for the detection, diagnosis and therapy of emotional and social illness among newcomers to Israel.
Net income of the Stauffer Chemical Company reached a new high of $22,222,000 in 1959, the company reported yester-
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 1 -- The Screen Actors Guild suggested today to the major studios a way to avert the threatened strike by movie actors.

From the wreckage of last month's falling market prices, one stock market statistician has come up with the results. In the month the common stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange lost 87 1/4 per cent of what they had gained in price all last year, according to Harold Clayton of Hemphill, Noyes Co.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UPI) -- The Federal Communications Commission concluded hearings today on the radio and television industry.
ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- The stately yacht once favored by Franklin D. Roosevelt for excursions across the state appears to be headed for decommissioning.
TRENTON, Feb. 2 -- New Jersey was urged today to adopt a personal income tax or a general sales tax as the only practical methods of efficiently financing governmental services.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The railroads' proposal that they be allowed to engage in other forms of transportation was revived today at a House Interstate Commerce subcommittee hearing.

ALGIERS, Feb. 2 -- While troops and laborers were removing the debris of the settlers' insurrection, more than 300 of the city's European militants who had gone off to join the Foreign Legion found their way back home today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The series of recent air transport crashes should again focus public attention on the inadequacy of protection afforded to the innocent families of passengers who are killed or seriously incapacitated thereby.

The General Tire and Rubber Company expanded its earnings last year by 136 per cent and sales by 44 per cent over 1958 figures, far surpassing the former records, William O'Neil, president, reported in the annual statement.

I FEEL sorry for you guys," said Pee Wee Reese in his most patronizing fashion. "Travel, travel, travel. All season long you jump from one city to another. Being a ballplayer is a tough way of earning a living."
ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- The Legislature received a Republican proposal today to strip the New York City Transit Authority of its power to conduct labor negotiations.
PARIS, Feb. 2 -- Cristobal Balenciaga; the greatest designer in the world in the opinion of most experts, retains his crown.
PROVIDENCE, Feb. 2 -- Dave Kelley scored three goals and had one assist to lead Brown University's hockey team to a 6-2 Ivy League victory over Princeton tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The House Veterans Affairs Committee approved today a Treasury plan for raising the interest rate it pays on the $6,900,000,000 it has borrowed from reserves for G.I. life Insurance.
Central jury pools in Manhattan and the Bronx, hitherto in an experimental stage, will be made permanent and expanded.
STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 2 -- President Eisenhower was pictured tonight as being "most skeptical about spending money, energy and resources" on the super - thrust Saturn rocket project.
Thirty-one thoroughbred stakes events with a combined value of $1,220,000 were announced yesterday by the New York Racing Association for the first two meetings of the local season.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The American motion-picture industry defended its self-policing today as adequate, despite occasional lapses, and far preferable to any censorship by law.
HUNTINGTON, L.I., Feb. 2 -- Supervisor Robert J. Flynn, head of Huntington Township's new Democratic administration, took personal command of a new town recreation program here tonight.
Top city and church officials showered praise on Fritz Kreisler at a ceremony yesterday morning at City Hall.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- An exchange of insults marked a Senate hearing today on Communist activities.

WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 2 -- An exceptionally heavy rainfall in Westchester is years overdue, and when it comes the county should expect the worst floods it has ever had, according to Public Works Commissioner James C. Harding.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Consumer installment credit rose another $270,000,000, seasonally adjusted, in December, but the rise was the smallest for any month in 1959.
CHICAGO, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Grain futures worked rather feebly both ways from preceding closes here today without attracting much force in either direction.

CAIRO, Feb. 2 -- The newspaper Al Ahram reported today that the Egyptian Second Army was massed on the Egyptian-Israeli borders in the Sinai Peninsula awaiting orders to engage Israeli forces should fighting break out on the Israeli-Syrian border.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate today approved a proposed constitutional amendment to outlaw poll taxes in relation to Federal elections, empower Governors to fill House vacancies in emergencies and give District of Columbia residents votes in Presidential sections.
The Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday that 781 persons had been injured in automobile accidents in the city last week. This was a drop of 137 from the period the year before.

One of the most impenetrable of all iron curtains -- that surrounding the Dominican Republic -- is beginning to crack. There is grave trouble in that tightest of dictatorships. We now know the important fact that the Roman Catholic hierarchy of that oppressed country has come out openly in a dramatic plea to Generalissimo Trujillo.

With the top-seeded Charles Ufford Jr. of the Harvard Club biding his time until today, Bill Tully of the fcew York Athletic Club showed the way by winning his first-round match in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class A tournament at the Harvard Club last night.
The New York Public Service Commission will act today on an application of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad to raise commuter fares within the state by 10 per cent at midnight tonight.
WHILE American buyers are placing their spring orders with the Paris couturiers this week, New York stores are receiving shipments of ready-to-wear fashions from the same designers.
AUBURN, Ala., Feb. 2 (AP) -- Auburn toppled Georgia Tech to its first Southeastern Conference basketball defeat tonight, beating the Yellow Jackets, 48 -- 45.

Every group joined in a broad advance on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. This added about 1 1/2 per cent, or $4,700,000,000, to market values. There was a slight interruption in the upward progress in the fourth hour. After this, however, prices advanced again and were at their best when trading ended.
Employes of seven social-work agencies affiliated with Federation of Jewish Philanthropies voted overwhelmingly yesterday to authorize their union to call a strike.
ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- The Nelson Commission investigating New York City affairs received a vote of approval today from one of its chief Republican critics in the Legislature.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 2 -- United Nations authorities were reported to have asked the United Arab Republic today for the immediate withdrawal of armed forces from the demilitarized zone between Israel and Syria.
Maurice Chevalier, who stars tomorrow evening on a Columbia Broadcasting System television show, has been booked for a spring program on the American Broadcasting Company network.
The following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is suggested for an easily prepared main dish.
SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., Feb. 2 (AP) -- Nationalist China and India were barred today from skiing competition in the 1960 Winter Olympics.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board told Congress today that the $4,200,000,000 budget surplus planned by the Administration was "a minimum condition of reasonable fiscal health." He implied that the surplus should be bigger.
The action is expected to be feverish tonight when the New York Rangers skate against the Toronto Maple Leafs in a National, Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden.

Cautious and conservative inventory policies can help prolong the business upswing, the First National City Bank of New York says in its monthly bank letter, published today. But, it warns, a frantic attempt to stock industrial shelves could precipitate a business bust.

Ingemar Johansson, the world heavyweight champion, and officers of Feature Sports, Inc., the group seeking to promote the return bout between Johansson and Floyd Patterson, conferred for an hour and a half here yesterday.
ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- The As sembly Banking Committee reported out favorably today a bill to permit foreign and Puerto Rican banks to open branches and receive deposits in New York State.
NASSAU, Bahamas, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Drizzling rain became an unwelcome substitute tonight for a favorable wind in the Miami-to-Nassau sailing race.

AN EXHIBITION of "Twentieth Century United State Coins" is on view at the New York Public Library's Fordham Library Center, 2556 Bainbridge Avenue, the Bronx. The coins include a complete set of Jefferson nickels from 1939 to 1960, the Mercury dime from 1916 to 1945, and 1909 Lincoln pennies fron all three United States mints.
BRUNEI, Jan. 25 -- Oil from the Shell company's big fields here has made this little Moslem sultanate the richest territory of its size and population in East Asia.

The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) reported yesterday that it cleared $139,600,000 in 1959. This was 18.5 per cent higher than earnings of $117,775,022 in 1958, when there were nonrecurring charges of $2,532,526 from the abandonment of a refinery.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Feb. 2 (UPI) -- The Air Force fired the ninety-five foot Titan intercontinnental ballistic missile today and for the first time achieved successful separation and ignition of its second stage in flight.

State investigators in effect yesterday absolved Rocco Parisi, executive assistant to the Richmond Borough President, of any implication that the $2,708.30 in cash he deposited in a bank Nov. 14, 1958, might have come from a Staten Island builder.
One floor and part of another have been leased by the Aluminum Company of America in Grand Central City, a skyscraper to be constructed on a site adjoining Grand Central Terminal.

TO be one of the National Broadcasting Company's men of letters appears to be an arduous assignment. Steve Allen has been having problems with Dostoevski and Freud, while Jack Paar, pursuing a more contemporary tack, has been having difficulties in imparting fresh perspectives to Fidel Castro and Dorothy Kilgallen.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Administration strategy to saddle the Democratic Congress with responsibility for the costly farm surplus problem was disclosed today after a conference of Republican legislative leaders with President Eisenhower.

A RECENTLY popular method of bridge study is the "seminar," so called after the fashion of discussion courses in colleges. At a bridge seminar one or more experts and an audience of students have a question-and-answer session on the latest practices in bidding and play.

"SHORT farces are better 'than long ones," William HazJitt wrote 140 years ago. Conceivably, Jack Dunphy, author of the two short farces presented yesterday afternoon at the Theatre de Lys, had Mr. Hazlitt's observation in mind when he tossed off "The Gay Apprentice" and "Too Close for Comfort."
ALGIERS, Feb. 2 -- The French Army sees three important gains emerging from last week's events in Algiers.
JERSEY CITY, Feb. 2 -- For the first time in fifty-one years an agency in the Jersey City municipal administration has come under the control of a Republican majority.

When a basketball team scores field goals at the rate of fourteen for every forty-nine attempts, it has to get into trouble. That was the New York Knickerbockers' pace in the second half last night and they got into trouble.
Common shares of the Tampa Electric Company are being offered to the public today at $27 each by Stone Webster Securities Corporation and associated investment bankers.

Mayor Wagner directed city commissioners yesterday to have confidential aides make special investigations where needed. This order was one of several steps designed to bring about a "uniform program" to prevent corruption in the inspection services of fifteen city departments.
HARTFORD, Feb. 2 -- The Supreme Court of Errors was asked today to rule on the constitutionality of a Connecticut statute permitting public transportation for pupils of nonprofit private schools.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy held a secret hearing today to study whether the Administration planned to place atomic weapons in the hands of certain military allies.

LONDON, Feb. 2 (Reuters) -- A wholesale fashion concern that often supplies dresses for informal wear to members of the royal family announced today that It had reached agreement on exchanging fashions with a nation-wide American organization.
BLIDA, Algeria, Feb. 2 -- The home town of Pierce Lagalliarde showed no compassion today for the unsuccessful insurrectionist leader who disappeared behind Paris prison, walls last night.
One of the casualties of the writers' strike in Hollywood may be the $1O,OOO,OOO production of "John Brown's Body," Joseph L. Mankiewicz revealed yesterday.
YESTERDAY (Feb. 2, 1960) THE GOVERNOR Attended breakfast of legislative council of State Council of Churches. Presented New York State flag to San Diego Naval Base in ceremony in office.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : I read with considerable interest your editorial of Jan. 20 dealing in part with appointments to the Board of Higher Education. The present members of the board have out gratitude and esteem as public-spirited citizens who are devoting their sincere energy to thia civic enterprise.

The City Council's Democrats took three hours yesterday to draft a statement describing it as a hard-working, progressive body -- not "the weakest but highest paid City Council in America." The disparaging quotation came from the Nelson Commission's study of New York City.
HERE is a chance for the strong, hardy American hunter, padding craftily through the forest as silently as an Algonquin or a herd of buffalo, to take a look at himself in a charitable mirror.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission today asked Conressional permission to require manufacturers to make television sets capable of ultra-high frequency as well as the normal very high frequency reception.
A panel of economic and political experts agreed yesterday that aid to under-developed countries could not wait for an agreement on disarmament and the subsequent release of military funds.
YESTERDAY (Feb. 2, 1960) THE PRESIDENT Conferred with Republican Congressional leaders. Met with his board of consultants on foreign intelligence activities.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- Concentration of the British aircraft industry was taken a stage further today when the Westland Aircraft Company and the Fairey Company announced an agreement that makes Westland the sole manufacturer of helicopters in this country.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Feb. 2 -- The hard-rock mining industry has teen plagued by the doldrums. As a result, manufacturers of specialized mining equipment increasingly are using their facilities, manpower and engineering skill to fill the machinery needs of other fields.
The condition of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur continued to show "gradual improvement" yesterday, according to a bulletin issued from Lenox Hill Hospital by the First Army.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The Senate spent a busy afternoon voting to revise the Constitution today.

Costumes are being touched with glitter for the ninth annual Carioca Ball, New York's slightly smaller version of the Mardi Gras that will attract visitors from all over the world to Rio de Janeiro Feb. 27.
LONDON, Feb. 2 -- London can boast of its own leaning tower. Big Ben is on the bias.
CHICAGO, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
PARIS, Feb. 2 -- The French police, carrying out President de Gaulle's decision to crack down on the leaders of the Algiers insurrection, arrested two more members of the National Assembly today.
A Prediction Made by Maugham W. Somerset Maugham made prognostication on the eve of his eighty-sixth birthday that has been gaining followers in recent years.
HONG KONG, Jan. 26 -- The use of the army as a labor force has been given increasing publicity recently in the Communist Chinese press.

GREENSBORO, N.C., Feb 2 (UPI) -- A group of welldressed Negro college students staged a sitdown strike in a downtown Woolworth store today and vowed to continue it in relays until Negroes were served at the lunch counter.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 2 -- Representatives of the nation's coat and suit industry listened today to advice from their own experts and leading retailers on ways to improve the industry's economic level. The experts recommended adherence to fair trade practices, more emphasis on fashion merchandising, general promotion by the industry and greater production efficiency.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 2 (AP) -- Anisado, a 6-year-old South American horse, captured the $10,000 Chests Handicap at Santa Anita over the grass course today. He ran the mile and one-quarter in 2:06 2/5.
An effort to streamline stevedoring and shorten the turnaround time cargo ships spend at pierside will be undertaken this month at the Navy's supply center at Oakland, Calif.

ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- Governor Rockefeller today set March 8 as the date for a special election to fill a vacancy in the House of Representatives from the Twenty-third Congressional District in the, Bronx.
LONDON, Feb. 2 -- The rally on Wall Street yesterday helped the stock market here today to make a slightly better showing than of late.
TIMBUKTU, Sudan Republic Jan. 27 -- Timbuktu, a commercial and spiritual center in the Middle Ages and storied for its remoteness, may become more accessible than it has been for hundreds of years.

Human nature and politics being what they are, a grieved, indignant Wagner administration reply to the Nelson commission's criticisms of mismanagement by the New York City government could have been expected.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Sales of manufacturers rose 13 per cent last year to a record of $357,000,000,000, the Department of Commerce reported today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Gen. Thomas S. Power, head of the Strategic Air Command, reiterated today his appeal for a continuous airborne alert.

The current policies of the Military Air Transport Service may eventually force the United States into subsidizing the nation's overseas air carriers, Charles S. Thomas, president of Trans World Airlines, declared here yesterday.
WASHlNGTON, Feb. 2 (UPI) -- Vice President Nixon granted permission today to have his name entered in Indiana's Republican Presidential primary on May 3.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb 2 -- New York University de feated Duquesne, 67 -- 58, and lona College trimmed Seton Hall in overtime, 71 -- 68, in a basketball double-header before 3,100 fans at the County Center tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- When the giants of the automotive industry decided late in 1957 to go all out for a smaller car a wag surreptitiously altered the standard wallmark "Think" in some Detroit offices to read "Think Small." Last summer a postscript advised "but not too small."

The net Income of the Continental Oil Company rose to a new high of $60,300,000, or $2.85 a share, in 1959, L.F. McCollum, president, reported yesterday. This was 24.5 per cent above the earnings of $48,400,000, or $2.40 a share, in 1958.

MANY contemporary novelists believe that they and their works do not receive the respect and understanding they deserve; that many readers and even some critics, when they think of fiction, still tend to put the word "only" in front of the words "a novel."

The local branch of the Screen Actors Guild voted unanimously yesterday afternoon to support its parent organization on the West Coast in the current mailed referendum of members regarding a strike against the major movie companies.
BERGEN-BELSEN, Germany, Feb. 2 -- West German and Jewish leaders made a pilgrimage today to the site this Nazi concentration camp on the wine swept North German plain.

PARIS, Wednesday, Feb. 3 -- The National Assembly approved by 441 -- 75 early today special powers for President de Gaulle to rule by decree to meet subversive resistance to his policy of self-determination for Algeria.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Gen. Thomas Sarsfield Power dominated the opening of the Senate Preparedness subcommittee hearings today with his warnings of the Soviet ballistic missile threat Yet it was not the first time that the head of the Strategic Air Command had charged that the Administration's defense spending was inadequate.

The land comprising the blockfront on the west side of Seventh Avenue, from Fifty-eighth Street to Central Park South, has been leased by builders who are considering a plan for a large apartment house on the property.
The son of a North Carolina slave took office yeaterday as president of a 12,500-member union of municipal employes here.
At the annual meeting yesterday at Toronto, stockholders Cockshutt Farm Equipment, Ltd., were told that the company was acquiring a large tract of land in central Florida.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 2 -- President Eisenhower's project for a top-level conference of labor and management to promote industrial peace will probably be carried out this spring, Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell reported here today.
A protest was voiced from the bench in Special Sessions yesterday because the city had assigned only one attorney to handle a large volume of cases against landlords in two courtrooms.

Most bankers take their jobs rather seriously, and so does the management of Girard Trust Corn Exchange Bank, of Philadelphia. But there is laugh-provoking evidence that their gravity does not extend to themselves. The bank's 123d annual report, out today, continues a tradition begun twelve years ago.

The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation has agreed to the purchase of a 50 per cent interest in the Grand Central Rocket Company of Redlands, Calif. Thus Lockheed is entering the field of propulsion. No terms were announced.

The bond market was occupied largely yesterday with transactions in United States securities related to the Treasury's $11,363,000,000 refunding. Today is the last day for holders of the maturing debt -- 3 3/4 per cent certificates of indebtedness due on Feb. 15 -- to enter exchange subscriptions at the Federal Reserve Banks.
WHITE PLAINS. Feb. 2 -- A neighborhood quarrel stemming from rambunctious squirrels and an oversize cherry tree occupied Justice Frank H. Coyne in State Supreme Court here today.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Feb. 2 -- The controversy over the size of the bases Britain is to retain in Cyprus has unexpectedly brought the Greek and Turkish Cypriotes together in common hostility to the British proposals.
A fort that has stood watch in New York Harbor since the War of 1812 is being razed. The island on which it stands will disappear too.

An American edition of the autobiography of Fredric Warburg of the British book publishing, concern of Seeker Warburg will be published Feb. 24 by Houghton Mifflin. It will be called "An Occupation for Gentlemen."
Ralph W. Whelan, Commissioner of Youth Services and executive vice chairman of the New York City Youth Board, defended yesterday the juvenile delinquency prediction test he announced recently.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 2 -- The entry list for the 500-mile late-model stock car race here on Sunday, Feb. 14, reached eighty-two today.

Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, assailed the United States Navy yesterday for "succumbing to the Arab boycott of Israel by barring owners of any United States ships engaged in business with Israel from bidding for naval contracts."
Continued long liquidation and uncovering of stop-loss orders caused prices of potato futures to decline again yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange in heavy trading.

AFTER the ghoulish humors of Friedrich Duerrenmatt's "The Visit," "The Deadly Game," which opened at the Longacre last evening, seems to be on a smaller scale. It lacks the originality and intensity of the corrosive drama in which the Lunts appeared two seasons ago.

Following, in unofficial translation, is the text of a joint pastoral letter of the Roman Catholic Episcopacy of the Dominican Republic read in a churches there Sunday on the occasion of the Feast of Our Lady of Grace, as obtained, by The New York Times:
LONDON, Feb. 2 -- Britain's National Gallery has purchased Rembrandt's "Portrait of a Man on Horseback" for a price in excess of $386,400.
ALBANY, Feb. 2 (UPI) -- The following ski conditions were reported today to the State Department of Commerce:
ASPEN, Colo., Feb. 2 -- Residents of this old silver mining town, most of them ski buffs, are impatiently awaiting the return of the United States Olympic Alpine team on Thursday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (UPI) -- Steel imports rose to a new high In 1959 and exceeded exports for the first time on record, the Department of Commerce reported today.
MOSCOW, Feb. 2 -- Soviet health authorities are confident that their hurried vaccination of 10,000,000 persons in the Moscow area has arrested the spread of smallpox here.
"One for the Dame," the Harry Essex-Lesser Samuels comedy about a gambler who spreads his activities into the television field, has been reactivated for Broadway.
TWO American men have just returned from Paris, yawning and weak in the knees, after a mission that might have strengthened the average woman for the rest of her life.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- Kenya's Right-Wing United party rejected today as totally unacceptable the proposals by the British Colonial Secretary for transforming Kenya into an independent state under a parliamentary government.

The 18-year-old daughter of an Alfred University official, who had been reported as missing yesterday morning, was found last night in a motion picture theatre with a former basketball player at the university.

District Attorney Frank S Hogan's office reported yesterday that it would not appeal the decision of General Sessions Judge Thomas Dickens on the Hulan E. Jack records. The judge had refused to release to Governor Rockefeller the minutes of the grand jury that indicted Borough President Jack.
Hope for a settlement of the strike by 16,000 v/orkers at eight East Coast shipyards of the Bethlehem Steel Company dimmed last night as mediation was suspended.

ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- The Assembly, after a heated debate, passed and sent to Govern Rockefeller today a bill permitting local welfare departmens to hire persons who are not college graduates as case workers and investigators.
THE work of two contemporary American painters, Milton Avery and Lee Gatch, is surveyed in a pair of retrospective exhibitions opening today at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

That Larry Sherry of the Los Angeles Dodger Sherrys was the outstanding player in the 1959 world series was widely acknowledged months ago. However, it was not until yesterday that the New York Chapter of the Baseball Writers' Association of America made it official.

The World Bank has just completed the articles of agreement for the proposed International Development Association. This plan, it will be recalled, originated in the United States and follows lines first proposed by Senator A.S. Mike Monroney of Oklahoma. The plan was approved here last fall by representatives of the sixty-eight nations that are members of the World Bank (International Bank for Reconstruction and Development).
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 2 -- A Soviet delegation touring the United States was greeted at Independence Hall today with insults and handshakes.
LANSING, Mich., Feb. 2 -- The Michigan Highway. Department announced today that bids would be opened on March 1 for $18,000,000 in bonds for completion of the Grand Rapids Expressway.
The Pepsi-Cola Company in 1960 will spend more money for advertising than ever before in its history.

A 10 per cent reduction in auto liability insurance premiums for owners of small and compact cars, "except those of the sports car type," was announced yesterday by 400 affiliated companies. However, the cut will not apply to residents of New York State.
ANNAPOLIS, Md, Feb. 2 -- Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts formally entered Maryland's May 17 Democratic Presidential primary today.

A diminutive painter from Peru is sitting in a hotel room near Times Square these days, wondering just how one goes about carrying out "a cultural mission to the United States," as his passport puts it.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Prospects brightened today for Congressional action on an omnibus bill to create new Federal judgeships.

The March 28 performance by the Georgian State Dance Company from the Soviet Union will aid the work of Childville. The Manhattan Chapter, sponsor of the event, has taken blocks of seats in the orchestra and loges at Madison Square Garden for the performance.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Dr. Wernher von Braun said today that the United States would not overtake the Soviet Union in the space race for "several years," despite 'the accelerated development of super-thrust rockets.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- A bill to set up a new security system for defense plant workers slipped through the House of Representatives today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NKW YORK TIMES: The Times is to be commended for its sympathetic editorial Jan. 26 congratulating India on the tenth anniversary of its Constitution. Carried away by the sentiments of the occasion, however, the editorial went beyond the facts to create parallels with the American Constitution which do not exist.
MINEOLA, L.I, Feb. 2 -- Registrations in adult-education programs in Nassau County are declining this year.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Forty finalists in the annual Westinghouse "Science Talent Search" were announced today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The United States expects Europe to carry the main burden of assisting the economic development of newly independent African nations, United States officials said today.

DARIUS MILHAUD'S Symphony No. 8 was the novel item in last night's concert of the Philadelphia Orchestra at Carnegie Hall. The work, which is in D, is called "Rhodanienne" because it describes the Rhone River.
TRIVANDRUM, India, Wednesday, Feb. 3 -- An anti-Communist alliance appeared virtually certain early today to have captured control of the State of Kerala.
LONDON. LONDON gives the impression of a boom town these days. There is a definite vitality in the air generated by the sound of millions of fresh pound notes rustling across counters.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to 7 points (35 cents a bale), off yesterday.

Ralph E. Casey, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute, scored the Administration yesterday for delaying the implementation of a maritime policy that he said "would provide adequate appropriations' for the maintenance of a strong merchant marine.

THE Rock Cornish game hen, that remarkable variety of poultry admired for its pleasingly plump contours and fine-flavored white meat, originated just eleven years ago. Yet the small birds, first bred by Mr. and Mrs. Jacques Makowsky in Pomfret Center, Conn., now are served in elegant establishments around the world.
ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- Governor Rockefeller and his critics traded statistics and statements today over the financial plan he submitted to the Legislature yesterday.

One of the two major 1960 changes in the National Collegiate track and field rules will be in operation today for the first time in the outdoor phase of the eighteenth annual Metropolitan Intercollegiate indoor championships.
A New York County grand jury began hearing evidence yesterday on payola to radio and television disk jockeys to have them plug songs.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 2 -- The slow but steady trend toward union of the many branches of American Lutheranism will take what amounts to a giant step forward in the early years of the new decade, it became apparent here today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The House of Representatives adopted a resolution, today saying that Panama's flag should not fly over the Canal Zone unless a new treaty gave special permission.
Operations of the Minneapolis-Honeywell Regulator Company last year resulted in the highest tales and earnings in the history of the large maker of automatic control equipment.
LONDON, Feb. 2 -- The sterling area's reserves of gold and convertible currencies fell last month by u18,000,000 ($50,400,000).

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 2 (UPI) -- Wilt Chamberlain and Tom Gola sparked a late Philadelphia rally to enable the Warriors to gain a 109 -- 107 victory over Cincinnati before 4,136 fans in a National Basketball Association game tonight.
TULSA, Okla., Feb. 2 -- The motion for acquittal in the oil price-fixing trial was denied here today by United States District Judge Royce H. Savage.
An important segment of the advertising industry took steps here yesterday to impose self-discipline, especially with respect to factual accuracy and good taste in advertising.

PARIS. "A little rebellion, now and then, is a good thing," Jefferson told Madison, "and as necessary in the political world as storms in the physical." Now that the insurrection of the "ultras" in Algeria has ended one may scrutinize it in that philosophical light.

HARTFORD CITY, Ind., Feb. 2 (AP) -- A school principal killed two teachers with a shotgun today while their pupils watched. Then he changed into hunting clothes, fled to a woods and killed himself with the same gun.

The six Roman Catholic Bishops of the Dominican Republic have intervened with Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina, head of the country's regime, on behalf of the thousands of Dominican. citizens imprisoned as revolutionary plotters.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- The Trades Union Congress, central federation of British unions, intervened in a railway pay dispute today in an effort to stave off the nation-wide rail strike scheduled for Feb. 15.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Automobile dealers were warned today to "clean house" or the Government would do It for them.

PROPOSALS for restrictive striped bass legislation will be among conservation matters that will be considered at public hearing of the New York Joint Legislative Committee on the Conservation Law on Feb. 25.
The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad has raised commuter fares to New York City by 10 per cent.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 3 -- The United Arab Republic and Israel accused each other today of committing armed aggression in the demilitarized zone south of the Sea of Galilee.

Jurors have long been forgotten people -- from the point of view of pay and working conditions. Not that they have been worked too hard or for too long hours. Their main cause for complaint has been the long hours they have to spend in dreary surroundings doing nothing but wait until they are called to serve on a case -- which seems such a maddening waste of time.

THE story of the long-lost Army Air Force's bomber, "Lady Be Good," was dramatized in a fascinating telecast last night. The aircraft, missing since 1943 when it took off from North Africa on a World War II mission, was discovered in an isolated desert area in Libya last year.

The following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is suggested for an easy-to-prepare main dish Asparagus spears marinated in French dressing, served on lettuce with chopped parsley Chicken paprika Steamed rice Canned baby petis with small white onions Frosted devil's food cake

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Archbishop Octavio Beras has been designated apostolic administrator of the Santo Domingo Diocese, it was learned today. He replaces Archbishop Ricardo Pittini, who is 80 years old and blind.
Three familiar names were called in Housing Court again yesterday.
DETROIT, Feb. 3 -- The American Motors Corporation is giving increasing attention to possibilities for diversification, George Romney, president, said today.

FELIX ADLER, the celebrated circus clown who died here last Monday, was a bridge player -- at one time an enthusiastic one. The late William E. McKenney, executive officer of the American Contract Bridge League, used to play as his partner occasionally and ranked him high among the theatrical bridge-playing fraternity.

Electric power production in the nation dipped last week to 14,313,000,000 Kilowatt-hours from a record 14,523,000,000 kilowatt-hours the week before, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. A year earlier the figure was 13,151,000,000 kilowatt-hours.
LONDON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- A token cut of 2.5 per cent in sugar export quotas to meet the continued fall In the price of sugar was announced today by the International Sugar Council.
A 65-year-old man was killed in Brooklyn last night in a hit-and-run accident. The victim, Cecil Moore, was the thirteenth person to die in such and accident in the city since Dec. 28.

CHARLES DILLON STENGEL, a man who has been known to exaggerate on occasions, gleefully tells of the performances he gave when the Brooklyn Dodgers scouted him for the first time during a double-header at Montgomery, Ala., in 1912.
ALGIERS, Feb. 3 -- Instead of being Algiers' trouble spot as usual, the Casbah is the city's most relaxed neighborhood these days.
YESTERDAY (Feb. 3, 1960) THE PRESIDENT Held news conference. Named Dr. Henry M. Wriston as chairman and Frank Pace Jr. as vice chairman of the Commission on National Goals.
A return to some towing away of illegally parked cars was advocated yesterday by Traffic Commissioner T.T. Wiley.
There was another indication yesterday that the TV pendulum was swinging tack to mystery in the traditional style.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The United States Public Health Service announced today that strontium 90 counts in milk during October were somewhat higher than in September in all but one of the twelve testing centers.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) expects to offer publicly $100,000,000 of 5 per cent, twenty-five-year bonds next week, Eugene R. Black, president, announced yesterday. It will be the bank's first borrowing in the United States market since November, 1958.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Vice President Nixon cast his first tie-breaking vote of the session tonight to help stem a strong drive for approval of a broad program of Federal aid to education.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Representative John Bell Williams, Democrat of Mississippi, called today for equal rights for Negroes in Harlem.
The performance by the New York Rangers last night at Madison Square Garden was as cold as their chances for a National Hockey League Stanley Cup play-off berth.
A 17-year-old admitted narcotics addict was arrested in East Harlem yesterday as a suspect in more than 100 burglaries since last July.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Feb. 3 -- Prime Minister Macmillan's recent visit to the Rhodesias and Nyasaland has intensified mistrust and jealousies in their Federation.
Women from leading families of Polish descent met recently at the Sheraton-East to plan for the twenty-seventh annual bail of the Kosciuszko Foundation.
ALGIERS, Feb. 3 -- In his spacious paneled office here Jean-Claude Dupont is worried.
MOSCOW, Feb. 3 -- Two Chinese Communists have arrived in Moscow as observers for tomorrow's meeting of European Communist leaders.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 3 (AP) -- Winter circuit standouts did not have any trouble today advancing in the first round of the women's golf championship of Palm Beach.
Net Income of the Sinclair Oil Corporation in 1959 decline to about $45,500,000 from $49,472,613 in 1958, P.C. Spencer, chairman, reported yesterday.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 3 -- David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, denounced the Department of Justice today for charging that the women s garment industry was seeking to restrain trade and limit competition.

A warning against complacency in the face of the battle for men's minds that is being conducted by the Soviet Union was given yesterday by Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, president of the American National Red Cross.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Administration decided today to increase aid to India by at least 50 per cent and probably more.

A one-story taxpayer occupying a plot 25 by 140 feet at 3008 Third Avenue, near East 153d Street, the Bronx, has been purchased by an investing client of Leverett Cady, broker Mr. Cady recently arranged a long-term net lease of the property to the Hyarge Purchasing Corporation for the sale of household appliances, furniture and allied lines.

TRENTON, Feb. 3 -- An analysis of the records of 128 boys released from the Highfields center for delinquents shows that the majority became successfully readjusted to normal community and family life.

NASSAU, Feb. 4 -- Only one thing seemed even half way certain yesterday after night fall threw a blanket of secrecy over the slow-moving fleet in the Miami-Nassau yacht race; Either Pacifica or Tigress would be the first yacht to finish.

"The Far Shore: An American at D Day," a new book by Rear Admiral Edward Ellsberg, will be issued Feb. 23 by Dodd, Mead. It is a personal account of the building of the floating docks that were to be used as an artificial harbor at Normandy.

City Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa charged yesterday that financial proposals by the Nelson commission would result in a loss to the city's taxpayers, instead of a saving. Mr. Gerosa asserted the proposals would overload the market with city bonds and thus drive up interest rates the city must pay.

Volume in prime fixed-income securities declined in all parts of the bond market yesterday Prices generally fell except in United States Government obligations, most of which gained.
The New York Stock Exchange closed at the day's low point yesterday, as the market gave up about half its Monday and Tuesday gains.

Plans for the long-awaited Lower Manhattan Expressway were approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission. The cost of the project is expected to run between $83,000,000 and $100,000,000.

Thayer Hobson announced yesterday the sale of his controlling interests in William Morrow Co., Inc., William Sloane Associates, Inc., and other affiliated companies in the book publishing field to a group headed by John T. Lawrence, John Lawrence Hughes and James C. Finkenstaedt.

Bollock's, Inc. Directors of Bullock's, Inc., yesterday declared a quarterly dividend of 35 cents on the common stock payable on Feb. 29 to shareholders of record of Feb. 10. The company paid 30 cents on Dec. 1, following a two-for-one split.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Feb. 3 -- Col. James A. Crist, chief signal officer of the New York Guard and senior commands of the New York City detach ment, died yesterday of a hear attack in his home, 164 Gaylor Road. His age was 58.

Being Waited Upon This is the time of year when a man gets waited upon for a day or two. It is the time of the common cold. To be sure, the common cold, unlike a man, is no clock-watcher, and is prepared to go to work at any hour of any day, but it is now that it works most willingly.

RESPECT and compassion are the just due of venturous souls willing to brave "The Tempest," most especially on television. One signal light failed on the IRT East Side line at Eighty-sixth Street during the morning rush hour yesterday. It showed red to southbound express trains, although the track ahead was clear.

During their first season last summer as entertainment purveyors at the Westport (Conn.) Country Playhouse, Henry T. Weinstein and Laurence Feldman established a new record in receipts over a thirteen-week season.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (UPI) -- Union membership declined from 1956 through 1958, reversing a twenty-year trend. the Labor Department reported today. The proportion of union members to the total labor force remained unchanged.

Shelby County, Tenn., is planning the sale of $8,000,000 of school bonds on Feb. 24. The securities will come due serially on March 1 from 1961 to 1985.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz moved yesterday to dissolve three real estate corporations and appoint a receiver to operate buildings in which they had permitted allegedly hazardous conditions.

ROSWELL, N.M., Feb. 3 (UPI) -- An Air Force jet Stratatanker crashed on a take-off today, killing five crewmen.

ALBANY, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Skiing conditions reported today to the State Commerce Depart ment:
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 3 -- The Boy Scouts of America, which will be fifty years old on Monday, has passed the 5,000,000 mark in active membership.
CONCORD, N.H., Feb. 3 (AP) -- A leader of the original New Hampshire Rockefeller-for-President forces today moved into the camp of Richard M. Nixon.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- President Eisenhower said today he would favor a change in the atomic energy law to permit the United States to provide its allies with atomic weapons.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 3 -- A driving lay-up shot by Al De Jardin in the closing seconds enabled Army to defeat Albrigrht College, 66 to 65, in basketball today.
As a concession to reform elements, the Democratic state committee will set up an executive committee, empowered to make interim party decisions, at a meeting here Feb. 13.
An increase of $56,200,524 in dollar sales of the American Tobacco Company last year raised its earnings to a record for the fifth successive year according to the report of Paul M. Hahn, president.

"There are endless hours of work in preparing a dog for the ring," said Tom Gately late last Sunday night in Boston after the "endless hours" had produced their reward. The professional handler from Wilton, Conn., had just taken an Airedale to best in show at the Eastern Dog Club competition, one of the country's most distinguished bench events.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 3 -- Israel and Syria have been asked by United Nations officials to withdraw their armed personnel from the disputed region southeast of the Sea of Galilee.
Directors of Philip Morris, Inc. and A.S.R. Products Corporation yesterday approved in principle the acquisition of the latter corporation by the former.
LONDON, Feb. 3 -- The National Union of Railwaymen announced today that the country-wide rail strike it has called for Feb. 15 would include the London Subway.
ALGIERS, Thursday, Feb. 4 -- An investigation of last week's insurrection here has begun. A Fascist political leader, an army colonel and a newspaper publisher have been confined.
PARIS, Feb. 3 -- President de Gaulle was armed tonight with sweeping powers to enforce his Algerian policies and fight off subversion.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Feb. 3 -- Prime Minister Macmillan said today that South Africa could not expect support for its racial policies from Britain. Without referring to apart-heid, the South African Government's policy of racial separation, Mr. Macmillan condemned it as contrary to Britain's belief "in a society in which individual merit, and individual merit alone, is the criterion for a man's advancement, whether political or economic."
The public, which has invested millions of dollars in Levitt houses, will have the opportunity today to invest in the builder, Levitt Sons, Inc.

Directors of S.H. Kress Co., variety store chain, cut its dividend In half yesterday with the declaration of 25 cents a share, payable on March 1 to holders of record of Feb. 15. In recent quarters 50 cents was distributed.

The seventeen-story office and showroom building and adjoining three-story structure at 114 to 120 East Thirty-second Street nave been sold by the 114 Bast Thirty-second Street Corporation to an investor.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- The British Government is considering retaliatory measures against those countries, particularly the United States, that practice flag discrimination against British shipping.

MIAMI, Feb. 3 -- The Edge hill Farm's Bally Ache made it two straight for 1960 by winning the $26,000 Bahamas at Hialeah today. The 19,096 fans liked the past performance of the colt and they made him the odds-on favorite for the seven-furlong sprint.
CHICAGO, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- President Eisenhower today stepped into the controversial issue of federally sponsored medical care for the aged.

WITOLD MALCUZYNSKI, as many more will do during the course of the year, dedicated his Carnegie Hall concert last night to the 150th anniversary of Chopin's birth (Feb. 22, according to most authorities).

St. John's captured two of four field events yesterday and took the lead in the metropolitan intercollegiate track and field championships. The events were held at New York University's Ohio Field in the Bronx.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 3 -- A Belgian-Congolese committee planning the form of an independent Congo state ran into a snag today: whether the King of the Belgians would continue to be the chief of the new country in the interval between the proclamation of independence and the adoption of the new state's Constitution.
At least one of the three players for whom the Yankees last Dec. 11 gave up Don Larsen, Hank Bauer, Norm Siebern and Marv Throneberry is happy with his lot.
Potato futures prices firmed lightly yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
An experimental radio transmitter for use in space capsules has been developed. It is said to have solved the problem of short circuiting when the capsule re-enters the earth's atmosphere.
ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- Assembly Speaker Joseph F. Carlino acted today to enhance the stature of the Republican Assembly delegation from New York City, which is now outnumbered 4 to 1 by Democrats.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Air Force, which denies it uses enlisted men as servants for officers, admitted today that it had issued an "on-the-job-training" manual instructing G.I.'s how to wash an officer's dog, make his bed and mix his drinks.
BOSTON, Feb. 3 (UFI) -- For the second successive time, the nation's baseball writers failed to elect a former major leaguer to the Hall of Fame in their biennial election today.
NEWARK, Feb. 3 -- A request by the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad for an increase in intrastate passenger fares affecting about 10,000 commuters was turned down today.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 3 -- Representatives of the Screen Actors Guild and important independent movie companies conferred this afternoon on labor contracts.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: This session of the New York State Legislature will probably see the introduction of approximately 8,000 bills. Obviously, with this volume of work there is bound to be a tremendous log-jam at the end of the session.
MEN are going to tha head of the class in the state's elementary and secondary schools. Just by their presence they are teaching youngsters more than can be learned from books.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 3 -- The election results from Kerala showed today that the anti-Communist front had won a commanding margin over the Communist party.
DETROIT, Feb. 3 -- The Fore Motor Company's net income last year was almost four times that of 1958 and was the second highest in the company's history.
ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 3 -- The National Lutheran Council has embarked on an intensive campaign to convert Jews to Christianity.

CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Itally, Feb. 3 (UPI) -- Stan Benham's bobsled driving skill probably prevented a crack-up today on the ice-sheathed Olympic track as trials began for the word four-man championship this Saturday and Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities said today it had information from "an unimpeachable intelligence source" that a Chicagoan had passed documents to a Soviet Embassy representative in 1958.

The dominance of Charles de Gaulle on the French scene since May, 1958, is an extraordinary phenomenon. His position has, if anything now been strengthened by the National Assembly's and the Senate's approval yesterday of a bill delegating special powers to the Government to rule by decree for one year.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 3 -- The Soviet Union informed the United States today that the new United Nations Committee on the peaceful uses of outer space should not begin work until the latter part of March.

Fordham University's basketball team, despite blowing a 17-point lead near the end of the first half, came on in the final twenty-minute session to whip the Seahawks of Wagner College, 89 -- 80, at the Rose Hill gymnasium last night.

Election of Stanley B. Erlandson as a director of the United States Tobacco as pany was announced yesterday. Mr. Erlandson is manager of the company's Chicago plant. He started with the United States Tobacco a clerk in the receiving department thirty-one years ago.

UNTIL recently, the references to nature in Theodoros Stamos' paintings were embodied in easily identifiable symbols. Gradually, however, Mr. Stamos has distilled his landscape experiences to a point of complete abstraction.

A NEW and unusual home fashion boutique is Henrietta Tlschler's. The shop, on the second floor of 837 Madison Avenue (near Sixty-ninth Street), is charmingly furnished as an apartment. The main clues to its identity are the several tables that are set for breakfast, lunch and dinner.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 1 point (5 cents a bale) off to 9 points up. The new-crop months showed the most strength.

Money will continue tight this year, according to Salomon Bros. Hutzler, underwriting and brokerage concern. NEWPORT, R.I., Feb. 4 -- Mrs. Anita O'Keeffe Young, executrix of the estate of Robert R. Stinson Young of Bernardsville, N.J.

Loans to businesses at the fifteen large New York City banks rose $50,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with a drop of $12,000,000 in the week a year ago.

Charles Gilman, who Joined the school system in 1908 as $300-a-year office boy, announced yesterday that he would retire next month as the top business officer of the Board of Education.

THE Metropolitan Opera had a new Lady Macbeth last night. She was Irene Dalis, and the California mezzo-soprano scored her greatest success to date in the part.

Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy sent a telegram to Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. yesterday telling him, in essence, to stick to politics and let the Commissioner run the department. The telegram was in answer to Mr. Powell's request on Wednesday that the Commissioner transfer three high police officials from areas in Harlem and Manhattan East and West.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- A union accused of illegal picketing won today the first preliminary decision issued under the 1959 amendments to the Taft-Hartley Act. The decision was given by the National Labor Relations Board.

Starring Melvyn Douglas, Lee Tracy and Frank Lovejoy, "The Best Man" will be greeted March 31 at the Morosco. Gore Vidal, who wrote the satirical "Visit to a Small Planet," is the author of the play, dealing with national politics.

New York City borrowed $22,000,000 in the public market yesterday to finance street repaving, contributions to a transit pension fund, and payment of judgments and claims against the city. The money was raised by the sale of serial bonds due Feb. 15 from 1961 to 1963.

With revenues of only $144,335,105 -- the slimmest for any year since 1941 -- the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad closed its books last year with a net loss of $10,816,003. It was one of the road's worst showings since the turn of the century.

The boat show season is only beginning, even though New York's National in the Coliseum has faded to a memory. Long Island has one starting tomorrow and Chicago has one beginning tonight. Both will close Feb. 14.

Democratic party leaders turned out in large numbers yesterday to meet and hear Senator Stuart Symington of Missouri. The size and the importance of the groups that met with the Senator reflected a widely held view among New York Democrats that the Missourian might become their candidate for President.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The Department of Defense asked Congress today to authorize spending $1,034,161,000 on new military construction projects throughout the world.
Prices of cotton futures or the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 1 to 10 points (5 to 50 cents a bale) yesterday. All months shared in the advance.

The Vulcan Materials Company reported yesterday that net income was $6,191,000 in 1959, compared with $6,786,340 in 1958. Last year's earnings were equal to 94 cents a common share, based on the average of 5,108,964 shares outstanding, against $1.13 a share a year earlier, when the average number of shares outstanding was 4,789,443.
