WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The Netherlands protested today the United States' refusal to permit the Royal Dutch Airlines to fly between Amsterdam and Los Angeles.
ASPEN, Colo., Feb. 4 -- Ski experts were confident today that the United States would put up a strong showing in men's Alpine events at the 1964 Winter Olympics.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Senator Ernest Gruening said today that Sigfrid B. Unander was prejudiced and unfit to serve on the Federal Maritime Board.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, former Army Chief of Staff, questioned today the adequacy of United States forces, particularly the Army, to meet commitments to forty-eight nations.

HAVANA, Feb. 4 -- Anastas I. Mikoyan, a First Deputy Premier of the Soviet Union, arrived here today. Premier Fidel Castro went out onto the airfield as the Russian turbo-prop plane in which Mr. Mikoyan and his party of forty had made the trip rolled to a stop.

Of Slums and prposperity At almost the same time that President Elsenhower was describing the state well-being of our economy, an inside-the-paper news item mentioned that the City Council had passed six bills aimed at cutting down single-room occupancy (SRO) in tenement building, one of the worst slum-creating practices.

THE busy fishermen of the Club Nautic in San Juan, P.R., and especially Dr. Esteban Bird appear to have discovered something authentically new about the movements of the giant blue-fin tuna. Bird found the fish about twentyfive miles north of San Juan on Jan. 16 and others found them there the next day.

American Motors A quarterly dividend of 25 cents was declared yesterday on the new common stock of the American Motors Corporation, payable on March 30 to stockholders of record of March 11. Directors previously indicated their intention to vote 25 cents

TOWARD the end of yesterday's news conference at the Board of Education, at which Charles Gilman announced that he would retire as administrator of business affairs, a school official came into the room.
If a piece of transplanted skin is large enough it may overwhelm the body's natural defenses that tend to repel the transplant, a Soviet scientist suggested here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UPI) -- A House subcommittee investigating complaints about sexy films and ads today asked the industry to keep off the screen all movies -- foreign, or American -- that failed to meet "acceptable moral and social standards."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Rail and truck loadings last week were above year-ago levels an slightly higher tha nthe week before.

Louis and Bernard Jacobs, realty investors, have contracted to buy 426 to 434 West Fifty-seventh Street and the adjacent parcel at 438-40 West Fifty-seventh Street. The purchase includes the abutting parcel through the block at 425-29 West Fifty-sixth Street.
The Maytag Company had the most successful year in its history in 1959, with records in both sales and earnings, Fred Maytag 2d, president of the home appliance producer, reported yesterday.
The bond market had another quiet trading session yesterday, but with noteworthy assurance in the undertone.

The wholesale commodity price index halted a three-day retreat by rising to 84.7 on Wednesday. The daily index, compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, stood at 84.6 on Tuesday and at 84.5 on Feb. 6, 1959.
THE PRESIDENT Met with National Security Council. Presented decorations to Jacques Piccard and Navy Lieut. Don Wals for 37,800-foot dive in bathyscaph. THE SENATE Approved liberal school-aid bill.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Secretary Arthur S. Flemming said today that he was at work on proposals for the Federal financing of catastrophic illness of the aged.
ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- New York City's share of the financial aid that the state parcels out to local governments will decline by nearly $7,000,000 this year, the Division of the Budget estimated today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UPI) -- The Census Bureau reported today that Americans -- and especially Negroes -- are continuing to improve their educational levels.
Copper futures prices rose yesterday on the Commodity Exchange in active trading.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- A new banking bill that would prohibit bank holding companies from acquiring more than 35 per cent of the commercial banking assets in any banking district has been filed in the Legislature.
LONDON, Feb. 4 -- The seven members of the Western European Union emphasized tonight their determination to maintain close and effective political cooperation.

TWO anniversaries are being observed at the Artists Gallery, 851 Lexington Avenue, at Sixty-fifth Street. Hans Boehler, who is 75 years old, is marking his fifty years of painting. The gallery is celebrating its twenty-fifth year.

LONDON, Feb. 4 -- The Soviet representatives at an informal East-West disarmament meeting here subscribed today to a resolution urging that "small auxiliary seismic stations" be considered as a means of detecting nuclear tests.
The city's firemen began a petition campaign yesterday to obtain 2,000,000 signatures in support of their proposals for salary increases and new impartial arbitration methods.
Jonathan Logan, Inc., one of the country's largest manufacturers of dresses, was admitted to trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, achieving thereby at least one "first."

DETROIT, Feb. 4 (UPI) -- The New York Rangers ended a ten-game streak without a victory and spoiled the National Hockey League debut of a rookie goalie, Dennis Riggin, tonight as they beat the Detroit Red Wings, 3 -- 1.

DETROIT, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Automotive News said today that car makers would turn out an estimated 166,100 units this week. The figure is the lowest for 1960 but still well above the average for the first five weeks of the record car output year of 1955.

IN the city of Chambery in Savoy, almost in the shadow of the Alps, there stands a curious memorial fountain. On the top of a tall column is a statue of General Count Benoit de Boigne, a philanthropist and public benefactor. From each side of the column's large square base the forequarters of four elephants emerge.
SCALLIONS and onions are both among the scant list of vegetables to remain reasonable in price. Carrots, potatoes and yellow turnips are other possibilities in the moderate price range.

AN aging mother, who prides herself on the efficient management of her apartment, suddenly becomes forgetful. Among other lapses, she sometimes leaves her cooking unattended. Foods boil over and small fires begin.

TRENTON, Feb. 4 -- New Jersey college educators warned today of serious shortages in their faculties. They predicted that the situation could become critical by 1965. They blamed unusually low wage scales and the high cost of living.

BEVERLY SOMACH, appearing last night in the Young Artists Series of the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium, gave a recital of violin music that had its ups were downs. But as the ups were in the dominance, the evening could be termed a decided success.
The Republican leadership in the state drew the line yesterday against any "arrangement" with the Democrats to share the two Court of Appeals seats to be voted on in the November election.

IN championship fencing the blades flash with such speed that the eye hardly can follow. But when the bout director or chief judge calls a halt, he retraces the entire pattern of play with incredible accuracy. The initial attack fell short, the riposte was parried, the remise failed and sic ad infinitum.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Senators John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts and Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota settled today on West Virginia for a new clash in their campaigns for the Democratic Presidental nomination.
Rory Calhoun, with twice as much experience, is favored at 13 to 10 to defeat Billy Ryan in their scheduled ten-round light-heavyweight fight at Madison Square Garden tonight.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 4 -- Robert Ryan will soon be leaving his spacious Beverly Hills home for congested New York to appease a conscience that has made many in Hollywood consider him eccentric.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Feb. 4 -- Fighting between Israel and Syria spread to a new area today.
More than a dozen local symphonic organizations, an equivalent number of show orchestras and nearly as many television orchestras hired Negro musicians in 1959.
The state's Nelson Commission disclosed yesterday that it had asked Mayor Wagner for more files of the city Department of Investigation.

MONTREAL, Feb. 4 (UPI) -- The Montreal Canadiens scored at least once in every period tonight to defeat the secondplace Toronto Maple Leafs, 4 -- 2, and stretch their first-place margin in the National Hockey League to 19 points.
TWO near-by tournaments will begin today that will draw New York players.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The issue between the Wisconsin Democratic groups who are supporting Senator Kennedy and Senator Humphrey, respectively, for the party Presidential nomination this year is a point of political ethics raised by Kennedy.

LONDON, Feb. 4 -- Rear Admiral Sir Murray Fraser Sueter, a pioneer in the use of submarines, torpedo-carrying aircraft, armored cars and tanks died at his Oxfordshire home yesterday. He was 87 years old.
ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- New York City stepped up its campaign for passage of the off-track betting bill today despite heavy odds against its enactment by the Republican-controlled Legislature.

"Alas, Babylon," a play that had been announced for production and then withdrawn last fall, has been rescheduled by the Columbia Broadcasting System. It will be televised on Sunday, April 3, from 8 to 9:30 P.M. on the "Playhouse 90" series.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Shades of the Seabury investigation! The indictment of Manhattan Borough President Hulan Jack, the 'little Hoover Commission" investigation, the internal revolt against Tammany Hall boss Carmine De Sapio make a perfect blueprint for a Fusion Mayor.

In Kenya the rallying cry of the natives is "one man, one vote." In Ghana that objective has long since been achieved. In the Congo it is coming to fruition. In the forests of South America, in the cities of southern Asia, in the remotest stretches of the non-Communist world the people have a franchise.
A police official suggest yesterday that the police we so legally hamstrung in their campaign against juvenile gangs that "presumption-of-guilt" bills should be enacted.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- New Jersey's dispute over a site for a jet airport to serve metropolitan New York centered today on a possible Congressional investigation of the Port of New York Authority.

LONDON, Feb. 4 -- Small selling in the absence of support found industrial share prices sensitive in the stock market here today. Despite the firm tendency in late dealings, many leaders lost a shilling (14 cents) or so, lowering the Financial Times index of industrial common stocks by 3.2 points to 322.4.
The swimming set will keep close watch on two dual meets tomorrow.
The following reports were provided by operators of the ski areas. Messages were filed at telegraph offices yesterday at the times indicated in parentheses:
Paul Anderson, who won the 1956 Olympic heavyweight weight-lifting gold medal for the United States, is going to become a professional boxer.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers agreed today to have an arbitration board settle its eleven-month-old wage dispute with the nation's railroads. This is a move seldom taken by railroad unions in the past.
Two pedestrians were mysteriously wounded by single shots within three hours of each other yesterday at the same spot in West Thirty-fourth Street, outside the Empire State Building.

DETROIT, Feb. 5 (AP) -- A strike at the General Motors Corporation's Chevrolet engine plant at Flint, Mich., was reflected in a decline of about 7,000 units in United States passenger car production this week. Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Feb. 5 (AP) -- A mild little man, who for a year made his home in a shack in southern New Mexico, has been arrested by Federal agents under an indictment charging him with evading $358,980 in income taxes.

The Connecticut General Life Insurance Company had $10,- 522,576,000 in life insurance in force and $2,083,544,000 in assets at the end of 1959, Frazer B. Wilde, president, announced yesterday. Funds for policyholders' and beneficiaries' security were increased by $10,204,000 last year, compared with $9,404,000 in 1958.

The fifth annual Viennese Opera Ball was held at the Waldorf-Astoria last night. For the occasion, silver and blue streamers with twinkling stars were hung from the huge crystal chandelier in the Grand Ballroom to the boxes.
ALBANY, Feb. 5 (UPI) -- Skiing conditions reported today to the State Department of Commerce:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) Paul Robeson Jr. denounced the House Committee on Un-American Activities from its witness stand today, but refused to say whether he was a member of the Communist party.
SELINSGROVE, Pa., Feb. 5 -- Hofstra broke away in the final ten minutes tonight and downed Susquehanna, 70 -- 60 in a Middle Atlantic Conference Northern Division basketball game.

MIAMI, Feb. 5 -- The McLennon Handicap, one of the more prominent stake offerings of the winter season, will be run at Hialeah Race Course tomorrrow, with nine contestants likely to go. The test of a mile an an eighth will be run for the twenty-fifth time.
WITH valentine's Day a week from tomorrow, it is not too soon to think about an appropriate gift -- if a card will not fill the bill. Here are a few suggestions from New York stores.

The State Attorney General yesterday withdrew dissolution proceedings against the TelePrompTer Corporation. It had been accused two weeks ago of attempting to exercise "monopolistic control" of professional boxing matches.

Business in the air continues to grow more popular, according to the latest figures. During 1959, deliveries of utility and executive type aircraft increased 20 per cent from the 1958 level to 7,689 units with a retail value of about $170,000,000, according to Aerospace Industries Association, Washington, a trade group.
A market shortage of the Treasury's discount bills developed yesterday as a result of recent persistent demand from non-financial corporations.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The United States said today the Soviet Union's threat to make a separate peace with East Germany was inconsistent with the Soviet's disavowals that it intends aggression.

COMMACK, L.I., Feb. 5 -- Pancho Gonzales played his first match under the "threebounce" rule tonight and won it before a gallery of 2,500 in the attractive, perfectly illuminated new Long Island Arena.

A three-story loft building at 182 Third Avenue has been purchased by the 168 Third Avenue Realty Corporation, which owns adjoining property and now controls the blockfront on the west side of the avenue, between Sixteenth and Seventeenth Streets, with the exception of a small parcel at the southwest corner at Seventeenth Street.
GARY, Ind., Feb. 5 -- Senator John F. Kennedy ended two days of high-velocity campaigning in northern Indiana today with a new nickname, "Fighting Jack."
Sales and earnings of the Owens-Illinois Glass Company set records in 1959, according to a preliminary report issued yesterday.
Shipments of grain to India, moving recently at the emergency rate of 400,000 tons a month, face a substantial temporary reduction.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Rising sentiment for a higher minimum wage has put the Eisenhower Administration in a political quandary.
City Investigation Commissioner Louis I. Kaplan has begun an inquiry into a $2,000,000 sewer contract awarded in 1956 to a company headed by a former convict.

ARMONK VILLAGE, N.Y., Feb. 5 -- School bus service between this northern Westchester community and Pleasantville High School was halted "indefinitely" this morning because student vandals failed to respond to a school board ultimatum.

Nicanor Zabaleta pursued his usual course last night in Town Hall. The eminent Spanish harpist put together a program of works originally composed for his instrument. Composers of previous centuries -- Cabezon, the well-known Anon., Mehul, Handel and Viotti -- were offset by four modern composers.

PARIS, Feb. 5 -- Philibert Tsiranana, President of the Malagasy Republic, arrived here by air today for talks with the French Government on a new treaty providing full independence with continuing close links between the two nations.
LOME, Togoland, Feb. 4 -- When Togoland becomes sovereign April 27 she will be standing on her own two feet and "not asking one shilling of anybody," Premier Sylvanus E. Olympio said today.
Thomas K. Finletter said yesterday that state Democratic leaders had shown their "insecurity and weakness" in rejecting a bid to make the selection of national convention delegates more democratic.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The cigarette industry has agreed to halt the less-tar-and-nicotine claims in its advertising as soon as mechanically possible, the chairman of the Federal Trade Commission said today.

Directors of the Associated Stationers Supply Company have voted a quarterly dividend of 13 cents on the new common, payable May 2. This is equal to 39 cents on the shares outstanding prior to a three-for-one split approved by stockholders yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 5 -- Calvin MacCracken, the New York metropolitan titleholder, advanced to the third round of the Atlantic Coast squash racquets tourney by defeating Lieut. Richard Hoehn of the Marines, 18 -- 16, 15 -- 12, 15 -- 8, tonight.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- House Democratic leaders quietly laid the groundwork today for early action on a new school-aid bill that they believe President Eisenhower will accept.

A Crown and an Irishman Men the world over are talking and taking action in their efforts to secure for themselves more freedom and independence, and here in New York and adjacent parts Governors and their advisers have been deeply concerned over how to collect and apportion taxes on two sides of certain state boundaries that thousands cross in their daily travels.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On Jan. 28 you reported a speech by Attorney General William Rogers in which he described Mr. Nixon as "the best trained, completely knowledgeable, most able and experienced and most logical successor to the Presidency in the history of American elections."

PARIS, Feb. 5 -- Pierre August Joseph Messmer takes over the tough role of Minister of the French Armed Forces with unique qualifications: he has come direct from the battlefield. Last week this husky 43-year-old reserve lieutenant colonel of paratroops was with his Eighth Parachute Regiment fighting the Algerian rebels, in the snowy mountains of eastern Algeria.
CHICAGO, Feb. 5 (AP) -- After scraping around at its lowest levels in several weeks, the grain futures market mustered a little more general support today and posted numerous moderate gains.
HACKENSACK, N.J., Feb. 5 -- Bergen County, where the death rate from heart disease is said to be the highest in the nation, has a new agency to aid heart patients.
COLOGNE, Germany, Feb. 5 -- The two men who desecrated the Cologne synagogue Christmas morning went on trial today unrepentant and clinging to their extreme nationalist beliefs.
CHICAGO, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Venezuela has asked the Organization of American States to hear an accusation of mass arrests by the Government of the Dominican Republic in violation of human rights.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 5 -- India is preparing to sign a cultural and scientific agreement with the Soviet Union.

PAARL, South Africa, Feb. 1 -- Grapes hanging heavy on the vine in a sunny vineyard may be difficult to imagine at this time of year in the Northern Hemisphere, but here in the Cape Province of South Africa the wine harvest is in progress.
IT is hard to tell what this may mean later, but the greatest concentration of striped bass ever seen in Jersey waters at this time of year is reported there now.
RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 5 -- The campaigning for tomorrow's elections in Burma drew to a close today.

THE amateur cook looks at a jar of egg whites that have accumulated in her refrigerator and wishes that her cookbook did not warn that making an angel cake requires more skill than making a butter cake. The fact is that a dedicate angel cake is not more difficult to make.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 5 -- Ted Nicholls scored 21 points tonight to lead Upsala College to its eleventh consecutive victory, a triumph over Clark University of Worcester, Mass., 79 -- 74, on the winner's court.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UPI) -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson announced today that Federal grading of lamb would be continued but under revised standards.
Heavy construction, contracts amounted to $377,400,000 this week, lifting the year's total to $1,642,500,000, or about equal to the year earlier levels, The Engineering News-Record reports.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Following are excerpts from a statement on civil rights by Attorney General William P. Rogers before the Senate Rules Committee:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Over the outraged dissent of Justice Tom C. Clark, the Supreme Court today postponed until next fall argument on an important Smith Act case that has been on the docket for five successive terms.

A large volume of major new capital financing is slated for next week. Although relatively few issues are scheduled, more than $325,000,000 in corporate an dmunicipal fixed-interest securities are expected to reach the market.
A Presbyterian magazine has devoted its February issue to a symposium on "Would you want your daughter . . .?"
NASSAU, Bahamas, Feb. 5 -- The new year has ushered in new look for the Southern Ocean Racing Conference.

Two Detroit Red Wing players quit hockey yesterday after being traded to the last-place New York Rangers. And the two Rangers in the deal, who said they were glad to be leaving, found themselves back on the New York roster.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The Gulf Oil Corporation said today that to meet contract commitments it was being forced under the oil import control program to buy at premium prices imported residual fuel oil that it sold at distress prices at its Venezuelan refinery.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 5 -- Trailing by as much as 15 points midway through the first half, Harvard's basketball team rallied for a 79-78 upset victory over Cornell in an Ivy League basketball game here tonight. It was the first Ivy victory for the Crimson in five league starts.
MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 5 -- An omnibus bill to provide about $75,000,000 more in state aid for schools will be introduced in the Legislature next week, Assembly Speaker Joseph F. Carlino said today.
SAN SALVADOR, Feb. 5 -- Dr. Felipe Herrera, 37-year-old Chilean economist, was elected tonight as president of the Inter-American Development Bank.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The Federal Communications Commission proposed today to make rules barring television quiz shows and contest programs that are fixed but not publicly indicated as such.

NORWALK, Conn., Feb. 5 -- Three hundred persons in a Triple-A residential zone northeast of the Merritt Parkway today indicated they would continue to oppose a motel planned on upper New Canaan Avenue.

THE squeeze in bridge -- so named by Sidney Lenz because it reminded him of the squeeze play in baseball -- is the process of making an opponent discard a stopper in one suit so he can save a stopper in another suit.
GREENVILLE, Ala., Feb. 5 (AP) -- An official of a large research laboratory in New York was arrested tonight on a charge of altering a $175,000 check and sending it in interstate commerce.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey is expected to propose a consolidation of commuter rail facilities in North Jersey.
THE specific gravity of the music on yesterday's New York Philharmonic program at Carnegie Hall was not high. But it would be unreasonable to look for the most precious metals at every concert.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 5 -- The executive head of the United Jewish Appeal called on United States Jews today "to realize" that 345,000 immigrants in Israel were "without decent housing or real jobs or enough welfare help."

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Feb. 5 -- A four-engined Bolivian airliner crashed in the Andes southeast of here today, Killing all fiftysix persons aboard. These included a 2-year-old girl who survived the impact but died in a hospital a few hours later.

WARSAW, Poland, Feb. 5 (Reuters) -- Church and state have agreed to reopen discussions on bitterly disputed problems following a secret meeting last month between the Polish Communist leader, Wladyslaw Gomulka, and Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, reliable sources here reported today.
NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 5 (UPI) -- Hope vanished today for five Navy men pitched into the Atlantic Ocean when their destroyer, bound for the mothball fleet, hit a huge swell off the Virginia Capes.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 9 (UPI) -- Directors of Universal Match Corporation today proposed a two and one half for one split of the common stock and said that, if the split were approved by shareholders, the company intended to raise the dividend by the equivalent of 25 cents a year on the new shares.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UPI) -- The Air Force ordered today a reorganization of its reserve program to put 30,000 men into atomic age disaster "recovery" units.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 5 -- The money lent to the Roman Catholic Diocese of Miami by a pension fund of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters will be used to build homes for the aged.

Net income of the Shamrock Oil and Gas Corporation rose to a record $9,181,907, or $2.64 a share, in 1959, J.H. Dunn, president, reported yesterday. Earnings in 1958 were $9,052,049, or $2.60 a share.

HAVANA, Feb. 5 -- Gunfire resounded as the Soviet exhibition here was opened today by Anastas I. Mikoyan, a Soviet First Deputy Premier. The shooting occurred at an anti-Communist demonstration. Three persons were wounded. The police arrested seventeen.
LONDON, Feb. 5 -- The decline in industrial shares was arrested in the stock market here today despite usually depressing end-account and weekend influences.

BERKELEY, Calif., Feb. 5 (AP) -- The University of California today named Marvin Levy, the 34-year-old football coach at the University of New Mexico, to succeed Pete Elliott as head coach of the Golden Bears.
ALGIERS, Feb. 5 -- The political house-cleaning continued here today.

As a counterpart to the recent Western summit meeting of independent Allied nations, the Soviets have staged a one-day Eastern meeting with their European satellites. At this gathering the assembled Communist party chiefs and Government Premiers of the latter promptly signed, in that order, a complete endorsement of Premier Khrushchev's program for the East-West summit meeting in May.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The Navy plans to remove the guided-missile cruiser Springfield from the strike-bound Quincy, Mass., shipyard unless the dispute is settled or assurance obtained that work will be resumed in a reasonable time.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your editorial of Feb. 3 and in Arthur Krock's column of Feb. 2 Senator A.S. Mike Monroney is credited with being the author (about three years ago) of the idea which has now materialized in the International Development Association, formed as an affiliate of the World Bank.
ASPEN, Colo., Feb. 5 -- The eight men and six women on the United States' Olympic Alpine skiing team arrived in Aspen early this morning and will compete in the Roch Cup races tomorrow and Sunday.
The best "sixth man" in professional basketball has been promoted, and many fans are a little sorry about it.
PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 5 -- Joe Campbell smacked a hole-in one worth $50,000 in the Palm Springs golf tournament today. But he must share the proceeds with a partner and a sponsor.
Details of an important mechanism by which the body's natural defense forces deal with foreign invading cells were described yesterday at a conference sponsored by the New York Academy of Sciences.
ALBUQUERQUE, N. Mex., Feb. 5 -- Texans tried today to sell "that great Westerner," Senator Lyndon B. Johnson, to Democratic party professionals from thirteen Western states.

The United States Steel Corporation yesterday announced price revisions by its warehouse division in three cities that are expected to result in an average price reduction of $1 a ton for some customers.
ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- A program to end casual and haphazard training of rookie policemen, particularly in small towns and rural areas, was made public today by Governor Rockefeller.

PARIS. Khrushchev has not only ordered substantial reduction in the size of his military forces; he plans to eliminate heavy bombers in favor of the long range missile and to cut to a minimum Russia's surface navy. He is studying the possibilities of switching his entire army over to territorial system subject only to intermittent call-ups.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 5 -- George Meany today urged Congress to reject President Eisenhower's recommendation for higher interest rates on long-term Government bonds.
News that Russia was purchasing 345,000 tons of Cuban sugar caused active trading in world sugar futures on the New York Coffee Sugar Exchange yesterday. Futures closed 1 point off to 4 up.

The Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service, largest passenger and cargo organization in the world, will expand its operations on the Great Lakes this year by more than 50 per cent, according to Vice Admiral Roy A. Gano, commander of the fleet of 148 vessels.
JERSEY CITY, Feb. 5 -- After fifty-six years of continuous operation this city's municipal public baths will be discontinued at the end of this month.

The Continental Casualty Company, Chicago, wrote net premiums of $293,228,109 during 1959 for an increase of $48,903,923 over the level of 1958, Roy Tuchbreiter, chairman, announced yesterday. This was the largest increase in the company's history.
Martyn Green, the English actor, who lost his left leg as a result of an elevator accident here Nov. 7, filed a $150,000 negligence claim against the city yesterday.
CAPETOWN, South Africa Feb. 5 -- Prime Minister Macmillan of Britain ended his month-long African tour today with a warning against extremism in attacking the continent's promlems.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 5 -- Tribal chiefs of the Belgian Congo indicated today that they were dubious about a complete break with Belgium June 30 when the colony is to receive independence.

Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy has rejected in vigorous terms a request by Harlem leaders that he appoint a Negro as a Deputy Police Commissioner. Mr. Kennedy declared that appointments, promotions and assignments in the Police Department were not made and would not be made on the basis of politics, color or religion.
PARIS, Feb. 5 -- President de Gaulle forced his Government into submission by shaking it up today.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 5 -- The National Lutheran Council warned Congress today that it would vigorously oppose any attempt to authorize Federal loans for the construction of private or parochial elementary and secondary schools.
A man was thwarted in an attempt to rob a bank yesterday, but more than $9,000 was obtained by other gunmen in hold-ups over the city.

Samuel Beckett's plays invariably puzzle, as well as fascinate, audiences as to their meanings. His latest, "Krapp's Last Tape," now on view at the Provincetown Playhouse, is no less recondite than the others, including "Endgame" and "Waiting for Godot."

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 5 -- Dartmouth's ski team took the lead as its fiftieth Winter Carnival opened today. Clear skies, sunshine and 2,000 co-eds invited here for two days of festivities added to the picture in this college community.
IOWA CITY, Feb. 3 -- There is a suspicion that Explorer VI, the satellite whose transmission life was cut short last October, was "scalded" into inactivity by extremely dense radiation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The Treasury reported success today in this week's big refunding. Public holders of about 93 per cent of one large and one small maturing issue accepted one or the other of the two replacements offered in exchange. As usual, the Federal Reserve System converted its entire holding, making the over-all conversion 96.4 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Key military, diplomatic and scientific officials met with President Eisenhower today for more than an hour.
Billy Ryan of Lowell, Mass., went into the Madison Square Garden ring last night with a weight advantage of six and one-half pounds and as the 8-5 favorite in a last-minute shift of the odds.
OMAHA, Neb., Feb. 5 (UPI) -- Hundreds of nails were scattered on streets near the strikebound Wilson Co. plant here today.

With confidence and quiet enthusiasm, Twentieth CenturyFox is getting ready the national release of a Belgian-made color feature called "Masters of the Congo Jungle," a CinemaScope documentary procluced entirely in Africa and the first such offering to be sponsored by the American film company in several years.
LAST night at the City Center the New York City Ballet presented George Balanchine's "Theme and Variations," set to the last movement of Tchaikovsky's Third Suite, as its final novelty.
NEWARK, Feb. 5 -- A paroled wife-slayer was held today on a homicide charge in the shotgun killing of a woman last night.

A study of a decisive battle in the Pacific has been made by Thaddeus V. Tuleja, a teacher of history and a commander in the Navy Reserve, who wrote "Twilight of the Sea Gods." His new book, titled "Climax at Midway," will be published March 23 by Norton.

BOSTON, Feb. 5 (UPI) -- Big Bill Russell gathered fifty-one rebounds, bettering his own National Basketball Association record, and paced the Boston Celtics to a 124-100 triumph over the Syracuse Nationals at the Garden tonight.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Attorney General William P. Rogers today urged all civil rights advocates to abandon voting-registrar bills in Congress and support his plan, for court-appointed referees.
WOMEN, as everyone knows, have always affected the course of history. Now, it appears, they are influencing men's fashions.
The sudden popularity of documentary shows as television fare has taken a man-bites-dog turn.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Two punches -- a left hook to the chin and a right to the jaw -- kept the world bantamweight and junior welterweight crowns on the heads of their owners, Jose Becerra of Mexico and Carlos Ortiz of New York, last night.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 5 (AP) -- Dartmouth, undefeated in the Ivy League, scored its fifth league victory tonight with an 86-77 triumph over Columbia. It was the second time this season the Indians had defeated the Lions.
Nelson Commission experts conceded yesterday that some of the specific estimates in their financial proposals for the city were "iffy" and "conjectural." But they stuck to their basic plan.
MEYRIN, Switzerland, Feb. 5 - "Just a vague, do-good phrase," said the scientist, "but just look at the little baby it has produced."

MOSCOW, Feb. 5 -- Western diplomats in Moscow believe that the Communist leaders of Europe who met here this week reached important secret decisions affecting their strategy for East-West negotiations next spring.

ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- A bill that would make former Lieut. Gov. George B. DeLuca eligible for a $23,000-a-year position as a state Supreme Court referee has been introduced in the Legislature.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- A major chemical company believes it has a cure for digitaria sanguinalis, the summer complaint better known as crabgrass. The new weed killer, -- which was patented this week, will be offered shortly to home owners in the New York area.
SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 5 -- The Dominican Republic this week sentenced forty persons, including some who are sons of Government-connected officials, to thirty-year prison terms hard labor.

Some time this afternoon, Roger Brown probably will become the scoring champion of the Public Schools Athletic League.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UPI) -- A non-denominational Protestant magazine said today that it was ''perfectly rational" for Protestants to oppose the election of a Roman Catholic as President.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 5 (UPI) -- Dr. R. Bernard Finch testified today that he had fatally shot his wife, Barbara Jean, accidentally in a scramble for a gun that she had brandished.

Plans have been made for the seventh annual Piarist Ball to benefit the Piarist Fathers School Building Fund. The Hungarian Piarist Alumni Association has arranged the ball in the Plaza Hotel next Friday.
Only Mayor Wagner can reveal the secret, adverse report of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York on former Magistrate Robert F. Mahoney, the president of the association said yesterday.

STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 5 -- Fairfield County commuters were assured today by the chairman of the Connecticut Public Utilities Commission that the New Haven Railroad never would be permitted to abandon commuter service.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 1 point (5 cents a bale) off to 7 points (35 cents) up. The far months posted the most strength.

AN "annual checkup on marriage," similar to a yearly medical checkup, is advocated by Dr. Lena Levine, a psychiatrist and family counselor. Dr. Levine considers an annual reevaluation beneficial to both new and old marriages.
VILSECK, Germany, Feb. 5 -- Snow blanketed this Bavarian maneuver area today as 65,000 American and German troops began the second half of Exercise Wintershield.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Average wholesale primary market prices declined 0.3 per cent during the week ended last Tuesday to 119.2 per cent of their 1947-49 level, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

The seniors at New York City's School of Industrial Art, unlike most other artists, cannot spare their work for exhibits.

Retail trade in this area last week rose about 5 to 8 per cent above the comparable 1959 level, leading store executives reported. Seasonal weather during the week spurred consumer buying. Merchants said big gains were registered on Monday and Tuesday.

RADAR TO THE SUN -- Man's first direct contact with the sun was achieved by scientists of the Radioscience Laboratory at Stanford University when they sent a radar signal directly to the sun, from which it bounced back seventeen minutes later after a round trip of 185 million miles.

Stocks zigzagged last week. There was a short-lived rally, but selling wiped out most of the gain later. The market showed the smallest change for any week so far this year. AT 4 A.M. Fifth Avenue is deserted by all but a few strolling insomniacs, some cruising cab drivers, and a group of sophisticated females who stand in store windows all night (and day), wearing cold, perfect smiles -- smiles formed by lips of clay, eyes of glass, and cheeks that will glow until the paint wears off.

LOS ANGELES -- Southern California, noted for the unusual, now offers winter visitors the opportunity to participate in whale hunts. WHEN Otto Graham served as quarterback for the Cleveland Browns, only one facet of Paul Brown's coaching methods met with, his violent disapproval. It was Brown's insistence on calling every play by shuttling his guards in and out of the line-up as messenger boys. The quarterback thus became a mechanic instead of a strategist because all the thinking was done on the bench.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Feb. 8 -- Eric H. Louw, Minister of External Affairs, sharply criticized Prime Minister Macmillan of Britain today for his comments on South African racial policies in a speech to members of Parliament here last week.

Health Careers Week This is Health Careers Week, when increasing opportunities in the many fields of ministering to man's physical well-being are brought to the attention of the boys and girls of Our Town.
ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- The Senate approved unanimously tonight a bill extending the freeze on the further expansion of bank holding companies. The measure now goes to the Assembly for concurrence.

FOR bridge players who collect safety plays the way stamp collectors do postage stamps, today's deal should be a candidate for any collection. The deal comes from New England, where an annual regional team-of-four tournament was played at Norwich, Conn., over the last week-end, and it was contributed by Jerome Scheuer of Boston.

There are always persons who keep bucking the odds, such as betting every race at a horse track, arguing with a mother-in-law or trying to make a spectator-sport of bowling. Once in a while, though, the odds give way and the one who keeps at it may come up with a winning performance.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Feb. 8 (UPI) -- Twelve top Soviet officials, trying to feel America's industrial pulse, spurned a manufacturing plant and a high school today, but praised a farm.
St. Louis, Mo., is planning the sale of $12,435,000 of improvement and public building construction bonds on Feb. 17. The issue will come due serially from 1962 to 1980.

The Bell Company of Cleveland, Ohio, announced yesterday its entry into the aluminum siding field through the acquisition of the Weather-Tite Company of Walton Hills, Ohio. The transaction involved more than $3,000,000 in cash and was approved by Bell shareholders at the annual meeting yesterday in Boston.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 7 points up to 5 points of yesterday. Old crop months held steady. A point is equal to 5 cent a bale.

IN his Second Symphony, which had its first New York performance at Carnegie Hall last night, Benjamin Lees proclaims himself as a composer of marked individuality. This is the work of a man who is finding his own way among the disparate pulls of clamorous trends and conspicuous fashions.

The New York Rangers' front office has received considerable criticism for not loosening its purse strings to purchase players to strengthen the club, which rests in last place in the National Hockey League, but Muzz Patrick doesn't think that is the answer.

TULSA, Okla., Feb. 8 -- Top officials of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) and its affiliate, the Humble Oil and Refining Company, discussed the necessity of increasing crude oil prices in the final week of December, 1956.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The commissioners of the two rival professional football leagues met for four hours Saturday, it was revealed today. It appeared that a "no-raiding" agreement had been reached.
Amid the excitement over the change in cigarette advertising, the P. Lorillard Company has scheduled a heavy television spot campaign to introduce a new-size Old Gold cigarette.
ALBANY, Feb. 8 -- A group of college presidents urged the state today not to burden private colleges with the cost of unemployment insurance.
The National Labor Relations Board yesterday stepped into the strike of 16,000 shipyard workers against eight East Coast yards of the Bethlehem Steel Company.
The following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is suggested for an easily prepared main dish.
YESTERDAY (Feb. 8, 1960) THE PRESIDENT Asked Congress for $950,370,665 supplemental appropriation.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 8 -- Parliament began a new session today in an atmosphere of pride for India's achievements but concern for the future.

Governor Rockefeller is having his legal counsel study provisions of retirement laws that permit New York City teachers to leave the service on lifetime pension without giving thirty days' notice of intention to retire.
ROME, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The Italian News Agency ANSA reported, that Premier Khrushchev urged President Gronchi today to become a Communist and remain in the Soviet Union.

ALBANY, Feb. 8 -- Assembly speaker Joseph F. Carlino served notice today that there was no plan to change the residential Rent Control Law at this session of the Legislature. The law was extended in 1959 for two years.
VILSECK, Germany, Feb. 8 -- Bavaria, with its rolling woods and pine forests, has long been a proving ground for armies in both peace and war.
The Georgian State Dance Company from the Soviet Union will open an American tour on Sunday, March 20, at the Metropolitan Opera House.

El Salvador, the smallest and most densely populated of Latin-American countries, has been drawing uneasy glances lately from those concerned with hemispheric events. The situation there seems to be ripening toward a crisis that could turn into a revolution or its opposite, a military dictatorship.

Controller Arthur Levitt warned yesterday that the mushrooming of special districts, set up for such purposes as water supply, sanitation and parking, constituted a threat to the fiscal soundness of town government.

Mort Sahl and Alan Jay Lerner, dramatist and lyricist, have dropped proposed plans for the comedian to star in "P.S. From Paris," a TV series that Mr. Lerner expects to produce in Europe. Another performer is being sought for the role.

The proposed wording on the new Thomas Jefferson Credo stamp has been amended just as Freedom House issues a report indicating that there was some loss in human liberty during the calendar year 1959. The two topics belong together, for there never was any responsible person in the United States who talked quite as freely about freedom as did the author of the Declaration of Independence.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Feb. 8 -- The faculty senate of Michigan State University voted 400 to 248 in favor of making basic military training voluntary.
There was no abatement yesterday of the strong upsurge in bond prices that reached the market last week in the wake of the Treasury's $11,363,000,000 refunding.

When the Civil War began, Frank Stringfellow was an undersized stripling of 21. He was turned down by the Confederate Army four times before joining Colonel, later General, J.E.B. Stuart's cavalry group as a scout.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb 8 -- Leaders of the Congressional coalition that forced through the Landrum-Griffin labor reform law last year were accused today by George Meany of thwarting efforts by the Eisenhower Administration to give the law a "reasonable" interpretation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The Navy plans to seek $975,000,000 for six more Polaris submarines in a supplementary budget request, Admiral Arleigh A. Burke told the Senate Preparedness subcommittee today.

THIS may yet wind up in a cigarette commercial. You know the one, "They said it couldn't be done, but Bill Cox did it." The Bill Cox in this instance is a glib and convincing talker of considerable personal charm. He dabbled in baseball as the president of the Phillies and dabbled in football as the boss of the Brooklyn Dodgers, but left enduring monuments in neither.

DENVER, Feb. 8 -- In the same manner that a scattered Army squad begins converging on a rendezvous, three parts of the United States Olympic ski team began moving from three Colorado bases toward Squaw Valley, Calif., today.

MOSCOW, Feb. 8 -- Soviet experts in the detection of nuclear explosions renewed charges today that United States scientists had made several important errors in data they presented to the Geneva negotiations on a ban on tests of nuclear weapons.

Selling of clothing by house-to-house salesmen is making rapid gains. Canvassers are increasing volume, so that this division of merchandising represents 18 per cent of the total of house-to-house credit business, it was learned yesterday as the National Association of House-to-House Installment Companies began its ninth national trade show of the industry at the New Yorker Hotel.
Suspension of a $14,000,000 interim annual increase in electric rates granted to the Consolidated Edison Company last Jan. 18 by the Public Service Commission was sought on three fronts yesterday.
A DREAM came true last night: a glorious evening of theatre presented under impeccable conditions of commercial sponsorship:

IF it had been possible for Edna St. Vincent Millay to be present at the Hudson Theatre last evening, she would have found nothing strange in "A Lovely Light." Everything would have seemed true and familiar.

Stocks hesitated yesterday in the middle of what looked like a selling climax. From 1 P.M. onward, volume declined and prices rallied. A loss in market value of more than $5,600,000,000 was trimmed to about $3,600,000,000, the equivalent to a net decline of 1.2 per cent.

News that Cuba would not increase its sugar crop to offset Russia's purchase of 345,000 tons of sugar from that country, announced on Friday, firmed world sugar futures yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.
THERE is a German proverb that states that man is what he eats. It is exhilarating to think that, if this is true many New Yorkers do not have the foggiest notion who they are.
RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 8 -- The prospects for democracy in Burma appear greatly improved as a result of last Saturday's general elections.

ATLANTA, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Neither Senator Russell nor Senator Talmadge gave any encouragement to a group seeking their aid to keep public schools open in the developing crisis over pressures for integration.
MILWAUKEE, Feb. 8 -- Vice President Nixon said tonight that he had a deaf ear for personal criticism from Democrats who would like to be President.
The Atomic Energy Commission has the embryonic equivalent of a fire department. It is a series of eight "hot-spot teams," ready at a moment's notice to fly to the scene of a nuclear disaster.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (UPI) -- A House Education subcommittee voted today to exclude funds for teacher salaries from a new pared-down school aid bill.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- A Government attorney told the Court of Appeals here today that a witness before a Congressional Committee had no right to withhold the names of former associates in the Communist party.
A 32-year-old stereotyper, heavily in debt, was accused of an attempted bank robbery yesterday.
A convicted murderer who declared, "I have nobody to live for" asked a judge yesterday to sentence him to death in the electric chair instead of life imprisonment.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Dr. R. Bernard Finch admitted today he had had affairs with two other women before he made Carole Tregoff his mistress.

ALGIERS, Feb. 8 -- One of the leading symbols of "French Algeria" was struck down today by the French authorities who are rounding up the men responsible for the unsuccessful insurrection thAt started Jan. 24.

ATLANTA, Feb. 8 -- Georgia's two United States Senators, hinting at filibusters and walkouts from the Democratic party, promised a cheering state Legislature today that they would fight to the last for "our way of life."
Tests to determine what grades of imported teas Americans will drink in the year beginning May 1 were begun yesterday at the offices of the Food and Drug Administration here.
EAST ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 8 -- Coach Fred Wieboldt's Upsala basketball team posted its twelfth straight triumph tonight by whipping the Fairfield (Conn.) University team, 90 --74.
Mike Dubin, whose passion for trivia is matched only by his preoccupation with minutiae, is the author of perhaps the largest unwanted encyclopedia in the history of high school sports.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Democratic members of a Senate panel studying the problems of the aged urged Congress today to expand the Social Security program to provide them with medical care.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 8 -- George Meany used the single world "terrible" today to sum up his reaction to the prospective appointment of Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. as chairman of the House Committee on Education and Labor.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) borrowed $125,000,000 yesterday in the United States capital market through the sale of 5 per cent bonds. It was the first money requisition of the World Bank here since November, 1958, and it turned out far better than the bank's officials expected a few weeks ago.
A special meeting of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York will be held March 2 to consider the qualifications of former Magistrate Robert F. Mahoney for reappointment.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The Treasury bill rate took another steep dive today.

Paul Wolfe, an earnest young Texan who studied harpsichord with the late Wanda Landowska and who has appeared here in a number of ensemble performances, made his debut as a solo recitalist at Carnegie Hall last night.

With its eye on the buildup, Northern Trust Company of Chicago ponders chances of a letdown. The bank, in its monthly comment on economic conditions, notes that "20 per cent or more" of present steel and auto ouput is going into inventories.
The Bemis Bro. Bag Company announced yesterday the election of F.G. Bemis of Boston as chairman and Judson Bemis of Minneapolis as president and chief executive officer.
Live-virus poliomyelitis vaccine has been given to 400 newborn infants at Bellevue Hospital to see if they can be immunized for life.

ALBANY, Feb. 8 -- A series of bipartisan bills has been submitted to the legislature that would enable twenty present or former Municipal Court Justices to claim nearly $200,000 in back pay from New York City.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (UPI) -- Evidence that some failures of the Titan Intercontinental ballistic missile were caused by human errors has been given to Congress.

Memphis State University and Providence College yesterday joined three other teams that will compete in the 1960 National Invitation basketball tournament. The competition will be held at Madison Square Garden, March 10 through 19.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 8 -- Paramount has purchased and will distribute in the United States a movie written and directed by men who have been considered subversives in Hollywood.
Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell urged the automotive service industry yesterday to provide more jobs for older workers.
CHICAGO, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

ONE of the costs of hunting and fishing in New York State that is going up steadily is the cost of breaking the law. The chances are that this basic cost will continue to rise, for that is the trend reflected steadily in the State's Summary of Game Law Violations.
THE Navy's needs and policies are being defended before Congress by a no-nonsense officer whose reputation for fast and decisive action has spread far outside service circles.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) --The world fabric tariff quota applies to most woolen and worsted fabric imports. It was established first in 1956 under the so-called Geneva Wool Fab- ric Reservation, and has been extended periodically since.
DURHAM, N.C., Feb. 8 (AP) -- Negro demonstrations against stand-up service only at lunch counters of variety stores spread today to Durham and Winston-Salem.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- A White House official said today that a sweeping study of the Federal tax structure offered promising opportunities for the return to the states of some tax sources, perhaps in 1961.

After visiting sixty-four cities over a span of two seasons, Katharine Cornell and Brian Aherne finally will reach New York in the two-character comedy, "Dear Liar." They will be ready for the reviewers on March 17 at the Billy Rose Theatre.

LONDON, Feb. 8 -- Queen Elizabeth II announced today that her descendants, apart from princes and princesses of the royal family, are to bear the surname Mountbatten-Windsor.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter said today that Moscow had adopted a tougher attitude on Germany.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The Dominican Republic stood isolated and friendless today as the Council of the Organization of American States debated for more than four hours a charge that the Government of Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina was guilty of "patent and flagrant violations of human rights."

LONDON, Feb. 8 -- With investors hesitant to buy, share prices fell heavily in the stock market here today. Losses in shillings among industrial lead ers were reflected in 4.4 drop in The Financial Times common stock index to 318.5.

Collins Aikman The Collins Aikman Corporation, manufacturer of textile fabrics and yarns is planning to expand into tricot lingerie fabrics through the acquisition of Bangor Mills, Inc. of Pen Argyl, Pa.

HAVANA. WOULD you like to know how to cook roast tapir, smothered iguana, jaguar stew or monkey pie? These are some of the recipes in a cookbook entitled "Tropical Cooking," written by Gladys R. Graham of the Panama Canal Zone.
ALBANY, Feb. 8 -- A possible compromise solution of the longstanding legislative dispute over a residence requirement for relief eligibility was proposed today by Lieut. Gov. Malcolm Wilson.

THE husband who turns a deaf ear whenever his wife starts to talk is usually reacting less to the words than to the tone and delivery. His wife would be well-advised to take a break from trying to put her ideas across, and use the time to reexamine her attitude toward her husband.
The New York Philharmonic is planning to go to Hawaii in the fall as part of a seven-week tour of the West.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Feb. 7 -- Senator John F. Kennedy is convinced that he must know where the votes are and have the Democratic Presidential nomination nailed down before the party's national convention gets under way on July 11.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The House Rules Committee, accused of delaying action on civil rights legislation, had trouble getting witnesses today when it met to consider the bill.

Walter E. Heller Co. last year had the highest volume of business and earnings in its forty-year history, according to the annual report of the commercial financing and factor- ing firm. It was the twelfth successive year of record net income despite increased money costs, Walter E. Heller, president, informed stockholders.

Passage of legislation giving New York trust institutions the privilege of operating under the prudent-man rule could prove a "sobering disappointment," a banker predicted yesterday. Such legislation has been introduced at Albany and is expected to be passed during the present session.

Some interstate telephone calls made within forty miles now cost 5 cents less -- and in a few cases 5 cents more -- as the result of a rate-change program ordered last July by the Federal Communications Commission.
RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 8 (AP) A curious chemical found in blood is immunizing some animals against some forms of cancer, scientists reported today.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 8 -- The Arkansas Supreme Court upheld today the controversial state law that requires public school teachers to file affidavits listing their organizational memberships. At the same time the court warned that the use of the law in a discriminatory manner would render it invalid.
The hiring of waterfront labor on the basis of seniority will be extended to about half the longshoremen in the Port of New York starting Feb. 23.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- President Eisenhower said today that the struggle for freedom must continue as long as it was suppressed or threatened anywhere in the world.

IT is a lucky youngster whose birthday is celebrated around this time of year. February being the month of St. Valentine's Day and Abraham Lincoln's and George Washington's birthdays, the opportunities for a different kind of party are conveniently at hand.

Two dogs nearing the end of their competitive careers won best-of-breed ribbons at the opening of the Westminster Kennel Club dog show in Madison Square Garden yesterday.

Percy Gale Jr. former director of the city's Bureau of Real Estate, has been asked to testify before the grand jury that is investigating Borough President Hulan E. Jack of Manhattan and Sidney J. Ungar the real estate operator.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- A Boston disk jockey conceded today that he had received more than $6,000 in gifts and cash from record distributing concerns. He denied that it was payola for promoting records on the air.

CAIRO, Feb. 8 (Reuters) -- Military tension dominated the opening meeting of the Arab League Council here today. The Syrian-Israeli border clashes topped the agenda.
The Maritime Administration's loan and mortgage guarantees for ship construction are expected to total $683,000,000 by 1961.
Comercial production of a tiny new electron tube said to be superior to the transistor for some applications has begun at plants of the Radio Corporation of America.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Grain futures prices worked out of a general early weakness and finished mostly higher here today with all new crop wheat contracts at new highs for the season by scant margins.

The uniformed firemen who have been a familiar sight in legitimate theatres here for the last forty years will be withdrawn March 1. The firemen have been on hand as a safety measure.
Potato and copper futures were the most actively traded commodities yesterday on the New York exchanges.

ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- For the third time in five years the Assembly approved a bill today to make parents responsible for vandalism committed by their children.

BEN WEBER'S Two String Pieces (1952) had its New York premiere at last night's Clarion Concert at Town Hall. On paper, this work by a contemporary American seemed like an odd selection for an otherwise eighteenth century program.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- A disk jockey who was dismissed from a $40,000-a-year job with a Cleveland radio station told Congressional investigators today how record companies "evaluate" the commercial potential of popular music.

MIAMI, Feb. 9 -- Several of the leading fillies and mares in this section will compete in the $20,000 added Columbiana Handicap at Hialeah tomorrow. The seven-furlong event, which will have its eighteenth running, has attracted a field of twelve.

This year, as in the last five years, Irvington House will benefit from a booth at the National Antique Show. The show will open at Madison Square Garden Feb. 28 and run through March 6.

Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 4 points (20 cents a bale) off to 1 point up yesterday.
CHICAGO, Feb. 9 -- The Chicago Police Department, under investigation and lacking a permanent leader, was confronted with two more violent crimes today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- A new school-aid bill limited to grants for construction was tentatively approved today by a House subcommittee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- A senior member of the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy cautioned today that providing allies with atomic weapons would "increase the mathematical chances of a nuclear war."

THE man appointed yesterday to the presidency of Hunter College, John Joseph Meng, has a somewhat unusual last name. His friends and associates think it highly appropriate because, although the name is of German origin, there is a descriptive Chinese ideogram for "Meng."

JERSEY CITY, Feb. 9 -- Members of the majority bloc of the City Commission here introduced a budget today calling for a record tax rate of $101.20 on each $1,000 of assessed property valuation. At the same time they defeated a proposed budget that would have set the 1960 rate a few cents lower than last year's.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- President Eisenhower urged Congress today to legislate an "economically sound" farm program at this session. He promised to approve such a program even if it meant "more regimentation" of farmers.

Majority Leader Joseph T. Sharkey acted in the City Council yesterday to thwart a move in the Legislature to decontrol rents in New York City.

ALGIERS, Feb. 9 -- New appointees took over today as attorney general and director of police for Algeria and police commissioner for Algiers. At the same time authorities pressed their investigation of the recent insurrection by European settlers.

TULSA, Okla., Feb. 9 -- Two officials of the Continental Oil Company testified here today that they had no prior knowledge of the crude oil price rise initiated by Humble Oil and Refining Company on Jan. 3, 1957.

Fafnir Bearing Co. Directors of the Fafnir Bearing Company declared a quarterly dividend of 50 cents a common share yesterday, payable on March 15 to holders of record of Feb. 16. The company paid 37 1/2 cents a share in previous quarters and an extra dividend of 25 cents a share last September.

The University of Oregon notes with pride, and only slight distortion, that it is supplying this week-end's three major invitation track meets with six runners who have bettered, or are deemed capable of bettering, 4 minutes 10 seconds for the mile.
GOLDEN, Colo., Feb. 9 (AP) -- Adolph Coors 3d, 44 years old, a Denver area industrialist, was reported missing tonight. Sheriff Art Wermuth said he might be a kidnap victim.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- Reginald Maulding, President of the Board of Trade, announced today the Government was opening an industrial development office in New York to inform United States business men of opportunities for establishing manufacturing plants here.
VIENNA, Feb. 9 -- Data from Moscow received here describe a decline in two branches of the Polsih economy and improvements in others.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- President Eisenhower's Farm Message gave more hope today to those here who feel that the worst may be over in the nightmarish program of farm expenditures.

OHRBACH'S is running in stiff competition with itself. Its reputation for superior line-for-line copies of the haute couture was challenged yesterday with its new exclusive made-in-France dress collection.
The Transit Authority reported yesterday with pride -- but with bewilderment, too -- that business was good.
For the second time in a week, the American Legion has rebuked Stanley Kramer, one of the leading American independent film producers.

MONTREAL, Feb. 9 (Canadian Press) -- George W. Bourke, president of The Sun Life Assurance Company of Canada, told the annual meeting today that the company had acquired all the outstanding shares under its mutualization plan.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 9 (AP) -- The widow of Robert R. Young, the railroad financier, was authorized today by Judge Patrick P. Curran of Superior Court to borrow $900,000 with stock of Mr. Young's estate pledged as collateral.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- President Eisenhower will fly tomorrow to Cape Canaveral, Fla., for a personal inspection of the big missile test center.

A $30,000,000 Issue of 5 5/3 per cent sinking fund debentures of Montreal Metropolitan Corporation, due In 1985, was offered to the public yesterday by First Boston Corporation and associated investment bankers. The debentures are priced at 99 to yield 5.70.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 9 -- The world's largest wine ship was disabled today by towering seas outside the Golden Gate as a three-day storm along the California and Oregon coasts gathered new violence.

The Federal Trade Commision is not worried about the tardy compliance of the Brown Williamson Tobacco Corporation with the industry-wide agreement to delete references to tars and nicotines in filtertip advertising.

Representative James Roosevelt asserted yesterday that a Michigan gasoline station operator's lease with a major oil company had been canceled abruptly after the operator had submitted testimony to a House subcommittee.

STUART, Fla., Feb. 9 -- Frederick B. Williamson 3d of New Hope, Pa., has announced the engagement of his mother, Mrs. Virginia Ranson Williamson, widow of Frederick Beasley Williamson Jr., to Wilbur Studley Forest of New York and Fort Pierce.
PARIS. Khrushchev is not wasting time as he prepares for the summit. He has just met satellite bosses to explain the new Soviet strategy.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 9 (AP) -- Stockholders of the Federal Pacific Electric Company have approved plans to acquire all or as much as possible of the common stock of the Cornell-Dubilier Electric Corporation, producer of capacitators and electronic components.

A DEVELOPMENT in food technology that might conceivably have a tremendous impact on the flavors of canned, frozen and dehydrated foods was announced in New York this week. The method, patented yesterday, derives its strength from natural rather than artificial flavors and was demonstrated to a small taste panel.
DURANGO, Colo., Feb. 9 -- In this community, once the stamping grounds of miners, cowhands and dance-hall girls, the United States Olympic cross-country nine-man squad has been training intensively.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial of Feb. 5 "Plain Talk in Cape Town" could perhaps profitably be followed by some plain talk in New York on important facets of the South African situation which do not seem to be correctly understood here.
Leaders of the New York County Lawyers Association are considering whether to take a public position on Mayor Wagner's decision not to reappoint Robert F. Mahoney for a third term as magistrate.

CAIRO, Feb. 9 -- Arab proposals to cut off Jordan River waters before they reach Israel are being subjected to a serious reappraisal by the Arab League Council now meeting in Cairo.
