Governor Rockefeller appealed to local governments yesterday to cooperate with the state in compiling an inventory of needed public works.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Western officials expressed concern today over the United States' slowness in evolving a new disarmament plan to meet Premier Khrushchev's proposal for total disarmament.
Geography of Meat Habits American habits have undergone many changes since the days of our grand-parents, but in one respect they hardly have been altered at all.

Bill Tully of the New York Athletic Club and W. Alston Flagg Jr. of the Racquet and Tennis Club triumphed as the third round of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class A singles championship was completed last night on the Harvard Club's courts.
A plan to screen a portion of the Clearview Expressway behind dense plantings of trees and shrubs was presented yesterday by Queens Borough President John T. Clancy.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Two Senators said today that recent questioning of Gen. Lyman L. Lemnitzer on Army appropriations had been misrepresented as a rebuke.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 9 (AP) -- Lookout Point, ably ridden by Don Pierce, won the $29,800 San Luis Rey Handicap on the grass at Santa Anita today by a length and a half.
HAVANA, Feb. 9 -- The agrarian reform program of the Cuban Government has won the approval of Anastas I. Mikoyan a First Deputy Premier of the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- The Government announced today plans for another exchange of mortgages for Treasury bonds -- a step that helps balance the budget.

State Investigators have begun looking into a $2,000,000 West Side sewer project after disclosures last week that the politically active head of the contracting company had been convicted on a 1940 fraud charge.
VILSECK, Germany, Feb. 8 -- Three tactical highlights manifested themselves during Exercise Wintershield, the largest war games to be held by the United States and West German Armies.

Willie Naulls is expected to return to action tonight when the New York Knickerbockers tangle "with the Philadelphia Warriors and Wilt Chamberlain in the headline game of a National Basketball Association double-header at Madison Square Garden.

SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., Feb. 9 -- The directors of the Winter Olympic Games relaxed a bit tonight. The threat of a disruption or a washing out of the eleven-day international competition was eased, at least for the time being.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- The rejection by the National Union of Railwaymen of a compromise plan to avert a railroad strike caused some reaction in the stock market here today. But most sections managed to hold part of the gains scored in early trading.
CHICAGO, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Trade in the grain futures market was meager again here today. Prices held virtually stationary, although there were spots of both weakness and firmness from time to time.

After three indecisive hours, tie stock market made up its mind yesterday afternoon. Prices ad been up at the opening but ad drifted back to Monday's losing levels. Then the market allied on light volume that added $2,800,000,000 to the market value of New York Stock Exchange stocks.
CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Feb. 9 -- General Trujillo said today that he would agree to free multi-party municipal elections within a year.
Dr. John Joseph Meng, 53-year-old dean of administration at Hunter College, was appointed president of the college yesterday.
ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- Following is a Budget Division estimate of the apportionment of state aid to the counties for the fiscal years 1959-60 and 1960-61:

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 9 -- The head of the largest Orthodox rabbinical group in the country appealed to American Jews today "to break the Arab boycott of Israel by resorting to similar boycotting methods."

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Feb. 9 (AP) -- A passive resistance movement by Negro students in North Carolina against segregated service at lunch counters spread to Charlotte today. A young ministerial student was reported leading the protest here.
THE newest testing grounds for home furnishings products are decorated model apartments.
The bond market's sharp rise in prices came to a halt yesterday.
The American Cyanamid Company rolled up the largest sales and earnings in its history last year, W.G. Malcolm, president, reported yesterday.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 9 -- Glenn (Fireball) Roberts, who turned a record lap of 152plus miles an hour here on Jan. 31 in a 1960 Pontiac, took the wheel of a Sportsman-modified machine a few days ago and was clocked at better than 154 miles an hour during practice.
IT has been two seasons since "Die Walkuere" was presented at the Metropolitan Opera House, and many more seasons since Wagner's music-drama had a performance as consistently lyrical as last night's.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- The Veterans of Foreign Wars urged Congress today to ease restrictions on payments of pensions to veterans, their widows and orphans.
The Federal Reserve Board was chided yesterday for failing to restudy and modernize its regulations governing common trust funds.
GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 9 -- The town counsel here requested a special $13,500 appropriation today for legal fees to fight the appeals of 100 property owners from increased assessments.
MOSCOW, Feb. 9 (AP) -- A Soviet scientist suggested today that Sodom and Gomorrah might have been destroyed by a nuclear explosion set off by invaders from outer space.

The owner of three Manhattan, tenements was sentenced to thirty days in jail yesterday for a failure to provide sufficient heat. He was also fined $600, which he paid in lieu of serving 110 days more.
HONG KONG, Feb. 3 -- Measures to improve the lot of the people have been emphasized in North Vietnam's economic plan for 1960.

YESTERDAY (Feb. 9, 1960) THE PRESIDENT Sent Farm Message to Congress. Met with Republican Congressional leaders. Nominated General of the Army Omar N. Bradley and Maj. Gen. Leif J. Sverdrup as members of the board of visitors to the United States Military Academy.

DETROIT, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Wilt Chamberlain broke the National Basketball Association's single - season scoring record with a 41-point output tonight against the Detroit Pistons, but the Philadelphia Warriors lost the game, 122-113.
MORGANTOWN, Pa., Feb. 9 (AP) -- Some members of the Amish sect, proclaiming that their faith is older than their Government, refused to send their children to a new $2,000,000 school.

The twelve-story and penthouse apartment building at 863 Park Avenue, northeast corner of Seventy-seventh Street, has been sold by Armino A. Campagna, realty investor and builder. It was bought by the Carnegie Management Company, which is controlled by Ralph W. Kern, Harris L. Shapiro and Irving Klein.
PARIS, Feb. 9 -- Playing to a virtually empty theatre in Paris has forced an all-Negro musical, "Free and Easy," to end its European tour.

ALTHOUGH the second quarter of 1959 brought rock bottom egg prices, the current first quarter is likely to take 1960's laurels. Experts predict that the present attractive prices will be hard to beat during the remainder of the year.
MOSCOW, Feb. 9 -- President Giovanni Gronchi of Italy spoke on the Soviet television tonight in an attempt to give the Russians a better picture of the "capitalist" world.

OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. 9 (AP) -- The selection of California-born Eddie Erdelatz as coach of the Oakland club excited San Francisco and East Bay football fans today. Many had resented his being bypassed as coach at the University of California.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) Feb. 9 -- An American rabbinical student with an unwanted electric shaver caused a small international incident here yesterday.

THE field in the Cavendish Club invitational pair tournament last week-end consisted entirely of first-class players. Observers were hard put to remember a previous field in which the quality was so uniformly high.

The report of the House Subcommittee on Legislative Oversight is a devastating commentary on some practices of the broadcasting industry and on the feeble regulatory efforts of the Federal Communications Commission in recent years. The stern language of the report is the more significant because the committee and its chairman, Representative Oren Harris of Arkansas, have been regarded as sympathetic to the industry and the commission.
Net income of the New York Air Brake Company last year rose to 12,271,452, or $3.07 a share, from $1,039,965, and $1.42
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 1 -- When it comes to schools, Ethiopia just cannot get enough foreign influence.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- A working group of the Organization of American States wrestled today with the problem of curbing acts of terror ascribed to the Government of the Dominican Republic.

Sales of the Continental Can Company reached a record of $1,146,529,000 last year, Gen. Lucius D. Clay, chairman, reported in the preliminary annual statement yesterday. Last year's sales were up 6.1 per cent from the previous peak of $1,080,393,000 set in 1958.
The Electric Auto-Lite Company of Toledo, Ohio, cleared $10,104,730, equal to $6.45 a share, in 1959. This compared with $25,816,911 or $1.79 a share, the year before, the company reported yesterday.

Mayor Wagner announced yesterday that the city would take over, one by one, the single-room-occupancy buildings that have become the hard core of its slum problem. The city will either buy the buildings from the present owners or take them by condemnation, he said.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Thirty-three coffee nations -- seventeen growers and sixteen drinkers -- are meeting here this week on plans to make the growing match the drinking, and vice versa.
The New York Yankees have suggested that the city take over Yankee Stadium and operate it as a municipal project instead of building the proposed new Flushing Meadow Municipal Stadium.
Eight hundred forty-three persons were injured in automobile accidents in the city last week, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday. This is a decrease of forty from the same week in 1959.

Fidelity and Deposit Company Net earnings of the Fidelity and Deposit Company of Maryland in 1959 were $3,293,157, or $3.66 a share, B.H. Mercer, president, disclosed yesterday. They compared with earnings of $2,511,047 and $2.79 in 1958 and were the largest in the company's history.

THE declining quality of "Playhouse 80," once the major dramatic undertaking on the networks, has been one of this season's more saddening developments; the program's spirit has seemed to ebb with the cutback in its number of productions.

New York City has borrowed $45,000,000 on 3 1/8 per cent tax anticipation notes due April 29, Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa announced yesterday. The notes were sold by allotment to eighteen banks and trust companies as follows:
ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- The Public Service Commission today rejected requests for a temporary suspension of a $14,000,000 increase by the Consolidated Edison Company in electric rates.

The season's second Intimate Concert was presented at the Mannes College of Music last night by the Artur Schnabel Memorial Committee. It was a joint piano recital by Claude Frank, one of Mr. Schnabel's last pupils, and Lillian Kallir.

William Bradford Huie, whose controversial, novels were once considered too explosive for Hollywood, can now cite six of his own works as potentially important film properties in the Nineteen Sixties.
Patrolman Samuel Morris, arrested Monday on a narcotics charge, was denounced yesterday by a police official as a disgrace to the department, the city and his family.
The editorial staffs of Time, Inc., have been granted a child's dream: freedom to scribble on the walls to their hearts' content.
DALLAS, Tex., Feb. 9 (AP) -- Continued inflammatory attacks against farmers could bring chaos to agriculture, the National Cotton Council was told today.
TRENTON, Feb. 9 -- Negroes would be permitted to buy homes in Levittown, N.J., and other Federally financed housing projects under a 6-to-0 ruling today by the New Jersey Supreme Court.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 9 -- Whether it deals with gnats, gnomes or gnus, 1,000 is a nice, round number. When it refers to the total games in which a fellow has served as coach, it is more than just plain news.

NO bride will quibble if you use a cliche to describe the way she looks coming down the aisle. Call her a "vision of loveliness" and she will be happy. This month, a number of brides-to-be are shopping for the one dress that will make them a vision.

JACK LENOR LARSEN was torn between Brazil's past and future in designing his present fabric collection. Some of his new designs hark back to the romantic nineteenth century; others are as futuristic as space vehicles.

Ch. Chik T'Sun of Caversham, a brilliant red Pekingese, ended the most remarkable show-dog career last night by winning the one great prize that had been beyond his reach. The dog owned by Mr. and Mrs. C.C. Venable of Atlanta was judged best-in-show at the eighty-fourth Westminster Kennel Club competition in Madison Square Garden.
ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- The Assembly tonight passed and sent to Governor Rockefeller the bill extending to March 21 a freeze on further expansion of bank holding companies.

Six five-story tenement houses at 509 to 513 Second Avenue and 241 to 245 East Twenty-eighth Street, the northwest corner, have been sold by the Bres Realty Corporation to Benjamin H. Cooperman Associates. The property, 75 by 75 feet, was sold in a deal negotiated by Peter Bresciani, broker.

A COLLECTION of thirty paintings by Bantu boys from the African Art Center, Salisbury, Southern Rhodesia, will go on view today in the Junior Museum Studio at The Metropolitan Museum of Art. The boys, about half of whom are from the "bush," ranging in age from 9 to 14 years, belong to a group of pastoral nomads who boast no artistic tradition.
Idlewild's "dream city" will move a step closer to completion this morning when American Airlines' eye-catching terminal with a stained-glass facade opens for business.
Governor Rockefeller accepted the resignation of Otto L. Nelson Jr. yesterday as chairman of the state commission investigating New York City.
OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. 9 (UPI) -- Eddie Erdelatz was hired today to coach Oakland's team in the new American Football League.

WAKING in the night, terrified by nameless and unidentified horrors, it is always comforting to be able to cling to reality and say to one's self: "It was only a nightmare. Something I ate, no doubt." And nightmares don't last long. They either wake us up or they fade away.

Companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange paid record cash, dividends of $9,336,518,000 last year. That was some $631,000,000 more than was paid by the same companies in 1958.

A Kings County grand jury reported yesterday that there had been 10,000 fewer claimants for relief from the Welfare Department since it began its inquiry into alleged chiseling in September, 1958.
A reduction in borrowing cost from 3.861 to 3.822 per cent was registered yesterday In the first public sale of housing bonds subsidized by the Federal Government since October.

GLADYS STEIN presented a kind of program last night in Carnegie Hall that even Schnabel would have thought twice about. Alien Industries Alien Industries, Inc., yesterday declared a 30-cent quarterly dividend on the common stock, payable on March 15 to holders of record of March 1. Last year the company paid 25 cents quarterly with a 25 per cent stock dividend in September.
HEIDELBERG, Germany, Feb. 8 -- The new West German Army flexed its growing muscles in Exercise Wintershield and found both strengths and weaknesses.

BELGRADE, Feb. 10 (UPI) -- Archbishop Jodsip UJcic of Belgrade took over acting leadership of the Roman Catholic Church in Yugoslavia today after Cardinal Stepinac's death and promptly proclaimed a week of mourning.

John G. (Steve) Broady, the 56-year-old former lawyer private investigator who a, ready is serving two to four years in prison for illegal wire tapping, was indicted again yesterday for illegal eavesdropping. He pleaded not guilty to the eleven-count indictment.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 3 points off to 6 points up yesterday. The far months showed the most strength. A point Is equal to 5 cents a bale.

The Diplomatic Tourist Sales Company, a shopping center catering to United Nations personnel and for export sales for foreign visitors leased space in 101 West Thirty-first Street for a showroom and general offices.

BUFFALO, Feb. 10 -- Governor Rockefeller applauded Vice President Nixon tonight for urging the Republican party to campaign in I960 on a forward-looking program. It was the first public mention of Mr. Nixon by the Governor since he announced the day after Christmas he would not be a candidate for the Republican nomination for President.

A Brooklyn butcher testified yesterday in Kings County Court that Frederick J. Loughran, former director of the Bureau of Weights and Measures, had demanded "a couple of thousand" to overlook the butcher's practice of short-weighing meat.
HICKSVILLE, L. I., Feb. 10 -- The installation of a $500,000 traffic control system for Its Port Jefferson branch was announced today by the Long Island Rail Road.

NEWPORT, Ore., Feb. 10 (AP) -- The Administration's policy of high interest rates and tight money has cost the nation heavily, Senator John F. Kennedy asserted tonight.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Liquidation of grain futures increased in the last few minutes on the Board of Trade today and nearly all contracts posted their steepest setbacks of the week.

THE Orchestra of America completed its first season last night at Carnegie Hall. Taking advantage of the nearness of Lincoln's birthday, Richard Korn, the orchestra's musical director, built this, the fifth and final program, around the Civil War President.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization of parents, lists the following films as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old. They will be shown through Sunday, unless otherwise noted.
After three days of visits to high achools and colleges here, a leading Soviet education official reported yesterday that he was highly impressed.
A new approach to medical advertising that would give physicians an easier access to current medical information is expected to be introduced in September by the Radio Corporation of America.
Low-income families are being stampeded into inflated installment buying of everything from cradles to graves, a group of settlement houses charged here yesterday.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Jan. 31 -- A showpiece of American aid in Ethiopia is a survey to determine to what extent Ethiopia may some day compete with Egypt and the Sudan for waters of the Nile.

The fifteen-story apartment house on plot 115 by 100 feet at 419 East Fifty-seventh Street was sold by tha Edgerly Realty Corporation to Leonard S. Kandell for investment. Henry Hart Rice, vice president of James Felt Co., and Norman E. King were the co-brokers.
General Electric Company announced yesterday the development of a line of "ultra-lightweight" gas turbines that are expected to find fields in which mobility and small size are required.

SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., Feb. 10 -- Weather conditions that have threatened the winter Olympic Games continued to improve today. Major segments of the $11,000,000 snow-sports plan went back into operation, accompanied by a generous measure of confusion and complaint.
Lincoln's Birthday will be observed tomorrow as a holiday by most New Yorkers, a regular working day by many and an occasion for speeches, dinners and memorial services by a few.

"THE FINAL BALL," by Gerd Gaiser, is a novel about post-war Germany, gripped with a heritage of remorse and a prospect of unexpected prosperity. The material dangers of affluence seem to weigh more heavily on the author's mind than the spiritual burden of remorse. You'd almost think a few of these people had been condemned to grow rich as a penalty for losing a barbaric war.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The curious case of barbed wire imports was reopened today by the Tariff Commission.
BONN, Germany Feb. 10 -- Chancellor Adenauer disclosed today that the Soviet Union had rejected the idea of a vote by West Berlin to decide its future.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- Both New York City and upstate rural areas showed increases in arrests for major crimes last year, the State Correction Commissioner reported today.
RALEIGH, N.C., Feb. 10 -- Negro student demonstrations against segregated lunch counters spread today to variety stores in this state capital. It is the sixth North Carolina city to be affected.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- New regulations to prevent ships on the Great Lakes and St. Lawrence Seaway from polluting water supplies of port communities were announced today by the Public Health Service.
GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 10 -- The National Council of the Protestant Episcopal Church plans to build a $3,500,000 headquarters in midtown Manhattan.
GOLDEN, Colo., Feb. 10 (AP) -- Authorities today abandoned organized search for Adolph Coors 3d, millionaire brewer and industrialist, who has been missing since yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 10 -- During the last decade the steadily expanding importance of fishmeal has made it a "sleeper" commodity on the international market.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- A housewife today told a House committee looking into food and color additives that it was virtually impossible these days to find a "plain food, with nothing added or taken away."

PARIS, Feb. 10 -- President de Gaulle and his Government ordered sweeping civil and military reforms for Algeria today. The action is intended to prevent repetition of last month's insurrection in Algiers by Europian settlers.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In connection with the current debate on defense I should like to call attention to the article by Hanson Baldwin on Jan. 26 headed "Rough Seas for Carriers" touching upon an important feature of our defense.

MANOUCHER YEKTAI is by birth an Iranian but his painting personality emerged in the United States. The prevailing American expressionism is reflected in his show of recent landscapes, still-lifes and figures at the Poindexter Gallery, 21 West Fifty-sixth Street.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The Soviet Union paid the United States $1,100,000 today to settle a number of maritime claims incurred during World War II.

Otto L. Nelson Jr. has resigned as chairman of the State Commission on Governmental Operations of the City of New York, and his resignation has been followed by the departure of several staff employes. Thus a sizable reorganization of the commission seems to be under way, Mr. Nelson was and is a man of unquestioned integrity, fairness and ability, moved by a desire to be of public service.

The United States has "an immediate and almost desperate" need for forty-three new Federal judges, the president of the American Bar Association said here yesterday. He urged support for the Omnibus Judgeship Bill, which would create more Federal judgeships, now before Congress.
NEW DELHI, India, Thursday, Feb. 11 -- India prepared today for another high point in the busiest diplomatic season she has ever had, the arrival of Premier Khrushchev.
JOHN McGRAW made the gravest mistake of an otherwise notable career when, in a fit of pique, he drove the Yankees out of the Polo Grounds almost forty years ago.

The Reynolds Metals Company in 1959 had the best sales and earnings in its thirty-two year history, R. S. Reynolds Jr., president, reported yesterday. Fourth-quar- ter earnings were the larges for any quarter thus far.
TULSA, Okla., Feb. 10 -- Are affiliated companies violating the Sherman Antitrust Act when they agree on prices?

Uncertainty continued to rule the stock market yesterday. Prices on the New York Stock Exchange were up a little at the opening, fell steadily until the fifth hour, then rallied to the close. The loss In market value, however, was about $1,900,000,000.

HAVERFORD, Pa., Feb. 10 -- Mrs. Carter Simonin, the New Jersey and Connecticut title-holder from Philadelphia, gained the semi-final round of the Pennsylvania State squash racquets championship by scoring a 15-12, 15-7,15-10 victory over Mrs. Walter B. Mahony Jr., Chappaqua, N. Y., today at the Merion Cricket Club.

Five years have gone by since A. E. Hotchner indicated he was planning a dramatization based on some works of Ernest Hemingway. Yesterday it became known that the package was wrapped up by Mr. Hotchner, author-TV writer, who has not been represented on the stage previously.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Feb. 10 -- President Eisenhower spent three hours today acquainting himself with the intricacies of rocketry and space exploration at the Atlantic missile range here. He pronounced the experience "worth while."
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 10 -- Belgium proposed today a treaty of friendship, assistance and technical cooperation with an independent Congo. The Belgian Congo is to achieve independence June 30.
LONDON, Feb. 10 -- A dispute developed today between the African and the Asian and Arab delegates to the Kenya constitutional conference.

DURANGO, Colo., Feb. 10 -- Business was combined with pleasure today as the United States Olympic cross-country ski team concluded its pre-Squaw Valley training operations. Tomorrow the team will emplane for the California winter games center.

The Fifth Avenue Fellowship of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church will benefit from a concert by Adele Addison, soprano. She will appear on the evening of March 7 in the Hunter College Assembly Hall.
CHICAGO. Feb. 10 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markels here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Lou Rossini, the New York University basKetball coach, saw enough of Jerry West, the West Virginia star, Monday night to last him for a considerable spell. Tonight at Madison Square Garden it will be the task of Coach Joe Lapchick and his St. John's University players to attempt to check the slick Mountaineer.
A block of 200,000 common shares in the California Water and Telephone Company are being offered to the public today by a syndicate led by Blyth Co. The price is $27 a share.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 10 -- Two campus leaders resigned from their eating club at Princeton University today and joined Woodrow Wilson Lodge, the university-sponsored club.
Two Federal agenciejs appeared yesterday to be scuffling for the ball in a controversial action involving the behavior of steamship conferences and their member ship lines.

New York savings banks would be permitted to convert to state-chartered savings and loan associations and state-chartered savings and loan associations would be permitted to convert to savings banks under one of four banking bills introduced at Albany by Assemblyman Lawrence P. Murphy, Democrat of Brooklyn.

The Missouri Pacific Railroad Company, which is diversifying, continued to accumulate class A capital stock of the Mississippi River Fuel Corporation last month, increasing its holdings by 12,300 shares to 259,500 shares.

A resolution calling for the repeal of the 10 per cent Federal excise tax on legitimate theatre admissions was passed yesterday by the American National Theatre and Academy at its annual business meeting at the ANTA Theatre.

BERLIN, Feb. 10 -- East Germany set up today a twelve-member National Defense Council to organize and streamline the country's security system and named the Communist leader, Walter Ulbricht, the council's first president.

Otto L. Nelson Jr., who resigned Tuesday as chairman of the state commission investigating New York City, was accused yesterday of a conflict of interest in representing the New York Life Insurance Company in a case before, the city's Board of Standards and Appeals.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Feb. 10 -- Julian Amery, British Colonial Under Secretary, flew home from Cyprus tonight after his departure earlier in the day was postponed by a series of unscheduled talks.
Mayor Wagner announced yesterday the appointment of Arthur J. Benline as Commissioner of Air Pollution Control.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 10 (AP) -- Yale scored all of its goals within four minutes tonight and beat Rensselaer Poly, 3 -- 2, in hockey.

W. Alston Flagg Jr. of the Racquet and Tennis Club, seeded fourth, was among the winners in quarter-final-round play in Class A of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association championship last night at the Harvard Club.

Bank of California, The Bank of California, National Association, San Francisco, is planning a rights offering of 256,930 shares in the ratio of one new common share for each five held by stockholders on March 29.
Yet More About "The War" And still they come from the presses -- the Civil War books. About battles, generals, Lincoln, Davis, Lee, Grant. The material seems inexhaustible.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- A Federal court jury today convicted Edward F. Weinheimer of falsely denying that he handled a labor peace payoff for a Pennsylvania trucking concern.

CHATHAM, N.J., Feb. 10 -- Mr. and Mrs. Henry E. Sharpe have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Ann Sharpe, to Alan H. Reider. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Reider of Schuykill Haven, Pa.

Mrs. John Jay Ide, benefit committee chairman, has announced patrons and patronesses for Monday's modern-dress performance of Mollere's "Le Misanthrope" at the Phoenix Theatre. The event will be followed by an after-theatre champagne supper dance at the Astor.

"IN the spring a young man's fancy lightly turns to thoughts of love," so the saying goes. But this has no bearing at Plummer's. Here love has no season; prospective brides inundate the store all year around.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Feb. 10 -- Chief Justice Joseph Weintraub of the New Jersey Supreme Court, who disqualified himself in a housing bias decision handed down yesterday involving Levitt Sons, Inc., has been married since Jan. 29 to the former wife of William Levitt, head of the home-building concern.

William T. Rossell, president, director and trustee of the Transit Research Corporation, died yesterday in Long Island College Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 72 years old and lived at 24 Georgia Avenue, Long Beach, L.I.
One of the oddest historica documents of modern times --a receipt for an entire country -- arrived here recently from England and will be auctioned on March 2.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The foreign ministers of six Western powers are planning to meet in Washington in mid-April to survey plans for the East-West summit meeting one month later.

The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company announced yesterday that it was increasing prices of replacement tires by 3 per cent on certain of its passenger lines and from 3 to 5 per cent on most truck tires. The action is expected to trigger increases throughout the industry.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Jack Egan scored 29 points tonight and led St. Joseph's quintet to a 78-73 victor over St. Peter's of Jersey City at the Palestra.
TRENTON, Feb. 10 -- The presidents of New Jersey's six state colleges warned today that they could not obtain good professors unless salaries were raised.

Dr, George N. Shuster, retiring president of Hunter College, called yesterday for greater appreciation of Chancellor Adenauer's "tremendous service" in trying to stamp out anti-Semitism in West Germany.
A little more thaw a year ago the Chase Manhattan Bank began its retail charge plan here. Yesterday Clinton W. Schwer, vice president charge, reported on the , operation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- An unidentified, silent satellite has been discovered circling the earth in a near-polar orbit by United States tracking stations, the Defense Department said today. The identity and origin of the mystery satellite -- which has been dubbed "the dark satellite" are not known despite nearly two weeks of tracking.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The Soviet Union made two unsuccessful launching attempts during its recent test firings of a powerful new rocket into the Pacific Ocean, United States officials said today.
CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Feb. 10 -- The Dominican Government called a news conference today to accuse Roman Catholic bishops of insincerity in protesting the recent wave of arrests.
The prices of prime fixed-income securities fluctuated in uncertain fashion yejterday, with weakness dominant.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In connection with your Jan. 25 article "Rise in Racial Extremism Worries Harlem Leaders" I would like to make it clear that I have no desire to take part in the dispute it involves or to interfere in the activities of the various groups listed in the article.

MIAMI, Feb. 10 -- Royal Native, owned by Perne L. Grisom, capped a formful day Hialeah by winning the Columbiana Handicap today. The 4 year-old daughter of Royal Charger scored easily in the seven-furlong race, enjoying a margin of almost five lengths ver the runner-up, J. G. Krams' Starlet Miss.
Tenements owned by Herbert S. Wolfe, a former physician against whom action by State Attorney General Louis L. Lefkowitz is pending, were involved in Housing Court cases yesterday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10 (UPI) -- The Chicago Black Hawks tonight beat the New York Rangers for the sixth straight time at home this season, triumphing by 5 -- 1. Even the Hawks' goalie, Glenn Hall, got in on the scoring.

A campaign to enshrine Jefferson Davis in the Hall of Fame here is under way, but it has been given about as much chance for success as his supporters had originally to to keep him in office as President of the Confederacy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- House investigators heard testimony today that more than 8,000 bridges on the interstate highway system were too low to meet modern defense needs. Of this total, 2,259 have been constructed or authorized since the interstate system was inaugurated in 1956.
ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- Mayor Wagner told the Legislature's fiscal committees today that Governor Rockefeller's $2,035,000,000 state budget showed a callous disregard for New York City's needs.
Eighty-one European athletes arrived yesterday at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, enroute to the winter Olympic Games at Squaw Valley, Calif.
Four staff members of the state commission investigating the city's affairs have resigned, three of them after talks with former Lieut. Gov. Frank C. Moore, the new acting chairman.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (UPI) -- Sixteen House Democrats accepted President Eisenhower's challenge today and introduced a new "Brannan Plan" bill that would pay farmers direct Federal subsidies if prices dipped too low.
ALGIERS, Feb. 10 -- The French Army and the European community were struck hard tonight by announcement of the Cabinet decisions in Paris.

An iron broom has been sweeping through Algeria, as President de Gaulle employs the neat-dictatorial powers voted him to root out military disaffection and civilian subversion and clear the way for a more energetic "pacification" of the Moslem rebels and for Algerian self-detirmination. That sweep is likely to be intensified under the new decrees issued by President de Gaulle to tighten up the penal code and to speedup the judicial processes.

President Gronchi of Italy now knows just how Vice President Nixon felt in Moscow when Premier Khrushchev criticized, argued and joshed him in undiplomatic fashion. This is what happened to the Italian President and his Foreign Minister Giuseppe Pella at a reception the Italians gave in Moscow on Monday.
The plan by the Radio Corporation of America to put a closed-circuit FM radio system in doctors' offices has already raised a storm in the pharmaceuticals advertising business.
DELRAY BEACH, Fla., Feb. 10 (AP) -- The defending champions and the medalists in the twenty-fifth annual national amateur mixed foursomes golf tournament moved through the first round today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) A publishing company here sought today to overturn a court ruling that Vice Admiral Hyman G. Rickover's speeches could not be published without his permission.
THE 1960 queen of fashion will be a princess.

INTERIOR designers of the future may have to know as much about sound as furniture arrangement. A demonstration of coordinated light and sound in the homes of tomorrow, which goes on view today at Macy's, makes it apparent that light, when triggered by music, can alter the mood of a room.

FORT COLLINS, Colo., Feb. 10 (AP) -- A group of Soviet officials collided verbally with Gov. Stephen L.R. McNichols today, then spent the rest of the day touring the fanning area of northern Colorado.

"I don't think I would ever want to go through with that again," said Mrs. Clara Alford at the Hotel Taft yesterday. The slight, copper - skinned woman with the rich, dark hair tied in a ponytail was not referring to the victory she had achieved Tuesday night with a Pekingese, Ch. Chik T'Sun of Caversham, in the greatest of American dog shows.
Al Goldfarb's foul shot with eleven seconds remaining enabled Hunter's basketball team to beat Adelphi, 62 -- 61, last night in a Tri-State League game at the winner's court in the Bronx.

Stockholders of Francisco Sugar Company were told at the annual meeting yesterday that the company had not received any offer of compensation from the Cuban Government for its intervention last November into the company's 23,000-acre cattle operation.
Governor Rockefeller has been urged to curb some well known New York institutions from what was said to be a move to oust long-time tenants from rent-controlled apartment buildings.
Seven guest conductors will appear with the New York Philharmonic next season. Four of them will be making their debut with the orchestra.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Opposing factions in a proxy fight for control of Managed Funds, Inc., St. Louis, agreed today to adjourn the annual meeting until March 11 in St. Louis to permit completion of proxy solicitations.

Domestic production of crude oil last week was at the highest level In thirty-two months. Output at that time was high because of reduced shipments from the Middle East following the Suez Canal crisis.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 10 -- There was considerable disagreement here today about the effect of the movie writers strike on film production.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 10 -- Winning eight of ten events, Yale scored a 67-27 swimming victory over Columbia in the Payne Whitney Gymnasium tonight.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The Navy announced today the fourth trip by United States atomic submarines to the North Pole.
MAX LIEBMAN, who in television's earlier days produced "Your Show of Shows," returned to the medium last night with a small revue on the American cowboy.
LONDON, Feb. 10 -- Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lioyd vehemently assailed today those in Britain who conduct a propaganda campaign against West Germany.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 10 Chilean Government leaders plan to discuss with President Eisenhower the Chilean proposal for a Latin-American disarmament conference.

Representative Herbert Zelenko, chairman of a House Merchant Marine subcommittee, said yesterday he would call for an "immediate full-scale investiation" of Frederick H. Mueller Secretary of Commerce, and Clarence G. Morse, head of the Maritime Administration.
Continued long liquidation and uncovering of stop-loss orders weakened potato futures yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange in active trading.

Directors of the Krattcr Corporation yesterday increased the monthly dividend on the classes A and B stock with the declaration of 10 cents a share for payment on April 1 to holders of record of March 15. This raises the dividend on both classes of stock to $1.20 a year from the former tate of $1.08.
A warning of possible disaster resulting from the improper conversion of some buildings to places of public assembly was sounded yesterday.

The Underwood Corporation may discharge as many as eighty electronic engineers at its Hartford, Conn., research and development department. This was announced yesterday by Luigi Gandi, an Underwood director and a director of Olivetti of Italy, which recently purchased a substantial, if not controlling, interest in Underwood.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 10 -- Alojzije Cardinal Stepinac, whose conviction in 1946 on war crimes charges signaled the start of the post-war struggle between church and state in Eastern Europe, died today. He was 61 years old.

The American Presidency is examined in two forthcoming books. To be published next Thursday by Doubleday is "The Splendid Misery: The Story of the Presidency and Power Politics at Close Range." Jack Bell the author, draws on his twenty-three years as a Washington reporter to give the pattern by which the workaday functions of the country's highest office are carried out.
The enormous cost of various Federal programs is a time-bomb threatening the country's fiscal future, Secretary of Commerce Frederick H. Mueller warned here yesterday.
This week-end the Jewish Chronic Disease Hospital in Brooklyn will benefit from the efforts of five of its auxiliaries which are holding fund-raising functions.
EASTON, Pa., Feb. 10 -- Two teen-agers needed the wisdom of Solomon today to obey a court's instructions on being good neighbors.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- new item of controversy was added today to the "confusion over the national intelligence estimates of Soviet missile progress.

De La Salle Institute at 160 West Seventy-fourth Street, a Roman Catholic high school for boys for more than 112 years, will go out of existence voluntarily in June because of building code violations.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Eighteen record companies and a radio corporation ran up a hotel bill of $117,664.95 at a disk jockeys' convention in Miami Beach last year, House investigators disclosed today.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 10 -- The merged labor federation took the first step today toward endorsing a Presidential candidate this year.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 10 -- The Rabbinical Council of America today asked all state legislatures to establish commissions to study "potentially dangerous problems of sectarian influence in governmental and public institutions."

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- Wall Street's big recovery yesterday was the dominating influence on the stock market here today. It was also helped by hopes that Government intervention would avert a nation-wide rail strike set for next Sunday.

The employment of screen writers with "possibly suspect" political records will be debated on television by Stanley Kramer, a prominent independent producer, and Martin B. McKneally, national commander of the American Legion.
TORONTO, Feb. 10 (UPI) -- Maurice (Rocket) Richard fired two goals tonight as the Montreal Canadiens beat the Toronto Maple Leafs, 4 -- 2, in a National Hockey League game.

CAIRO, Feb. 11 (Reuters) -- The Arab League has agreed at a closed meeting here on the circumstances in which war would be declared to prevent Israeli attempts to divert the waters of the River Jordan, the authoritative newspaper Al Ahram reported today.
The Chrysler Corporation Incurred a net loss of $5,431,024 in 1959. This was $28,393,541 less than the 1958 loss of $33,824,565. Sales rose 22 per cent to $2,642,980,037 from $2,165,381,754.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 5 points (25 cents a bale) off to 24 ($1.20) up yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The Federal Communications Commission joined today in the demand to make deceit on the airwaves a crime.

THAT comforting cup of coffee is loaded with potential danger if there are very young children in the home. This somewhat surprising information is underscored in a report from the American Academy of Pediatrics.

An agreement has been reached between Aluminium Ltd., and Aluminum Company of America whereby Alcoa will pay $9,000,000 in 1960 to the Canadian producer to cancel a contract between the two companies, it was disclosed yesterday.

The Face of Lincoln Poems have been written about the rugged earthiness of Lincol's features. Speeches and sermons have been made on the lines of his face. Essays and cartoons have taken advantage of his awkward, lanky figure and the completely unsophisticated manner in which he carried himself.
SYRACUSE, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Dolph Schayes scored 33 points tonight to lead the Syracuse Nationals to a 116-109 victory over the New York Knicker-bockers.
A New York heart surgeon yesterday reported "encouraging" progress toward the development of a method for correcting coronary artery disease without surgery.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Relative to your editorial of Feb. 8 entitled "A Call for Greatness," I should like to make the following comments:
WlNDHOEK, South-West Africa, Feb. 11 -- The political future of South-West Africa is becoming a matter of growing concern to the territory's dominant white minority.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- New York City's chances of getting new anti-slum measures from this session of the Legislature brightened today with the filing of Republican bills backing proposals of the Wagner administration.
Thirty private-school girls from 13 to 16 years old have volunteered to spend an afternoon a week helping care for 220 nursery-age children.

The American Optical Company, manufacturer of optical materials, has leased 6,000 square feet of store-floor space in the Pan-American Magazine Building, 1150 Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue), between Forty-fourth and Forty-fifth Streets.

A NEW electric clothes dryer that collapses for storage is being introduced by Hammacher Schlemmer. Made by the Wonder-Fold Home Dryer Company, the white enamel dryer is a standard-size, box shape, thirty-six inches high by twenty-six inches wide and twenty-six inches long. But after use, the front of the dryer can be retracted from its twenty-six-inch width to six inches converting it into a slim form rather like a long suitcase.
A Navy Department explanation of its tacit support of an Arab boycott against American-flag ships trading with Israel was described yesterday as "most inadequate" by the American Jewish Congress.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Premier Khrushchev's remark that Soviet success in hitting the moon with a rocket makes communism better than capitalism is "crazy," President Eisenhower said today.

President Lincoln was 56 years old on this day ninety-five years ago. He had had a busy two weeks. He had been down to Hampton Roads for a fruitless conference with three Confederate commissioners, one of whom, Alexander H. Stephens, Vice President of the Confederacy, was an old and once valued friend. Mr. Lincoln had held Cabinet meetings on Feb. 4, on the evening of Feb. 5, on Feb. 7 and on Feb. 10.

The Very Rev. Laurence J. McGinley, president of Fordham University, broke ground yesterday morning for the university's $25,500,000 Lincoln Square campus. It will be bounded by Amsterdam and Columbus Avenues and Sixtieth and Sixty-second Streets.
The United States Court of Appeals here struck a blow yesterday at the New York State law permitting wiretapping by the police and prosecutors.

DURANGO, Cola., Feb. 11 -- Sven Wiik, the coach of the United States Olympic Nordic ski squad, was anticipating his first meeting with his five-man combined team in eleven days when he left with his nine crosscountry specialists for Squaw Valley, Calif., today.
TOKYO, Feb. 11 (UPI) -- A Japanese shipping company has forecast that 1960 will be a favorable year for the tanker market because of a turn for the better in the excessive supply of tonnage.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Unofficial food rationing was imposed on Washington today by a strike of 1,400 butchers against five major food store chains. The five, and a sixth that shut its doors by agreement, normally supply 75 per cent of the food for homes in the capital area.
TUNIS, Feb. 11 -- Algerian nationalist leaders here view the house-cleaning by President de Gaulle in the French Army and among civilians as an essential move toward peace in Algeria.

WHAT has been called "cold" painting admits broad interpretation. In its long twentieth-century line, there are the sharp-angled abstractions of the Cubists, the precise nonobjective paintings of the Constructivists, the rectilinear compositions of Mondrian and his followers, and finally, the variations that have occurred since the Nineteen Thirties, all lingering in one way or another with geometric shapes.

The nation's private atomic power industry called on the Atomic Energy Commission yesterday to clarify its policies and intentions with regard to the placement of future work under the A.E.C.'s research and development program.
Gaspar (Indian) Ortega of Mexicali, Mexico, rapidly overhauling Ralph (Tiger) Jones as boxing's most televised "actor," will be on view again tonight in Madison Square Garden.
ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Feb. 11 -- The body of Alojzije Cardinal Stepinac lay in state today in the little church in his native village of Krasic, near Zagreb.

A bill to give the state's mutual thrift institutions wider branch powers has been introduced at Albany under joint auspices of trade associations for the state's savings banks and savings and loan associations. It is the first time that the two groups have joined formally in an action of this kind.

Crum Forster Directors of Crum Forster, insurance underwriters, declared yesterday a common stock dividend of 60 cents payable on March 10 to holders of record of Feb. 25. The company paid 50 cents in previous quarters.

In a directorial career that goes back to 1935 and "Awake and Sing," Harold Clurman estimates that he has staged more than fifty plays. Now he is to undertake the direction of an off-Broadway entry for the first time.
Mayor Wagner urged the city's taxpayers and voters yesterday to bring political pressure on Republican leaders of the state to compel the Legislature to give the city fair fiscal treatment.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UPI) -- Following is the text of a White House statement on the new United States proposal for a ban on nuclear weapons teats:
Christopher Plununer will portray the late Oliver Wendell Holmes, Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, in a television drama titled "Autocrat and Son."

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : James Finucane, executive secretary of the Committee for Return of Confiscated German and Japanese Property, whose letter you printed on Feb. 6, argues against showing in today's Germany the film "Nuremberg," which documents the atrocities of the Nazi regime.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Feb. 11 -- Plans to convert the Great Swamp in Morris County into a wildlife preserve or additional county park land moved swiftly today. The Port of New York Authority has recommended the site for a $220,000,000 jet airport.
It didn't snow here yesterday, But it did everything else, sometimes all at once, as the weather ran quixotically through the full four-season gamut.

ONE symbol of status, not to be confused with tail fins on longer-than-life cars or other noisy manifestations of money, is a mild-mannered arch conservative named Mainbocher. He stands alone in America as the only couturier who heads his own house and is lauded alike by young society women, famous Broadway actresses and even grandmothers.
LINCOLN'S Birthday does not command its own menu, beyond the possible inclusion of a log cake. Perhaps this is why chain store specials cover such a wide assortment of meats this week-end.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Rail and truck loadings last week showed increases over the levels of a year ago. But rail freight was down and truck haulage only slightly above the level of the week before.

THE first part of Jack C. Richardson's "The Prodigal," which opened last night at the Downtown Theatre, unfolds rather like a shadow dance. There are lights, figures and motions, but the meaningful details remain obscure.
ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 11 -- An Orthodox rabbi emphasized here today that Jewish religious law "does not advocate for Israel the establishment of a theocracy."

In a new effort to break the fifteen-month long deadlock at the Geneva conference on nuclear weapons tests the United States yesterday advanced a plan whose importance is emphasized by President Elsenhower's personal announcement of it.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The recent Administration comments on proposals for free hospital and nursing care of elderly citizens, to be paid for out of Federal revenues, marks another unwilling step by the Republican party toward the "welfare state" they long arraigned and opposed.
LONDON, Feb. 11 -- Yesterday's setback on Wall Street, coupled with the threat of a nation-wide railroad strike set for next Sunday put the brake on dealings in the stock market here today.

DURING one of the Giants' football games last fall, Eddie Erdelatz was discovered in a box seat belonging to Toots Shor. On second thought, it wasn't really a discovery. Eddie's host whacked an unseeing reporter on the head with his program and bellowed in his most genteel fashion:

LONDON, Feb. 11 -- Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd said tonight that agreement on West Berlin at the forthcoming summit conference remains "possible and desirable," in the view of the British Government.
The Department of Parks, with the cooperation of the police, has moved firmly to frustrate what one official described yesterday as "a concerted attempt to aid motorists."

Average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $42,000,000 to $850,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Reserves in excess of requirements declined $18,000,000 to $413,000,000.

BOSTON, Feb. 11 (UPI) -- Bob Armstrong's shot from the blue line with seventy-one seconds left proved the winning goal tonight as the Boston Bruins beat the Detroit Red Wings, 3 -- 2. The Bruins moved into a fourth-place tie with Chicago in the National Hockey League.

GENEVA, Feb. 11 -- Many things have been said in Geneva this past year about a rather lonely man given to solitary Sunday rambles through the streets of this city. Most of them have been rather kind things, and they have been said by people who have fought and haggled with him through more than 160 long and dreary technical talks.
CHICAGO, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
TAUNGGYI, Burma, Feb. 11 -- Scattered insurgent activity is causing anxiety and economic dislocation in the Shan States' plateau lands of eastern Burma.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- A New Jersey delegation met with Atomic Energy Commission officials today to explore the possibility of establishing a large atomic industrial park in the southern part of the state.

TOKYO, Feb. 6 -- Japanese-made outboard pleasure boats with a catamaran hull structure aft are expected to be put on the United States market in the latter part of this year. A fifteen-foot runabout with fiberglass reinforced plastic body and a sixteen-foot craft of aluminum construction are the first to be exported among a few types designed and built in Japan.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The Army disclosed with considerable elation today that it had successfully used an antiaircraft missile to destroy a ballistic missile in flight.

Whether the city needs revision in its zoning resolution was debated yesterday by James Felt, chairman of the City Planning Commission, and Frank Barrera, spokesman for the Metropolitan Association of Real Estate Boards.

CREWEL work, a fashionable first in England during the reign of Elizabeth I, is enjoying a renaissance under Elizabeth II. The embroidery technique of "painting" pictures on fabric with wool thread has been revived by the fabric concern that "upholstered" the present throne of England.
PARIS, Feb. 11 -- Farmers from the north of France clashed with policemen and firemen today in Amiens during a demonstration against the Government's agricultural policy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- President Eisenhower admonished Congressional and Pentagon critics of his defense policy today that they were not helping the nation's morale by making headlines over disagreements on weapons.
Eastern gymnastics supremacy will be at stake at West Point tomorrow in the dual meet between Penn State and Army.
Major crime in the city increased 4.8 per cent last year, continuing an upward trend that has prevailed for six years, the Police Department said yesterday.

Organized labor demanded yesterday that no further rate increases be granted to the Blue Cross here until a report on a study of the hospital insurance plan had been made public and completely reviewed.
Many agencies involved in advertising of pharmaceuticals are firmly opposed to the plan of the Radio Corporation of America to provide an FM medical information program for doctors.
LONDON, Feb. 11 -- With little hope of a settlement remaining, the Government has decided to ask Queen Elizabeth II to proclaim a state of emergency if there is a nation-wide railroad strike.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 11 -- Leaf tobacco harvests throughout the world rose slightly in 1959, but failed to match the record of 3,015,000 tons in 1956. The Food and Agriculture Organization, reporting in its January bulletin of statistics, estimated last year's output at 2,935,200 tons, exclusive of that of the Soviet Union and mainland China.

TO avoid fires in television sets the Greater New York Safety Council offers the following warnings:
CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Feb. 11 -- Forty more persons were sentenced here today to thirty-year terms at hard labor for participation in an alleged conspiracy against the Trujillo regime.

Robert L. Reynolds, director of sales of the plastics and coal chemicals division, Allied Chemical Corporation, died yesterday of a heart attack in a taxicab while on the way to his office at 40 Rector Street. He was 41 years old.

Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. was accused of "union-busting activity" yesterday. The charge was made by G d J. Ryan, president of the Unformed Firemen's Association, and John Corcoran, head of the Uniformed Fire Officers' Association.

The Nafi Corporation, formerly National Automotive Fibres, Inc., has entered into a contract for its projected purchase of the outstanding stock of Chris-Craft Corporation, it was announced yesterday by Paul V. Shields, chairman of Nafi.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 11 (AP) -- The Murchison interests of Texas have the right to advance the delivery date of Alleghany Corporation stock they are buying for $10,229,232 under the terms of an agreement signed with the widow of Robert R. Young, the late railroad financier.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 11 -- They call William S. Schlamm the "most disputed American in Germany."
