Gainer in this mix-up is the Kent Rockwell; customs inspectors are likely to tell him how much they enjoy his Saturday Evening Post coven and pass his luggage with barely a glance.
DETROIT, Feb. 13 -- A campaign for a modernized Constitution for Michigan was begun this week.

"IT appears that opinion will always treat this artist unjustly, whether in praise or blame." wrote the French painter, Jacques Emile Blanche, of James McNeill Whistler. Indeed, this "charming and unique painter" has been much under-valued, then overpraised, and now is under a cloud once more -- a cloud largely of his own making.

ALTHOUGH many parts of the country are still locked in winter's icy grip, it is spring in South Carolina. Charleston's three show gardens -- Magnolia, Middleton Place and Cypress -- are about to open their gates for the spring garden season.
ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- Governor Rockefeller's educational finance program, although modified to meet some criticism, still contains elements not likely to win the support of many Republican legislators.
Six composers were represented in Saturday night's Composers Group of New York concert at Carnegie Recital Hall.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 14 (UPI) -- Bill Collins and Jack Fleck tied for first place in the $22,500 Phoenix open golf tournament today and will meet tomorrow in an 18-hole play-off.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (UPI) -- The Cabinet Committee on Economic Policy, headed by Vice President Nixon, is having trouble agreeing on a policy statement dealing with the nation's economic growth.

Winners of the first annual playwriting contest, named in honor of Rosamond Gilder, were announced yesterday by the Maine Masque Theatre of the University of Maine. Miss Gilder is a board member of the American National Theatre and Academy and the director of the United States Center of the International Theatre Institute, air adjunct of ANTA.
KABUL, Afghanistan, Feb. 14 (AP) -- With Soviet assistance, Afghanistan is about to start on her second most ambitious valley development.
Better inter-group relations require appropriate education at home and in schools, a New York Times Youth Forum stressed yesterday. The topic was: "How can we combat bigotry?"
NAPLES, Italy, Feb. 14 -- The San Carlo Opera House was thrown into an uproar last night when the male lead of the opera "II Trovatore" leaped into a box and attacked a spectator.

The New York stock market has been undergoing a readjustment since the beginning of the new year that had by last week reached major proportions. At their low closing point of Thursday, just under 375, The New York Times stock market averages had shown a net decline from their January high of 44 points, leaving them at the lowest level since April of last year.

MONT TREMBLANT, Que., Feb. 14 (Canadian Press) -- Mary Moriarty, the defending champion, from Stowe, Vt., won the Ryan Cup giant slalom today, whipping through the fifty-six-gate course in 1 minute 59.6 seconds.
Governor Rockefeller yesterday bluntly put the blame for the rupture of friendly city-state relationships on Mayor Wagner and city representatives in the Legislature.

THE different kinds of white flour arrayed on supermarket shelves sometimes confuse shoppers. Should they choose the cake flour, the allpurpose flour or the one labeled as "self-rising"? At home the question arises as to whether one of those flours can be substituted for another in a recipe.
ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- A statewide plan to teach all teen-agers how to drive will be submitted to the Legislature tomorrow.

SWEET are the uses of nervous tension. It mobilizes the body against imminent peril. It stimulates the heart, which sends extra supplies of blood racing to the brain, enabling the individual to think more swiftly and creatively.
Mayor Wagner will make public today a city program "of considerable importance," his executive secretary announced yesterday.
Week Ended Feb. 11, 1960 Foreign exchange market was dull during the past week. British pound sterling and Canadian dollar fluctuated within a limited area on light turnover.

The stars of track and field, scattered all over the map in meets last week-end, will congregate in their greatest force of the winter at the Amateur Athletic Union's national indoor championships on Saturday.
Prices of cotton moved irregularly and in a narrow range in the domestic market last week.

DETROIT, Feb. 14 (UPI) -- Last-period goals by Toronto's Ron Stewart and Gerry James gave the Maple Leafs a 3-1 victory tonight over the slumping Detroit Red Wings, who now have won only one of their last eleven games.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The Atomic Energy Commission will offer a ten-year reactor program to Congress this week. It is designed to achieve economic nuclear electricity by the late Nineteen Sixties in areas of the United States that have high-cost power.
The Eastern Collegiate Athletic Conference may appeal to college officials to end player free-for-alls at basketball games.
Sales and earnings of the Colgate-Palmolive Company last year were the highest in its history, Edward H. Little, chairman and president, announced in the statement issued for release today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Tailfins, truth, the installment buying boom and the interest rates issue; those are the things that S. 2755 is made of.
Several major account changes dominate the advertising news today.
Members of the Community Church of New York were "frankly urged" yesterday to stop buying from two nationwide variety store chains because of their policy of racial segregation at lunch counters.

In a paper prepared for the American Assembly two years ago, Henry C. Wallich, the unobtrusive but articulate Professor of Economics on leave from Yale who is now serving as member of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, summed up the unenviable position that is the normal lot of the monetary authorities.
LONDON, Feb. 14 -- The threat of a nation-wide railroad strike slowed business on the Stock Exchange last week, but prices remained surprisingly firm.

Winter weather blew into New York from the South yesterday, but it outwitted the forecasters by proving much milder here than had been predicted. The main part of the storm veered farther west than had been expected.
Frank C. Moore expressed amazement yesterday that City Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa had joined in a statement with Mayor Wagner Saturday atacking fiscal proposals for the city.

RYE, N.Y., Feb. 14 -- Charles Ufford of the Harvard Club won the squash racquets tournament at the Apawamis Club today by beating Calvin MacCracken of the Englewood Field Club, 15 -- 12, 15 -- 10, 15 -- 7, in the final round.
PARIS, Feb. 14 -- French industrial production in 1960 should be double what it was in 1952, according to the calculations of experts here.
At least two-thirds of the sixty-two Democratic county chairmen in this state are leaning toward Senator John F. Kennedy as their candidate for the Democratic nomination for President.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Hong Kong, a crown colony of Britain, has been declared a country for certain purposes.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Ezra Taft Benson insists that he would not accept a Congressional farm measure that would increase price supports, even though it attempt strict controls of production.
ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- A proposal to modernize and simplify the New York laws governing all corporations will be placed before the Legislature tomorrow.
A CAREFULLY prepared, up-to-date report on "The Missile Race" was shown Saturday night in the "World Wide 60" series over Channel 4.
HELSINKI, Finland, Feb. 13 -- The short, white-haired Finn puffed on his pipe a bit and said quietly:

An American edition of Sir Anthony Eden's memoirs, called "Full Circle," will be published by Houghton Mifflin on March 1. Sir Anthony says that his book "is neither an apology nor a recrimination.'' It covers his range of experience in both national and international affairs from 1951, when he was Foreign Secretary, through his Premiership until his resignation because of illness in 1957.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Tom Heinsohn's 30-point performance paced the Boston Celtics to a 125-115 victory over the Philadelphia Warriors today. Wilt Chamberlain returned to action with the Warriors and set another National Basketball Association record.
The New York Catholic Charities served almost 600,000 men, women and children in the community through its central office and its 192 member agencies in 1959.
The Douglas Moore-John Latouche "Ballad of Baby Doe" was back at the City Center yesterday afternoon, still fresh and vital.

BOSTON, Feb. 14 (UPI) -- Harry Lumley turned in his second shutout of the season and the seventy-eighth of his long career tonight while pacing the Boston Bruins to a 3-0 victory over the New York Rangers and into third place of the National Hockey League.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, Feb. 14 -- Anders Glidje, 47 years old, and Arnold Berge, 52, shared the laurels today in the oldtimers' ski-jumping tournament.

A recent poll of state school commissioners has indicated that the classroom shortage is much less acute than it has been pictured, President Eisenhower's chief adviser on education matters said yesterday.
BHILAI, India, Feb. 14 -- Premier Khrushchev declared bitterly tonight that Western nations' economic aid to India was aimed to "get them profits."
VIENNA, Feb. 14 -- The Central Committee of the Hungarian Workers (Communist) party has decided to halt Hungary's land collectivization drive until further notice.
These are practically loafing days for Richard B. Fant, partner in charge of research and investment advisory services for E.F. Hutton Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange.

Is there any significance in the fact that two of Off Broadway's biggest hits, "The Connection" and "The Zoo Story," both of them initial works by young American writers, have suicidal heroes? Are Jack Gelber (author of "The Connection") and Edward Albee (author of "The Zoo Story") representatives of a nihilistic attitude in the American avantgarde theatre?
ALGIERS, Feb. 14 -- The possibility that Algerian nationalist leaders are about to make a bid for cease-fire talks has created new tension here among Europeans still shocked by recent events.

The New York City Opera saved its revival of Gian-Carlo Menotti's "The Consul" until Sunday for a special reason. It wanted Patricia Neway for the role of Magda Sorel, and Miss Neway, having a large role in the Broadway musical, "The Sound of Music," is only free on Sundays.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 14 -- President Mohammad Ayub Khan received a nearly unanimous vote of confidence today from 80,000 electors representing the people of Pakistan, according to preliminary results of a referendum available here tonight.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The President says he deplores public argument by military experts regarding our defense policy. Prior to this, he had called his critics parochial and had invoked his superior expertise in the subject. It is impossible, of course, for laymen to pass judgment on a debate of such technical complexity.
The tenth and last performance this season of the double bill, "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci" will take place on Wednesday, Feb. 24 at the Metropolitan Opera.
THE MOSCOW State Symphony Orchestra took its leave of New York with a lavish performance before 16,100 listeners at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

FRESNO, Calif., Feb. 14 -- If California's eighty-one votes at the Democratic National Convention were as elusive tonight as they were three days ago, it Was not because of any weekend loafing by Presidential aspirants.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 14 (AP) -- The world champion, Eugenio Monti, driving a borrowed sled, won the national Amateur Athletic Union twoman bobsled championship today.
A new scholarly publication, Labor History, will make its appearance today. It is published by the Tamiment Institute, a nonprofit, educational, cultural and social welfare organization.

Mrs. Lewis Iselin and Percy S. Weeks head the committee that is planning for a benefit on May 25 for the Leake and Watts Children's Home in Yonkers. It will be a dinner and an evening at the races at the Yonkers Raceway.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 30 -- Unlike the situation last year, when the collectivization campaign was centered in what is called Transdanubia -- the area between Budapest and the Austrian border -- the collectivization drive has been going on throughout the country.
The Old Twenty-fourth Street Clubhouse of Alcoholics Anonymous, with a fractional street address (334 1/2) and a front just wide enough to accommodate its door, was closed last night.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Feb. 14 -- Negro student demon- strations against segregated eating facilities have raised grave questions in the South over the future of the region's race relations. A sounding of opinion in the affected areas showed that much more might be involved than the matter of the Negro's right to sit at a lunch counter for a coffee break.

The pertinent question about the French A-bomb explosion in the Sahara is not whether the de Gaulle Government should have ordered it but what its effects will be on Western defense and the prospects for atomic disarmament.
The Port of New York last month made a good start toward another record year in customs revenues.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The Commerce Department named six veterans of Government service today as regional coordinators to insure uninterrupted performance of essential functions of the department in the event of an enemy attack.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- A former chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority called today for action by Congress or President Eisenhower to prevent construction of a dam that he said would destroy the Seneca Indian reservation in Western New York State.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A situation which is as distressing as the perpetuation of substandard housing in our city is the premature destruction of satisfactory buildings to make way for the construction of vast apartment buildings with prohibitive rents for the families displaced by the construction; and also the transformation of present structures into luxury dwellings, where the present inhabitants are similarly incapable of meeting the high rents.
American journalism, with brilliant exceptions, is falling short of its "enormous responsibility," Edward W. Barrett, dean of the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism, warned yesterday.
SAN JUAN, Dominican Republic, Feb. 13 -- An American-born Roman Catholic Bishop in this small Dominican city has called again, for an end of "excesses" by the Trujillo regime.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 14 -- No major parcels of land are left in Nassau County for development, according to a report made public today. The report noted that the county's greatest period of building activity occurred in the last decade.

ROME, Feb. 14 -- A large part of the inestimably valuable patrimony of art that Italy holds in trust for the world and that millions of tourists flock to Italy every year to see is threatened with destruction.

News that revision of the Local Governments article of the New York State Constitution has been delayed again, making its earliest effective date Jan. 1, 1964, instead of 1962, is disappointing, so disappointing in fact that it should not be accepted without a struggle. The postponement is announced by David W. Peck, chairman of the Temporary Commission on the Revision and Simplification of the Constitution.
CAIRO, Feb. 14 -- The United Arab Republic sought today to lead Asian-African "indignation and fury" against France for her atomic explosion in the Sahara yesterday.
ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 14 -- Governor Rockefeller today in effect endorsed the Federal aid to education program proposed by the Eisenhower Administration.
A rapidly flaring feud between Governor Rockefeller, a Republican, and Mayor Wagner, a Democrat, has many interesting political and other implications.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Feb. 14 -- The Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, president of the University of Notre Dame, proposed today that the right to vote be given to every citizen who meets the age and residence requirements of his state.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 14 -- Geoffrey Atkins of New York won the United States racquets singles championship today for the fifth time since 1954.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- United States officials expresses doubt today that they would have a systematic disarmament plan ready in time to submit to the Western disarmament delegation heads now meeting here.
SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., Feb. 14 -- Although the start of the winter Olympics is only four days away, the ice in the $3,500,000 indoor skating rink had more slush than slide today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Senator Allen J. Ellender joined the fight today against President Eisenhower's request to repeal a United States veto over the jurisdiction of the World Court.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 14 -- Robert (Junior) Johnson, a 28-year-old Ronda, N.C., hillside farmer, won the second annual Daytona International 500-mile stock car race today.
In a rugged contest played on an icy field, the Austria Football Club of Vienna was held to a 3-3 tie by Colombo of the American Soccer League at Gaelic Park, the Bronx, yesterday.
LEAVENWORTH, Wash., Feb. 14 (AP) -- Nineteen-year-old Gene Kotlarek of Duluth, Minn., went above 300 feet today in winning the twenty-ninth annual Leavenworth ski-jumping championship.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Feb. 14 (UPI) -- Authoritative sources said today that three top officials on Cyprus had initialed an agreement concerning the British bases that brings Cypriote independence a step closer.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UPI) -- Top Air Force officers agree that the Soviet Union should be credited with having more, not less, power to launch a ballistic-missile attack.
A Bishop who is president of the United Lutheran Church in Germany declared here yesterday that prejudice could be overcome only through the acceptance of the Christian theology.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The long-awaited civil rights debate will get under way in the Senate tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (UPI) -- "Right-to-work" laws have retarded industrialization of states that have adopted them, the National Council for Industrial Peace said in a report today.
HAVANA, Feb. 14 -- The Cuban Government is consciously moving closer to the Soviet Union to demonstrate its independence of the United States.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 14 -- Martin B. McKneally and Stanley Kramer clashed again today on the subject of whether movie producers should employ a writer regardless of his political past.
DAMASCUS, United Arab Republic, Feb. 14 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasaer arrived unexpectedly in Syria today amid renewed tensions on the Israeli frontier.
MOSCOW, Feb. 14 -- The Soviet people read a strongly worded Chinese warning in their leading newspaper today against United States tactics in the coming East-West negotiations.

The director of the Intergovernmental Committee for European Migration called yesterday for an accelerated movement of migrants from overpopulated free nations suffering from economic stress to other countries.
Ratio Ten to One There was a puzzling item in Variety the other day. In discussing Valentine Day cards, it noted the insult or tongue-in-cheek type cards outnumber the others, ten to one.
A 501-foot seagoing tanker will be cut in two, lengthened and broadened into a 730-foot bulk cargo ship for the Great Lakes iron ore trade.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: With the number of investigations going on in various parts of the city and state, some of which yield fruitful results and some of which result in a deplorable waste of the taxpayers' money, it would appear that one vast and vital field of activity is the highly profitable children's camp industry.

WHEN Columbia recently announced the appointment of a new director for its experimental Citizenship Program, it was expected that the move would meet with approval in educational circles. Few gave a thought however, to the fact that it also would reach all the way to the sports pages. Yet, that was inevitable.

AMERICAN women are getting slimmer all the time. A recent report from the Statistical Bureau of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company lists a definite decrease in the average weights of women. This diet-conscious development is making itself felt in the fashion world with a decline in the popularity of the larger sizes.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 14 -- The Argentine Navy today rained heavy explosives, which probably included depth charges flown here by the United States Navy, into the Golfo Nuevo in Patagonia.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy was accused last light of distorting crime staistics, imposing arrest quotas on policemen and lowering police morale.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 14 -- Ch. The Ring's Banshee, an exceptional 2-year-old basset hound owned by Chris G. Teeter of Birmingham, Mich., became best in show tonight in the thirty-eighth event of the Elm City Kennel Club.

PARIS. Stalin, as he was moving into Roman Catholic Europe, sneeringly asked a visitor: "And how many divisions does the Pope have?" Napoleon, a dictator with perhaps a keener sense of history, once answered this question.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 14 -- The United States has withdrawn three professors from a university in northeastern Brazil because one of them was the target of abuse by students who resented low grades. A class at the University of Recife in the state of Pernambuco had issued ultimatums against Prof. Max G. White, a United States geology teacher.

In his recent address before a conference of the American Bankers Association President John D. Randall of the American Bar Association suggested a good slogan to back up a plea for forty-three "almost desperately needed" new Federal judges: "Justice in need, justice delayed, justice denied." He also gave some impressive and timely figures to measure the delay in Connecticut and why it occurred, and showed how justice is being denied as a result.

Average American families are paying 42 per cent more for personal health services than they did in 1953, a survey shows. The total bill is now about $294 a year, the Health Information Foundation reported yesterday.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 14 -- A recession next year was predicted today by the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.

ST. GEORGE, Utah, Feb. 13 -- The days of the open Western range and of cowpunching have just about vanished. One of the last vestiges has been huge turkey flocks and "gobbler-herders." Now these too are becoming an anachronism.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 14 -- Pancho Gonzales defeated Ken Rosewall, 11 -- 9, 6 -- 1, in the feature match of Jack Kramer's professional tennis show at the Westchester County Center today before 1,200 fans.

The International Business Machines Corporation has developed a new automatic assembly system for making computer transistors, it was announced over the week-end. Transistors are tiny substitutes for vacuum tubes.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The Federal Aviation Agency is "bearing down hard" on the human errors that cause airplane accidents, Elwood R. Quesada, Administrator of the agency, said today.

A major target of income tax audit checks by the Internal Revenue Service this year will be underreported and unreported dividend and interest payments. After studies revealed a gap of $5,000,000,000 a year in the amount of dividends and interest paid to taxpayers and the amount reported on their income tax returns, the service undertook an educational program to close the gap.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 14 -- Steel output last week continued at peak levels, with no sign of any significant falling in the production rate. Most steelmakeers were scanning their books to see if order volume was approaching its peak and would soon level off.

Despite man's progress in science and living standards, history indicates that his tendency toward evil remains as strong as it ever was, the Rev. Bernard P. Donachie said yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral.
The following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is suggested for the main dish, which is easy to prepare.

Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa estimated at a record $781,168,000 yesterday the city's general fund revenues for the fiscal year starting next July 1. In a report to the Board of Estimate and the City Council, Mr. Gerosa predicted that the total would consist of $738,576,000 of actual receipts and a $42,592,000 cash carry-over on June 30 from the general fund for 1959-60.

Two loading religious periodicals -- one Protestant, the other Roman Catholic -- are publishing simultaneously this week an article laying down basic ground rules for furthering "conversations" between adherents of the two faiths.

IN a rare appearance here, the Minneapolis Symphony Orchestra introduced two American works new to New York at Carnegie Hall last night. They were Roger Sessions' Fourth Symphony and Gunther Schuller's "Seven Studies on Themes of Paul Klee."
More than 525,000 persons in the Greater New York area were assisted last year by the 221 agencies of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, the federation reported yesterday.

Following is the text of a reply yesterday by Frank C. Moore, acting chairman of the State Commission on Governmental Operations of the City of New York, to a statement issued jointly Saturday by Mayor Wagner and City Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa.
Everybody cried yesterday at a cheerleading contest in the Bronx.
TRENTON, Feb. 14 -- A major bid to attract New York's famous Washington Market and associated food enterprises to New Jersey will be made here tomorrow.
PARIS, Monday, Feb. 14 -- International hostility to France's successful explosion of an atomic bomb made hardly a dent in the sense of national pride evident in this morning's Paris press.
CHICAGO, Feb. 14 (UPI) -- Bobby Hull broke out of a ninegame scoring slump tonight to help the Chicago Black Hawks beat the Montreal Canadiens, 2 -- 0.
TRENTON, Feb. 14 -- Thorn Lord, a member of the Port of New York Authority, agreed today to become the organization candidate for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator.
Contracts for all types of new construction in the country last year (excluding Alaska and Hawaii) amounted to $36,269,000,000, a gain of 3 per cent over 1958.

THE 42-year-old priest who wants to make a drastic overhaul of voting procedures to guarantee civil rights for all, in the South and elsewhere, preaches for others the dramatic process of improvement that he practices at home.
MIAMI, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Jim Hearn overtook Alvin Dark in the final round today and won the national baseball players' golf championship.
Jack Paar said yesterday that he hoped to leave here by plane today or tomorrow on a vacation that may take him and his wife to South America or Mexico.

" TO Princess May and to all her family, Royalty was a profession -- the highest and the finest in the world." Her Serene Highness Princess Victoria Mary of Teck never doubted in her youth that royalty was a sacred duty as well as a noble profession and she did not change her opinion as she grew older.
THE London masters' pair tournament, which ended yesterday afternoon in England, was won by the only invited foreign pair in the field -- Georges Bourchtoff and Claude Delmouly of Paris.

COLOGNE, Germany, Feb. 15 -- Chancellor Adenauer said bluntly today that the non-Communist world risked the loss of West Germany if it jeopardized the freedom of West Berlin in negotiations with the Soviet Union.

MORE than 1,200 persons crowded the ballroom of the Hotel Astor yesterday to see what is considered by many to be the year's most spectacular fashion show, the sixteenth annual parade of styles for the benefit of the March of Dimes.
SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., Feb. 15 (UPI) -- A heated dispute broke out today between East and West German officials over the selection of the all-German team for the 1960 Olympic Winter Games.
PROVIDENCE, Feb. 15 (UPI) -- The National Boxing Association vacated Archie Moore's world light-heavyweight championship today "for his failure to defend within the prescribed six-month period."

RABAT, Morocco, Feb. 15 -- Accusing Paris of an "unfriendly attitude" in ignoring repeated protests against atomic tests in the Sahara, the Moroccan Government abrogated its diplomatic accord with France today and summoned home its Ambassador.

A Lifeless Boardwalk There is a sense of being Adam when one takes a long walk by one's self down the beach in winter. Or, if not the first man on earth, the last. The sand, flat and hard packed by the sea, shows not a footprint, save those of the lone stroller.
Paul Seymour, the coach of the Syracuse Nationals, was fined $150 yesterday for his scuffle with an official during a National Basketball Association game at Madison Square Garden last Wednesday.
HONG KONG, Feb. 15 -- Communist China has decided to strengthen further its spare-time army of peasants and workers, a formidable backstop for its regular forces.
MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., Feb. 15 (UPI) -- A Navy jet bomber crashed into a home today, exploding it in a mass of gasoline-fed flames that killed the pilot and a woman resident.
The Bell System shattered almost all of its previous records last year.

The New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday that it would accept bids for $27,750,000 in temporary loan notes on Tuesday, Feb. 23. The notes will be dated March 21, and will mature on Sept. 20. Proceeds from the sale will be used to continue the temporary financing of Castle Hill Houses, a state-aided public housing development in the Bronx.
The Columbia Gas System, Inc., reported yesterday that its gas sales rose to a new high for the fifteenth consecutive year in 1959, producing record gross revenues and net income.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: We should like, with your permission, to direct public attention to the cases of two men now serving sentences of thirty years' imprisonment for espionage. We feel that in both cases the sentences were excessive and that -- a full decade having passed -- an act of clemency is now in order.

World sugar futures registered one of the sharpest rises in more than a year yesterday in active trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Final quotations rose 3 to 13 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 65,100 tons.
SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., Feb. 15 -- Two European down-hill skiers, Battista Pordon of Italy and Luis Molne of Spain, went crashing out of the Olympic Winter Games today.

BUFFALO, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Assemblyman Joseph R. Young-love of Johnstown urged daily newspaper editors today to aid in curbing publishers of indecent literature. He called such publishers "parasites of printed poison."

Building inspectors from the Board of Education started a "intensive" city-wide check of school safety conditions yesterday, as a result of the collapse of a wall last Friday at an old East Side elementary school.
St. Bonaventure of Olean, N.Y., was selected as the sixth basketball team for the National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square Garden. The event gets under way March 10.

THE Cleveland Orchestra, which last year gave the world premiere of George Rochberg's Symphony No. 2 in Cleveland, last night gave the New York premiere of the work at Carnegie Hall. It made a deep impression.
SHOUL, Tuesday, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Death has erased President Syngman Rhee's major opponent in South Korea's presidential election for the third time in three campaigns.

A year ago, Dan Ferris predicted that five world records would be broken in the 1959 Amateur Athletic Union national indoor track and field championships. Sure enough, five marks were set. For good measure, another was tied.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower will send a special message on foreign aid to Congress tomorrow. He will ask about $4,170,000,000 to strengthen America's allies during the next fiscal year.
The IRT East Side subway was disrupted widely in yesterday's morning rush hour after a southbound express train broke down near the Eighty-sixth Street station.

SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 15 (UPI) -- Two horses from Down Under will compete in the $150,000 International Pacing Series at Yonkers Raceway.
"THE FLYING DUTCHMAN" was performed at the Metropolitan Opera last night, with Albert da Costa singing Erik for the first time with the company.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The Justice Department moved today to prevent the large steel companies from absorbing independent manufacturers of prefabricated metal buildings.

LONDON, Feb. 15 -- Prime Minister Macmillan returned from his 20,000-mile tour of Africa tonight confident that Ghana and Nigeria would seek close friendship with Britain and other members of the Commonwealth.
The City Housing Authority is recruiting a panel of art experts to help overcome the drabness that characterizes most low-rent public housing developments.

ALGIERS, Feb. 15 -- Conservative Europeans were gloating over reports today that the French Army was obstructing the arrest of two leading figures in last month's extremist insurrection who had sought refuge in the army's ranks.
SOUTHOLD, L.I., Feb. 15 -- A decommissioned baby aircraft carrier with a history of "fantastic luck" as e fighting ship almost lost a battle with high winds on Long Island Sound today.

ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- The State Education Department announced the winners of 7,511 state scholarships today. Of these, 6,211 were regents college awards, 1,000 regents science and engineering awards and 300 nursing scholarships.

BENJAMIN BRITTEN'S Nocturne for Tenor and Small Orchestra received its first New York performance last night in Town Hall by the Little Orchestra Society conducted by Thomas Scherman. But the other works on the program were so unhackneyed that, to all intents and purposes they could have been first performances, too.

RALEIGH, N.C., Feb. 15 (UPI) -- Negro students at North Carolina A T College who originated the sit-down demonstrations in Greensboro drafted an open letter today to State Attorney General Malcolm Seawell.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The Senate easily defeated a Southern move today to force a one-week delay in further action on civil rights. The vote was 61 to 28.

NEW DELHI, India, Wednesday, Feb. 17 -- Premier Khrushchev and Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru have declared that Soviet-Indian relations are now on "a firmer basis of friendship and understanding" than ever before.

AN unusual supermarket opens today on Thirty-fourth Street next door to the Empire state Building. The grocer, shelves and refrigerated cases of Dilbert's-34th Street stocked with wares that meet the needs of those who rush home after work and prepare dinner.
The St. Joseph Lead Company, the nation's largest producer of lead, has announced several changes involving high executives.

WASHINGTON. Feb. 16 -- President Eisenhower asked Congress today to provide $4,175,000,000 during the fiscal year beginning July 1 for continued military and economic aid abroad. The amount is about $1,000,000,000 more than that voted for the current fiscal year.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The letter published Feb. 13 from Lt. Col. Clinton Phillips, U.S.M.C., Retired, in defense of the Trujillo dictatorship is astounding at this late date. It is all too reminiscent of the "trains run on time" defense of Mussolini's tyranny a quarter of a century ago.

George Mikan, the greatest basketball player of the first half of this century, was among the 9,147 fans who found it hard to believe what they saw at Madison Square Garden last night as the New York Knickerbockers beat the Syracuse Nationals, 125 -- 116.
MIAMI, Feb. 16 -- Today's feature at Hialeah was run two divisions, and according to the time posted by the winners, it was a dead heat.

ABOARD U.S.S. GLACIER, Off Antarctica, Feb. 15 -- Two Navy icebreakers reached Thurston Peninsula today. The peninsula, dividing the Bellingshausen and Amundsen Seas, had never before been reached by water.
EVERYONE knows Columbus discovered America: The question is whether women are aware that Gimbels' shoe department has discovered Italy.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 16 -- Delegates from the Belgian Congo who are planning the independence of their country are concerned over the need to take measures to insure the financial stability of the new state.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- President Eisenhower will address the national legislative bodies of Brazil, Argentina, Chile and Uruguay on his forth- corning goodwill tour.

Seymour R. Candee, Morton Candee and Herbert Albert, realty investors and builders, are putting in the foundations for a seven-story apartment building at 406 to 412 West Thirty-fourth Street through the block to 405-07 West Thirty-third Street.

Mayor Wagner announced his Charter revision proposals on Monday with full commitments from the most influential Democratic leaders, in and out of government, to support all recommendations to be developed in the four-month study.

Snow Flakes for Tomorrow Whatever else the weather experts may predict or the elements actually produce tomorrow, the post office guarantees snow -- 120 million flakes of it, each in mathematical symmetry against a blue background.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 30 -- Hungary's Communist Government feels its relations with the Roman Catholic Church in the country are "satisfactory."

Electro Instruments Electro Instruments, Inc., San Diego, Calif., maker of electronic test equipment, has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering 78,000 shares of common stock.
A family of eight in Greenwich, Conn., has sent the fund for New York's Neediest Cases $20 and expressed the hope that it might be used to help another large family.

A WASHINGTON'S BIRTHDAY Youth Fitness Rally will be held at 10 A.M. on Monday at the Seventy-first Armory. Thirty-fourth Street and Park Avenue. More than 500 youngsters representing thirty youth groups will perform gymnastics and give exhibitions of fencing, bioyeling, wrestling and judo.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The country's five principal manufacturers of heavy electrical equipment and eighteen of their officers were indicted today on charges of rigged and collusive bidding in sales to Government and private industry.
The prosecutor in the Apalachin conspiracy case renewed a plea yesterday for a permanent unit to be set up in the United States Attorney General's office to prosecute crime syndicates.

Bubba Farr, Junior Johnson, Crawfish Crider, Fireball Roberts and Banjo Matthews have had two weeks of glory and excitement in the second annual stock car "jumblelee" at Daytona Beach. Now, along with Cotton Owens, Rosebud Flowers and all other colorful names of the jalopy and late-model divisions of racing, they fold their tents and await the opening of the regular season.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 16 -- A United States Navy anti-submarine-warfare expert was flown today to the scene of the Argentine Navy's search for an unidentified submarine.

DETROIT, Feb. 16 (UPI) -- Walter W. Fuller, fraternal editor of The Detroit News, today was under orders from the Imperial Potentate of the Shrine to show cause why he should not be ousted from the organization for reporting the removal of two officials of the Detroit Moslem Temple of the Shrine.

THE GOVERNOR Conferred with Dr. Paul Hoch, Commissioner of Mental Hygiene, and members of New York State Mental Hygiene Association. Conferred with Raymond W. Houston, Social Welfare Commissioner, and members of State Social Welfare Board.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The Secretary of Treasury refused today to promise reforms that a bloc of Senate Democrats insisted be made before Congress acted on repealing the interest rate ceiling on Government bonds.
The Weather Bureau will move its office here from the old Whitehall Building at 17 Battery Place to Rockefeller Center this summer.
WHAT Marlowe's "Tamburlaine" was to the sixteenth century, Camus's "Caligula" is to ours.
MOGADISHU, Somalia, Feb. 5 -- Premier Abdullahi Issa pleaded today for an end of the "misguided 'pessimism" about the future of this coastal territory, which will become independent, July 1.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Vladimir Bakaric, Communist chief of Croatia, said in a speech published today that the Communists were trying merely to keep politics out of religion and not to quarrel with the church.
Diana Barrymore bequeathed $35,000 of her $50,000 estate to friends and the residue to the Actors Fund of America. Her will was filed yesterday for probate in Surrogate's Court.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Senator John F. Kennedy accused Republicans on the Senate rackets committee today of having issued a biased statement and of having broken faith with their fellow members.
An interim agreement halting threatened division of Western Europe into rival trade blocs was termed a good possibility yesterday by a high-ranking official of the Common Market group.

Irrespective of any hope of lessened tensions between East and West, President Eisenhower has again warned Congress in a special message that "the menace of Communist imperialism * * * remains" and continues to threaten Communist world domination. Accordingly, he calls upon the United States and other free nations to join more closely in military and economic defense to meet this challenge.
WINDHOEK, South-West Africa, Feb. 14 -- Increasing political awareness among South-West Africa's 500,000 Africans has led in the last year to formation of two African political parties.

The West Coast representative of the Broadcasting and Film Commission of the National Council of Churches said here yesterday that the National Broadcasting Company had canceled plans to do a television play about a Protestant minister who commited adultery.
NOW is the time, while fishing and hunting temporarily are all but dead, for strong, hardy outdoorsmen to spend at least a cigaretwhile every day in sincere meditation on the virtues of tolerance.
The Pacific Intermountain Express Company and the United States Leasing Corporation are planning to merge if their boards and stockholders approve.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 16 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of a communique issued today on talks between Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru and Premier Khrushchev:
ALBANY, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The State Department of Commerce reported the following ski conditions today:

The Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday that 929 persons were injured in the city last week in traffic mishaps. This is a decrease of seventy-one compared with last year when 1,000 persons were injured in that period.
Sales of the nation's major chain and mail-order companies last month rose 4 per cent above the level of January, 1959, according to a survey completed yesterday by The New York Times.

TWENTY-EIGHT countries have entered the Olympiad World Championship Bridge Tournament to be played at Turin, Italy, April 23 to May 4. The countries will be represented by thirty-two teams, Alvin Landy of New York, secretary of the World Bridge Federation, has also announced.
Cotton futures moved 7 points (35 cents a bale) up to 8 points (40 cents) off yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

The appointment of Gordon K. Greenfield as president and a director of the America Corporation was announced yesterday by the directors. Mr. Greenfield will resign today as president of City Specialty Stores, Inc., at a meeting of that company's directors.

Commercial Credit Company, Baltimore, the nation's second largest independent sales finance company, reported net income yesterday of $27,860,866, or $5.48 a share for 1959, compared with $26,802,391 and $5.29 in 1958.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 16 (UPI) -- Billy Cannon, all-America halfback, today charged the Los Angeles Rams with "fraud and deceit" in signing him. He said a contract with that National Football League club was invalid.

ALTAMONT, Tenn., Feb. 16 -- Circuit Court Judge Chester C. Chattin revoked the charter of the Highlander Folk School today and ordered a receiver to "wind up" the affairs of the twenty-seven-year-old interracial adult education center.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Directors of the Pet Milk Company voted today a three-for-two split of common stock, provided stockholders authorize an increase in common stock.

SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., Feb. 16 -- Injured contestants already have started streaming off the Olympic slopes. And waiting for them -- if not, indeed, hauling them down -- is a Winter Games medical organization set up on battlefield lines.

PARIS, Feb. 16 -- The French Foreign Ministry said today that France had no intention of joining the nuclear test suspension talks now being conducted in Geneva by the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union.

THE Olympic Fund gained an unexpected contribution of 534 on May 5, 1956. It was the day John Landy of Australia, the then holder of the world record for the mile, was racing Ron Delany of Ireland, soon to be the Olympic 1,500-meter champion. They were matching strides in California but across the continent at Randalls Island Stadium track writers and other experts were evenly divided as to the winner.
The directors of the Fifth Avenue Association went on record yesterday in favor of a plan to build public garages in mid-Manhattan.

Automatic Canteen The Automatic Canteen Company of America ordered a 15-cent quarterly dividend on the new common stock, payable April 1 to holders of record March 15. This is equal to 30 cents on the old stock, split two for one in December, on which the company had paid 25 cents quarterly.

William Zeckendorf is seeking to sell the completed portion of Park West Village. This is the Title I slum-clearance project on the West Side that he took over in 1957 when the original sponsors were ousted for failing to proceed with construction.

The manufacturer of "Come Back Jack" buttons received bad news yesterday. The National Broadcasting Company announced that Jack Paar, who had been A.W.O.L. since last Thursday night, would return to his television program March 7.

Relations between New York City and Albany are at their worst for many a year. This hostility between the Wagner administration on the one hand and the Rockefeller administration and the Republican legislative leadership on the other can do nobody any good. It substitutes heat for reasonableness in the consideration of legislation.
KENOSHA, Wis., Feb. 16 -- Senator John F. Kennedy opened today what he called "my drive for victory" in the Wisconsin Presidential primary to the accompaniment of the recorded voice of Frank Sinatra.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (UPI) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's special message to Congress on foreign aid:
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is suggested for a comparatively easy-to-prepare main dish.
Stocks continued their general decline yesterday, breaking through all closing marks since last Feb. 19. Market values on the New York Stock Exchange fell some $2,400,000.

PARIS. It was originally hoped the Big Four summit meeting could be held late last year. Paris, however, objected and the conference was postponed until spring because de Gaulle had three reasons for urging delay.

The Appellate Division, First Department, yesterday set aside the dismissal of a New York City patrolman for allegedly failing to disclose past Communist affiliations. It ordered him reinstated to the Police Department.
Borough President Hulan E. Jack of Manhattan moved yesterday in General Sessions Court for two separate trials of the charges against him.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Most of us at some time have been patients in hospitals and know how much visits from friends mean. But when one is disabled by a longterm illness and the hospital is one's only home and often the volunteer is one's only friend, how much more do these visits signify.

President Meany of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. has expressed opposition to the proposed removal of the present interest rate ceiling on Treasury bonds. He declares that the effect of this proposal would be to increase the burden to the taxpayer for "carrying" the Government debt, which he tells us "already takes $12 out of every $100 in taxes each year."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Industrial production rose by 3 per cent in January and topped the peak reached before the steel strike, the Federal Reserve Board estimated today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Alien W. Dulles, director of the Central Intelligence Agency, made public today the names of the ten members of the United States Intelligence Board. He said it was in reponse to numer- ous inquiries.

GENEVA, Feb. 16 -- The Soviet Union offered to allow the West today to inspect just about any suspicious explosion on Soviet territory -- but only a few times a year. The offer and the limitation were the heart of a new proposal put forward at the negotiations for a treaty to ban nuclear tests.
"DON GIOVANNI" was presented at the Metropolitan Opera last night, with Calvin Marsh singing Masetto for the first time with the company.
January was the eighth consecutive month in which the American shipbuilding industry received no new orders.
KADUNA, Nigeria, Feb. 11 -- Northern Nigeria is slashing away vegetation in four-mile-wide swaths -- like firebreaks in a forest -- to halt the spread of sleeping sickness.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- President Eisenhower is considering making a radio and television address to the nation to try to clarify the controversy over the nation's defenses.
Snow Crop Frozen Orange Juice will begin a big push in the Northeast next month on behalf of what the company calls a much-improved version of its product.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: We in the city administration are always aware of the thoughtful consideration given to municipal problems in the editorial columns of The Times.

John Halpern of the City Athletic Club and Robert L. Gerry of the Racquet and Tennis Club won first-round matches yesterday in the Fowler Memorial invitation squash racquets tournament at the Seventh Regiment Armory.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Miss Carole Tregoff said today she was so terrified when Dr. R. Bernard Finch and his wife fought for a gun that she fled with never a thought for Dr. Finch.

DAMASCUS, United Arab Republic, Feb. 16 (UPI) -- The United Nations Syrian-Israeli Mixed Armistice Commission blamed Israel tonight for recent troop clashes in the Syrian Israeli demilitarized zone around the village of Tawafik, a United Arab Republic military spokesman reported.
ALBANY, Feb. 16 -- Legislation to exempt the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts from taxation was introduced today by two Manhattan Republicans.

Office space in the new Time Life Building, Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue) and Fiftieth Street, has been leased by Time, Inc., to Wasim International, Inc., of Geneva, Switzerland, financiers. The lessees have branch offices in leading cities throughout the world.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 16 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru was criticized today for having invited Premier Chou En-lai to New Delhi to discuss the border dispute between India and Communist China.
A double shot of merger and money is the medicine the British Government has prescribed for the ailing British aircraft industry in an effort to steel it for fierce fights ahead in world markets.

Pacific Natural Gas Directors of Pacific Natural Gas Company and Cascade Natural Gas Corporation agreed yesterday to a merger of Pacific into Cascade, subject to approval by stockholders of both companies, the regulatory commissions of Washington and Oregon and "holders of certain other securities."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate defeated a motion today by Senator Richard B. Russell, Georgia Democrat, to postpone to next Tuesday consideration of the Missouri school bill used as a vehicle in the civil rights debate:

The directors of the Bankers Trust Company elected a new president yesterday. He is Wallis B. Dunckel, a senior vice president who has been with the bank since 1923. Mr. Dunckel succeeds Alex H. Ardrey, who was elected vice chairman.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- A Governor, eight Mayors and a group of railroad executives pressed their plea today for Federal aid in dealing with the metropolitan commuter crisis.
ALBANY, Feb. 16 -- Mayor Wagner's charter revision proposal received a skeptical reception from Governor Rockefeller and Republican legislative leaders today.
The Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company sold yesterday $72,000,000 of thirty-three-year 5 1/8 per cent debentures to investment bankers led by Halsey, Stuart Co. on a bid of 100.53 per cent.

A spokesman for Rockefeller Center, Inc., owners and operators of the Roxy Theatre for the last four years, disclosed yesterday that a contract for the purchase of the theatre had been signed by Webb Knapp.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The Treasury is making a new and intensive survey of an old proposal that banks should pay interest on the Government funds deposited with them.

Boys High of Brooklyn posted its thirty-sixth straight basketball triumph by defeating Curtis of Staten Island, 72 -- 43, in the first round of the Public Schools Athletic League championship at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

The Chicago Black Hawks, who have been a stumbling block for the New York Rangers this season, will be back at Madison Square Garden tonight to meet the last-place Blues in a National Hockey League game.
CHICAGO, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
Persons who set their watches by the steeple clock at St. Mark's-in-the-Bouwerie owe a debt of which they know nothing to a man named Forman Cole.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 16 -- The merged labor federation ended today its monitorship over the United Textile Workers of America. The 40,000-member union was put under supervision two-and-one-hall years ago after the federation had found it guilty of domination by corrupt elements.

ALBANY, Feb. 16 -- Governor Rockefeller announced today that financing arrangements had been completed for the huge limited-profit housing project on the site of the former Jamaica Race Track in Queens.

DETROIT, Feb. 16 -- George Romney, who keeps emphasizing that the American Motors Corporation faces an ever-brighter future, went to considerable pains today to explain his personal problem of finding sufficient funds with which to take up his stock options.
The Federal District Court here will take up tomorrow the issue of whether airline pilots past the age of 60 should he permitted to fly commercial planes.

Dr. John Hunter, biologist, naturalist, collector and surgeon extraordinary to George III, is the subject of a biography by John Kobler. To be called "The Reluctant Surgeon," the book will be published Feb. 25 by Doubleday.
ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 16 -- American education was pictured today as in need of an emergency transfusion of ideas and money.

Height isn't everything in basketball, after all. Horace Walker, Michigan State's center, stands a relatively modest 6 feet 3 inches. Nevertheless, he has bettered in scoring and rebounding every pivot he has feced in Big Ten competition this winter.

The B.F. Goodrich Company realized a 6 per cent increase in earnings on a sales gain of 10.7 per cent over 1958 levels, according to the report of John L. Collyer, chairman, and J.W. Keener, president, released today.

TRENTON, Feb. 16 -- The State Public Utility Commission received a setback in Federal District Court here today in its effort to force the resumption of passenger service on the New York Central Railroad's West Shore division.
The French joined the world's nuclear club last week before the rules to govern its members were even formulated.

BUFFALO, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The New York State Publishers Association today endorsed the stand of the State Society of Newspaper Editors in opposing the Youth Court Act. The publishers also commended the County Judges Association for its campaign against the act.

PORTSMOUTH, Va., Feb. 16 (AP) -- White and Negro high school boys squared off in a parking lot fight here today in the worst outbreak of violence in the South's two weeks of demonstrations at lunch counters.

SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., Feb. 17 -- On the snow-blanketed, pine-dotted slopes and flats of this little Sierra Nevada basin, the winter edition of the world's top-ranking athletic competition will open tomorrow.
CHICAGO, Feb. 18 -- The Sunbeam Corporation announced today that it planned to buy the John Oster Manufacturing Company of Milwaukee.
TUNIS, Feb. 17 -- The Premier of the Algerian nationalist Provisional Government called on the Europeans of Algeria today "to share in building" an independent nation.

Toronto, Ontario The Municipality of Metropolitan Toronto, Ont., Canada, plans to offer $41,318,000 of debentures on the American capital market, according to a registration statement filed yesterday with the securities and Exchange Commission.
American Airlines, Inc., announced yesterday that last year's earnings, including non-recurring credits, reached a record of $21,013,000. This was equal to $2.53 a share on the common stock.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The Administration has begun a high-priority study into the possible use of robot seismic stations to improve the detection of underground explosions. In the opinion of many leading Administration scientists, the robot network holds promise of breaking the technical and diplomatic impasse over detecting underground tests that has developed in the Geneva negotiations for a ban on nuclear testing.
CARROLL GLENN and Eugene List played the Liszt Violin Sonata last night at the Lexington Avenue Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association. This is not a typographical error.

WANTAGH, L.I., Feb. 17 -- The scene at the Long Island Rail Road station here resembled a coffee break in overcoats this morning when commuters were treated to free coffee and doughnuts as an inducement to attend a conference on education.
ALTHOUGH the materials of Ketti Frings' "The Long Dream" are vital, the play is heavy. As acted at the Ambassador last evening, it seldom comes alive.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A New York Times editorial of Feb. 10 attributes the failure of the Federal Communications Commission to regulate the broadcasting industry more vigorously to the fact that some of the Commissioners are men of "low quality."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- A Government scientist testified today that nine coal tar colors used in cosmetics, mostly lipsticks, were "toxic and not innocuous."
TRENTON, Feb. 17 -- The State Youth Study Commission today strongly urged the use of "street club workers" as the most feasible means of reducing juvenile delinquency in New Jersey.

The Algerian rebel "Provisional Government" in Tunis made its expected overture yesterday in the direction of President de Gaulle and at first reading it is hard to avoid a sense of disappointment. It seems probable that opportunity, knocking for a second time, is still not being sincerely welcomed.
ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- New York City and four suburban counties would get more than half of the extra state aid for schools under the plan proposed by the Nassau Republican delegation in the Legislature.

THE letter came from the playground of the idle rich, West Palm Beach. Only something of great moment can bestir Earle (Greasy) Neale to set aside his golf sticks and take pen in hand. When emotion moves him, however, he writes not only long but well.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The House Rules Committee finally broke under rising political pressures today and cleared the way for the House of Representatives to start writing a civil rights bill on March 10.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 17 -- Sometime between tomorrow and Sunday the Screen Actor Guild will announce whether it members have authorized its board of directors to call a strike against the major studios here.
SEVENTEEN months ago a reporter asked Alexander Leonard Guterma his formula for success. "I'm an unbounded optimist," replied the bald, owlish financier with a puff of his Corona Corona.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 10:

A state commission decided yesterday to call Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa to a public hearing on a statement he had made with Mayor Wagner attacking its proposals for fiscal changes here. It will also call "the authors of the criticism."

The Sons of the Revolution in the State of New York will celebrate the 228th anniversary of the birth of George Washington on Monday with a banquet and dance in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza. Mrs. J. Baird Magnus is chairman of the women's committee for the eighty-third annual event.

An executive of the National Council of Churches Broadcasting and Film Commission declared yesterday that he was "astounded" to learn that the West Coast representative of the commission had engaged in "a censorship operation on behalf of the National Council."
Reflecting record sales, earnings of the Upjohn Company rose 15.9 per cent last year to $23,224,000 from $20,043,000 cleared by the producer of pharmaceuticals in 1958.

An American edition of Yvonne de Bremond D'Ars' experience as an antique dealer in Paris will be published March 8 by Putnam. It will be titled "In the Heart of Paris." In it the author tells of being assigned to divide among five women a "fabulous" antique collection.

Mrs. Henry Fonda, chairman; Mrs. Giulietta d'Alessandro and Mrs. Mario Pansa, her co-chairmen, and members of their committee are completing plans for a theatre party for the benefit of Girls Town of Italy.
ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- Democrats in the Legislature set the stage today for a showdown over the explosive civil rights issue.

TRENTON, Feb. 17 -- The New Jersey Chamber of Commerce and the State Manufacturers Association today endorsed a proposal that each county assess real and personal property at the ratio of true or market value that it desired.
The controversial Chelsea Community Council voted last night to dissolve itself, thus ending a strife-ridden three-year experiment in social living on New York's lower West Side.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The letter published Feb. 10 from the South African Ambassador du Plessis, in reply to your editorial of Feb. 5, "Plain Talk in Capetown," calls for comment, for he makes at best a pathetic attempt to justify the policy of white supremacy and racial segregation in South Africa.
In a policy reversal, the Russians submitted their TU-114 turbine-propeller airliner to noise tests here by the Port of New York Authority yesterday.
WESTBURY, L.I., Feb. 17 -- Musical discord and spiritual harmony were the keynotes of an off-beat concert rehearsal for parents and children here last night.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The Western Allies are having trouble working out a unified stand on Berlin and the German problem in preparation for the summit conference with Premier Khrushchev.
FOND DU LAC, Wis., Feb. 17 -- A record, singing crowd greeted Senator John F. Kennedy here tonight.

Three composers have been Cited at the annual award meeting of the Music Critics Circle of New York. They are Norman Dello Joio, for his opera "The Triumph of St. Joan"; Paul Hindemith, for his Six Madrigals, and Leon Kirchner, for his String Quartet No. 2.

SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., Feb. 17 -- Athletes from the Soviet Union today were poised to make a big splash in the VIII Winter Olympics as competitors from five continents prepared for the gala opening of the Games tomorrow.
Eastman Dillon, Union Securities Co., investment banking and brokerage firm, announced yesterday that it had proposed the admission of eight new general partners, effective on March 3.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- More indictments charging manufacturers of electrical equipment with bid rigging in violation of the antitrust law were returned today.
The Clark Equipment Company had record sales and earnings last year, George Spatta, president, reported yesterday in a preliminary annual statement.

General Acceptance Corporation, sales finance concern, moved yesterday to encourage the conversion of its 5 3/4 per cent capital debentures, due on June 1, 1984, into common stock. The company announced it would redeem the $2,724,000 of debentures outstanding on March 18 at 104 1/2, plus interest.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Coastal steamship operators and labor asked Congress today for protection against railroads and the Interstate Commerce Commission.
A leading lawyer warned yesterday that America's antitrust laws had hindered efforts of private business men to combat the Soviet trade offensive.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- United States-Cuban relation have deteriorated to the point where the Administration's policy of "patience and for bearance" is under serious review.
Two of college basketball's best marksmen will be in action tonight in Madison Square Garden, where Niagara plays Seton Hall and New York University goes against Holy Cross.

ROME, Feb. 17 -- A majority of the Liberal party's directorate decided today against further support of the Italian Government. Premier Antonio Segni said that if the Liberals withdraw their support he will resign immediately, without waiting for an adverse vote in Parliament.

Leading sales finance companies increased by 1/4 to 1/2 percentage point yesterday the return to investors on commercial paper sold directly to investors. This is in line with a recent uptrend in the Treasury bill rate.

TWO American who have arrived were on display at the Boston Symphony's concert at Carnegie Hall last night. One was a composer, Leon Kirchner, who was 41 last month, and the other was a violinist, Ruggiero Ricci, who will be 40 in July.

HAWTHORNE, N.Y.,, Feb. 17 -- Westchester's first "research park," to provide facilities for organized industrial research and development, will be established near Kensico Reservoir if plans on file today are approved by Mount Pleasant officials.

Market yields on prime debt securities fluctuated narrowly yesterday in a quiet session. A defensive tone prevailed in exchanges of local government bonds, but among Treasury and high-grade corporate securities prices generally were stable.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The Pentagon repudiated today an Air Force training manual that said communism had infiltrated churches in the United States.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- President Eisenhower denounced as despicable today a suggestion that he had misled the American people about the adequacy of United States defenses.

GLUCK'S "Orfeo," even in concert form, is such a rarity that a performance of the work is always welcome, especially so excellent a reading as that coriducted by Arnold Gamson at Town Hall last night.
The 1964 World's Fair in New York will run for two years instead of one if the sponsors can solve "a slight diplomatic problem," the chairman of the exposition's executive committee said yesterday.
A former official of the strife-ridden deck officers union sought yesterday to block its current election.
To expedite the construction of middle-income housing, the City Planning Commission approved the proposed $22,300,000 Ebbets Field housing project yesterday.
MOSCOW, Feb. 12 -- For several decades there have been a cat and some rats living peaceably together in one cage on Durov Street.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt offered praise today for the women "actually doing work as well as talking." She said women had power "if they'll use it."
ATLANTA, Feb. 17 -- The Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. was arrested here today at the request of Alabama authorities following his indictment in that state on perjury charges.
Fordham's basketball team returned to the winning column last night with a 90-68 victory over Adelphi at the Rose Hill gymnasium.
PARIS, Feb. 17 -- The North Atlantic Treaty Organization received from its miltary experts today a preliminary report showing progress in solving two disputes that have hampered the alliance.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., Feb. 17 -- Princeton's winter track team won the one-mile, mile and two-mile relays to clinch an upset victory over Pennsylvania today in the twenty-second annual Polar Bear meet in the Lavino Field House at Lawrenceville School.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Former Senator Tom Connally denounced today a resolution to repeal a United States veto over jurisdiction of the World Court. He called it a propaganda device designed to "win an international popularity contest."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Robert B. Anderson, Secretary of the Treasury, said today that a Senate Democratic proposal that the Government sell bonds by competitive bidding "could only result in a much higher interest cost to the Treasury."
CHICAGO, Feb. 17 (AP) -- A few spots of strength and weakness fringed a nearly stationary futures market today on the Board of Trade.

The volume of unsold coal at the mine pitheads of Western Europe had reached the dimensions of a mountain range as the end of 1959 approached, according to the Economic Commission for Europe of the United Nations. Unsold coal, at 70,000,000 metric tons, exceeded by 25,000,000 the total on hand at the end of 1958.
"The Play of the Week" show, threatened not long ago with extinction for lack of support, will be televised in nine other cities around the country.
TORONTO, Feb. 17 (Canadian Press) -- Steep Rock Iron Mines, Ltd., cleared $9,049,000, or $1.13 a share, in 1959, compared with $1,386,508, or 17 cents, in 1958.

WESTBURY, L.I., Feb. 17 -- The C.W. Post quintet scored an 86-83 overtime victory over Bloomfield College of New Jersey at Westbury Junior High School tonight. The score was 76 -- all at the end of the regulation time.
Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa announced yesterday that he would fight any move by Mayor Wagner's Charter-revision task force to weaken the powers of his office.
LONDON, Feb. 17 -- Britain and British Honduras agreed today on preliminary steps for advancing the British colony toward eventual self-government.
New products are expected to turn sales of the valve industry upward still further this year.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Feb. 17 -- The sun burns down on neat villas painted in soft colors and arranged gracefully behind tropical shrubbery and walls along clean streets lined densely with trees.

Joseph Walker, New Jersey State Athletic Commissioner, last night granted a license to Feature Sports, Inc., to promote the Ingemar Johansson-Floyd Patterson heavyweight title fight or other bouts in Jersey City.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Senate investigators are looking into reports of a financial relationship between rival boxing promoters, Bill Rosensohn of New York and James D. Norris of Chicago.

In another action, a bill to give Congress a firmer hand over the Authority was introduced in the House.
RANGOON, Burma, Thursday, Feb. 18 -- Premier Khrushchev ended a quiet one-and-a-half-day visit to Rangoon and left this morning for Jakarta, Indonesia.

The textile and apparel industries in this country are in grave danger because of a flood of foreign imports, their leaders warned yesterday. Meeting here to discuss the cost of helping to free world trade, representatives of a score of associations in the field joined to urge speedy adoption of high import barriers and extra duty payments on imported goods.

Heavy liquidation of potato futures induced stop-loss selling yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The market closed at the lows of the day. Trading was heavy. Short covering and scale-down trade buying limited the decline.

FRENCH chefs for the most part always have taken a fairly dim view of English cuisine. The dishes that the label "a l'anglaise," or English style, are always simply perpared, many of them merely simmered or poached or breaded.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The United States and Canada took steps toward common policies on European trade problems and aid to under-developed countries during two days of talks that ended today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 (UPI) -- Henry Hank scored his twenty-ninth knockout in fifty-two fights tonight, stopping Sixto Rodriguez at 2:41 of the sixth round.
ACCRA, Ghana, Feb. 17 -- Negotiations began here today between the British Overseas Airways Corporation and the Government regarding Ghana's plans to reorganize and expand her civil aviation.

Stocks yesterday veered into what looked for a time like a true selling climax, with a late tape, heavy volume and wide losses. All these were present until noon. Then prices snapped back. At the close the market showed a net gain.

The closing down of most of the nation's steel plants in mid-July last year, and the accompanying curtailment of employment in related industries, brought to a temporary halt the vigorous expansion in industrial production that had carried the Federal Reserve Index (as recently revised) from about 133 in April, 1958, to 166 in May and June, 1959, an expansion of 33 points, or about 25 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- President Eisenhower will report to the nation on television and radio Sunday evening or the purpose of his 15,560-mile tour of South American capitals that is to begin Monday.

Anton Rost of Brooklyn, a former judge who now imports pure-bred dogs, swung briskly at Cruft's, London's big dog show; the competence of many judges, the operations of breed clubs and the written breed standards yesterday.

Directors of Pullman, Inc., yesterday proposed a two-for-one stock split and also voted a dividend of $1 a share on the present stock.

Distributors Group, Inc., a mutual fund management company, has leased a floor in the office building being constructed by Samuel Rudin at 80 Pine Street. Lawrence B. Whitman of the Cruikshank Company was the broker.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- President Eisenhower threw cold water today on a proposed wide-open convention to pick the Republican Vice-Presidential nominee. He reiterated his view that the Presidential nominee must have "some say" in choosing his running mate if they are to work closely together after election.

A public offering of $7,500,000 of convertible subordinated debentures of the Dayton Rubber Company is being made today. The securities, priced at par, bear 5 1/2 per cent interest coupons and fall due in twenty years.

Light fuel oil stocks, used mainly for home heating, declined seasonally by 3,181,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday. This was reported by the American Petroleum Institute. Supplies at the week-end were 118,340,000 barrels, compared with 88,255,000 in the 1959 period.

Apparently as a result of intervention by Premier Khrushchev, Mikhail A. Sholokhov has finally completed the sequel to his famous novel "The Virgin Soil Upturned" -- with a new ending.

The New York State Thruway is planning to sell $50,000,000 of long-term state-guaranteed bonds on March 3, Controller Arthur Levitt said yesterday. The borrowing will constitute the final issue of the $500,000,000 of authorized Thruway obligations backed by the full faith and credit of the state.

The New York City Opera, which ends its eleven-day winter season at the New York City Center on Sunday evening, will leave on Tuesday for its longest tour. It will take the company to nineteen cities during the five-week period ending March 26.
The Flatbush General Hospital, a private institution in Brooklyn operated for profit, was struck Tuesday morning by a group of its nonprofessional employes.

The short interest position in share listed on the New York Stock Exchange declined in the latest reporting month to the lowest level in almost two and a half years. On last Monday it stood at 2,736,012 shares, down 14,832 from the 2,750,844 reported for Jan. 15.

An indictment charging Dave Beck, former Teamsters Union president, two trucking company executives and three corporations with violating the Taft-Hartley Act was dismissed yesterday.

President Eisenhower was asked yesterday by the American Trade Association for British Woollens, Inc., to order admission of more higher-quality wool fabrics. New records in sales of ordinary insurance, premium and annuity income and benefits payments were set by the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States in 1959, James F. Oates Jr., president, reported yesterday.
