A question that has puzzled many people in New York since Feb. 4 is going to be answered next week.
SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., Feb. 18 -- The snowfall that hit the Olympic village today caused officials to postpone the race that was to be in the big spot at the opening of competition tomorrow.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- Republicans, stung by the election of three Democratic supreme court justices last November in the Tenth Judicial District, moved today to preserve part of the area for future Republican candidates.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Rail and truck loadings of freight last week were above the year-ago levels, but they were both below those of the preceding week.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 (UPI) -- Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz called for a crackdown today on investment advisory services that "tout" a stock, regardless of its value, and create a false or inflated market.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The recent political crisis in French Algeria has raised a most disturbing and complex problem which is of the greatest concern to us all. It is the greatly misunderstood problem of "colonialism" -- a word which has been distorted by many people both here and abroad.
LONDON, Feb. 18 -- Higher pay for family doctors in the National Health Service and for physicians and dentists in the service's hospitals was recommended today by a Royal Commission.

An exciting 66-64 victory by Jamaica High over favored Franklin highlighted a schoolboy basketball triple-header at Madison Square Garden yesterday. The decision came after the buzzer had sounded, since a foul had been charged to Franklin in the final second of play.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday unchanged to 3 points (15 cents a bale) off, except the far July contract which closed, nominally 7 points (35 cents) up.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Feb. 18 -- This town could expect a substantial increase in tax revenue if it relaxed its zoning restrictions to permit executive offices and research laboratories, a study showed today.

Mayor Wagner's do-it-yourself, do-it-cheap and do-it-quickly plan of City Charter revision is already encountering difficulties. For a day or two it looked as though everything was running like a well-oiled machine. Then things began to come unstuck, and the public may well wonder whether it will get from the Mayor's Charter revision staff a substantial improvement in government.

Between 1953 and 1959 this newspaper published a column called "About New York," which gave anecdotes and human-interest stories about the city's people and places. It was written by Meyer Berger, author of four books and winner of a Pulitzer Prize in 1950.

STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 18 (UPI) -- An 81-year-old retired railroad foreman who invested in the stock market on savings from his $100-a-week job donated $228,000 to the University of New Hampshire today -- the largest amount it has ever received.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 18 -- Organized marketing on a cooperative basis has proved a boon for farmers in the Federation of Malaya, a spokesman for that country reported at a recent conference of the Food and Agri- culture Organization in Rome.
A MAJOR work by a gifted novelist received appropriately sensitive treatment on television last night.

BOSTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Operations of the United Fruit Company on four continents yielded a profit last year of $12,087,670, or $1.39 a share. This was a little more than half the $22,741,575, or $2.60 a share, cleared in 1958.
JERSEY CITY, Feb. 18 -- There is an immediate need for 20,000 trained speech pathologists in the United States, a House of Representatives subcommittee on special education was told today.

World-Wide sales of Chas. Pfizer Co., Inc., passed the quarter-billion-dollar mark in 1959 for the first time in the 111-year-old history of the drug and chemical producer. This was reflected in record earnings.
Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., the nation's largest brokerage concern, had its best year yet in 1959.
VOUDEHI, United Arab Republic, Feb. 18 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser gave the signal today for work to begin on a new railroad in Syria linking Aleppo with its seaport at Latakia 145 miles away.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 18 -- The Government hopes to be able to work out an agreement with the Vatican on the role of the Roman Catholic Church in Communist Yugoslavia.
CHICAGO, Feb. 18 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Directors of the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad voted yesterday to distribute its extensive Florida land holdings and farming operations to its stockholders. The board authorized the distribution of one share of stock of the Alico Land Development Company, a new corporation, for each share of Coast Line stock held.

WICHITA, Kan., Feb. 18 (AP) -- A spokesman for a lay committee of the First Baptist Church said today the committee had recommended withdrawing support from the National Council of Churches because it "takes sides in controversial political, economic and social issues."

THE heat wave that spread across western Europe in the summer of 1952 was in full force by June 12. But the two men in the wine cellar of the house at 22 Muhlstrasse in the outskirts of Bonn were not bothered by the heat. The cellar was too deep. In 1937 it had been converted into an air-raid shelter complete with supporting steel posts and a massive steel door.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The Navy is withdrawing from its oil-cargo shipping contracts a protested clause that seemed to support the Arab boycott of Israel.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Labor Secretary James P. Mitchell implied today for the first time that the Administration would support an increase in the $1 minimum wage.
Rise Stevens, the Metropolitan Opera mezzo-soprano, urged New York teachers yesterday to help develop America's "enormous" untapped reserves of artistic talent.
ELTON J. ENDRESS of Hamburg, N.Y., brings up a subject that has interested many New York State private pond owners: how to get black bass to stock their ponds. His letter, in part:

MIAMI, Feb. 18 -- It wasn't until the eighth race today that a favorite won at Hialeah. With the chalk failing regularly all afternoon, the figure men in the crowd of 18,961 were progressively more gloomy until Fred Hooper's Alhambra came to their rescue.

A Lament for the Old Farm A visitor to the office the other day, noting the role that farm issues were playing in talk about candidates for election this year, was prompted to call attention to the changes that have taken place with the farmer in the last twenty years.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 18 -- Indonesia received from Premier Khrushchev today a pledge of support for her neutralism, a promise of continued Soviet economic aid and an attack on "colonialists."

GLEN RIDGE, N.J., Feb. 18 -- William E. Hamilton, who directed construction of hydroelectric power plants throughout the country, died today at Mountainside Hospital of a heart ailment. He was 75 years old and lived at 76 High Street.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Feb. 18 -- Claims totaling $3,375,000 were filed against this village and the Town of Bedford today by the families of two women who were killed and four who were seriously injured in an automobile crash here on Nov. 20.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter called on the Soviet Union today to help safeguard the world against "war by miscalculation."
CHICAGO, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Soybean futures suddenly reversed a lower trend here today and finished with their first general gains of the week despite some considerations traders considered bearish.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 18 -- By an overwhelming vote members of the Screen Actors Guild today authorized the union of actors to call a strike against the major movie studios here.
The following reports were provided by operators of the ski areas. Messages were filed at telegraph offices yesterday at the times indicated in parentheses:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Ezra Taft Benson made clear to Congress today that the Administration would oppose raising price supports for wheat even with stricter production controls.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- President Eisenhower formally asked Congress today to approve United States participation in the new International Development Association.
HOUSTON Feb. 18 (AP) -- Continental League officials said today they would open as a third major league on April 18, 1961, with games in Atlanta, Houston, the Fort Worth-Dallas area and Denver.

Average borrowings by member banks increased $123,000,000 to $973,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Average reserves in excess of requirements increased $17,000,000 to $440,000,000.
Art from the Arctic has been providing collectors with a new field in the last decade or so. It also is giving its Eskimo creators a relative and unwonted affluence.

John S. Burke, chairman of the board of B. Altman Co., has sold his five-story town house at 46 East Sixty-sixth Street to Mrs. Patrick B. McGinnis, wife of the president of the Boston and Maine Railroad.
LONDON, Feb. 18 -- Maj. Mark Milbank, Master of the Queen's Household, and Comdr. Richard Colville, her press secretary, said tonight that the birth of Queen Elizabeth's baby was not imminent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- It was reported today that the Air Force Reserve training manual that had discussed communism and churches was preceded by at least one other version printed five years ago.
New York University put on a dazzling display of old-time New York basketball as it trounced the Crusaders of Holy Cross, 74 -- 60, in the feature game at Madison Square Garden last night.

GIULIETTA SIMIONATA, who sang Azucena on opening night and later Santuzza, undertook her third role at the Metropolitan Opera last night. It was Amneris in Verdi's "Aida," and again the Italian mezzo-soprano had a striking success.

MICHAEL TREE continued his good work last night at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium. This violinist has made several New York appearances in the past, each time leaving the impression of an unusually gifted young man.
ONE of the major annual tournaments of the Greater New York Bridge Association begins today at the Statler Hilton Hotel and will continue through Monday. The principal contests scheduled are:
NEWARK, Feb. 18 -- Business leaders were cautioned here today by the president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States to guard against "new spending programs" in Congress.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The leader of a visiting Soviet political delegation contended today that there was more free criticism in his country than in the United States.

SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., Feb. 18 -- Elwira Sieroczynska and Helena Pilejczyk, two Polish speed skaters, have clearcut Western ideas of fashion and yet had never before seen the clothes produced and worn in the United States.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The Justice Department today sent to Congress a new version of its voting referee bill.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- A Government expert testified today that experiments that preceded a proposed ban on use of fourteen coal-tar colors in lipstick were aimed at establishing that the colors caused harm to laboratory animals.
YESTERDAY (Feb. 18, 1960) THE PRESIDENT Met with National Security Council.
Drama shows starring Ingrid Bergman and Sir Alec Guinness, first televised last fall, will be among several to be repeated by the "Startime" series between now and the end of the season.
A Federal-state minimum wage of $1.25 an hour would save New York at least $1,000,000 a year in welfare costs, Welfare Commissioner James R. Dumpson said yesterday.
RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 18 -- Burma and the Soviet Union have agreed on new steps to arrange a cultural and scientific exchange between the two countries.

"THIS is big enough for all Israel," commented a business man from that country, as he surveyed the 185,000 square foot floor of a supermarket warehouse. Similar remarks kept Paul Sayres entertained as he conducted ten leading Israeli business men through three supermarkets north of New York City.
NEVER underestimate the power of a female Mexican peasant. That is the moral of Theodore Apstein's "Come Share My House," which opened at the Actors Playhouse last evening.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 19 -- Governor Rockefeller flew to this central New York city tonight to rally public support behind a mandatory fall-out shelter program.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 19 -- Pete Campbell, a sophomore scored 32 points, 9 of them in the five-minute overtime period enabling Prince ton to upset Dartmouth tonight, 76 -- 69.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 2 points up to 6 points off yesterday. (A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.) The market lacked a trend all day.

WINTER'S long evenings need not be idle ones. Now is the time for those nimble with the needle to start brightening the home for spring. This could mean a gaily striped bedspread, a floral slipcover for the sofa, checked cafe curtains or, for the novice seamstress, brightly patterned scatter pillows.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UPI) -- The average newspaper reader could become confused by the controversy over an Air Force training manual that accuses some religious leaders in the United States of Communist leanings.
A lunchtime crowd of 200 at Nassau and Wall Streets shivered yesterday in raw, gusty weather at a ceremony honoring George Washington.

Is price inflation a necessary prerequisite to, or accompaniment of a high rate of national economic growth, as one school of thought holds? Or is it true that, as many are firmly convinced, the process of currency depreciation, though it may, under favoring conditions, contribute to temporary bursts of economic expansion, is fundamentally inimical, if not potentially fatal, to the achievement of a state of long-term economic expansion?
TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 19 (AP) -- Dave Marr of Cedarhurst, L.I., three-putted the last two greens today but led by a stroke after thirty-six holes in the $20,000 Tucson open golf tournament.
SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., Feb. 19 -- A four-goal rally In the final period enabled the United States to get off to an impressive start as the Olympic hockey tournament opened at the Blythe Arena tonight.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Feb. 19 -- Representatives of more than 1,000 South Jersey egg producers tonight urged James R. Hoffa to open his Teamsters Union to poultry farmers. He immediately agreed and set March 3 to start organizing them.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- High interest rates in the United States pushed the lending rate of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) above 6 per cent for the first time today.
ROBERT RIEFLING, the Norwegian pianist, has played with orchestra In this country, but last night marked his first solo concert.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Senator Stuart Symington, in a clear challenge to President Eisenhower, today attributed misleading defense information to the Administration.
FREEPORT, L.I., Feb. 19 -- A dog named Buck got a telephone call from his former mistress here, and it apparently led him to bolt his new home in Ohio to get back to her.

MIAMI, Feb. 19 -- Two horse and a man will be among the more important factors of the racing program at Hialeah tomorrow. One of the horses is Sword Dancer, Mrs. Isabel Dodge Sloane's 4-year-old. The other is Bally Ache, Leonard Fruchtman's 3-year-old.

BOWIE, Md., Feb. 19 (AP) -- Bowie Race Track canceled its plans to run a ten-race can tomorrow after the Maryland Attorney General ruled today that the State Racing Commission did not have the power to grant a tenth race.
SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., Feb. 19 -- The Soviet Union's hopes to gain the jump on its rivals in the Winter Olympics failed to materialize today. Sweden and Canada took the first two gold medals.

An operator of hat check concessions and restaurants in hotels over the country was convicted yesterday of willfully attempting to evade withholding taxes and social security payments to the Government.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Four Senators and a Representative protested today the State Department's role in the last-minute reprieve of Caryl Chessman from the California gas chamber.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The Pentagon ordered an investigation today of the production of training manuals in all the services to insure against further embarrassment.

THE principal part or the New York Philharmonic's Mahler Festival Is being completed this week with the performance of the Second Symphony. There remains only "Das Lied von der Erde" to be conducted by Bruno Walter in mid-April, which should be a generous dividend.

PARIS. Political fall-out from France's first atomic explosion obscures this country's evolving military strategy. The French are planning to build their own nuclear striking force capable of acting, as de Gaulle says, "anywhere in the world" regardless of whether Washington decides to share atomic arms and secrets.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Two fouls by Ed Cuffe and one by Mike Donohue in the last fifteen seconds of play helped Harvard gain a 61-58 victory over the Penn five tonight at the Palestra.
The first American ship to carry an all-container cargo to a foreign port lay at anchor under a boycott for the sixteenth day yesterday, just outside he first port of call.
CHICAGO, Feb. 19 -- An international conference on the administration of criminal law debated today whether the police should be given broader powers to arrest, detain and question suspects.
HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 19 -- The Yale team extended its dual-meet victory streak to 191 today by routing Dartmouth, 60 to 35, in an Eastern Inter-collegiate Swimming League meet in Spaulding Pool.

A number of moderately large issues of fixed-interest securities are slated for next week's new capital market. More than $135,000,000 in offerings of municipal tax-exempt securities and utility company bonds and debentures are slated for sale.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Alaska's Democratic Senators said today they did not plan a determined fight to block the appointment of Sigfried B. Unander to the Federal Maritime Board.
The annual observance of Brotherhood Week, conducted since 1934 by the National Conference of Christians and Jews, will formally begin tomorrow in communities over the nation.
A 57-year-old Brooklyn man, described by Federal authorities as the nation's No. 1 bootlegger, was sentenced yesterday in the Federal Court, Brooklyn, to two years in the penitentiary.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- From Scotland to the Scilly Isles, church bells, cannon and bonfires tonight welcomed the birth of a son to Queen Elizabeth II.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Feb. 18 -- Two recent events have added yeast to the political ferment in South Africa.
DURHAM, N.C., Feb. 19 -- Dr. A. Hollis Edens, 59-year-old president of Duke University, announced his resignation today.
PROVIDENCE, Feb. 19 -- Brown pulled away in the last five minutes and defeated Columbia, 59 -- 52, in an Ivy League basketball game tonight.
The Bureau of Information of the Eastern Railways has leased large space for executive and general offices in 342 Madison Avenue, at Forty-fourth Street. Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., was the broker.

NEWARK, Feb. 19 -- The State Board of Public Utility Commissioners called today for "vigorous action" to amend the Federal Transportation Act of 1958 to let New Jersey resolve its rail commuter problems.

HIGH prices arc as prevalent in Greenwich Village, on the whole, as elsewhere. But the astute buyer, ferreting out the off-beat and one-of-a-kind bargain in the small shops, is likely to do considerably better for himself there than uptown.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The United States acknowledged today that an airplane that crashed 100 miles east of Havana yesterday had flown from Florida.
A request for an across-the-board pay rise of $500 a year for the 100,000 employes covered by the city's Career and Salary Plan was heard by Mayor Wagner at City Hall yesterday.

A gale-driven snowstorm swirled out of the North Texas plains yesterday, piling snow-drifts throughout much of the East up to the Canadian border. Long stretches of both the New York State Thruway and Pennsylvania Turnpike were closed.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The first open signs of dispute over the strategy for passing a civil rights bill appeared today between the Senate's Democratic and Republican leaders.
After a six-week delay, the New York State Athletic Commission granted yesterday a promoter's license to Feature Sports, Inc.

[noncommissioned officer] might come in contact either on or off duty unless he had all the evidence of such activity available to him that it was possible to provide."
LONDON, Feb. 19 -- Industrial shares here responded to the advance on Wall Street yester day with widespread gains. But a later reaction caused prices to become irregular.
Don't start clubs to keep the aged active; form "listening groups" to let them do what they like to do-talk about the past, a mental health researcher suggested yesterday.

That Winter Vacation After Ground Hog Day in February, irrespective of what that temperamental animal prophet may be meaning to forecast, there are plenty of cold days left with accompanying high winds, sleet and snow.

CANTON, N.Y., Feb. 19 -- St. Lawrence University's hockey team skated closer to a National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament berth tonight by defeating Boston University, 6 -- 3, in Appleton Arena before 4,000 fans.

One of Webster's definitions for the word "adapt" is "to alter so as to fit for a new use." Undoubtedly, Warner LeRoy must have had this In mind when he undertook the adaptation of Diego Fabbri's "The Trial of Jesus."

MADISON, Wis., Feb. 19 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey turned his heavy guns on Vice President Nixon tonight in his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination. He compared the Vice President's political morality to that of a river boat gambler.
DAMASCUS, United Arab Republic, Feb. 11 -- Lingering over their coffee in a restaurant here, a foreign visitor and two Arabs fell into a friendly but heated political argument.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Commercial exports in January were up 12 per cent from January a year ago, but the performance brought no great cheer to Government officials concerned about the deficit in the United States balance of payments. The Department of Commerce reported the preliminary January figures today.

ALONG career of sober dedication to improving inter-American relations has had a startling result for Roy Richard Rubottom Jr. He has suddenly become a key name in a criminal case that has reverberated around the world.

Forecasts of freezing temperatures in potato growing areas in Florida, Alabama and California buoyed futures prices yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. However, the market drifted easier on the close because of evening operations before the long week-end.
HAVANA, Feb. 19 -- In a speech last night Premier Castro said that the defense and security measures of the United States must be deficient if a plane could leave Florida without detection.

The Esso Standard Oil Company reduced yesterday the price of light heating oil and Diesel fuel by eight-tenths of a cent a gallon for all methods of delivery throughout its marketing area along the Atlantic Coast from Charleston, S.C., to Maine.
The case of a landscape gardener accused by the Army of being a wartime deserter turned to confusion and mystery here in Federal Court yesterday.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The article "A Rebel Knocks at Shrine Here," published Feb 11, is most unfortunate and should not go unchallenged.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- In a country increasingly conscious of all kinds of trends, a New Yorker has created a business in mechanical charts that don't have to be drawn. They have real bars instead of the inked-in kind, cords for lines, and movable disks.
A large nuclear tanker, powered by a boiling water reactor, could compete with conventionally powered tankers by 1966, an expert declared yesterday.
Bridgeport Brass Company is studying the possibility of producing aluminum pig and ingot, it was disclosed yesterday.
CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Feb. 19 -- A 23-year-old political prisoner said today that a democratic movement was certain to succeed in the Dominican Republic.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The index of average wholesale primary market prices remained at 119.2 per cent of its 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
Bids for prime debt securities were lowered all along the line by dealers yesterday, giving the bond market a sloppy appearance on the eve of the winter's last holiday week-end.

HERKIMER, N.Y., Feb. 19 (AP) -- The president of a financially pressed furniture company shot himself to death today, two days after announcing that the company was for sale despite workers' efforts to save it.

OBVIOUSLY, only the best qualified persons attendee the birth of Great Britain's newest prince. It therefore struck many people here as odd that the term "midwife" should occur so frequently in connection with this important event.
SYOSSET, L.I., Feb. 19 -- When the 5:03 arrived here tonight, there was hardly a dry throat aboard.

A NUMBER of contemporary painters, unlikely ever to be canonized by the Museum of Modern Art, still find that the American scene offers a romantic field for their observation and transcription. Hughie Lee-Smith, showing recent work at the Nessler Gallery, 718 Madison Avenue, is one of these.

SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., Feb. 19 -- Competition in tin VIII Olympic Winter Games began today in perfect weather with Sweden and Canada scoring coups in cross-country skiing and figure-skating, respectively.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- A Government pharmacologist testified today that a coal tar color used in some lipsticks could be harmful if it got into the human system.
The School Crossing Guards Association last night postponed a strike it had threatened for next Tuesday.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 19 -- The Western Big Three Governments and the Soviet Union reasserted their contradictory positions today on the claim of the East German Government to status as a sovereign power.
NORWALK, Conn., Feb. 19 -- Life is far from dreamy these days for fifty tenants in the newly built Dreamy Hollow Apartments on Wolfpit Road here.

Plymouth Oil A dividend of 25 cents was declared on the common stock of the Plymouth Oil Company, for payment on March 28 to stock of record of March 4. This is a reduction from the 30 cent quarterly payment made last year along with an extra of 2 per cent in stock distributed in December.
"Awful speculation" was the way one high Soviet official described the New York Stock Exchange during a visit to Wail Street yesterday.
A Brooklyn man who promised a magistrate yesterday morning that he would "be good and go straight" was back in the same court shortly after noon, charged with petit larceny.

A baby born to Queen Elizabeth II of Great Britain is not just an ordinary baby. He is a child whose unbroken line of descent can be traced back to the Saxon King Egbert who first united England in the ninth century. He has the blood of the Saxons and Normans, the Guelphs, Plantagenets, Tudors and Stuarts in his veins.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 19 -- Premier Khrushchev, accompanied by President Sukarno, began his tour of outlying parts of Indonesia today.

MEYERSDALE, Pa., Feb. 19 (AP) -- A two-unit Baltimore and Ohio Railroad train running twenty-four minutes behind schedule rammed the rear of a stopped work train near this southwestern Pennsylvania town today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 19 -- An unexpected and dramatic sixty-day reprieve by Gov. Edmund G. Brown enabled Caryl Chessman to see a blue sky today instead of a green-walled execution chamber.
John Solum, a young man with a flute, put that elusive instrument to some fine musical uses last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.
MOSCOW, Feb. 19 -- Victor G. Bakayev, Minister of Merchant Marine, said today that Soviet shipping was competing favorably with that of other nations throughout the world.
NEW DELHI, Feb. 19 -- Fighting between workers and the police at the Soviet-built steel mill in Bhilai, in central India, was reported today. Fifty persons were said to have been arrested.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 (AP) -- The 109-day strike of 5,500 workers at seven packing plants of Wilson Co. ended today after ratification of a two-year contract by members of the United Packinghouse Workers Union.

A study of relations among the Communist states will be published Feb. 29 by Harvard University Press. It will be titled "The Soviet Bloc: Unity and Conflict." The author, Zbigniew K. Brzezinski, explores the implications of the status of Yugoslavia and China, the significance of the Hungarian revolution and the position of Poland in the Soviet bloc.

Stocks continued to nibble away at their 1960 losses yesterday. By the end of the day, market values on the New York Stock Exchange had risen about $2,400,000,000 or eight-tenths of one per cent and the market had returned to its level of the end of January.
WASHINGTON, Feb 19 -- The United States Commissioner of Education has made spirited defense of the American school system against criticisms lodged by Vice Admiral Hyman G. Rickover.
Verdi's "Aida" will be sung at the Metropolitan Opera on Thursday, March 3, In Russian and Italian.

VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Feb. 19 (AP) -- The trouble-beset Discoverer satellite series had its most spectacular failure today -- a mighty explosion directly over this base that had all hands diving for cover from raining debris.

The president of a hospital workers' union that struck seven voluntary institutions last year charged yesterday that the hospitals were not living up to the terms of a statement of policy that ended the strike.

THERE are several dishes in this world so thoroughly associated with cities that they almost qualify as landmarks. One such is pressed duck at La Tour d'Argent in Paris; another is fettuccine in Rome.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 19 -- The Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America reported today that its welfare and pension funds, pioneers in their fields, had distributed $214,688,675 in benefits. Their reserves exceed $150,000,000, it added.
WASIHNGTON, Feb. 19 -- The ninety one - day Treasury bill rate rose a little more today, erasing more of the steep decline registered earlier this month.

THERE may be some of that old blood left in hunters and fishermen after all, especially in the elderly ones. Not all of them have to have the game and fish laid in their laps while they sit in their cars.
MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 19 -- The dominion of Robert Moses was given a third dimension today.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 19 -- The complicated future of Rio de Janeiro and Brasilia is an exciting Brazilian tale of two cities.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Cardinal Spellman of New York was honored as Big Brother o the Year at a White House ceremony today. He told President Eisenhower that he deserved the same recognition.
HOW long ago "Not So Long Ago," a chronicle of the five years between World War II's end and the Korean conflict, seemed on Channel 4 last night.
Mrs. Augusta Redman was back In Housing Court yesterday to face new charges of housing violations in Manhattan tenements she owns.
The Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority reported yesterday that a record of 153,708,939 toll-paying vehicles used its bridges and tunnels in 1959. This was an increase of 3,097,094 over 1958.

A dream began to come true in Latin America this week when the foreign ministers of seven nations signed a treaty for a free trade zone linking a portion of their economies. This is not exactly the first step, as three of the Central American nations made an even more extensive agreement earlier this month, but the "big seven" are certainly far more important in every respect.

TUNIS, Feb. 18 -- President Habib Bourguiba has used African resentment toward the French atomic tests as the basis of an explosive attack on one of Islam's strongest institutions -- the month-long daylight fast of Ramadan.

The Duke and Duchess of Windsor created a stir yesterday by bringing a pug to an unusual dog show in an unusual place. The show was in the lounge of the Manhattan Savings Bank, Forty-seventh Street and Madison Avenue.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 19 -- Photographs and reproductions of art from the Monastery of St. Catherine, the world's oldest Greek Orthodox monastery, went on display today at the Princeton University Library.

ONE difference between American and European women is in handbag styles. "When it comes to her pocket-book, a French or Italian woman is interested chiefly in appearance. In America, the handbag is a woman's home away from home," declared Lou Nathan, a designer-manufacturer who spends most of his working hours studying the ins and out of ladies' purses.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 19 (UPI) -- The United States cannot follow a "go-it-alone" policy or return to big scale protectionism in foreign trade, Chairman Ralph T. Reed of the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce, said today.
ASUNCION, Paraguay, Feb. 14 -- Gen. Alfredo Stroessner, the Paraguayan strong man, is in financial difficulties and his regime has turned to the United States for cash assistance.

WITH the sectional tournament of the Greater New York Bridge Association under way at the Statler Hilton Hotel, another tournament begins in New York today, the regional tournament of the American Bridge Association, at the Sheraton Atlantic Hotel.

Duels between two of the finest schoolboy athletes In the country In the high jump and high hurdles today may decide the team championship in the twenty-seventh annual Amateur Athletic Union interscholastic indoor track and field games at Madison Square Garden.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Feb. 19 -- More than 1,400 Chinese Nationalist leaders were registered today as electors in the republic's forthcoming third Presidential election. They are members of the National Assembly, the supreme power of the Nationalist Government.

ALTHOUGH the historian Frederick Jackson Turner noted the ending of the American frontier many years ago, the news only spurred Western writers to vaster and sometimes better efforts. They multiplied the vanishing point, as it were, until it became bigger than the Rocky Mountains. A neat trick. But it was done.

KADUNA, Nigeria, Feb. 10 -- A half-million lepers dwell among the 20,000,000 Africans of Northern Nigeria. Here, the high incidence of the dread Hansen's bacillus is being checked by an intelligently planned assault with a whole new armory of weapons.

The Federal National Mortgage Association stepped up its mortgage purchases in the final quarter of las year while sales dropped practically to a stand-still, J. Stanley Baughman, president, has disclosed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Senator Jacob K. Javits urged Congress today not to leap into an investigation into the Port of New York Authority, which was proposed earlier this week. A hasty inquiry, he said, might hurt the authority's efforts in combating competition with New York and New Jersey ports.
Nearly 2,000 doctors in eight sections of the metropolitan area heard a demonstration last night of the National Broadcasting Company's proposed medical radio network.

The Long Island Rail Road said yesterday it might have to raise passenger fares and curtail service if the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad were permitted to continue a new freight service in Nassau and Suffolk Counties.
Five television stations m as many Central American countries plan to start a network operation within the next six to eight weeks.

The Belding Hemimvay Company, Inc. is planning to acquire the operating assets of M. Hausman Sons, Inc. and to merge Weldon Mills, Inc. into its organization.
LONDON, Feb. 19 -- The British Government has begun a comprehensive study of the nationalized railroad system that is expected to result in drastic changes in the system's financing and organization.
DAMASCUS, United Arab Republic, Feb. 12 -- Arab observers here are predicting a series of splits among the Communits of Iraq.
WOMEN please pass the word: Buy a new hat or prepaid to spend spring in the laundry hamper. There is no alternative as any witness to the Fashion Group luncheon yesterday will testify.

LAKE WORTH, Fla., Feb. 19 (AP) -- Louise Suggs of Sea Island, Ga., fired a one-underpar 69 today for a 141-total to gain a two-stroke lead over last year's winner, Betsy Rawls of Spartanburg, S.C., at the halfway mark of the 72-hole $7,500 Lake Worth invitation golf tournament.
LONDON, Feb. 19 -- British public opinion welcomes the sixty-day reprieve for Caryl Chessman, but on the assumption that it ends the threat of execution.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla. -- This is the peak of the winter season in Florida, but there Is plenty of room for lots more tourists than have arrived. All advance signs indicated that this would be Florida's biggest winter tourist season and, on the basis of the number of visitors here now, it is or should be.

BRASILIA, Brazil -- This bustling expanse of excavation and construction that is shaping into a city if now South America's most spectcular tourist spot. Whereas long tradition formerly called for foreign visitors to view famous ruins and monuments, Brasilia, stressing the new spirit of a developing continent, stands for a city rising from the ground almost over-night.

The world's largest ocean-going dredge went to work last week in Venezuela.

HERE, in thirteen short stories, A.B. Guthrie Jr. has thrown his loop around the northern Great Plains. The stories range in time from the days when the French Canadians led the mountain men and trappers went about their business with one ear forever stretched for the sound of Blackfeet to the time of farms and tractors, with some concentration on the period when cowboys really did carry guns.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 20 -- Political pressures of a Presidential election year, deepseated economic problems highlighted by still uncontrolled inflation and a growing assertion of nationalism paint in broad strokes the panorama of Brazil these summer days.

THE story of Ulysses S. Grant, his triumphant achievements, his personal problems and his poignant death will be dramatized on television tonight. The program, "Shadow of a Soldier," will be shown in the "Our American Heritage" series over the National Broadcasting Company network from 8 to 9 P.M.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 20 -- California, rich with Presidential candidates last week-end, was reduced to one today. He is the man all the others were gleefully riding on an oratorical rail a week ago, Vice President Nixon.

EDWARD R. MURROW has lived in a shadow of speculation since he began a year's leave of absence last July from the Columbia Broadcasting System. One question has been whether he will return to the C.B.S. staff.
The president of City College expressed the view yesterday that the role of a municipal college chancellor would not necessarily be strengthened by proposals before the Board of Higher Education.

AROUSED by a proposed California law that Japanese children should attend segregated schools, Genevieve Caulfield decided her role in life at the age of 17. She would go to Japan and work for closer understanding between Japan and the United States.
VERO BEACH, Fla. -- If there are any Dodger fans left in Brooklyn, they will be interested to know that this attractive Florida city is giving a big blowout for the Los Angeles Dodgers on March 12.

KINGSTON, Jamaica -- This island's tourist season has finally got off the ground and is now proceeding full steam ahead. Now, with the season well under way and the number of available rooms diminishing, the hotel operators and others interested in tourism have changed their attitude from one of dire pessimism to one of extreme optimism.

BUFFALO, Feb. 20 -- Highway crews battled huge snow drifts throughout most of Western and Central New York today in the wake of an overnight storm that stranded hundreds of motorists and school children.

The commander in chief of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, Louis G. Feldmann, made known his itinerary yesterday for a ten-week visit to twenty-one countries "as an average American with nothing to sell."
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 30 -- The Government is still trying with little success to win the support of Hungary's writers.

GOOD food from all over the world is the subject of these three books. Joan Parry Dutton concentrates on her native land in "The Good Fare and Cheer of Old England." She feels that Americans have vilified British food unkindly and unreasonably and is out to defend it.

ONLY the gullible will be lured, as I was, to Central Park West at Seventy-seventh Street by the New York Historical Society's announcement that the Belknap collection of early and earlyish American portraits is on exhibition in its building at that address.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 20 -- The Yale swimming team defeated Colgate this afternoon, 65 -- 28.
Former Gov. Theodore R. McKeldin of Maryland yesterday received the fourteenth annual Brotherhood Award of the Men's Club of Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, 257 West Eighty-eighth Street.
HONG KONG, Feb. 9 -- Standing in the shadow of the unpredictable colossus that is Communist China, the British colony of Hong Kong might be expected to view its future with some trepidation.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 16 -- A 17-year-old Chilean schoolboy is building a house of wooden blocks here. He hopes to have his family moved into the new home by the time of President Eisenhower's visit to the San Gregorio housing development, scheduled for March 1.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Jak Twyman today became the fourth player in National Basketball Association history to score 2,000 points in a season. He tallied 40 in a 110-107 victory by the Cincinnati Royals over the Detroit Pistons.

"DEAR Upton Sinclair," Albert Einstein wrote, "To the most beautiful joys of my life belongs to me your wicked tongue!" Theodore Roosevelt in the last week of his life told Sinclair in a letter, "Perhaps I shall be less shocked by your book ("The Profits of Religion"] than you imagine -- although I will not guarantee this!"

BOWIE, Md., Feb.20-Horse-players like a spit of spring training. So it was not surprising that at least 700 New Yorkers, 200 miles and thirty days away from the "Big A," were among the 18,361 breed-improvers who saw the favored Yes You Will score an easy victory in the the W.P. Burch Memorial Handicap at Bowie today.

Red Bank, N.J, plans to resume its National Sweepstakes Regatta on the Navesink River there after a lapse of seven years. A one-day event has been tentatively scheduled for July 17 as a resumption of the popular regatta that had been run for twenty-one consecutive years.

Moscow. ON the Queen's birthday in 1958, in her Majesty's Embassy opposite the Kremlin, Nikita Sergeyevich Khrushchev was asked by one of the dozen foreign correspondents crowded around him why -- now that he was Premier and therefore interested in doing things in a new way -- he did not hold regular news conferences away from the tinkle of cocktail glasses, eavesdropping diplomats and glory-seeking tourists.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The Pentagon appears to be spending as much time worrying about military training manuals as it devotes to the defense debate over missiles.

THE sixteen short stories that comprise the current O. Henry Awards, edited for the first time by Mary Stegner, possess in common considerable technical competence. Beyond this it is difficult to generalize, so a few facts may be of interest.

Iona, the defending champion, and Montclair State shared team honors in the annual relay carnival of the Collegiate Track Conference yesterday afternoon at Fitzgerald Memorial Gymnasium, Queens College, Flushing, by scoring 13 points each.

MONTEVIDEO, Feb. 20 -- Uruguay on a smaller scale is having the same experience as its neighbor, Argentina, in trying to reconstruct a broken down economy. Although this is one of Latin America's outstanding democracies, a spendthrift Government voted out of office last year left a pile of debts; habits of consumption based on subsidized prices for beef, transportation, fuels and luxury imports; and labor unions accustomed to getting what they demanded.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 20 -- Labor is changing faster than the labor movement, with results that are likely to have a crippling long-range effect on the power and influence of American unions. This was the conclusion that emerged with depressing force from the top-level meetings held in this are in recent weeks by labor's high command.
The Beilehurst Stable's 3-year-old, Warfare, a leading candidate for triple-crown honors, is expected to campaign at the Aqueduct meeting opening on March 21 before he goes to Louisville.

In Congress last week the leadership in both parties took the offensive on a fundamental issue of civil rights. MUCH of the response to Russia's challenge to American higher education has been a demand for more money to do more of what we have been doing, and somewhat less willingness to examine the soundness of what we are doing. TO THE EDITOR: Herbert Mitgang's thesis that "What Made Lincoln President" (Feb. 7) was his "constitutionally rooted speech" at Cooper Union is well founded.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 20 -- Army upset Rutgers in wrestling, to highlight a clean sweep of today's sports card by the cadets.

WITH a Presidential election coming up, the public opinion polls are once more about to have their quadrennial year of conspicuous testing. This is the Rose Bowl game for pollsters. Will their forecasts be on the nose, as in 1956? Or will they again elect the wrong man, as when all the polls enthusiastically, and, in fact, rather smugly, put Mr. Dewey into the White House in 1948?
THE old question -- now do we rear children to produce men of good will? -- becomes more important than ever in view of recent headlines.
HOLLYWOOD. WHEN shooting started here last week on "Go Naked in the World," it was the first movie to be started this year at the vast Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer studio.

Premier Khrushchev's mood and demeanor varied sharply last week, the second of his Southeast Asian tour. Much of the time he seemed subdued, a trifle grim and weary. Reporters travelling with the 65-year-old Premier felt he might be showing the strain of the heavy travel and diplomatic schedule he has maintained over the past several months.

UNTIL a few years ago, the radial arm saw was a heavy, industrial type power tool used only by professional wood-workers and construction men. However, its exceptional versatility, combined with its ease and safety of operation, soon created a demand for it in the home workshop.

In a quieter way, the same question occurs to the reader who has worked his way through this medley of misanthropy.

But television, that deus ex machina, has come up with a device that is making life more bearable around the hot-stove league -- canned baseball.

Eo, a cave boy, is of a pre-tribal family just down from the trees. ALMOST every major discovery in medical history was accompanied by a long-fought battle for recognition, often with tragic results for the discoverer. Nowhere was this more true than in the uphill fight waged by a gentle English physician named Edward Jenner to prove the ability of cowpox virus vaccination to prevent the lethal epidemics of smallpox which had swept the world almost since the beginning of man.

RABAT, Morocco, Feb. 20 -- Work has begun on extension of the port facilities at Tangier so that the volume of traffic can be doubled by 1962. The Public Works Ministry announced today the sinking of the first caisson for a new pier at Tangier.

The stars did not shine at the Planetarium yesterday but a man in a lionskin did.
NICE, France, Feb. 22 -- The world soon may be too small for riding to hounds.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As your well-reasoned editorial of Feb. 19 points out, strange things are happening in this city. In January, 1959, Mayor Wagner submitted a bill to the City Council authorizing him, in accordance with the state law passed for that purpose, to appoint a commission to revise the Charter of the City of New York.
St. Francis Prep upset Bishop Loughlin in the track championships of the Brooklyn-Long Island Catholic High Schools Athletic Association yesterday.
NEW YORK doesn't have to wait for Lincoln Center to have its concert hall of the future; it has a small one already.

SEOUL, Korea, Feb. 22 (UPI) -- The commander of the United States Eighth Army declared today that a "major improvement" in the modernization of weapons of the United States forces in Korea "will occur during this calendar year."

Borough President Albert V. Maniscalco will meet with his aides this morning at Staten Island Borough Hall in an effort to ascertain whether any of them bought city land. The City Charter prohibits such purchases by municipal employes.
"THE COOL WORLD," which opened at the Eugene O'Neill Theatre Monday night is "West Side Story" without frosting.
World tankship operators, who last year faced a glut of surplus tonnage amounting to 772 ships, can expect excess capacity to reach a high of 1,200 ships by 1962.
Thousands of California house flies and south Texas honey bees are flying new flight patterns to destruction as a result of a new contract obtained by Chance Vought Aircraft, Inc.
ALBANY, Feb. 22 -- A bill that would abolish the junior driver's license system in Nassau County was unanimously approved by the Senate today.

In the Karakoram Range of northwest Kashmir in Pakistan, live the Hunzakuts, a people whose life span is said to exceed 140 years. An account of those people is given by Dr. Allen Banik, who spent several months among them, in "Hunza Land."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- State Department officials said they would consider sympathetically any reasonable proposal made by Cuba for resuming discussions.

ONE of the potential advantages of "The Play of the Week" is to provide a secondary exposure of dramas that may not have been able to survive the severe economics of Broadway but still merit a further hearing.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson today put off a decision whether to lay aside the civil rights bill in order to pass appropriation bills.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 22 -- Finalists in the race for Oscars of the movie industry's major categories were announced here today by the Academy of Motion picture Arts and Sciences.
CHICAGO, Feb. 22 -- Orlando W. Wilson, a criminologist appointed to pick a new Commissioner to clean up the Chicago Police Department, took the job himself today.

Plans for the twelfth annual Spring Frolic of the Humane Society of New York will be discussed this afternoon at a cocktail party at the East Eighty-ninth Street home of Mrs. Arthur Boyer Schoen, benefit chairman.

SURREALISM is not exhausted for Granell, a Spanish-born painter whose recent work is being exhibited at the Bodley Gallery, 223 East Sixtieth Street. On the contrary, Granell, with a rare ability to turn surrealist axioms to good account, shows a region of his imagination that not only encompasses surrealism but also goes a few steps further.
LAS VEGAS, Nev. Feb. 22 -- Political maneuvering for Democratic Presidential aspirants stole the spotlight today as the executive committee of the Governors Conference closed its two-day meeting.
Following is President Eisenhower's official program for his South American trip. All times are regional (Puerto Rico is one hour ahead of Eastern standard time and eastern Brazil two hours ahead).

A plot of 42,000 square feet on the west side of Valles Avenue, 100 feet north of 254th Street, in the Riverdale area of the Bronx, has been resold for $125,000 to Corin Mann as the site for a 110-unit apartment house. The plot is about 250 by 200 feet.

JERSEY CITY, Feb. 22 -- Seventy-two men and three women employed in the Jersey City Incinerator Authority's plant here went on strike today, and most of them picketed the building, protesting the dismissal of twelve employes over the weekend.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- The Senate Appropriations Committee cut $22,133,935 below the House today in approving its first new money bill of the session.
The longer a child remains in foster care, the less likely he is to be suitable for adoption, the State Charities Aid Association asserted yesterday.

DETROIT, Feb. 22 -- The United Automobile Workers asserted today that a report of four Republicans on the Senate rackets committee was a politically motivated, anti-labor document based on "falsehood" and "malicious slander."
VALLEY FORGE, Pa., Feb. 22 (AP) -- Senator John L. McClellan, Democrat of Arkansas, said today that the East-West struggle might be decided in the next few years.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 22 -- Spain and West Germany have been working on an agreement to permit West German Air Force units to train at Spanish bases, according to Allied sources.
HINESVILLE, Ga., Feb. 22 (AP) -- Revision of voting lists has cut 1,000 persons, mostly Negroes, from rolls in the only county in the South having more Negro than white registered voters.
At last the first physical step has been taken, to re-estabilsh the St. Croix River, the boundary between Maine and New Brunswick, as an Atlantic sea-run salmon stream.
Barry MacKay yesterday won the indoor tennis championship of the United States, the first national singles title to fall to him other than the inercollegiate crown.

Proceeds from the Queen Esther Ball on Purim Eve March 12, will establish an education and acquisition fund at the Jewish Museum of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America. Mrs. Albert A. List and Mrs. George Moskowitz are co-chairmen for the fete, which will be held at the museum Fifth Avenue and Ninety-second Street.

Jack Benny, whose television show is currently presented on alternate weeks, may appear on a once-a-week basis, beginning next fall. Although the comedian has been working in television for a number of years, he has never starred on a weekly program.

HANOVER, N.J., Feb. 22 -- Bowlers poured into Hanover Lanes today. Some brought their families, including young- sters who couldn't manage the big, round, rubber balls. Other bowlers came in groups that included some who knew what they were doing on the lanes.

Carl Braun will continue as coach of the New York Knickerbockers for the 1960-61 season. The 32-year-old athlete who had a dual role as basketball player-coach for a while is not likely to be back in uniform, however.
DETROIT, Feb. 22 -- Passenger car registrations for 1959 showed that Ford cars outsold Chevrolets and all other makes last year.

THE GOVERNOR Held conference with Republican legislative leaders. Submitted special message to Legislature urging creation of the New York State Housing Finance Agency. Accepted group of Civil War flags of the Fifty-fifth New York Militia from Comdr.
Glamorous academic innovations cannot give strength to the college curriculum, Dr. John G. Palfrey, dean of Columbia College, asserted yesterday.
ALBANY, Feb. 22 -- Governor Rockefeller urged the Legislature today to enact a bill to set up a new state agency to lend funds for private middle-income housing construction.
HAVANA, Feb. 22 -- Amadeo Barietta Sr., an Italian citizen and a General Motors Corporation distributor, was arrested last night. Most of his property, including his home, has been seized.
St. Helena's upset its Bronx rival, All Hallows, in the quarter-final round of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association basketball play-offs yesterday at the Fordham University gymnasium.
Petroleum, pillar of the world's economy, may have fallen from the skies, according to a noted botanist.

BRASILIA, Feb. 22 -- President Eisenhower and President Juscelino Kubitschek will issue a "Declaration of Brasilia" tomorrow, reaffirming inter-American principles and Brazilian-United States friendship.

A TRIP to the grocery store with Mrs. Norman Jolliffe would be an education for the woman whose family has special dietary problems. She must shop for foods suitable for members of her family who have diabetes and must avoid sugar and who are on salt-free diets.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 22 (AP) -- Twentyone Guns out-gamed Porter in a blazing stretch duel to win the $60,700 Washington's Birthday Handicap at a mile and one-half over the grass at Santa Anita Park today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Soviet Union has just made another concession in the Geneva negotiations on the cessation of atomic tests. It has declared its willingness to allow international inspection of a limited number of underground disturbances whose nature cannot be identified with the presently available seismographic equipment.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 25 (AP) -- An inquest is scheduled Friday in the death of Mrs. Anita Rogers, 37-year-old divorcee.

ANOTHER spring training season is about to move on the scene, bringing with it familiar names, places and faces. Strange what a fascinating hold this singular diversion continues to exert on the fan although its pattern hasn't changed in years.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The State Department underwent further condemnation from Senators today for its part in the granting of another reprieve to Caryl Chessman.

Bernard J. Rosenshein has been appointed manager of the commercial real estate development department of the Asher Corporation. He was formerly with New England Industries and with the Leonard L. Farber Company.
The first self-policing system by a steamship conference in this country has been formulated.
RICHMOND, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Thirty-eight Negro students were booked on trespassing charges here today when they refused to leave the food-serving areas of a big downtown department store.
Bargain hunters had a field day yesterday, particularly along Fourteenth Street here and in the near-by suburbs.
MOSCOW, Feb. 22 -- Moscow's official sports newspaper, Sovetsky Sport, is using its own calculations to give an unofficial point score for the Olympic Winter Games at Squaw Valley, Calif.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 22 -- Cuba has gone over the heads of the Latin-American group and appealed to the United Nations membership at large to support her candidacy for a Security Council seat.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have just learned what, sur prisingly, I didn't see in The New York Times -- namely, that the Federal Parole Board has once more refused a medical parole to Henry Winston.
The first junior-senior Lutheran parochial high school on the Eastern Seaboard is expected to be ready for students this fall.

THE much ado about French ready-to-wear and its growing influence in America has fresh ammunition with Rosette Pennington's (20 East Fiftysixth Street) new collection. Made and designed in France, the collection of 125 fashions was selected by Louis von Weise Jr., the store's president, during a whirlwind ten days in Paris.
MILLSTONE, N.J., Feb. 22 -- The roar of the antiquated forge and the ring of the smith's hammer may soon be heard again at a 267-year-old blacksmith shop here.

The Russian Mi-Carema Dinner Dance at the Sheraton-East on Friday will recapture the carnival spirit of Imperial Russia and will benefit ill and needy members of the Association of Officers of the Former Imperial Russian Cavalry and Horse Artillery.

Leonard E. Reisman, a special assistant in the State Attorney General's office, was chosen by the city yesterday to head the Police Division of Licenses.
A new traffic pattern for Queens Plaza to improve the flow to and from the Queensboro Bridge is being developed by the Department of Traffic.

Howard Fast, author of the novel "Spartacus," said yesterday that he was "directly responsible for at least half of the finished script of the film version of the book." Strenuous objections were filed yesterday against pro- posals that Macombs Dam Park be converted to use as an auxiliary parking area for Yankee Stadium.
DETROIT, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Passenger car output this month apparently is going to run about 10 per cent below the original schedule of 728,080 units.

THE MASTERPIECE AND THE MAN: Yeats As I Knew Him,"* by Monk Gibbon, is a strange tribute to a great poet. It reminds me of those novels in which an author sets himself to discover the truth behind a blazoned celebrity's reputation and finds that he is only human after all.
ALBANY, Feb. 22 -- The State Education Commissioner proposed today that the basic formula by which the state distributes aid to local school systems be modernized.

Twenty-five persons, includ- ing eighteen children, died in cold weather home fires during twenty-four hours ending last night, United Press International reported.

MIAMI, Feb. 22 -- The Calu- met Farm entry of Pied d'Or and Hillsborough ran one, two in a seven-furlong race today, a circumstance that brought satisfaction to, a, the favorite players in the crowd of 21,108 and, b, to Trainer Jimmy Jones.

NEWARK, Feb. 22 -- Three years ago a gang of Negro youths called the Barracudas roamed the streets of a slum, spoiling for trouble. On Friday night the group will hold a dance to raise funds to send a representative to President Eisenhower's White House Youth Conference next month.
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 22 -- John W. Fowell, a special agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in New Haven, was named today as Security Director and Associate Dean of Students at Yale University.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 22 -- Representative government returned to Kerala today.

SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., Feb. 22 -- The United States, blanked so far in the gold-medal department, may take two to- morrow as the Winter Olympics move into the sixth day. Americans are favored in women's figure skating and the women's giant slalom.

LONDON, Feb. 22 -- A leader of the Labor party forecast tonight a "blazing row" over West Germany's efforts to establish military bases in Spain.
The Russian pulp and paper industry is expanding rapidly, but does not represent a threat to world markets yet, an American pulp expert said here yesterday.
Demonstrations ranging from exotic dances to bicycle races were given at a Youth Fitness Rally of 400 youngsters yesterday in the Seventy-first Regiment Armory.

A touch of Valley Forge winter was in the air here yesterday as school children, bankers and most business folk, took the day off to celebrate George Washington's birth on Feb. 22, 1732.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 22 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru strongly defended himself today against a charge that his Government had "betrayed" India in the frontier dispute with Communist China.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- A broad program to close gaps in conflict-of-interest laws covering Federal employes and military personnel was recommended to Congress today. ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 22 -- Harvard's hockey team moved into a second-place tie in the Ivy League tonight by trouncing Cornell, 12 -- 2. The defeat was the sixteenth in a row for the Big Red.

President Eisenhower began his trip to Latin America yesterday where it is going to end -- in Puerto Rico. There, as they say wherever Spanish is spoken, he is en su casa -- in his own home. His problem, as he recognized in his predeparture television address on Sunday evening, is to make everyone realize that the phrase is not literal.

PAVEL LISITSIAN, Soviet baritone, who is making his first American tour, is a formidable vocal technician. The finishing touch, in sports, is often the most difficult: the final yards to the mountain peak; the bell lap in a mile race; and, for Bill Spiegel, the 500th victory as a high school basketball coach.

CHILDREN may handle a variety of animals, including snakes, frogs and toads, at the Natural Science Center for Young People in the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West and Seventy-ninth Street. The center is open Tuesdays through Fridays from 2 to 4:30 P.M.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's message to Congress on his veto of the water-pollution bill:
